column2: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 17 --William J. Sullivan, a sports announcer in the New York and Newark metropolitan area for forty years, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 72.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17-- The book was closed today on the matchless deeds of Richard Kazmaier against Yale and Harvard with a final lustrous performance that carried Princeton to a 27-0 victory over the Elis and a recordbreaking fifth successive Big Three championship.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 17 (UP) --The Golden Bears of California--looking ahead to their big game with Stanford next Saturday --had all they could do today to beat a young, determined University of Oregon team, 28 to 26.

WHILE popcorn is not an important commercial crop in New Hampshire, it is grown on a large scale in the Midwest. Whole counties out there grow nothing but popcorn for a cash crop, and grain elevators handle it in much the same way as sweet or field corn.

LONDON. THE change of Government has evoked no jubilation in film circles, though in terms of personal politics the people involved may be glad enough to see a private enterprise regime succeed one behind which they always saw, however far off, the dark cloud of nationalization.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Morton of the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Walton, to Kirk Hollingsworth, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Hollingsworth of New York and Cornish, N.H.
CLINT HIGHTOWER and Claudie, Dillon Anderson's bumpkin heroes, are endowed with the type of humor which brings out the chuckles as you pass the peppermints around the parlor on Sunday afternoon.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 27 --Swarthmore defeated Haverford on the football field, 19--7, today and simultaneously walked off with "better courtesy" honors by a 45-43 score.
THE spicy odor of sage, the tenderness of tur key meat, the look of richly brown gravy are the things Thanksgiving is made of.
In April, 1950, the Department of Commerce and the American Medical Association jointly examined the incomes of physicians in private practice for the year 1949.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17-- Dr. Hugo Leichtentritt, well known musicologist, died here last Tuesday afternoon in a nursing home, after a long illness, at the age of 77. A sister resides in Cambridge.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17 (AP)--Another opportunity for 200 precocious youths to go to college without a high school diploma was offered today in the form of scholarships in liberal education providing tuition plus maintenance up to $1,000 a year at Chicago, Columbia, Wisconsin or Yale Universities.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 17 --Despite a shortage of trained staff workers, considerable success has been achieved by the Child Guidance Clinic of the Oranges and Maplewood, Dr. Charles R. Roberts, director, reported this week.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 17 --Miss Eleonora van Reekum, daughter of Mrs. Aafke Maria van Reekum and Johannes van Reekum of New Rochelle, was married this afternoon to Werner Arnold Kobelt of the Bronx, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold A. Kobelt of Greenwich, Conn.
IT is a truism to say that our public education, especially at the, grammar-school and high-school levels, is today in a state of considerable confusion. This is to be expected.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. l2 (Reuters)--Finland's coalition Government is trying an inflation cure that other countries have found usually leads to bankruptcy. Many neutral observers here, however, believe that Finland's unorthodox medicine will work.

TELEVISION came along just in the nick of time to res cue Lee Tracy from a growing state of lethargy. In twenty-eight years of brash and breezy acting in the movies and on the stage, the man with brass tacks in his voice became so severely typed in newspaper roles that enthusiasm for his work waned accordingly.

IT is always gratifying to make the acquaintance of a writer of intelligence and feeling; it is these qualities which most clearly mark the work of Hortense Calisher, whose stories in the last few years have made their quiet, cogent bids for our attention.

The engagement of Miss Dacie Marshall to Warren E. Kershaw, son of Mr. and Mrs. George V. Kershaw of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Ruperti Marshall of 164 East Seventy-second Street and Charles R. Marshall, also of New York.
NO reader who finishes Mary Jane Rolfs' "No vacancy" will ever again regard motelkeeping as an untaxing occupation, suitable for elderly couples who have retired on a small pension.
FONTANA VILLAGE, N.C. --Wild boar hunting, East ern America's newest sport, is attracting the nation's big-game hunters to the wild and rugged mountains of western North Carolina.

DEDHAM, Mass., Nov. 17--Miss Lucy Lowell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Lowell of Sunrise Farm, Westwood, was married here this afternoon to Roland DuBois Grimm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Hasbrouck Grimm of New Paltz, N.Y., in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--The marriage of Miss Audrey Clair, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Verne Clair of Rye, N.Y., formerly of Shanghai, to Arthur Potts, son of Mrs. Richard Potts of Frederick, Md., and the late Mr. Potts, took ...

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 17--The seventeenth "Battle of the Tarrytowns," between Washington Irving High School's authors of Tarrytown and oncebeaten North Tarrytown High's Headless Horsemen, ended in a 6-6 tie today.

SPOTSWOOD, N.J., Nov. 17-- Several incidents in Bicycle Court here this week severely tested the poise of the presiding judge. He was accused in open court of violating this borough's bicycle laws and had before him for sentencing a juror and a policeman.

IN the Eighteen Seventies the state of Texas and the boom ing railroads joined in spreading exciting tales of waiting riches on the boundless acres of the "Far West"--the idea being to entice settlers who could pay taxes and produce things to haul.
Builders announced plans yesterday for developments to meet the eastward expansion of the housing demand into Suffolk County.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 17--Regulation of real estate trading and practices for the good of the business and for protection of the public has come a long way since the first state realty license law was adopted in California in 1947.
SEATTLE is grist for any author's mill. It is the gate way by sea to Alaska and the Yukon. It packs more fish than any other port.
The thirty-third anniversary of the founding of Latvia, now one of the Soviet-subjugated Baltic states, was celebrated last night in Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street.

An exhibit of paintings, as fanciful in conception and as brightly colored as any modern audience could wish, opened last week at the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases, 444 East Sixty-eighth Street. Of the 200 objects in the show, half were by patients, the rest by their doctors, nurses or staff members.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 17 (Reuters)--An uneasy calm has settled on the strife-torn Australian waterfront, but prospects of continued peace are not promising.

THIS is it. The Cleveland Browns, champions of whatever league they've been in for the past five years, collide head-on with the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds today in a game that has everyone keyed in anticipation. From the standpoint of public interest it's a throwback to the 1946 season when the Giants ...
"NOW, what I am trying to do is eliminate the dollar sign. That is something brand new in the thoughts at everybody in this room, I think--get rid of the silly, foolish old dollar sign."

OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 17 (AP)-- Relying on straight power football and its trio of battering backs-- Hank Lauricella, Andy Kozar and Bert Rechichar--undefeated Tennessee rolled to a 46-21 triumph today over the fighting but outgunned University of Mississippi Rebels.
COMPARED with the number of people who enjoy the tall May-flowering tulips, only a few know the pleasure that can be derived from some of the species tulips and their hybrids.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 17-- Eight fumbles, on four of which the ball was lost, rather spoiled the big home-coming week-end for 14,000 Dartmouth rooters on Memorial Field today, Cornell winning by a 21-13 score.

The issue of "unity" between the A.F. of L. and the C.I.O. has been joined. C.I.O. President Philip Murray has charged that the A.F. of L. wishes to carve up the industrial unions of the C.I.O. and distribute each segment among the A.F. of L. craft unions.

NEWARK, Nov. 17--The police began today the laborious task of dragging the Passaic River bottom with a magnetized steel plate in hope of recovering the pistol that was used by hold-up men Nov. 9 in the slaying of James Law, a special policeman.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 17 (UP)--Vic Toweel of South Africa successfully defended his world bantamweight championship against Luis Romero of Spain over fifteen rounds of a one-sided fight tonight.

MONTREAL, Nov. 17 (UP)-- Berth Olmstead, normally the setup man for Maurice (Rocket) Richard, came into his own as a scorer tonight with a third period goal that gave the Montreal Canadiens a 3-2 National Hockey League victory over the New York Rangers.

The personnel of the aircraft carrier Oriskany received the praise of the Secretary of the Navy Dan A. Kimball and Mayor Impellitteri yesterday for the donation of 1,436 pints of blood they and their families made last Tuesday and Wednesday for troops in Korea.

SOME people call him Pops, perhaps because of his bristly thatch of white hair and perhaps because he has been on the jazz scene for forty-five years, but Sidney Bechet is young in spirit. His soprano saxophone shrieks poignantly from one end of the land to the other--and on the Continent, too--and wherever he goes the halls are filled.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 17--The era of bargain food for the American people "is probably gone," a leading farm authority today told delegates here from thirty-seven states attending the eighty-fifth annual session of the National Grange.
Plans for riverfront homes are included in new construction work projected in the Rumson area of New Jersey.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 17 (UP) --Wisconsin's battling Badgers stayed in the Big Ten race by downing last-place Iowa, 34 to 7, before 45,000 chilled fans today.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 17 --Notre Dame made an early two-touchdown lead stand up in the face of a desperate closing bid by aroused North Carolina today for a 12-7 decision over the Tar Heels.
Dr. Walter Aloysius Coakley, director of surgery at Kings County Hospital, died of a heart attack Friday night at his home, 100 Lenox Road, Brooklyn. He was 62 years old.

Characters prominent in folklore, both the living and the makebelieve, will march, ride and float in the air next Thursday in Macy's twenty-fifth Thanksgiving Day parade from Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West to Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 17-- Through her Deputy Premier, Iran blamed the newly elected British Government under Winston Churchill today for the failure of the United States efforts to mediate the British-Iranian oil controversy.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 17--Orange balloons floated over Archbold Stadium this afternoon as Syracuse won its traditional game from Colgate by 9--0.
ADOLESCENTS have been on the front pages pretty con sistently the past year or two. Argument and discussion have raged about the drafting of 18-year-olds and about the effects on such.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--The collision of two Union Pacific passenger trains, in Wyoming Monday in which twenty-one persons were killed has served to highlight again the railroad industry's struggle with the vagaries of the elements and the lapses of man and machinery.
THIS is something different in picture books. Leonard McCombe is a good photographer; he is also, evidently, a natural reporter with a fine sense of story and endless persistence.

THIS is the season when gardeners start their annual campaign to lure the birds. They are readying ingenious food-dispensing devices and gathering up tidbits to tempt the hungry residents of the North and bribe the summer visitors to linger longer in somber winter gardens.

The wholesale market here last week was very active, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Southern stores ordered spring goods, northern retailers requested special values in winter coats and reorder volume from all over the country was heavy on holiday items.
BOSTON, Nov. 17 (UP)--Boston College turned Villanova's bowl dreams into a nightmare today by coming from behind to win, 20--13, before 7,782 at Braves Field.

PELHAM, N.Y., Nov. 17--The Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Katharine Brenton Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Brenton Shaw, to David Morris Minton 3d of Louisville, Ky., son of Mr. and Mrs. Minton Jr., of Pelham Manor. The Rev. Dr. Willard P. Soper performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception in the Manor Club.

British factories are unable to get workers to put in overtime on their jobs because of a tax situation that makes it more profitable for employer to utilize their free time at other work.
LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP)--Portsmouth, champion in English soccer in two of the last three seasons, gained first place today with a 3-1 decision over Manchester United at Manchester.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 17 (AP)-- Texas upset favored Texas Christian, 32 to 21, in a wild and furious Southwest Conference football game today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17--Representative Thomas B. Curtis, Republican of Missouri, called on President Truman today to dismiss Attorney General J. Howard McGrath as "the obvious next step" to the discharge of Assistant Attorney General Theron Lamar Caudle.
Four awards were made by the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers at its fiftyninth annual meeting, which ended yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 17 (UP)--A pounding ground attack, good for four or five yards a play, brought Tulane from behind to a 14-to-10 victory today over Vanderbilt--the first Southeastern Conference triumph of the season for the Green Wave.

THANKSGIVING DAY will be the primary or secondary theme of practically all television programs this week. The day itself, Thursday, will bring viewers four special offerings.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 17-- Joseph Wilshire, chairman of the board of Standard Brands, Inc., who started his business career as a $7-a-week yeast-packer at the age of 18 for the Fleischmann Company in Cincinnati, died this afternoon in Greenwich Hospital. He would hate been 72 years old on Dec. 18.
A WINDOW box which has been a pleasant sight all summer is too often allowed to become an eye sore in winter. There are several ways of remedying this.
A French functionary returning from his post in the Saar reports optimistically on conditions there in respect to the local sanity.

Mr. and Mrs. Warner Rutherford James of 40 Fifth Avenue, and Lakeville, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Clare Rutherford, to Harris Bates Stewart Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Harris B. Stewart of the Manse, Aurora, N.Y. The wedding will take place early in February.

TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 18-- United Nations troops struck hard yesterday along a nine-mile front in east-central Korea, and within a few hours had advanced up to two miles in the sector southeast of Kumsong.
PARIS, Nov. 17--Secretary General Trygve Lie supported today a proposal made yesterday by Egypt for United Nations administration of a plebiscite to deternone the future status of the Sudan.
Daniel A. Kerr, a former inspector in the New York Police Department, who retired in 1934 after thirty-nine years on the force, died on Thursday in a Rhinebeck (N.Y.) hospital after a week's illness.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 17-- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, declared here today that he did not believe the United Nations and the Chinese Communists would reach "any peaceable agreement" that would "materially change the situation" in Korea.

The legal battle for either strong maintenance or abolition of the "fair trade" system reached a new stage last week. Opponents of legal retail price fixing by manufacturers said the $75,000 treble damage suit by Masters, Inc., against Sunbeam, Inc., in Federal Court Tuesday was unexpected but "welcome."
A Federal judge, two lawyers and a layman joined yesterday in stressing the moral responsibility of bench and bar in Communist trials to sustain the American tradition of a fair trial for all.
Joe Lapchick's New York Knickerbockers are still looking for their first home league victory.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP)-- The Defense Department disclosed today that it would not recommend any change in the draft law as long as voluntary enlistments continue at a high rate.

THROUGHOUT the Northeast operators of bird feeding sta tions are anticipating the most exciting winter in many years. Veteran bird watchers point to three favorable signs in predicting a busy season. First was the remarkably early and heavy fall migration.

Women headed by Mrs. Joseph Wickes Welsh and Mrs. Theodore F. Whitmarsh 2d are serving on the junior committee for the performance of "The Grand Tour," with Beatrice Straight and Richard Derr in the leading roles, on the night of Dec. 14 at the Coronet Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the House of the Holy Comforter.

Detective Maurice J. Dobson, who was a bodyguard for the late Gov. Alfred E. Smith during his Presidential campaign in 1928, retired last week as a member of the New York Police Department after thirty-eight years of service.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 17 (AP)--Contracts to cover costs of the Raritan Valley trunk sewer project have been submitted to all towns and industries for formal acceptance.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 17--Michigan State's undefeated Spartans tottered on the brink of the season's biggest football upset today, but stood off Indiana's fired-up Hoosiers, 30--26.

DETROIT, Nov. 17--Dr. A William Lescohier, long a leader in the pharmaceutical industry and former president of Parke, Davis Co., died in Jennuigs Hospital here today at the age of 66. He had suffered a stroke last Sunday.
Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday he would ask for more taxes this year to finance the spiraling cost of governing the city and operating its services.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP)-- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, declined today to make public the state and county reports on his family farm policy review that have been in his hands since mid-October.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17--A copy of the Index of Christian Art, comprising nearly 100,000 photographs and 500,000 catalogue cards, has been, prepared at Princeton University for presentation to Pope Pius XII.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP)--Grains sank on the Board of Trade today on some week-end profit-taking, helped along by news that the United Nations forces in Korea had offered to accept a Communist buffer zone proposal if an armistice is signed within thirty days.

A man with a police record was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Week-end Court charged with stealing $7.85 from a church bazaar on Friday night. He was Harold Daly, 43 years old, of 3815 Lyme Avenue, Brooklyn, a salesman.

TORONTO--More people are traveling these days, and normally Canadians would be more than pleased. But in the past few years Canadians in the travel business have been startled by an important development. There are more American visitors than ever to Canada each year.

IN a delightful and informative book Margery Finn Brown performs two minor miracles. She makes her gallery of Japanese subjects understandable to Western readers, and she manages to speak with authority without undertaking more than a stay of twenty-one months in Japan entitles her to attempt.

The sharp cut made by higher taxes on corporate net earnings in the third quarter and the expectation of additional cuts in earnings in the final quarter of the year are causing some apprehension among stockholders who were hopeful of increased year-end dividends.

Warm and rainy weather checked an upsurge in retail sales in the week, but they showed important advances over 1950 for Armistice Day. Volume for the week is estimated at 3 per cent below 1950, which in turn was 3 per cent above the 1949 week. Retailers continued optimistic on the holiday business outlook.

Mrs. William Otis Bailey, was married here this evening to Harry Lloyd Merring Jr., son of Rear Admiral Merring, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Merring of Washington, in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church by the Rev. Frank H. Moss. A reception was held in the Bailey home.

National Power and Light Company and the United States Leather Company serves to illustrate the changing nature of business enterprises as management seeks new outlets for the investment of stockholders' funds.

The Boys High football team, Brooklyn Division I football champion, registered its sixth straight victory by routing New Utrecht, 32--0, at Bays High Field yesterday. The Red and Black will meet Abraham Lincoln, the Division II winner, for the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. crown at Ebbets Field Saturday.

WHILE international developments continue to hold the center of the stage, the turn for the better in retail trade is being watched carefully by business men. Although volume for the week just closed was affected by unseasonable weather, continued uptrend is foreseen for holiday trade which may well carry over into the first half of next year.

LONDON, Nov. 18--The City and stock markets have been disturbed because of the adjustment of values to a new basis as a resalt of minor steps already taken and those still to come. LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 19-- The first of a new series of atomic explosions designed particularly to test the effects on standard military emplacements and materiel was set off at the Atomic Energy Commission's desert proving ground near here this morning.

ONE of the fine novels of the year is in danger of being overlooked unless the few people who have discovered it shout its praises so loudly that the many people who would delight in it sit up and take notice.

Peter Ptuchin, a short stocky Cossack of 91, is a practical man, not given to boasting. If you ask him a straight question--in Russian, Chinese or Serbian--he will give you a straight answer, as he demonstrated yesterday.

NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Nov. 19--Two small girls were burned to death and a boy was injured fatally in their home, which was swept by flames here today while their mother was at a store near by making a telephone call for medicine for them.

Undismayed by Soviet Russia's negative attitude, the General Assembly of the United Nations has begun immediate consideration of the Western arms-reduction plan as a matter of such urgency that it has been given first place on the Paris program.
Plans are being formulated for the Christmas fair and sale of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church to be held on Dec. 6 and 7 in its Community House, 109 East Fiftieth Street.

An exhibition that points up the variety and richness of the New York Public Library's holdings will be ready for public view today in its building at Fifth. Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent of Canada came out strongly last night in defense of United States foreign policy, declaring that while the free nations might differ on tactics they "cannot quarrel with the strategy of American leadership."
The Census Bureau, usually concerned with the big and the important, took a look yesterday at communities that have seen better days. It released the names of the three smallest towns in the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--The Council of State Chambers of Commerce saluted ten Republican Senators and a single Democratic Senator, Harry F. Byrd of Virginia, along with ten Republican Representatives today for having the "best voting records in the fight for Federal economy" during the recent session of Congress.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 18--Modern science, by means of the rotary printing press, the radio, and motionpicture and television cameras, has made it possible for people at great distances to "see" an event almost simultaneously, and in dimension and detail that not so long ago only the labor of historians could supply.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--Former Senator Hiram Bingham, Chairman of the Loyalty Review Board, urged today that a single agency receive jurisdiction over cases involving disloyalty suspects and those having to do with security risks.
Most New York State fire insurance companies will put into effect today substantially higher rates for extended coverage protection, the New York State Insurance Department announced Saturday.

Mayor Impellitteri has confirmed the expected, that the city will ask new taxing powers from the Legislature. He knows that such a request will be unpopular--but we doubt that he realizes how unpopular. Apparently he doesn't take much stock in economy as a way of balancing the budget.

PARIS, Nov. 19--The Western powers have decided on a plan to call in the United Nations Peace Observation Commission and to have it keep long-distance watch on troubles of Yugoslavia and Greece with their neighbors.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 (AP)--The billion-dollar Ford Motor Company today reported to the Massachusetts Tax Commissioner an increase of $125,742,000 in its total assets last year--from $1,343,349,000 on Dec. 31, 1949, to $1,469,091,000 on Dec. 31, 1950.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 19 (AP)-- Eleven major league teams, seeking to strengthen their 1952 pennant chances, elected to gamble in the annual draft today by picking up seventeen minor loop players at a cost of $159,000.

License Commissioner Edward W. McCaffrey yesterday banned the sale of nudist picture magazines at the 1,200 newstands under his jurisdiction. He said he was taking the step because the department's advisory committee considered the publications "objectionable to morals."
LONDON, Nov. 19--A heavy fall in the prices of British Government Securities of about 27s 6d ($3.85) in the irredeemable issues led a general price decline in the stock markets here today.
A succinet foreword statement sums up the sound advice presented in "Eating Problems of Children," a leaflet for parents prepared by the National Association for Mental Health.

The "sculptured look" in furniture appears again in some of the new birch pieces designed by Edmond J. Spence for the Walpole Company and made in Sweden. Seventeen pieces in the group are on view at Modernage.

Taft's Presidential candidacy will not affect Senator Dirksen's status as the principal speaker at the dinner of the United Republican Finance Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Dec. 3, it was said yesterday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 21-- The Communist truce negotiators at Panmunjom today offered a counter-proposal to the United Nations program looking to an armistice in the Korean war within thirty days at the current battle positions.

LONDON, Nov. 20--Mrs. Barbara Castle, one of Aneurin Bevan's supporters on the left wing of the Labor party, tried to precipitate a debate in Parliament today on what she called "the danger of the use of atomic weapons in Korea without the consent of the British Government."

STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 20 --Robert Boothby, British delegate to the Council of Europe, told a group of United States Congressmen meeting with European parliamentarians today that Britain was considering participating in the projected European army.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 20 (AP)-- Bosses of the Reds and the Dodgers conferred again today and a Redleg spokesman said they were "getting closer" to a player trade.
For reasons that are far from clear, the New City Ballet last night presented its own version of "Swan Lake" at the City Center.

The Gibson Girl look flashed onto the scene yesterday when Lord Taylor presented the newest of its resort, play and casual togs for inspection by the fashion press. Not only did Lord Taylor show cottons with bustled skirts, it added nifty little sailor hats to complete the trick.
Mrs. Esther Randall Barton, wife of Bruce Barton, advertising executive and former Representative in Congress, died today at her home at 117 East Fifty-fifth Street after a long illness.

QUEMOY ISLAND, Nov. 20-- When the Communists overran South China two years ago, thousands of fleeing Nationalists from Amoy and Swatow escaped to Quemoy (Chinmen) Island, off the coast of Fukien Province.

Party clothes for young persons today can be anything from blue jeans to sequined nylon tulle. The present emphasis on dressing even for informal gatherings at home has inspired designers to create novelties of all kinds.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 20--Jose Estrada Menocal, ace Mexican driver, died from burns and injuries in the hospital in Oaxaca to which he was taken after an accident today on the first leg of the second Pan American road race for stock automobiles. The event began near the Guatemalan border and will end Sunday in Juarez, a distance of 1,933 miles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--Government officials today denied a charge by Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, that Government agencies under the State Department control had used a "Russiantype veto" to thwart European rearmament.

Steps to clean up intercollegiate athletics were taken yesterday at City College and in other parts of the country as an aftermath to the denunciation by General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit of commercialization of college basketball and football as breeding dishonesty and undermining educational standards.

Mr. Eden's first presentation in the House of Commons of the foreign policy of the new British Government differed so little from that pursued by the Labor Government that it received the general approval of his predecessor, Mr. Morrison.

Albert Anastasia, dour-faced and tight-lipped hoodlum accused of being a leader of Murder, Inc., and a Brooklyn waterfront boss, has been advised to depart, without delay, for the gangster haven of Hot Springs, Ark., the New York City Anti-Crime Committee reported here yesterday.

Two office buildings adjacent to the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Fiftysixth Street changed hands with the sale by the Bradish Johnson Estate of the sevenstory structure at 558 Madison Avenue and the five-story structure at 22 East Fiftysixth Street.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 20--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Norman Mokren of the engagement of their daughter, Marilyn, to Edward Weisman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman L. Weisman of New York and Scarsdale, N.Y. The wedding will take place on Christmas Day in the Ambassador East Hotel, Chicago.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., hinted last night that the union would stop service for 3,200,000 riders on the privately operated bus lines of the city on the night of Tuesday, Dec. 4.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 20 (AP) --Vojta Benes, former Czechoslovak political leader, died here today of a heart attack. His age was 73. He was a brother of the late Eduard Benes, former President of Czechoslovakia.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20--A strike that would have choked off a substantial part of the flow of blood plasma to the armed forces was averted here tonight when workers accepted unanimously a settlement that had been worked out earlier in the day in Washington.

United States Government officials believe that a major Soviet drive to bring Iran and Afghanistan into the Kremlin's economic orbit is foreshadowed by reorganization of the Soviet foreign trade agency doing business with those countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)-- Newsprint paper will soon be declared essential, clearing the way for a 250,000-ton expansion of producing capacity in this country, it was reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--Presi dent Truman expressed confidence today that George F. Kennan, the State Department's Russian expert now on leave, would "make a good Ambassador" to the Soviet Union.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20-- Capt. Franklin B. Weaver of the freighter Flying Trader of the Isbrandtsen Line was charged by the Coast Guard at a hearing to day with "wrongfully killing" a member of his ship's crew during a fight at sea.
We cannot get one holiday out of the way before another looms up. The Thanksgiving feast has yet to be served, but already merchandisers are looking forward to Christmas.

TOMORROW, while a number of foot-loose individuals are chivvying the whitetail deer among the minor peaks of the Catskills, the tender, roasted flesh of turkey will be bitter on the tongue of many who are bound to the festive board by family ties or wifely dictums.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today that employment in industry, commerce and government was maintaining a continuing high level for the season, despite some job losses in consumer goods industries.

Now and then "Never Say Never" does sound like a smart comedy about the follies of New York. Carl Leo, who wrote it, does have that giddy attitude out of which smart comedies occasionally come and he can put a funny line together correctly.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (UP)--Illinois, undefeated but tied once in eight games, won four first team positions today on the 1951 All Big Ten team.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 20--A United States military plane carrying diplomatic cargo and four crewmen was fired upon by Hungarian and Rumanian border guards Monday and is missing, the United States Embassy announced tonight.

The B.F. Goodrich Company increased its earnings to $24,500,272 in the first nine months this year from $21,967,990 a year ago, despite taxes that were $29,054,000 more. The company also announced yesterday the declaration of an extra year-end dividend of 50 cents in addition to the quarterly of 50 cents, both payable to common stockholders on Dec. 31.

Gen. Mark W. Clark, wartime commander of United States forces in Italy, told a gathering of 1,000 guests at a $100-a-plate dinner in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night that Italian Boys Towns were playing a vital part in the moral and physical rehabilitation of thousands of orphaned and homeless children.
Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "Come Fill the Cup," a Warner Brothers newspaper drama, starring James Cagney, is at the Warner.

Mike Wallace and his wife, Buff Cobb, very likely will restore the television viewer's faith in marriage. Working as a team on six presentations a week over C.B.S., they behave as though they had known each other before the program started.

Experiments to determine if it would be economically feasible to remove the abandoned trolley tracks imbedded in the city streets have been started by Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan. The high-grade steel is sorely needed in the defense effort, and the Office of Price Stabilization recently authorized a premium of $25 a ton over the ceiling of $42 provided demolition was involved.

The merits of the forty-hour week are not open to question. But the manner in which Michael Quill, president of the C.I.O. Transport Workers Union, and his fellow officers approach this much-desired concession from the private bus line operators is decidedly open to question.

If the Republicans make foreign policy and "our program for world peace" issues in the 1952 campaign they "will be overwhelmingly" defeated, President Truman said yesterday. "Partisan politics," he added, "ought to stop at the water's edge."

The busy fight program in the metropolitan area this week continues tonight when Jimmy Bivins, veteran Cleveland heavyweight, encounters Charley (Doc) Williams of Mahwah, N.J., in the ten-round feature at the St. Nicholas Arena.

JIM THORPE bumped into the bottom of yesterday's column as he was talking with obvious reluctance about his fantastic career. No man in the history of sport would have more reason for boasting than the big Indian but none is more modest.

A man, who over a period of several months had won a Brooklyn woman's confidence by pretending to collect comic books for wounded veterans, yesterday bound and gagged the woman in her apartment and robbed her of $24,000 in jewelry, furs and money.

A joint New York-New Jersey drive against waterfront crime and racketeering, the first full-scale effort of its kind, is now in the making as a result of conferences between Governor Dewey and Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

With a 1952 goal of $4,000,000, the Greater New York Campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis--"The March of Dimes"--got under way yesterday at a luncheon attended by 200 local business, industrial and professional leaders.
Madam President of the Women's National Democratic Club and ladies and gentlemen:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--Mutual Security officials expect to ask President Truman to divert $580,000,000 from the purchase of military weapons for Europe, to economic support of countries contributing to the rearmament program of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 20 (AP) --The two players who may play singles for the United States forces in the coming Davis Cup tennis matches were escorted out of the New South Wales tourney today in a pair of quarter-final round upsets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP)-- Telford Taylor, Small Defense Plants Administrator, reported today that steps were being taken to stop large defense contractors from imposing "credit hardships" on small buisness.

It is good news that President Truman is planning to name George F. Kennan as the next United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, succeeding Admiral Alan G. Kirk, whose desire to retire has been known for some time. Mr. Kennan, who is now on leave from his post as Counselor of the State Department, has apparently indicated his willingness to serve, but prefers to remain on leave till next May.
LONDON, Nov. 20--Labor party members seemed bent today upon making Prime Minister Churchill's task of getting economic and financial aid from the United States as difficult as possible.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 20 (UP)-- A special committee of college presidents, appointed to find ways of eliminating problems facing intercollegiate athletics, reported "definite progress" today as it adjourned its investigation until Dec. 12 and 13. The group held two meetings yesterday.
TOKYO, Wednesday Nov. 21-- The Communists were forced to yield territory below Kumsong yesterday for the third time in less than a week. This time United Nations troops advanced more than two miles.

A little touch of St. Moritz was brought to the heart of New York last night, when three score rabbits, pussycats, Santa Clauses, devils and assorted clowns and monsters glided around the Rockefeller Plaza skating rink.

Assistant Chief Inspector John J. Travers, one of twenty-nine suspended policemen being tried by the department on graft charges connected with the gambling operation of Harry Gross, denied yesterday that he had ever received money from the bookmaker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (U.P.)-- Guy G. Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said tonight that the Republican party's three national committees spent less on the 1950 Congressional elections than the comparable Democratic committees.

Hope still simmers for New York's two professional football coaches, Steve Owen of the Giants and Jimmy Phelan of the Yanks. Both made this clear at the weekly football luncheon at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The main floor of the United Nations headquarters building at the East River and Fortysecond Street was converted into a blood donor center yesterday ...

PARIS, Nov. 21--In the old city of Strasbourg, where only the Rhine separates France and Germany, a new building rises among the graceful seventeenth century palaces which is called the "House of Europe."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20-- George Munger and his Pennsylvania football coaching staff of Rae Crowther, Paul Riblett, Bill Talarico and Rix Yard were seated at lunch today when a young man walked into the room and informed them that a member of the team had just undergone an appendectomy.

Underwriting business records of Goldman, Sachs Co. and First Boston Corporation were submitted in the investment banking anti-trust trial in Federal court here yesterday as the Government moved ahead with the "reciprocity" phase of the case, that is, the charge that the defendants restrained trade by giving business to each other on the basis of what business they got back.

A further decline by the stock market was cushioned a bit yesterday by a late show of strength. Some of the extreme losses were reduced in the afternoon, while several special issues came to the front, the comeback resulting from actions on dividends.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20-- Film rights to "Sobbin' Women," a short story by the late Stephen Vincent Benet, have been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. Joshua Logan had held the story under option for the last five years, planning to convert it into a play. This agreement was recently canceled by the author's widow.

Building up in alarming crescendo of revelation in first one district, then another, the scandal of the Bureau of Internal Revenue shocks a public that has lately been through so much that it has begun to expect shock.
PUSAN, Korea, Nov. 20 (AP)-- The Gloucestershire Battalion, or all that was left of it, departed today for Britain after more than a year of service in the Korean war.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20--A sixty-foot victory bonfire blazed merrily on Princeton's historic Cannon Green tonight as more than 2,500 students and townspeople gathered to pay tribute to the Tigers' 1951 Big Three champions.

PARIS, Nov. 20--The United States said today that the Balkans were exposed to the "general threat of aggression" from the Soviet world and joined with four other countries in recommending that the United Nations set up stand-by machinery for that traditional trouble spot.

Underwriting syndicates will offer to investors today new issues of senior public utility and railroad securities totaling $45,400,000. The issues were acquired by banking syndicates at competitive sale yesterday and Monday. The offerings are as follows:

Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas said yesterday that while the Near East was "heading up to one of the greatest crises in modern history, we sit in this country trying to underwrite the status quo."
New across-the-board cost-of-living salary increases for city employes constitute "one of the things the city has in mind" and "very much wants to do," Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday.
LLOYD MORRIS, a bland and impressively cultivated writer who wears his fermidable erudition with easy grace, has been in love with New York City for a long time now.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)-- The Government lost today its case against the Peace Information Center and five of its leaders. Matthew F. McGuire, United States District Judge, entered a ...
PARIS, Nov. 20--The United States will not abandon its programs of aid to underdeveloped countries because of the economic strains of the defense program, ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--Citizens of the Republic who are interested in secrecy, bureaucracy or the dignity of the English language will want to take note of a memorandum (marked "Restricted--Security Information") that has just been circulated by the secretariat of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Gina Pinnera, American soprano, well-known on the concert stage since her debut at Carnegie Hall in 1928, died in a hospital here yesterday morning.
SOMEWHERE IN NORTH KOREA, Nov. 20 (AP)--This was Lieut. Madeline Quinn's wedding day.

As a prelude to the public participation air-raid drill next week, auxiliary police and air-raid wardens will make an appearance along the route of Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade tomorrow to acquaint New Yorkers with their insignia.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 20 (AP)--G. M. Cohen's Jess Linthicum and David G. Neuman's Rose Beam shared honors at this Southern Maryland course today in winning the Potomac and Slide Rule purses, respectively.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20 (AP)--The Soviet press poured cold water today on Secretary of State Dean Acheson's outline to the United Nations of a Western Big Three disarmament plan, declaring that he had failed to cite "even one slightly weighty conclusion" that would halt the arms race or end world tensions.
Transportation facilities in and out of New York stretched to meet the rush of Thanksgiving travel today and a good share of the nation's record 53,000,000 turkey crop prepared to take a basting.

Manufacturers of materials handling equipment are studying recommendations for helping the nation's railroads to cut the cost of handling "less-than-carload" freight. The recommendations are the result of a recent round table conference with engineers from seven important Eastern railroads.
In commemoration of the day 330 years ago when the Pilgrim Fathers knelt in grateful prayer, New Yorkers of all faiths will ob

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--President Truman predicted today that the Republican party would attempt to win the 1952 election by means of a "slush fund" of national scope and by use of "the art of misrepresentation" that would attain "new heights."
WILLIAMS AIR FORCE BASE, Ariz., Nov. 20 (AP)--A husky, shy 14-year-old boy embarked today on another of his great adventures.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (U.P.)--A 30year-old steel broker told a Senate Small Business subcommittee investigating a steel gray market today that he started with $1,300 of his own money in 1948 and expected his sales to gross about $7,000,000 this year.
PARIS, Nov. 20--The Pleven Government won the vote of confidence it sought in the National Assembly today by the narrow majority of eighteen, 246 Deputies supporting the Cabinet and 228 opposing it.
The news that a "truce" exists between Fordham and New York University before their traditional football game Saturday recalled many incidents of this series to old grads yesterday.

TOKYO, Nov. 20--Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, supreme commander of United Nations forces in Korea, said yesterday it was possible 6,000 American soldiers now listed as missing in action in Korea had been captured and killed by Communist troops. At the same time, however, he said the United Nations investigation showed positive proof covering 365 Americans.

A promise that Gerardo (Jerry) Anastasio, whose brother Albert was reportedly once a "trigger man" for Murder, Inc., would soon be requested to testify before the state fact-finding panel now investigating the recent longshoremen's strike was made yesterday by George Mintzer, board counsel.

Underwriting syndicates will put on the market today about $1,000,000 of outstanding common stock of the Oxford Paper Company and the Acushnet Process Company, New England enterprises. The shares do not represent new financing, but the holdings of stockholders.

PARIS, Nov. 20--Nasrollah Entezam, Iranian Ambassador to Washington, said today that Premier Mohammed Mossadegh had submitted a new and "more favorable" offer to the State Department for settlement of the oil dispute with Britain before he left the United States Sunday.
The news that "Bepo," one of two atomic energy plants at Harwell, England, is heating an eighty-room building and saving $7,420 a year in coal is not unexpected.

PARIS, Nov. 20--Debate on the Western Big Three's disarmament proposal almost came to halt today while the United Nations delegates waited for Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, to give his verdict on the West's proposal, as explained and modified yesterday by Secretary of State Dean Acheson.

A plea for God-fearing men in public office as an antidote to the current lowering of public moral standards was made last night by Lewis L. Strauss, president of the board of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--An airline pilot guided a lost flier and his woman companion down through the clouds to a safe landing today. A few hours later, after taking off on another flight, the couplewas killed in an aerial explosion.

ROME, Nov, 20--Increasing the world's food production should be regarded as part of the defense effort, not as additional to it, said Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan, speaking to the sixth session of the conference of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization this morning.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 21 (AP) --General Headquarters Communique 1,074 for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A.M., Wednesday (4 P.M., Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

ROME, Nov. 20--The difficulties standing in the way of the appointment of a United States admiral to command the naval forces of the Western powers in the North Atlantic were understood to have been overcome on a military level today by the Atlantic pact Military Committee.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 20-- Steps to combat "irresponsible attacks" on public education from both the extreme right and left, were taken today at the closing session of the House of Delegates of the New York State Teachers Association, which has 50,000 members.
CAIRO, Nov. 20--Premier Mohammed Mossadegh of Iran received a rousing welcome when he arrived in Cairo today.

The Republican state organization has completed its plans for reapportionment of Congressional districts in New York State and has been assured of enough votes to pass the redistricting bill at the special session of the Legislature tentatively set for Dec. 4 or 5.

A report that Irene Mayer Selznick prizes "Flight Into Egypt" so highly that she would buy George Tabori's new drama was confirmed by her yesterday. More than that, the script now belongs to the sponsor of such stage phenomena as "A Streetcar Named Desire" and "Bell, Book and Candle" for production in this country and England.
TRENTON, Nov. 20--A highway renumbering plan, designed to reduce traffic confusion in New Jersey, was announced today by the State Highway Department.
PALEMBANG, Sumatra, Nov. 20--Oil companies operating in Sumatra are planning to bring new fields into production that will add substantially to present yields.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--The Office of Price Stabilization is expected to authorize a cent-a-bottle increase in the price of beer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, denied today in a letter to Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, that the Executive Branch of the Government had any intention of "seizing" or "taking over" by Executive Order the submerged oil-rich lands of the continental shelf.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)-- George B. Gillin, superintendent of the Federal Mint at San Francisco, resigned today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, announced today that President Truman has authorized withdrawal up to 30,000 tons of lead from the national stockpile to meet current needs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20(UP)-- Clark Griffith celebrated his eighty-second birthday anniversary today with a fond hope that his Senators would win "one more pennant" and with President Truman's "best wishes for many more years of health and happiness."

An appeal charging that a decision of the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court violates the American principle of seperation of church and state was filed yesterday in United States Supreme Court by the Free Synagogue Child Adoption Committee of New York, one of the nation's leading adoption agencies.
Sales of the Eastman Kodak Company were up for the three quarters of 1951, but taxes reduced net earnings to $32,350,194 from $43,134,237 last year.

ROME, Nov. 21--The necessity for the United States to speed the deliveries of military equipment to Europe if the Western European "ready" divisions are to reach their stepped-up 1952 goals was emphasized today by Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, chief of staff to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.
Considerable progress is being made on the construction of an atomic-powered submarine, it was indicated yesterday by one of the engineers on the top-secret Government project.

A day-long public hearing of the state fact-finding panel that is investigating the recent twenty-fiveday dock strike was dramatically interrupted yesterday when an official of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., admitted having lied while under oath.
TOKYO, Nov. 21--Gen. James A. Van Fleet promised today that even after the Korean war ended the young republic would not be deserted by the United Nations.
Fordham's football team sharpened its running attack yesterday while the New York University squad drilled on defense for their clash Saturday afternoon at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.
Clusters of buses at street stops in mid-Manhattan have become a major headache for riders, traffic engineers and the companies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--Two Republicans and two Democrats on a House Ways and Means subcommittee investigating tax scandals joined today in stating that rumors suggesting that their chairman had intervened in three Southern California tax cases were "completely without foundation."
The key sentence in the statement of Judge Saul S. Streit vividly describing the commercialization of college athletics is this: "In effect, they were professionals, masquerading as amateurs."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (U.P.)-- The armed forces will have to tap more unwilling reservists to fill the gap being left by those who are completing their tour of duty, a survey disclosed today.

It is almost thirty-five years since Jascha Heifetz burnt his name indelibly into New York's musical life. Crises may come and go in the affairs of men and nations, but he keeps his place serenely as a superb violinist. Back at Carnegie Hall last night he ...

The disruption of the forthcoming Broadway attraction, "Nina," due here at the Royale Theatre on Dec. 5, was narrowly averted yesterday when Gloria Swanson, costar of the French comedy, decided against a sudden withdrawal from the attraction.

LONDON, Nov. 21--Colonial Secretary Oliver Lyttelton told the House of Commons today that the British Government was convinced of the urgent necessity for a federation of the three British territories in Central Africa.

At a meeting in the Municipal Building yesterday the City Planning Commission approved adding to the 1952 capital budget four city construction projects totaling $725,000 and disapproved ... three other items amounting to $3,550,000.
Net profit of Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries amounted to $3,347,466 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)-- The Government approved today an almost 50 per. cent expansion of domestic newsprint production facilities, but officials said it might be some time before necessary materials could be made available.
United Nations ground forces along the battle front in Korea (on Wednesday) were attacked by enemy groups from platoon to battalion strength.

City Council President Rudolph Halley began yesterday to organize an office staff to help him function as a self-styled "watchdog for the public." His first move was to swear in Louis E. Yavner, former Commissioner of Investigation, as his assistant and deputy at an annual salary of $1.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 21 (U.P.)--The University of Miami accepted an invitation today to play in Jacksonville's Gator Bowl New Year's Day.

The Arab states are standing at a crossroads of grave importance to them and to the democratic West. Within the next few days they will decide whether or not to go along with the Egyptians and reject the opportunity offered to them by the United States, Britain, France and Turkey to join the "cooperative efforfs" for the defense of the Middle East.

BREMERHAVEN, Germany, Nov. 21 (AP)--General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower personally welcomed vanguards of Pennsylvania's Twenty-eighth Infantry Division and Canada's Twenty-seventh Brigade today as reinforcements for his European defense command.

The Government's anti-trust suit against certain investment banking houses is not intended to wipe out the syndicate system of marketing new securities but rather to have "illegal price-fixing taken off the back of the syndicate system," Government counsel asserted in Federal Court here yesterday.
Indictment of one or more City College employes for forgery became a possibility yesterday as a special committee of the Board of Higher Education called witnesses ...
A half-dozen seagoing monkeys are on the loose and having a merry time of it on the South Brooklyn waterfront.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--Oscar L. Chapman, Sercretary of the Interior, refused today to exchange oil-rich submerged lands along the coasts of Louisiana, Texas and California for land scrip, which gives the holder the right to select and receive a specified number of acres of available public land.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Nov. 22--Vice President Alben W. Barkley, his wife, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway and Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy arrived ...
The chances of Coach Jimmy Phelan's Yanks winning their first game of the season next Sunday were not bright yesterday after the hour-and-a-half workout at Yankee Stadium.

Every people that ever stayed still long enough to plant seeds and reap a crop has had a harvest festival. There are no exceptions. It has seemed worthy of celebration that there should be enough to eat. In many parts of the world today there would be celebrations if there were enough--but there is not. There is just a little less per capita, take the world over, than there was a dozen years ago.
SIXTY-ONE novels appear among the 118 volumes chosen by the Grolier Club of New York, a posse of eminent bibliophiles, as "The Important Books in English, 1901-1950."
MOSCOW, Nov. 21--Andrei A. Gromyko, acting Foreign Minister, delivered to the United States today a sharp protest that accused Washington of violating the Roosevelt ...
One man was killed and another seriously injured yesterday in what the police described as a homicide and an attempted suicide at 300 East Eighty-third Street.

Yellow chrysanthemums, goldcolored balloons and smilax provided a gold and green decor for the annual Junior League Ball held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The occasion marked the culmination of a series of events celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the New York Junior League.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21-- Gov. Earl Warren, a candidate for the Republican nomination for President, underwent an operation for the removal of his appendix and abdominal adhesions today at the University of California Hospital.

The American Woolen Company lifted its payments to stockholders to a total of $6 a share on the common stock this year with the declaration yesterday of a year-end dividend of $3 a share. It will be paid on Dec. 15 to holders of record of Nov. 30.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)-- The Army is using the experience of veterans who went through winter in Korea to teach new soldiers how to survive in extreme cold.

MUNICH, Germany. Nov. 21-- With the exception of certain sophisticated sections, the German people as he has found them in Bavaria, are socially unstable and have not grasped the essential issues of the world situation, Dr. George N. Shuster, retiring United State commissioner for Bavaria, said today.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 21--A national outcry against the Allied "strangling" of industry is the latest and most serious impediment to the Federal, Government's hopes for West Germany's speedy economic integration with the rest of Europe through the Schuman plan.

Mayor Impellitteri will ask the Board of Estimate at an executive meeting scheduled for Dec. 5 to approve and finance a seven-man Transit Advisory Commission with broad powers to study and recommend operating and economic coordination of all public and private transit facilities operating within the city limits.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21--Dr. Paul H. Musser, chairman and former provost of the University of Pennsylvania, died today in Graduate Hospital. He was 59 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--The Salary Stabilization Board authorized employers today to raise salaries of foremen, supervisors and other so-called salaried employes to match the cost-of-living adjustments and certain other increases given to their wage workers.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21-- Princeton's most famous football player of modern times, Richard Kazmaier, will make his farewell appearance Saturday against Dartmouth in Palmer Stadium.

A legal loophole threatened yesterday to destroy the prosecution's case against most of the twentynine suspended policemen who have been on departmental trial in Brooklyn Borough Hall for allegedly taking graft from Harry Gross, the bookmaker.

Powerful Princeton, unbeaten and untied in twenty-one straight games, dominated the 1951 United Press All-East college football team yesterday by placing four players, including triple-threat halfback Dick Kazmaier.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 21 --Two ordinances, adopted by the town of Cortlandt to prevent further disorders such as the allegedly Communist-inspired riots that broke up two Paul Robeson concerts in that northern Westchester community two years ago, were voided as unconstitutional today by Supreme Court Justice Robert Doscher.

HOLLYWOODD, Calif., Nov. 21 --Paramount had hoped to keep it secret since nothing definite has been accomplished yet, but word is out now that the studio is interested in filming the life of Carl Sandburg, the author and Lincoln biographer.
SEATTLE, Nov. 21 (AP)--Seattle's $8,000,000-municipally owned transit system is about to go out of debt for the first time in its stormy thirty-two-near history.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21-- Capt. Franklin B. Weaver's fatal shooting of a handcuffed member of the crew aboard his ship, the freighter Flying Trader, in the China Sea last month was defended today by a prosecution witness at a Coast Guard hearing.

West Street, the bustling thoroughfare abutting the Hudson River along downtown Manhattan, had an added fillip yesterday. It started shortly before noon on a task that plainclothes Patrolman Joseph A. Schlipf expected to be a routine bookmaking arrest.

More vigorous control over irresponsible drivers on the nation's highways and adoption of driver education as part of the curriculums of all high schools was advocated yesterday by the casualty insurance industry as it threw its full weight against compulsory automobile insurance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28--The addition of fluorides, properly controlled, to drinking water that lacks these chemicals appears to be both safe and effective, a report by a special committee of the National Research Council announced today.

THE anthologlodytes are getting out picture books these days in great style. They are putting together briskly handsome portfolios of pictorial enterprise ranging from Stefan Lorant's magnificent history of "The Presidency" to Marshall Davidson's fine "Life in America" and "Life's History of Western Man," all triumphantly proving that a thousand lines of painted brushwork, sketching or photographic detail can tell a story just as eloquently as a hundred lines of prose, if not better.

A slump in the European economy can be avoided by increased aid from the United States in the form of coal, steel and aluminum, according to Rolf von Heidenstam, Swedish industrialist and president of the International Chamber of Commerce. Europe needs these materials to halt inflation, he said, and forestall a depression that will further Soviet aims.

After dropping $16,000,000 a week earlier, business loans rebounded last week, rising $29,000,000 to reach a new high level of $7,573,000,000, and exceeding the previous peak of three weeks ago by $13,000,000.

The 104-year-old Community Service Society, one of the nation's largest family counseling agencies, held yesterday the charter meeting of its new women's council. The group is being formed to expand participation by women in the society's program, especially as part-time volunteer workers.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP)-- Tropical Park opened Florida's 122-day racing season today with attendance and wagering well ahead of opening day a year ago.

Manhattan will oppose Siena and New York University will meet William and Mary tonight in the first college basketball doubleheader of the 1951-52 season at Madison Square Garden.

Dr. Roma Gans, Professor of Education, Teachers College, Columbia University, charged yesterday that valuable programs and proposals for work on behalf of public school children were continually "scuttled behind closed doors." HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30-- The Warner Brothers are planning a musical romance with an early western background that will reach the screen as "At the End of the Rainbow." Winston Miller is writing the script and Louis F. Edelman will be the producer.

Many dinner parties were given at the annual Winter's Eve Dance last night at Sherry's for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association. Proceeds will further the work of the beneficiary, which this winter is conducting a campaign against air pollution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--The United States will reach the peak of its military production in 1953 after which re-accelerated civilian production may even exceed the record-breaking civilian production before korean hostilities, Charles E. Wilson, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, predicted today.

MacIver of Columbia University, one of the nation's leading sociologists, said today that despite ideological differences among Jewish organizations there could be effective co-operation among all Jewish groups in combating antiSemitism, protecting civil rights and promoting intergroup relations.'

Exports of bituminous have just about reached their ceiling, members of the Coal Exporters Association of the United States, Inc., reported here yesterday. A record net profit of $2,866,278 for the fiscal year ended with September was reported yesterday by the Liquid Carbonic Corporation, despite taxes almost double those of the year before. Equal to $2.94 a common share, the earnings compare with $2,417,629 or $2.43 a share earned in the preceding year.

Gerard W. Dwellings dominated trading in the real estate transactions reported yesterday in Brooklyn.

The amount of cargo handled for Economic Cooperation Administration account since the National Shipping Authority was created last March has now reached 6,579,203 tons, with coal movements responsible for 4,652,567 tons, grain 1,845,962 tons and the remainder made up of coke, sugar, sulphur and phosphates.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active all day yesterday and closing prices were 53 to 85 points, or $2.65 to $4.30 a bale, net higher than on Thursday.

The United States Court of Appeals issued a decree yesterday enforcing a National Labor Relations Board order that prohibited the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York and vicinity, independent, and Hearst Consolidated Publications from discriminatory hiring practices.

A world-wide survey covering commercial experience with revised telegraphic and cable communication rates has been started by the International Chamber of Commerce, it was announced yesterday by the group's United States Council.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 30-- In taking over the presidency of the Investment Bankens Association here today, Joseph T. WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Two of the principal aides of Senator Robert A. Taft in his campaign for re-election in Ohio last year were witnesses today before the subcommittee on Privileges and Elections of the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration, which is inquiring into that election. The whole company was on its toes, and under Eugene Ormandy's gay and affectionate leadership everything moved cheerfully.

WASHINGTON, Nov., 30--Average primary market prices increased 0.2 per cent in the week ended on Nov. 27, 1951, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, 177.6 per cent of the 1926 average, was 13.2 per cent above the pre-Korean average-- May 24-June 25, 1950--and 2.9 per cent above the level of a year ago.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 30-- A yacht tragedy that cost eight lives was discovered off the Atlantic coast today when a Navy mine sweeper came upon a provisionless lifeboat containing two bodies, a dying boy and a nearly incoherent man survivor.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 30-- William H. McCarter, director of athletics at Dartmouth College, tonight issued the following statement on the Dartmouth-Princeton game last Saturday.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 30-- David Irving Mead of 143 East Hartsdale Avenue, former chairman of the board of the South Brooklyn Savings Bank, died today in White Plains. His age was 76.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)-- Farm prices increased about 1.7 per cent between mid-October and mid-November, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

The stock market enjoyed its best rally in three weeks yesterday as broad demand spread through several important divisions and raised prices an average of 1.7 points. Followers of the market were content to label it a technical rebound in the wake of recent shuttling performances.

Paddy Young of Greenwich Village and Ernie (the Rock) Durando, aptly nicknamed slugger from Bayonne, N.J., fought last night in Madison Square Garden for a crack at Ray Robinson's world middleweight title. But after ten rounds of gruelling fighting the selection of a foeman for the champion was as confused as it had been before hostilities started.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 30-- Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, assistant United States high commissioner, said today he was leaving Germany with the feeling that the German people were not trying hard as they might to make up for the Nazi past. Expected Revulsion

The State Supreme Court has ruled that the city's Smoke Control Board can summon Consolidated Edison and other offenders directly into Magistrates' Courts and prosecute them for violations of the Administrative Code.

PARIS, Nov. 30--The Western Big Three powers and eight to eleven other countries plan to ask the United Nations General Assembly to give its formal backing to a plan for preparing the world organization to deal swiftly with any future outbreaks of aggression.

Representatives of all phases of the life insurance business were in general agreement yesterday that New York State should change its laws to permit increasing the recompense of agents. They appeared as witnesses yesterday at the Bar Association Building before a Joint State Legislative Committee headed by State Senator William F. Condon. The next hearing is to be held on Jan. 4.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, an open candidate for the 1952 Republican Presidential nomination, challenged an "available" Harold E. Stassen today on the latter's home grounds in Minnesota.

The General Assembly of the UnitedNations has voted unanimously to experiment with an off-the-record "little disarmament conference" of the Big Four Powers--the United States, Britain, France and Soviet Russia.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30-- J. Brooks B. Parker, financier, sportsman and member of the International Olympic Committee, died today in Bryn Mawr Hospital after a heart attack. He was 61 years old.
WATERLOO, Iowa, Nov. 30 (AP) --The will of a man who left a $70,000 trust fund to "persons who believe in the fundamental principles of the Christian religion" was ruled invalid here today.

A plan of recapitalization to result in a distribution of stock in a new corporation next year to stockholders of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company has been approved by the company's trustees, it was announced yesterday...
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 (UP)-- Southern California was a onetouchdown favorite tonight to defeat Notre Dame tomorrow in the final football game of the season for both teams.

STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 30 --Federalists in the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe submitted today a statute amendment that would permit the Council to develop a European political authority with the active participation of part of the member nations and in close association with Britain and other non-participating states.

Antony Tudor's "Lilac Garden," which the New York City Ballet last night added to its repertoire at the City Center, is fifteen years old and has been well known in this country for at least ten of those years, yet last night's performance tempts one strongly to say that one has never seen it before.

United Nations Command patrols operated in all sectors of the battle zone (Friday), but generally made only minor contacts with enemy forces. The enemy probed at our lines with units up to two platoon strength. One friendly patrol in the western sector ran into an estimated company, and after an exchange of small arms fire withdrew and directed artillery at the hostile unit.

Orson Welles said last night in London that he might accept one of several offers to bring his stage production of "Othello" to New York late this season, but that he expects to wait until next winter before opening on Broadway.
LONDON, Nov. 30--The stock market's recovery was checked today by a flood of new stock issues and a warning by the banks that requests for loans would be more critically examined and that bank...

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 30-- Charging that The Associated Press was attempting to confuse the American people, a White House spokesman today disclosed secret Eighth Army orders and reports declaring there had been no command to United Nations forces to cease firing in Korea and that ground fighting never had come to a complete halt on either wednesday or Thursday, Korean time, as The Associated Press reported.
Max Laserson, lecturer in contemporary civilization at Columbia University, died of a heart attack Thursday in his home, 526 West 113th Street. His age was 64.
There were no reported marriage proposals at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park yesterday as for three hours a legendary "tree of romance" failed to cast its alleged spell.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 1--United Nations truce delegates at Panmunjom flatly rejected yesterday a Communist proposal for withdrawal of foreign troops by stages as a feature of an armistice in the Korean war.

The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Local 813, A.F.L., called a strike early today against 600 private garbage collection concerns that gather an estimated 65 per cent of all the refuse in the five boroughs and Nassau and Westchester counties.
Chief Magistrate John IV. Murtagh imposed a sixty-day workhouse term and a $1,000 fine yesterday on a driver who had ignored forty-even traffic tickets in the last year.
ROME, Nov. 30--The business of organizing the Western World is a terrific job of pioneering. It has no rules or precedents because it has never before been attempted on a voluntary basis.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (UP) The National Collegiate Athletic Association defended tonight its football television program of the 1951 season and criticized pressure applied to the program by "political and alumni groups and by the television industry."

The chapel of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Judith Paige, daughter of Mrs. Edgar A. Nelson of New York, and Richard C. Paige of Santa Barbara Calif., to James Drummond Erskine 3d, son of Mrs. James D. Erskine of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and the late Mr. Erskine.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 30--The second annual assembly of the World Veterans Federation ended tonight with its membership increased to eighty-two organizations from fourteen countries. The newly admitted organizations were from Canada, Norway, Denmark, the Philippines and Israel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--The Department of Agriculture today urged farmers to drive for a new high in production next year to meet the "greatest" demands this country has ever faced.

Improved blood transfusion methods promising to save many additional lives among the wounded on the battlefield and victims of disaster, accidents and injuries were described yesterday at a conference on shock under the auspices of the New York Academy of Sciences.

In the face of demands for higher salaries to head off resignations of specialized medical personnel on the city's payroll the Budget Director's office has ordered a $250 cut in the annual pay of seven of the thirteen tuberculosis clinicians in the Health Department, it was learned yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 30 (AP)-- Favored teams paraded smoothly through opening-round doubles matches in the Victorian tennis championships tdoay. Ted Schroeder and Tony Trabert, the United States' new Davis Cup combination, crushed the Melbourne pair of Peter Molloy and Jim Matthews, 6--3, 6--4, 6--3.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30--The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to comply with a request of forty-one railroads for the suspension of a rate schedule for Seatrain Lines, Inc., on service between Edgewater, N.J., and points in Alabama, Georgia and Tennessee, under the temporary authority the I.C.C. recently granted Seatrain to operate between New York and Savannah, Ga.

Tommy Henrich, the Yankees' famed "Old Reliable" these many years, has finally come to a parting of the ways with the Bombers. His contract as coach, under which he operated the past year following his retirement as an active player, is not to be renewed for 1952.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 30-- President Truman today called the heads of his secret foreign intelligence agency and the defense mobilization effort here for personal conferences over the weekend.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman temporarily restrained the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., yesterday from striking against the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and directed the union to postpone a strike vote set for Tuesday.

DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP)--Senator Homer Ferguson, of Michigan, questioned today whether it "doesn't actually verge on treason" for middlemen to capitalize on shortages to multiply the cost of much-needed steel and copper.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 30 (AP)--For the second time this week Alan T. Clarke's King Mowlee won the feature race at Bowie, scoring today by a neck over Auntie.
HONOLULU, Nov. 30--Seven residents of Hawaii indicted for violating the Smith Act began a legal battle today to keep their cases from coming to trial.

James M. McInerhey, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Criminal Division, announced yesterday that the Department of Justice would order the impaneling of special Federal grand juries early next year for a country-wide survey of crime conditions.
Holding the upper hand virtually all the way, Columbia University's 1951-52 quintet made its debut last night by conquering the New York A.C., 67--64, in the Winged Foot clubhouse gymnasium.
