WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Increases in compensation to salesmen and other employes paid on a commission basis were authorized today in a regulation by the Salary Stabilization Board. The regulation is effective immediately.

With the cooperation of the state, the local Board of Education and leaders in industry, New York City has just opened its first publicly supported two-year community college. This step marks a new movement in the educational program offered here.

THE Twisses' rolling parlorbedroom-and-sink, or "rig," was indeed very, very long. In Utah, when Clint and another tourist parked in tandem, the two cars with their gleaming leviathan appendages took up fourteen parking meters; by the time the fourteenth meter had been bribed, the violation flag had popped up on the first.

AN herb garden is almost evergreen. Hardy kinds are an oasis in the fast-browning landscape of winter and the essence of summer lingers in the stilt fragrant foliage of lavender rue, hyssop and thyme.
LONDON, Dec. 1 (Reuters)-- Preston, struggling to rise above fifth place in the first division of English soccer, today upset thousands of pool bettors by holding Portsmouth to a 2-2 draw at home.
THAT fickle, amorphous mass designated as the "theatre going public" has recently had its pulse taken by the first Market Research Consultant ever employed to stalk The Street.
An all-Mozart, program, commemorating the 150th anniversary of the composer's death, will be the weekly recorded concert on Wednesday between noon and 2 P.M. at the New York Public Library.

PARIS, Dec. 1--Fifty members of the United Nations voted today in favor of a Yugoslav resolution asking the Soviet Union and the Eastern European states to resume normal diplomatic relations with Belgrade and settle border disputes peaceably.

HOLLYWOOD. MARY McCALL JR., in as suming the office of presi dent of the Screen Writers Guild, is faced with the task of attempting to restore harmony in an organization that has been riddled by political strife.

Former President Hoover yesterday criticized as "fuzzy-minded" those who contend that nationalism is an evil. The eradication of nationalist felings "is not the road to the freedom of mankind," Mr. Hoover said.

A sizable group of the European industrialists now visiting the United States on the invitation of the Economic Cooperation Administration has received its first exposure to the competitive system of marketing as practiced in the United States.

There will be no break in mill prices of carpets before the end of the year, Sol Stoumen, president of the National Association of Carpet Retailers, declared last week. He took issue with reports by a buying-office executive that prices were cracking and due for an official reduction soon.
HOUSTON, Dec. 1--Larry Isbell led Baylor to a 34-13 triumph over Rice and an invitation to the Orange Bowl today.

CHICAG0, Dec. 1--The head of the United States Olympic Committee today warned that subsidized college athletes, "rewarded financially for their talent alone," will be ineligible for the 1952 Olympic Games at Helsinki.

A ROMANTIC photographer of old Paris, who died in 1927 after thirty years of making pictures, was remem bered last week by the opening of a show of 200 of his prints at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Of the large volume of medical literature published each week, two recent pamphlets have special interest to many persons suffering from disabling chronic illnesses. BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 1-- The future of Thailand's new Government, set up yesterday after a peaceful coup by a military junta, focused tonight on the country's 23year-old King Phumiphon Aduldet.

Homer E. Robertson, formerly vice president in charge of sales for the Somerville Iron Works, Newcastle, Pa., manufacturer of cast iron pipe and fittings, has been appointed executive vice president of the Cast Iron Soil Pipe Institute, Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec, 1--With the largest score registered by either teams in their fifty-two football meeting since 1890, Navy defeated Army, 42-7, today before a paid attendance of 96,116. The crowd was approximately 2,500 short of a sell-out, the first time there have been empty seats at this game since it, was brought to Municipal Stadium.

Hope flickered brightly but briefly in thousands of American homes last week as premature and fallacious reports of a ceasefire in Korea confused once again both the troops at the front and the public at home.

Dr. Selman A. Waksman, president of the foundation and chairman of the Department of Microbiology at Rutgers University, made this announcement yesterday.

United Nations and Communist negotiators wrangled over proposed armistice terms at further truce sessions, with Allied delegates strongly opposing an enemy demand that the Communists have the right to build and maintain airfields in North Korea during an armistice.

Three floors of the new ten-story, $8,000,000 Tuberculosis Building at Kings County Hospital will be opened tomorrow with the transfer of 360 patients from other units, Dr. Israel Magalaner, medical superintendent, announced yesterday.
VIENNA, Dec. 1--The arrest this week of Rudolf Slansky, former general secretary of the Czechoslovak Communist party, on charges of espionage and treason took the Western World by surprise.

THE latest exhibit to go on view in the New York Bo tanical Garden brings a touch of the tropics to the wintry New York scene. "Puerto Rico, U.S.A." is the title of the display, which may be seen in the main greenhouse from 10 A.M. until 4 P.M. daily, until Jan. 12.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 28-- The Government of Indonesia is able to cite as impressive list of achievements as the second year of Indonesian independence draws to a close. Many grave problems remain unsolved and the next few years will be critical, but sympathetic observers here feel the achievements so far are greater than had generally been thought possible two years ago.

City College, sparked by sophomore Billy Behrens and Dick Watson, defeated Roanoke College, 63--62, in a thrilling game at the victors' gym last night. With less than a minute to go, the score was knotted at 62-all. Jerry Domershick caged a foul shot to win the game.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1--There were empty seats at the ArmyNavy game today, for the first time in recent memory. Nevertheless, there were more eyewitnesses than ever before to the pomp and pageantry and spirited combat of the fifty-second service classic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)-- The Congressional Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Federal Spending said today civilian employment in the Government increased by 2,591 persons in October. Seven agencies showed decreases for the month, eight reported increases.

Frederick W. Leamy of 944 Park Avenue, for many years vice president of the Delaware Hudson Railroad, died yesterday morning in Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

WHO was the real Franz Liszt? Was he the man who, after leaving a party one night in Paris, took a broom from an idler's hand and swept the streets?

A FUNDAMENTAL conservation problem in New York State has been pointed up by a renewed attack on the provision of the state Constitution requiring that the Forest Preserve "shall be forever kept as wild lands." The Forest Preserve consists ...
DE LAND, Fla.--Shad fishing is one of the newer sports in Florida. Shad were discovered in the St. Johns River near here only a few years ago by a New York State visitor who was trolling for bass.

Miss Wendy Curtis Salmond, daugliter of Mr. and Mrs. Felix Salmond of 124 East Eighty-first Street, was married here yesterday afternoon to Clarke Kimberly Oler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley Marion Oler of Greenwich, Conn., in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church.

Do men and animals fight because of some inherited inner urge? Or is it because they are trained to be belligerent? Some light is thrown on these questions by experiments that Drs. J.P. Scott and Emil Fredericson of the Poscoe B. Jackson Memorial Labora

THE way things have been go ing in recent years, it would seem like turning the clock back to give anyone a dark room outfit for Christmas. But no time was ever more propitious than the present, when amateurs

CAMP KILMER, N.J., Dec. 1-- This camp's "Soldier of the Week," Pvt. Andrew Rupert, who is assigned to Detachment Eleven, has had an unusual military recordhe has served with the German, French and American armies!

Rabbi William F. Rosenblum commemorated yesterday the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination by preaching a sermon at Temple Israel, 210 West Ninetyfirst Street, in which he omitted emphasis on his past and addressed himself to the future.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Events of the last few days indicate once more that East and west, Communist and non-Communist, American and European, Republican and Democrat, have at least one thing in common: they are overwhelmed by events and trapped by the consequences of their mutual hostility.

At 11 A.M. tomorrow Rockefeller Center tenants and their employer will begin the first community bloodmobile operation there. All of the blood collected will be sent to the armed forces. The bloodmobile units will be set up in the gymnasium on the fourth floor of 10 Rockefeller Plaza.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--An American who vaulted to high place from the springboard of Senatorial inquiry once called investigation "one of the most important powers of the Congress."

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 1 --The Council of Europe came close to a crisis today when the proposal to create a high authority for European agriculture was saved from flat rejection by the fraction of one vote.

NORMAN, Okla., Dec. 1-- The University of Oklahoma swamped Oklahoma A. and M. College, 41--6, today and gave future foes something to worry about by sending an 18-year-old freshman halfback on four scoring errands.

BOSTON, Dec. 1--Boston College defied everything except tradition in its clash with Holy Cross at Braves Field today. Pelegates to the underdog role in all the pre-battle calculations, the Eagles came through with an upset triumph, setting down the Crusaders by the score of 19 to 14.
DEAD in 1924, at the age of 39, after an agonizingly long illness from gas poisoning at the end of the first war, Roger de La Fresnaye is one of the casualties of French twentieth century painting.

A century ago this morning France suffered a national shock. It waked to find itself in the hands of a dictator. The situation which brought this about was confusing. The Second Republic, which the coup d'etat of Dec. 2, 1851,

THE indoor gardener can have his own special set of tools and gadgets just as his out door counterpart does. The possibilities include any number of interesting and useful pieces of equipment, from the tiny spading fork that loosens soil in pots to the miniature greenhouse complete with automatic controls.

The last month of the year was ushered in by the trading fraternity with little enthusiasm. The surprising and confusing news from Korea had little effect on financial markets. Traders were influenced
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed very irregular yesterday, and prices were 15 points higher to 18 points lower.

AFTER spending nearly half of his fifty-odd years at the limelight's edge, a British actor named Barry Jones suddenly has been brought into clear public focus, both screen and stagewise, by the realized dream of

In the wake of the scandals that have placed the sport under a cloud, no one can be certain of college basketball's future in this city. Still, in the 1951-52 inaugural double-header last night at Madison Square Garden, where Siena defeated Manhattan, 55-45, and, New York University routed William and Mary. 85-70, there were, encouraging signs.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (UP)-- There was a mist in the eyes of Earl Blaik when he greeted Navy Coach Eddie Erdelatz at midfield after the Cadets had absorbed their worst walloping in the fifty-two-game series.

THE revival of Hermann Hesse's popularity in post Nazi Germany is so logical one is tempted to suggest that literature like history repeats itself. Ever since the publication of his first novel, "Peter

CUBA'S promised "Action de el Morrillo" series honoring Antonio Guiteras Holmes (1906-35), Philadelphia-born Cuban pharmacist, who became a "national hero," reached New York last week from E. Taboada in Havana.

STARKSVILLE, Miss., Dec. 1 (AP)--Missippi's Showboat Boykin ended his college football career in a burst of speed today setting a new Southeastern Conference individual scoring record and overwhelming Mississippi State, 49--7.

THE age-old dramatic formula of boy meets girl, loses her and then gets her back is being used by a young husband-and-wife television team as the peg for-of all things-a chitchat show. Mike Wallace, a former radio and television announcer in Chicago, and Buff
General Dwight D. Eisenhower invoked a Biblical analogy last week to emphasize the predicament confronting the North Atlantic Community. He quoted from St. Luke:

Analysis of the existing economic data on concentration in the American economy shows that there is no statistical support for the frequent statements by the Federal Trade Commission and other agencies that concentration is increasing, Prof. M.A. Adelman reports.
The Automobile Club of New York reported recently that each year some 2,000,000 American youths reach the driving age, yet only one out of every eight is properly trained to handle an automobile.

The efforts of the Communists to destroy the Church in China will fail because of "the loyalty and faith of the missionaries and pastors," Bishop Yu-Yue Tsu said yesterday in a sermon at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 2-- Harvard University reported today that gifts totaling $1,762,955.03 were received during the third quarter of the year.

Dissatisfied with unofficial assurances that there would be no bus strike tomorrow, the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Fifth Avenue Coach Company demanded last night that Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private transit industry, obtain an unequivocal no-strike pledge from Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C.I.O.

ZURICH, Dec. 2-Comment in Switzerland endorses the view expressed in an article entitled "Sterling Dollar Rate of Exchange. that appeared in the Corriere Della Sera of Milan on Nov. 27, signed by C. Bresciani-Turroni, chairman of the Banco Di Roma and executive director of the World Hank, that if the rigid attitude of British monetary authorities, particularly to

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 2 (AP)-- Bob Celeri tossed three last quarter touchdown passes today to pace the New York Yanks to a 31-28 decision over the Green Bay Packers and their first victory of the waning National Football League season.
LONDON, Dec. 2--The stock market's brighter appearance last week was mainly due to a technical rally.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 2 (AP) --President Hashem al-Atassi resigned today and Col. Adeeb Shishekly, Army Chief of Staff, took over sole executive authority.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 2' -- Federal Government support programs for the education, training and employment of research scientists have been so expanded as to constitute a "national danger," according to H. McKinley Conway, director of the Southern Association of Science and Industry.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 2-- Charles E. Wilson, Defense Mobilization Director, told newspaper men after a series of conferences with President Truman today that civilian production was not being allowed to interfere with military output.

Nobel Prize winner in chemistry predicted yesterday, as he took off for Sweden to receive his award, that it would take at least twenty years before atomic power could be developed to compete with coal and water in supplying the United States with electricity and industrial power.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 2 --The first month's results in car rying out the policy of price deflation has encouraged the Government to proceed with the rest of its economic decentralization program, which will now be completed in its major outlines before Jan.1.
DETROIT, Dec. 2--The 1951 winter session of the American Contract Bridge League's twentyfifth annual national contract bridge championships officially opened here this afternoon at the Leland Hotel.

The first Sunday of Advent, the four-week period of prayerful penitential preparation for Christmas, the Feast of the Nativity, was marked in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday by the opening of the "Forty Hours Adoration."

HONG KONG, Nov. 27--A new railway network scheduled to connect Soviet Central Asia with Northwest China is shaping up in outline on the China mainland. This railway system would provide the Moscow-Peiping alliance a giant communications are useful for military or economic purposes.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 2--Probably no group in the National Production Authority worked harder in the past few weeks than those charged with getting scrap to the. right places quickly. It was nip and tuck with many steel mills which were low in scrap inventory and needed more of it immediately.

Argyle R. Mackey, United States Commissioner of Immigration, said yesterday that the 37,000 displaced persons in Germany now being processed for immigration into this country would receive visas by the end of this month.

Ten buildings have been chosen to receive first awards and bronze plaques for "excellence in design and construction" in the 1951 competition of the Queens Chamber of Commerce. Seven other structures completed in the borough between Nov. 1, 1950, and Oct. 24, 1951, will get honorable mention.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (UP)--Bill Mosienko, with two goals and three assists, led the Chicago Black Hawks to a 6-4 victory over the New York Rangers tonight and dropped the Rangers into the National Hockey League cellar. The Hawks rose from last place to fifth.

A specialist in the training of blind children of pre-school age has been appointed to the staff of the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street, M. Robert Barnett, executive director of the foundation, announced yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 2--The Government of the Union of South Africa has not granted travel documents to a delegation of South-West African tribal chiefs invited to appear before the Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, the chiefs reported today.
A best-in-show decision that may be without precedent in this country was made last night to bring the thirtieth all-breed event of the Bronx County Kennel Club to a close at the Kingsbridge Armory.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 3--Soviet Air Force planes forced a missing United States Air Force C-47 transport plane to land in Hungary two weeks ago and the four-man crew was turned over to Hungarian authorities, the Soviet news agency Tass reported today.

ALBANY, Dec. 2--Daniel P. O'Connell, veteran Albany County Democratic leader, said today his attempt to force Paul E. Fitzpatrick from the Democratic state chairmanship was not the culmination of a patronage dispute.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 2--Citing the Far East's distaste for Western colonialism, John Foster Dulles said here tonight that "what happens in Japan in the coming months will be important in showing that fellowship is possible" between East and West.

HONG KONG, Dec. 2--Accused of "willfully murdering" 2,116 Chinese babies at Canton's Holy Infant Orphanage, two French-Canadian nuns were sentenced to five-year prison terms and three others ordered deported from China at a mass rally held today in Kwantung's provincial capital.

Dinah Shore has begun her own television program over N.B.C., and it should be one of the delights of the season. Relaxed, informal and running only fifteen minutes at a time (7:30 P. M. Tuesdays and Thursdays), the presentation is a TV tidbit imbued with charm and simplicity.
One of American Protestantism's "elder statesmen" will observe his ninety-fifth birthday today with a vigor that would do justice,to a young clergyman about to begin his daily round of

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Ehrenclou of 925 Park Avenue, and Camden, S. C., of the engagement of their daughter, Jessie Harding, to Cecil Browne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rollin Browne of 290 Park Avenue, and Easton, Md. Plans have been made for a sprint wedding.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--The National Education Association, in a bulletin today, urged that college athletics be preserved, possibly even as spectator sports, in the face of mounting criticism of professionalization and scandals springing from it.

LONDON, Dec. 2--Benjamin Britten conducted his new fulllength opera, "Billy Budd," to a triumphant first performance last night that brought generous acclaim to Theodor Uppman, young American baritone who sang the title role. There were fifteen curtain calls as E. M. Forster, the senior librettist, joined the composer and cast on the stage at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden.

PARIS, Dec. 2--The examination of military budgets of the North Atlantic Treaty partners by a small international staff of technicians here has produced recommendations for "substantial savings" in the cost of rearming Western Europe.

The Knickerbockers returned to the victory column in impressive fashion last night. Paired against the Philadelphia Warriors in a National Basketball Association tussle at Madison Square Garden the New Yorkers swept to an 86to-72 triumph.
Once upon a time, the police said, Freddie Holmes, 25 years old, of 173-12 108th Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, lost his shoe--and it was no glass slipper from his Fairy Godmother.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 3 (AP)-- General Headquarters communiqu 1,086, covering Sunday's operations:

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 3--Five Communist jet fighters were destroyed in another air battle over North Korea yesterday as fortysix Sabre jets tangled with more than sixty MIG's. All United Nations pilots returned safely to their bases.

TOKYO, Dec. 2--Lieut. Gen. O. P. Weyland, commander of the Far East Air Forces, said today that the Communists were making a bid for aerial supremacy in the northwestern section of Korea. He asserted that more F-86 Sabre jets might be coming this way from the United States to make certain that the enemy did not succeed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2--A new 70-millimeter X-ray camera, described by its designers as the largest motion picture camera in the world, went on exhibit today as the Radiological Society of North America opened its thirty-seventh annual convention in the Palmer House.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 2-- Should Joe DiMaggio decide to cal it a career--a matter upon which the Clipper is expected to reach...

The new tax measure, under which employers are to withhold federal income taxes from pay checks at the rate of 20 per cent--instead of 18 per cent--after personal exemptions but before deductions for charitable contributions, has made people strongly

VIENNA, Dec. 2--Nine members of the staff of the Economic Cooperation Administration and the United States High Commissioner's office have been dismissed or transferred in the last week in a drastic shake-up.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 2James Dwight Dana, corporation and probate lawyer who served as a special assistant to the Department of State in Washington during the first World War, died in his home today. His age was 62.

Aubrey, Moore Wallace, Inc., Chicago, will change its name to Aubrey, Finlay, Marley Hodgson, Inc., effective Jan. 1. James T. Aubrey, president of the agency since its inception in 1923, will become chairman of the board and chief executive officer. John J. Finlay, a vice president since 1933,
JAMESTOWN, R. I., Dec. 2Ross Ray Harrison, president of the Anchor Tool and Die Company of Providence, died last night in Newport Hospital. His age was 67.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 (AP)--The San Francisco Forty-niners, who thrive in killing off the big fellows, booted the Detroit Lions out of first place in the Western Division of the National Football League today with a 20-10 victory before a crowd of 52,024.

The profound air of pessimism, cynicism and discouragement that pervades the disarmament talks in Paris and the truce talks in Korea is unhappily their most distinctive feature. A modern Diogenes could no more find an optimist in either place than the old Greek Cynic could find an honest man.

PUSAN, Korea, Dec. 2--Early this morning reinforced South Korean troops cut off and surrounded a mountain area in Southwest Korea believed to shelter at least 8,000 guerrillas. The regular forces made a surprise move by sea and overland to join the national and provincial police and Youth Corps...

After an absence of two seasons, Olga Coelho, Brazilian sopranoguitarist, returned to Town Hall last night to give one of her unusual programs. She proved again that she is an unofficial ambassador for which not only Brazil but all Latin America should be grateful.

Fordham University is facing its first operating deficit since the war years as the result of a decline of $250,000 in income. This was made known yesterday by the Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president, who presented his annual report at a convocation of the faculties in Keating Hall.

To talk with Mrs. James A. Reed, even for a few minutes, is to be aware of a woman of broad and varied interests. Conversation moves rapidly from travel to music, education, the country and on to out-of-doors sports. Only when the interlocutor insists does it turn to business and fashion.

Even if their title chances are next to hopeless, the New York Giants maintained mathematical "life" in the American Conference of the National Football League by defeating the Pittsburgh Steelers, 14--0, at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

After an ownership of about a month, Fred H. Hill, operator, has resold the former residence of Cecil Pecci-Blunt at 9 East Eighty-fourth Street to Bee-Lee Holdings, Inc., Leo Glass, president. The new owner plans to convert it to small apartments from plans by Alexander Zamschnick, architect.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2--Wheat prices were lifted to new high levels for the crop last week, and in spite of free realizing, declines from the top were not specially significant. Much buying was the direct result of the heaviest export business in a long time, buyers including Great Britain, Germany, Italy, Austria and other countries.

Private Matthew J. Stovall isn't as alone in the world as he thinks, and maybe now he won't be going bath to Korea. As a result of a story yesterday in THE NEw York TIMES about the unofficial "adoption" by two New Jersey gold star mothers of the lonely soldier, who knew no kin, Mrs. Elizabeth O'Connor of 346 East Sixty-fifth Street, identified herself as the twin of Private Stovall.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2--Seven hundred and fifty Jewish leaders here today unanimously adopted a series of resolutions calling for the raising of "maximum gift dollars" next year to meet "the tremendous needs" of Jews in Israel, overseas and at home.

The proposal of the State Board of Regents that daily prayers be said in public schools was endorsed by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale in his sermon yesterday morning at Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twentyninth Street. He urged that letters be written to the New York City Superintendent of Schools and Governor Dewey in support of the suggestion.

ALBANY, Dec. 2--The Governors of New York and New Jersey will meet tomorrow to pool their law enforcement agencies in a bi-state drive to smash waterfront racketeering at the port of New York. Governor Dewey and Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, who have been planning the inquiry by telephone for three weeks, will confer in Mr. Dewey's suite at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York.

The 990-foot superliner United States, the largest shipping enterprise ever ordered in this country, is now 85 per cent completed, according to a progress report made public today by the United States Lines.

Swift strides in research abroad were made by the Armour Research Foundation of the Illinois Institute of Technology in the fiscal year just ended. In its annual report, the foundation notes that it grew by a third in size and in volume of investment by sponsors in the period ended on Aug. 31.

The Investment Bankers Association, in annual convention at Hollywood Beach, Fla., last week, heard a sharp warning from Robert H. Craft, chairman of the Government Securities Committee, concerning the nature and purposes of the coming Patman investigation into Federal Reserve

Ten-year-old Antonio Gaidoni walked yesterday, with the help of crutches, aboard an Ireland-bound plane at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, four months after he had arrived in this country for rehabilitation from poliomyelitis, which had left him without use of his legs seven) years ago.
A new approach to solving one of the city's critical problems-- foster homes for children--was announced yesterday by the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

Yesterday's New Friends of Music program was unexpectedly graced with the appearance of Erna Berger, who stepped in when Claudio Arrau became indisposed. Much as those present regretted Mr. Arrau's misfortune--including those who came to hear a pianist and were confronted with a soprano--they at least heard singing that is pretty much unique in this day of generally sloppy vocalism and unprepared interpretations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--A Considerable part of the United States military equipment now earmarked for Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's Far Eastern Command in 1952 will be diverted to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's North At lantic Treaty Command early in the new year, if an armistice can be negotiated in Korea by Christmas.
Herbert W. Payne, vice president of the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital after an illness of four weeks. His age was 49.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--The number of people protected by sanitation regulations meeting the standards of the Public Health Service of the Federal Security Agency, has increased in the last five years from 40,000,000 to 82,000,000 persons.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 2--Negotiations for a new steel wage contract will strip down to the serious bargaining stage this week, with most observers still convinced that the final decision on steel wages and prices will have to be made by the Government.

Irish Shipping, Ltd., already embarked on an ambitious 30,000- ton program of ship construction, will soon place orders for five additional vessels that will raise its over-all total of new tonnage to 70,000 deadweight tons.

A torpedo skimming by within feet of his troop-jammed transport the terrific explosion of a mine that put his ship in drydock for four months air and submarine attacks and long, tense Atlantic runs in blacked-out convoys are incidents that will forever be etched in the memory of Capt. Edwin T. Cline.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 2--Owing to the continued increase in foreign exchange reserves which last week again rose 46,000,000 guilders to 1,501,000,000, the Netherlands gold and foreign exchange reserves have, in four months, practically recovered the 630,000,000 loss suffered from February to July.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 2-- Radium poison claimed its fortyfirst victim among former employes of the United States Radium Corporation when Mrs. Florence C. Caster died today in the East Orange General Hospital.

Salesmen's organizations will continue to fight for a "floor" on commission earnings, complementing the freeze on maximums in effect since Jan. 25, and a prohibition on a shift in the method of payment from commission to salary or vice versa.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 2--The Centennial Convocation of Northwestern University honored today 100 "men and women selected for distinguished service to society" while residing in one of the six states that comprised the old Northwest Territory.

In its eighty-sixth year of voluntary aid to all races and creeds, the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service and Children's Aid Society is turning to the public once more in an effort to raise $150,000 for its four essential services.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 2 (AP)--Otto Graham passed to four touchdowns and ran over another himself today as the mighty Cleveland Browns trimmed the Chicago Cardinals, 49 to 28.

Defense Mobilization Director Charles E. Wilson flew from Washington to Key West Saturday morning with the indicated intention of reporting to President Truman and then flying back the same afternoon. But Mr. Wilson had to stay over night. The talk was serious, as the photographs suggest, and couldn't be wound up in an hour or two.

A premiere of more than passing interest occupied the feature spot at Saturday evening's Philharmonic concert. For young Roy Travis' one-movement composition was conceived in a manner rare to our new generation (and, truth to tell, to much of the older one), a manner that apparently followed the dictates of his inner ear.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (UP)--The Los Angeles Rams vaulted back into first place in the National Football League's National Conference today, belting the Chicago Bears, 42 to 17, before 50,286 fans.

PARIS, Dec. 2--The Western Big Three issued today their plan for creating a United Nations commission that would investigate the possibility of "genuinely free elections" throughout Germany. Detailed in the proposal were the various aspects of individual freedom that the investigators should study.

Picketing of the Empire State Building, regional office of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, and mass picketing of the company's home offices in Newark were promised for today by insurance agents who walked out on strike at midnight Friday.
The Waldensian Church of Italy, the oldest Protestant church in history, made an appeal here yesterday for $80,000 to help build a new church in Milan, Italy.

While Mr. and Mrs. Allan Cameron of River Forest; Ill., and their two children enjoyed a stroll in Central Park yesterday, afternoon, their sixteenth-floor suite at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel was the scene of the latest in the series of robberies at East Side hotels. Intruders made away with $16,075 in jewelry and cash.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP)--Douglas F. Roby, Detroit manufacturer and a University of Michigan halfback in 1922, was elected president of the National Amateur Athletic Union today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP)--The president of the Zenith Radio Corporation said today his concern retained James P. Finnegan, former collector of internal revenue at St. Louis, to help get films for Zenith's tests of phonevision, a movie-television device.

CHICAGO, Dec, 2--A retired Chicago police captain, sought for nearly two weeks by subpoena servers, submitted voluntarily to questioning today by the State's Attorney's office in connection with the murder here last night of a former henchman of Al Capone.
HONOLULU, Dec. 2-Sir Peter Henry Buck, director of the Bishop Museum here and Professor Emeritus of Anthropology at Yale University, died here yesterday at the age of 71.

JOHN DOS PASSOS' new novel, "Chosen Country,"* is much better than the dull trio of political novels about the Spottswood family which was his last major fictional effort. It contains some good short episodes and an attractive and appealing heroine. Nevertheless, like all Mr. Dos Passos' novels, "Chosen Country" is sorely handicapped by an ideological thesis and...

Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung" will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday, Dec. 13, with Helen Traubel singing the role of Bruennhilde and Set Svanholm as Siegfried. It will be the first Wagnerian performance of 1951-52.

Premature extraction of primary or baby teeth is responsible for at least 50 per cent of adult tooth trouble, Dr. Harold R. Klein, assistant professor of children's dentistry at New York University, said yesterday at the midwinter meeting of the New York Society of Dentistry for Children.

NAPLES, Dec. 2--The headquarters of the Mediterranean Command is a brand new apartment house overlooking the Bay of Naples and the note smokeless cone of Vesuvius. It is a provisional location, expected to be replaced soon by another temporary building modeled after General Eisen
Even Santa Claus has gone Paris-mad and found himself a boutique; this one at Hattie Carnegie's, 42 East Forty-ninth Street.

This week Phi Beta Kappa celebrates its 175th birthday, Founded on Dec. 5, 1776, at the College of William and Mary, the organization has evolved into an honorary society which, through its chapters in colleges and universities over the land, grants recognition to the best students in those schools. The desire to win membership spurs tens of thousands on to better work in their studies.

The Mangeorge Realty Corporation, lessee of the twelve-story showroom building at 1071 Avenue of the Americas, southwest corner of Forty-first Street, has pur-. chased the property from Gerry Estates, Inc., in a deal negotiated by Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., brokers, who in connection with

It is difficut to describe the sensations that follow exposure to a performance of the late Gertrude Stein's play, "Dr. Faustus Lights the Lights." A straight dive from the high board into a dry swimming pool might produce similar effects.

The accelerated tempo of industrial mobilization for national defense may be the deciding factor that soon will complete the recovery of the $10,000,000,000-a-year home-furnishings industry from the slump it has been in for the last eight months.

PARIS, Dec. 2--While the Assembly prepares for its debate next week on ratification of the Schuman plan for the merger of the coal and steel industries of Western Europe, Government officials are emphasizing the fact that the French steel industry produced a record 890,000 tons of unfinished steel in October, compared to the previous record of 853,000 in October, 1950.
A conference between opposing sides in the strike of 1,500 private refuse collectors broke up soon after last midnight, with no progress reported. The session lasted an hour and a half.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2-- The boards of directors of the Screen Actors Guild and the Screen Extras Guild in a joint statement tonight demanded that the jurisdiction claims of Television Authority be limited expressly to performers working in live television shows.

The creation of a Transportation Authority in this city to run the subways and transit lines was proposed yesterday by James Marshall, Manhattan member of the Board of Education and its former president. Only in this way, he said, will the city get enough money to build the schools needed to meet increased enrollments.

Mayor Impellitteri's plan to create an unsalaried seven-man Transit Advisory Commission with a paid staff of experts to regulate and coordinate all rapid transit and surface transportation in the city, including taxicabs, has not yet been "sold" to the Board of Estimate.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 3--The Communists, in an abrupt reversal of their position, proposed a compromise plan today on keeping the truce that would embody some of the main points set forth by the United Nations.

Many buyers were in the wholesale market here last week placing fill-in orders for holiday merchandise, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Shopping of spring lines continued and a few initial orders were placed.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 3--United Nations and Communist negotiators spent another day of unprofitable discussion at Panmunjom yesterday over enforcement of a military armistice in the Korean war, neither side retreating from its earlier demands.

Pakistan should attain self-sufficiency in cotton textiles by 1955, according to advices received by the Pakistan Consulate General in New York. It is expected that commercial production of cotton textiles in that year will be well over ten yards per capita, in addition to fabrics that are hand loomed on a substantial basis.

During the rising tide of public interest in the dispute between Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union and nine private bus lines it will be well to review certain fundamentals. What are the facts? The union threatened to strike for the forty-hour week a year in advance of its contract expiration.

On Friday of this week, the Metropolitan Museum will open officially its long-heralded exhibition "American Sculpture--1951." Similar in scope to the museum's large preview of contemporary American painting, held last year, it will draw on work by Americans of all tendencies and techniques.

Julius Mintz, operator, bought the five-story building containing four stores and twenty-two apartments on plot 68 by 115 feet at 886 Belly Street, corner of Intervale Avenue, the Bronx, for cash over mortgages amounting to $32,000. The property is assessed at $56,000.
The season's first performance of the twin bill, "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Saturday night at the Metropolitan, presented largely familiar casts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--The Navy has begun to rate its officers on "cost consciousness" as well as other qualities of leadership, Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, chairman of the Senate Preparedness subcommittee, announced today.
Bernard Shaw's "Don Juan in Hell," now playing a limited engagement at the Century Theatre, will reopen on Broadway for a spring season of four weeks, beginning on March 31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--The course ahead in the House investigation of tax scandals appeared today to be only one of the difficult questions the major political parties will have to answer in the next several weeks.

THE analogy is not too precise but the Army team which faced Navy in the service classic at Philadelphia the other day bore a vague resemblance to the Joe Louis who fought Rocky Marciano. As far as outward appearances were concerned, here was a great champion who still resembled the fearsome, awe-inspiring destroyer of yesteryear. But he just didn't have it any more.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 2-- Arthur Knapp Jr., national dinghy champion, who hasn't been topped in any dinghy regatta since last March, today piloted his Agony go a sixth-straight victory in the Larchmont Yacht Club's championship frostbite series.

The bells are still ringing in Crabtown along the banks of the Severn in celebration of the most thumping victory Navy ever scored over an Army on the gridiron. At Boston College, too, they've been whooping it up over the stunning surprise perpetrated upon Holy Cross with five seconds remaining in the game--a typical turnabout in the rivalry between these two schools.

The completion of mutual assistance pacts enabling New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts to aid each other with their full civil defense resources in an emergency was announced yesterday.

For those who have been won over to the versatility of separates or are in search of Christmas gift suggestions, the holiday, blouses now available are more inviting than ever. Particularly tempting are the evening styles.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 3--A statement by Dr. Dov Joseph, Israel's Minister of Industry and Commerce, who believes in telling the public the hard facts, made it clear to the Israelis today that December would be for them another month of austerity, perhaps a little more austere than November, for there will be no meat at all.

MELBOURNE, Tuesday, Dec. 4 (AP)--Dick Savitt of Orange, N.J., defeated Mervyn Rose of Australia, 6-1, 2-6, 4-6, 7-5, 7-5, before 4,000 persons in the Kooyong Club Stadium today to reach the semi-final round of the Victorian tennis championship. The United State Davis Cup player will meet Ken McGregor of Australia on Thursday.

The Penthouse Gallery, a shop devoted to accessories and furnishings for the home, has come down to earth. Formerly on the top of the building at 15 West Fifty-fifth Street, it now may be found in new quarters on the ground floor of the same building.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has declared himself "flattered" at running second in a recent poll of Republican members of the House of Representatives as to who should be the party's Presidential nominee next year.

HONOLULU, Dec. 3 (UP)--Joseph Boyd Poindexter, Governor of Hawaii during the early years of World War II, died here today, after a long illness, in Queene's Hospital. He was 82 years old.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 4--British and United States Marines struck deep behind the Communist lines in a commando raid Sunday night' near Tanchon, south of the east coast port of Songjin, it was announced this morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--A reader suggests that "it has been a very long time since the Gridiron Club or anybody dusted off that Hamlet routine of a politician trying to make up his mind." The following attempt will probably demonstrate that it hasn't been long enough, but, as too many people like to say, "This is a challenge."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 3-- Two months ago the Pakistan Government stopped incoming shipments of Soviet propaganda material. The step was taken quietly and the Government officially still is mum about it. But apparently the move has met with success.

THE wildfowlers seem to be doing very well both north and south of us, but the Connecticut and New Jersey shooting seems to have undergone something of a slump during the past few days, possibly because of the milder weather.

Unbeaten, untied Tennessee was crowned 1951 national football champion yesterday by The United Press coaches rating board in its final rankings c: the season.

Sandy Saddler, world featherweight champion, and Paddy DeMarco, Brooklyn lightweight, were examined by the State Athletic Commission yesterday and were pronounced in excellent condition for their bout in Madison Square Garden Friday night. The official weights were not announced.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Dec. 3-- Former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey Gity was accused today of having libeled John Warren, a Jersey City attorney, in 1942 with "malicious motives" to keep him "forever" from criticizing the political leader's form of government.
A plaque in memory of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University from 1902 to 1945, was dedicated yesterday at a service in St. Paul's Chapel on the campus.

W. Averell Harriman, director of the Mutual Security Agency, took another step in Europe yesterday toward determination of the knotty problem of who pays for what in the Atlantic defense program.

Harmon Rowe, who exceled on defense in Sunday's 14-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers, is lost to the New York Football Giants for the rest of the season. X-rays disclosed Rowe suffered a cracked transverse process after being bumped in the spine in the Steeler clash.

Christmas activities began in earnest here yesterday as the giant Christmas tree in Rockefeller Center was set in place, children at Bellevue Hospital had a pre-Yule songfest party, and two reindeer began touring the town in behalf of the Police Athletic League.

NAPLES, Italy, Dec. 3--Probably the greatest single bottleneck restricting rearmament programs on both sides of the Iron Curtain today is the shortage of coal. Both communism and the system of relatively free enterprise are suffering acutely from this lack.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, will appear as a witness for the Government today in the anti-trust investment banking trial now going on in Federal court here before Judge Harold R. Medina.

Undefeated Princeton dominated the 1951 All-East football team by placing Dick Kazmaier and four of his teammates on the twoplatoon squad picked for the Associated Press yesterday by Eastern coaches.

The Theatre Guild announced yesterday the last five weeks for "Saint Joan," starring Uta Hagen as the Maid of Orleans. Bernard Shaw's drama, which opened the Guild's 1951-52 subscription season in New York on Oct. 4, will terminate its local engagement on Jan. 5, registering a total of 108 performances at the Cort Theatre.

WASHINGTON Dec. 3--A Department of Justice attorney testified today that Theron Lamar Caudle, dismissed Assistant Attorney General, shut off all assignments to him after he had obtained indictments in an Alabama tax fraud case involving more than $700,000 in undeclared income.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--A catalogue of plant facilities available for handling defense contracts is being compiled by the Defense Production Authority in anticipation of the day when scarcities of materials may cause the shutdown of plants or production lines now devoted to civilian goods, it was made known today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)--They Internal Revenue Bureau decided today to send copies of the filings of registered gamblers to local police throughout the nation. It also prepared a campaign of its own against an estimated 15,000 suspected gamblers who have not registered.

LONDON, Dec. 3--As Dr. Konrad Adenauer arrived in London today on his first visit as Chancellor of West Germany, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons that the Western powers wanted to complete negotiations for a new contractual relationship with the Bonn republic "as rapidly as possible."

The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., independent operator of a fleet of fourteen American-flag cargo ships, has applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a common carrier certificate to transport passengers and freight eastbound from American Pacific Coast ports to North Atlantic Coast ports.

Y., Dec. 3 --A request was made to Westchester County today to convey 170 acres of undeveloped park land in Greenburgh to the state for conversion into the first state park in the county. The Taconic State Parkway Commission made the request, although the county already had sidetracked the plan for two years.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 3--The United States, Britain and France will deliver a formal joint protest to the German Government tomorrow against what a French spokesman described as the "arrogant nationalism" in a recent speech by Dr. Hans Chr istian Seebohm, Minister of Transport.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L. I., Dec. 3 --Nassau County's new $7,000,000 sewage treatment and disposal plant in Bay Park went to work today when County Executive J. Russet Sprague pushed the starting button at dedication ceremonies.

LONDON, Dec. 3-Details of an oil deal that would put the equivalent of about $140,000,00 a year into the hands of one man were disclosed here today by the Kuwait Oil Company.
The Sunbeam Corporation has won a preliminary legal victory in a West Coast court action similar to its recent $6,000,000 treble damage suit against R. H. Macy Co., Inc., here.

Well-dressed pickets marched yesterday before offices of the Prudential Insurance Company of America in thirty-two states as unionized district agents started the third day of their strike against the company.

Commodities were active yesterday, sugar, cocoa and wool rising and coffee and vegetable oils falling. Tin in two switch trades on the Commodity Exchange also was marked down 200 to 250 points.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman refused yesterday to reduce the sentence imposed on Jacob Freidus, 34-year-old income--tax evader, of Great Neck, L. I., whose case was mentioned last Thursday before the House Ways and Means subcommittee investigating tax irregularities.
PAWNEE CITY, Neb., Dec. 3-- National and local dignitaries said their last respects here today to Kenneth Spencer Wherry in the Presbyterian Church, Senator Wherry died Thursday at the age of 59.

Draper Jr., who resigned after eleven months to devote his entire time to the post of Chairman of the Long Island Transit Authority.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 3--Thailand's new military-backed regime continued today to consolidate its position as the de facto and legal government of the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)-- T. C. Davis, board chairman of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, said today it is "ridiculous" to suggest that any Mopac security holder be squeezed out in proposed reorganization of the company.
William Constable Breed, senior partner in the law firm of Breed, Abbott Morgan of 15 Broad Street, died yesterday at his home, 435 East Fifty-second Street, of a heart attack. He was 80 years old.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 3.5 per cent in November, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In October the stores made a gain of 4 per cent over sales of the like 1950 month.

Directors of the Manufacturers Trust Company increased the annual dividend rate on its stock to $2.60 a share from the previous $2.40, with the declaration yesterday of a quarterly dividend of 65 cents a share. In previous quarters shareholders received 60 cents a share.

Japan cannot rely indefinitely upon extraordinary dollar receipts to finance her continuing heavy trade deficit with the United States, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York warns in today's issue of its monthly Review.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3--Ford C. Frick, attending his first winter meetings in his new role as Baseball Commissioner, may be called upon soon to cast his first deciding vote on a major issue.
RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 3 (UP)-- Beattie Feathers was released today as head football coach at North Carolina State after his fourth losing season in eight years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--A reStatement of United States foreign aid policy, making clear that the European Rearmament Program was "merely incidental" to the broader purpose of improving social and economic health of Western Europeans, was called for today by Richard M. Bissell Jr., deputy director of the Mutual Security Agency.
A guide to toy buying, this one based on safety, has just been issued by the Greater New York Safety Council, Inc. Mrs. Marjorie B. May, home safety director for the council, prepared the report.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3--Diplomatic observers regarded today with seriousness Soviet charges concerning a United States plane forced down in Hungary. They expressed belief the incident would further aggravate the already deeply strained relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, and the United States and Eastern European countries.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3--Chicago straphangers began getting freed jokes with their rides today but few roared with laughter. Streetcar, bus and subway riders who asked for a transfer slip were directed to read the joke printed on the back.

The Musicians' Guild, which hgs provided some of the town's best chamber music in the last five seasons, gave evidence last night when it opened its sixth subscription series that it was going to do the same for 1951-52. It was cheering, too, to see that the guild his picked up an additional hundred subscribers since its last concert.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange finished 4 to 27 points lower yesterday compared with last Saturday's close.

WINDSOR, Ont., Dec. 3 (AP)-- Workers who halted production at the giant automobile plant of the Ford Motor Company of Canada here today by a "spontaneous" strike, later forced open the gates of the factory's powerhouse and virtually shut it down.

Top American industrialists advised their European opposite numbers yesterday to speed up the fight against communism by modifying Old World capitalism and adopting essentials of the American brand of free enterprise.

Sal Di Martino, Hartford (Conn.) middleweight, spoiled the American ring debut of Doub Miller, Johannesburg, South Africa, at the St. Nicholas Arena last night by gaining a unanimous decision in a sizzling eight-round bout.

PARIS. Dec. 3--Eleven powers introduced a resolution on collective security machinery today that would invite countries now outside the United Nations to join in any action that the would organization might take against future acts of aggression.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--Lawrence Koenigsberger, sole member of the District of Columbia Board of Tax Appeals since his appointment in 1943; died yesterday at a local hospital of a heart ailment. His age was 59.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 4--The conferences at Panmunjom for an armistice in the Korean war moved back to the subcommittee level this afternoon after the Communists advanced a new surprise proposal for neutral inspection behind the battle lines during the truce.

PARIS, Dec. 3--France's most important literary award, the Goncourt Prize, was spurned today by Louis Poirier, a 49-year-old novelist, playwright and history teacher who uses the pen name of Julien Gracq.
Graciela Rivera, Puerto Rican soprano, who sang with distinction this fall with the New York City Opera, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall that was vocally outstanding.

A new technique in which complete upper and lower dentures are fastened with screws driven into the jawbones was demonstrated here yesterday at the twentyseventh annual session of the Greater New York Dental Meeting at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a Christmas bonus paid to employes over a twelveyear period was an integral part of the wage structure and as such was subject to collective bargaining.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The Office of Price Stabilization fixed dollars-and-cents ceilings today for veal at wholesale levels averaging 1 to 1 cents a pound higher than present quotations in the New York area.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 4 (UP)-- Extradition proceedings were started today against Samuel Barr, vice president of the Western Union Telegraph Co., who has been declared a fugitive from Michigan justice in failing to appear to face gambling conspiracy charges.

Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, sailed with his wife yesterday on the United States liner America for a whirlwind visit to Europe which, he said, would probably determine his role in the Republican 1952 Presidential race.

The prize-winning artists in the second national competition of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, "American Sculpture, 1951" were announced yesterday by the institution. They will receive their awards, which total $8,500, at a members' preview tomorrow evening.

The garment industry made its contribution to the campaign of American Relief for Korea yesterday in a parade of decorated hand trucks through the apparel center in the noon hour. It marked the close of the two-week drive for 1,000,000 pounds of clothing from all sections of the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP)-- Deposits in the country's 14,680 banks rose $8,000,000,000 between June 30, 1950, and June 30, 1951, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today.

ALBANY, Dec. 4--Brooklyn Republicans, led by John R. Crews, their county chairman, were waging a last-ditch battle tonight to force the Republican state organization to consent to a revision of its Congressional redistricting plan.

While marching forward into its second half-century of progress, the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League will turn back the clock in celebration of its golden anniversary.

Letters from victims urging mercy for William J. Johnston of Shrewsbury, N.J., formerly a wealthy stock broker who has admitted misappropriating $180,000 of his clients' funds, moved General Sessions Judge Edward J. McCullen yesterday to suspend execution of a two to four-year prison sentence.

NEWARK, Dec. 4 (UP)--Jimmy Walker, 191 pounds, of Plainfield, N.J., a 2-5 underdog, won the New Jersey state heavyweight championship tonight when he knocked out Archie McBride, 189, Trenton, at 2:26 of the first round of their scheduled twelve-round bout at Laurel Gardens.

The Office of Price Stabilization will hold a meeting in Washington tomorrow to consider suggestions for revising used machine tool price schedules recommended by the trade, it was announced here yesterday by machine tool dealers, ...

LONDON, Dec. 4 (UP)--Jimmy Slade of New York floored the British and European light-heavyweight champion, Dan Cockell, five times tonight and scored a fourthround technical knockout at Harringay Arena before a crowd of 10,500 that included the Duke of Edinburgh.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., increased sales for the thirteen and fifty-three weeks ended on Nov. 3, but earnings declined from the corresponding periods last year, according to the report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

The often-told story of how Robert R. Young, insurgent financier of the Thirties, won control of the Allegheny Corporation's railroad empire and thereafter spurned the financial counsel of the Morgan interests began to unfold again yesterday, but for the first time the story is being told in a courtroom.

CHARLIE JOHNSTON is one of the topflight managers in the Busted Beak industry. He handles, among others, Sandy Saddler who happens to be the world featherweight champion and who fights rough, tough Paddy De Marco in the Garden on Friday. But Charlie never will become famous because he must forever remain in the shadow of his brother, Jimmy Johnston, the almost legendary Boy Bandit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--A fundamental disagreement has arisen within the Atlantic community over the military budgets of the twelve North Atlantic Treaty nations and it is unlikely to be resolved ...

Substantial increases in the operating costs of its member steamship lines have forced the Leeward and Windward Islands and Guiana Conference to increase freight rates by about 10 per cent beginning March 1, 1952, it was announced here yesterday by A.J. Pasch, chairman of the group.

The Cities Service Company joined the Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation yesterday in filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission a comprehensive amended plan of reorganization for the gas utility.

Women's auxiliaries, along with religiously ignorant parents and cold parishes, are responsible for this "lukewarm generation of Episcopalians," the Woman's Auxiliary of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York was told at its Advent meeting yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

St. Francis College has the tallest basketball team in the history of the Brooklyn school, and the quiet-spoken Dan Lynch finds it difficult to conceal the fact that he is more than a little pleased with his current outfit.

A gift that would serve as a year-round remembrance is one for the home. Unusual objects from many parts of the world are available for Christmas presents. Some suggestions, priced between $10 and $30, are described here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--William A. Roberts, an attorney, told Judge James R. Kirkland in United States District Court here today that nine officers and six civilian employes of the Chinese Air Force's Washington office had resigned.

Conflicting statements on the effectiveness of the strike of district agents of the Prudential Insurance Company were made yesterday by the company and the union, the Insurance Agents International Union, A.F.L.

PARIS, Dec. 4--The Soviet Union showed some signs today that it would agree to sit on the disarmament commission proposed by the Western Big Three powers to plan for a reduction of armament and control of atomic weapons.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 4--If Joe DiMaggio within the week decides to call it quits on an illustrious career, it may be that Ted Williams, Red Sox slugger, will be seen in a Yankee uniform.

SEATTLE, Wash., Dec. 4--The American public was advised tonight by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee to look at the facts of the Korean war, "instead of being misled by the loose attacks of defeatists and Monday morning quarterbacks, even though they may wear five stars upon their shoulders."

Further progress on the recovery side was made yesterday by the stock market, with several of the railroads and oils leading the drive to higher ground. Corporate news provided the stimulus for the larger additions in price. The market showed a net increase of 1.09 points as measured by the combined averages of THE NEW YORK TIMES index.
NAPLES, Italy, Dec. 4--One consequence of establishing the southern headquarters of N.A.T.O. in Naples is to stress the potential role of the Italian Army in Western defense.

A "Pageant of the Opera," an exhibition of costumes, playbills and other memorabilia of opera in New York in the last hundred year, was opened yesterday afternoon at the Museum of the City of New York with a preview for 400 invited guests.
Santa Claus must have moved to New York if the 4,698 letters addressed to him in care of the local post office are any indication of his new headquarters. Whether he appeared as "Til ...

A clarification of manufacturers' obligations under a National Production Authority amended order M-79, designed to assure supply of essential industrial equipment to friendly nations, was issued yesterday through the regional office of the Department of Commerce.

Philip D. Reed, chairman of the General Electric Company, called yesterday for reducing this country's peak defense production goal in 1953 from $65,000,000,000 to $50,000,000,000 or $55,000,000,000, and ...

MELBOURNE, Dec. 4 (AP)--A possible preview of the Davis Cup challenge round was set for Thursday as America's Dick Savitt and Vic Seixas and Australia's two top players, Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor, gained the semi-finals of the Victorian tennis championships today.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 4-- A State Police officer testified today, at the opening of the manslaughter trial of Dr. Donald F. Gibson, that the Danbury physician had admitted, while under police ...
PARIS, Dec. 4--The Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly decided this afternoon to invite representatives of East and West Germany and of the East and West

Four new films will open at first-run theatres today. "Callaway Went Thataway," a MetroGoldwyn-Mayer comedy with Fred MacMurray, Dorothy McGuire and Howard Keel, is at Loew's State. Norman Panama and Melvin Frank wrote, directed and produced.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 5-- Communist delegates yesterday put sharp limitations on their proposal for neutral inspection behind the battle lines during an armistice in the Korean war and again demanded the right to build airfields in North Korea free from attack after a cease-fire.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4--Describing voluntary health insurance as "our greatest bulwark against socialized medicine," Dr. John Cline, president of the American Medical Association, acknowledged today that the best type of health insurance remained a matter of uncertainty.

UPTON, L.I., Dec. 4--Discovery of a new type of cosmic entity, an atom without a nucleus, composed of just one positive and one negative electron revolving around each other in the manner of a double star, was reported here today at the Brookhaven National Laboratory of the Atomic Energy Commission.

MANY who insist that it is the crisp, cold days that pay off in deer hunting now have a chance to revise their opinions, for the reports that have come in from the opening day in eastern Pennsylvania indicate unusually fine hunting despite the balminess of the weather.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 4 --Ivan Karaivanov, leading Yugoslav specialist on Cominform activities, reported today that Gen. Markos Vafiades, the Greek Communist rebel leader, whose ...

Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, admitted yesterday that he was "far from satisfied with what we are doing" and said that government and industry "could do with more drive" in carrying out the defense program.

Equipped with a "weighted boot," Mickey Mantle, Yankee infielder who injured his right leg in the second game of the world series, yesterday received Dr. Sidney Gaynor's consent to return to his home in Commerce, Okla.

CANAAN, N.Y., Dec. 4 (AP)-- George R. Coughlan, president of Central Manhattan Properties, Inc., and a member of the bar in New York for more than fifty years, died last night of a heart attack at a meeting of members of the local Protestant Episcopal Church, of which he was a vestryman. He was 74 years old.

For the last of the novelties scheduled for its present season at the City Center, the New York City Ballet last night presented a mild madhouse by Jerome Robbins entitled "The Pied Piper" and set to Aaron Copland's concerto for clarinet and strings.
The threat of a bus strike on lines that normally carry 3,000,000 New Yorkers a day evaporated last night.

Resumption of Fire Department trials against eight civilian employes and one uniformed member produced yesterday a lawyers' wrangle over admission of testimony by a welding contractor that he had paid gratuities to department employes.

One of the minor irritations of television, about which seemingly nothing can be done, is the Monday night schedule for dramatic programs. Every other week the viewer is torn between watching Robert Montgomery's presentation from 9:30 to 10:30 on N.B.C. or "Studio One" from 10 to 11 on C.B.S.

Last summer, in what sounds like a mighty pleasant assignment, Frank Schoonmaker, the American wine expert, tasted his way through the cellars of the provincial restaurants of France in search of good wines for a New York department store.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 4-- Caracas put the finishing touches today on preparations for the inauguration tomorrow of the third Bolivarian Games, northern South America's Olympics, which will pit athletes from Venezuela, Panama, Colombia, Peru, Ecuador and Bolivia against each other in a threeweek series of events.

MIAMI, Dec. 4 (AP)--The season's first spill resulted in the death of a filly and injuries to two of the three jockeys in a smash-up which marred the running of the fourth race at Tropical Park today.

Tennessee has a year's lease on the Father O'Donnell Trophy, emblem of the nation's No. 1 college football team as determined by The Associated Press poll. Yesterday after the ballots of 307 sports writers and sportscasters had been tabulated, Tennessee was on top.

Agreement on a new touristclass service was reached yesterday at the conference of the International Air Transport Association in Nice, France. As a result the cost of transatlantic air travel will be reduced considerably beginning next spring.

Mayor Impellitteri moved yesterday to determine the method of reorganizing New York's smoke and air pollution administration, At his request, two bills calling for the creation of a new Department of Air Pollution Control were introduced into the City Council.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--Emergency measures, including the setting of a limit on the time auto wreckers can hold junked automobiles, will be used by the Government to increase the flow of scrap metal to steel mills, which are desperately short of iron and steel scrap, officials of the National Production Authority announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The Internal Revenue Bureau made it known today that 7,706 individuals in the United States had declared themselves to be gamblers and had paid the occupational tax decreed by the last session of Congress.
The comic book industry, concededly unable to unite for selfregulation, presented a solid front yesterday against state regulation through pre-publication censorship or amendments to the penal law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--Another round in the efforts of fur dealers to have the plebian word "rabbit" stricken from the advertiser's lexicon in favor of the more distinctive "coney" took place here today in an open hearing before the fur-labeling committee of the Federal Trade Commission.
The State of Connecticut announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Dec. 13 on $45,000,000 of rental housing notes dated Dec. 31, 1951, and due on Sept. 12, 1952.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 4--A race is on between the city of Stamford and the Connecticut Light and Power Company for acquisition of eighty acres of shorefront property known as Cove Island.
Tentative plans for a "pooling" agreement to cover war-catastrophe death hazards and spread insurance death losses were disclosed yesterday by a special committee of life insurance companies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--Sixtyfive new schools for the training of members of the Organized Reserve Corps will be opened in key cities soon after the first of the year, the Army said today.

Greater cooperation between educators and the community is essential for the building of better schools, speakers representing the Board of Education and civic organizations declared yesterday. They spoke at the first all-day borough-wide school community conference held in the Bronx.

With six of their next eight games booked for home ice, the hardships of the schedule will balance off for the New York Rangers starting tonight when they skate against the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden.

Ten buildings occupying a large plot at the southeast corner of Third Avenue and East Twentyseventh Street have been resold after an ownership of less than two months by Chobol Navone, operators, to a client of Jesse Friedman, attorney.

SOON after the defeat of Japan Benjamin Appel went to the Philippines as special assistant to the United States High Commis sioner, Paul V. McNutt. His duties were sufficiently flexibly so that he could devote a great amount of time and energy to investigating what life in the islands had been like during the Japanese occupation.

The current furor over the American C-47 plane forced to land in Hungary provides an instructive case history of Soviet paranoia and propaganda skill. It is a classic example of how the Kremlin can make a mountain of a molehill, even when working with the most meager materials.
Thieves who left no trace took $20,000 in jewelry from the twelfth-floor suite of a Pittsburgh industrialist and his wife at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 4-- Thailand's new Government was expected to be ready to ask for foreign recognition within the next week, possibly by Saturday. Today a source close to Premier Pibul Songgram said he was confident that recognition would be given.

There are in this country an estimated 100,000 cases of muscular dystrophy, a mysterious, chronic, progressive weakening and wasting of the muscles that invariably ends in suffocation from pneumonia or some other respiratory disaster.
CAIRO, Dec. 4--British forces and Egyptian policemen and civilians clashed for the second day outside the city of Suez today.

Recovery of rayon textile prices from their low point of early fall is holding in the face of sluggish Movement of some types of goods, survey of the market showed yesterday. Special items are being sold in substantial volume by mills and fabric converters and a backlog is being built up by textile manufacturers for the first quarer of 1952.

A year-end dividend of $l.38 will be paid on Dec. 22 by the Adams Express Company, of which 84 cents is from ordinary net income and 54 cents represents a capital gain dividend. It is the first capital gain dividend paid by the company. Yesterday's declaration brings 1951 disbursements to $2.13 a share compared with last year's total of $1.52.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--Members of the Wage Stabilization Board from the Congress of Industrial Organizations have pro posed that the board recognize all wage rates below $1.25 an hour as substandard and permit employers to correct all substandards without board approval.
Undergraduates of Smith College, including the Misses Joan Gilpatric and Susan Scott, debutantes of this season, are active in behalf of the joint Smith-Harvard

Rewarded with an extra day of rest by Coach Jimmy Phelan for their victory over Green Bay, the New York Football Yanks will start preparations today for their contest with the Chicago Bears at Yankee Stadium on Sunday.

GUATEMALA, Dec. 4--Official's of the United Fruit Company here have indicated a desire to continue operations in Guatemala if conditions can be arranged that will permit production at a reasonable cost and will give safety to further ...

LONDON, Dec. 4--A twin-jet bomber, already in service at bases in the Soviet zone of Germany, was described as "probably the first really successful Soviet jet bomber" in Jane's All The World's Aircraft published today.
CAMBRIDGE, MaSS., Dec. 4-- Dr. George Sarton of Harvard, professor emeritus of the history of science, said today that a group of more than sixty professors, clergymen and other citizens was ...

MINNEOLA, L.I., Dec. 4--A $3,000 slander suit against a Port Washington civil defense official for allegedly labeling a Sands Point reserve Army major as a leader of a Communist conspiracy in the area, began before a jury in Nassau County Court here today.
OMAHA, Dec. 4 (AP)--Robert D. Harrison, Republican, won the special election today in the Third Nebraska Congressional District. He is an oil dealer at Norfolk.

Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, charged the Federal Administration last night with bringing the nation to the verge of economic collapse through reckless spending, lack of leadership and "an overdose of legislative activity."

MADRID, Dec. 4--Jos Solis Ruiz, head of the Spanish syndicates representing both labor and management, said today he would welcome a visit from delegates representing the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and other ...

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 4-- Frank Hague's wealth in 1942 was variously estimated today at "from $15,000,000 to $50,000,000" and at $100,000,000 by two witnesses for John Warren, a Jersey City attorney who is suing the former Jersey City Mayor for $2,000,000 for libel.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 4--Fordham's tall and talented Rams withstood Yale's late drive to score a 67-63 triumph in the opening basketball game of the season in the Payne Whitney gym tonight.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 4-- The United States demanded today that Hungary free four crewmen and return the American C-47 transport plane that was forced down by Soviet fighters Nov. 19 while on a flight from West Germany to Yugoslavia.
A tentative agreement was reached late yesterday that would end the four-day-old strike of 1,500 private garbage collection employes.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4--The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is studying a new loan of as much as $75,000,000 to finance development of new copper supplies, it was disclosed today.

PARIS, Dec. 4--One of the biggest problems for United States policy makers during the next two months will be to attempt to pre pare an alternate plan for incorporating West Germany's potential in Western defense efforts should the European army concept now being drafted by six nations collapse.

CHATHAM, England, Dec. 4--A suburban bus mowed down and killed twenty-three marching boys in a dimly lit street here tonight. Nineteen others in the marine cadet formation of about fifty boys were injured.

The United States has moved to fourth place in the total tonnage of shipbuilding under construction and on order, according to a study of world orders issued yesterday by the Shipbuilders Council of America.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4--Dr. Ernst B. Chain, the Nobel Prize-winning biochemist, who helped develop penicillin, has been barred twice from entering the United States, once on a science mission for the United Nations World Health Organization.
STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 4 --Acceptance of the goal of a 25 per cent increase in Europe's production in the next five years, as proposed in the Marshall Plan ...
With the greatest plurality in the seventeen-year history of the award, Richard William Kazmaier of Princeton yesterday was established as the 1951 winner of the Heisman Memorial Trophy.
The cotton futures market one the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closing prices were 1 point higher to 14 points lower.
