SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Dec. 5 (AP)--British Commandos and United States Marines on Monday made a second daring night raid in as many days deep behind Communist lines in Northeast Korea.

MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 4 (UP)-- Representative Frank W. Boykin, Democrat of Alabama, denied today that he ever attempted to discourage a tax fraud prosecution but said he has telephoned Justice Department officials at the insistence of the wife of a defendant in a tax case.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The National Planning Association called on President Truman today to appoint a national commission to draw up an integrated foreign policy geared to "a new world order" based on a balanced regional grouping of sovereign free nations.

A new addition to the many ceramic collections that have been introduced to the public recently will go on view tomorrow at the annual Christmas sale of the Greenwich House Pottery School, 26 Jones Street.
MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 5 (AP) --Officials of Camiguin Island expressed fear today that as many as 2,000 persons might have perished in yesterday's eruption of Hibok Hibok volcano.
The Holland-America Line plans to build another passenger vessel of 36,000 gross tons as a sister ship of the liner Nieuw Amsterdam, which she will join in the North Atlantic service.

A 1952 capital budget of $542,107,525, or $29,789,453 larger than the previous record budget adopted for 1951, was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The 1952 amount was $1,017,190 lower than the proposed capital budget submitted by the City Planning Commission.
Small fry will have a room with a view this year for the holiday carnival the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, arranges at this season for 4-to-8year-olds.

Miss Belle Preston, who did much to make the Flatbush-Tompkins Church, Dorchester Road and East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, one of the world's largest Congregational churches, in point of membership, died on Monday in a hospital in Melrose Park, Ill., after a week's illness.

LONDON, Dec. 4--Making his first speech in Britain, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany strongly impressed upon Parliament tonight his views on the imperative need for European integration and the necessity for rearming his country.
Lester W. Du Bois, president of the Henry Du Bois Sons Company, dredging contractors at 17 State Street, died on Monday at the age of 54. His home was at 20 Church Street, Greenwich, Conn.
A promising start has been made in the bi-state drive by New York and New Jersey to combat waterfront racketeering. Governors Dewey and Driscoll have met and laid the groundwork ...
Four states--New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts--have now completed mutual-assistance pacts to play the good neighbor in an emergency such as an atomic bombing.

Joyce Flissler, who made her Town Hall debut yesterday afternoon as a winner of a Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation award, added luster to that organization's record. She is a young violinist of unquestionable talent, and in helping to promote her career, the foundation proves once again not only that its heart is in the right place but that its standards are exacting.

One hundred of the country's largest corporations received 61.5 per cent of primary defense contracts of more than $10,000 during the fiscal year ended June 30 last, according to the Munitions Board of the Department of Defense.
Colette is celebrating what you might call her second empire period. Gilbert Miller's production of "Gigi," made into a play by Anita Loos, is keeping the Fulton Theatre alight.

Funeral services for Edwin L. James, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who died Monday evening, will be held at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street. The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of the church, will officiate.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 4 (AP)-- A milk producers association representing 27,000 Northeastern dairy farmers voted today in opposition to the Government's price control program "in its entirety."

For two and a half years, "Nina" glittered on the Parisian stage. At 8 o'clock tonight the Andre Roussin comedy, adapted by Samuel Taylor to fit a cast of four (instead of the original quintet)-- Gloria Swanson, David Niven, Alan Webb and William Le Massena-- ...
DETROIT Dec. 4--Eastern contract bridge supremacy was challenged when Midwest experts assumed an early lead in the 1951 Master Mixed Pair Championship.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 5 (UP)-- An unusually jovial Joe DiMaggio stopped here today en route to New York where, he said, he would announce whether he would continue to play baseball.

Gordon Dean, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said last night that the commission and the Department of Defense were "currently working on the development of plans for still another expansion of the atomic energy productive capacity of the United States." The plans, he reported were limited, however, by certain factors, including the uranium supply, the state of the art and the effect on the economy.

Last night's concert, the first of three, showed a somewhat different format from that of the Bach Aria Group's presentation of former seasons. The emphasis in programming has shifted from a succession of individual arias to complete cantatas. Instead of the vocal soloists who had been associated primarily with the organization, there were singers of international reputation engaged specifically for the occasion.

Sponsorship of youth organizations by churches and other sectarian agencies often leads to the development of "exclusive" groups, representatives of young people's agencies agreed yesterday at a conference on prejudice and discrimination. The conference was held at the McBurney Young Men's Christian Association, 215 West Twenty-third Street.

PARIS, Dec. 5--The United States proposed to the United Nations General Assembly today that two covenants on human rights, one covering political and the other economic and social rights, be drawn up and opened for signature simultaneously.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--Charles Oliphant, one of five high Washington figures linked by a Chicago lawyer to a $500,000 shakedown attempt, resigned today as chief counsel to the Bureau of Internal Revenue. At Key West, Fla., where President Truman is vacationing, a White House spokesman said the President would accept the resignation.

Studies shedding light on the mechanism used by nature to convert a type of unspecialized cell into one performing a specific function--one of the basic processes of life, the elucidation of which may provide an important clue to the mystery of cancer--received one of the two $200 prizes in natural science awarded annually by the New York Academy of Sciences.
The news from Europe, the Middle East and Asia yesterday again emphasized that a time of tension and a period of great decision was at hand between now and the early months of the New Year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The House subcommittee headed by Representative King, Democrat of California, which has been pursuing evidence of betrayals of public trust by federal tax officials, showed some indications today of being for the first time on the defensive because of its conduct of hearings.
LONDON, Dec. 5-High-spirited undergraduates squelched a demonstration against Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of Western Germany when he visited Oxford University today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 5-- Dr. Donald F. Gibson was acquitted today of manslaughter in the death of Elizabeth May Ayres, 74year-old spinster who was dependent on his medical skill, jealous over his affections and bountiful to the extent of making the handsome, 50-year-old physician sole heir to her estate of $65,000 to $100,000.

Rubber manufacturers have started planning production of new types of rubber products for announcement after the first of next month. These will be items made from cold rubber, which will enable some cost reduction in manufacturing to be made by the products manufacturers. Announcements of the new products will not be made until rubber has been officially released from restrictive controls after the first of the year.

PARIS, Dec. 5-In plain informal language France has told the Soviet Union she considers United States superiority in atomic weapons her own best defense. The French statement was made yesterday in a closed session of the Big Four powers, which are trying to find out whether substantial common ground exists between the East and the West on the basis for disarmament and atomic control.

MARYKNOLL, N. Y., Dec. 5-- Bishop Adolph J. Paschang of Maryknoll, a Roman Catholic missionary stationed at Kongmoon, China, has made contact with Hong Kong three times recently to say that the Red Chinese authorities in his district are demanding money from him under torture, according to word received here today.

A definite easing of the serious recent scarcity of steel pipe has appeared in the eastern area of the country, it was reported here yesterday by large pipe jobbers and industrial purchasing agents. The supply is still not equal to demand, but there are more offers of delivery of pipe on requests for bids by local governmental buying offices and industrial purchasing departments, it was said.

Mayor Impellitteri, one of the speakers at the recent dinner that officially opened the annual fund-raising campaign of The Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind, aptly summed up the present plight of such philanthropic organizations when he declared that generous support of The Lighthouse was needed today more than ever because "appeals that got...

LAKE CHARLES, La., Dec. 5-- Definitions of "legal double talk" were at issue today as testimony relating to the first of five indictments charging five local newspaper mill with defaming sixteen public officials and three admitted gamblers was heard in court here.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, with Pierre Monteux as guest leader, played a curiously assorted program last night in Carnegie Hall. This great musician, whose eclecticism is equalled by his interpretive insight, put before us in deliberately planned contrasts of the most extreme sort a series of standard pieces by Richard Wagner on one hand and other works, much more "precious," and much less known, by Debussy, on the other.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 6--Allied pilots in F-86 Sabre jets again jumped superior numbers of the Communist MIG-15's over North Korea yesterday and shot down five of the enemy planes. It was the tenth consecutive day of jet clashes--the longest period of sustained air fighting in the Korean war.

Robert R. Young, insurgent rail-, road financier, faced courtroom cross-examination for the first time yesterday on the story of his break with J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., and the Guaranty Trust Company over holding companies controlling the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway.
KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 5--Mrs Truman and her daughter, Margaret, ended their Key West vacation with the President today.
It has been thirty years since Nathan L. Miller drew up a budget for the state but he was able yesterday, without a moment's hesitation, to recall details concerning it.
Howard J. Stagg has been appointed director of training by the Crucible Steel Company of America.

Mayor Impellitteri, Gov. Luis Munoz Marin of Puerto Rico, John J. McCloy, High Commissioner for Germany, Ambassador Henri Bonnet of France and other leading figures of public life and journalism paid tribute to Mr. James and expressed sympathy for his family and colleagues in additional messages received here yesterday.

A greenish-tint glass that absorbs the sun's heat, reduces eyestrain and the sun-bleaching of fabrics has been developed by the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, it was announced yesterday by Richard B. Tucker, executive vice president.

Gen. Li Tsung-jen announced yesterday that he planned to oust Chiang Kai-shek as President of Nationalist China and branded the Generalissimo a usurper of the office General Li held for fourteen months as acting president.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 5--A plan to reduce "unhappiness and disappointment" during the Williams College rushing periods was recommended today by a committee of fifty-three students, alumni, trustees and faculty members.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--Recommendations by the Joint Chiefs of Staff that the Air Force be increased from ninety to 143 wings-- 126 of them combat--appeared today to have received White House approval.
The television comedy series starring Bob Hope, Fred Allen and Jerry Lester will be dropped by its sponsor, the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, on Jan. 6, at the end of its first thirteen-week cycle.

ALBANY, Thursday, Dec. 6-- After meeting for twelve and a half hours in special session, the Legislature last night approved a Republican bill reshuffling the state's Congressional districts, then adopted a second measure revising the first.

First Army prosecutors opened their case yesterday against seven soldiers charged with mutiny and riot in a disturbance Sept. 17 in Castle William, the 140-year-old guardhouse at Fort Jay, Governors Island. The seven are being tried before a general court martial on the island.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The Small Defense Plants Administration, one of the more obscure defense agencies with a limited staff and budget, took a strong stand today in demanding more attention for small business in the defense production program.

Michael J. Quill decided to lead his Transport Workers Union into a factfinding process instead of a contractbreaking strike, and the membership has agreed. This fact-finding will begin on Saturday before Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the transit industry, with all privately owned bus lines except the Third Avenue System represented.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The newer "back-pressure arm-lift" method of artificial respiration will speedily supplant the "prone pressure" method that has been used in this country since 1927 as the result of a sweeping official endorsement announced today.
FRIDAY, 4 P. M.: Fairy tales about golden-haired princesses and rainbows will be told during the New York Public Library's free story hour at the Epiphany Branch, 228 East Twenty-third Street.

Countries of southeast Asia must be made less dependent on present large-scale imports of food, Morris N. Rosenthal, New York foreign trade leader recently returned from the Far Eastern area, declared yesterday.

Brooklyn's rackets grand jury, which has received nation-wide recognition for its expose on policegambler tie-ups, had its second birthday yesterday and was told that its work will continue at least another six months.

Speaking at the first International Conference of Manufacturers at its sessions here this week, two leading American industrialists urged upon their visitors from Europe that they seek to remodel their countries' version of capitalism along the general lines of American free enterprise.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 6--The Communist delegates at Panmunjom yesterday named Poland and Czechoslovakia, members of the Soviet bloc in the United Nations, as two "neutral" nations qualified to supervise the enforcement of an armistice in the Korean war by inspection behind the battle lines after a cease-fire.

LONDON, Dec. 5--While Prime Minister Churchill has been pondering the need for an agreement with Washington on the control of United States air force units in this country, their establishment has been growing larger and becoming more deeply rooted here.

To earn your living sitting in a swivel chair in an air-conditioned office is not necessarily easy, and it can cause ulcers, nervous breakdowns and high blood pressure; but it certainly seems easy compared with the vocations some people choose deliberately. This may be a security-minded age with millions of persons longing for a good job, paid-up life insurance and money in the bank.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP)--The Reconstruction Finance Corporation said today it was considering a loan of about $75,000,000 to develop a huge copper deposit in Pinal County, Arizona. The agency said the project, if approved, could produce up to 140,000,000 pounds a year of the scarce defense material.

Manhattan has more alcoholics than any other city borough and there should be a screening facility in that borough to sort them out, Magistrate Morris Ploscowe asserted in a report submitted yesterday to the Coordinating Committee on Alcoholism.
Two incoming stage attractions yesterday settled on their New York opening dates, although both have not as yet completed booking arrangements for local theatres.

Cocoa took a long spurt forward yesterday, with 426 lots traded, closing 59 to 72 points higher. Much of the gain was ascribed to the stronger attitude of the British cocoa marketing board, which has steadily advanced its asking price from the equivalent of 26 cents a pound to 28 cents in the last few days and apparently has been able to sell cocoa at each new price.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 5--The head of the Port Washington civil defense auxiliary police is expected to deny before a jury in Nassau County Court tomorrow that he labeled a Sands Point reserve Army major as a leader of a Communist conspiracy in the area.

Arrivals of Scotch whisky in the United States for the first nine months of 1951 are a million gallons above arrivals for the same period a year ago, Harry L. Lourie, executive vice president and Washington representative of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc., said here last night.

Plans for remodeling the fivestory dwelling on lot 18 by 102 feet at 55 East Seventy-fourth Street into apartments of four rooms each tvere announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by Dr. Otto Burchard in a deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. The suites are expected to be ready for occupancy about April 1.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--Price advances affecting hundreds of consumer items, from shoes to wool and cotton fabrics, were made possible today in a regulation issued by the Office of Price Stabilization.

The auction mart has been offering in recent weeks some of the choicest material slated for the block this season, much like other merchandise vying for the Christmas trade. Rare and attractive antiques and art objects, books and furnishings for the collector and homemaker, have been offered in quantity.

Cross--currents were dominant yesterday in the stock market and, on balance, prices just managed to hold the line. Except for the attention accorded some special situations, notably stocks of companies associated with the oil discoveries in the Williston Basin of the Dakotas and Montana, the list presented a sticky appearance.
James E. McDonald, former chief magistrate and special sessions justice, died yesterday in his home at 604 Riverside Drive, after a long illness. His age was 72.

William C. Foster, Deputy Secretary of Defense, called on American and European industrialists last night to make a "full-hearted" effort to get "over the hump" of lagging arms production in the next twelve months. He warned this period might prove "the most dangerous in Western history."

HONG KONG, Dec. 5--After receiving "donations pledges" listed at more than four trillion people's dollars the Chinese Communists have decided to conclude their campaign for public subscriptions toward the purchase of "planes, tanks and guns" for the Korean front.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 5--Nat Holman's depleted City College basketball squad edged Rutgers, 63-61, in a see-saw game in the Rutgers Gymnasium tonight.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. charged yesterday that the Government's proposed order to settle a Federal Court decision that the company had violated the antitrust laws amounted to "confiscation" and was "beyond the power of this court." The charge was contained in du Pont's own proposals for an order to carry out the decision of Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan.

The nation's gasoline stocks gained 778,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they amounted to 112,476,000 barrels, compared with 111,698,000 a week earlier and 109,509,000 a year ago.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP)--Hierarch, considered one of better 2-year-olds early in the season, romped off with the Sainfoin Purse before a crowd of 6,755 at Tropical Park today.

CAIRO, Dec. 5--The Egyptian Government barred all demonstrations, beginning tomorrow, after nineteen more persons were injured in new student disorders in Cairo today. In addition, all schools in Cairo, Alexandria and other localities, and a number of universities were closed for an indefinite period.

The Circuit Court of Appeals agreed yesterday to pass on the validity of the anti-strike injunction issued last Friday by Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman against Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

In writing of the typically winter vegetables, this column has been known to adopt a coaxing, please-try-them tone concerning the hidden qualities of oyster plant, the temptations of the turnip and the excellence of squash. We need go to no such lengths in respect to mushrooms, most readily available, like the others, in the cold weather.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5-Emil Rieve, administrative chairman of the committee on economic policy of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, asserted today that "despite some optimistic statements about the increasing flow of military output, it is clear from published figures that our arms build-up is far behind schedule."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 28:

We welcome heartily Mayor Impellitteri's interest in reorganization of smoke control, as expressed by introduction of two bills drawn at his request by the office of Commissioner Robert Moses, the Construction Coordinator. These bills would set up a Department of Air Pollution Control, headed by a Commissioner "who shall be a mechanical engineer in good standing or shall have equivalent professional training and experience."

CHICAGO, Dec. 5--The general price level will rise not more than 3 to 5 per cent in each of the next two years if the cold war gets no hotter than it is at present, Earl L. Butz, Purdue University economist, predicted today. He addressed members of the American Bankers Association at their annual credit conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The General Electric Company can turn out 20,000,000 "high-reliability" tubes a year by the end of 1953 for military electronics equipment, it was said today by E. F. Peterson, manager of company tube sales, at a meeting with military electronics experts at the Pentagon.

Defense Director Arthur W. Wallander said yesterday that "a lot of people" had told him the city should have another air-raid test like the one held Nov. 28. While he had not planned to hold another, he said, he would do so if public opinion demanded it.

Events today: Gerard Silverman, folk singer, Townsend Harris Auditorium, City College, 12:15 P. M.; "Fledermaus," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; Philharmonic-Symphony, soloist, Jascha Heiftz, violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Carol Smith, contralto, Town Hall, 8:30; Paganini Quartet, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30; Angelo Cafarelli, piano, Mannes Music School. 8:30: Program of...

The "little disarmament conference" now being held in Paris among the Big Four Powers under United Nations auspices has still five days to run, but there is no evidence thus far of a break in the deadlock between East and West --particularly in the crucial matter of control of atomic energy.

The automatic reinstatement of Sandy Saddler, world featherweight champion, was recorded yesterday at State Athletic Commission, throwing a cloak of legality about the Harlem Negro's ten-round non-title bout tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden against Paddy De Marco, rugged Brooklynite.

The idea that "love is a very personal matter" seemed to keynote a symposium held this week at the Museum of Modern Art on the theme of good design. The opinion was expressed by Eve Zeisel, ceramic designer, one of a panel of home furnishings experts chosen to discuss the results of a poll in which selected consumers rated objects in the "good design" exhibition currently at the museum.

BERLIN, Dec. 5--All indications here today were that East Germany would reject any invitation to send representatives to the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly to discuss the proposal for a United Nations survey of conditions for free elections in Germany.
TORONTO, Dec. 5 (Canadian Press)--Daniel Ernest Burritt, general news editor of the Canadian Press, died today at the age of 44. He had undergone a stomach operation Nov. 16.

Confronted by a Bronx contractor "mystery witness" who told of paying graft over a two-year period to Fire Department inspectors involved in "about 400" aircompressor tests made by his firm, four of the eight civilian Fire Department employes on departmental trial resigned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5--All grain futures were strong in the early part of the session here today, but the buying demand became slow on the rallies, while there was considerable hedge pressure indicated in wheat and some in corn, which helped to take the edge off the markets at times. Export business in wheat, corn and sorghums was sufficient to spark the early buying.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 5--Finance Minister Eliezer Kaplan told the Knesset (Parliament) today that the Government's fiscal policy aimed at achieving independence for Israel's economy between 1957 and 1960. He warned of increasing hardships and suffering and "perhaps even shocks" during the interim when foreign aid will be sunk into capital investments and the gap between supply and demand will widen.

Plans to split common stock on a two-for-one basis were announced by Wamsutta Mills in the annual statement issued yesterday by Joseph H. Axelrod, president, announcing record sales for the year ended on Sept. 30.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 5 (AP)-- Delegates to the baseball meetings will vote today on thirty-seven proposed amendments, including one that would establish an "open" classification by which a minor league club could advance to major status.

Wednesday in Korea United Nations ground forces along the battlefront continued to maintain positions and patrol. In the eastcentral sector an estimated enemy company attacked friendly outpost positions but was repulsed following an hour-long engagement. In the west-central sector, two small enemy probing attacks also were repulsed. United Nations reconnaissance elements made only minor contacts with small hostile forces, which were dispersed with the aid of supporting mortar and artillery fire.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 5 --The conditional release of Roman Catholic Archbishop Aloysius Stepinac of Zagreb was announced officially late this afternoon.

Although the proposed entry of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company into the aluminum production field has been stalemated by objections raised by the Department of Justice and the Department of the Interior, the project is still very much alive and retains the support of the Defense Production Administration.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 5-- Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., has been named defendant in a $250,000 plagiarism suit filed in Superior Court in Los Angeles on behalf of Franklin Coen, author. The complaint alleges that "Storm Warning," the film starring Ginger Rogers and released early this year, infringes on a story of the...
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 5--Iran's oil nationalizers fell to quarreling among themselves today, as two Senators resigned in a huff from the oil nationalization board.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 5-- Government policies on controls within the next few months will determine whether American sheepmen liquidate or increase their flocks, William H. Steiwer of Fossil, Ore., president of the National Wool Growers Association, told 1,000 delegates to the annual convention here today.

THOSE who have been unable to line up a guide or blind for the opening week-end of the second waterfowl season that begins at noon tomorrow, and they appear to be legion, will have to move up to the Catskills and chivvy some of the varying hares, which are more plentiful than they have been in years.

Members of New York's hardhit building industry met yesterday with Manly Fleischmann, National Production Administrator, and said later that he had "made solid commitments to reappraise the situation" here.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt. France, Dec. 5--High United States officials at the Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Powers in Europe have redoubled their efforts in the last few days to persuade the British Government to drop--or at least to modify--its long-standing hands-off attitude toward the projected European Defense Community plan.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 5 (AP)--The third Bolivarian Games were inaugurated today in a dazzling spectacle witnessed by thousands of cheering spectators.
MELBOURNE, Thursday, Dec. 6 (AP)--Frank Sedgman, Australia's top tennis player, beat Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, 5-7, 6-2, 11-9, 7-5, to reach the final of the Victorian championships today.

More messages of tribute and sympathy for the death of Edwin L. James, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, came from all over the world yesterday to his, family and his colleagues on this newspaper.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 5 (UP)-- Harry Matthews of Seattle, a top light heavyweight contender, skilfully boxed his way to a unanimous decision tonight over willing but awkward Danny Nardico of Tampa in the ten-round main event of the twenty-sixth annual Toyshop fund boxing show.
The United States Treasury, for the present at least, is somewhat pressed for cash.
American gambling-syndicate bosses--fairly shrewd psychologists who think they have a good line on their 50,000,000 customers and the lawmakers--are lying low in the present anti-gambling blast.
Brooklyn College broke even in twenty-two basketball games last season, and from all indications Coach Morris (Tubby) Raskin's present varsity has the ability to improve on that record.

Asserting that our armed forces were not getting jets, tanks, radar, bomb sights and some other items fast enough, William C. Foster, Deputy Secretary of Defense, said last night his department and the Office of Defense Mobilization were trying to break bottlenecks and get greater production.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 15 points lower to 6 points higher.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5--Asserting that governmental extravagance could produce "complete socialism" as certainly as outright seizure of private business, Senator Robert A. Taft warned tonight that the present pace of Federal spending threatened to turn the people of the United States into "schoolboys" with a little pocket money but no liberty.

St. Nicholas rode through New York yesterday, just as he once rode the lanes of Nieuw Amsterdam, to bring toys and candy to the poor. His flowing robes were a glowing red, his pointed hat trimmed with gold, his beard curly and white. But instead of the white stallion he uses in Holland he rode in a shiny motor car, leaving his mount tethered at the Plaza, Fifth Avenue and Fiftyninth Street.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 5-- The migration conference, representing twenty-three non-Communist nations, wound up its work today with a resolution setting up new organization to take over the work of the International Refugee Organization early in 1952.

Hungary's Communist regime has substantially raised the price of food and clothing and has partly abolished rationing in a sweeping economic reorganization aimed at increasing workers incentives to raise industrial production, the Budapest radio reports.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5-- Dr. Ray B. Westerfield, 67-year-old Professor of Economics at Yale, leveled a surprise attack against the Economics Department of the university in today's edition of The Yale Daily News.

CALGARY, Dec. 5 (Canadian Press)--A reciprocal exchange of natural gas between the Province of Alberta and the United States was proposed here today by R. R. Herring of Houston, Tex., vice president of Prairie Pipelines, Ltd. He spoke before the Alberta Petroleum and Natural Gas Conservation Board which is hearing six applications for permits to export Alberta gas.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 5-- The $2,000,000 libel suit against Frank Hague, former Mayor of Jersey City, was abruptly and unexpectedly settled out of court tonight.

Frank Costello was re-indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for contempt of the United States Senate, growing out of his refusal to answer questions last March before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

DETROIT, Dec. 5--Mrs. George L. Rosenbloom and Sidney Silodor, both of Philadelphia, held the lead today in the American Contract Bridge League's master mixed pair contract bridge championship by 1 match points. The leading pairs and their scores are:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP)-- The Defense Department reported today that United States battle casualties in the Korean war now total more than 101,688, an increase of 805 in a week.
Italian and American-designed resort fashions were shown yesterday by David Crystal and Saks Fifth Avenue at a luncheon in the Empire Room of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

With Johnny Peirson scoring twice, the Bruins sent the Rangers down to defeat in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The New Yorkers also had a two-goal man, Gaye Stewart, in their lineup, but the Boston sextet had the skater who scored the odd goal, Hal Laycoe, on their side.

Alfred G. Vanderbilt, president of Thoroughbred Racing Associations, urged sports not to wait "for Congressional committees" but to learn "what's going on within their houses" in an address at the Hotel Plaza yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 5 (AP)--Baseball's reserve clause survived another test today when Judge Johns H. Druffel of the United States District Court dismissed two cases attacking it. He based his action on the opinion of Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, who, in 1932, held that baseball was a sport and not a commodity to trade or commerce.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5--The backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower are basing their whole campaign to draft him for the Republican Presidential nomination on the conviction that he will relinquish his command in Europe by Feb.1.
Collection of trade waste by private garbage collectors was resumed yesterday after settlement of a strike that piled up refuse here and in Westchester and Nassau Counties for four days.
GREENVILLE, S. C., Dec. 5 (AP) --"Shoeless Joe" Jackson, a prominent figure in the 1919 White Sox world series scandal, died of a heart attack here tonight.

After ten years of frustration, the St. Francis College basketball team came within one shot of defeating N. Y. U. last night at the Second Corps Artillery Armory in Brooklyn. Coach Danny Lynch's tall Terriers got the shot, too, but when Frank Dentico's last-second hook missed the target, the decision went to the Violets, 59-58.

Dress manufacturers in the popular price brackets have begun active sampling for spring, 1952, and initial orders indicate wide acceptance of several type of fabrics and styles, it was reported here yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William C. Chanler of 350 East Fifty-seventh Street and Golden's Bridge, N. Y., of the engagement of Mrs. Chanler's daughter, Miss Evelyn Rogers, to Bronson Winthrop Chanler, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Stuyvesant Chanler of 59 East Ninety-second Street and Rhinebeck, N. Y.

Ranked among the country's top five teams in pre-season polls, St. John's University will face its first test tonight at Madison Square Garden when it opposes Brigham Young of Utah, 1951 Invitation Tournament champion, in the feature game of a collegiate double-header.

Official spokesmen for industry and labor in New York and New Jersey warned Federal defense agencies yesterday that their contract placement policies were causing "serious economic difficulties" in this area.

Directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad declared a dividend of $5 a share yesterday on the preferred stock, payable on Dec. 27, to stock of record of Dec. 17, This is the first dividend to be paid on the stock since the reorganization of the company and it will leave an accumulation of $15 a share. The dividend will be paid out of 1948 earnings.

Gale H. Carter, a director and former vice president of W. R. Grace Co., international industrial and trading concern, and former president of its affiliate, the Grace Line, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, after a long illness.

Dean Rusk, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, was invited yesterday to become president of the Rockefeller Foundation, according to an announcement made by foundation officials here. At a meeting held at Williamsburg, Va., it was decided to extend the invitation to the 42-yearold State Department executive.

Alfred Fromm, head of the Paul Masson vineyards in California, said here yesterday he believed the ultimate future of the American wine business rested on sound wines produced to standards like other American products and sold through sound advertising on a brand name basis.
No major rate increase for the long-suffering passengers of the Long Island Rail Road is foreseen by its new trustee for the next two years.
Thomas Hammond Silver of 277 Park Avenue, president, of the Lumber Mutual Casualty Insurance Company of New York, died Tuesday in French Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 66.

Daniel (Dutch) Lamont, a wealthy shoe manufacturer, onetime owner of El Mono, winner of the $62,400 Widener Racing Handicap in 1948 and described as the "biggest bookmaker in Altoona, Pa.," was under arrest last night on charges of fixing a basketball game.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 5-- Almost at the very hour that George M. Trautman, head of all the minor leagues, formally opened the National Association's annual convention with a withering blast against the evils of radio and television as exploited by the majors, the Yankees today became the first club in the big leagues to admit "seeing the light."

IT'S just a year since the major league owners voted Albert Benjamin Chandler out of office and it must be a couple of months since this reporter promised to write more fully about the stunning inside information which appeared in Arthur Mann's fascinating expose of the Chandler-Durocher incident in his book, "Baseball Confidential." It had been mentioned once most casually and now we have finally gotten around to letting the other shoe drop.

Ballet divertissements were features of the third annual dinner dance of the Ballet Associates of America, Inc., held last night in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria for the benefit of the production fund of the New York City Ballet Company.

WHEN I disembarked," General Bradley said, describing the invasion of Hitler held France in "A Soldier's Story," "Lieut. MacGeorge Bundy of Boston, Mass., reverted to his earlier eminence as the ranking Army officer on board the admiral's flagship." The Army, as usual, was ubiquitous.

A New York company organized to provide regular helicopter service in the metropolitan area was authorized yesterday to begin operations. No definite starting date has been announced, but if the company can prove itself financially capable of operating for a sixmonth period, it will get a fiveyear permit.
Twelve investment banking syndicates competed yesterday for three issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $14,483,000. The awards were as follows:

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 5-- India's international political position as an independent force shunning any open ideological commitments was described tonight by her Foreign Secretary, K. P. S. Menon, as "fundamentally" similar to that of Yugoslavia which, he said, occupied a "unique" status in Europe.

J. Roland Sala, whose sleek dress and sonorous speech help make him a colorful member of the Magistrate's bench, made it clear yesterday that he valued allaround efficiency higher than simple punctuality. Mr. Sala's fitness for the bench has been placed at issue by the Appellate Division, Second Department, because of sixteen alleged instances of tardiness in his appearance in court.

A seven-point program to combat professionalism, subsidization and academic deficiency in intercollegiate athletics was outlined yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference. Urging that college presidents assume personal responsibility for adherence, he also proposed means for enforcing the code.

A shortage of marine engineers and radio operators that is becoming more acute each day has delayed the departure of thirty-four ships from Atlantic Coast ports alone in the last week. Fifteen of the vessels are concentrated in the Hampton Roads area of Virginia and in some cases sailings have been postponed as much as six days.
Underwriting syndicates will offer to investors today new issues of industrial preferred and common stock having a market value of more than $16,000,000. The offerings are as follows:

The Cuba Mail Steamship Company announced yesterday it had purchased a sixth ship for its expanding freight service between New York, Havana and Mexico. The vessel, named the Yucatan, was commissioned yesterday under the flag of the Ward Line, the house name of the 105-year-old company. C. H. C. Pearsall, president of the line, turned over the commissioning papers to the ship's new master, Capt. John Nordscog.

PARIS, Dec. 5--Three new members of the United Nations Security Council will be elected tomorrow. Western circles expect Greece to win in a close contest with Byelorussia for the seat now held by Yugoslavia.

A shuffling of ships that will add two modern luxury liners to the North Atlantic passenger trade and also increase the availability of tourist-class space in 1952 was announced yesterday by Capt. Giuseppe Cosulich, head of Fratelli Cosulich, operators of the Home Lines.
TRENTON, Dec. 5--This is an unusual time for a graduation, but then it was an unusual class that was graduated tonight. The scene, too, was unusual--a state mental hospital.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 5--"Subsidized political housing" and Governmental extravagance in many lines came in for criticism today by state and national realty leaders at the opening of the thirtyfifth annual convention of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards.

A plea of guilty by a Fire Department hero and the resignation of a fifth civilian employe were highlights yesterday at the departmental trial of inspectors charged with accepting graft... in connection with their jobs.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 6--Kurtis R. Froedtert, industrialist, died here this afternoon of a blood clot on a lung. His age was 64.

With testimony by a former fellow-plainclothes man the state rested its case late yesterday in the perjury trial of Patrolman John J. Doyle Jr., 31 years old, of 2039 Valentine Avenue, the Bronx, in Kings County Court.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Curtis of New York and Washington have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Kristin Longfellow, to Francis Bacon Lothrop Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lothrop of Boston.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)-- Leading European exiles said today more than 8,000,000 persons had been forcibly deported from their homes in central Europe-- most of them sent to slave labor camps--under Moscow's orders.
Gambling is something like the porcupine. It bristles with anomalies instead of with quills, but as a social problem is just as dangerous to handle.

American industrial leaders were told yesterday that survival of the free world depends upon spreading the news that the United States has the true revolution, while Soviet Russia is reactionary. If American free enterprise and the American free press are destroyed, the industrialists were warned, all freedoms everywhere will fall.

Cocoa prove an exception to a generally higher commodities market yesterday, cracking 25 to 45 points under pressure that came principally from a single trade house. Futures trading volume amounted to 488 lots.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Higher prices for new passenger automobiles were made possible today by an Office of Price Stabilization order.

Democrats prepared yesterday to go into the Supreme Court in an effort to upset the Republicansponsored revision of the State's Congressional district lines, particularly the alterations in Brooklyn made at the request of John R. Crews, Kings County Republican chairman.

Chinese in New York united last night in an appeal to the United Nations to intervene in behalf of their relatives in the homeland, threatened with torture or death by Communist extortionists, and sought the cooperation of their own people here to frustrate further payments of ransom for these unfortunates.
Christmas trees are a feature of De Pinna's yuletide display. They bring a festive air to the main floor of the Fifth Avenue specialty store, shedding their glamour over counters bright with gifts.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 6-- City officials, school children, members of the clergy and the citizenry tonight joined in a solemn candlelight procession through semi-darkened streets, marking the third annual Nativity scene presentation at Bedford Park.

Throughout many of the hospitals striving to make whole again wounded veterans of our recent wars the healing art of music is being successfully practiced as a supplement to the work of doctors and nurses. The idea of such a benefit for veterans originated five years ago when a lone veteran...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The Wage Stabilization Board ordered today a cut of 13 cents an hour in wage rates at a new jet engine plant of the Avco Manufacturing Company near Bridgeport, Conn. In another decision, the board approved wage increases for employes of twelve copper, lead and zinc companies.

Eastern skiers had a record early taste of sport the first week of last month and enjoyed it until last week-end but will have to bide time before they can ride the slopes and trails again. Usually, the ski season doesn't get under way until the third week of this month, when all facilities officially open on a huge scale.

Ten tremendous years have passed since that terrible Sunday of Pearl Harbor which President Roosevelt described as "a day that will live in infamy." If we are thinking in terms of Eastern standard time we may clock the anniversary of the entry of the United States into the Second World

Bail of $25,000 was set yesterday for Daniel (Dutch) Lamont, 42-year-old Altoona, Pa., manufacturer and bookmaker, who pleaded not guilty yesterday in Felony Court of having bribed a New York University basketball player to fix a game last New Year's Day with Cornell University.

Christmas comes twice a year for some New Yorkers. The extra holiday was celebrated yesterday by several hundred members of the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, where St. Nicholas, patron saint of good girls and boys, had left the makings for the annual festival the evening before.
HONOLULU, Dec. 6--Hawaii will remember Pearl Harbor tomorrow with a special observance in which Vice President Alben W. Barkley and Secretary of the Interior Oscar L. Chapman will take part.

Many of the subscribers are planning to entertain guests at the Christmas party for the benefit of Common Cause to be held this afternoon in the Starlight Roof and Palm Court of the WaldorfAstoria. Mrs. Philip L.B. Iglehart is chairman of the executive committee in charge of the arrangements.
MUNSAN, Korea, Friday, Dec. 7 --Allied truce negotiators reversed themselves today and told the Communists they would be willing to discuss withdrawal of troops from Korea.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 6 (AP)--Hungary issued a 323-page White Book today charging the United States with 157 hostile acts against the Hungarian Communist regime since 1947. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said that the document had been forwarded to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The Communications Workers of America, C.I.O., asked President Truman today to become a candidate for re-election.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 6 (AP)--Six B-36 bombers of the Strategic Air Command, the kind that can carry an atomic bomb 10,000 miles, landed at home today after a 4,984-mile nonstop flight from Africa.

Although defense loans were an unimportant influence, business borrowing from New York banks continued its expansion last week, advancing $78,000,000 to reach $7,651,000,000, the highest total on record.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 6-- Baseball's minor leagues, sitting in the major session of their annual convention, today voted on the second try to wipe out the 24-hour recall of optioned players by major league clubs.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 6--Opening business sessions of the Thirty-fifth annual convention of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards today were turned largely into a rally against socialism and in favor of the preservation of the so-called free enterprise system in this country.

Dr. J. Douglass Sharpe testified yesterday before Surrogate William T. Collins that he had a feeling of guilt in connection with the death of, his wife, Mrs. Josephine Benedict Collins, from an overdose of sleeping pills on Feb. 10.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6--The American Medical Association's House of Delegates, the organization's policy-making body, voted today to take steps to improve the geographical distribution of the nation's doctors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)-- The Government today exempted from price control the services of these licensed theatre ticket brokers whose maximum charges are fixed by state or local law.

Despite Communist acceptance of several conditions laid down by the United Nations the Korean armistice negotiations continue to drag along in a grim sort of Alice-in-Wonderland atmosphere in which the madness of Lewis Carroll's characters has been replaced by Communist effrontery and double-talk.

PARIS, Dec. 6--A United States resolution providing for the continuation and possible expansion of the United Nations program of technical assistance to underdeveloped areas was approved by an overwhelming vote today by the Economic Committee of the United Nations General Assembly. No country voted against the resolution and only the Soviet bloc, Brazil and Burma abstained.

PARIS, Dec. 6--A warning that French military expenditures would be far greater than so far estimated and that considerably more United States financial aid would be necessary was given in a memorandum submitted yesterday to

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6--Reuben O'Brien, who served for thirtythree years as administrator of the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital in New York, died here yesterday in the home of a daughter, Mrs. Esther MacKay, where he had been living since September.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)-- The net income of Class I railroads for October was estimated at $85,000,000 without taking into accont special tax refunds.
MEMPHIS. Dec. 6 (AP)--Admiral William M. Fechteler said today that United States carrier-based planes could rain atomic bombs on any target in the world within 600 miles of the sea.

Part of the Christmas fun in most families is decorating the tree, a business that both the youngest and the oldest members like to have a hand in. Those families that indulge in popcorn or cranberry-stringing bees to provide ornaments for the tree might like to try making some new decorations suggested by various concerns.

The New York Central Railroad ended its direct testimony yesterday morning before the Public Service Commission at a hearing on its petition for increases of 30 per cent on the prices of restricted and unrestricted monthly commutation tickets and 21 per cent on twenty-six-trip multiple-ride tickets.
C.W. (Gus) Benedict of the Whippoorwill Club was re-elected president of the Westchester County Golf Association yesterday at the annual meeting of the organization held at the Hotel Roosevelt.

A month ago the Congress of Industrial Organizations held its annual convention in this city. Several Government officials appeared on the platform, and they came through with the assortment of unctuous platitudes that seem to be reserved for such occasions. All, that is, except one.
The National Child Labor Committee reported yesterday that the employment of children 14 through 17 years old has risen more than 250,000 since the start of hostilities in Korea.

Only 7,117 fans were at Madison Square Garden last night when St. John's finished strongly to defeat Brigham Young, 66--52, and Manhattan conquered Texas Christian, 65--52. The attendance at the season's second college basketball doubleheader was nearly 50 per cent under the turnout for last Saturday night's twin bill.
A port-wide court of industrial justice to enforce longshore cons tracts and eliminate wildcat stoppages was proposed yesterday by the International Longshoremen's Association.

Sandy Saddler, world featherweight champion, who has been casting glances at Jimmy Carter's lightweight crown, will engage Paddy De Marco of Brooklyn, in the ten-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. De Marco, a lightweight who has title aspirations also, will carry an eleven-fight winning streak into the ring.

In his acquisition of another Brooklyn property, Jack Brause, operator, has contracted to purchase the two-story building at 1385 Coney Island Avenue, occupied by Smilen Brothers, dealers in fruits and vegetables.

PARIS, Dec. 6--The Big Four negotiations on global disarmament came to a virtual dead end today. Western diplomats were making it plain that any last hopes for a substantial agreement had flickered out.
Dick Kazmaier, the phenomenal triple-threat star of Princeton, heads The Associated Press AllAmerica football team for 1951, retaining his 1950 honors.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 6--Five thousand Communist-led youths, shouting death threats against Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, fought a wild five-hour battle in the streets today with the police, troops and anti-Red civilians who totaled 10,000.

Columbia University and the American Broadcasting Company have joined forces on a new educational program in television, and it can be heartily commended to viewers interested in a calm and adult discussion of different facets of contemporary life.
ANN ARBOR., Mich., Dec. 6 (U.P.) --Michigan Athletic Director H.O. (Fritz) Crisler today was criticized for "ignoring the school's alumni" by a university faculty member.
Senator James H. Duff, Republican of Pennsylvania, declared last night that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower "is available" for the Republican nomination for President.

PARIS, Dec. 6--A blueprint for the state machinery of a new member of the family of nations, the United Kingdom of Libya, was laid before the General Assembly here today by Adrian Pelt, commissioner for Libya, in his second report to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The Economic Cooperation Administration called Europe's continued dependence on American coal today a "shocking" state of affairs and one that demanded "a change in policy at the highest Cabinet levels in the big coalproducing countries."

The inability of social work to meet its professional responsibility in administering America's welfare programs, costing $12,000,000,000 annually, was attributed yesterday to a scarcity of qualified personnel.

Group shows opening in the gallevies this week have been selected in most cases with an eye to Christmas. Prints and paintings within comparatively modest price ranges have been put to the fore. Special Yuletide efforts have been made, for instance, at Perls, Kleemann, Babcock and in the contemporary section at Milch, as well as at the National Serigraph Society.

PARIS, Dec. 6--Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Noebl Prize-winning director of the United Nations Trusteeship Division, said today he had heard in Europe more criticism of the United States and more anxiety about its policies than ever before.

The State of California will offer for sale an issue of $25,000,000 of veterans' aid bonds on Jan. 9, State Treasurer Charles G. Johnson announced yesterday, The bonds will be dated Feb, 1, 1952, and will be due from 1953 to 1972.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Dec. 1 totaled 821,776 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Six doctors have accepted $6,900 a-year appointments in the Department of Health's pediatric services "under protest because of the salary offered," it was learned yesterday. The supervisory jobs had been vacant for from a few months to three years.

More than 500 persons attended funeral services for Edwin L. James, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, yesterday morning at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street. Mr. James died suddenly last Monday evening at the age of 61.

E.J. Hockenbury, vice president and one of the founders of the American Hotels Corporation of 570 Lexington Avenue, died yesterday in the Polyclinic Hospital, Harrisburg, Pa. He was 72 years old. With Brig. Gen. J. Leslie Kincaid, he founded in 1924 the corporation which today manages fifty-three hotels in this country, Panama and the Dominican Republic.

The ranks of American teeth are being thinned twice as fast as they should be, a dental educator said yesterday, because of false reliance on dentifrices and mouthwashes and the resulting neglect of early diagnosis and preventive care.

LONDON, Dec. 6--To a distinguished British audience Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, gave assurances tonight that his Government wanted to avoid communism, suppress nazism and make partnership in the free world the basis of its policy.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 6--The nation's cigar manufacturing in dustry is being squeezed between frozen prices and rising costs and therefore is in serious need of price relief, Edward J. Regensburg of New York, president of the Cigar Manufacturers Association, said here today.

Underwriting syndicates will offer to investors today new issues of bonds, convertible debentures and railroad equipment trust certificates having a total principal value of $19,900,000. The offerings are as follows:

The Thoroughbred Racing Associations terminated their two-day tenth annual convention with a dinner at the Hotel Plaza last night. The principal speaker was Republican Senator James H. Duff of Pennsylvania, and the recipient of the chief award was C.V. Whitney, owner of the 1951 champion, Counterpoint.

The first transcontinental color television transmission took place two months ago when the Radio Corporation of America sent a fifteen-minute variety show out to San Francisco and Los Angeles, it was learned yesterday.

A $50 cut in the tourist-class rate for steamship travel between New York and Naples and Genoa was announced yesterday by Capt. Giuseppe Cosulich, head of Fratelli Cosulich, managing operators of the Home Lines.

THERE are ordinary rabbits and extraordinary rabbits, the latter known variously as snowshoe rabbits or varying hares, and although it may be necessary to drive 100 miles to the Catskills to find these changelings, the results will be worth the time and effort.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Repercussions from the tax scandals being investigated by a House Ways and Means subcommittee already are being felt by the Internal Revenue Bureau's field personnel.

One of the most beautiful voices to be revealed here in many a moon was heard at Carol Smith's debut recital last night. Her appearance was her reward for winning the National Federation of Music Clubs' l95l contest, and it was well and most enthusiastically attended.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 6--President Truman worked through the day and into the evening on a review of non-defense features of his proposed new budget which, with the addition of military items, is expected to total in the neighborhood of $90,000,000,000, entailing new tax increase proposals.

LAKE CHARLES, La., Dec. 6-- District Attorney Griffin T. Hawkins was ordered to leave the courtroom today after he had interrupted testimony in a newspaper defamation trial by advancing toward the witness and shaking an extended finger in a gesture of warning.
Parents with children preparing for college are among those for whom the United States Office of Education has just brought out a new 248-page publication, "Scholarships and Fellowships Available

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 6 (UP)--Ted Yochum, sprinted to a two-length victory in the featured Port o'Jobe Purse at Tropical Park today, but the crowd of 6,945 fans got its biggest thrill when Skyflare won the fourth race at 65 to 1.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (UP)--Kenneth L. Wilson, Big Ten commissioner, granted "dictator" powers last year, today warned members that he had hired a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent to discover facts "necessary to reinforce confidence in the integrity of our program."

J.B. Herndon Jr., who was elected president of the American Hotel Association yesterday at its annual convention in Miami, urged hotel men present from all parts of the world to search for better methods of solving problems of profitable operation and for a program of economic education for the industry.

One of eight packed cars in a Manhattan-bound Brighton Beach subway train jumped the tracks at 8:19 A.M. yesterday in the Brooklyn tunnel near the approach to the Manhattan Bridge, causing a snarl in service on the B.M.T. division that was not unraveled completely until 4:37 P.M., just before the evening rush.

The Brooklyn College basketball squad rallied in the third quarter to defeat Fort Monmouth, 70--47, in the Kingsmen's gymnasium last night. A 13-point spurt marked the collegians' third session drive.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 6 (AP)-- The Iranian Government today ordered Michael Clark, NEW YORK TIMES correspondent, to get out of the country within forty-eight hours.

George Szell, with Jascha Heifetz as soloist, made his first appearance this season as guest conductor of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. The program was of the tried and true variety, embracing much fine music.

After an ownership of about a month, Harry Horwitz, operator, has resold the twelve-story loft building on plot 50 by 103 feet at 116-18 West Fourteenth Street in a deal negotiatied, by Williams Co., brokers. Mr. Horwitz was rep

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 7--Allied planes went after Communist field guns yesterday in a new Air Force campaign to wipe out an enemy weapon that has been giving United Nations infantry forces in Korea a big headache.

DETROIT, Dec. 6--Official forecasts that the Detroit area faced a steep increase in unemployment were presented to the Common Council today as Mayor Albert E. Cobo announced that he would seek Federal aid for a public works program to provide jobs for the growing army of idle workers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 6--The Filmakers, Inc., producing unit headed by Collier Young and Ida Lupino, has signed a new one-year contract with R.K.O.-Radio Pictures to make three features during 1952. R. K. O. will finance completely the pictures and provide Filmakers with studio space and facilities including the services of technicians.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--During the week ended Dec. 5, member bank reserves increased $316,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Further evidence of rioting, fighting and refusal to work, which brought charges of mutiny against seven soldiers confined to the guardhouse at Fort Jay, Governors Island, was disclosed yesterday at the second session of a general court-martial.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Elimination of the "set-off," under which a prime contractor is privileged to withhold payments on subcontracts as a means of collecting debts or claims due from the subcontractor on other accounts, is being sought by the Small Defense Plants Administration, Telford Taylor, administrator of the agency, announced today.
DETROIT, Dec. 6 (UP)--An 11year-old boy who won $2,805 on horse races last summer was told by a judge how he can boost that amount to $3,500.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 6--President Truman formally accepted today "reluctantly and with genuine regret" the resignation of Dean Rusk as Assistant Secretary of State. Mr. Rusk will become president of the Rockefeller Foundation next June 30.
The Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company introduced yesterday a blended textured, two-level pile Axminster carpet to retail at less than $7.50 a square yard. James

PARIS, Dec. 6--The United States and several small powers introduced a resolution in the United Nations General Assembly today that would censure the Union of South Africa for its policy regarding the neighboring territory of South-West Africa, a former League of Nations mandate.

The stock market yesterday staged its most vigorous rally in four months. Prices were returned to the mid-October rates in a sudden expansion of interest which carried volume to the heaviest since Oct. 23 and raised values from 1 to 3 points.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 6 (AP)--Dick Savitt, who has all but clinched a singles berth on the United States Davis Cup team through his impressive performances in the Victorian tennis championships, will meet Australia's leading player, Frank Sedgman, in the final.

MONTREAL, Dec. 6 (UP)--A detective's 19-year-old son, who quit the Boy Scouts when he was 15 to join the Communist party as an undercover agent, was credited today with helping authorities to cripple Canada's Communist movement.

The first of the 3-cent postage stamps commemorating the Battle of Brooklyn was sold yesterday to the great-granddaughter of the man who bought the first postage stamp ever printed by the United States.
Plans for the construction of a 780-mile natural gas pipeline by the Gulf-Michigan Transmission Corporation have been postponed because of the shortage of steel pipe.

Because of the present type of price controls on merchant importers, an increasing amount of necessary foreign goods is being diverted to Communist countries, the National Council of American Importers was told yesterday at a meeting in the Astor Hotel.

Mrs. Sarah McDade, Tennesseefarmgirl wife of an American G.I., conceded yesterday that the big city has a heart after all. She sailed on the Ile de France after a hectic series of events involving the loss of all her money and an alleged gouging by a cab driver.
The life of an 8-day-old boy, born with reversed intestines, was saved by a dramatic operation at Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital, it was reported by the hospital yesterday to the United Hospital Fund.
Sixteen out of fifty-one fruitcakes now being sold for the Christmas holidays ranked as outstanding in the fifth annual tasting completed yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES' test kitchen.
The Board of Estimate gave the brush-off yesterday to Mayor Impellitteri's plan for a seven-man Transit Advisory Commission to guide the city on higher fares and other transit problems.

Fearful lest college football fall "within the eager clutches of rapidly expanding Federal controls," General of the Army Douglas MacArthur warned last night that the sport must be kept free of governmental regulation or it will become a plaything of politics and a pawn for greedy patronage.

United Nations ground forces along the battlefront in Korea continued to maintain positions and patrol. In the central sector several small enemy probing attacks were repulsed. Elsewhere along the battle line friendly elements made only light patrol contacts as they continued to seek out enemy defensive positions.
The Board of Education voted unanimously yesterday to dismiss teachers who are found to be members of the Communist party or any other subversive groups.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, called on the Senate Subcommittee on Privileges and Elections today to cease investigating his past in the years before he reached the Senate.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 6--More than half, and probably at least two-thirds of the financial claims held by the Western Allies against West Germany for post-war economic aid will be written off, according to present plans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--After a day of arguments, Judge James R. Kirkland announced in the United States District Court today that he would rule next Monday on a motion to dismiss the suit of the Republic of China against Lieut. Gen. P.T. Mow and Col. V. S. Hsiang, former officers of the Chinese Air Force.

DETROIT, Dec. 6--Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan this afternoon on behalf of the American Contract Bridge League presented the Bermuda Bowl, symbol of world contract bridge supremacy, to the team of Howard Schenken, B. Jay Becker, Samuel Stayman and George Rapee, all of New York, and John R. Crawford of Philadelphia.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 6 (AP)--Defending champion Sammy Snead and Tommy Bolt of Durham, N.C., fired 64's today to take the firstround lead in the $10,000 Miami Open Golf Tournament.
LONDON, Dec. 6--J. Edward Bromberg, American actor who came to England six weeks ago to take over a leading part in "The Biggest Thief in Town," was found dead today in his apartment. His age was 47.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--A code of practices for television stations was proposed tonight by the television board of the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters.

A considerable reduction in the volume of "forward buying" is apparent throughout eastern industries, it was reported here yesterday by members of the National Association of Purchasing Agents in leading plants.

The Elliot Import Corporation, a leading importer of Japanese knit gloves, has established a large glove manufacturing unit in Nagoya, Japan, it was announced yesterday by Herman Gross, president. He said that this was the first post-war instance of an American investment in knit glove plant and equipment.

Harold Ross, editor of The New Yorker, sophisticated weekly magazine, died at 6:30 P.M. yesterday in the New England Baptist Hospital in Boston, after undergoing a lung operation. He had celebrated his fifty-ninth birthday on Nov. 6.

City Council President Rudolph Halley struck a blow yesterday against one of the city's traditional practices, the expensive reception to "distinguished visitors," ranging from the heads of foreign governments to defeated pugilistic champions.
In a move aimed primarily to clear clogged side streets, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh will institute a mandatory $15 fine for double parking anywhere in the city after Jan. 1.
Present earnings of the nation's railroads are falling far short of funds needed to carry out the modernization programs necessary to meet the expanding needs of commerce and the national defense.
ALBANY, Dec. 6--The Court of Appeals ruled today that an unborn child who was injured during its mother's pregnancy as a result of another's negligence might sue, after it was born, for damages.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Two methods by which Congress next year might greatly modify or supplant the President's recent rules for withholding official information from the public are now being debated, and they will be closely examined in the scheduled hearings on the problem by the Senate Expenditures Committee.

Neil Colville yesterday resigned as coach of the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League. Offering ill health and the team's poor showing as reasons, Colville's decision will take effect as soon as his successor, Bill Cook, arrives from Edmonton, Alberta.

Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, director of the State Civil Defense Commission, said yesterday that under state law additional defense tests must be held here and in other communities. He asserted that such tests would be aimed at perfecting the work of defense services.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Attorney General J. Howard McGrath ordered a grand jury investigation today into a Chicago lawyer's charge of an attempt to shake him down for $500,000 to obtain a favorable settlement of his tax difficulties.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP)--This year's "wet" corn crop will occasion no special policy changes gin the Government's sales of old crop holdings, Gus F. Geissler, Production and Marketing Administrator, said today.

While Fordham's basketball team fell somewhat short of its anticipated development in winning road performances against Adelphi and Yale, Coach Johnny Bach still feels that he has "potentially a very good club."

PARIS, Dec. 6--The United States suffered its first major setback at this session of the United Nations General Assembly this morning when Greece, the United States candidate, was unable to win election to the Security Council as the successor to Yugoslavia.

It is possible to motor by four different routes across the nation without finding drinking water from a tested source, milk from a tuberculosis-inspected herd, or restaurants that have been subjected to sanitary inspection. This was reported here yesterday at the ...

City Council President Rudolph Halley struck a blow yesterday against one of the city's traditional practices, the expensive reception to "distinguished visitors," ranging from the heads of foreign governments to defeated pugilistic champions.

GLYNDEBOURNE, England, Dec. 6--The Glyndebourne Opera Company has canceled its visit to the United States planned for next summer, because of the death of Fritz Busch, noted conductor, who was to have led the group on its first American tour, it was announced today.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Dec. 6-- Drastic reforms in the operation of the Rockland County Poor Farm and Home at near-by Viola were ordered by the State Department of Social Welfare today in a report filed with the home's board of supervisors.

Singling out black and white for resort wear, Russeks based an entire presentation on this color duet yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. For the beach, crisp acetate (rayon) white as the sunbleached sands, fashioned a brief full jacket with drop shoulders, long voluminous ...
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were quiet and closed 11 to 19 points higher.
MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 6--A Nassau County Court jury awarded an Army Reserve major $1,000 damages today in a slander suit against a Port Washington civil defense official.
CAIRO, Dec. 6--The Egyptian Government today placed the volunteer liberation battalions, farmed to fight the British, under the command of Abdel Meguid Abdel Hakk, Minister of State.

TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 6--William Thomas (Doc) Skinner, photographer and inventor of the Skinner Speed Gun, died here today in his home, 543 Sagamore Avenue, at the age of 69. For thirty years he had been a staff photographer of The New York Journal-American.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6--Active export buying again supplied the motive for further buying of wheat and corn on the Board of Trade here today.
PARIS, Dec. 6--Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden will come to Paris on Dec. 17 to confer with Premier Rene Pleven and Foreign Minister Robert Schuman.

With meat of all varieties in plentiful supply, prices have been reduced for the second successive week on a few lamb and pork cuts. The city Department of Markets, after its weekly survey of retail food costs, also reported that rib roast of beef had declined 7 cents since last Friday, to 89 a pound.

It is often useful to think in terms of truisms; we are inclined to overlook them or take them for granted. The United States is now a world Power, the greatest of all world Powers, we like to feel. But power is not an abstract concept. If the United States did not exercise its power that strength ...
Looking younger than his fifty-three years as a railroader, 74-year-old William Bronson White sauntered out of Pennsylvania Station yesterday afternoon. The handsome six-foot dean of the
DOVER, Del., Dec. 6 (AP)--A stockholders committee refused today to submit voting proxies at the first annual meeting of directors of the newly-organized R.K.O. Theatres Corporation.
A special dividend of 75 cents and a quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, both payable on Dec. 29, have been authorized by directors of American Hard Rubber Company.

This is the time of year when the shadow of Charles Dickens hovers over hearths and homes. But we never expected to have his classic work on the Christmas spirit brought down to the hard realities of twentieth-century industrial life quite so firmly as it has been in a decision by the National
The United States Court of Appeals, it was learned yesterday, has set aside a District Court decision which, in effect, had conceded that a seaman killed in Government service left two widows.

Eight days of hearings on Magistrate J. Roland Sala's fitness for his office ended yesterday with the prosecution calling for his removal from the bench, and the defense attorney urging his exoneration and reappointment. Magistrate Sala's current ten-year term, to which he was appointed by the late Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia, ends Dec. 31.

LONDON, Dec. 6--Prices continued to fall on the stock markets here today for the third day in a row. Selling of British Government securities again was heavy and prices dropped until an hour before the close, when they steadied. Some stocks of the nationalized industries fell 1.

ROME Dec. 6 (AP)--The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization wound up its sixth conference tonight by rejecting a United States proposal to give the United Nations General Assembly "blank check" support on any emergency action for world peace.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The Office of Defense Mobilization headed by Charles E. Wilson has taken over the responsibility of choosing the military items that will get first priority in production.

KRASIC, Yugoslavia, Dec. 6-- Archbishop Aloysius Stepinac, the Roman Catholic Primate of Yugoslavia, who was released conditionally last night after five years' incarceration in Lepoglava prison, defied the Government today to deprive him of his episcopal rank.

Terms under which GeorgiaPacific Plywood Company later this month is expected to acquire the C.D. Johnson Lumber Corporation were outlined in a letter to Georgia-Pacific shareholders by Owen R. Cheatham, president.
Samuel Kass, an associate of Irving (Waxey Gordon) Wexler and called a "top-level underworld narcotics dealer" went to state prison yesterday for a term that might extend to twenty-two years.

Leon Rothier of 435 West 123d Street, basso at the Metropolitan Opera House from 1910 to 1941, died yesterday morning at Sydenham Hospital from complications due to a chronic heart condition. He would have been 77 years old on Christmas Day.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Dec. 6--Dr. Jerohn J. Savitz of 731 Clark Street, president of the New Jersey State Teachers College at Glassboro from 1923 until his retirement in 1936, at one time superintendent of schools here, died yesterday afternoon at his home after a long illness. His age was 85.
