What 400 children from orphanages and settlement houses would do with $5 was a mystery at 10 A. M. yesterday. By noon, however, they had set paradoxical patterns in generosity and thrift.

Ed Danowski, head coach of Fordham football for the past six seasons, has signed a new threeyear contract, it was announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics. Danowski had just completed a two-year contract.

Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, who resigned last Friday as United States Assistant High Commissioner for Germany, charged here yesterday that "too many Germans" were trifling with their country's destiny by "playing hard to get."

LONDON, Dec. 6--Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today that he did not think his Conservative Government could carry out the defense program laid out by the Labor Government that preceded his.

Heretofore concerned with Broadway's managerial phenomena, David Lowe now steps forth as the adapter of "The Ostrich Eggs," the Andre Roussin comedy satire produced in Paris two years ago under the title of "Les Oeufs de L'Autruche." It will also be presented by Mr. Lowe early next season. Roussin's first Broadway effort, "Nina," was introduced Wednesday night.

A small but valuable segment of the vast art collection assembled through many years by the late William Randolph Hearst came up for auction yesterday before an audience of collectors, museum representatives and dealers.

Katharine Cornell opens tonight in her own production of "The Constant Wife" at the National Theatre. The actress-manager will be co-starred in the Somerset Maugham comedy with Brian Aherne and Grace George.

PAGE 1 of the first edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES a century ago said that the Royal Mail steamer Europa had arrived at Boston and indicated that the letters she carried, to be sent on by train, would be delivered just about as quickly as mail is distributed in New York today.
TRENTON, Dec. 7--City Commissioner George W. Page, former warden of the state prison, died today at the age of 67. He had been in ill health for nearly a year.

A funeral service for Harold Ross, editor of The New Yorker, will be held at 4 P.M. Monday in the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Church, Madison Avenue and Eighty-first Street, where, Mr. Ross had said in a note, "things are about as simple as possible." The body will be cremated.

The Los Angeles market has several top houses making readyto-wear fashions, some of whose collections were recently reported in these columns. Currently showing are Don Loper, Howard Greer and Bruce Stuart.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--Average primary market prices declined 0.4 pet cent in the week ended Dec. 4, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, 177 per cent of the 1926 average, was 12.8 per cent above the pre-Korean average (May 24-June 25, 1950) and 2 per cent above the level of a year ago.

Robert R. Young, the railroad executive called to testify for the Government in the investment banking anti-trust trial here, was reminded by Judge Harold R. Medina in Federal Court here yesterday to limit his participation in the trial to answering the questions of counsel.

Both in what it did and the way it did it the Republican-dominated Legislature of the State of New York descended to a low political level Thursday morning when it passed the second of two bills revising the state's Congressional districts.

The president of a North Carolina trucking concern that has garnered at least 412 parking summonses by leaving large trailers on the West Side waterfront was advised yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh to be in Traffic Court Monday with a sizeable wad of bills.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--Wisconsin backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination opened a campaign tonight to impel the general to declare his intentions far ahead of the state's Presidential primary of April 1.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP)--Four golfers tied with 132 at the end of thirty-six holes today in the $10,000 Miami open tournament as par took another beating over the Miami Springs municipal course.

The Federal Maritime Board rejected yesterday an application by the Grace Line for the bareboat charter of two Government-owned Liberty-type vessels for its service between California ports and Venezuela because the steamship company had failed to prove that its use of the ships would be in the public interest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--Highlevel talks by officials of the Department of Defense, the Munitions Board and the Office of Defense Mobilization on the question of "freezing" military weapons at present stages of development for at least a year are nearing a conclusion.
Duke Iversen, out of action with an injured back since Nov. 11, will return to his linebacker position when the New York Yanks take the field against the Chicago Bears at the Yankee Stadium Sunday.
Speculative holders of scarce ferrous metals have started shaving prices to unload inventories before stricter price controls become effective, metal products manufacturers revealed here yesterday.

The belief that another world war can be averted through collective security and the joint efforts of peace-loving nations was expressed yesterday by six senior high school students participating in the weekly Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Max Bregman has purchased the five-story and penthouse building containing offices and apartments at 32 East Thirty-ninth Street from the Bertfried Realty Corporation.
All meetings in Paris. All hours given are Paris time, which is six hours ahead of New York time.

A collision in Times Square between a bus and two taxicabs at 2:20 P.M. yesterday set off a spectacular chain reaction in which nine vehicles were damaged and eight persons injured. Only... one of the victims was seriously hurt.

PARIS, Dec. 7--General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower conferred in succession today first with four leading United States atomic scientists and soon after with two senior United States Air Force generals.

Santa Claus, ice skates and woolen mufflers were remote subjects yesterday--only fifteen shopping days before Christmas--when the mercury pushed up to 65.7 degrees at 2:35 P.M. to surpass by 3.5 degrees the previous high record of 62.2, set in 1932.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7-- Tony Curtis and Piper Laurie will do a modern romantic comedy, "My True Love," as their next costarring effort for Universal-International.

The stock market managed to ride out a late selling drive yesterday that reduced earlier gains but still left prices higher. Some of the railroad issues recently in favor were targets for the final hour offerings and the inability of this division to maintain its previous strength invited some liquidation in other groups.

BUFFALO, Dec. 7--A new generation of American pioneers will be flying atomic-powered space ships to the moon in three and a half hours within the next fifty years, Maj. Alexander P. de Seversky, aeronautical engineer and inventor, predicted today.

It can be said that the performance of Massenet's "Manon" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House was in general livelier, with more energy and drive in it, than any previous "Manon" in our experience of this theatre.

United States Attorney Myles J. Lane suggested yesterday that Gus Hall, Communist party national secretary, be given an additional five-to-seven-year prison term for failure to surrender on his conspiracy conviction.
Surgeons in Los Angeles, Chicago and New York watched on color television yesterday a delicate surgical operation on the heart of a 20-year-old youth performed in Los Angeles.
Conference, United Parents Associations of New York City, WaldorfAstoria Hotel, 10:15 A.M. Luncheon, 12:30 P.M. Speaker: Dr. Willard E. Goslin.
Harold Ross once said that all he knew "about getting out a magazine is to print what you think is good (or as near to your standard as you can get) and let nature take its course."
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 7--The marriage of Miss Monica Dickens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Charles Dickens of London, and a ...
Christmas trade throughout the country is not measuring up so far to expectations. A late shopping spurt may materially change this situation for the better.

Today's new film is "The Strange Door," Universal-International's adaptation of Robert Louis Stevenson's "The Sire de Maletroit's Door," featuring Charles Laughton, Sally Forrest, Richard Stapley and Boris Karloff, at the Criterion.

A chance to spend both Christmas and New Year's on the high seas under tropical skies while cruising down to Rio will be offered to travelers on a twentythree-day holiday cruise of the Moore-McCormack liners Argentina and Uruguay, the line announced yesterday.

An increase from 15 to 20 cents in the tube fares of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company between New York and stations in Jersey City and Hoboken was approved yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington.

The School of General Studies at Columbia University, which specializes in adult education, will be governed by its own faculty beginning with the next semester and thus will become the sixteenth faculty at Columbia to enjoy administrative autonomy.

Barring a sharp change in the world military situation, there will be no public participation in atomic bomb defense tests in New York State before next April, Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, director of the State Civil Defense Commission, told a convention of contractors yesterday.
In the west-central sector of the Korean battlefront United Nations ground forces repulsed several probing attacks as enemy units from squad to company strength attacked friendly outpost positions.
The minor leaguers having ended their Columbus convention, the baseball scene shifts to New York today with the major circuits taking over as they launch into their three-day winter conclave.
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, accused Soviet Russia last night of dealing a "death blow" to the achievement of "enduring security" by free, democratic societies.

The National Production Authority will turn over soon to the Department of Justice for criminal prosecution eight cases involving charges of willful violation of N.P.A. orders, Robert H. Winn, assistant general counsel of the agency, said yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 7--The stock markets were steadier today after the slump of the last three days. Some prices fell slightly in the late dealings when news was received of the Chancellor of the Exchequer's formal request to the banks to restrict credit, but the markets generally were steady at the close.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 8--Rain and snow covered most of the Korean front yesterday, grounding all but a few planes and putting a damper even on patrol action. It was one of the quietest days since the Communists attacked June 25, 1950.

An articulate crowd of 600, which at times bordered on the unruly, filled the auditorium of Public School 54 at Columbus Avenue and 118th Street last night to hear city, state and Federal officials explain how present tenants in the Bloomingdale area on the upper West Side would be affected by the two housing projects planned to wipe out one of the city's worst slums.
St. John's and New York University, rated the strongest of the local college basketball teams, will place their undefeated records on the line at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--The use of political pressure on teachers in North Carolina and the extortion of political "kickbacks" from them through threats of dismissal were protested in a report today by the National Education Association.

The Rev. Damion Smith, 57 years old, a member of the Benedictine Order of the Roman Catholic Church and attached to St. Mary's Abbey, 528 High Street, Newark, died of undetermined causes yesterday morning on a Pennsylvania Railroad train inbound from Chicago.

ALBANY, Dec. 7--Radical changes in legislative procedures to remedy what it described as "undemocratic" processes were proposed today at the annual legislative conference and executive council meeting of the State Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--Personal income in October, spurred by higher income of farmers and wages of Government workers, climbed to the record annual rate of $257,500,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 7--Dr. Neil Carothers, dean emeritus of the School of Business Administration of Lehigh University, said today that this nation's economy was balanced on a shaky foundation "and our greatest danger is not military or economic, but political."
Fact-finding hearings will begin today on the demand by Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., for a forty-hour week on New York's private bus lines.

The 32-year-old woman chief in charge of routing supplies for the Army Ordnance Corps here was arrested yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and charged with attempting to "shake down" a trucking com pany.

NEWARK, Dec. 7--The engagement of Miss Muriel Hecht, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Hecht, to Dr. Herbert B. Silberner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Silberner, has been announced by her parents. The wedding will take place on Jan. 27.

In a battle notable for its absence of primitive fighting, Paddy De Marco, Brooklyn lightweight, last night pounded out a decision over Sandy Saddler, world featherweight champion, in Madison Square Garden before a gathering of 5,635 fans, who paid box-office receipts of $21,926.

When the stock of a corporation is freely and actively traded on a securities exchange, its price in that market constitutes an adequate appraisal of its value, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled last week in one of the most far-reaching decisions of recent years in the field of corporation finance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP)-- The Government has told the Copper Range Company it may write off of its tax bill $28,631,500 of the cost of a huge new northern Michigan copper mining project.
NEWARK, Dec. 7--The most comprehensive investigation of waterfront crime ever undertaken in this area was planned today by Federal and state officials.

VIENNA, Dec. 7--President Klement Gottwald of Czechoslovakia, denouncing former Vice Premier Rudolf Slansky as a Titoist, declared last night that there would be more arrests and another reorganization of the Communist party's Central Control Commission.

With Christmas coming on a Tuesday, the Exchanges about New York are making special plans. The New York Cotton Exchange will be closed on Dec. 24. Moreover, it will shut down trading at 1 P.M. on Dec. 31.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 6 (AP)--The Missouri Pacific Railroad was authorized by Federal Court here today to make back interest payments on its bonds totaling $35,088,575.

Letters went out yesterday from the City and Country School, 165 West Twelfth Street, to some 200 school principals, psychologists, pediatricians and heads of parents groups in the city asking their reactions to the way distribution of identification tags to the city's school children has been handled.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--Mrs. Josephine Foster Black, wife of Hugo L. Black, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, died today at her home in Alexandria, Va., after a brief illness. Her age was 51.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--The Order of Railway Conductors appealed directly to the Secretary of the Army, Frank Pace Jr., today, to join in an agreement to arbitrate the long-standing dispute on the railroads. He has been legally responsible for the operation of the railroads since the Government took them over in August, 1950, to avert a strike.

If there is such a strictly regional thing as Times Square or Broadway or Bright Lights cooking, then probably a relatively new restaurant on West Fifty-first Street, at number 129, is among the best exponents of it.

Charles A. (Chuck) Taylor, 31year-old first-year mentor of Stanford's Pacific Coast Conference champions and Rose Boml nominee, has been acclaimed college football's coach-of-the-year for 1951 by his fellow coaches throughout the nation.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, received a vote of confidence from the members of the Democratic State Committee yesterday. The vote was 256 to 35, with nine committee members absent and not represented by proxy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--The Wage Stabilization Board eliminated today some of the reports required of employers when they give wage increases. Record-keeping requirements were substituted.
Telford Taylor, Small Defense Plants Administrator, told the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday that many small business men had their "backs to the wall" because of materials shortages.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--The Senate Preparedness Subcommittee accused the Air Force and all the armed services today of tolerating a waste of supplies and men enough to "create a profound danger to the finances of the nation."

Negotiations for an international ring battle which would clear title to the world welterweight championship yesterday were launched by the International Boxing Club, at the suggestion of the State Athletic Commission.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Dec. 7-- Hints that the Communists do not hold more than 5,000 Americans of the more than 10,000 reported missing were dropped today by a Chinese Communist correspondent covering the cease-fire talks.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 7--Art took over banking here this afternoon when the brick and marble building of the First National Bank at Main and Lawton Streets became an art gallery. Keys to everything except the vaults were given to the New Rochelle Art Association until 10 P.M. tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7--Bulls had another field day in the grain markets today, with talk of ceiling prices, prospects for wage increases and higher prices for consumer goods, together with export business of a fairly large volume, combining to stimulate broader investment buying, and shorts finding their position untenable.
On Dec. 7, 1851, the cannons boomed, the church bells rang and the whistles of the boats in New York harbor went full blast as Louis Kossuth, Hungary's dauntless exile, stepped ashore at the battery.

PARIS, Saturday, Dec. 8--The French Cabinet, at 5:45 o'clock this morning, invoked its right to ask a vote of confidence to forestall what it feared might be the defeat of the Schuman plan in the National Assembly to which it had been submitted for ratification.
ROME, Dec. 7--The tired statesmen of Western Europe are making an almost desperate effort to infuse new life into two projects they can neither bring into being or let die.
There is promise of saving human lives and abatement of human suffering in the new program of traffic research announced by Cornell University.
CARACAS, Dec. 7 (AP)--Peru, Panama and Colombia won the major track events at today's Bolivarian Games.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 7 (AP) --Bob Blaik, whose Army football career was cut short by the cribbing scandal at West Point, today accepted an invitation to play in the North-South football game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--A Bureau of Internal Revenue attorney testified today that Charles Oliphant, resigned chief counsel of the bureau, had personally intervened in a tax fraud case following a telephone conversation with a man to whom he owed $1,300.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 7-- Creation of a permanent "investigating committee" to look into charges brought against officials of the New Jersey State Congress of Industrial Organizations, was urged here today by Carl Holderman, president, at the twelfth annual convention of the organization.
ROME, Dec. 7--A formal request for revision of the Italian peace Treaty will be made to all the power's concerned tomorrow, or at the latest on Monday.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 7-- Goaded by military insecurity and worried by the possibility that the European army plan may fail, Bonn officials are discussing other methods by which West Germany can contribute to the defense of Europe.

Shortages of boys' tailored clothing may develop in the spring, manufacturers said yesterday. While ample supplies of goods are available, a production bottleneck is forecast because stores have been delaying the placing of orders.

Once again cocoa futures went through spectacular convolutions yesterday, with advances of 65 to 81 points on the Cocoa Exchange. December delivery closed at 29.60 cents a pound and volume was 329 lots of 30,000 pounds each.
The Fifth Avenue Association appealed to the buying public yesterday to cooperate in a campaign to drive "gyp" linen shops out of the Fifth Avenue area.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 8-- United Nations negotiators discussing an armistice in the Korean war offered today to withdraw Allied naval forces beyond territorial waters after a cease-fire, but demanded the right to sail the high seas north of the Thirtyeighth Parallel and hold captured islands offshore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--A shortage of manpower is holding in East Coast ports twenty-three ships already loaded with cargoes urgently needed by friendly countries in Europe, Vice Admiral E. L. Cochrane, head of the Maritime Administration, said today.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday and 3 to 34 points net higher.

The strains and stresses imposed on Western Europe by the Atlantic rearmament effort have been emphasized again by Mr. Churchill, who warns that Britain may be unable to complete its $13,160,000,000 defense program on schedule.

Meyer Berger, in his series of articles just concluded, finds on the basis of his own research and reports from this newspaper's correspondents that "all mankind except the Eskimo has a weakness for gambling."

PARIS, Dec. 7--The United Nations General Assembly today adopted a French resolution holding that it was "necessary" for Italy, whose application had been vetoed four times by the Soviet Union, to be admitted to the United Nations so that she could become a member of the Trusteeship Council.

Preparations for Christmas will be well under way next week among churchgoers of the city. One event will be the formal lighting of thirty Christmas trees in Park Avenue from Thirty-fourth to Ninety-sixth Streets.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP)--Eatontown, away from the races since last January, staged a successful comeback today when he won the Teddington purse at Tropical Park.
Edward Angly of 333 Central Park West, former war correspondent and author, died yesterday of a heart ailment in St. Luke's Hospital. His age was 53.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 7 (AP)--Hopes of the United States to recapture the Davis Cup from Australia took on a brighter hue today as Ted Schroeder of La Crescenta, Calif., and Tony Trabert of Cincinnati won the doubles final of the Victorian tennis championships.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 7--Last week's peaceful coup by Army, Navy and Air Force leaders received constitutional bolstering today in the form of proclamations from King Phumiphol Aduldet, signifying royal assent to the governmental changes made by the group that engineered the coup.
The following is a round-up of items that may be of interest to the homemaker.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 7 (AP) --Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, once Hitler's financial wizard, has told Indonesia that insecurity is the main cause of her difficulties and recommends in a report that the country make full use of foreign manpower and capital.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 7 (AP)-- Baseball's minor leagues ended their convention today by voting for elimination of the ban on talking with high school players and asking the majors for half their radio-television revenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--The Defense Production Administration announced today that it had granted 162 accelerated tax amortization certificates fo new or expanded defense facilities between Nov. 17 and Nov. 23.

Italy's struggle for better economic conditions has brought gradual improvement in her foreign trade, but such basic problems as overpopulation still present serious obstacles to the improvement of general living standards, a round-table discussion brought out yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--No one should shrink from adopting the princess waist line, Robert Trigere of New York told the Washington Fashion Group today.

DETROIT, Dec. 7--A record field of fifty-one contract bridge teams of four this afternoon completed the second session of the 1951 open team championship conducted here by the American Contract Bridge League.

General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit administered a strong rebuke yesterday to David Blair Owen, president of Bradley University, as he suspended penitentiary sentences on three former basketball stars at the Peoria, Ill., school who had taken bribes to fix games.
The city's traditional receptions for visiting foreign dignitaries, including formal luncheons or dinners, were defended yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri.

In a new move to combat corruption in the Fire Department, Commissioner Jacob Grumet announced yesterday that a captain and five firemen would be brought to departmental trial in connection with the alleged false signing of a fire station logbook for Gerard W. Purcell, recently dismissed fireman.

LISBON, Portugal, Dec. 7--A B-29 Superfort with sixteen men aboard crashed five miles off the island of Sao Jorge in the Azores last night, reports from Lages said tonight. Rescue and search ships and planes were mobilized to seek survivors.

TOURISTS planning a holiday trip in Latin America will have to accept their gifts from the somber Reyes Magos, the three Wise Men. And Santa Claus, although he does appear in decorations, plays no real role at all.

Receding for the third successive quarter this year, in contrast to last year's consistently upward climb, industrial profits for the first nine months of 1951 declined 10 per cent from a year ago.

STROUDSBURG, Pa.--Resort owners in the Poconos of northeastern Pennsylvania, appropriately termed a "ski playground for the masses," are eagerly looking forward to the coming winter and a busy calendar of ice and snow sports. In the past six weeks, resort and hotel managers have cleared up brush, cut new trails and slopes and planned many interesting events for the 1951-52 season.

THE place of music in the early days of this nation's history was not negligible, even though it may get little attention from historians. For a voyage of rediscovery you are ...

Drs. Bernard Roswit and Gustave Kaplan, two radiologists associated with the department of radiotherapy, Veterans Administration Hospital, the Bronx, report in the Journal of Radiology that as more experience is gained the nitrogen mustards are establishing themselves as "a truly valuable adjunct" to X-rays in treating inoperable bronchogenic cancer.

At last week's meeting of the American Physical Society in Houston, Drs. Morton F. Kaplon and David M. Ritson of the University of Rochester, N.Y., reported their success in measuring for the first time the life of the neutral meson.

The importance of support from the community for the nation's public schools is being stressed more and more by educators. There is a growing realization that greater cooperation from the citizen and citizen groups is needed to maintain adequate standards in a time of rising costs.

New housing construction and restoration of blighted areas throughout the country during the next decade will strain the usual sources of mortgage financing, according to Aubrey M. Costa, president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, who thinks the building industry would do well to explore the possibility of pension funds for loans.

The hands that Raymond Leizer was born with were blown off by a land mine three years ago in Israel, where he was a Haganah soldier. He gave a piano recital here last week before an audience that had expected to be amazed that a could play at all. When he finished the first piece there was a moment of incredulous silence, then a roar of applause.
A NURSERY rhyme, like a Shakespearean tragedy, can be all things to all people. To the child it is sound and rhythm, joy and sorrow, his first encounter with the excitement of drama.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--The Italian Government formally asked the United States and other signatory nations to the Italian Peace Treaty today to revise the 1947 pact.

The last of the fifteen maritime nations whose signatures were required to ratify the new International Safety of Life at Sea Convention has signed the document, and the regulations will be placed in effect Nov. 19, 1952, it was announced last week by the State Department.

THE camellia is rapidly gaining esteem among both southern gardeners and northern travelers that visit warmer climates between now and March. What is more, it is becoming evident that certain kinds will thrive farther north than was originally realized.

With the exception of aviation gasoline, which is in critical supply in parts of the Eastern Hemisphere, the oil industry has replaced the loss of refined products resulting from the cessation of petroleum operations in Iran.

How much more money should go into the wage envelopes of the 1,100,000 members of Philip Murray's United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O., is being argued out by labor-management committees in Pittsburgh and other major steel center, but not all the pressures ,that influence the negotiators find direct expression at the bargaining table.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8--St. Joseph's College's fast driving attack and strength under the boards proved too much for the City College of New York quintet and the Hawks triumphed, 66-45, in the St. Joseph's Memorial Field house.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 8--The Columbia basketball team scored a 61-41 victory over Amherst before 2,500 fans tonight in Alumni Gymnasium for its third triumph in three starts. The Lions' defense and rebounding gave them the edge as they pulled away steadily in the second half after holding a halftime lead of 23--20.
