He gave a piano recital here last week before an audience that had expected to be amazed that a could play at all. When he finished the first piece there was a moment of incredulous silence, then a roar of applause.
A NURSERY rhyme, like a Shakespearean tragedy, can be all things to all people. To the child it is sound and rhythm, joy and sorrow, his first encounter with the excitement of drama.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8--The Italian Government formally asked the United States and other signatory nations to the Italian Peace Treaty today to revise the 1947 pact.

The last of the fifteen maritime nations whose signatures were required to ratify the new International Safety of Life at Sea Convention has signed the document, and the regulations will be placed in effect Nov. 19, 1952, it was announced last week by the State Department.

THE camellia is rapidly gaining esteem among both southern gardeners and northern travelers that visit warmer climates between now and March. What is more, it is becoming evident that certain kinds will thrive farther north than was originally realized.

With the exception of aviation gasoline, which is in critical supply in parts of the Eastern Hemisphere, the oil industry has replaced the loss of refined products resulting from the cessation of petroleum operations in Iran.

How much more money should go into the wage envelopes of the 1,100,000 members of Philip Murray's United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O., is being argued out by labor-management committees in Pittsburgh and other major steel center, but not all the pressures ,that influence the negotiators find direct expression at the bargaining table.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8--St. Joseph's College's fast driving attack and strength under the boards proved too much for the City College of New York quintet and the Hawks triumphed, 66-45, in the St. Joseph's Memorial Field house.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 8--The Columbia basketball team scored a 61-41 victory over Amherst before 2,500 fans tonight in Alumni Gymnasium for its third triumph in three starts. The Lions' defense and rebounding gave them the edge as they pulled away steadily in the second half after holding a halftime lead of 23--20.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 9--With a further gain of 26,000,000 to 1,527,000 guilders, the Netherlands foreign exchange and gold reserves have recovered more than the year's loss of 600,000,000 guilders and have reached a new high. The Dutch surplus in the European Payments Union of 195,000,000 guilders for November also was substantial.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9--Archbishop J. Francis A. McIntyre accused Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today of "assuming the role of agnostic" and questioned the fitness of the late President's wife to be chairman of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--An Administration move against corruption in government appeared likely tonight as President Truman, returning abruptly from a Key West vacation, scheduled conferences with J. Howard McGrath, Attorney General, and other high Justice Department officials.

PARIS, Dec. 9--Experts are predicting that the sliding wage scale will be one of the first issues the Government will face after discussions upon foreign policy have been concluded. It is felt that the whole future policy on prices and even of public finance will depend on the outcome of the wage debate.

PARIS, Dec.9--The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is prepared to put both money and influence behind projects that contribute to the economic integration of Europe, Eugene R. Black, the bank's president, said in an interview here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec.9--The Committee to Explore Political Realignment, reporting on a ten-week study, declared today that the Republicans would need affirmative help from Southern Democrats to insure defeat of the Fair Deal in the 1952 national election.

Pay very little attention to the ensuing comments. For the production of Somerset Maugham's "The Constant Wife," which opened at the National on Saturday evening, has brought Katharine Cornell, Grace George and Brian Aherne together on one stage and it thoroughly delighted the ladies and gentlemen who attended the first performance.

Production of men's clothing during October reached the lowest point since the depression in the early Nineteen Thirties, according to an analysis of production data by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A. Using men's suits as an index, in October, 1951, the industry operated at 49 per cent of capacity, compared with 99 per cent in the corresponding month last year.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 9 --William R. Meneely, president of the Meneely Bell Foundry in Troy, N.Y., one of the world's oldest and most famous manufacturers of church bells, died here last night at the age of 82. He was spending his twenty-third winter season in St. Petersburg.

An Institute of War and Peace Studies, to examine the impact of international tensions and wars on American society, has been established at Columbia University. It will conduct a series of research projects on the causes of war and on less costly ways of protecting ourselves and our values.

Several specific announcements pertaining to package tours to Europe were made yesterday following the agreement reached at Nice, France, on Monday by eleven members of the International Air Transport Association.

The American Woman's Association Award for Eminent Achievement was presented yesterday to Dr. Martha M. Eliot, chief of the United States Children's Bureau, in recognition of her "spirit of leadership and career of service to others."

Felt is the darling of the day, when it comes to casual fashions. It goes to the country, it stays at home. It may even attend an informal party if properly dressed up with the aid of trimmings and accessories. With this in mind, we offer you a couple of holiday "quickies."

Glittering holiday fashions at budget prices lured career girls into Namm's, Brooklyn, last Friday evening, where an array of evening gowns and separates dramatized the differences in formality of dress.

A clergyman's primary responsibility is to his congregation, Dean Lawrence Rose of General Theological Seminary, Chelsea Square, told twelve priests and a deacon yesterday morning at their ordination in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
TORRINGTON, Conn., Dec.9-- Santa Claus made his first appearance of the year at Christmas Village here today and was greeted by 196 delighted childred.

The "tragedy of our disordered days and our fearful insecurity" will be a "redemptive tragedy if it leads us to the living Christ Whom we now know we need," the Rev. Timothy J. Flynn declared yesterday in the first of a series of Advent sermons at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Legislation that would strip the Traffic Commissioner of his discretionary powers over parking regulations and compel him to prohibit parking on one side of every street in the city forty feet or less in width has been introduced quietly in the City Council. Most side streets are thirty-four feet wide.

Among the many days dedicated to persons and events it is fitting that Human Rights Day, commemorating certain basic principles adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on Dec. 10, 1948, should have its respected place. We cannot take as casually as we used to the fact that we are human and have rights.

SINGAPORE, Dec.9--A request that Prime Minister Churchill make an "unequivocal" statement about Britain's intentions with regard to the political future of Malaya, was made by Dato Onn bin Jaafar, chairman of the organizing committee of the new multi-racial Independence of Malaya party in a party organizational meeting at Port Dickson yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP)--Slammin' Sammy Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., today won the $10,000 Miami open golf tournament with a brilliant 68 in the final round for a five-stroke victory over Chandler Harper of Portsmouth, Va., and E.J. (Dutch) Harrison of St. Andrews, Ill.

Moving at a pace that must have set some sort of world indoor record for baseball conclaves, the sixteen club owners of the two major leagues completed their two-day sessions at the Hotel Commodore yesterday by making it clear they considered the game in no urgent need of changes.
MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 9-- The Payne Whitney Memorial court tennis doubles tournament was won today by Long Island for the first time since 1946.

Park Avenue made its annual gift to New York last night when thirty towering Christmas trees, lining the famous thoroughfare from Thirty-fourth Street to Ninety-sixth, were lighted for the holiday season.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 (AP)-- With an amazing comeback in the final four minutes, the Detroit Lions defeated the Los Angeles Rams today, 24--22, and regained the lead in the bitter division title fight in the National Football League.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Dickson of 580 Park Avenue, formerly of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Shirley, to Samuel William Henry Boyce 3d, son of Mrs. Boyce Jr. of Hamden, Conn., and the late Mr. Boyce. Plans have been made for a February wedding.

Severe demands on a young child before he is biologically prepared to meet them may overwhelm him to such an extent that they distort his future relationship with parents and others, Dr.Phyllis Greenacre, New York psychoanalyst, declared yesterday.

The decision on where New York City shall go for expanding its future water supply is one of the most important now facing the city government. Therefore it goes without saying that the engineering consultant report made public this morning by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey is one of the most important documents that will emerge from that committee.

The Brookhattan-Galicia eleven scored a 1-0 victory over the New York Americans in the first game of an American Soccer League twin bill at Croke Park, the Bronx, yesterday. Dom Mogoglione, new center forward for the winners, tallied on a solo play eight minutes before the finish.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 (AP) --Southpaw Quarterback Frankie Albert engineered two swift touchdowns early in the final period today to give the San Francisco Forty-niners a 31-to-19 victory over the Green Bay Packers in their National Football League game.

A record sales volume for toys, topping $330,000,000 at manufacturers' value and amounting to a 10 per cent increase over 1950, was predicted yesterday by William A. Wenner, president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A. The forecast was made at a board of directors' meeting preceding the association's annual convention, which opens today at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
STUTTGART, Germany, Dec.9 (AP)--Three small states of southwest Germany voted overwhelmingly today to merge into one big state that will be the fourth largest in West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Dec.9--A warning that payments to Chinese Communists in response to extortion demands are unlawful under the Trading with the Enemy Act was issued today by Edward H. Foley, Acting Secretary of the Treasury. Persons who permit themselves to be victimized were reminded that they are subject to maximum penalties of ten years in prison and fines of $10,000.

The problem of Germany throughout the twentieth century has resembled the classical marital dilemma: Europe cannot live with her and cannot live without her. German unification in 1870 started Europe on the road to two world wars; her disunity today could conceivably lead to another one.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 (AP)--The Cleveland Browns, juggernauts of professional football, clinched their second straight American Conference title in the National League today by defeating the Pittsburgh Stealers, 28--0.

A bus and a taxicab collided yesterday afternoon on the lower East Side, with results almost as spectacular as in the similar accident in Times Square on Friday. Twenty-one persons were injured and the bus, the taxi, two other vehicles and the store front of a meat and poultry market were damaged.

Irmgard Seefried, lyric soprano of the Vienna State Opera, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Young, comely, blessed with a voice of decided natural beauty, Miss Seefried made an easy conquest of the capacity audience in attendance.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 9 (UP)-- The Big Seven Conference today banned all post-season athletic competition. The new rule becomes effective next Sept. 1.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9--The bull market in grains gathered momentum the last week, wheat, corn and rye futures moving up to new highs for the season, with all grains showing a marked capacity for absorbing profit-taking sales, which were heavy from time to time.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Dec. 9--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Chew Mickle Jr., formerly of Centreville, Md., of the engagement of their daughter, Anne, to Ensign Albert Layton Register 3d, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Register Jr. of Rumson, N.J.

CAIRO, Dec. 9--The Egyptian Government is considering the possibility of breaking diplomatic relations with Great Britain as a result of the events at Suez, Ibrahim Farag, acting Foreign Affairs Minister, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec.9--The evolution of the recent psycho logical warfare strategy of the United States is a story of unpreparedness and, under the pressure of reverses, of buckling down for a do-or-die struggle against the Soviet Union for men's minds.
A plentiful flow of holiday cheer in Manhattan taverns was assured yesterday when 2,200 unionized bartenders approved a new, twoyear contract.
At 8 o'clock this evening, "The Grand Tour" will begin its travels at the Martin Beck. The pre-Broadway tour was dispensed with in favor of local previews.

After a season's absence from Town Hall during which they engaged in television and concert activities, Josef Marais and Miranda gave one of their very special performances there last night. They had a large audience, and held it easily under their spell.
Carmen Berendsen is a good violinist, and although she made less of an impression Saturday night than she did at her debut last season, the audience applauded happily.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 9--The twentieth all-breed event of the Camden County Kennel Club today produced a best-in-show victory for an imported wire-haired foxterrier, Ch. Wyretex Wyns Traveler of Trucote. The selection by Edward J. Doyle ended a 761dog sho win this city's Convention Hall.

Victoria de los Angeles, Spanish soprano who gave three New York recitals last season, was heard in a program last night at Carnegie Hall that was announced as her only New York recital of 1951-52. It attracted a large audience, which applauded her long and fervently, adding cheers and shouted requests when she came to her Spanish selections at the end.

The principle that television must have an unchallenged freedom to report the news, even if it reflects unfavorably on the advertising sponsor who pays the cost of the news program, has received timely reaffirmation in an unusual incident brought to light by Edward R. Murrow, the Columbia Broadcasting System commentator.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph Summerville Minnis, assistant rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, told his morning congregation yesterday to "read the Bible and not books about the Bible." Dr. Minnis, who also is vicar of the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession in Trinity Parish, said:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9--Was this trip necessary? All along the suspicion was strong that the New York Giants would be going to the City of Brotherly Love just for the ride. For the Browns won at Pittsburgh today to clinch their second straight American Conference championship in the National Football League while the Giants were routing the Eagles, 23--7, before 19,342 at Shibe Park.

The increase in holiday activity was offset by the lack of interest in cold weather goods because of the unusual warm spell, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Some buyers were in the wholesale market here last week taking advantage of excellent opportunities available for special purchases.

The services of the Sidney Hillman Health Center will be made available Jan. 1 to the wives of workers in the men's clothing industry, Louis Hollander, president of the center and manager of the New York joint board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C.I.O., announced yesterday.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 9--The library of the polar regions assembled by Vilhjalmur Stefansson has been placed in the Baker library of Dartmouth College, John Sloan Dickey, president of the college announced today. The collection contains 35,000 volumes, 18,000 pamphlets and many valuable manuscripts dealing with the arctic and antarctic regions.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9--The steel industry was rolling to a showdown on the wage-price picture last week but steel production showed no signs of the backstage strain.
The Norwegian liner Oslofjord left her a Saturday with Thomas Fearnley, Norwegian shipowner, landowner, industrialist, financier, sportsman and philanthropist.

Burlap has lost one-third of its market in the United States this year, mainly as the result of high prices, it was pointed out yesterday by New York importers. Bag manufacturers, the largest consumer of the product, have been able to purchase heavy cotton fabrics at prices considerably under that of burlap.

The Rudder Club's twelfth an-- nual Christmas party, to be held Thursday evening in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, is expected to bring together 1,500 persons from the maritime industry, Vincent J. Griffin, vice president of William Spencer Sons and commodore of the club, said yesterday.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec.10 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 1,093, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A.M., Monday (4 P.M., Sunday, Eastern standard time):

DETROIT, Dec.9 (AP)--Robert L. Lowe, former major league baseball player, died yesterday at the age of 83. He was the first of four men in baseball history to hit four home runs in a regulation nine-inning game.

It is good news that the highest officials of the State Department have decided to press for change in the restrictive provisions of the McCarran Act which govern the issuance of entry visas for foreigners. The application of these provisions has made a mockery of American demands for freer ...

LAST Wednesday morning in the auditorium of Higbee's department store in Cleveland the lights were too bright in my face for me to be able to distinguish individuals in the audience. But I knew that of the 600 persons seated in front of me (595 of them women) a dozen were my relatives and a dozen others were childhood friends. It was nerve-racking.

As the Protestant Church grows in Latin America the region is "penetrated more and more by the light of the Gospel," the Rev. Dr. Marcel Pradervand, executive secretary of the Alliance of Reformed Churches Holding the Presbyterian, System, said yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church of Forest Hills Queens.

National output of machine tools, required for this country's rearmament program is now moving into the mass production stage. About $2,900,000,000 in machine tools will be needed before the end of 1954. These tools are the metal-working equipment required by ordnance, aircraft, tank and atomic energy plants to make the finished products scheduled as future supplies for ...

Dr. Earl James McGrath, United States Commissioner of Education, said yesterday that Jewish culture had become "increasingly a part of the whole American pattern," and that if anti-Semitism "is again to become a threat it will menace the whole of the American people, the whole of American democracy."

With a strike of 3,000 fuel oil and coal drivers set for New Year's Day, union leaders plan to notify city, state and Federal mediators today that they should do their intervening now and not wait until the last minute to plead for postponement of the tie-up.

ALBANY, Dec. 9--The State Defense Council will meet with Governor Dewey here at noon Thursday to discuss means of getting Federal financial aid for state programs of bomb shelter construction and insuring defense workers against injuries.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 9-- For the seventh straight time in this cool-weather season of sailing dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Arthur Knapp today won with his craft Agony.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)-- The Federal Reserve Board today announced a survey to determine whether the tax burden of banks is so high they cannot attract new capital.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Dec. 9-- The marriage of Miss Grace Van Swearingen Alexander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lane B. Alexander, to Joseph Ray Fowler of the Navy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Fowler of Atlanta, took place today in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Charles R. Stires.

Receipt of a cable message indicating that the hitherto unexplored headwaters of the Orinoco River in Venezuela might finally have been reached by an expedition, was announced here yesterday by the American Geographical Society.

The problems of a literary executor, according to Prof. Norman Holmes Pearson of Yale University, are legion and they are generally unsuspected by the author and a surprise to the custodian he appoints to look after his literary remains and reputation upon his death.
DETROIT, Dec. 9--One hundred and twenty contract bridge pairs completed the third qualifying session of the 1951 open pair championship today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec.9--The Dutch are entering the Strasbourg conference of European foreign ministers on a European defense community moderately hopeful that they can win a settlement on something close to their terms, although they foresee many obstacles before the views of the six Governments can be knit into an agreement.
The recital that Friedrich Gulda gave Saturday evening was the only one he will play in New York this year. His program was a good reflection of his training and musical inclinations.

WASHINGTON, Dec.9--Offering reassurance to the public that no sudden world emergency dictated his return, President Truman flew back to Washington late today to give personal direction to the United States negotiators in the deadlocked Korean peace talks and to confer with his principal law enforcement officers about mounting reports of corruption inside his Administration.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 9--American Protestantism was taken to task here tonight by Dr. Walter G. Muelder, dean of the Boston University School of Theology, for failing to champion realistically the rights of the laboring man.

LONDON, Dec. 9--The steadier appearance of the stock markets, which led to some talk of the persistent down-trend being at last halted, has been shortlived owing to the fresh and disconcerting break in Government securities. In this relapse is seen the fact that dearer money as a policy is certainly beginning to work.

MANILA, Monday, Dec.10 (AP)-- Rains from a destructive typhoon sent landslides of lava crashing down the slopes of Hibok Hibok today as the volcano spewed out boiling rock and ash for the sixth straight day.
Several policemen have faced departmental trial and others are awaiting a hearing on charges of altering traffic summonses so guilty motorists could escape fines.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9-- Marge and Gower Champion, who danced their way from night clubs and the musical stage into motion pictures, have been elevated to stardom by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and will be accorded top billing in "Everything I Have Is Yours."

Mayor Impellitteri has refused on three occasions in the last month to sit down with representatives of nineteen civic groups coordinated by the Public Education Association to discuss their views on an appointment pending to the Board of Education, it was charged yesterday.

Presidents of American colleges too often are "stale and inert" be cause the trustees have neglected to provide rewards and incentives that would help to keep faculty members "fresh and vigorous," Charles Dollard, president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, said yesterday. He recommended sabbatical leaves, fellowships and opportunities for leisurely travel.
An important decision in the field of finance has just been handed down by the Oklahoma Supreme Court.

Changes are being made at the top level of the State Department in our diplomatic staff, for the Middle East is a region fast becoming of supreme importance to the United States, where there is need for the best brains and the most expert knowledge. This has been, and still is, fully recognized at the White House, as the new appointments show.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Dec. 9-- The Rev. Frederick W. Weidmann, a member of the Synodical Appeals Board of the Lutheran Church and pastor of St. John's Evangelical Church here, died yesterday at his home, 209 Liberty Street, after an illness of several weeks. His age was 69.

In the current issue of "The Review of Economics and Statistics" Professor M.A. Adelman of M.I.T. has provided us with what in this day and age must be regarded as, if not an intellectual museum piece, then at least as a collector's item.

In its first change of ownership in more than twenty years the six-story apartment house for fifty-five families on plot 110 by 104 feet at 1425 University Avenue, the Bronx was sold by Leo and Florence L. Eiseman and Gerard N. Lemon to the Sidmor Realty Corporation, Morris Friedman, ...

TOKYO, Monday, Dec.10--The United Nations delegates to the Korean armistice talks took a new step today to push negotiations for an exchange of war prisoners simultaneously with the deadlocked debate on true enforcement conditions.
The fortieth annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opened yesterday with 243 donations totaling $40,052.52 already in hand.

The upward adjustment of welfare benefits for members of the International Longshoremen's Association has been completed and will become effective on Jan. 1, Joseph P. Ryan, president of the union said yesterday.

Bill Cook received a welcome present from the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. Coaching the Blue sextet for the first time, Cook enjoyed the glowing sensation of watching his athletes submerge the usually puissant Toronto Maple Leafs, 7 to 2, before a crowd of 12,683, fans.
The Chicago Bears mixed a powerful running attack with a deadly aerial barrage to defeat the Yanks, 45 to 21, at the Stadium yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP)-- Dealers for Studebaker, KaiserFrazer, Packard and Willys-Overland autos must post their ceiling prices tomorrow for all their customers to see.
The number of openings of art exhibitions decreases as Christmas approaches, but there still are many announced for this week.

LONDON, Dec.9--The distribution of Britain's limited labor resources to the best national advantages is now the subject of urgent consideration by a Cabinet committee to which Sir Walter Monckton, Minister of Labor, has made recommendations.

NOW that Shoeless Joe Jackson is dead, there undoubtedly will be crass sentimentalists who will clamor to have the stigma re moved from his name and to get his records restored to the roll's. Many will go to the extreme of urging that he be placed in baseball's Hall of Fame on the strength of his tremendous skills as a ballplayer.

There's already a Christmasy look at the Duvernoy pastry shop, 752 Madison Avenue (Sixty-fifth Street). Display shelves are laden with such festive sweets as petit fours iced with green sprigs of holly, red poinsettias and dark pink candles topped by tiny yellow flames. Bakers have been engaged for some time in the making of the traditional holiday stollen and gaily frosted gingerbread men that are a specialty of the shop.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec.9-- Russian-Swedish trade relations returned to a cash or barter basis at midnight tonight when Sweden's obligations to deliver merchandise to the Soviet Union under the $200,000,000 long-term credit agreement of 1946 ceased.

Unless there is a meeting of minds between Fred Saigh and Horace Stoneham today--and apparently they are as far apart as ever--Eddie Stanky will be playing second base for the Giants again next season, and some one other than The Brat will be managing the Cardinals.

The furniture and bedding industry has shown higher level profits during 1951 than at any other time in its history, according to a study by the United Furniture Workers of America, C.I.O. Profits before taxes in 1951 will total about $201,000,000, compared with $187,000,000 in 1950, the report says, adding that the increase in profits over 1949 was 203 per cent.

President Truman assured the American public that his sudden return to Washington yesterday was not a result of any crisis. "There is nothing wrong, there is no emergency," he said. It was easier for him to come to Washington for his bimonthly talk with the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the President explained, than to have them fly to Florida.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved irregularly within a narrow trading range last week, closing with mixed net changes. For the weekly period ended on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 29 points ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)--A number of Government officials took to the air waves today to counsel the public on the state of the economy.
The special panel of engineering experts retained more than a year ago by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey has recommended the Hudson River as the city's next major source of water supply.

The latest in the long series of jewel thefts from wealthy guests of fashionable New York hotels occurred yesterday morning. This time the hotel was the Savoy Plaza. The victims were a Philadelphai wholesale jeweler and his wife, who lost $15,000 in jewelry and $85 in cash.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec.10-- United Nations fighters and bomblers roamed at will yesterday over North Korea, but Communist jets stayed out of sight.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 9 (AP)-- Thirty-two Opposition Deputies and newspaper editors, who have taken refuge in Iran's Parliament building charging their lives were threatened by "Government gangsters," drafted today a formal protest to the United Nations.

Events tonight: Johann Strauss' "Fledermaus," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman, conductor; Martial Singher, baritone, and the Choral Art Society led by William Jonson, Town Hall, 8:30; Haydn program, Schneider Quartet, Lexington Avenue Y.M. and Y.W. ...

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, predicted yesterday that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower "might very well win" the Republican nomination for President on the first ballot at the party's national convention next summer.

For eleven months of 1951 total advertising in seven New York newspapers showed a decrease from the comparative 1950 figure of 1.02 per cent, according to a tabulation of linage reports. Two standard-size newspapers showed good gains and a third had a fractional gain.

BERLIN, Dec.9--East Germany's surprise acceptance of the United Nations invitation to appear before its Special Political Committee and discuss all-German elections was viewed almost uniformly here today as a mild tactical victory for the West.

Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin declared last night that a truce in Korea would not mean the end of the struggle between a free and a slave world. He asserted that so long as the Soviet Union continued to rebel against moral and international law the free world must guard its frontiers and build its strength.

ROME, Dec. 9-The roving reporter used to go abroad to study the ways of nations. Now he is so busy watching international developments that he hardly has time to survey the local scene. The striking phenomenon of our age is that countries count less and less as separate entities and more and more as pieces in a picture puzzle. National affairs interest the outsider chiefly as they affect one state's relations with other states.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The Atomic Energy Commission is preparing proposals for the exchange with friendly countries of vital atomic information, short of information on how to make atomic weapons themselves, and will put these recommendations before Congress in January.
A preaching mission in eightytwo Army and Navy camps in the United States was started yesterday at a luncheon in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--Demands of the defense production program are so great that there is little hope of increasing allocations of steel to states for the construction of schools, hospitals or highways, mobilization officials said today.

Faced with reductions in the use of critical metals, the toy industry was pledged yesterday to make fullest use of available materials to continue production of quality merchandise that meets play and development needs of the nation's 45,000,000 children.

Mayor Impellitteri made it plain at City Hall last night that he did not intend to seek the advice of groups coordinated by the Public Education Association in filling a vacancy on the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--Frank E. McKinney, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that he had made a profit of about $68,000 in ten months on an investment of $26,000 in preferred and common stock of the Empire Tractor Corporation. The transaction took place in 1946.
JAMES RONALD, a Scotsman now a resident of Connecticut, is a born novelist--which isn't the same thing as saying that he is a distinguished one. He isn't.
Ohrbach's has crowded the racks of its sports shop with exclusives for the budget-minded shopper heading south. A comprehensive group from the collection was shown yesterday morning.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 10 (AP) --Middleweight Robert Villemain of France snapped the twentynine-bout winning streak of rugged Jimmy Cerello of Hoboken, N.J., tonight as he pounded out a unanimous ten-round decision before 2,588 boxing fans.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., Dec. 10 (AP)--Four University of Connecticut students who forced an entrance to the women's dormitory at the State Teachers College here Sunday morning paid for their prank in City Court today.

Top leaders of the American Federation of Labor in this city and state called upon all A.F.L. unions yesterday to "cooperate to the utmost" in any official investigation of crime and corruption on the New York waterfront.

The fact that "there is nothing new under the sun" is again demonstrated in a new exhibit of silk fabrics that will open today at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street. The materials, all modern ones available through decorators at Scalamandre Silks, Inc., 598 Madison Avenune, will be shown through March 1.
Orville C. Sanborn, 70-year-old Town Attorney of Harrison, N.Y., surrendered to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office yesterday on a first degree grand larceny charge.

DETROIT, Dec. 10--Pyramided middlemen's profits cost the Government an overpayment of $305,507,749 in the purchase of spare parts for military vehicles during the fiscal years 1949, 1950 and 1951, the House subcommittee investigating Army procurement was told today.

Women headed by Mrs. J. Lakin Baldridge and Mrs. Robert S. Salant and including Mrs. Walter C. Teagle Jr. and Mrs. David Heath-Eves are aiding plans for the thirteenth annual White Elephant Party, to be held on Jan. 18 in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

Kentucky, which won the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship and the final 1951 Associated Press poll, came out on top again yesterday in the first Associated Press court ratings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--President Truman conferred for more than an hour today with the nation's highest military and diplomatic officials amid continuously optimistic reports that a military cease-fire agreement in Korea might be closer at hand than frontline reports had indicated.

There are few place names on maps of the southern panhandle of Venezuela, out of which comes the Orinoco River. White men don't go there much, except to look for oil along the Colombian border. Indians to the number of ...
PARIS, Dec. 10--In five languages, Representative John Vorys, United States delegate, asked the delicate question today about the United Nations budget: Who picks up the check?

The nation's steel industry is scheduled to surpass all previous production records this week when the 100,000,000th ton this year is poured on Thursday. Never before has that amount of steel been turned out during even a full calendar year.
Cardinal Spellman will spend part of the Christmas season in Korea and intends to celebrate mass on Christmas Day as close to the fighting front as possible.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10--The rise in grain futures continued on the Board of Trade today, although export business was in much smaller volume. All wheat and corn deliveries made new crop highs, and rye extended its recent sensational upturns into new high ground.

MONTREAL, Dec. 10--The engagement of Mrs. June Magor Beckwith of Westport, Conn., to Dr. Claus W. Jungeblut of New York, son of Mrs. Nicholas B. Jungeblut of New York, formerly of Berlin-Wannsee, Germany, and the late Mr. Jungeblut, has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Robert J. Magor.

Buses operated by Nassau Bus Lines, Inc., break down so frequently that company mechanics are too busy to keep up to schedule on periodic overhauls, a Public Service Commission official testified yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 10 (AP)--Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that she believed in immortality, but was not certain in her own mind what form the future life might take.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Dec. 10--The chances that communism will engulf any extensive portions of the Far East are less than a year ago, Vice President Alben W. Barkley declared here today in a review of his recent tour of Korea, Japan and the Philippines.
Both the New York Giants and the New York Yanks of the National Football League had the day off yesterday. Both will begin preparations today for their battle Sunday at Yankee Stadium.

HERMISTON, Ore., Dec. 10 (UP) --A 51-year-old farmer was rescued today after being trapped for eighteen hours in a caved-in well at times buried up to his neck and in danger of being suffocated by crumbling soil.
Edgar Schoen has been appointed to head sales, production and styling for Maynard Suits, Inc., half-sized women's coats and suits.

Just when it looked as if the whole thing would go up the flue along with all the other warm air the baseball meetings had generated, the Giant-Cardinal Eddie Stanky deal yesterday popped to life again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--Representative Cecil R. King, Democrat of California, tonight concluded his subcommittee's examination of Theron Lamar Caudle, former assistant attorney general, who resigned at President Truman's request, with a dramatic denunciation of the one-time official as a man who had betrayed a public trust.

"Faithfully Yours," co-starring Ann Sothern and Robert Cummings, will call it quits after Saturday night's performance, the sixty-eighth, at the Coronet Theatre. A comedy in two acts by L. Bush-Fekete and Mary Helen Fay (Mrs. Bush-Fekete), it is based on Jean Bernard-Luc's play that opened in Paris last winter.

PARIS, Dec. 10--The draft report completed today by W. Averell Harriman, Sir Edwin Plowden and Jean Monnet, the executive committee of the Temporary Council Committee of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, was understood to urge greater defense ...

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 10--The platoon system in basketball--that's the idea Coach Honey Russell, Seton Hall, is experimenting with these days. That the plan is successful is attested by his team's four consecutive victories this season. The Pirates placed seventh today in The Associated Press' first nation-wide poll of the season.

Emil Alvin Hartman, founder and director of the Fashion Academy, a school of design, styling and merchandising at 812 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 57 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10-- The Independent Union of Marine Firemen, Oilers, Watertenders and Wipers reached an "understanding" today with the Pacific Maritime Association, ending a three of delayed sailings of ships from West Coast ports.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Dec. 11 (AP)--Philip Cline, an elderly, retired business man, was reported today to have died in Tsingtao, in Communist China. He was said to have been released from prison before his death.

Berlioz' "L'Enfance du Christ," so long neglected and absent from the repertory that to most of last night's audience, including the writer, it was a novelty, received an admirable performance from the Little Orchestra Society under Thomas Scherman's direction in Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--Mrs. Harry S. Truman and many other figures in Washington's official and social life attended a funeral service this afternoon for Mrs. Hugo L. Black, wife of the senior Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.
LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP)--Algernon Blackwood, author of dozens of novels and short stories dealing with the supernatural, died today after an illness of two months. He was 82 years old.

In "The Grand Tour," which opened at the Martin Beck last evening, Elmer Rice breaks the heart of an enchanting school teacher from Connecticut. Before the final curtain comes down he also breaks the spirit of some theatregoers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The Internal Revenue Bureau reported today $632,363,000 in delinquent taxes were outstanding, including $96,000,000 in payroll taxes deducted from workers' pay checks by employers, but not turned over to the Government. Income taxes accounted for $505,000,000 of the delinquency.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 10--The biggest propaganda agency ever established by the United States in a foreign country will be set up in Federal Germany once this country attains quasi-independence.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh imposed yesterday a record traffic fine of $4,740, on a North Carolina trucking company that had violated the parking regulations by leaving large trailers under the West Side Highway.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 10-- A smooth operation by this community's "professional" Republican organization easily crushed an "amateur" uprising within the ranks of the Town Meeting tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The Federal Reserve Board was asked today to find that the Giannini banking empire had violated the Clayton Act by monopolizing commercial banking in the five-state Pacific Coast area and to order Transamerica Corporation, its parent holding company, to divest itself of control of all but one of its 667 formerly independent banks.
Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett's press conference last week leaves no doubt that the 143-wing Air Force is now a national goal.

Reports that a Korean ceasefire was closer than front reports had indicated were heard yesterday in Washington. However, these received no confirmation from the White House, where President Truman conferred with military and diplomatic leaders.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 10--The Yugoslav Government announced today the re-establishment of the free market for the purchase and sale of industrial and mining products as of Jan. 1, 1952. The Government will continue to fix the prices of essential raw materials and semi-manufactured goods.

PARIS, Dec. 10--Egypt has prepared a note for presentation to the United Nations tomorrow protesting destruction by British troops of peasant homes in the Suez Canal zone, Mohammed Salah el-Din Pasha, Egyptian Foreign Minister, said today.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 10--Gov. Val Peterson named Fred A. Seaton, a Republican, today to the United States Senate to succeed the late Kenneth S. Wherry. Mr. Seaton, who will be 42 years old tomorrow, is general manager of the Seaton publishing group of newspapers and is publisher of The Hastings Tribune.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11--A crop production goal for next year 6 per cent higher than the 1951 yield, which itself was a record, was announced here today by Clarence J. McCormick, Under Secretary of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--Judge James R. Kirkland, in United States District Court, refused today to dismiss a suit brought by Nationalist China to compel Lieut. Gen. P.T. Mow and Col. V.S. Hsiang to account for approximately $49,000,000 advanced to them for Air Force procurement purposes.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec, 10 --Seven Nobel Prize winners for 1951 received their diplomas, gold medals and checks from King Gustav Adolf in the annual presentation ceremony at Symphony, Hall this afternoon.

A brief and simple funeral service for Harold Wallace Ross, founder and editor of The New Yorker, was held yesterday at the Frank Campbell funeral home, Eighty-first Street and Madison Avenue. Four hundred persons, including many members of the editorial and business staffs of the publication, were present.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, named William D. Pawley, industrialist and aircraft plant specialist, today as a "personal troubleshooter" and immediately assigned him to a study of the machine-tool bottleneck plaguing arms production.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, the Stone Webster Securities Corporation and Mitchum, Tully Co. will place on the market today a new issue of 240,000 shares of $50 par value 4.75 per cent dividend convertible preferred stock of the General Telephone Corporation at $50 a share.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday and 25 to 55 points net lower than final prices last Saturday.
Santa would be hard put to match the imagination of the city's great stores in suggesting Christmas gifts for women. Let's take a look at a few glimpsed in a recent whirlwind tour.

Four members of the House of Representatives, a United States Senator and the Duke and Duchess of Windsor were among the 1,732 passengers who arrived here yesterday from abroad on the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth.

A jury of men will begin this morning to hear evidence on charges of grand larceny and forgery against Mrs. Evyleen Ramsay Cronin, 59-year-old, former secretary and personal maid to Tallulah Bankhead.
A biography of Jane Francesca Elgee, who later became Lady Wilde and mother of Oscar Wilde, will be issued by the Philosophical Library on Jan. 7, entitled "Speranza." Horace Wyndham, the ...

As an outgrowth of the investigation of a police practice of altering traffic summonses so that guilty motorists could escape punishment, Commissioner George P. Monaghan transferred a captain and two sergeants yesterday and charged them with failure to safeguard police property.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP)--Dr. Walter B. Lancaster, noted eye specialist and surgeon, died yesterday at the age of 88. Born in suburban Newton, he was graduated from Harvard College in 1884 and Harvard Medical School in 1889.
STRASBOURG, France, Tuesday, Dec. 11--The European Consultative Assembly early today endorsed the formation of a supranational authority to control the projected European army.
A drive by local internal revenue officials to collect more than $80,000,000 of unpaid income taxes, payroll and social security deductions has been under way for three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--When American historians write the annals of the "cold war" era they will record the name of Peter Pospelov among the infamous. He was the man who switched the Soviet propaganda machine away from generalized attacks on the capitalist system and whirled it this year into a virulent campaign of hate against the American people themselves.

Johann Strauss' "Fledermaus," the Metropolitan Opera's standingroom-only hit of last year, had its third performance of the season there last night. Josef Blatt, Vienna-born conductor who has been on the opera's staff for just over a year, made his debut in the pit, leading the experienced cast.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10-- Film business prospects for 1952 are being surveyed by top New York executives of two major motion-picture companies who today began a series of production-planning meetings with their studio heads.

The Federal Trade Commission has issued with final approval the revised trade practice rules of the rayon and acetate textile industry, it was announced simultaneously yesterday by the commission in Washington and the Rayon Yarn Producers Group in New York.

Increased city taxes will be asked in January to expand services and meet the mounting costs of city government, Mayor Impellitteri told a graduating class of 543 policemen and women rookies yesterday at exercises in Washington Irving High School.

Samuel M. Barr, a vice president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, opened a legal battle yesterday in Supreme Court to forestall extradition to Michigan to face charges of conspiring to violate the gambling laws of that state.

Organized labor's Point Four is a welcome complement to the Truman program. The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions is making progress in its efforts to raise a fund of $700,000 to foster trade union activities in undeveloped areas.
A fourteen-story loft building at 313-315 West Thirty-fifth Street and a similar five-story structure at 30 Beekman Street were among Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Dec.10--Albert Weiss and Arthur Glatt of Chicago won the 1951 National Open Pair Contract Bridge Championship early today. They came from behind in last night's fourth and final session and finished four match points in front of the field.

As another bribed basketball player received a suspended penitentiary sentence yesterday from General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan indicated his ten-month inquiry into college sports fixes was far from over.

Reflecting the lack of activity in the early part of November as a result of the wildcat longshoremen's strike that ended on Nov, 9, customs collections here slumped to $27,051,349 last month, compared with $31,764,673 in the same month of 1950.

The guttersnipe quality which Winston Churchill detected in nazism reveals itself also in communism. The Chinese variety of Communists have been working, or attempting to work, a cynical bit of racketeering on the 80,000 Chinese resident in this country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The National Production Authority today backed up its Controlled Materials Plan, by which it exercises authority over steel, copper and aluminum supplies, with a further order under which the agency can channel essential parts to producers of military goods.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 11--Almost total quiet again marked the Korean fronts yesterday, with only brief patrol skirmishes breaking the general silence. It was also the second straight day that no sky fights occurred, although ten Communist MIG jets were sighted just before they raced back toward Manchuria.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 10 (AP)--Dick Savitt took a painful, straight set beating from Frank Sedgman of Australia today in a rainy final of the Victoria tennis championships and promptly was yanked from a singles berth in the inter-zone Davis Cup final against Sweden starting here Thursday.

A test pilot, his jet aircraft disabled 30,000 feet over Long Island, had to make a split-second decision yesterday afternoon. He could bail out and let the plane crash where it might in the thickly populated area or he could stick to the plane and plunge with it into Long Island Sound.

Five years ago today the General Assembly of the United Nations took a step that has meant the difference between hope and despair, between health and sickness, even between life and death, to many millions of the most important people in all the world.

Tulsa's Golden Hurricanes, who defied a Southwestern tradition that the time to run with the ball is only when you can't pass it, emerged from the 1951 football season as offensive leaders among the major college teams.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10--Protests on "inaccuracies" by the Department of Agriculture's crop reporting service in estimating farm crops with detrimental effects on prices to producers were voiced today at the opening sessions of the American Farm Bureau Federation.
The first step in a two-year dredging project that will send deep sea shipping 175 miles into the Venezuelan interior has been taken with the award of the contracts to two American concerns.

A significant debate on the future of Europe has taken place at Strasbourg between leaders of France and Belgium on the one hand and of Germany and Italy on the other. The debate is significant for two reasons.
Three times in the last decade, Frank Cohen, New York industrialist, has been involved in deals with the Government, once coming under the fire of Harry S. Truman.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 11 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 1,094, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A.M. Tuesday (4 P.M. Monday, Eastern standard time):

Manhattan's basketball team, paced by its 6 foot 8 inch center, Junius Kellogg, turned back Wagner, 76 to 55, on the victors' court last night. The triumph was the Jaspers' third in four starts this season.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 10--Recent political developments in Thailand are viewed with considerable misgiving by analysts of the affairs of that country.
Four new rug collections and a decorator workroom are features of the new Kenmore Carpets showroom, now at 208 East Fifty-eighth Street.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 10-- If Santa in his wondrous flight on the eve of Christmas should find one of his reindeer a trifle winded he might reasonably make a stop at the home of Harold A. Nehrbas on Greenlawn Road here.
Veteran Don Richmond, who couldn't hit National League pitching last spring, is the International League's first "repeater" for the batting title in twenty-five years.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10-- Testimony in the Empire Tractor Corporation's bankruptcy case shows that Mr. McKinney purchased 1,000 shares of the company's stock for $1,000 in October, 1946 and sold it back ten months later for $75,000 less a discount of 7 per cent.

The nation's debt limit of $275,000,000,000 may have to be raised in 1952, if the current pace in budget deficits continues. Although the Federal debt is now about $16,000,000,000 short of the limit, the outlook for a sizable deficit by next June when the fiscal year ends and the expectation that a deficit three times as large is likely for the 1953 fiscal year makes a change in the debt limit a distinct possibility.
ALBANY, Dec. 10--The state took in $98,108,749 more in taxes the first eight months of this fiscal year than in the like period a year ago, the State Tax Commission reported today.

PARIS, Dec. 10--The Big Three Western powers and the Soviet Union ended their ten days' disarmament talks today without agreement on any of the basic issues of international control that have divided them since 1946.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 10--Iran has ended her six months' boycott of the International Court of Justice and has agreed to contest Britain's complaint over the nationalization of the properties of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

The Celebrity Opera Company, a group of ten young singers who have been touring for the last two months with small-scale productions of two popular operas, showed New York the first of them, "The Marriage of Figaro," at the President Theatre last night.

EZZARD CHARLES, the unfrocked heavyweight champion, and Joey Maxim, the boss of the cruiser-weight division, will have a return match in San Francisco tomorrow. It's not far enough away. Outer Mongolia would be a better site.

A postage stamp took its place yesterday besides baseball's Dodgers in the affection of Brooklyn's civic leaders. This happened at ceremonies in the Brooklyn Museum on Eastern aPrkway in celebration of the 175th anniversary of what schoolbooks call the Battle of Long Island, but which speakers insisted must logically have no title except "Battle of Brooklyn."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- The Government trimmed another 3 per cent off of its estimate of this year's cotton crop today, indicating production barely large enough to meet conservative forecasts of domestic and export demand until a new crop is produced.
The Port of New York Authority bluntly accused Mayor Impellitteri yesterday of using the "city's naked power" to block the start of construction of the $85,000,000 third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10--The third anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights was marked here today with a radio forum in which high school students called the observance of human rights for all peoples a first step toward the maintenance of world peace.

Increased business volume in display materials and fixtures during the first half of 1952 was predicted yesterday as the National Association of Display Industries completed the first full business day of its market week showing of spring and Easter lines. The four-day trade showing opened at the New Yorker on Sunday.

MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 11-- Twin disasters--a death-dealing typhoon and continuing activity of Hibok Hibok Volcano on Camiguin Island--posed newly complicated relief problems today for the Philippine Red Cross and Government agencies.

ZURICH, Dec. 10--Answering in Parliament last Thursday the demand made over a year ago that the Swiss National Bank resume the public sale of gold, Finance Minister Ernest Nobs disclosed that in the near future the Swiss Federal Council would deal with the motions before Parliament for abolition of the regulations that now curtail trading in the metal on the Swiss home market.

MADRID, Dec. 10--The Spanish Government was understood today to have instructed its newly appointed Ambassador to the Vatican, Fernando Castiella, to open preliminary negotiations with the Papal Secretariat of State as to the likelihood of negotiating a concordat to regulate all questions between church and state in Spain.

Robert R. Young insisted under cross-examination in Federal Court here yesterday that his 1939 publicity campaign against the negotiated underwriting of railroad bond issues was "to get justice for my stockholders and a fair price for the bonds," and was not to ...
With all kinds of new commodities seeking cold storage, the rate of growth of refrigerated warehouse space doubled this year compared with the annual average increase since the end of the war.

A radio series designed to demonstrate by actual case histories how communities have and can solve local problems through selfhelp will be presented over the Columbia Broadcasting System network, beginning Sunday, Jan. 6, from 10:05 to 10:30 P.M.

ALBANY, Dec. 10--Governor Dewey ordered the State Crime Commission today to hold public hearings on gambling, vice and other organized crime in Columbia County, the largely rural area that borders the east bank of the Hudson River south of here.
The scene in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday was not unfamiliar. For the third successive year that ornate room was turned into a giant kitchen.

Joe Lapchick, coach of the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association, told the metropolitan basketball writers at their weekly luncheon meeting at Leone's yesterday that he had offered to resign his post if Madison Square Garden officials felt the coaching was to blame for the Knicks' poor showings.

Sales for income tax purposes tended yesterday to halt any further recovery on the stock market. The session shuttled back and forth and failed to establish any definite course with final quotations about on dead center.

A first-grade class at Public School 126, 75 Meserole Avenue, Brooklyn, won the $2 prize in a cake sale recently and today the $2 is acknowledged as the class' gift to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- Harold Baynton, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Alien Property Office, defended today as reasonable the fees paid to William Siskind, New York lawyer, for legal work for the Government.
Yesterday's cotton crop estimate --considerably higher than the trade had expected--unsettled some commodity markets. Vegetable oils dropped abruptly in heavy trading.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 10 (AP)-- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, played tonight for an audience of 200 a brief part of a wire recording he said was made at a meeting of left-wing leaders mapping plans to wreck the United States war effort by working within labor unions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--Last Saturday evening in Key West reporters assigned to the Little White House there were informed that the President would fly back to Washington Sunday afternoon for conferences with the Chiefs of Staff and representatives of the State Department.

No major change is foreseen in cotton textile prices as a result of the December crop estimate released yesterday by the Department of Agriculture. Buying yesterday in the Worth Street primary market was extremely light, according to leading commission agents, in contrast with substantial purchases of gray goods on Friday.

Lawrulyn Estates, Inc., has sold the taxpayer containing nine stores and a loft at 22-31 West Burnside Avenue, the Bronx, to a client of Howard Rikoon, lawyer. The property was purchased for all cash above mortgages totaling $120,000. Langsam Schiffman were the brokers.

Directors of Canadian Pacific Railway announced a final dividend of 75 cents a common share yesterday, payable on Feb. 29. Dividend payments amounted to $1.75 a share in 1951, against dividend declarations and payments of $1.25 a share in 1950.

Winners of $1,000 in prizes in the building identification contest sponsored by Cushman Wakefield, Inc., in October received their awards from Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. last week in the Municipal Building.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 10 (AP)-- Harold Johnson of Philadelphia finally beat top-ranking light heavyweight contender Archie Moore in their third meeting, taking a unanimous decision in a slow ten-round bout tonight.

PARIS, Dec, 10--Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said today that a proposal made by United Nations experts that his organization could lend backward countries $1,000,000,000 a year was "unrealistic" and could do more harm than good.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- The Government authorized today a 3 per cent increase in ceiling prices for extra, special or optional equipment on automobiles. The Office of Price Stabilization said the adjustments might be made beginning next Saturday.

The country's smaller shipyards, including those on the inland waterways, thus far have been the chief beneficiaries of the Navy's $2,000,000,000 program of reactivation, modernization and new construction that was started early last summer.
CARMEL, Calif., Dec. 10 (UP)-- The Pacific Coast Conference today placed its policing action of college athletes in the hands of its college presidents.

The Reds yesterday traded Pitcher Howard Fox, Second Baseman Connie Ryan and Catcher Forrest Burgess to the Phillies for Catcher Andy Seminick, Outfielder Dick Sisler, Infielder Eddie Pellagrini and Pitcher Nyles Jordan.
Hardware sales have finally turned upward, ending a decline at retail levels that had prevailed in recent weeks, big distributors reported here yesterday.

THE Long Island wildfowlers apparently hit the jackpot over the opening week-end of the second split season, and most of the reports indicated limit bags of blacks, broadbill, an occasional pintail, and a few teal.

Its new high-speed automatic system having doubled its message capacity, the sales forces of the Western Union Telegraph Company were told yesterday by A.K. Mitchell, assistant vice president for sales and services, that the company plans a vigorous advertising and selling campaign for the coming year.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 11--The Communist command agreed today to begin immediate discussion of an exchange of prisoners parallel with negotiations on other conditions for an armistice in the Korean war.

PARIS, Dec. 10--Soviet insistence upon blocking Italy's admission to the United Nations has forced Rome to seek other machinery to revise its 1947 peace treaty with the open support of Washington, London and Paris.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--A report reassuring consumers against charges that certain new chemicals used in or on foods were dangerous was issued today by the Food Protection Committee of the National Research Council's Food and Nutrition Board.

A new group of lamps by the Heifetz Company is now on display at the company's showrooms at 16 East Fifty-third Street. The collection, based on experimental ideas, won prizes in a contest held last year in cooperation with the Museum of Modern Art.

ALBANY, Dec. 10--William L. Pfeiffer, state Republican chairman, cut off today all political patronage from a Republican county chairman who announced Saturday that he would support Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for his party's Presidential nomination.

MIAMI, Dec. 10 (UP)--Sheriff Jack Henderson of Dade County deputized fifty war veterans today in a campaign by Jewish leaders to put twenty-four-hour guards around synagogues to prevent further acts of racial and religious terrorism here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)-- Two Navy commanders announced today they have invented a new mouthpiece for boxers and football players.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP)--J.L. McKnight's Mr. Buster, closing swiftly along the inner rail, raced to a notable triumph in the All American Purse at Tropical Park this afternoon.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 11--Opposition and Government Deputies fought with their fists inside Parliament today while a frenzied mob outside shouted for the blood of the opponents of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh.

Pending approval by the Civil Aeronautics Board, Trans World Airlines early next year will offer coast-to-coast air coach service in Lockheed Constellations for a oneway fare of $99. The present coach charge is $110.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 11 (AP)-- Federal tax liens totaling $60,348.42 were filed in Kansas today against Larry Knohl of Long Beach, L.I., and his wife, Rea, Lynn Brodrick, United States Collector of Internal Revenue for Kansas, reported.
