Only a man with character and an overwhelming pride could take a step like that. The Yankee Clipper has always been a proud man. That's why he was such a great ball player.

HONG KONG, Dec. 11--Diplomatic sources said today that the Peiping Government had continued to ignore representations and other efforts that have been made to obtain the release of Western nationals imprisoned in Red China. Thirty-one Americans are among those known to be in jail, with more than twenty others still reported to be under house arrest.

A recipe that rings a new change on that old favorite, chocolate cake with chocolate frosting, won $25,000 and a model General Electric kitchen yesterday for a 39-year-old mother of two small boys, Mis. S.P. Weston of La Jolla, Calif.
Dr. Angelo Luigi Soresi, honorary consulting surgeon at Greenpoint Hospital, Brooklyn, died there yesterday after a heart attack that followed a recent illness of pneumonia.

Dr. William F. Russell, president of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared last night that the Communists were conducting a tremendous anti-American drive throughout Europe based on new tactics.

District 50 of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers, which has tried to organize people as remote from the coal pits as taxicab drivers and dairy farmers, is now seeking to recruit social workers in this city.

Nearly 500 leaders in industry and the professions attended the fourth annual $100-a-plate dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night under the auspices of the Cancer Research and Hospital Foundations, with headquarters at 101 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn.
Commodities were weak yesterday. Cocoa and vegetable oils took the heaviest losses. Wool dropped moderately. Sugar and coffee moved in both directions.

Dodd, Mead is working on a plan with the Public Trustee in Britain, administrator of the estate of Bernard Shaw, to publish within the next four or five years a definitive selection of the famous playwright's letters.

Joe DiMaggio, whose name for a decade and a half has symbolized the success of the New York Yankees as completely as did that of the late Babe Ruth in an immediately preceding span, has announced his retirement from baseball.
The State of New York borrowed $65,000,000 on serial bonds yesterday to finance roadway improvements and grade-crossing eliminations at an interest cost of 1.39036 per cent.

PARIS, Dec. 11--A $250,000,000 program that by July, 1954, would develop into a self-sufficient relief project for Arab refugees from Palestine was proposed today to the United Nations General Assembly by the U.N. agency caring for these refugees.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 12-- United Nations delegates, negotiating for a Korean armistice, today accepted a Communist proposal for inspection behind the lines by neutral observers during the cease-fire to guarantee that neither side used the truce as a breathing space to build up forces and renew hostilities.
PARIS, Dec. 11--Stressing high corselette belts and crushed cumerbunds, Marcel Rochas shows a small collection for winter sports and Christmas parties.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 (AP)--Two Pittsburgh Steamship Company vessels churned across Lake Superior tonight with the final iron ore cargoes of the biggest peacetime ore-shipping season in history. The D.M. Clemson and the Thomas F. Lynch are due to lock through the Soo Wednesday and on Friday will unload 22,000 tons of ore at Conneaut, Ohio.

Opening at the Booth this evening will be "Lo and Behold!" the Theatre Guild's third subscription offering of the season. It really marks the Guild's second presentation, the other one ("Barefoot in Athens") was put on by the Playwrights Company. An 8 o'clock curtain is announced.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Frank E. McKinney, Democratic National Chairman, predicted today "drastic" action by President Truman in the immediate future to seek out and punish wrong doers among Federal employes
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today another sharp rise in retail food prices, increasing the food index to a new high.

Nearly one-tenth of New York City's expense budget goes to operate the municipal hospital system, with its 300 buildings in twenty-six institutions, 30,000 employes, a nursing staff of 12,000, 2,027 full-time doctors and 7,400 attending physicians from private practice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Two influential Democratic Senators called upon the Administration today to put every pressure on Britain to find agreement with West Europe toward participating in a common European army and an approach at least to economic federation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Attorney General J. Howard McGrath vigorously defended the administration of his office today in the face of growing rumors and at least one published report that he was on the verge of resigning.

The birth of a new and theoretically independent state ought to be a cause for rejoicing; in the case of Libya there is only too much reason for misgivings. Of all the strange (and probably foolish) things done since the war in the name of nationalism the creation of the United Kingdom of Libya takes the prize.

The two-week recovery drive by the stock market met real opposition yesterday in the form of selling for income tax record purposes. Values were reduced from fractions to as much as 2 points in some of the key divisions, while the composite rate showed a drop of 0.75 point.

A veteran civilian employe of the Fire Department, his recollection prodded by Trial Commissioner Albert S. Pacetta, testified yesterday that the head of a Brooklyn air compressor testing concern had told him about paying money to an inspector in the Division of Fire Prevention and Combustibles.

Sterner measures are now being applied in the Third Internal Revenue District, which covers most of Manhattan, to force delinquent Federal taxpayers to liquidate their tax arrears, Collector Monroe D. Dowling said yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11-- Albert V. Moors of New York, president of Moors-McCormack Lines, Inc., arrived here today aboard a company freighter, the Mormacrey, after a westward voyage through the Strait of Magellan to determine at first hand whether his decision to pioneer a new cargo ship route was justifiable. He voiced enthusiasm over the results.

PARIS, Dec. 11--The Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today against almost no opposition two resolutions, chiding the Union of South Africa again for refusing to submit the territory of SouthWest Africa to international authority.

The First National Bank of the City of New York, altering its capital for the first time since 1901, plans a three-for-one stock split by declaration of a 200 per cent stock dividend out of un divided profits. Subject to approval of a two-thirds vote by stockholders, the proposal will be submitted at the annual meeting on Jan. 8.

Television's culture of the box top continues in full flower. Another of the superior video programs for children is scheduled to go off the air on Dec. 23, thereby providing one more illustration of why commercial broadcasting so often behaves the way it does.

PARIS, Dec. 11--Dr. Lothar Bloz, Deputy Premier of East Germany, charged today that the Western Big Three and the West German Government did not want to have Germany unified and had proposed the United Nations inquiry into the possibility of holding free elections as a means of blocking progress toward that end.

Issues of new securities amounting to $88,000,000 will be placed on the market today, including mortgage bonds of a public utility company and convertible preferred stock of a chemical company. The offerings are as follows:
New York Girl Scouts did good deeds this year for 505 community agencies, according to the annual service report issued yesterday by the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York.

Motormen on the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad (Hudson Tubes) were accused yesterday of conducting a slowdown to force the line to lead the way for the rest of the nation's railroads on higher pay and other concessions.

The "little disarmament conference" of the Big Four at Paris has come to an end with some progress toward agreement on further procedure, but East and West remain worlds apart on the fundamental issue of how and when to disarm.

IGNORANT as I am about the quality of the current crop of suspense stories, I find my self without adequate standards of comparison for a proper judgment on "The Paper Thunderbolt" by Michael Innes. The only thing I am certain of is that this is the most exciting novel I have read in years. It is well written, bland, witty, gruesome, preposterous and clever.

The first part of the home to welcome the many extra guests during the holiday season is an often neglected spot; the door. For those who would spice it with seasonal gayety, some new accessories are available. The following, which aim to be attractive as well as practical, are all priced from $5 to $10.

A new calculation of the orbits of the Sun's wandering five outer planets--Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune and Pluto--has been published by the Nautical Almanac Office of the United States Naval Observatory. The 327-page volume lists the planetary positions at forty-day intervals over a 407year span from 1653 to 2060.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Terror is stalking along the Iron Curtain, on both sides. Terror comes wholesale on the Eastern side, but Russia has no monopoly of it. On the Western side, terror is serving the free world in a modest way.
Patrick H. Gorman, advertising manager of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., has been named assistant to E.L. Mabry, president of Vick Chemical Company, affective Jan. 1.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Dec. 11-- Although a majority of deer hunters contend that the shotgun and buckshot provide the most unsatisfactory method of obtaining venison, the states which limit the gunner to this combination have no shortage of deer hunters, as anyone roving the New Jersey pinelands and cranberry barrens during the past two days could testify.

Overriding the opposition of City Council President Rudolph Halley, the Council members approved a resolution yesterday asking Governor Dewey and the Legislature to permit the city to operate lotteries for hospital and medical needs.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11--A Mississippi farm group started a move today to get the American Farm Bureau Federation, the country's largest farmer organization, to support its demand for a higher Federal support on cotton as a result of what was described as the Department of Agriculture's "unfair" treatment of cotton producers this year.

The cost of delivering bulk merchandise has risen 25 per cent in the last three years because of the city's failure to end parking abuses, leaders of trade and civic groups told Acting Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11--Dissatisfied with the progress of the pattern-making wage negotiations in the steel industry, Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., is considering calling the union's 170man wage policy committee to an emergency meeting here next week.

The seven-story office and showroom building on lot 25 by 100 feet at 4 East Fifty-third Street has been sold by the Seventeen Investing Corporation, represented by Kenneth S. Keyes, of Miami, Fla., to investing clients of the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker in the deal.

Nearly sixty years after the time of its composition we were given the opportunity to hear the Lemminkainen Suite of Sibelius at the concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

Two film previews yesterday-- one arranged by the United Parents Associations and the other by the Mental Health Film Board--showed how moving pictures could be used for parent education and to increase community understanding of problems of school and home.

LONDON, Dec. 11--Urgent talks on Britain's financial situation began today when W.L. Batt, head of the United States Economic Corporation Administration mission to Britain, and Richard Austen Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, sat down at the Treasury to discuss what this country needs to carry out its rearmament program and what help the United States is prepared to give it.

PARIS, Dec. 11--Negotiations between the French Government and representatives of its North African protectorate of Tunisia on the latter's demands for internal independence have reached an impasse that may throw the issue into the United Nations, according to authoritative Tunisian sources.

Music that has not been performed since the eighteenth century will be featured tonight in an unusual concert-lecture at Barnard College. The compositions, so obscure that the original scores had to be photostated, were discovered by Dr. Lucyle Hook, Assistant Professor of English at Barnard, who will speak on musical comedy of the period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The Supreme Court ruled today that by refusing to accept advertising from merchants who patronized a competing radio station the Lorain, Ohio, Journal tried monopolize interstate commerce and thus violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

Turnstiles' clicked at a merry pace and the tote boards blinked with added brilliance at the nation's race tracks during 1951 as betting increased 14.3 per cent and attendance rose 14.4 per cent over 1950, a United press survey revealed yesterday.
starring Robert Mitchum, Lizabeth Scott and Robert Ryan, at the Paramount.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 11--Russian military preparations are concentrating on the complete and urgent modernization of the armies in the Soviet Union and the reorganization and re-equipment of the satellite armies in Eastern and Central Europe.

PARIS, Dec. 11--The Western powers said today they would not surrender the atomic bomb on the basis of Soviet promises but issued a new plea for a continuation within the United Nations of a search for a disarmament formula acceptable to both sides.

Mayor Impellitteri's appointments to the five vacancies that will occur at the end of the month in the Court of Special Sessions may "make or break" the efficiency of that court, it was declared last night by Harris B. Steinberg, chairman of the Committee on Criminal Courts, Law and Procedure of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--An inventory control order intended to force 2,000,000 tons of iron and steel scrap from the yards of auto wreckers in the next few months was issued today by the National Production Authority.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The Federal Reserve Board ended its turbulent hearings of monopoly charges against the Transamerica Corporation today after counsel for the Giannini banking chain attacked the board's complaint as a "worthless distortion" and its rulings on evidence as "so arbitrary as to be shocking."

MOSCOW, Dec. 11--The Soviet press advanced the thesis today that the economic effects of the "cold war" were leading Western European countries deeper into inflation and threatening them with bankruptcy. This thesis maintained that the resultant strains were producing heavy new pressures between the United States and its Allies.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 11--Beginning with the academic year 19521953, Yale University will charge undergraduates a blanket fee of $1,600 a year for tuition, board and room and other services. This will be a rise of $185.

Mayor Impellitteri's refusal to see representatives of the Public Education Association's coordinating committee before he fills a forthcoming vacancy on the Board of Education drew fire yesterday from the United Parents Associations and the Citizens Union.

Princeton's football coach, Charlie Caldwell, on hand to join in honoring the Tiger ace, Dick Kazmaier, as recipient of the Heisman Memorial Trophy, offered a program last night at the Downtown A. C. "to eliminate commercialism in sport."

Mayor Impellitteri declined yesterday to assume personal responsibility for blocking the Port of New York Authority's plans to begin construction of an $85,000,000 third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel under the Hudson River.

DETROIT, Dec. 11--The Army has turned over to the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission evidence of possible collusion between builders of military vehicles and parts suppliers to control bidding on defense contracts, the House subcommittee investigating Government procurement learned today.

Children digging into penny banks, an ambassador whose country suffered severely in the last war, a woman whose husband is an invalid--these and many more contributed $11,612.06 yesterday to raise The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund receipts so far to $59,892.83.

Drastic economies by the Hospitals Department of the city could save $14,313,081 a year plus 50,900,000 in the long-range construction program, according to a management survey consultants' report issued yesterday.

The Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges yesterday ruled that freshmen would be ineligible for varsity or junior varsity crews in that organization's regattas in 1952. The decision was taken as the fifteenth annual convention of the Eastern College Athletic Conference opened at the Hotel Biltmore.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11 (AP)-- Argentina's atomic research chief, Dr. Ronald Richter, said today that Argentina was negotiating with a "highly industrialized foreign country" for a proposed interchange of atomic-energy information and materials.

The American Bach Society assembled a group of more than fifty musicians for its third public concert last night at Town Hall. There was a chorus of ten men and thirteen women, a chamber orchestra and a group of capable soloists, all of whom were led by Clifford Richter, who appeared with the society as guest conductor.

FLORENCE, Italy, Dec. 11--Florence is one of many Italian cities which ousted their Communist administrations in last spring's municipal elections. In its long and turbulent history this capital of the Renaissance has always been a kind of city-state, as jealous of its independence as of its unrivaled art treasures.

Sheet price increases announced by two of the leading producers were long overdue, Worth Street commission men said yesterday. It was expected that sheet and pillowcase prices would go up after the cotton report released Nov. 8 by the Department of Agriculture but the increases were deferred because of market conditions at the time.

The Public Service Commission has asked the United States Supreme Court to reconsider its recent ruling upholding the Interstate Commerce Commission's order granting the New York, New Haven Cent and Hartford Railroad a rice in intrastate commutation fares higher than those allowed by the state body.

The anonymous gift of $38,000 from a prominent New Yorker for a chess and checker shelter in Central Park, which has just been announced, grew out of a picture of two old men playing chess on a park bench.

Tallulah Bankhead capped a courtroom performance yesterday that ranged from tears to a stifled guffaw by walking out of the trial of her former maid-secretary after the defense lawyer asked the judge to make Miss Bankhead "keep her mouth shut."

Robert R. Young, the Alleghany Corporation industrialist called by the Government as a witness in the investment banking anti-trust trial here, underwent a fifth day of cross-examination in Federal Court yesterday.
The Yankee Clipper has made his last graceful catch and taken his last cut at the ball.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 11-- Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, declared today that if any segment of the country's economy should adopt in this critical period a philosophy of "I'm gonna get mine," it would impair national security and "bring joy to the hearts of the Communists."

PARIS, Dec. 11--"The revolution, like Saturn, successively devours all its children," said PierreVicturnien Vergniaud, a Girondist Deputy, during the French upheaval, shortly before he was executed by his fellows in 1793.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 12 (AP) --General Headquarters communique 1,095, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday (4 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern standard time):
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11-- Lauritz Melchior is considering an offer from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to return to the screen, which he quit in 1947 after appearing for the studio in "Luxury Liner."

PARIS, Dec. 11--A periodical examination of the defense efforts of the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on the lines of the draft report made yesterday to the Temporary Council Committee was urged today by W. Averell Harriman, United States chairman of the committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Donald R. Richberg, who helped draft the Railway Labor Act twentyfive years ago as counsel for railroad unions, opposed the demand of those unions today for union shop contracts with the railroads.

Women headed by Mrs. Leonard B. Leeming, chairman, and Mrs. Kenneth H. Sheldon, co-chairman, are furthering the success of the Jan. 4th performance of "The Constant Wife," with Katharine Cornell, Grace George and Brian Aherne in the leading roles, at the National Theatre for the benefit of the Grenfell Association of America.

OAK PARK, Ill., Dec. 11--Karla, the oldest Seeing Eye dog in active service, celebrated her fifteenth birthday here today. By commonly accepted measurement in terms of human years, Karla has reached the nineties, but this dowager today belied the weight of the years on her shaggy shoulders and munched daintily at her birthday cake, fashioned of ground meat and cottage cheese and festooned with fifteen hot dogs.

The membership of Television Authority, representing video performers, has adopted a resolution that "strongly advocates" a merger of five talent unions. Two alternatives were adopted, however, in case the five-branch merger cannot be effected.

PARIS, Dec. 11--The French National Assembly gave Premier Rene Pleven a vote of confidence today when it rejected, by 376 votes to 240, a motion to return to committee a bill to ratify the Schuman plan for merging Europe's coal and steel. The Communists and Gaullists were joined by only a few members from the extreme right in asking that the bill be recommitted.

CAIRO, Wednesday, Dec. 12--Egypt decided last night to withdraw her Ambassador to Britain, leaving a diplomat of lower rank in charge, as a result of her dispute with the British Govern ment over the Suez Canal, a Government spokesman announced early today.

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 11 --The year-old plan for pooling the armde forces of six Western European nations and placing them-- initially--under General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower moved nearer to reality today.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 12-- Two air battles were fought over North Korea yesterday, between Sabre jets and enemy Russianbuilt MIG's, and the Communists were on the losing end of both. Two of their jets were "probably destroyed" and two others damaged.

The Advertising Council late this month will begin the celebration of its tenth anniversary in 1952 with a two-page spread in thirtytwo magazines, described as a public service campaign rivaling in size the biggest commercial campaigns.

LONDON, Dec. 11--Viscount Addison, who ended his long career a British politics as Labor party Leader in the House of Lords, died tonight at his home in Buckinghamshire. He was 82 years old and had had three serious illnesses in the last eighteen months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The Bureau of Internal Revenue abandoned today its long-established policy of not recommending criminal prosecution in any tax case where the taxpayer's life or sanity might be endangered if he stood trial.

A protest by the New York Academy of Medicine brought to public notice yesterday an amendment to the New York State Education Law, which, since January, 1951, has caused the omission of all questions dealing with the germ theory of disease from high school Regents examinations.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11--A complete reversal of recent trends occurred today on the Board of Trade here, all grains and other products working substantially lower.

The taxpayer property at 8402 to 84-20 Astoria Boulevard in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased by Jack Brause, operator, from the Abefein Realty Corporation. FarberWittman, Inc., was the broker and the attorneys were Irving Paulson for the seller and Alfred Fayer for the buyer.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 11--The forces of former Mayor Frank Hague were routed here tonight in a special election he and his "Regular Democrats for Clean Government" had requested, to have the voters pass on the question of the Mayor and Council versus the City Commission form of municipal government.

Studies on tuberculosis at the Public Health Research Institute of the City of New York, Inc., have shown a direct relationship between the virulence of the organism producing the disease and its waxy protective cover, according to the tenth annual report of the institute, issued yesterday.
Possible further inflation poses the biggest problem for the $68,500,000,000 life insurance industry during 1952, life company leaders were told yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11--A complete reversal of recent trends occurred today on the Board of Trade here, all grains and other products working substantially lower.

The taxpayer property at 8402 to 84-20 Astoria Boulevard in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased by Jack Brause, operator, from the Abefein Realty Corporation. FarberWittman, Inc., was the broker and the attorneys were Irving Paulson for the seller and Alfred Fayer for the buyer.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11--The Poor Richard Club of Philadelphia presented its silver medal award today to Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in recognition of the "many and significant journalistic accomplishments" of the newspaper's first century.

Dr. Calvin B. Spencer, medical officer in charge of the United States Public Health Service's quarantine station at Rosebank, S.I., will be honored at a dinner tonight in Vincent's Restaurant, 14 Pearl Street, marking his recent promotion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the constitutionality of the "released time" program of the New York City public schools and the state statute under which it was established and administered.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 11--Speedy action to intensify the suppression of the Malayan Communist guerrillas was promised by Oliver Lyttelton, Secretary of State for Colonies, in a press conference here today that marked the end of a twelve-day tour of investigation in Singapore and the Federation of Malaya.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 11 (AP)--Eddie Stanky, fiery Giants' second baseman, signed a two-year contract as manager with the Cardinals today.

The long-sought methods of operating aircraft under all types of weather conditions has stimulated cooperative research in instrument flying by many governmental, military and private agencies, but pilots still have to see the runway for at least a second or two before their plane's ...
The New York Central Railroad Company announced a dividend of 50 cents a share yesterday, payable on Jan. 15 to holders of record of Dec. 26.

BOSTON, Dec. 12 About 1,900 members of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L. voted today to end a three-day walkout here that had sent all except two of thirteen freighters sailing to other ports.

PARIS, Dec. 12 A move by the United States to cut its contribution to the United Nations budget to one-third of the organization's expenditures in 1952 went down in overwhelming defeat today, with only Nicaragua siding with the United States delegation.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 12 At the request of the Office of the United States High Commissioner for Germany, exhibition of the Twentieth Century-Fox feature film "The Desert Fox" is being withheld "until the situation changes," a United States official disclosed today.

The Bankers Trust Company has been appointed fiscal agent, paying agent and registrar for $15,410,000 of New York City Housing Authority 2 per cent bonds (first issue) due serially from Oct. 1, 1952 to 1987.

Continuing to flash their newfound scoring power, the New York Rangers last night did something they had been unable to do in six previous attempts this season. They defeated the Boston Bruins, and defeated them soundly, submerging Lynn Patrick's crew by the count of 6 to 3.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12 The United Artists Corporation has proposed to a leading talent agency a profit-participation production deal involving a number of top stars, which, if carried through, not only would give individual film making a big boost but might conceivably lead to ...

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 13 United Nations forces supported by a tank unit made a sudden raid yesterday against a Communist company defending a hill position to the south of Panmunjom, the site of the cease-fire talks. The Allied troops withdrew after handto-hand fighting when the Reds brought up two more companies.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 12 (AP) The Charlotte News said today that Tom C. Clark, then Attorney General of the United States, had been advised by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of "indiscretions" by Theron Lamar Caudle as United States Attorney in North ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 President Truman conferred secretly today with Attorney General J. Howard McGrath and J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as indications mounted that the White House soon would appoint a special commission to investigate and purge wrongdoers in the Government.
Columbia marked the opening of its home intercollegiate basketball season last night at the Morningside Heights gym with a 50-to-41 triumph over Rutgers.

The payroll of the domestic iron and steel industry during October reached a monthly record of $249,856,000, bringing the total for the first ten months of this year to nearly $2,400,000,000, or more than was paid out in any full year previously, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 Grain future prices had several sinking spells today but met unexpected buying resistance on the declines, with a substantial rally late in the session.

Returning here last night from a six-week diplomatic mission in Europe, Secretary of State Dean Acheson expressed confidence that when the Western world built up enough strength, the Soviet Union would agree to talk peace and disarmament in good faith.

Maj. Honore Joseph Jaxon, 90year-old champion of the Indians and a man whose individualistic habits of living have caused him a wigwam full of trouble, found himself once more out on the street yesterday.

The Public Housing Administration announced yesterday that bids were to be opened on Jan. 15 on new issues of local housing authority bonds totaling less than $150,000,000. The issues to be offered will number between thirty and thirty-five, it was said.
MONTERREY, Mexico, Dec. 12 (AP) Mexico's Olympic jumpers carried off the honors tonight in the touch and out "cooperation test" of the International Horse Show.

Student designs and designers starred in the seventh annual fashion show of the Fashion Institute of Technology last evening. The gala event was held in the auditorium of the institute at 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.
Mrs. Helen L. Massenat, who died July 6, 1949, left a gross estate of $2,211,417, and net of $1,876,516, according to an estate tax appraisal filed yesterday.
Princeton's Dick Kazmaier, the most honored college football player of 1951, turned his back on the professional game yesterday because, he said, it can only offer him money.
ALBANY, Dec. 12 Governor Dewey ended abruptly today the possibility of state cooperation in the request of the New York City Council for legalization of cityoperated lotteries.

Net income of the International Telegraph and Telephone Corporation and consolidated subsidiaries for the nine months ended Sept. 30 increased 45 per cent above the results attained in the corresponding period of 1950, according to the report issued yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 12 The Soviet Union's political game in the Middle East is exceptionally clever as it urges the Moslem masses to push their governments into an attitude ever more hostile toward the West. The pashas, beys and monarchs of that troubled area, ...
An investigation of alleged widespread abuses of parking privileges accorded to physicians has been started at the request of Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh.

B. S. Moss, formerly for many years an active figure in the New York theatrical world, who was a pioneer in bringing motion pictures out of nickelodeons into real theatres, died last night at his home, 983 Park Avenue, from the effects of a heart attack suffered on Sunday. He was 73 years old.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 12 The marriage of Miss Miriam Camp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orton P. Camp of Waterbury, to First Lieut. James Corson Niederman, Army Medical Corps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Niederman of Oxford, Ohio, took place here this afternoon in the chapel of the Second Congregational Church.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) College sports were stanchly defended today by Lloyd P. Jordan, football coach at Harvard.
Though he is one of the busiest and most successful pianists around these days, Alexander Brailowsky seemed as taut as the piano wires at the outset of his recital last night at Carnegie Hall.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 12 The West Germans, suffering from "occupation fatigue," are making excessive demands and becoming intransigent in their dealings with the Western Allies, according to John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner.

The unbeaten St. John's University quintet ran into surprising first-half opposition before downing Wagner College, 63 47, last night at Grymes Hill, S. I. The Redmen held a 27-22 margin at the end of the first half.

URBANA-CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 12 A family of four who answered a blind advertisement offering six months' free rent in return for cooperation in an experiment has just moved into a most unusual home here.
Backed by a set of laudatory out-of-town notices, "Point of No Return," starring Henry Fonda, makes its Broadway debut tonight at the Alvin Theatre at 8 o'clock.

Shareholders of the Jefferson Lake Sulphur Company approved yesterday a proposal for a 100 per cent stock dividend on the $1 par value common stock, of which 355,595 shares are outstanding. The dividend will be distributed Jan. 18 to holders of record Dec. 28.

So far this seems to be the week set aside for enjoyable first acts. In "Lo and Behold!" which the Theatre Guild put on at the Booth last evening, John Patrick has written a neat, original and acidulously amusing first act; and Leo G. Carroll and Lee Grant act it with style and distinction.
PRINCETON N. J., Dec. 12 Princeton's scoring record was broken tonight as the Tigers coasted to an 88-39 victory over Lehigh in Dillon Gym tonight.

BREMERTON, Wash., Dec. 12 (AP) Dr. Robert Benjamin Irwin of nearby Port Orchard, retired executive director of the American Foundation for the Blind, died here today of a heart attack after an illness of four days. His age was 68. He had been blind since the age of 5.
No solution was forthcoming yesterday as seamen aboard the Israeli-flag freighter Yaffo continued their strike here for a second day.

With pretty packaging and clever food combinations, delicacy shops and department stores offer a variety of suggestions on what to give for Christmas. Here are some of the possibilities a delegate from this department found on a recent tour of these establishments; more will appear later this week.

PARIS, Dec. 12 The United Nations General Assembly will make another attempt tomorrow to elect a successor to Yugoslavia on the Security Council. Greece, the United States candidate, is believed to have a 50-50 chance to defeat Byelorussia.

AUSTIN, Minn., Dec. 12 (AP) Jay C. Hormel, chairman of the board of the Geo. A. Hormel Company told stockholders last night that strange and imaginative experiments in the field of livestock production might prove as spectacular as introduction of hybrid corn.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 A new computing machine that "thinks" 20,000 times a second was announced today at a joint meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers and the Institute of Radio Engineers.

The gift of sight was made to a Korean war veteran yesterday through a delicate operation by which a healthy cornea was grafted into his damaged eye. Six years ago he probably would have been doomed to lifelong blindness.
PARIS, Dec. 12. Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, insisted today that the Soviet Union would fully obey a United Nations decision outlawing atomic weapons.

YOU always met interesting people at the Snoods' annual Christmas party for au thors and characters from the year's new books. It was as if she were being offered a tableau of holiday presents, Mrs. Carruthers thought, as she wandered with her saturnine husband from room to room in the extraordinary modern house overlooking Debenture Bay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Producers and fabricators of basic materials lead all others in the grants of accelerated tax-amortization certificates, the Defense Production Administration announced today. Of the total granted by the agency up to Oct. 19, basic material producers and fabricators received 64.7 per cent.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 12 Politics, sports, education, trade unions and industry have been more successful than the Christian church in breaking down racial barriers, Dr. Liston Pope, dean of the Divinity School at Yale University, declared here today.

Men and women grateful for the narrow margin that separates them from want were among the 570 contributors yesterday whose gifts of $13,697.29 brought the 1951-52 total for the New York Times Neediest cases fund to $73,950.12.

Although accidental deaths from all causes have fallen here, the number of motor vehicles fatalities is increasing, according to statistics presented yesterday at the annual meeting of the Greater New York Safety Council at the Statler Hotel.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 13 (AP) Ted Schroeder of La Crescenta, Calif., and Tony Trabert swept the United States Davis Cup team into a 2-0 lead in the interzone final today against Sweden, each winning his singles match in straight sets.
The double-header, an established institution in baseball and basketball, now is invading track and field.

The first New York showing of the Indonesian-inspired fashions by Lotte of Drewyn took place yesterday at a luncheon in the Pierre Hotel. The Republic of Indonesia's first Ambassador to the United States, Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo, who instigated the fashion promotion last spring, was guest of honor.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $10,158,520 in the quarter ended on Oct. 31, after deducting $17,300,000 for income and excess-profits taxes, the report revealed yesterday.

JOE DiMAGGIO confessed at his farewell press conference the other day that the high spot of his career was his fifty-six-game hitting streak in 1941. It almost had to be, because it's a major league record which may never be broken.

Like many another housekeeper, New York was forcefully reminded yesterday of the rising cost of living. The opening of bids for the proposed vertical lift bridge between Queens and Welfare Island produced a low offer of $6,434,900. The advance estimate had been $4,615,745.
Sara Kaufman, who gave a recital last night in Town Hall, is a mezzo-soprano of considerable vocal endowment matched to a stylistic sense that is somewhat less than infallible.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Henry W. Grunewald, who may be a key witness in a House Ways and Means subcommittee's investigation of tax scandals, refused to answer any questions this afternoon when members of the subcommittee visited him in a Washington hospital where he was under treatment.
PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP) South Africa recalled her chief delegate to the United Nations tonight for consultations on the touchy question of trusteeship for South-West Africa.
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady, 16 to 53 points net higher on the active months, yesterday.

Public utility and railroad companies raised more than $33,000,000 yesterday by the sale of new issues of bonds, stock and equipment trust certificates at competitive bidding. The awards were as follows:
Coffee, sugar and tin sagged in futures trading yesterday but cocoa, wool and cottonseed oil were firm. It was a day without noteworthy features.

Twelve-year-old Owen Seitel, who has to pay as much attention to drawing his breath as the average boy pays to tying his shoelaces, went home to Brooklyn yesterday to carry on his long fight against polio.

The New York State horse racing season will open on April 1 and continue through Nov. 15, 1952. The dates, released by the New York State Racing Commission yesterday, embrace the maximum period permitted by law, and the total number of racing days, amounting to 197, will be the largest in recent years.

The notorious practice in the State Legislature of introducing and passing bills at the last moment before adjournment has come in for some serious and thoughtful criticism at the hands of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The penetration of Soviet communism in troubled France is regarded by some American officials almost as gravely as the German military campaign that overwhelmed France in 1940.

The Korean armistice negotiations now enter their decisive stage with the simultaneous consideration of two issues that provide the final test of the Communists' intentions. These issues are adequate supervision of the armistice terms and a fair exchange of prisoners.

In Korea yesterday (Wednesday) ground elements of the United Nations Command continued to adjust and maintain their positions and operate patrols. A limited-objective atack by our forces was met with considerable enemy opposition on the western front. Elsewhere along the line, patrols reported only minor enemy contacts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 5.

A procedural reform that is expected to reduce drastically the waiting time for the trial of negligence and personal injury cases has been ordered by the Appellate Division of the First Department to go into effect on Jan. 1.
The stock market continued yesterday to set a lower pattern, although some progress on the recovery side showed in a few of the key divisions.

A warning, that lagging Christmas seal sales in Manhattan threaten the year-round program of prevention and control of tuberculosis was sounded yesterday by Myron I. Borg Jr., chairman of the forty-fifth annual seal campaign.

Within the next ten years the development of transsonic airplanes will turn out to be the greatest impetus to the American standard of living yet seen, according to predictions of Harold W. Sweatt, president of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company.
The cautiousness with which Egypt has been approaching a break with Britain over the Suez Canal is encouraging.
THE first big sailfish run of the season has arrived off the mouth of the St. Lucie River at Stuart, Fla., which is one of the greatest concentration points for the Atlantic sailfish.

Defense lawyers in the investment banking anti-trust trial finished cross-examination yesterday of Robert R. Young, the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway chairman called by the Government to testify in support of monopoly-conspiracy charges against seventeen banking houses.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur called yesterday for the reviving of religious motivations in our national household to stem a rising moral deterioration in its political management. He warned against indifference to baseness and weakness in public stewardship.

St. Maurice Chemicals, Ltd., of Montreal, has been selected by the Heyden Chemical Corporation and Shawinigan Chemicals, Ltd., subsidiary of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company of Montreal, as the Canadian corporation to carry out their joint program to build a $2,000,000 plant at Varennes, Quebec.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 A leading witness suffered an unexpected "loss of memory" during a three-hour examination today before a new Federal grand jury as it moved into the internal revenue field.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz signed an order yesterday releasing to the State Crime Commission the testimony of former Mayor William O'Dwyer and Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh before the rackets grand jury.

DETROIT, Dec. 12 A former ordnance inspector who left his $6,200-a-year job to set himself up as a manufacturer's agent told the House subcommittee investigating middlemen's profits on defense contracts that he had earned $14,- ...

After hearing the last defendant, a first grade fireman, deny ever taking graft, Third Deputy Fire Commissioner Albert S. Pacetta brought to a close yesterday the departmental trial of civilian and uniformed members accused of taking money in connection with air compressor tests.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (U.P.) The American Federation of Labor's new weekly newspaper, The A.F.L. News, published today its own all-star team "The 1951 All-American team of reactionary Senators" and nominated Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio as coach of the squad.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The nub of the steel wage dispute is prices. It is a repetition of the 1946 episode and the final settlement, when it comes is expected to be made on the price front.

LONDON, Dec. 12 As Britain had not been informed late today that Egypt would withdraw her Ambassador from London, there was still hope here that the partial break in relations would not in fact take place.

An increase last week of 1,112,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 113,590,000 barrels, compared with 112,478,000 a week earlier and 109,647,000 a year ago.

Plans for reaching a $3,000,000 goal next year to finance fellowships in the United States for Latin-American students and to build a center for the Cordell Hull Foundation for International Education were discussed here yesterday by the foundation's board of trust.

Mr. and Mrs. Jean-Pierre Millon of 1192 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jo Jeanne, to Thomas Heisler Barton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Barton of Chicago. The wedding will take place here in the spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The National Planning Association proposed today the creation of an independent Federal investigating unit to assure the proper use of money and manpower by the Department of Defense.

David J. Mahoney, who resigned as a vice president of Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., to found his own agency in October told the Metropolitan Advertising Men at the Bedford Hotel last night that his venture had succeeded.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 The United States policy of nonintervention in the free countries should be abandoned in favor of "a total American foreign policy of intervention on the side of the common man" to help defeat communism, Robert Oliver, labor adviser to the Economic Cooperation Administration, said today.

The Methodist Church Home for the Aged has sold a plot 200 by 135 feet on the west side of River Avenue, near East 167th Street, the Bronx, to Bridge Motors, Inc., which is planning to erect a garage there.

Proposals to limit the number of American troops in Europe were assailed yesterday by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who urged that the United States send abroad as many divisions as it could muster to stem the threat of dictatorship.
By order of the judge yesterday, Tallulah Bankhead moved her personal show out of the courtroom where her former maid-secretary is on trial for grand larceny and forgery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The United States, ready for almost any subject that Prime Minister Churchill may raise during his visit here next month, will fully support his expected call for stronger Anglo-American ties, but not at the sacrifice of unity with other Allies in Europe.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Dec. 12 Chinese Communist infiltration into the independent kingdom of Nepal from Tibet already is going on, and Gurkha units have been posted among Himalayan passes to stop it, according to official sources here.

The Columbia University Club will celebrate its fiftieth birthday tonight at a party whose merriment is sure to be haunted by the traditions and problems of the alumni that the club has served since 1901.

Even greater community support of public education was urged yesterday to enable the schools to meet the serious problems arising from the post-war increase in the birth rate, the lack of buildings and the shortage of qualified teachers.

ROME, Dec. 12 An early breach of diplomatic relations with Albania is under consideration by the Italian Government. This was deduced from a statement by Paolo Emilio Taviani, Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, to the Senate this morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The president of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, A. F. L., told a Presidential emergency board today that the railroads opposed a union shop because they wanted to play nonunionists against union members. The board was set up in an effort to avert a strike threat.

Charles B. Hitchcock, the American Geographical Society's expert on Venezuela, cabled the Venezuelan Government's expedition exploring the headwaters of the Orinoco River yesterday for further information on its find- ...

Theodore W. Kheel, whose peace plan helped avert a pre-Christmas strike on eight privately owned bus lines, hinted yesterday that he would urge union and company officials to make advance preparations to install the forty-hour work-week as soon as present contracts expire on Dec. 31, 1952.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today the discharge of two employes who refused to resign when asekd to do so on Nov. 28.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (U.P.) The American Municipal Association demanded today that Congress provide more money "immediately" to help the nation's cities protect themselves against possible atomic attack.

The Right Rev. Msgr. John L. Belford, a Catholic priest for sixty-three years, died last night at the age of 90 in the rectory of the Church of the Nativity of Our Blessed Lord in Brooklyn, where he was pastor.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 12 Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, speaking in the Knesset (Parliament) today on the subject of immigration, charged that Zionist leaders in the United States "went bankrupt" after the founding of Israel in 1948.

Birthdays are properly for children. So it was only fitting yesterday when the Port Authority marked the first anniversary of its vast $24,000,000 bus terminal, Eighth Avenue between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets, that a youngster should cut the cake.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 13 The Communists today invited the United Nations delegates discussing an armistice in Korea to make "a new proposal" that would guarantee the North Korean Communist state against interference with its internal affairs while neutral nations made inspections behind the lines during the cease-fire.
Joe DiMaggio's retirement as a player and the resulting void in the Yankee ranks were the subject of much speculation in baseball circles yesterday.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 12 The first official figures on the defense budget for Norway were given in the Storting [Parliament] today when, Trade Minister Erik Brofoss said the Government was proposing 2,500,000,000 crowns (about $350,000,000) for the next threeyear period from July, 1951, through June, 1954.

The singing of Christmas carols by seven sightless children highlighted the final meeting held yesterday at the Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, by the women's committee to report on the campaign to raise $425,000 for operating expenses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Secretary of State Dean Acheson's return to the capital marks the beginning of a new opportunity both for him and his foreign policy.
Malcolm P. Murdock has been appointed general sales manager of Ethyl Corporation. S. T. Pruitt succeeds him as manager of the central sales region.
An analytical study of the military intervention of the United States in Siberia in 1918 has been scheduled for spring publication by Library Publishers under the title "The Siberian Fiasco."

WATCHUNG, N. J., Dec. 12 Representative Charles A. Eaton, who has held the seat for New Jersey's Fifth District in Congress since 1924, announced today he would not be a candidate for reelection next year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 (U.P.) Ezzard Charles, former heavyweight champion, made it five in a row over light-heavyweight titleholder Joey Maxim tonight as he pounded out a unanimous twelve-round decision in a slowpaced, drab non-title fight in the Cow Palace.
LONDON, Dec. 12 Bagpipes made their Covent Garden debut tonight when the Sadler's Wells ballet gave the first performance of "Donald of the Burthens," a ballet with a strong Scottish Highland accent.

Russell A. Firestone, second son of the late Harvey S. Firestone, and a director, since 1932, of The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, died yesterday morning, after a long illness, at his home, 1040 Park Avenue. He was 50 years old.

THOMASVILLE, Ala., Dec. 12 (AP) Federal Bureau of Investigation agents arrested today the president, cashier and a leading customer of this lumber mill town's only bank in an alleged $800,000 shortage.

New York University will seek its eighth straight triumph when it meets Colgate in the second contest of a collegiate basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. In the opener at 7:45 P. M., Texas A. and M., Southwestern Conference champion, will engage once-beaten Manhattan.

CARMEL, Calif., Dec. 12 (U.P.) The Pacific Coast Conference took its first step in the battle against "over aggressiveness" in football today when it announced that all future conference games would have a fifth official on the field.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 12(AP) Fighting among priests, anti-British and anti-Soviet demonstrations and legislative sitdowns against the Government tonight swelled Iran's turmoil over the paralysis of her big oil industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Despite the disapproval of the Democratic organization in New Hampshire, a young Democrat of that state is actively engaged in a political project that conceivably could threaten one basic strategic line of those national Repub- ...

LONDON, Dec. 12 In spite of the serious loss of gold and dollars that Britain has incurred this year there is every indication that she will offer to pay in full the first installments due at the end of this year on loans from the United States and Canada.

LONDON, Dec. 12 Improvement in the stock markets became more pronounced today as the new bookkeeping account started. Selling of British Government securities was much lighter and, with an improved demand, prices finished with net gains of as much as 15s after fluctuating erratically.
Directors of Colonial Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday that they had accepted an offer to merge the company with National Airlines, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) Louis G. Caldwell, nationally known attorney and chief counsel of The Washington Times-Herald, died tonight at his home in Northwest Washington. He suffered a heart attack two weeks ago. His age was 60.
For the second time in recent months a cargo ship belonging to a Marshall Plan nation has bean sold to a country behind the Iron Curtain, it was learned here yesterday.

Scholarships were presented yesterday to two graduate students at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business by the Kiwanis Club here and Dean Philip Young hailed the action as an important means of bridging the gap between business and business education.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it had cancelled bids for $10,000,000 of cast metal segments for the first phase of construction of the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel because of Mayor Impellitteri's refusal to let the agency start tearing up streets before the controversy over street connections was settled.

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores in November showed an increase of 10.1 per cent over the like month of last year, according to a compilation of fortyfour companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Dec. 12 (AP) Mildred Bailey, one of the nation's most popular blues singers for many years, died tonight at St. Francis Hospital here. Her "Old Rockin' Chair" song made her famous.
LONDON, Dec. 12 A new organization to assist Britain's dollar-export drive has been formed by industry with the support of the British Government it was announced today.

Nathan P. Feinsinger, chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board, hints that that body is considering favorably the idea of giving the green light to wage increases when they can be shown to be related to increased productivity.

PITTSBURGH, Dec.12 The 170man strategy committee that sets wage and strike policy for 1,100,000 unionized steel workers was summoned today to a meeting here Monday to decide what to do about the slow pace of negotiations for a new steel wage agreement.

Eastman, Dillon Co. and underwriting associates will place on the market today an issue of 100,000 shares of new $50 par value, 5.2 per cent dividend, convertible preferred stock of Suburban Propane Gas Corporation at $50 a share.

A Red Cross certificate of commendation was awarded yesterday to Sydney Flum of Norfolk, Va., disabled World War II veteran who has donated thirty-six pints of blood since 1946. The presentation was made at a meeting of de- ...

John Lindsay Clark of Wilton, Conn., a partner in the New York brokerage firm of Abbott, Proctor Paine, and former president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, died yesterday of a heart attack in the New York Stock Exchange Luncheon Club. His age was 57.

A man identified from his papers as Bruno Ehrman Jr., 35 years old, of Lebanon, N. J., parked his automobile in the middle of George Washington Bridge, took off his coat, climbed over the rail and jumped into the Hudson River yesterday at 5:55 A. M., the police reported.

Manufacturers of material-handling equipment are preparing to expand national sales of their machinery to makers of civilian products after the peak of the national defense requirements have been met by June, 1952, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Material Handling Institute, Inc., at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The State Department said today Russia's "little puppets" were making accusations against the United States in an effort to back up Soviet charges of widespread spying and sabotage against the Communist bloc.

PARIS, Dec. 12 The Netherlands, Greece, Colombia and Iraq endorsed today the proposal by the Western Big Three that the United Nations establish a commission to determine the possibility of holding free elections on reunification in both East and West Germany.

Tonight, while a young violinist plays with the Metropolitan Opera orchestra, special ceremonies will take place at Carnegie Hall where the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra will give its 5,000th concert.

White gladioluses and palm formed a floral background yesterday afternoon in Sherry's for the marriage of Miss Peggy Claire Lissner, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Lissner of the Hotel Wyndham, and the late Mr. Lissner, to David H. Schultz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isador Schultz of Newton, Mass.

City Council President Rudolph Halley swore in yesterday seven additional members of his office staff, bringing its manpower to twelve. He said that two more members would be sworn in before Jan. 2, 1952.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 President Truman today pledged continued drastic efforts to expose and punish faithless Federal employes as reports circulated that Judge Thomas F. Murphy of New York soon would be named to a special presidential commission to investigate corruption charges.

A new one-story taxpayer at 4032 Sunrise Highway in Seaford, L.I., has been sold by Jack Massaro to Sol Silvers. The property occupies a plot 158 by 50 feet. Harold Crane was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

Loew's, Inc., occupant for thirty years of Loew's National Theatre at 556-58 Bergen Avenue, the Bronx, has purchased the 2,200seat building from a group consisting of Irving Fishman, Nathan Weinberg and Jack Sonenblick. The

In a recent address Eliot Janeway of Newsweek Magazine made the statement that the United States, which used to pity Britain, Germany and Japan as "have-not" countries, has become one itself by the progress of technology. American security, he said, is being built more and more upon a foundation of nickel, tungsten, cobalt and other obscure imported

MELBOURNE, Friday, Dec. 14 (AP) The United States combination of Ted Schroeder and Tony Trabert defeated Sweden today in the doubles of the interzone final, and won the right to meet Australia in the challenge round for the Davis Cup at Sydney, starting Dec. 26. The score teas 10-12, 6 0, 6 3, 6 2.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13 The Soviet press charged today that the $100,000,000 fund provided by the Mutual Security Act of 1951 was only "a drop in the ocean" of money being spent by the United States to finance terroristic espionage and diversionary activity directed against the Soviet Union and the countries of Eastern Europe.

FEW men know as much about the old West as Ross Santee, novelist, artist and former cowpuncher and hoss wrangler. Some of the few who do know and have written good books about it learned all they know in other books. But Mr. Santee's knowledge is personal.

A plea for religion in the public-school system was made last night by Dr. Clarence W. Hall, managing editor of The Christian Herald, in an address before the annual meeting of the Manhattan division of the Protestant Council of New York City.

James M. Robbins, former Princeton golf captain, was elected president of the Metropolitan Golf Association at the fifty-fourth annual meeting of the organization yesterday at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
The United States Court of Appeals reversed yesterday an order by Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman, prohibiting a strike against the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation.

Selective strength in important units in the oil, chemical, copper, airline and rail divisions enabled the stock market to present a firmer appearance yesterday. Prices shuttled back and forth until the final hour, when bidding gave the list its major lift of the day. It was obvious that the market was not too eager to advance beyond

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 Frank E. McKinney, Democratic National Chairman, defended the Truman Administration tonight and attacked its Republican critics, "including newspaper publishers who belittle every constructive thing accomplished by the Government."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP) In an exciting duel, P.C. Taylor's Gillie Young, $5.60 favorite, outgamed the long-shot Ace Scholar, owned by J.H. Miles, for the major share of the $2,200 purse in the featured sixth race at Tropical Park today.

PARIS, Dec. 13 (AP) By its voting today the National Assembly pledged France to join a supranational authority designed to govern the coal and steel industries of six West European nations for fifty years.
There will be fewer American contributions to Christmas stockings all over Europe this year and that continent's counterparts of Santa Claus will be carrying 350,000 fewer Yuletide parcels.

Kid Gavilan, welterweight champion of the world, will engage Walter Cartier of Greenwich Village in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Gavilan's title will not be at stake, as Cartier operates in the middleweight division and may have the advantage of a dozen pounds over his Cuban rival.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13--Charles E. Wilson, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, declared today that wage controls would not be scrapped.

In the negotiations between the Government of Guatemala and the United Fruit Company, President Jacobo Arbenz's Nationalist Administration has won the company's complete concession on every legitimate point of difference, as well as the basic one: renegotiation of the company's contract.

Warner-Hudnut, Inc., manufacturer, of pharmaceuticals and cosmetics, announced yesterday plans to exchange 293,960 shares of its common stock for outstanding shares of the Maltine Company, producer of ethical drugs.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday and 19 to 80 points lower.

Mrs. Evyleen Cronin, Tallulah Bankhead's former maid-secretary, denied, before she had obtained a lawyer, that she ever had spent money to obtain "narcotics in any form or sex in any form" for Miss Bankhead, Bernard Dolgin, an accountant for the District Attorney's office, testified yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 Rita Hayworth and Columbia Pictures have come to a temporary parting of the ways over her next film, "Affair in Trinidad," and the studio announced today that it has "no alternative but to place Miss Hayworth under suspension and postpone plans to begin the film."

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 14 Communist armistice negotiators at Panmunjom informed the United Nations today that "a great majority" of the Allied prisoners captured in the Korean war would continue to be held in enemy stockades during an armistice unless an over-all exchange of captives was agreed upon.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 13 George B. Serenbetz, former president of the Nassau County Bar Association and police justice of Hempstead for twelve years, died today at his home, 1 Cedar Street, after a brief illness.

Morris Cooper-Smith, a 57-yearold tax consultant who used to write denunciatory letters about tax clerks and others who tried to spoil his devious plans, was sentenced yesterday to a year in jail for falsification of his 1947 state income-tax return. Justice Eugene

Hailing the city's parking-meter test program as a success, acting Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley has asked the Board of Estimate to appropriate $1,277,000 for installing 13,000 more machines in virtually every major business and shopping center in the five boroughs.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 14--United States Sabre jets shot down thirteen Soviet-type MIG-15's in two sky battles over North Korea yesterday. The F-86's probably destroyed...
DUESSELDORF, Germany, Dec. l3 Communism in the industrial Ruhr, the chief objective of the party's activity in West Germany, has suffered an important defeat.

Deputy Inspector Edward Whiteman, who had been second in command of the Twenty-second Division of the Jamaica police precinct in Queens for two years, was demoted to captain and transferred yesterday with two members of his staff after an investigation by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

Joe DiMaggio yesterday agreed to conduct a television, show before and after every Yankee home game. Since the one-year contract, with options for renewal, is a personal one between the Yankees and DiMaggio, the Clipper thus remains in the employ of the New York club.

CAIRO, Dec. 13--Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha announced officially today the decision of the Egyptian Cabinet to recall the Egyptian Ambassador to Britain.

NEWARK, Dec. 13 The twenty-cent fare between New York and Hudson County, N.J. station of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad became effective at 12:01 A.M. today under an Interstate Commerce Commission order last Friday holding the fifteen-cent fare inadequate.
A move that threatens to send the horse parlor to join bearbaiting in the limbo of forgotten American institutions was disclosed yesterday by Western Union.

Six Sanitation Department workers and an assistant foreman will receive gold medals today for acts of bravery ranging from rescues to apprehension of armed criminals. Andrew W. Mulrain, Commissioner of Sanitation, will present the awards at annual ceremonies held at department headquarters, 125 Worth Street.

The New York Philharmonic, wearing its years and accomplishments with proper dignity but no excess of gravity, played the 5,000th concert of its career of 109 years last night at Carnegie Hall.

The United States, Britain and France have submitted to the United Nations a revised version of their disarmament plan. The new version leaves all the fundamental principles and conditions of the Western plan intact, and is therefore unlikely to bridge the gulf between East and West on this issue at this time. But it does meet some...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 A commitment of $600,000,000 by the United States to France in support of the French rearmament program and the war in Indo-China was reported officially to Congress today by the office of W. Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 14 (AP) General Headquarters communique 1,097 for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A.M., Friday (4 P.M., Thursday, Eastern standard time):

Halsey, Stuart Co., and associates will place on the market today a new issue of $25,000,000 of first mortgage 3 5/8 per cent bonds of Long Island Lighting Company due in 1976 at 101.20 to yield 3.55 per cent. The bonds were bought at competitive bidding by the bankers Wednesday with a bid of 100.22.

That important sector of New York's economic life, its miles of waterfront, has assumed more of its usual hustle and bustle these cold December mornings, and almost overnight the spirit of the approaching Christmas season has crept into this beehive of commercial activity. Additional gangs

Clarence Campbell, president of the National Hockey League, said yesterday that more scoring, rather than overtime play, would help to eliminate the abundance of tie games that has beset the ice sport in recent years.
Details of an advertising campaign designed to support all manufacturers' brands and brand advertising in 1952 were released yesterday by the Brand Names Foundation, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Overriding objections by both the Departments of the Interior and Justice, Manly Fleischmann, Director of the Defense Production Administration, gave a "green light" today to the Anaconda Copper Mining Company to go into large-scale aluminum production.
Coffee and cocoa, two imported commodities, held out against the generally lower market trend yesterday. Sugar, wool and vegetable oils were weaker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The House Ways and Means subcommittee investigating tax scandals has been trying for two days to locate the man it calls the "chauffeur-bodyguard" for Henry Grunewald, mystery witness in the inquiry.
DETROIT, Dec. 13 (UP) Detroit increased its National Hockey League lead to six points tonight at the expense of the Toronto Maple Leafs with a 3-to-1 victory before 12,668 fans at Olympia Stadium.

Controller Lazarus Joseph and the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, of which he is chairman, are seriously considering a plan to scrap the 3 per cent sales tax in favor of greatly increased taxes on general and financial business transactions.

The New York County Medical Society announced yesterday that it would welcome investigation of alleged abuses of parking privileges accorded to physicians and promised to take appropriate action within its ranks for the protection of the vast majority of its membership that obey the laws.

The 134 young men who completed yesterday their studies at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., are fortunate in that their entrance into the maritime industry comes at a time when there is an almost desperate need for trained officer personnel, Vice Admiral E.L. Cochrane, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, said yesterday.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 13 (AP) The Iranian Government today ordered Leopold Herman, correspondent for Reuters, British news agency, to leave Iran within fortyeight hours. The Government...
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 13 (AP) Harry (Kid) Matthews, 178, of Seattle scored a second round knockout over Art Henri, 189, of New York in a heavyweight bout tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 A special Federal grand jury today ended its investigation into the race rioting last July in suburban Cicero by indicting the president of the town, three other officials and three policemen.

ROUSES POINT, N.Y., Dec. 13 (AP) More Americans are entering the growing racket of sneaking "smugs" into Canada. Smugs, the Canadian name for smuggled United States cigarettes, are fast becoming the favorite smoke in the dominion.

FLINT, Mich., Dec. 13 Increased automotive demand with fewer cars available for 1952 was predicted today by Ivan L. Wiles, general manager of Buick division of General Motors Corporation. There are indications of continued build-up pressure for retail buying, he added, which will add greatly to the purchasing volume in the next year.

Mrs. Walter E. Travis sold the residence at 23 East Eighty-third Street to a client of William B. May Co. for occupancy. The five-story house is in the Spanish style of architecture and occupies a lot 18.9 by 100 feet. The sale was the first involving the property since the seller bought it in 1928.

Two Denver residents, Mary Coyle Chase and Irving L. Jacobs, will be rooting for the same cause when Mr. Jacobs introduces Mrs. Chase's latest comedy, "Bernadine." Cooperating with them whole-heartedly will be Guthrie McClintic as director of the venture. Significant dates selected by

A blistering third period, during which the Violets stormed to 32 points, enabled the undefeated New York University basketball team to score a 78-66 triumph over Colgate last night at Madison Square Garden. Manhattan, limiting Texas A. and M. to 2 points in the final quarter, defeated the Southerners, 44 42, on Junius Kellogg's field goal in the opener.

Net profits after taxes for department stores with annual volumes of more than $1,000,000 each declined to 1.4 per cent in the first nine months of this year, representing a drop of 50 per cent as compared with 2.9 realized in the like period of last year. This was

In an austere atmosphere redolent of the United States Supreme Court, forty-two students from fourteen law schools argued before a moot version of the high tribunal yesterday in the fourth annual competition held by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York in seven simultaneous hearings at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Walter M. Jeffords Jr. has been elected a director of the Lafayette National Bank of Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by Walter Jeffreys Carlin, president. Mr. Jeffords is president and chairman of Brooklyn Borough Gas Company.

Skiers, a patient breed, continued to scan the skies yesterday for signs of snow. Reports from the Northlands indicated that frost, an important ingredient in preserving snow and essential for establishing a good base, already was in the ground.

The nine athletes in the running for the James E. Sullivan Memorial Award were named yesterday by Dan Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union. Their names have been submitted to sports authorities throughout the country and balloting will be concluded on Dec. 29.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Six prominent New Yorkers, all wellconnected politically, are under investigation by the House Ways and Means subcommittee now studying tax scandals.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 13 The number of persons in the South "who are able and willing to reject the taboos on interracial effort in their communities is growing" but "outmoded traditions, unjustified fears and ancient prejudices continue to exact a heavy toll on the unity, productiveness and integrity of our society," the Southern Regional Council declared today.

In a futile attempt to end the conflict between the city and the Port Authority over street connections for the proposed third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel, the City Planning Commission came up with a "compromise" solution yesterday that could cost the bi-state...

The four-volume, 685-page management survey report just completed on the city's Department of Hospitals was characterized yesterday by Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, as "too much philosophizing from an ivory tower and too little time taken to look at a sick person."
PARIS, Dec. 13 France's National Assembly today ratified the Schuman plan for merging Western Europe's steel and coal production by an overwhelming confidence vote of 377 to 233. This act

Defense and defense supporting loans provided the major pressure in the expansion of business borrowings from New York banks last week, raising these credits an additional $106,000,000 to reach $7,757,000,000, the second consecutive high record.

Louis Auchincloss, a New York attorney and writer, will have a novel published under his own name on Jan. 2 by Houghton Mifflin. "Sybil" is the story of a rebellious girl's search for a way of life with property and position. Mr. Auchincloss, who gave up writing while at Yale, began again while in the Navy. The result was...
CARMEL, Calif., Dec. 13 (UP) Abolition of spring football practice was proposed today as the Pacific Coast Conference completed its mid-winter sessions.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh accepted yesterday a North Carolina trucking corporation's check for $4,740 in payment of the biggest aggregate fine ever levied for parking violations here--the defendant's vehicles had been found in 467 illegal positions since last April.

To improve the competitive position of New York State industry a series of bills will be introduced in the Legislature next month designed to reduce the cost of workmen's compensation, now amounting to an estimated $300,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The State Department dismissed John Stewart Service tonight on the advice of the Government's top loyalty agency that there was "reasonable doubt" as to the foreign service officer's loyalty

Retired Police Capt. Joseph C. Workman, one of the eighteen defendants in the graft conspiracy trial that collapsed when Harry Gross, the bookmaker, refused to testify, was arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court on a perjury indictment.

A message from General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower praising the contributions made by the Columbia University Club to the university was read last night at a dinner celebrating the club's fiftieth anniversary.
Waiters in about 100 large restaurants, including many in the midtown area, and some night club, voted yesterday to strike at noon today in a fight for a fiveday, forty-hour week and pensions.
