SAN FRANCISCO, Dec.13 (AP) Ezzard Charles, the former heavyweight champion, has convinced the light-heavyweight title-holder, Joey Maxim, after five beatings, that is a hopeless cause to challenge him.

The title of Papal Countess was conferred yesterday on Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, wife of the former Ambassador to the Court of St. James, in recognition of her "exemplary motherhood and many charitable works."
Using a cake mix as a basis in making Christmas cookies represents a new approach to a pleasant domestic activity that is as old and traditional as trimming the tree. A manufacturer of white and

Business must give greater emphasis to its social contributions to the nation and the people in view of the changed social environment of this country, Holgar J. Johnson, president of the Institute of Life Insurance, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the institute held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Increasing interest in the social effects of the advancing age of our population was reflected yesterday at a hearing held by the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on the Problems of the Aging.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 13 William Hiram Dewey, New York wine merchant and cousin of Governor Dewey, died of a heart attack this morning at the Hartsdale Railroad Station. He was 65 years old. His home was at 8 Brook Lane in near-by Scarsdale.

DETROIT, Dec. 13 The Chrysler Corporation and a group of smaller defense contractors denied today charges by a Congressional investigator that automobile manufacturers and parts suppliers were inflating the cost of rearmament by prearranged bids and excessive middlemen's profits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) Housing Administrator Raymond M. Foley announced today that Federal funds will be used for the first time in the current emergency to construct sixteen temporary housing projects in fourteen critical defense housing areas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 President Truman made it plain today that he would persist in the face of powerful Senate opposition in his effort to send Gen. Mark W. Clark to the Vatican as the first United States Ambassador to the Holy See.

LONDON, Dec. 13 Continued revival of British Government securities helped all other Stock Exchange markets to improve further today. Prices advanced everywhere until late dealings, when some of them seemed to be slipping slightly.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 13 (AP) Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's Government announced today above a mighty chorus of death threats for his political foes that national elections would start next Tuesday.

A thousand of the nation's leading lawyers and judges paid tribute last night to Judges Learned Hand and Augustus N. Hand at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, given in their honor by the New York County Lawyers Association.
Seventeen of the twenty market classifications received more steel in the first ten months of 1951 than in the similar part of last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

In May 1949, a former troopship, rebuilt for passenger service, departed from New York on her maiden voyage to Mediterranean ports. For upward of a year, she was the largest American-flag liner on that run. Yesterday, she returned to this port to end her active but short-lived career, no loner wanted by her operators.

Aided and abetted by those Santa Claus helpers who are making use of the United States mails, the New York Post Office is doing, so far this season, about 20 per cent more business than it did at this time last year.

PARIS, Dec. 13 Withdrawal of South Africa's delegation today from the plenary meetings of the United Nations General Assembly and the recall of the chief South African representative to Pretoria won the Union Government little sympathy among its fellow members in the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13--On the surface, this was a dull day here in the field of international affairs. There was no announcement on the Truman-Acheson meeting at the White House. There were few diplomatic...

By every measure the New York market area is far ahead of any in the United States, according to a study of eighty-eight major markets made public yesterday by the Hearst Advertising Service. Chunky, 63 year-old Irving (Waxey Gordon) Wexler stood impassive in General Sessions yesterday as Budge Francis L. Valente shattered his dreams of a return via the narcotics racket to his Prohibition era status as a "racketeer of nation-wide significance." The Court sentenced him to a prison term of twenty-five years to life.

Two final rooms, containing fullscale designs for the chapel at Vence, France, now are open at the Museum of Modern Art's Matisse exhibition which, at the rate of 2,000 a day, has been visited by 60,000 persons, The delay in exhibiting this section of the French artist's most recent work was caused first by the dock strike and then by the exigencies of installation.

Four winners in a nation-wide contest for the best essay on ways of interesting more Negro families in the adoption of children received awards in person yesterday at a tea at headquarters of the child placing and adoption committee of the State Charities Aid Association, 105 East Twenty-second Street, sponsor of the contest.

BERLIN, Dec. 13 Although cessation of legal trade between the east and west zones of Germany has cut appreciably into the economy of the Soviet zone, there are indications that in important aspects the West has come off the worse.
NOW that the woods are free of deer hunters, the foxhounds are making their high music in the hills, and according to the reports from Maine, Vermont and up-state New York there are plenty of foxes.

ROME, Dec. 13 Minister of Finance Ezio Vanoni told the Chamber of Deputies today that he was satisfied with the "first experiment" on Oct. 10 when Italians were required to declare their 1950 incomes for the purposes of taxation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 The American Farm Bureau Federation reaffirmed its stand today favoring present farm legislation, including price-support measures, and criticized Federal agencies as endeavoring to speak for farmers. The country's largest farm organization asserted:

BONN, Germany, Dec. 13--An effort by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to obtain speedy ratification of the Schuman plan in the West German Bundestag not only met with failure today but put a severe strain on his control of the Government coalition.

Four youngsters who delivered their cash gift of $8 in person, many old-timers whose quavery handwriting bespoke their age, a friend of Sinclair Lewis and scores of persons with special reasons for remembering Dec. 14 were among those whose contributions to the Neediest Cases are acknowledged today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13--Oscar R. Ewing, the Federal Security Administrator, charged today at the first annual awards program of the Federal Security Agency that the Government worker was being maligned and misinterpreted.
A recommendatian by ten college presidents that post-season college football bowl games be abolished drew quick and from some points bitter opposition yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

Plans to recapitalize Basic Refractories, Inc., in order to raise $4,000,000 were announced yesterday by H.P. Eells Jr., president, Of the new money, which would be raised privately, $3,500,000 would go for a plant to increase production capacity for refractory dolomite, used for lining steel furnaces. The rest would be added to working capital.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Concilation Service, sent his two top troubleshooters to this steel capital tonight to determine what the Government could do to head off a New Year's Eve strike in the country's principal steel and aluminum plants.
The Wednesday night schedule in television boasts two new attractions a quiz at 7:30 P.M. on A.B.C. and a discussion series at 9:30 on the DuMont network.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 Walter Wanger, film producers shot and wounded a talent agent, Jennings Lang, today in Beverly Hills as Mr. Wanger's wife, Joan Bennett, looked on.
Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, said last night that racial and religious discrimination in employment was "a disservice" to America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The United States Senator had a "secret mission" according to a Soviet propaganda film shown to millions in Communist countries.
The 2-cent advance on butter reported this week by the city Department of Markets has brought the price to 89 cents a pound, the highest since August, 1948.

Great Britain is capable of solving present economic difficulties through her own efforts providing "outside help" is given in obtaining increased supply of raw materials needed for and intensified dollar exports drive and rearmament.

British loss of the Suez Canal would put an impossible burden on the international oil tanker fleet serving the free world, William F. Moore of the marketing coordination department of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) declared yesterday at a meeting of the Overseas Automotive Club in the Shelton Hotel.

PARIS, Dec. 13 The French Government, fully supported by United States diplomacy, will urge Winston Churchill in the strongest possible fashion to withdraw his opposition to the European defense force project when Britain's Prime Minister visits Paris on Monday and Tuesday.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 The State Defense Council today approved New York City's $15,000,000 program for building subway bomb shelters, but postponed any action on petitioning the Federal Government for its half-share of the expense.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., Dec. 13 John A. Bolles, active in New York Republican politics for many years, died this morning of a heart attack at his home, Strawberry Hill, on North Broadway. He was 72 years of age.

The first "Goetterdamemerung" of the season received a stirring performance last night in the Metropolitan Opera House; one that gave every evidence of having been carefully rehearsed and prepared perspecaciously in all essentials of a representative interpretation.

A special committee on the improvement of intercollegiate athletics recommended yesterday that the Eastern College Athletic Conference ban football bowl games and post-season contests in other sports, restrict out-of-season practice and tighten eligibility rules.

KINDSTON, N.Y., Dec. 13 (AP) The New York Central Railroad blamed the auto and the bus for a decline in rail passenser traffic. This testimony was given at a Public Service Commission hearing into the Central's dropping of two passenger trains between Weehawken, N.J., and Albany last Sept. 30.

PARIS, Dec. 13 The Western powers turned in A revised disarmament resolution today setting June 1, 1952 as the deadline for a first progress report from the proposed new United Nations arms reduction and atomic energy control commission.

Reporting a current order backlog of $1,280,000,000 for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, Robert E. Gross, president, told shareholders yesterday that sales for 1951 will approximate $235,000,000, a gain of 35 per cent over 1950.

The existence of an international gang of jewel thieves, numbering sixteen members and making their headquarters in Toronto, has been established by the New York police, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Toronto police.

THE longer a fellow is associated with sports the more reluctant he is to see a record broken, particularly a long-standing one Sometimes he almost resents the youthful Johnnycome-lately who destroyed a mark which had been set by an idol of younger days. Perhaps that's because memories start to stir and they invariably are such fond memories.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Charles Oliphant, recently resigned chief counsel of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, categorically denied today membership in or knowledge of a clique of prominent Washingtonians mentioned in an alleged plot to extort $500,000 from a Chicago attorney in an income tax "shakedown."

Although his name is familiar to music lovers, Michael Field's recital last night was his first solo appearance in Town Hall and one of his few anywhere. For this young pianist has spent the last eight years playing duos with Vera Appleton.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14-- Walter Wanger, film producer, who shot a supposed rival for the affections of his actress wife, Joan Bennett, last night, was released from Beverly Hills jail today under $5,000 bail.

WASHINGTON., Dec. 14--The Department of Justice reported to Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, today that since 1939 the General Dyestuff Corporation, which is owned by the Office of Alien Property, had paid salaries totaling $2,384,978 to thirteen officers.
Anecdotes were almost as thick as snowflakes last night after the arrival of the season's first real snowstorm. Virtually all the stories involved transportation tie-ups.

The peak rush hour crowd of an estimated 25,000 persons, augmented by many holiday shoppers, accumulated in the Port of New York Authority Bus Terminal on Eighth Avenue between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets last evening, only to find virtually no buses to take them to their New Jersey homes.

The Italian Line, which operated the famous pre-war luxury liners Rex and Conte di Savoia, is rapidly regaining its position in the trans-Atlantic steamship passenger trade as the result of the most ambitious construction program undertaken by any company since the war.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Dec. 14-- James Ernest Aiken Egleson, retired vice president of the Congoleum-Nairn Company, died, here this morning at his home on Old Eagle Rock Avenue. He was 72 years old.
The stock market made a modest attempt yesterday to extend the Thursday recovery, but sagging tendencies in the last hour produced an irregularly lower closing.

Two businesslike gunmen walked calmly into the second-floor offices of the Walton Hauling and Warehouse Company building at 609 West Forty-sixth Street yesterday during the lunch hour and scampered out again a few minutes later with an $8,500 payroll.

MADRID, Dec. 14--Sidney C. Sufrin, head of a special United States economic mission to Spain, today urged the Spanish Government and industrialists "to get existing equipment to operate at a more efficient capacity" before embarking on a policy of largescale rehabilitation and capital investment that, in Spain's case, would have to be financed through foreign loans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--An early eighteenth-century painting of "The Assumption of the Virgin" by the Neapolitan artist and scholar, Paolo de Matteis, has been returned by United States art authorities to the Benedictine monastery of Monte Cassino in Italy where it had served as an altarpiece for more than two centuries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)-- The Office of Price Stabilization said today that the Hudson Motor Car Company and the KaiserFrazer Company had asked for price increases under the Capehart Amendment to the Economic Controls Law--the first automobile manufacturers to do so.
HOULTON, Me., Dec. 14-- Charles P. Barnes, a retired Chief Justice of Maine's Supreme Judicial Court, died here today at the age of 82.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)-- President Truman announced today the nomination of Edward J. Sparks of New York to be Ambassador to Bolivia. The nomination was recommended by the State Department. It will be sent to the Senate for confirmation when Congress reconvenes next month.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP)--The Illinois Commerce Commission today decided that the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company is subject to state regulation of its direct sales of natural gas to industrial customers in Illinois.

The substitution of greatly increased city taxes on general and financial business for the present 3 per cent sales tax was opposed yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York and the Meat Trade Institute.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (UP)-- Prof. Hugh C. Willett, president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said tonight the N.C. A.A. will hear a proposal next month that a year-long study be made of post-season and bowl football games to avoid criticism of influence by "prejudice or misinformation."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The engagment of Miss Anne Brevoort Murphy to Per Cappelen Smith, son of Lorentz Cappelen Smith, Swedish Consul at Trondheim, Norway, and Mrs. Smith, has been announced by her parents, Col. Charles J.V. Murphy, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Murphy of Washington, and Rye, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--Sharp increases in the production of synthetic rubber over the last eighteen months have made it possible to relax generally the Government's restrictions on rubber, the National Production Authority announced today.

If you had walked up the 135th Street steps through St. Nicholas Park last night, bucking snowflakes up the same steps you had climbed to reach the Stadium Concerts in the summer, you would have come upon the High School of Music and Art beginning its semi-annual concert and art exhibition.

The Salvation Army's Christmas symbols--red kettles suspended from tripods--will be set up on several principal streets of New York on Monday to remain through next Saturday to receive Christmas contributions from passersby.

The six-story apartment house at 778-86 Driggs Avenue, Brooklyn, accommodating forty-one families, has been sold by S. Braun to an investing client of George C. Bluestone, attorney, in a transaction negotiated by Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers. Saul Berger was attorney for the seller. The property occupies a plot 84 by 81 feet.

GENEVA, Dec. 14--It is becoming accepted in United States circles in Europe that the establishment of a European army, now scheduled by those working on the plan for April 1, 1952, will bring about a fundamental change in the theory and administration of United States aid to Europe.
Paul D. White has been appoint ed textile sales promotion man ager of Celanese Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The primary lesson that is emerging from the Government's examination of the outlook for psychological warfare is that President Truman's campaign of truth, though nobly conceived, is not adequate of itself to cope with the Soviet challenge.

A round of meetings yesterday and last night developed indications that a basis might be reached for settlement of the threatened strike of three waiters' union locals against 125 members of the Restaurant League of New York, Inc. The estimated membership of the locals is "at least 5,000."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)-- T. Lamar Caudle, recently ousted by President Truman from his post in the Justice Department, said today that he called "rumors" about himself to the attention of the Attorney General in 1945, requested a Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry and "was completely exonerated."

A legislative program for the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, Inc., for next year was announced yesterday by Louis A. Capaldo, who was re-elected president for the fourth time. He sopke at the seventh annual convention at the New Yorker Hotel.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Dec. 14--Enthusiasm ran high in this winter sport playground in New York's back yard as several inches of snow surfaced all facilities today.
Installment 2 in the tale of our Christmas-shopping tour of the stores appears here today.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 15--The jet plane fleets were out again yesterday over North Korea and clashed in battles that cost the Communists one Soviet-built MIG15 destroyed and three damaged.

Industrial construction, military housing and other defense building work continue to keep operations at a high level in most parts of the country, in spite of a traditional year-end dip in contract awards, according to Engineering News-Record.

John Phillips Cosgrove of Locust, N.J., executive vice president of the American Radiator and Standard. Sanitary Corporation died on Thursday in the Columbia. Presbyterian Medical Center, after a brief illness. His age was 54.

BOSTON, Dec. 14--The Federal Government was urged here today to help develop Maine's vast ore deposits of manganese with the "same enthusiasm and intensity" that it put into development of the successful uranium ore-reduction process.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands Dec. 14--Pope Pius XII had given personal consent for a married former Protestant pastor to be ordained a priest in what Dutch Roman Catholic sources term a historic step toward the reunion of divided Christendom.
The following is a round-up of now products useful about the home.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 15-- United Nations delegates at Panmunjom rejected today the latest Communist truce proposal, which agreed to limited rotation of troops during the Korean armistice, but whose qualifications and conditions an Allied spokesmen called "a built-in veto."

BOSTON, Dec. 14 (UP)--The Braves appeared today to be waiting only a go ahead signal from Eddie Stanky, their former player who recently turned manager, to engineer a trade involving four established National League stars.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 14-- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion's remarks to the Knesset (Parliament) on Wednesday about the "bankruptcy" of Zionist leadership in the United States have started a storm of heated discussion here in which the delicate relations between United States Jews and Israel are much mixed with political rivalries.

PARIS, Dec. 14--The United Nations General Assembly asked the Soviet Union and the Cominform states today to resume normal diplomatic relations with Yugoslavia and settle their border disputes by peaceful means.

LONDON, Dec. 14--Speculation was rife in the stock markets here today that some action was imminent in the dollar-sterling exchange arrangements. Rumors ranged from further devaluation of sterling to a simplification of the exchange control system to eliminate some of the special kinds of sterling that now exist.

DETROIT, Dec. 14--The House subcommittee investigating middlemen's profits on defense contracts left Detroit today with new evidence that free competition was not always the rule in bidding for defense contracts.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of "Paint Your Wagon" on the night of Jan. 17 at the Shubert Theatre to raise funds for the Maternity Center Association. Heading the benefit committee are Mrs. Edward F. Hutton, Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse, Mrs. S. Maitland Goldsmith, Mrs. Edmund P. Rogers and Mrs. Virgil C. Damon.

The use of a roof for a television antenna cannot be included among the "essential services" demanded from a landlord, Supreme Court Justice Murray Hearn ruled yesterday in Brooklyn in nullifying an opinion by Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 14--The United States is scheduled to recognize tomorrow the present military Government of Syria created after the recent coup, according to sources here. It is believed that the Government has obtained agreement that Britain and France will follow the United States' example.
The State Congress of Industrial Organizations will ask the Legislature to conduct an open inquiry into workmen's compensation to forestall anticipated Republican efforts to amend the present law.

VIENNA, Dec. 14 (UP)--Alois Petr, Czechoslovak Minister of Transport and chairman of the People's party, died today at the age of 62 after an illness of several months, the official Czechoslovak radio announced tonight. The broadcast said he died in a Prague hospital.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Dec. 11, 1951, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

CAIRO, Dec. 14 (UP)--Egyptian underground terrorists, responding to appeals for intensified attacks against British nationals and Egyptians who collaborated with them, ambushed a British military car today, attacked a British soldier and mobbed two Egyptian employes of the British Embassy.

THE novelists usually wait until some time after a war has been won to attack the way it was fought. The big exposures are generally unveiled in disenchanted days of comparative tranquillity. That's natural. There is not the secure leisure to get them out much sooner. And, anyway, it is unfashionable and unprofitable to do otherwise, as well as perilous.

Kid Gavilan, Cuba's holder of the world welterweight title, pulled victory from defeat in Madison Square Garden last night when he knocked out Walter Cartier, Greenwich Village middleweight, in the tenth and final round of their non-title battle.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 15 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 1,098, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A.M., Saturday (4 P.M., Friday, Eastern standard time):

The National Labor Relations Board in a current decision holds that without regard to precisely what was said when an employer called in employes just before a collective-bargaining representation election the manner in which the meetings were conducted interfered with a free choice by the employes and warranted setting aside the election.

MELBOURNE, Saturday, Dec. 15 (AP)--The United States Davis Cup team completed a clean sweep of Sweden in the interzone tennis final today when Tony Trabert and Ted Schroeder scored straightset singles victories.

While most of Manhattan slept under warm blankets yesterday morning, fifty soldiers at Fort Monmouth, N.J., rolled out of their bunks in the pre-dawn cold preparatory to a two-hour ride to Manhattan to give blood for their brothers-in-arms in Korea.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 14 (AP)-- The Southeastern Conference refused tonight to ban football bowl games or spring practice.

Brillo Manufacturing Company through the J. Walter Thompson Company, has announced the big gest advertising schedules in its history for Brillo soap pads and cleanser. Newspaper schedules will be stepped up to weekly insertions in 108 papers in sixty-nine cities.

Dr. You Chan Yang, Korean Ambassador to the United States, charged here last night that the 7,000,000 Koreans who remain in North Korea "are facing deliberate and planned mass starvation" by the Communists.

JOHORE BAHRU, Malaya, Dec. 14--The last year of relentless, methodical hide-and-seek warfare against the Communist guerrillas in the big southernmost Malay state of Johore has yielded a toll of 400 rebels killed or captured. The figure is a measure of the indecisive, interminable character of the anti-Communist struggle in Malaya.
As an appropriate mantle of falling snow added a final touch to the scene, Mayor Impellitteri officially opened the Christmas season here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14--Members of the Democratic National Committee from fifteen states in the Middle West met here today with Frank E. McKinney, chairman of the committee, to map the party's strategy in the 1952 Presidential campaign.

ALBANY, Dec. 14--The Public Service Commission ruled today that the Consolidated Edison Company could not convert any more New York City customers to natural gas until the agency received assurance that alternate sources of supply for emergency service had been constructed.

BUCK HILLS FALLS, Pa., Dec. 14--An "aggressive" country-wide campaign to oppose, corruption, bribery and other evidences of moral delinquency in American society was approved here today at the final session of the first annual assembly of the Division of Christian Life and Work of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A.

An adult who was moved to contribute by a published letter from a child donor, other youngsters dipping into savings--and a wide range of gifts memorializing loved ones, who in many instances had been old-time contributors--were disclosed yesterday as the Neediest Case Fund for 1951-52 rose to $97,664.67.

Having reached 30 per cent of their goal of $4,000,000 to improve facilities and extend programs conducted by the Young Men's Christian Association, campaign workers were urged yesterday to push their efforts for contributions through the Christmas season.
HAVANA, Dec. 14 (AP)--John Barnum of Grand Rapids, Mich., and Marty Furgol of Lemont, Ill., were tied for first place today at the half-way mark of Havana's 72-hole invitation golf tournament.

Coffee and cocoa provided the main interest in commodity circles yesterday. In Rio de Janeiro Finance Minister Horacio Lafer revealed that Brazilian Federal funds were being used to manipulate coffee prices. Futures market prices here rose sharply, with ample evidence of Brazilian buying.
IF the letters of inquiry from anglers are an indication, there will be something of a housing shortage in Florida, for many are planning to make their first tropical fishing trip this season.
Stockholders of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, at a special meeting in Pittsburgh yesterday, approved an increase in the company's authorized indebtedness from $150,000,000 to $500,000,000.
Plans are under way for the Broadway presentation in February of "Mulligan's Snug," Robert McEnroe's Irish comedy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--President Truman held three conferences today on his projected drastic Governmental housecleaning program, but a fourth session was postponed by a heavy snowstorm that made it impossible for Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy to fly from New York.

A five-ton lead and steel container, which is to hold fifty grams of radium (about one-tenth of a pound) for a beam therapy unit at Roosevelt Hospital, was loaded yesterday aboard the Belgian Line steamship Houffalize for shipment to Antwerp.

ROME, Dec. 14--This is a pregnant moment in Europe, big with possibilities of progress or disaster. It is easier to feel than convey what is happening, but the reporter on the ground cannot fail to sense that out of the storm of talk, out of conferences, inquests and recriminations, fateful decisions are emerging.

The defense attorney for Tallulah Bankhead's former maid-secretary, Mrs. Evyleen Cronin, sought yesterday to portray the handling of Miss Bankhead's incidental expenses as a loose but long accepted system in which employes customarily filled in a check after the actress had signed it, and raised the amount if it proved insufficient.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange lost 19 to 57 points yesterday, with near months showing the most weakness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14-- Charles E. Wilson, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, and his first deputy, Manly Fleischmann, in charge of the Defense Production Administration, today appealed to business men to garner every ounce of iron and steel scrap they can find.
FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., Dec. 14 (AP) --Dr. Carl O. Lampland, assistant director of the Lowell Observatory and an astronomer at the observatory since 1903, died today in the Flagstaff Hospital.
Among the Christmas art shows, the one at the Downtown Gallery takes a high place, not only for its wide historical range but also for the quality of the pictures and sculpture on view.

LOWELL, Mass., Dec. 14--Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer urged New England leaders today to support the St. Lawrence seaway and power project so they might share in the "obvious" benefits of an additional 27,000,000 kilowatts of low-cost power a year.

ALBANY, Dec. 14--The Citizens Public Expenditure Survey, a taxpayers' organization, urged Governor Dewey today to make a $105,000,000 cut in state income and corporation franchise taxes for the 1952-53 fiscal year opening April 1.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14--The regents of the University of California named Dr. Raymond B. Allen, retiring president of the University of Washington, as chancellor of the California University's Los Angeles campus today.

Langdale Estates, Inc., of which the late Charles Walzer, operator, was the president, has sold the one-Story brick taxpayer building at 271-03 to 271-13 Eightieth Avenue, in Bellerose, Queens, to an investing client of Citadel Realty, brokers with offices in Bayside.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 14 --Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee declared tonight that this country had "much corruption within" and "there is no use in denying it."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--A dangerous trend toward the bureaucratic control of scientific research was discerned today by Dr. Vannevar Bush in his annual report as president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

Negotiations involving 32,000 workers in the Bethlehem Steel Company's eight shipyards on the Atlantic Coast are scheduled to open Tuesday in the company's New York offices, John J. Grogan, president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., said yesterday.

With but eight shopping days remaining before Christmas, New York City's leading retail stores have experienced sales volume declines for the third successive week, trade sources reported yesterday. A greater emphasis on promotional sales is now in prospect.

VIENNA, Dec. 14--Two members of the British Embassy staff in Prague were wounded by Czechoslovak security police yesterday when they were caught digging up secret documents from an underground hiding place, according to a broadcast tonight by the Prague radio.

Action by the Israeli Consulate on the strike by seamen here aboard the Israeli-flag freighter Yaffo yesterday resulted in the discharge of twenty-three seamen and their subsequent technical arrest by United States Immigration authorities.
OTTAWA, Dec. 14--Canada today abolished foreign exchange control.
STARKVILLE, Miss., Dec. 14 (UP)--Mississippi State College has hired Murray Warmath of Army's coaching staff as head coach and assigned him the job of building up a "winning football team."
Ninth Avenue, in the vicinity of the main post office, has become one of the busiest traffic areas in the city as a result of the huge volume of Christmas mail.

A program designed to enable Western Europe to rearm as planned without impairing its standards of living has been submitted to the Finance Ministers of the North Atlantic community by the special committee charged with surveying Europe's economic resources.

Traffic in this city, Westchester County, New Jersey and Connecticut came close to a standstill last night after a snowfall that struck heaviest during the evening rush hour forced thou sands of autoists to abandon their cars while others continued at a bumper-to-bumper crawl. WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The National Labor Relations Board set aside an election today because of the manner in which the employer communicated antiunion views to the workers before the voting.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 14 (AP)-- The Southern Conference tonight put the University of Maryland and Clemson College on probation for one year and, with two exceptions, slapped a football schedule boycott against them.
St. John's and Seton Hall, both unbeaten in college basketball circles thus far this season, will take part in Madison Square Garden games tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The United States has notified Sweden, Norway and Switzerland that they would be acceptable to the United Nations Command in Korea as members of a commission to inspect the keeping of a truce, now under negotiation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 14--An expenditure of $175,400,000 will be required in 1952 to carry out programs of urgent assistance to an estimated million Jews in Israel and in distressed areas throughout the world. This was the figure given today as the United Jewish Appeal opened its fourteenth annual national conference.

BODDHNATH, Nepal, Dec. 11-- The China Lama, the plump and jolly "reincarnated saint" who presides over the great, golden Boddhnath pagoda, reputedly the oldest Buddhist shrine in the world, says that Tibetan pilgrims to this holy place have told him that the Chinese Communists are firmly entrenched in the affections of the Tibetan masses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--A. management spokesman today blamed competition among the railroad unions for troubled labor relations on America's railroads.

A Federal Court jury yesterday took only an hour's deliberation to find an employer guilty of cheating blind employes of overtime pay. Federal Judge John W. Clancy Immediately sentenced the defendant, Morris Kleinerman, to a year and a day in jail and a $2,500 fine.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 14 --Four ships of the mothball fleet were recommissioned by a Navy nurse, a Wave lieutenant, a woman Marine captain and a Wave warrant officer in a ceremony today at the Green Cove Spring Naval Station.

In the investment banking antitrust trial yesterday Federal Judge Harold R. Medina said he would like to know, before the Government completed its case, which companies issuing securities were under banker control and which of the defendants exercised the control.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP)-- American farmers sold slightly more products this year than last and made 15 per cent more money, the United States Department of Agriculture reported today. The department said rising farm prices just about kept pace during the year with price increases in general.

The earnings of Phelps Dodge Corporation this year will approximate $43,000,000, or about $8.50 a share on the capital stock, Louis S. Cates, chairman, told stockholders at a special meeting held here yesterday to act upon a non-contributory pension plan for hourly workers, which they subsequently approved.

An alien held on Ellis Island for twenty-two months as a bad security risk was ordered released yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman, who noted that fifteen countries had refused him a visa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--Testimony tending to contradict statements made by Jess Larson, General Services Administrator, that he had ceased communication in 1948 with Frank Nathan of Pittsburgh and Miami, was introduced today before a House Ways and Means subcommittee investigating tax scandals.

A shipment of 56,500 packages of cigarettes lacking New York State tax stamps, which was being moved by truck from Maryland "in the direction of Canada," was seized yesterday near Harriman, N.Y., in Orange County, by state tax agents working in cooperation with the state police.
Another fabric name is about to become a general household term. Acetate, the man-made "beauty fiber," must now be recognized as a different fiber from viscose rayon or rayon.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 14-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and the Western High Commissioners turned today to consideration of the most difficult and complex of all the issues still separating the West German and the Allied officials in the negotiation of a new political status for the Federal Republic. This is how much the Germans are to pay for their share in the defense of Europe.

In response to a flood of protests from individuals and organizations objectively interested in the welfare and progress of the American Indian the Interior Department will hold hearings early next month on the impending regulations governing contracts between Indian tribes and their attorneys.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 14--Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, said today that as far as he could recall, the tax case to which Mr. Oliphant referred in his testimony was a "jeopardy assessment" case in which the person involved was being delayed in leaving on a vacation.
The New York Stock Exchange firm of Kling Co. will be formed on Jan. 2 by Seymour Kling, Edward A. Kerbs, Charles L. Woody Jr., and Louis A. Reilly, the last a limited partner.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP)--Seaflash, owned by Alvin Untermyer of New York, captured the featured seventh race at Tropical Park today, turning in the second fastest six-furlong time of the meeting, 1:10 1/5. It had been topped only by Yes You's 1:10.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--Steel companies will not be allowed to raise their prices to compensate for any wage increase they may grant in current wage negotiations, Roger L. Putnam, Economic Stabilization Administrator, said today.

Market value of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange last month fell $130,491,874, or an average of 23 cents a share. On Nov. 30 there were 2,603,547,374 shares of 1,490 issues, with a market value of $106,308,738,223.

Tabling the University of Pennsylvania's proposals for unrestricted football television, the Eastern College Athletic Conference yesterday endorsed a report favoring continued national controls and enjoining member colleges from making individual television commitments pending action by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14-- Another significant legal action involving television rights to motion pictures made for theatrical release has been instituted in the United States District Court in Los Angeles. The issue is a new one--that of an independent producer seeking to force a distributing company into selling pictures to television.

Governors of the New York Curb Exchange voted yesterday to follow the example of the New York Stock Exchange and close at 1 o'clock on Monday afternoon Dec. 24. The Montreal and Toronto Stock Exchanges voted to close at noon of that day.

Ilona Kabos, Hungarian-born pianist, faced her first American audience at Town Hall last night and immediately established herself as a performer of strength and character. Her playing favored the big line and the grand style, not because she could make a quick impression in this way, but quite convincingly because this was a natural approach to her.

A world of wonderful surprise where almost nothing is beyond the realm of possibility and all St. Nicholas' children are even better than they should be and are duly rewarded, is depicted in Fifth Avenue's windows for Christmas, 1951.

ROME, Dec. 14--By a vote of 262 to 200, the Chamber of Deputies deprived Communist Deputy Francesco Moranino of parliamentary immunity today and authorized not only his indictment on a charge of murder but also his immediate arrest. It is understood that Moranino has found asylum in Czechoslovakia.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec, 14-- Navy's undefeated quintet scored its fourth victory of the season tonight, downing Dartmouth, 64--55. High scorer for the middies was Big John Clune, who tallied 30 points, 22 in the first half.

PARIS, Dec. 14--The finance and other ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty countries at a meeting here today faced for the first time the full economic implications of the rearmament proposed under the treaty. Several of them were highly embarrassed by the financial and political tasks imposed by the new defense program placed before them.

Sidney M. Levy, 27, a former $75-a-week textile salesman who pleaded guilty last spring to first degree larceny in a $40,000 swindle and admitted spending the money on a chorus girl, yesterday received a suspended sentence and was placed on probation for ten years by General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein.

Charges made by former Mayor William O'Dwyer and echoed by other Democrats that the state has been "shortchanging" New York in the distribution of state funds are unfounded, according to a finding made by two experts for the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

In a candlelit setting of white chrysanthemums and gladiolus blossoms yesterday afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church, Miss Alison Thayer Prescott, daughter of Mrs. William Fabian Walsh of 1175 Park Avenue and the late Joseph Parsons Prescott of Holyoke, Mass., was married to Craig Francis Cullinan of Houston, Tex., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Craig Cullinan.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 15-In St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Judith Matthews Bailey, daughter of Mrs. Tyra Clingman Bailey, and the late Mr. Bailey, was married to Carter Lee Refo of Norfolk, son of the late Capt. Miles Refo Jr., U. S. N., and the late Mrs. Refo.

BONN, Dec. 15-The Germans, most numerous and potentially powerful of West European peoples, are approaching another of those periods in which solid achievements clash with political and psychological forces, creating situations which never fail to confuse and often frighten the rest of Europe.

The pattern of the ground fighting in Korea Saturday was basically the same as it has, been for the past several days, with forces of the United Nations Command standing alert at their posts, maintaining and adjusting their positions and sending out patrols.

ALBANY, Dec. 35--Governor Dewey today appointed Edward J. Donovan of Mount Kisco, a member of the State Board of Parole and a Veteran of twenty-seven years' experience in the prison and probation field, as the state's new Commissioner of Correction. The salary is $16,000 a year.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France, Dec.15--The United States will propose soon to Britain that if the latter will publicly pledge herself to "support" the planned European Army, the United States will do the same.

American colleges and universities are not doing an adequate job of training enough people for the profession of social work. This finding was reported last week in a 400-page report issued by the National Council on Social Work Education.

PITTSBURGH. Dec. 15--A University of Pittsburgh sophomore wrote a new chapter in Panther athletic history and at the game time snapped Columbia's long regular-season winning string, 65--69, as Memorial Field House was dedicated tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec, 15 (UP)The Army contended today that psychological warfare had led to the capture of about one-third of the 170,000 enemy prisoners taken in the Korean war.
TORONTO, Dec. 15--Two goals by Sid Smith helped carry the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 4-to-1 victory over New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game here tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15City officials are becoming incensed over what they charge is discrimination against San Francisco in Army policy governing the transportation of furloughed veterans of the Korean war to their homes.

Failure to solve the problem of court congestion, especially in accident cases, may lead to a loss of right to full trial, Supreme Court Justice Charles D. Breitel said yesterday. He made this statement at the seventy-sixth annual meeting of the New York State Shorthand Reporters Association at the Statler Hotel.

The famed Gould-Whitney-Vanderbilt mansion at 857 Fifth Avenue will add another chapter to its glamorous career next March, when the fifty-room residence at the northeast corner of Sixtyseventh Street will become a new world cultural center.

LONDON, Dec. 15--The Treasury announced tonight that Britain would pay both the interest and principal, due Dec. 31 on the United States and Canadian loans of 1946. The payments due amount to about $176,000,000, and the Bank of England will have to sell gold to meet the debt.

THE Columbia Television Workshop-dedicated to ex perimental techniques in script writing, acting and casting-will present an adaptation of Cervante's classic story, "Don Quixote," on its premiere show over the C. B. S. network on Sunday, Jan. 13, at 5:30 P. M.

DANIA, Fla. -- The Seminole Indians of Florida, slowly increasing in population, today number nearly 900. Taken together they raised the 1951-52 total to $107,623.57.

The National Association for Mental Health, which has held its first annual meeting at Chicago, becomes the pillar and ground for a broadening everywhere in the nation of the mental hygiene movement that began in 1908 with the publication of Clifford W. Beers' "A Mind That Found Itself."

A RENEWED surge of activity on the part of members of the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street, is re flected in the club's annual December members' show. Members entered more than 160 prints, some in color, on a great variety of subjects. The show will continue through Dec. 31.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 15Once a palatial showplace where financiers, diplomats and social leaders from many parts of the world were entertained, the mansion of the late J.P. Morgan is now a white elephant to Glen Cove officials. It has been owned by the city since June, when it was taken over from a realty company for unpaid taxes in foreclosure.

Ground and flight service personnel of Pan American Airways at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, and La Guardia Airport walked out on strike at 12:01 o'clock this morning-twenty-four hours ahead of the time scheduled for their walkout at major airports around the world.

THE joys of Atlantic salmon fishing will never be equitably distributed among American anglers, nor even among the residents of those provinces where this fine sporting fish exists in greatest numbers, but through the efforts of the Atlantic Salmon Association there is every chance that the future of the species will be brighter than its past.

THE more I see of other countries the more persuaded I become that the English are a very odd people. Their virtues are due to their vices, and their vices to their virtues. They are tolerant-more so I think than any other large nation-because They consider ideas unimportant. In other countries ideas are thought important and therefore dangerous; in England ideas are thought negligible and therefore not worth persecuting.

The first of several floating radio stations ordered by the Voice of America to dodge Soviet jamming and reach new areas behind the iron Curtain will go into action early next year, according to the Office of International Broadcasting of the State Depatrment.

FESTIVE displays of plants mark the holiday season here in New York City. The traditional exhibit of 3,500 poinsettias in the Prospect Park greenhouse, Brooklyn, will open Thursday and continue through Jan. 15. These colorful tropical plants are already on view at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden greenhouse, 1000 Washington Ave.

To attract students into the teaching profession, the New York State Board of Regents is sponsoring a recruitment program for elementary school teachers. Financial grants-in-aid will be given students to induce them into the profession of teaching.

The forty-hour workweek at sea, long a principal goal of the maritime unions, became a reality today for some 55,000 members of three seagoing affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, as another of the terms of a June negotiations agreement went into effect.

COMPULSORY motor vehicle inspection in this state be fore 1953 is one of the toppriority objectives in the legislative program adopted by the New York State Automobile Association. THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 15--A case that may set some kind of record for amiability and lack of practical importance came before the International Court of Justice today when Britain and France asked for a ruling on the ownership of a group of uninhabited islets in the English Channel.

WASHINGTON Dec. 15-The President, who on Wednesday was reported by a visitor to be angry with appointees who had "sold him down the river" and determined on a "drastic" housecleaning, on Thursday at his press conference made it clear that his anger did not extend to the general condition these appointees have revealed. And the housecleaning he proposed did not meet the definition of "drastic" in many quarters.

THE news that the Metropolitan Opera was going to present Igor Stravinsky's "The Rake's Progress" next season came from so many unofficial sources last week that an effort was made to track it down. Unbeaten St. John's University packed too much height and displayed considerably more polish than the opposition last night in sweeping to an 82-62 triumph over Rhode Island in the feature game of a twin bill at Madison Square Garden. ROME. WITH the coming of win ter and its unstable weather, of which the recent floods furnish elo quent and tragic testimony, the traditionally outdoors-minded Italian film industry is returning to the less realistic but more easily controlled settings of Rome's motion-picture studios, spread to the four winds along the ancient roads leading out of the city.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Benson Tallman of 1158 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Beekman, to Dr. Ralph Eugene Snyder, son of Mrs. Ralph G. Snyder of Herkimer, N. Y., and the late Mr. Snyder.

MT.HOPE, N.Y., Dec. 15-- Willie Cuthbertson and the No. 1 rink of the Caledonian Curling Club of New York reached the semi-final round in the thirtyfourth bonspiel for the Utica Cup at the St. Andrews Golf Club this evening.

Stock trading gave a tiresome performance last week. With slow progress being made in the steel wage negotiations and Korean peace talks, a more cautious attitude prevailed in financial markets. Year-end tax selling and profit-taking--following two weeks of advancing pricesbrought a halt to the rally in the stock market.

Seasonal music will be heard this week at two recorded concerts at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Fortysecond Street. One concert will be held between noon and 2 P.M. on Wednesday and the second, also on Wednesday, at 8:15 P. M. The evening program will include Christmas songs and madrigals performed by the English Singers.

The University of Arizona won the fourth annual moot court contest of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York in a divided decision over Georgetown University, victors in the 1950 competition.

Wine-drinkers will realize that the impossible has been found: A New York restaurant that serves sound vintages at about the prices one pays in retail stores and at a fraction of what other eating places charge.

One thousand children and their parents attended a pageant of the Nativity yesterday morning at St. George's Prostestant Episcopal Church, 207 East Sixteenth Street, one of the many pre-Christmas observances held throughout the city.

MONTERREY, Mexico, Dec. 16 (UP)--The United States took the final event in the International Horse Show this afternoon, winning the Cup of the Nation jumping competition by a 1 -point margin over Mexico.

The Miami Airline, Inc., operator of the C-46 that crashed in Elizabeth, N.J., yesterday, is one of sixty-five non-scheduled air carriers handling cargo and passengers on an irregular basis. The continued operation of all "non-skeds" is in jeopardy because of a so-called "death edict" regulation promulgated by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

MEXICO, Dec. 16--The conflicting psychology of delegates from countries with conflicting ideologies has been emphasized in the Fourth International Congress on Mental Health, which opened here last Wednesday and will run through this Wednesday.

The vast structure of modern county government is honeycombed with old-fashioned feepaying offices. The men who hold these public offices are paid, in part or in full, on a fee basis. There are thousands of them.

If he has nothing else of substantial value in his new role as manager of the Cardinals, Eddie Stanley will at least have the National League's leading hitter on his side during the 1952 campaign. He has the evidence of the official averages for 1951, released yesterday, to confirm this prospect, for The Man, Stan Musial, is practically off by himself in leading the league's batters.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16--The steel ingot operating rate advanced one point last week to 104 per cent of rated capacity. This was a welcome surprise in the industry but it was expected that because of the scrap situation and the possibility of a strike next year, every effort would be made to get the most out of equipment in the next month or so.

The 7 East Forty-seventh Street Corporation, Lionel Edison, president, bought the six-story brick building on lot 25 by 100 feet at that address from Charles A. Robinson and insured title with the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.

Edmond A. Ward, president of the American District Telegraph Company, a branch of Western Union, which provides fire and burglary protection through electrical systems, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 710 Park Avenue. His age was 55.

LONDON, Dec. 16--The Earl of Perth, who as Sir Eric Drummond was Secretary-General to the League of Nations from its formation until 1933, died yesterday at his home at Rogate, Sussex. He was 75 years old.

The first section of the 1,186-page report of the Education Study of the Mayor's Management Survey is made public this morning and will be followed by three other sections on successive days. This study, directed by George D. Strayer and Louis E. Yavner, required thirteen months and a staff of twenty analysts.

The death toll of fifty-six in the crash yesterday in Elizabeth, N.J., represents the second worst air disaster in commercial aviation history in the United States but sets a new death record on unscheduled airliners.
PARIS, Dec. 16--British Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Eden are expected here early tomorrow.

The Elain Art Realty Corporation sold the one-story taxpayer on plot 51 by 105 feet at 356-58 South Broadway, Yonkers, in Westchester County, to an investing client of Daniel D. Cantor, Brooklyn attorney. The building is occupied by four tenants and was sold subject to a twenty-one-year leasehold on the property plus two options of renewal.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16--Maj. Gen. David McCoach Jr., a former commissioner of the District of Columbia, died last night in Walter Reed General Hospital. He was 64 years old.

The metropolitan area was threatened with a bagel famine yesterday as thirty-two of the city's thirty-four bagel bakeries remained closed in a dispute between 300 members of Local 338 of the Bagel Bakers of America, A.F.L., and the Bagel Bakers Association.

Aside from Eddie Price's wrapping up of the National Football League individual ground-gaining championship and his setting of a new record for carries, there was no significance to yesterday's "Icicle Bowl" game in which the Giants conquered the Yanks, 27--17, at the Stadium.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 16--The Communist party of Croatia has published an official report giving an unvarnished account of the struggle of the peasants against the collectivized agriculture in that republic.

PARIS, Dec. 16--Georges Villiers, president of the Council of European Industrial Federations, who has just returned from a trip to the United States, said today that the group of European manufacturers he headed had a beneficial and instructive visit that would aid the development of Europe's production. He said they witnessed with great interest the accomplishments in the specialization and standardization of industry.
Net losses on the New York Cotton Exchange last week ran from $7.45 to $9.80 a bale through Friday. The December delivery went off the board at noon Friday $9.85 below the price of a week previous.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 16--South Jersey's industrial expansion, highlighted by the invasion of this tomato-growing countryside by two huge steel plants, has sent shipping records of the CamdenPhiladelphia port area skyrocketing to new highs.

The New York Rovers beat Eddie Barry's Boston Olympics, 5 to 1, in a rough Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. With sharp action and several fist fights enlivening proceedings, the New Yorkers whipped the powerful Pics for the fourth time this campaign.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (UP)--The Illinois football team departed tonight for the West Coast and a repeat performance in the Rose Bowl, where it started the Big Ten on an unbroken string of victories in 1947.
PARIS, Dec. 16--United Nations diplomats expect to wind up debate this week on several major controversies of the sixth session of the General Assembly.

VIENNA, Dec. 16--Clarence Meyer, chief of the Marshall Plan mission to Austria, and Ben H. Thibodeaux, deputy chief, flew to Washington yesterday in response to a State Department summons. According to mission officials here, they will confer on the amount of Mashall Plan aid that Austria will receive during the next fiscal year.

The United States had a rough time of it at the United Nation's meetings in Paris last week. What with the ArabAsian bloc, the Latin-American bloc and the always rambunctious Soviet bloc, the United States was not exactly playing a domineering or even dominant role. This is not necessarily a cause for complaint.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 16-- A mass of rubble in a sluggish stream and gaping holes in two buildings hit by the flaming airliner were mute testimony tonight to the grim tragedy that shattered the sabbath quiet of this North Jersey community.

Most local home furnishings stores are not yet equaling last year's holiday dollar volume except in furniture, a canvass yesterday of several leading outlets revealed. A few stores, however, reported they are running slightly ahead in all departments.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Dec. 16--Merrill (Mezzy) Barber today turned in two almost flawless flights on the Bear Mountain Park 50-meter slide to win the annual Torger Tokle Memorial ski jump for the second straight year. The 32-year-old veteran leaped 152 and 157 feet, both jumps combining outstanding form, to carry off Class A honors.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 16-- The year for all-breed dog shows ended tonight with the Worcester County Kennel Club's fixture. For the celebrated California boxer, Dr. and Mrs. R.C. Harris' Ch. Bang Away of Sirrah Crest, 1951 closed just as had 1950. Bang Away took best in show in the event for the second straight year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, who was relieved of his command on charges of failure to heed policy laid down by his civilian chiefs, declared himself in favor today of tighter civilian control over the Army.

True Meaning of His Coming Not Yet Clear in Many Minds, Dr. Van Dusen Says The Rev. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen characterized man's false interpretations of Jesus Christ yesterday as a "tragic obligato" running through the centuries. Dr. Van Dusen is president of Union Theological-Seminary and vice president of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16--All grain markets were reactionary last week, price declines being substantial all along the line. Heavy profit-taking on recent hard spots was the major factor but after the turn in the trend came there were a number of factors that temporarily at least unsettled the markets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16-Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy and J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, are expected to begin working as a team after President Truman announces the nature, authority and personnel of his special inquiry into corruption in government.
AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 16--The Maine sardine canning season, 1,000,000 fewer cases than is normal in a season.

The Oratorio Society of New York presented its 128th performance of Handel's "Messiah" at Carnegie Hall Saturday night, and once more a large audience was thrilled by the superb work, which remains one of the summits of human artistic achievement.
Formation of a new Guggenheim Brothers partnership to directly succeed the firm of the same name that was formed in 1949 was announced yesterday by Harry F. Guggenheim, senior partner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16--Authorization for a Jan. 1 steel strike, expected from the union's policy committee tomorrow, will start the dispute on the way to the Wage Stabilization Board, officials said today. This would mean a postponement of the strike date, possibly for thirty-one days.

LONDON, Dec. 16--Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden left tonight for Paris and two days of conversations with French authorities preparatory to their Washington visit next month.
Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte" will be revived at the Metropolitan Opera on Friday, Dec. 28 and will be sung in English. The title has been translated to "Women Are Like That."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16--Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Preparedness subcommittee, called on the Army today to stop sending some recruits to Hawaii for basic training.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (AP)-- Otto Graham's pinpoint passing and a stout defense that held the once feared Philadelphia Eagles' ground attack to a net 65 yards gave the Cleveland Browns a 24to-9 National Football League victory today. It was their eleventh straight after losing their opening game.

A delayed action strike in 125 of Manhattan's major restaurants appeared set for some time today. Three locals of the Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union, A.F.L., representing 2,500 employes ready to walk out yesterday, held off to give "Sunday diners a break," union leaders reported.

The American homemaker who collects unusual accessories might do well to inspect a large collection of pottery and basketware now on view at Kogei, 40 West Eighteenth Street. Imported from Japan, where similar items are in everyday use in homes, these objects are of the same type as those included in an exhibit of Mr. and Mrs. Antonin Raymond's collection at the Museum of Modern Art last Spring.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP)--Two early morning fires less than three blocks apart forced some 550 persons to flee today in 12 below zero weather. None of the occupants was injured, but one fireman was slightly hurt.

Mayor Impellitteri has been informed by his financial and budgetary advisers that the city's operating expenses for the fiscal year starting July 1, 1952 will have to exceed by at least $150,000,000 the record-breaking $1,336,400,575 provided in the current budget.

No society can hope to maintain stability by means of a military order which subordinates the individual to the state, the Rev. Dr. Chester A. Pennington declared in his sermon yesterday at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16--Swift Co., Chicago meat packers, reported today that its net income for the fiscal year ended Oct. 27 declined 25 per cent from the preceding twelve months desipte a rise in sales to a new peak of more than S2,500,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)-- President Truman was reported today to be trimming the new spending budget in an effort to hold it several billions below sums talked of just a few weeks ago.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (AP)-- The Los Angeles Rams, with an unblushing bow to the San Francisco Forty-Niners, marched into their third straight conference title today and the right to battle the Cleveland Browns for the National Football League championship here next Sunday.

Activity in the wholesale market here last week centered on the placing of special orders and open orders for fill-in holiday stock, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Good response to Christmas merchandise caused many rush orders. Some activity was noted on spring merchandise and on items for January selling and promotion.

EACH autumn with Christmas in the offing books of phbtographs bloom in the bookstores like chrysanthemums in the florist shops. Some of them are as lush and showy as the giant-size blossoms which cost a dollar apiece. Others are less imposing; but, preserved in paper and ink, they all last beyond their season. Liffey Restaurant Corp., store at 704 8th Ave--Walter Scott Co., brokers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 (AP) --San Francisco's Forty-Niners, scoring a touchdown after a sensational 51-yard punt return by rookie halfback Joe Arenas, defeated Detroit, 21--17, today to knock the Lions out of the National Conference championship of the National Football League.

The Very Rev. Hughell E.W. Fosbroke, dean emeritus of General Theological Seminary of New York, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine that "our general acceptance of the fundamental obligations of society is not merely, an adjustment to our environment," but the "claim that God makes upon us."
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 16-- For the eighth successive time, Arthur Knapp today won the sailing dinghy regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club with his Agony.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)-- The average American is 30 years old, is married, and has a wife and two children. Furthermore, the Census Bureau said today, he owns his own home. Or, rather, he and the loan company do, but he is struggling to pay off the mortgage.

LONDON, Dec. 16--The British Government's decision to meet the principal and interest of payments on the American and Canadian loans due at the end of the year and to permit immediate reopening of the London foreign exchange market came as something of an anticlimax to the London market.

The coldest weather of the season numbed the city last night, and the Weather Bureau forecast little let-up for today. Icy patches, the remnants of Friday night's 3.3-inch snowfall, made walking and driving hazardous.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16-- Joseph L. Mankiewicz, Academy Award winning writer-director of "All About Eve" and other notable films for Twentieth Century-Fox is about to place his signature on a three-way contract with MetroGoldwyn-Mayer as a writer, director and producer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)-- Representative B. Carroll Reece, Republican of Tennessee, predicted today that southern and border states would give Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio almost solid backing for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Thoughtfulness of programming and performance marked Jennie Tourel's appearance in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. It was her only solo recital of the season, although she is to sing with the Bach Aria Group later.

ALBANY, Dec. 16--Brooklyn's Democratic, legislators are planning to attempt revenge against the borough's only two Republican Assemblymen for the Congressional reapportionment plan by which the Legislature on Dec. 5 reshuffled Kings County districts.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16--Mrs. Elizabeth Meriwether Gilmer, known as Dorothy Dix to millions of readers of her newspaper column, died of a heart ailment here this afternoon in Touro Infirmary. Her age was 90. She had been in the hospital for more than a year.
A good many words have been uttered in praise of the Governor Alfred E. Smith Houses, but one really should go and see hopeful things in these days of the murky outlook.
Clarence Nowack has been appointed divisional market supervisor of women's, men's, boys' and children's shoes for the main store division of Associated Merchandising Corporation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 16-- The results of the annual election of Rhodes scholars in the United States were announced here today by Dr. Frank Aydelotte, American secretary to the Rhodes trustees. Thirty-two scholars representing twenty-eight states and twentyfour colleges were chosen from 400 competitors after an intensive screening.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 16 (AP) --Kentucky's N.C.A.A. championship basketball team aimed today at regaining national prestige in its clash with St. John's here tomorrow night.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman has ordered the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation to show cause Thursday why it should not be directed to end service on thirty-eight unprofitable routes in the Bronx and one in Manhattan.

Zoia Polewska, Ukrainian 'cellist who made her New York debut in Carnegie Hall last night, is an unusual--and, it must be said, an uneven--performer. A sizable audience heard her play and applauded with enthusiasm.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Dec. 16 --Fifty years ago today David Edwards returned to his home town here and hung out a shingle proclaiming to his neighbors that he was now a doctor of medicine qualified to minister to the aches and pains of young and old in true family physician style.

LONDON, Dec. 16--Elements of the Egyptian police in Ismailia were accused by Britain today of a "ruthless and murderous intention" to precipitate disorder "with the object of killing members of the British forces" in the Suez Canal zone.

Though of unequal importance, the financial moves announced this past week-end by Canada and Great Britain are both to be welcomed as constructive contributions toward the freer convertibility of national currencies required for the expansion of international trade and investment.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 17--A small raiding party of United Nations troops made another quick stab early yesterday at the Communist position on the West Korean front directly south of Panmunjom, the site of the cease-fire talks. The Reds, calling up reinforcements, held stubbornly to their position.

Victorious over miss Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, in the final of the national singles at Forest Hills last summer, Miss Maureen Connolly has been named the No. 1 performer in the 1951 women's rankings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association. She displaces Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont of Bellevue, Del., who captured the top berth three consecutive times.

Terry Sawchuk guided the Detroit Red Wings to a 3 to 1 victory over the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. The chunky goalie for Tommy Ivan's sextet was a constant target for the Blues' shots all through the game, but he played his position almost perfectly, holding the local athletes scoreless until late in the final period.

The biggest thing to happen in the foreign exchange market last week came after the close of trading on Friday. That was the announcement on Saturday by the Bank of England relaxing control of the dealings in pound sterling in world markets thus permitting it to find its own level.

The Rev. James M. Gillis rounded out half a century of priesthood yesterday when he celebrated solemn mass in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Ninth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, on the fiftieth anniversary of his ordination. There was a congregation of 1,800.
The picture of the "ideal child" frequently presented to parents these days--an "outgoing, vivacious youngster with many friends, who knows what he wants to do and can make his desires clear"-- ...

Legitimate sales of distilled spirits are falling off. A drop of almost 11 per cent in dollar volume for the period from April to October from the same months in 1950 is being reported to the trade this week by Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 16--The dispute between the Seamen's Union of Haifa and Israel's General Federation of Labor (Histadrut), which has tied up seventeen merchant ships for various periods, entered its sixth week today.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 16--Indonesian equities on the Amsterdam stock market have during the last two years been exceptionally depressed. Since the end of 1949 the general average of Dutch shares fell 12 per cent but the Indonesian average dropped 30 per cent.

The Theatre Guild's production of Bernard Shaw's drama, "Saint Joan," starring Uta Hagen in the title role, will not close on Jan. 5 as previously announced. Instead, the presentation will move from the Cort Theatre to the Century, where it will be offered at popular prices beginning on Jan. 8.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16-- Price Administrator Michael V. Di Salle expressed cautious optimism tonight that prices would be kept within bounds next year. In a television interview, the refused to predict the percentage ...

C. Gardner Mallonee, former athletic director at Johns Hopkins, was named president of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association at its sixty-ninth annual meeting at the Hotel Statler yesterday. Mallonee headed a slate presented by the nomination committee. All other officers recommended by the committee were elected.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 17-- United Nations armistice delegates at Panmunjom withdrew yesterday their demand for immediate inspection by the International Red Cross of Communist prisoner of war stockades in a move to expedite an exchange of captives after the Korean truce is signed.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 16--Lyon Boston, president of the Bill of Rights Commemorative Society, today assailed recent governmental corruption as exemplified in the current tax scandals and called upon the church to help "turn the rascals out."

From Yonkers and from Mountain Lakes, N.J., came donations to the Neediest Cases yesterday from children whose penciled messages bespoke an earnestness far beyond their years. Adult donors swelled the day's receipts to $7,335,71.

The appointment of Clinton L. Hodder to a new joint post as director of personnel and labor relations was announced yesterday by the Moore-McCormack Lines, effective immediately. Mr. Hodder, who has been in charge of the company's labor relations, will take on also the personnel duties of Louis F. Klein.

Puccini's "La Boheme" received its third performance of the season Saturday night at the Metropolitan. In this presentation of the popular work Hilde Gueden assumed the role of Musetta for the first time with the company.

Fifty members of the Young People's Orchestral Society performed in a concert yesterday from which they derived not only the pleasure of playing but the knowledge that as a result of the performance the Children's Aid Society would have 500 more toys to distribute to needy children.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 16-- The list of those killed in the Florida-bound plane here today follows:
