GENEVA, Dec. 15--The criticism leveled at Belgium's participation in the European defense effort by the Executive Group of the Temporary Council Committee of the North Atlantic Treaty Council puts a serious dilemma before United States foreign and economic policy makers as well as before the Government of Belgium.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP)-- The Salary Stabilization Board today authorized employers who had no previously established bonus plans to pay year-end bonuses for 1951 under certain conditions.
The Korean Consul General, D. Y. Namkoong, has "a heart filled with gratitude for the kindness of the people of Buffalo" who collected 100,000 pounds of clothing for the "Clothes for Korea" drive.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 16--One thousand Jewish communal leaders here unanimously adopted today a goal of $151,500,000 for the United Jewish Appeal's nation-wide campaign to meet the needs of Jews throughout the world with special emphasis on Israel.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 16-- The Majlis, or lower house of Parliament, adopted today a resolution instructing the Government to present within one month legislation prohibiting the use, sale or manufacture of alcoholic beverages. The Senate has already approved the measure.

The Public Utilities Advertising Association heard itself spanked in two respects at a meeting here recently. Its advertising was described as representing "too much corporate muscle-flexing." Its publicity was described as futile rewriting by operating vice presidents of copy prepared by skilled news writers on their staffs.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 16-- Hurlbut William Smith, president of the L.C. Smith-Corona Typewriter Company, banker and civic leader, died today at his home here after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage Dec. 9. He was 86 years old. He had been active in the typewriter corporation, one of the largest in the world, until two days before he was stricken.

Subway fares, based on how far a straphanger travels and what time of day he sets out, have been recommended to the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey by two experts on municipal finance. The fares would range from a nickel to a quarter and would be computed by an electronic key device.

There is an element of profound human tragedy in the fact that the Korean truce negotiations should have to be deadlocked on the issue of an exchange of prisoners. To us, of course, the whole question seems to be one of simple good morals and good behavior. There is, unfortunately, no evidence of a corresponding point of view in the Communist camp.

LONDON, Dec. 16--It is possible that next year the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will make some loans for projects in the British colonies, Eugene R. Black, president of the bank, stated today.

AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 16--Stocks of crude rubber throughout the world, excluding countries behind the Iron Curtain, will total about 1,800,000 long tons by the end of the year, an increase of almost 570,000 tons over the amount available prior to World War II, according to John L. Collyer, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company.

EDDIE STANKY was playing second base for the Boston Braves in 1948. He had been traded by the Dodgers a couple of months previously after a bitter salary dispute with Branch Rickey. There was a lull in the play one afternoon and Larry Goetz, the umpire, walked over to where Eddie was industriously scuffing up some dirt near the bag with his spikes.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16--A New Year's Eve strike in the nation's principal steel and aluminum mills will be authorized here tomorrow by the wage policy committee of the United Steelworkers of Americe, C.I.O.

Adversity can be no stranger to persons living in the world of today, where trouble seems universal. As the traditionally happy Christmas season approaches, many New Yorkers find themselves still searching for a security of spirit, mind and body. Despite this rough going, most of us will surmount our difficulties and achieve personal lives marked by peace of mind and contentment.
ROME, Dec. 16 (UP)--George Santayana said today that at 88 years of age he did not have as many answers to the world's problems as he had half a century ago.

A large number of Governmentowned vessels carrying foreign-aid coal and grain shipments suffered serious delay in the second half of last month because of shortages of skilled seagoing personnel, it was made known yesterday in the semi-monthly operational report of the National Shipping Authority.

Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy indicated strongly yesterday that he would accept the role of investigator of corruption in the Government if President Truman offered it and stated flatly that he would not accept any assignment that had strings attached to it.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 16-- Two members of the local police department were engaged in routine tinkering with their fifty-watt FM receiver today when they were suddenly party to a conversation with the Great Plains.

A five-alarm fire in a twostory taxpayer at 848-56 Broadway blazed for three and a half hours last night and caused $500,000 damage to six stores and business lofts. The fire tied up traffic in Union Square.
The American life insurance policyholder is the most versatile investor in the nation.

Orson Welles, who back in 1938 frightened the countryside with his tale of the invaders from Mars, is not apt to disturb many listeners with his current venture, "The Lives of Harry Lime," which was produced in London and is being heard by transcription at 9 P.M. Wednesdays over WJZ, among other stations.

Ludwig Lenel and Alan MacNeil, were the composers represented on Saturday night's Composers' Forum at the McMillin Theatre, Columbia University. Mr. Lenel's music came first on the program. He writes, if his String Quartet (1950-51) is a representative example, in an introspective manner that is quite modern in harmonic devices but post-romantic in style and conception.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 16 --In the Congregational Churchin-the-Highlands this afternoon, Miss Muriel Stuck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. William Stuck of White Plains, was married to Robert Sanford McCord, son of Mr. and Mrs. M.S. McCord of Little Rock, Ark. The Rev. Arthur S. Wheelock performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Roger Smith Hotel.

"Conservative preparedness" should be the key of executives' planning for the "inevitable competition for orders that lies ahead," according to Henry H. Heimann, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly business review and annual forecast of prospects for the new year, released for publication today.

Midwinter wardrobe doldrums can easily be dispelled with the addition of a few good separates, such as those we offer in today's Patterns of The Times. You've heard of the big bouffant sleeves that contribute so much glamor to blouse or dress. Well, here is a pretty separate blouse that can put you in the 1952 fashion swim in a jiffy if you are smart with your needle.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (UP)--Charlie Trippi, working from a newly developed spread formation, passed for one touchdown and ran for two more today to pace the Chicago Cardinals to a 24-to-14 triumph over the Chicago Bears in two-below-zero temperature.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 16 (AP)-- Barring a world upheaval, the proud city of Melbourne intends to play host to the 1956 Olympic Games. There's doubt elsewhere that the Queen city, of Victoria, can digest the huge international spectacle, but there is none here.

The throttling effect of a sudden strike at midnight Saturday by 5,800 flight service employes of the Pan American World Airways began to subside yesterday, but not before hundreds of passengers bound for world points had found their plans badly disrupted.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 16 (AP)--Uruguay voted today to abolish the Presidency and substitute for it a nine-man council.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 17 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 1,100 covering Sunday's operations:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 16-- The Supreme Court will have to "clarify if not modify" two decisions in recent years that Federal or state aid to religion is unconstitutional, 100 educators from state teachers colleges throughout the country were told today.
Four Constellations will fly from Burbank, Calif., on Thursday with seventy-five Hollywood personalities, who will give U.S.O. shows during the holidays in Korea, Alaska, Newfoundland, Iceland ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 (AP) --The man who directs the Voice of America said today that it was gratifying, and even a little surprising, to find concrete evidence of how well we are doing in the face of the physical odds against us in the Orient.
The Hufstader Singers, a welldisciplined group of nine men and nine women under the direction of Robert Hufstader, gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 16--John C. Oestreicher of Larchmont, who rose from copy boy to foreign news editor of The International News Service, died today in New Rochelle Hospital after a long illness. His age was 46.

The victory of President Truman over Governor Dewey at the polls in 1948 was hailed at the time-- and is still regarded by many--as one of the stunning political upsets of American history. Actually, it was never necessary to seek far for an explanation of that phenomenon, much less resort, as have some, to purely romantic interpretation.
The art exhibitions opening this week are not as numerous as in the weeks immediately past, but they include offerings of interest.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (UP)--The Chicago Black Hawks spotted the champion Maple Leafs a threegoal lead tonight and then came back to win, 4--3, on Bill Mosienko's last-period score past Goalie Al Rollins.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 16-- Fifty-six persons were killed this afternoon when a Florida-bound non-scheduled passenger plane fell flaming into the shallow Elizabeth River seven minutes after it had taken off from Newark Airport. There were no survivors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)-- The magazine U.S. News World Report reported today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower had given a final "no" to offers of the Democratic nomination for President, and "yes" to Republicans who wanted to put his name before their party's nominating convention.

PARIS, Dec. 17--Leaders of the nationalist movement in France's North African protectorate of Tunisia will meet tomorrow with United Nations delegates of all Arab states for an "exchange of views" on the recent French rejection of Tunisian demands for internal sovereignty.
Donld R. Wilson, national commander of the American Legion described the State Department yesterday as "incompetent" and called for a new foreign policy aimed at speedy victory in Korea.

The six-story loft, office and store building at 100 Warren Street has been sold by Charlotte and Walter Ruprecht to an investing client of William R. Altman, attorney, in a transaction negotiated by Arthur and Irwin Thomases, brokers.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 17--On the eve of the Iranian Parliamentary elections, Premier Mohammed Mossadegh warned all civil and military officials today against the slightest interference in the voting.

Mrs. Haywood Dana, Newbold of 817 Fifth Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Elizabeth, to J. Templeton Strong, son of Mrs. Halford W. Park of New York and West Chop, Mass., formerly of Greenwich, Conn., and the late John Sintram Strong.

LOS ANGELES. Dec, 17 (AP)-- Lines a block long formed today as fans flocked to buy seats for the game Sunday between the defending champion Cleveland Browns and the Los Angeles Rams for the 1951 National Football League crown.

The Strayer-Yavner Education Study under the Mayor's Management Survey, in the section of its report made public today, remarks that the "New York City school system is the operator of a multimillion-dollar industry in the building field alone."

So you think it's cold? Snuggle up to your radiator and consider the plight of thirty families-- among them seventy-one children --who spent the year's coldest week-end in heatless apartments in an East Harlem slum, huddled under blankets in a cooperative effort to keep warm or trying to thaw numbed fingers over an overworked electric plate.
Ownership of the 102-story Empire State Building is expected to change hands by Thursday at a reported price of $50,000,000.
Directors of Frazar Co., Inc., international merchants, have elected Merrill H. Leidy and Everett F. Warner vice presidents.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was irregular and closed 8 points lower to 30 points higher. The market started steady, 7 to 29 points higher, on trade support and with light hedge-selling.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--John B. Dunlap, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, disclosed today that the largest tax investigation in the country now was in progress in New York. He said that the investigators were digging into reports of heavy tax shakedowns.
WASHINGTON. Dec, 17 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture today estimated the 1951 burley tobacco crop at 583,000,000 pounds, 17 per cent greater than in 1950.

PARIS, Dec. 17--The visit of British Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Eden to Paris, even if it leads to no spectacular accords, has had the effect of reassuring the French that in the talks that Mr. Churchill will have with President Truman in Washington two weeks from now, France will not be left aside.
Seas as high as forty feet and winds of heavy gale to hurricane force, blowing in an easterly direction over the main North Atlantic shipping lanes, affected shipping yesterday.

In another of its nation-wide surveys of spending, savings and investment preferences, the University of Michigan has found considerable mental confusion among the 1,000 "representative families" polled.

After a flight from Dallas, broken by an agonizing five-hour delay in Memphis, Astrid Varnay reached New York late yesterday afternoon in time to step into a part that she had not rehearsed this season and that she had never sung at the Metropolitan Opera-- that of Bruennhilde in Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung."

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Tuesday, Dec. 18--The Communists gave the Allies today a list of 3,100 American prisoners of war. The list also included about 7,000 South Koreans and slightly more than 1,000 other United Nations prisoners.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 17-- Warning that United States interest and support cannot be taken for granted unless Europe is reorganized along federal lines, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, urged the Germans today to take positive constructive action on the Schuman plan to pool European coal and steel production and on a European army.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Dec. 17--A forty-five-room mansion on a ten-acre tract in the fashionable Tuxedo Park millionaires' colony was sold today as a tax delinquent by Orange County for $1,500.

Ralph U. Hyde has sold his large home and sixty-six acres on Dune Road in Quogue, L. I., to Frank C. Lynch. Edward D. Burden was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

Illinois, winner of its only two games this season, took over first place in the United Press weekly basketball ratings. In the list released yesterday before Kentucky's rout of St. John's, the Lexington Wildcats, leaders last week, dropped to third.

PARIS, Dec. 17--The Western Big Three proposed today that Brazil, Iceland, the Netherlands, Pakistan and Poland be named to the proposed United Nations Commission to investigate election conditions simultaneously in both East and West Germany.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17--Following is the text of the statement issued today by Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., on plans for a national steel strike:
Chief Fire Marshal Martin Scott spent all yesterday investigating the mysterious disappearance of $316 in cash belonging to civilian and uniformed Fire Department personnel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17-- The C46, the type of plane that crashed in Elizabeth, N. J., Sunday, with a loss of fifty-six lives, has been a controversial airplane since the first one flew in March, 1940. Its performance has been praised and assailed by both military and civilian pilots.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 17 --Westchester County will enter the concert business on a permanent basis at the County Center here next year if a budget revision proposed today by Republican leaders is adopted by the Board of Supervisors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)-- The Government's final report of the year today confirmed earlier indications that the vital corn crop --raw material for meat, milk and eggs--would be disappointing.

Full utilization of existing school buildings should be taken into account before the city undertakes the construction of new ones, according to a report submitted to the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey by Dr. George D. Strayer, education expert, and Louis E. Yavner, management consultant.

Because of generous benefactors, the advent of Christmas meant a lot more yesterday to thousands of children throughout the city who otherwise may not have tasted the fruits and spirit of the season. From the Bronx to the Battery they were feted and presented with gifts.

PARIS, Dec. 17--The Temporary Council Committee of the twelve North Atlantic Treaty nations, which sought to reconcile defense needs with available or potential resources, adourned today without disposing of the major concrete problems put before it by its executive board in a lengthy report.
The Government filed in Federal Court yesterday income tax liens for more than $4,500,000 against Jacob Freidus, convicted tax evader, his mother and his stepfather.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The distinguished panel of the Loyalty Review Board, that decided there is "reasonable doubt as to the loyalty" of John Stewart Service, in this instance construed "loyalty" to mean something broader than its usual definition.
STEPHENS, Ark., Dec. 17--Miss Virginia Garner, former head of the Journalism Department at Wesleyan College in Macon, Ga., died yesterday in her home here after a heart attack. Her age was 77.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 17 (AP) --A band of monkeys and chimpanzees is training in Texas for an Air Force problem: whether atomic radioactivity will have effects on mental abilities and on seeing, hearing and muscular dexterity.
Uruguay has decided to experiment again with the system of a Federal Council as the executive power instead of a President.

The jury in the larceny and forgery trial of Tallulah Bankhead's former maid-secretary heard yesterday the story of a white-haired ex-burlesque dancer who hitched her wagon to a star and wound up behind a team of stone lions.
At 7:25 A.M. yesterday the temperature here fell to the lowest point of the year, 7.9 degrees above zero.
Thousands of airmen well know the point of no return. Every flight plan has a point at which the aircraft will still have sufficient gas to return to the base.
A course of least resistance was followed yesterday by the stock market as prices drifted over an irregular course to a mixed close.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17(AP)-- Ten Missouri power companies argued today the Rural Electrification Administration has no right to finance steam power plants which they said would compete with them.

THE northern deer hunting ended with the New Jersey and Pennsylvania fusillades and, according to reports, both these states had excellent seasons, although the antlerless season held at the end of Pennsylvania's session did not seem as productive as many had anticipated.
Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private bus industry, will continue today his fact-finding mission on the wage and hour demands of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

Reflecting a substantial rise in sales, the net profit of Dresser Industries, Inc., for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 increased to $5,115,000, or $3.77 a common share from $4,303,043, or $3.15 a share in the previous fiscal year.

Brazil, according to the coffee trade, took over the market on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday and "gave it a gunning, especially in the back months." Prices rose 143 to 200 points in a volume of 97,250 bags.

In a recent bulletin on beef, the State Extension Service included the cheering information that next year Americans will get more of this, their favorite meat, than in 1951.
THERE was an item in yesterday's paper that had approximately the same surprise element as the news that Christmas Day would fall on Dec. 25 this year.

A 3,000,000-word history of mankind, from ancient Pithecanthropus to the supersonic jet plane, is to be written by a team of 1,000 leading world scholars. To take five years and cost $600,000,... the project will bring together in six volumes the pertinent knowledge of all races, cultures and peoples, past and present.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17--Accusing the steel industry of a "callous filibuster" in negotiations for a new wage agreement, the United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O., tonight ordered 700,000 workers in the nation's principal steel and aluminum plants to strike at midnight Dec. 31.

There are signs that influential forces in organized labor are abandoning the four-year-old slogan, "Repeal the Taft-Hartley Act," and are ready to cooperate in working out acceptable amendments on a piecemeal basis.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17-- Ernest Hemingway's most recent novel, "Across the River and Into the Trees," will be brought, to the screen by Marshall and Marx Productions, an independent producing company newly incorporated in California by William Marshall and Samuel Marx.

Christmas-like in its name as well as in the wares it displays is a tiny new shop, rather like a "boutique," called the Stable, 924 Seventh Avenue, which contains a variety of Christmas decorations and small gifts for the home.

KITTY HAWK, N. C. Dec. 17 (UP)--The aviation world paid tribute today to its birth here on windy Kill Devil Hill where fortyeight years ago Wilbur and Orville Wright put a plane in the air for the first time.
Chuck Solodare and Bruce Hale, the two referees who awarded a forfeit victory to the Knickerbockers over Milwaukee when the Hawk players appeared late for a game at Moline, Ill., Saturday ...
The Yankees' famed "Old Reliable," Tommy Henrich, who was dropped from the Bombers' payroll as a coach early this month, is still in the sports picture.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The Truman Administration is having more than its usual trouble in persuading outstanding men to take top jobs in the field of foreign affairs.
Women's coats and suits will play an important role in retailers January promotion sales, according to manufacturers and resident buyers in New York.
LONDON, Dec. 17--Both American and European history may be profoundly affected by tomorrow's meeting of Prime Minister Churchill with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, wrung a promise today from Michael V. DiSalle, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, that no immediate action rolling back prices of wool would be taken by Mr. DiSalle's agency.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 17 (AP) --Kentucky smashed St. John's, 81--40, in a battle of the nation's No. 1 and 2 basketball powers before a crowd of 12,000 here tonight.

KALIMPONG, India, Dec. 17-- Chinese Communist authorities in Lhasa, Tibetan capital, are reported to have established Tibet's first state bank to stabilize exchange rates for the Chinese dollar, the Tibetan sang and the Indian rupee.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 17-- The names of 343 recipients of fellowships sponsored by the Atomic Energy Commission were announced today by the Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies, which administers the fellowship program.
Christmas gifts for babies or very small children may be practical as well as pretty.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17--The foreign policy of the United States since World War II has proved a "total failure," Joseph P. Kennedy dedared tonight at a dinner meeting of the Economic Club of Chicago.

In his first move on the international stage since returning to office, Prime Minister Churchill is visiting Paris to consult with the French Government before going to Washington to see President Truman.

The Rev. Joseph Gould Snyder, pastor for fifty-nine years of the Olivet Chapel and its successor, the Olivet Presbyterian Church, 506 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home, 186 Prospect Place, Brooklyn. His age was 86.
The first seven patients were admitted yesterday morning to the new group nursing unit of Hark- ness Pavilion, the private service wing of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The Air Force announced today that a second engine manufacturer would undertake to build a nuclear reactor power plant for a planned "atomic aircraft."

CHICAGO. Dec. 17 (AP)--The full television committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association today ended a "progress report" meeting, but said the 1952 football video policy would not be determined until the N.C.A.A. convention at Cincinnati, Jan. 10-12.

The present shortage of skilled seamen and officers would be alleviated if the Government would adopt a realistic attitude on guaranteeing the shore jobs of men who go to sea during the emergency and on upgrading unlicensed personnel now on ships.

Returning to their regular spring training base at St. Petersburg, Fla., after operating last year at Phoenix, Ariz., the Yankees will prepare for the defense of their American League championship by playing thirty-six exhibition games.

The natural history museum used to be a cold and dusty place, poorly lighted, with a labyrinth of rows and rows of glass cases full of Indian arrowheads, ancient iron implements and beaver pelts, from its entrance to the exit.
LONDON, Dec. 17--An active market in dollars was soon established today when for the first time in twelve years the Bank of England allowed limited freedom in foreign exchange transactions.

Stockholders of the F.L. Jacobs Company at their annual meeting in Detroit yesterday were informed by Rex C. Jacobs, president, of the proposed conversion of the Detroit Division plant to defense work.
TORONTO. Dec. 17 (Canadian Press)--A public offering today of 450,000 no-par-value shares of Trans-Mountain Oil Pipe Company was oversubscribed.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 17--A howling wind and rain storm tonight, for the third night in succession, tore at tents and huts sheltering 165,000 of Israel's newest immigrants. It was the first severe storm of the winter.
Turner Catledge became managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, succeeding Edwin L. James, who died on Dec. 3

HUDSON, N. Y., Dec. 17--Details of a state-wide racing wire network that supplied information to more than 100 horse rooms from Plattsburg to Jamestown with the cooperation of the Western Union Telegraph Company were presented today to the State Crime Commission.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 18 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 1101, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A.M. Tuesday (4 P.M. Monday, Eastern standard time):
The admissibility of evidence antedating 1935 is no longer an issue in the anti-trust trial of seventeen investment banking houses in Federal Court.

WASHINGTON Dec. 17 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture reported today that early and midseason oranges for the 1951-52 season were estimated at 56,100,000 boxes--4 per cent above last season and 21 per cent above average.

Paramount's drama, "A Place in the Sun," the adaptation of Theodore Dreiser's novel, "An American Tragedy," directed by George Stevens, has been named the year's outstanding picture in the twenty-sixth annual selection of ten best films by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures.

PARIS, Dec. 17--Poland introduced a new proposal today under which the United Nations General Assembly would take no action on the Western Big Three disarmament proposals except to establish a consolidated atomic energy and conventional armaments commission.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 17-- The cause of the engine fire that doomed all fifty-six persons aboard the Florida-bound airliner that crashed here yesterday remained unknown today as six agencies organized their inquiries into a joint search for facts.

Eastern Air Lines' new Super Constellation, the first of a fleet of fourteen of the big eightyeight-passenger transports being built for the airline by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, began service yesterday with a flight from Newark Airport to Miami. The 1,200-mile trip was scheduled to take four hours.

In a stern rebuke to City Council President Rudolph Halley for his request that representative policemen and firemen be heard by the Board of Estimate in their demands for Day increases, Mayor Impellitteri said last night that there was no room in the current expense budget for salary adjustments for any groups of city employes.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 17 (UP)--Maryland football sources hinted today that the school may eventually bolt the Southern Conference, which wrecked the Terrapins' l952 schedule with a oneyear probation order for its acceptance of a Sugar Bowl invitation.

PARIS, Dec. 17--Atomic physicists from twelve European countries urged here today the rapid buildup of atomic research facilities in Europe on an international basis to stop the drift of young scientists to the United States and to prevent Europe's dependence on that country in the atomic sphere.
President Truman intervened it the strike of 5,800 ground and flight service employes of Par American World Airways yesterday by setting up an emergency fact-finding board.

A solemn pontifical requiem mass for the Right Rev. Msgr. John L. Belford, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity of Our Blessed Lord for forty-six years, was offered yesterday in the church, at Classon ...

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Dec. 17 --Hilary Aidan St. George Saunders, British historian and novelist, died in Prospect Hospital last night of asthma, which he contracted during the second World War. His age was 53. For many years he served in the secretariat of the League of Nations.
Three former associates of Harry Gross, the bookmaker, were sentenced yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions.
Nylon hosiery price wars are the culmination of conditions that produced a depressed state in the hosiery industry, manufacturers said yesterday.

Parents who are planning to take their youngsters on museum tours during the holiday vacation would be wise not to try to see too much on any one visit, Miss Katherine B. Shippen, an author of children's books who worked for ten years in the Brooklyn Children's Museum, advised yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17--Initial prices for grain futures were sharply higher in all pits this morning, with buyers trying to anticipate absorption by commercial interests against expected export business.

A plan for a small-plant network has been sent to Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., it was announced here yesterday by Thomas Jefferson Miley, executive vice president.
The National Production Authority is starting to crack down on violators of metal inventory regulations, it was announced here yesterday by Robert C. Winn, chief of the agency's compliance

Less than one month ago--Nov. 23, to be exact--the White House announced that Dr. Raymond B. Allen had been appointed head of the Psychological Strategy Board, the Government's top policy-making body in the war of ideas against the Soviet Union.

The Rev. Gerald Groveland Walsh, who had been Professor of Medieval History in the Graduate School of Fordham University since 1937, died of a heart attack Monday morning in the Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, where he had been a patient for four days. He was 59 years old.

The man who helped settle the lox (smoked salmon) strike four years ago brought his talents to the bagel famine yesterday. Gourmets who rarely eat one without the other gained new hope as Murray Nathan, a mediator for the State Board of Mediation, moved in to help end the bagel strike.
Expenses of the voluntary hospitals of New York increased 8.9 per cent last year over the year before, it was announced yesterday, in the seventy-second annual report of the United Hospital Fund.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 17-- About twenty former rulers of Princely States who surrendered their thrones after India became free four years ago now are seeking various elective offices in India's first national elections.

Fantastic personnel turnovers ranging in some cases to as much as 90 to 200 per cent in a year, are one of the major reasons for service, and particularly Army waste and inefficiency.

LONDON, Dec. 17--Britain's naval rearmament, program "is largely directed toward the underwater menace" that was the gravest danger to the life and security of the British Isles in two World Wars, the 1951-52 edition of Jane's Fighting Ships, which was published today, reported.
Prehistoric and Ancient Times, covering the Developments of Peoples and Cultures to about 1200 B. C.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17-- A widespread feeling that religion must be included in the training of public school teachers and the education of their pupils was recorded here today at a conference of 100 educators from state teacher colleges in all parts of the country.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Dec. 18--Red Cross representatives in Korea have given up hope of getting packages of supplies or gifts before Christmas to United Nations troops held in North Korea.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--A scientific report now available to the public states that there need be no hazard in the use of chemical additives in food provided adequate research is carried out before use of the chemical.

Seymour Lipkin, the first prize winner of the Rachmaninoff Fund Contest of 1948, and since then a soloist with orchestra and recitalist in many American cities, gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall since that contest.

Robert Perry of Los Angeles and Jerry Moss of Miami Beach, Fla., have been placed at the top of the rankings in the junior and boys' singles respectively, according to the listings announced yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association for 1951.
BOSTON, Dec. 17 (UP)--Norman Hayes, 162 pounds, of Boston, gained a split decision over Robert Villemain, 163, of Paris, tonight in a ten-round fight at the Boston Garden.
Members of the staff of City Council President Rudolph Halley have been instructed not to talk to or associate with newspaper men, particularly reporters assigned to City Hall.

PARIS, Dec. 17--Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, has asked top members of his staff not to attend social functions given by Soviet bloc delegations unless he himself is invited, a reliable source reported today.
A United States diplomat, an executive in a publishing concern and a titled woman joined with hundreds of other persons in contributing $5,386,25 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.
CAIRO, Dec. 17--Observers here were not optimistic today about the outcome of the meeting of Foreign Minister Mohammed Salah elDin Pasha with British Foreign Secretary Eden in Paris tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec.17--Sharply increased demands of the military for aircraft will force the Government to draw heavily upon its stockpile of aluminum in the next six months, officials of the National Production Authority conceded today.

The Allied Stores Corporation, which operates a chain of department stores, and its subsidiaries, announced yesterday increased sales for the three, nine and twelve month periods ended with October, but a decline in earnings from these periods from the corresponding ones a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec.17--President Truman today presented the Collier Trophy to the helicopter industry, the armed services and the Coast Guard for the greatest achievement in aviation during 1950.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 18--The United Nations Command warned the Communists yesterday that Allied warplanes, starting today, would fire on unidentified vehicles using the main highway from the North Korean capital of Pyongyang to the site of the Korean truce talks at Panmunjom.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec.17--The seizure by Indonesian authorities of a consignment of arms en route to Dutch Navy units in western New Guinea threatened tonight to bring to a head the twoyear controversy over control of the last Dutch possession in the Far East.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The State Department's Loyalty and Security Board began today an examination of the career of John Carter Vincent, now Consul General at Tangier and former...

In its tenth anniversary year, the American Fund for Israel Institutions gave a dinner concert in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. Edward A. Norman, founder and president, was guest of honor at the event, attended by an estimated 1,500 persons who paid $100 each for reservations.

Completely organized, except for a few minor production details, "The Shrike," Joseph Kramm's new play co-starring Jose Ferrer and Judith Evelyn, starts rehearsing today preparatory to opening at the Cort Theatre on Tuesday evening, Jan. 15. Mr. Ferrer, producer of the work dealing with marital problems, will be in charge of the directorial assignment.

The state board of inquiry investigating the dock strike that crippled deep-sea operations in the port from mid-October to early November resumed its public hearings yesterday to permit counsel for the opposing factions of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and employing stevedores to sum up their cases.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 17--Sentiment is growing in West Germany for the creation of a voluntary youth labor service organization in an effort to cut down unemployment and to "keep young men and women off the streets."

FIUME (Rijeka), Yugoslavia, Dec. 17--Vice Admiral Matthias B. Gardner, commander of the United States Sixth Fleet who arrived today aboard his flagship, the heavy cruiser Des Moines, will leave by plane tomorrow for Belgrade, where arrangements for a meeting with Premier Marshal Tito are being made.
from $55,000,000 to $70,000,000 at the close of the day's operations. On Friday there was a large increase in reserve requirements, which were met in part by net Treasury disbursements.

CORAL GABLES. Fla., Dec. 17 (UP)--Deflation, a New York horse making his first start in the south, carried Jockey Charlie Burr to his 297th winner of the year today in the McAllister Purse at Tropical Park.

RAYMOND T. BONDS, an amiable man and an astute judge of crime, is a publisher by vocation and a naturalist by avocation. As a publisher he devotes a great portion of his working hours to editing detective stories. As an amateur naturalist he watches birds.

The stock market's position was only altered by a fraction yesterday. Trading continued highly cautious, centered in selected issues. The net result of the day's activity was a slight leaning to the lower side in point of gains and losses, although strength in the leading motors accounted for a rise of 0.18 point in the averages.

With all the discussion of prospective automobile safety programs that has taken place in the past few years, statistical tabulations still point out increases in such fatalities rather than the hoped-for decreases.
PARIS, Dec. 13 A United Nations budget of $48,096,780 for 1952 was approvd today by the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee.

LONDON, Dec. 18 Experts in semantics and foreign affairs studied without much profit the communique issued in Paris tonight at the conclusion of the visit of Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to that capital.

The will of John Falahee, retired real estate operator, who died in St. Elizabeth's Hospital on Nov. 12 at the age of 86, bequeathes the greater part of his estate to Roman Catholic charities. The document was filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
Hopeful of getting back into the winning column, Bill Cook's New York Rangers entertain the Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden tonight.
CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 18 Make no mistake about it Santa Clause is a practical fellow, and the citizens of this village have tangible evidence to prove it.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 43 points lower to 5 points higher than on Monday on active months.

Frank Nawrocki, delegate of Brooklyn Local 808, International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., was re-elected yesterday in the union's first major contest since the recent twenty-five-day dock strike.
A day-long storm marked by snow, sleet, drizzle and freezing rain plagued the city and suburbs yesterday. Ice-sheathed highways made motor travel hazardous.

The net income of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad this year will be more than $18,000,000, or about $8.59 each on the 1,856,170 common shares, which recently were split five-for-one, Lynne L. White, president, told stockholders yesterday at the postponed annual meeting in Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Reports on four corporations with total assets amounting to $10,102,136 were submitted today to Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, by the Office of Alien Property of the Department of Justice.
PITTSBURGH. Dec. 18 (AP) The Pittsburgh Steelers of the National Football League fired Head Coach Johnny Micheloson today and hired Joe Bach for the job.

THE New Jersey upland game hunters will have another brief opportunity to gather in some grouse, quail and squirrels between now and Dec. 29, when the second phase of the season will be concluded. Wildfowlers in that State have until one hour before sunset on Saturday.

PARIS, Dec. 18 Prime Minister Churchill approved tonight a statement pledging more positive British cooperation with the European army and the unity of Europe than has ever been officially expressed by a British Government before.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 19 The United Nations command today studied the list of Allied prisoners captured in the Korean war that was handed over after long delay yesterday by the Communist truce delegation in the conference tent at Panmunjom.

MUNSAN, Korea, Wednesday, Dec. 19 The name of Maj. Gen. William F. Dean appeared today on the list of war prisoners supplied by the Communists, but even this did not clear up completely the mystery of his fate.

PARIS, Dec. 18 (AP) Following is the text of the communique issued in both French and English after the talks between Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Eden of Britain and Premier Pleven and Foreign Minister Schuman of France:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Department or Justice has stated that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has never turned over to it for possible prosecution any of his principal "cases" of alleged Communists in Government.

Defense production by the General Electric Company next year will amount to 30 to 35 per cent of the company's total capacity, according to Ralph J. Cordiner, president. He said defense work probably would level off at that rate, barring an all-out war.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 18--What Jean Antoine Houdin did in recording the birth of a nation in North America by sculpturing Washington, Franklin, John Paul Jones and other Americans is being done for the rebirth of Israel by Jo Davidson.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 18 William Henry Warren, former president of the Fuller Warren Stove Company, and a member of one of Troy's oldest families, died here today in Samaritan Hospital after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 President Truman sharply criticized today a committee of The Associated Press Managing Editors Association that withdrew an offer to submit proposed clarifying improvements and changes in his executive order establishing uniform security standards for safeguarding governmental information.

Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private transit industry, urged the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., yesterday to acknowledge that a contract existed between it and the Third Avenue Transit Corporation.

The Westchester Street Transportation Company, which is seeking increased bus and trolley fares in Westchester County from the Public Service Commission, estimated yesterday a $98,200 loss for this year. Suggested higher fares would yield an operating profit of $66,400; officials declared.

ROME, Dec. 18--Yesterday the Italian Cabinet was in almost continuous session, and when Premier De Gasperi was asked in an interlude what questions were important enough to require such long-drawn-out discussion he answered that the debate focused on two subjects--the effects of the flood in the Po valley and the European army.

One good turn followed another yesterday as a contribution of 2,637 new toys, made by employes of the Home Insurance Company, was added to the Police Athletic League's Christmas collection for New York's underprivileged children.

DETROIT, Dec. 18 The National Automobile Dealers Association, raising the lid on a public opinion survey conducted several months ago by Elmo Roper, disclosed today that "an alarming number of the people of the United States does not trust the new-car dealers."

Prices of major types of cutting tools are being reduced by manufacturers in order to comply with ceiling price regulations of the Office of Price Stabilization, it was revealed here yesterday by industrial purchasing agents.

John J. Weinheimer, business manager of the New York University Athletic Association and head football coach at the university from 1944 to 1946, died of a heart attack early yesterday at his home, 625 East Fourteenth Street. He was 55 years old.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Dec. 18 The United Nations and Communist lists of prisoners, cause of so much sharp argument, were exchanged this afternoon without so much as one word of thanks from either side.

MUNSAN, Korea, Dec. 18 (AP) The Communists are holding Allied prisoners in eleven camps between the North Korean capital of Pyongyang and the Manchurian border city of Sinuiju, a United Nations Command spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) The Southwestern Power Administration and the Rural Electrification Administration were accused today of attempting to "by-pass the intent of Congress" in proposing construction of super cooperatives.
Happy to be back "at the helm of the best club in our league," Chuck Dressen has mailed a signed blank contract to the Dodgers, E.J. (Buzzy) Bavasi, Dodger vice president, said yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 18--W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the Temporary Council Committee of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said today that the report of its executive board, which the committee had adopted, formed a "plan of action for building the defensive strength of the North Atlantic community."

W.W. Grainger, Inc., wholesale distributors of electrical equipment, bought the eight-story building at 533-41 Canal Street, northeast corner of Washington Street, from the Gerdau Realty Corporation in a deal negotiated by Wm. C. Walker's Sons and Shear Co., brokers.

A field goal after the final buzzer enabled the New York Knickerbockers to score a 69-67 triumph over the Minneapolis Lakers last night at Madison Square Garden. Vince Boryla was the hero. His 30-foot set shot determined the outcome and kept the Knicks in a third-place tie with Philadelphia.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) For the third consecutive afternoon, Charlie Burr, the nation's 1951 jockey champion, guided home the winner of the main event at Tropical Park. Today he scored with River Divide Farm's frontrunning Narrator in the $2,400 Dinner Key Purse, increasing Burr's total for the year to 298 winners.
PASADENA, Calif. Dec. 18 (AP) Pasadena gave a rousing welcome to the invading Illinois football team today as it arrived for its date with Stanford in the Rose Bowl New Year's Day.

The contest between supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination has resulted in the developing of considerably more strength than had been expected for Senator Taft in New York State.

Carolyn Schnurer, designer and inveterate around-the-world traveler, returned not long ago with a fresh inspiration, this time from Japan. She has incorporated her ideas in a collection of summer country and beach clothes. It was presented last night at a formal dinner dance, appropriately called...

Yesterday's driving rain held up the exodus of nearly half of thirty families from an unheated Harlem tenement, but higher temperatures and the kindness of neighbors in lending kerosene stoves made the lot of those left behind a little easier.

Kimberly-Clark Corporation and its affiliate, Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, Ltd., announced several organizational changes yesterday. W.R. Kellett and R.W. Lyons, one-time woodland chief for Spruce Falls, have been named vice presidents of Kimberly-Clark.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 18 Australia's biggest radio network broadcast to the children today that there really is no Santa Claus. This immediately touched off a great debate.

LONDON, Dec. 18 Most markets on the Stock Exchange were weaker today, the tendency being ascribed mainly to recommendation by the Federation of British Industries that industry should continue to observe restraint in payment of dividends.

Orphans from the New York Foundling Hospital held their annual Christmas party yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where Cardinal Spellman was host to contributors to the Foundlings Christmas Party Fund.

Stricter Federal control of all commercial flying was demanded yesterday by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey to reduce the likelihood of another crash such as the one of the C-46 airliner that fell aflame Sunday in the center of Elizabeth, N.J., killing all fifty-six persons aboard.

Of the 86,000,000 Americans who own life insurance policies today, probably few ever stop to think of the broader implications of the financial protection they have purchased for their families. Yet the striking fact, as was pointed out in this newspaper a day or two ago, is that life insurance funds have become the major single source of capital in our economy.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, one of the largest private philanthropic organizations in the world, will put 10,000 persons in the field next month in a mass effort to bolster the agency's lagging drive for $20,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 With more than 11,000 men carried as missing on their rolls, the armed services started tonight to notify the next of kin of 3,198 members of the armed forces listed as missing that there was hope their loved ones were held captive by the Chinese and North Korean Communists.

Historical personages as diversely sized up by Shaw in "Caesar and Cleopatra" and by Shakespeare in "Antony and Cleopatra" and as delineated by Sir Laurence Olivier and his wife, Vivien Leigh, attracted international attention at Britain's recent drama festival in London.

Disagreements between the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the tin producers on a suitable price for the metal appear to be due to a faulty understanding of the history of tin prices, Norman Cleaveland, president of the Pacific Tin Consolidated Corporation, said in an interview yesterday.
To help keep track of the 366 days of 1952, including Feb. 29, an engagement book or calendar is recommends as a good investment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Business activity, which remained level for several months despite the mounting defense program, probably will take a, new upturn soon, the Department of Commerce reported today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 18 (AP) Australian tennis fathers are indignant over the demands of Russell Kingman, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, that they promise to have Frank Sedgman defend his national singles title at Forest Hills next summer.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 Marshall Field Co., department store, will file with the Securities and Exchange Commission tomorrow a registration statement covering a proposed $30,000,000 financing, including preferred stock and longterm notes, Hughston M. McBain, chairman, announced today.

BAYONNE, N.J., Dec. 18 This city of 70,000 persons was without water for seven and a half hours today as a result of the bursting of a forty-two-inch main. Because of the danger of fire, a state of emergency was proclaimed until the water was turned on again.

CARACAS, Venezuela Dec. 18 (AP)--Ecuador's Galo Pinto and Alicia Wright won the mixed doubles tennis championship in the Bolivarian Games today by defeating Jorg Morales and Gabby Zapler of Peru, 6--3, 6--4.

On Sept. 5, 1861, twelve days after sailing from Liverpool, the Cunard liner Arabia docked at Boston. Anthony...
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 18 Unofficial reports circulated here today that the steel industry might make its first pay offer in Washington peace talks Thursday or Friday.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Dec. 18 Letters to Santa Claus have become almost outmoded for the children of this village. Spurning the task of writing to the North Pole, the kids merely pick up the telephone and say, "I'd like to speak to Santa, please."

Any danger of an immediate strike by the Bethlehem Steel Company's 32,000 shipyard workers on the East Coast was eliminated yesterday when the present contract was extended for two months. The agreement would have expired on Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Fred A. Seaton, newly appointed Republican Senator from Nebraska, made it clear today in his first press conference here that he disagreed with the isolationism of his late predecessor, Kenneth S. Wherry.

Stricter enforcement of the law against bookmaking and the Federal registration of professional gamblers accounted in part for a 12 per cent increase in pari-mutuel betting during 1951, according to the annual report issued by the State Racing Commission today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a union shop agreement need not give a thirty-day grace period to employes who were already in the union on the date of the agreement. Union membership is not required during a grace period.

Investment banking syndicates will place on the market today new issues of securities valued at more than $42,000,000, The offerings include common and preferred stock of public utility companies, common stock of a major department store enterprise, and equipment trust certificates of a Western railroad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Facing a steel strike deadline set for New Year's Eve, Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, today called the United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O., and ten representative employers to meet with him in Washington on Thursday.

Three seasoned travelers paused briefly on their way through New York yesterday. During their two hours in the city, they had lunch, changed trains and delivered themselves of the opinion that this would be a dreadful place if it were not for the Travelers Aid Society.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Army officers tonight gave the following explanation of some of the symbols used in the Communist list of United States prisoners of war as transmitted from Tokyo.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 Coast Guard spokesmen announced here today that steps were being taken to deal with a "serious shortage" of ship's officers by making it possible for alien officers to serve in the American merchant marine. A set-up similar to that in use during World War II...

It is less than a week to the time when the lights will be dimmed, the brandy added and ignited and the pudding brought to the table, rich and heavy, licked by blue flames. Some one at the groaning board is sure to quote Dickens' "A Christmas Carol" and remark "there never was such a pudding."

MOSCOW, Dec. 18 Pravda presented to the public eye today a prize example of "boondoggling" or, in the words of the Soviet paper, futilely "beating the air" at a cost to the state of many millions of rubles.

George Samuel Edgar, 9 years old, became a minority stockholder of the Erie Railroad Company yesterday, and promptly started collecting special dividends a chance to "steer" and blow the whistle of art Erie ferryboat and a ride in the cabs of two Diesel engines.

Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, said yesterday that if he should be dissatisfied with the fiscal program Mayor Impellitteri will submit next month to the Legislature to help the city out of its financial difficulties, he "will not hesitate" to go to Albany with his own recommendations.

Tallulah Bankhead made her long-delayed entrance yesterday at the trial of her former maid-secretary for grand larceny and forgery. But State Senator Fred G. Moritt, defense attorney, cut what was expected to be a fat part to a mere walk-on by declining to cast her as co-star with him.

Sharp reductions in price of imported wire products are being announced here, Kurt Orban, president or Kurt Orban Company, Inc., 21 West Street, said yesterday. These products, which include baling wire and barbed wire, are becoming competitive in price with the American-made article, Mr. Orban asserted.

"Dragnet," the radio series which does not regard police officers as either boobs or glamour boys but only as intelligent mortals, appears destined for a new success in television. In a preview performance on Sunday night, the program offered a documentary drama which in its terseness and understatement was an exciting thriller.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18--Soon after the California Supreme Court had cleared the way by lifting a restraining order, the State Toll Bridge Authority sold today a $21,000,000 issue of revenue bonds to refinance the San Francisco Oakland Bay Bridge.
All around the town there was merriment yesterday at Christmas parties for children, hospitalized veterans and others.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 103,009 today, an increase of 433 since last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Direct defense and defense-supporting production and construction will take more than 40 per cent of the carbon steel and about 60 per cent of the supplies of aluminum and copper wire mill and copper brass mill products, the Defense Production Administration announced today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 18 Premier Mohammed Mossadegh conferred tonight with the recently formed grand advisory council for the national elections, and preparations were started for setting up polling places.
BORDENTOWN, N.J., Dec. 18 Five young marines were killed and a sixth was injured critically early today in the first fatal traffic accident on the recently opened New Jersey Turnpike.

PARIS. Dec. 18 The debate on the Western Big Three's disarmament proposal was concluded this afternoon and a test vote indicated that it would be approved tomorrow by an overwhelming majority in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 18 Western Allied Officials have been finding the West Germans especially stubborn negotiators in their attempts to work out lasting agreements to guarantee against the re-creation of the giant cartels, such as I.G. Farben, that dominated the economy of Europe before the war.

Television, radio, newsreel and camera reporting of hearings by executive and legislative bodies was condemned yesterday by a committee of lawyers. In a report growing out of the recent Senate crime committee inquiry, the lawyers held that abuses of such reporting invaded individual rights and diminished the effectiveness of investigations.

HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 18 A picture of vote-buying officials with unexplained wealth and wide-open brothels patronized and mulcted by the local police was unfolded today before the State Crime Commission.

SHREVEPORT, La,, Dec. 18 (UP) The toll was raised to four crew members dead and nine others injured today after an Air Force B-29 bomber sheared off the top of a house and crashed in a deserted field here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--A Senate Investigating subcommittee charged today that a party of eighteen United States labor union representatives, "at least fourteen" of whom had "notorious Communist records," were able easily to exceed their passport travel authorizations in April and May to make an all-expenses-paid visit to Russia and her satellite countries and contribute to anti-American propaganda.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 19 Two United States-trained Russian spies, allegedly parachuted into southwest Russia on an espionage mission from a United States plane last summer, have been executed by a firing squad, the Moscow radio reported early today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 18 In a decision that may have far-reaching applications in other parts of the world, the International Court of Justice upheld today Norway's right to fix her territorial limits at sea by a method that Britain contested as a violation of international rules.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 19--The Communists contended last night over the Pyongyang radio that their troops had seized the two small islands of Chongyang and Ung, both just ten miles from the larger island of Cho. which the enemy reported having taken the previous day.

The No. 1 jinx has caught up with St. John's of Brooklyn. A week ago, Kentucky was picked as the top college basketball team in the country by sportswriters and sports broadcasters in the Associated Press poll. Minnesota then defeated Kentucky, 61--57.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 A threat of contempt-of-Congress citation appeared tonight to face Henry W. Grunewald, Washington private investigator, if he refused Thursday afternoon, as he did last week, to answer questions of the House subcommittee investigating tax scandals.

The Wage Policy Committee of the C.I.O. United Steelworkers has ordered a walkout of 700,000 employes in this key industry unless an agreement on wages is reached by midnight of Dec. 31. Even Government intervention, the committee declares, will not alter this decision.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18--The Screen Writers Guild is going to crack down on producers who make films for television and then permit them to be packaged and shown in theatrical release without compensating the scenarists with additional pay to meet the standard minimums for a lowbudget feature script.

For the first time since 1937, a first-year man topped the National League's pitchers in the earnedrun average department. Southpaw Chester (Chet) Nichols of the Braves, son of a former major leaguer, paced the senior loop's hurlers during the 1951 campaign, according to official statistics released yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 18 Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, declared today that the United States support of Greece's candidacy for the United Nations Security Council was a "shameful story" and again asserted this was a violation of the "gentlemen's agreement" of 1946 whereby each geographical region was permitted to select its representative on the Security Council. The United States denies the agreement is now valid.
Striking mechanics and flight service employes of Pan American World Airways voted 8 to 1 last night to go back to work at midnight, a spokesman for the Transport Workers Union, C.I,O., announced.

HONG KONG, Dec. 18 An official Roman Catholic spokesman said today that a 56-year-old Bishop, the Most Rev. Adolph Paschang of Kongmoon, Kwangtung Province, had been beaten again there following the church's refusal to pay "ransom money" to' the Chinese Communists as a means of saving him from the violence of the intensified "land reform" in that southeastern coastal province.
Christmas presents this year for a growing number of persons will take the form of contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which yesterday received $12,665.25.
MEMPHIS, Dec. 18 (AP) Bob Starr has been discharged by Memphis State College but not for the usual reasons. No college pranks, no flunked courses. It merely developed that Mr. Starr was:

With only nine days left before the deadline in the present stage of the armistice negotiations, the Communists in Korea have at last bowed to another United Nations demand and submitted a list of prisoners they are holding.

CAIRO, Egypt. Dec. 18 (AP) A British military spokesman threatened today that "clearing a military road through Ismailia may be one of the things we will have to do" to counter Egyptian guerrilla attacks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) A tuba player lost today his complaint that the American Federation of Muscians, A.F.L., had forced him out of his job with the Philadelphia Orchestra. The player, Clarence O. Karella, had won an earlier round before a National Labor Relations Board trial examiner, but the board itself rejected the complaint.

Coffee trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday was the heaviest of the year to date, at 101,250 bags in a day of lower prices for most commodities. Only sugar futures held out against the downward trend.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Moor Shoemaker, rector for the last twentysix years of the Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, resigned his post yesterday to accept a call as rector of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh. He will assume his new duties on March 30.
ATHENS, Dec. 18 The Marshall Plan allotment to Greece for the current fiscal year has not been announced, but it is expected that it may be $200,000,000.

PUSAN, Korea, Dec. 18 (AP)--The South Korean Government said tonight that the disparity between the number of South Korean and United States troops officially listed as missing and the number given by the Communists might mean the Reds were "camouflaging a tremendous number of tragic atrocities."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Secretary of State Dean G. Acheson may step into the deadlocked tin price dispute between the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Bolivian Government, it was reported today. Mr. Acheson in turn, informed officials said...

The rate on prime commercial loans was raised to 3 per cent by several large downtown commercial banks yesterday. Effective today, the advance from the prevailing level of 2 per cent brought the charge to the "best borrowers" to the highest point since shortly after the bank "holiday" in 1933.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) Supporters of the St. Lawrence Seaway disclosed today that President Truman again would ask for Congressional approval of the controversial power and waterway project next month.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 The Dewey Administration sounded a note of financial caution today against the growing chorus of demands for a substantial reduction in 1952 state taxes with the announcement that budget requests from just one group of state agencies were $30,000,000 above 1951-52 appropriations that totaled $167,000,000.

From the looks of things the next explosion in the Moslem-Near Eastern world is to be Tunisia, and we may expect it in a matter of days. There is no use lamenting these troubles, for in the nature of things they are inevitable.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 19 (AP) Following are the Americans named by the Communists as prisoners of war on a list given to the United Nations Command at the Korean truce talks:

All of us are aware these days of the shrinking margin of safety in our budget for living. Indeed, the shrinkage has perhaps brought some of us to the point where the margin between braking even or not seems no wider than the razor's edge.
Each day during the Tree pre-Christmas season

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 President Truman today commended as applicable to all Government departments and agencies a strict anti-gift and anti-gratuity policy recently promulgated for employes of the Housing and Home Finance Agency.
GENEVA, Dec. 18-There are definite signs that by late next spring Europe will have dug, bought or wangled enough coal so that it at least can start deflating the latest coal Crisis.
The seasonal merry Christmas battle of wits between Christmas tree merchants and householders who just want to buy a nice tree at a low price began here yesterday.
A million persons who will want telephone service in this country in 1952 will be unable to get it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 E. Roland Harriman, president of the American Red Cross, said today that almost a third of the organization's annual budget for the 1950-51 fiscal year was spent in services to United States armed forces in this country and overseas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 "Appropriate measures" will be taken if it is found that any individual has been deprived of constitutional rights in the recent dynamitings of Negro and Jewish properties in Miami, Fla., Attorney General J. Howard McGrath asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Coast Guard's new rules, relaxing its regulations to allow American flag vessels to hire alien officers and effective in thirty days, provide, however, that "in no case shall approved alien officers be employed in grades above that of second mate or second assistant engineer."

The newly announced project of a scientific and cultural history of mankind, to be prepared by an international board of scholars from many countries and every continent, opens fresh vistas in the unending quest for knowledge.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 18 An ambitious $800,000,000 program for Palestine Arab refugees, to be financed by governments under the United Nations, was proposed here today by a group of church and civic leaders.

The Harshaw Chemical Company attained a new high record in sales with $47,537,854, an increase of 22 per cent over the previous year's volume of 438,952,839. Earnings for the fiscal year ended with September, however, were slightly lower because taxes took $2,030,548 more than the year before.

CHICAGO. Dec. 18 In the face of a bullish Government crop report, the grain markets found too many holders willing to take their profits today, and the result was the most substantial decline in some time. Some of the large lines held by professional traders were reported sold out, and the general demand was swamped by the further long liquidation that ensued in all pits.

Jules H. (Julie) Bender, put in the class of convicted gamblers Frank Erickson and Jerry Kelley as "no ordinary, run of the mill bookmaker," was sentenced yesterday to a one-year penitentiary term and fined $5,000. Bender, 42 years old, of 499 Fort Washington Avenue, escaped an additional two years when execution of that part of the sentence was suspended.
PARIS, Dec. 18--The West asked the United Nations Security Council today to open the doors of the world organization to Italy and immediately ran into the threat of another Soviet veto.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 18 The Chinese Nationalist Government today became the first foreign regime to establish normal relations with Thailand's new government, set up three weeks ago after a coup d'etat staged by military leaders.

In an effort to eliminate shady selling practices of certain retail linen shops on Fifth Avenue, the Bureau of Weights and Measures of New York's Department of Markets has issued summonses for violation of the Advertising Law, it was announced yesterday by Fred J. Loughran, director.
At least one-fifth of the students in three Bronx schools, selected for a new venture in child guidance and education, are suffering emotional and personality disturbances of varying degrees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--A Democratic Senator was dreaming of a White Christmas (in 1952)--dreaming aloud, in the hearing of two other Democratic Senators and this correspondent. It was a lovely dream, up to a point.

Floored for a count of eight in the second round, Chico vejar, Stamford, Conn., welterweight, rallied to gain a unanimous decision in a ten-round bout with Carmine Fiore of Brooklyn last night at the St. Nicholas Arena.
Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., plans to release forty-seven features during the forthcoming season, it was announced yesterday by Jack L. Warner, executive producer.
The movement toward European unity and Continental unification has gained another powerful boost as a result of the conferences just concluded between Mr. Churchill and the French Government.
The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching announced yesterday that it had made a grant of $1,200,000 to key Southern institutions to develop high quality graduate and research programs.

The bumper Florida orange crop, expected to reach 72,500,000 boxes this season, compared with 68,300,000 for last year's record production, will largely be taken care of by increased use of frozen orange concentrate, it was learned here yesterday.

MUNSAN, Korea, Dec. 19--The chief United Nations armistice negotiator said today that he did not know what the Allies would do if they confirmed that the Communists had murdered United Nations war prisoners--"but I do know what me would all like to do."

Seven Army privates were found guilty of mutiny and not by a general court-martial at Governors Island yesterday. The young soldiers face a maximum penalty of death on the mutiny charge as leaders of a revolt in Castle Williams guardhouse, Fort Jay, on Sept. 17.

The Christmas spirit really began to take hold of New York yesterday. The subways were a bit more crowded, even with just the same number of passengers, because those who were there bulged with packages in a belated shopping rush.

Paddy Young, Greenwich Village middleweight, and Ernie (The Rock) Durando, Bayonne, N.J., slugger, yesterday signed for their fourth ring battle, to be waged in Madison Square Garden on Jan. 11. Whether the match will be approved by the State Athletic Commission is doubtful.
A white sedan, equipped with two loudspeakers and called the "Voice of Cleanliness," will make its bow today under Department of Sanitation auspices.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 (AP)-- The Los Angeles Rams, in winning their third-straight division title topped all National Football League opponents in total yards gained.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 19 (UP)-- Senator Frank Carlson said today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower wanted to give up his Army command and announce his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination as soon as possible.
The State of Texas borrowed $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday on bond issues intended to finance land purchases for war veterans. The bonds, which will mature from 1960 to 1986, were...
Prompt action by the wife of a bus driver who was visiting her mother at 716 Fifth Avenue. Brooklyn, yesterday brought all the building's occupants to safety when fire threatened them.

Official National League fielding averages, released yesterday, disclose that local players fared handsomely in the 1951 campaign. The Dodgers' Jackie Robinson and Gil Hodges and the Giants' Wes Westrum and Sal Maglie were outstanding.

President Truman yesterday emphasized this country had no way to verify the prisoners list handed to the Allies by the Communists in Korea. Some of the Pentagon's skepticism was tempered by the feeling that the enemy might have yielded the data to try to gain a psychological advantage.

Having shown a marked improvement this year over last, business volume in New York will not change appreciably in 1952, in the opinion of the majority of executives of 327 local companies participating in an annual surrey by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

A prisoner manacled with a pair of handcuffs joining his wrists before him succeeded yesterday in escaping from two deputy United States marshals on the steps of the Brooklyn Federal Building and in having the handcuffs subsequently removed by a confederate with a hacksaw.

The knotty problem of fiscal independence for the New York City public school system and the manner of choosing members of the Board of Education are the chief concern of the section of the Education Study of the Mayor's Management Survey that is made public this morning.

In one of the largest singleproperty realty deals in recent years on the West Coast, the Los Angeles Biltmore Hotel has passed into new hands.

The twenty-fourth annual contribution to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund from students of the Horace Mann School for Boys, in the amount of $3,000, was made yesterday at this office by a group of the boys.
