"Realities of World Power," by John E. Kieffer, an explanation of the complexities of power politics, will be published Jan. 25 by David McKay. Mr. Kieffer, who writes science fiction stories for relaxation...

Spotting their foes the first goal of the game, the New York Rangers overcame that obstacle and defeated the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night. Squaring the count in the first period and going ahead by...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) --Government officials estimate that only about one-fifth of the planned religious, community and commercial building projects throughout the country can be approved and started in the next three months.

At least thirty shots were fired as a police car chased a stolen automobile at high speed for fortyfive blocks in upper Manhattan about 3:30 A. M. yesterday until the quarry crashed into another police car. Although seven men were injured, no one was shot.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 19-- Unbeaten Navy toppled Princeton to its first defeat of the season today, halting the Tigers, 54--45. It was the fifth triumph for the middies. Princeton had won three.

Puzzled shoppers still in search of just the right gift for a man may find help from the following satisfaction in having a wellobjects for the desk, accessories for serving food or drinks and a single fireplace tool that does the work of three.
DETROIT, Dec. 19--The pilot model of a new heavy tank, the first to be built in the United States since World War II, was completed Nov. 19 at Newark, Del., the Chrysler Corporation disclosed today.

Prompt and vigorous action by the city to increase the subway fare to 12 cents and raise assessed valuations of one- and twofamily houses 33 1/3 per cent are among 'the recommendations in a report submitted to the Mayor's...

THE earmuff brigade, with tipups held at the ready, is be ginning to eye the thermometer with anxiety, for with the icefishing season open they are restrained only by an inability to walk on the water.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP)--A million-dollar libel suit against Robert Montgomery, movie and television actor, was settled today by payment of $2,500 to charity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Defense production contracts placed by the military will come under close scrutiny from the Office of Price Stabilization in the future, Michael V. DiSalle, head of the price agency, disclosed today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19--Grain futures were well bought in the early trade when further declines were registered on fairly heavy overnight selling orders, and there was a sharp recovery from the low spots.

In calling a strike of ground crews and flight service attendants on Pan American World Airways, Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union flouted the clear and usually respected provision of the Railway Labor Act governing orderly wage negotiations.

Vivien Leigh and Sir Laurence Olivier go on to portray Shakespeare's "Antony and Cleopatra" this evening at the Ziegfeld Theatre, having interpreted Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra" last night. The opening night curtain will rise at 7:20.

TODAY, 4:30 P. M.: Children of all faiths are invited to a free Christmas program, "The Light of the World," in the auditorium of Presbyterian Labor Temple, 242 East Fourteenth Street. Holiday customs of many races and creeds will be portrayed.

There was little change in the conduct of activities along the front in the Korean battle zone during the past twenty-four hours. United Nations Command ground elements continued to patrol, maintain and adjust their positions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The United States declared today that a defense command for the Middle East was being made necessary by the acknowledged and documented aggressive intentions of the Soviet Union toward that area.
Nine members of the Cleveland Browns--almost enough to round out a complete team--yesterday were named on the 1951 National Football League All-Star squad selected by United Press sports writers.

A fashion review of "careless attire," (definition of the word negligee, from Funk Wagnalls) was presented yesterday by the Fashion Group, Inc., at the Biltmore Hotel. It showed the imagination back of present-day leisure clothes.
The Caterpillar Tractor Company has acquired the Trackson Company of Milwaukee, it was announced yesterday by L.B. Neumiller, president of Caterpillar, and Walter H. Stiemke, Trackson president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Wheat production next year may be the third largest in history and big enough to supply all prospective demands and then some.
"Flame of Araby," a new Technicolor desert romp co-starring Maureen O'Hara and Jeff Chandler, is full of horses, sand, rocks, pulchritude, flowing veils and burnooses.

Freezing temperatures under clear skies chilled New Yorkers yesterday and kept an icy glaze on many thoroughfares to harass motorists and pedestrians. The crisp cold came as charts indicated another snowstorm, part of a national weather disturbance, would roar into the metropolitan area around noon today.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Sports writers voting in the sixteenth annual Turf and Sports Digest poll agreed with racing secretaries that Counterpoint was the best thoroughbred this year, but dissented when it came to the handicap leader.

The Federal Government has rejected an application of the Consolidated Edison Company to purchase $3,739,500 of smoke control equipment, thereby setting back by at least a year the utility's proposed modernization program.

With its first line figuring in all the scoring, the St. Paul's School hockey team of Concord, N.H., turned back Andover Academy, 5-3, in a benefit contest at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Life insurance companies representing 85 per cent of assets of all such companies made new commitments to acquire loans and investments in October amounting to $758,100,000 and 47.9 per cent of the total was for defense or defense-supporting purposes.

Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and now president of the University of Pennsylvania, is ready to announce whether he will be a candidate for the Republican nomination for President or support General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--As the Defense Department continued today the processing of United States prisoner names submitted by the Chinese Communists and North Koreans, President Truman urged that every emphasis be given the fact that the list was unverified.

The Board of Estimate in executive session last night declined to grant a hearing today to representatives of the line organizations of the Police and Fire Departments on their requests for a 30 per cent salary increase.

Three ministers of the East Harlem Protestant Parish continued yesterday their roles as moving men, relocating five of the families at 339 East 112th Street that have been without adequate heat since Sunday.

Brooklyn College gained its fourth basketball victory in five starts by downing Queens College, 63-48, last night on the Kingsmen's court. The winners got off to a quick lead and held a 37-19 margin at the intermission.

Offsetting Fordham's under-thebasket power with deadly longrange shooting, Columbia's scrappy quintet last night toppled the Rams from the ranks of the unbeaten. A 7-point surge in the final period gave the Lions a 47-46

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19-- John L. Lewis said today that the United Mine Workers and the soft coal operators had joined in proposing to the Government the setting up of an industry-union shipping corporation to develop a long-term, worldwide export coal trade.

Eleven issues of United States Government securities sold at new low prices yesterday as dealers retreated farther from the nominal price levels that have been prevailing lately in a thin market.

Sub-contracts for national defense work obtained by metalworking plants in this area have increased substantially since the third quarter. Nevertheless, many machine shops, sheet metal shops, stamping plants and plating shops...

The city is well repaid for the little it spends on centers for older people, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy told the 300 men and women over 60 who yesterday filled the Sirovich Day Center to overflowing in celebration of its second birthday.
The Dana Corporation and its subsidiaries, producers of automotive parts, announced yesterday increased sales for the quarter ended with November, but lower profits as a result of higher taxes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)-- The Government is undertaking a survey of grocery stores' costs and profits to determine whether retail food dealers are entitled to raise prices. Spokesmen have asked for a general increase, contending their costs have increased.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Dec. 19 (AP)-- Libya, whose independence is to be proclaimed two days after Christmas, soon will announce an important agreement granting to the United States long-term permission to maintain its Wheelus Field air base here, authoritative sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--The lie detector, for three decades a controversial instrument for testing criminal suspects, is now being used to test the integrity of persons employed, or seeking employment, in certain Federal agencies.

MUNSAN, Korea, Dec. 19--As United Nations truce delegates and advisers continued to study the enemy prisoner-of-war list for the second day, it became increasingly apparent that among the major problems in the armistice negotiations would be the method of exchanging North and South Korean prisoners.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Retail price advances that might range from $71 to $545 for passenger automobiles are sought in applications for increases filed with the Office of Price Stabilization by Ford, Studebaker, Hudson and Kaiser-Frazer, the agency disclosed tonight.

Recent cancellation by the Office of Price Stabilization of a 15 per cent increase granted early this year to carpet mills is not indicative that another general carpet price reduction is coming soon,...

Recent scientific evidence indicates that there is no clear division between heredity and environment in the shaping of human qualities, it was reported here last night at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

Dr. G. Carleton Lacy, Bishop of the Methodist Church in Foochow, Fukien Province, China, died of a heart ailment in Union Hospital there on Dec. 11, according to word received here yesterday. His age was 63.

PARIS, Dec. 19--The Special Nations General Assembly approved today the creation of a fivenation commission to conduct simultaneous investigations in both East and West Germany and determine if free unification elections were possible.

The best holiday skling since the record-breaking snows struck this area four years ago is in prospect for this week-end in the Northlands. Reports yesterday told of plenty of powder snow on bases and more snow is forecast today.

Political and Security Committee--Adopted tripartite disarmament resolution by vote of 44 to 5 with 10 abstentions; began consideration of Soviet complaint against United States Mutual Security Act of 1951.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 19 (AP)-- Arthur Capper, Governor of Kansas for four years and a United States Senator for thirty years before his retirement on Jan. 3, 1949, died tonight of pneumonia. He was 86 years old.

The prosecution rested its case yesterday in the trial of Tallulah Bankhead's former maid-secretary, Mrs. Evyleen Cronin, who was indicted on thirty-two counts of grand larceny and forgery after the actress accused her of slipping...

Identification of the last two unclaimed bodies of the fifty-six persons killed in the airline crash at Elizabeth N.J., on Sunday was made yesterday as it was announced unofficially that public hearings on the tragedy probably would be held in Elizabeth in about three weeks.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Dec. 20-- Robert Ashley Fairbairn, a retired member of the executive committee of the National Biscuit Company, who was for many years a leading figure in the horse world, died at his home here today at the age of 85.
Accountants of the Office of Price Stabilization have been making a survey of more than ninety rayon weaving mills to obtain data for dollars and cents ceilings, it was learned yesterday.

LAKE CHARLES, La., Dec. 19 (AP)--The trial judge joined the prosecuting attorney tonight in a scathing criticism of the manner in which The Lake Charles American Press conducted an anti-gambling crusade last summer.
Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan ruled yesterday that Gus Hall, convicted Communist leader, was guilty of criminal contempt for failing to surrender last July to begin a five-year term for conspiracy.

HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 19--The District Attorney of Columbia County testified today before the State Crime Commission that a known gambler had offered to pays him $100 a month for advance warnings of any clean-up campaigns.

Short interest in all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange dropped 111,662 shares between Nov. 15 and Dec. 14, the Exchange reported yesterday. On the latter date there were short interests in 887 of the 1,496 individual stock issues, aggregating 2,450,584 shares.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--An experimental program designed to resettle during the coming year 115,000 refugees now in overpopulated countries of Europe was reported ready to President Truman today by Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 18-- In the opinion of some well-informed persons in this most "neutral" of neutral capitals of Europe, the United States is overlooking its best bet for strengthening European resistance to communism at low cost.

The strike that immobilized two Israeli-flag freighters in East Coast American ports last week is part of a larger dispute over union autonomy in election of officers and negotiations, a spokesman for the striking seamen said here yesterday.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 37 to 69 points yesterday, with strength most pronounced in near months.

The four-story dwelling with garden at 247 East Fiftieth Street has been purchased by a stage artist, who plans to alter and occupy it, it was announced yesterday by William B. May Co., the brokers in the sale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19--Secretary of State Dean Acheson, surveying the aims and accomplishments of a six-week-long diplomatic mission in Paris and Rome, said today that Europe had moved further toward unity in the past four years than in the preceding five centuries.

Mayor Impellitteri, leading educators, teachers, members of local school boards and others attended a dinner last night in tribute to Maximilian Moss, president of the Board of Education, who is to be sworn in Jan. 1 as a justice of the Brooklyn Supreme Court.
The time is one hundred and thirty-three years ago this month; the place is Oberndorf, a village not far from Salzburg.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Business outlays for new plants and equipment in the first quarter of 1952 are expected to exceed any previous first quarter and, if realized, the seasonally adjusted rate will be at a new high level, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Commerce reported today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 20--It was learned today that Croatian Communist party leaders had been forced to purge the peasant members of their party to halt the movement that developed last spring, summer and autumn to break up the collective farms.

John Nicholas Brown of Providence and Newport, R. I., former Assistant Secretary of Navy for Air, last night was elected commodore of the New York Yacht Club, succeeding Henry S. Morgan, who had held that office for three years.

Probably no city in the world offers Christmas in so many flavors as does New York. Yorkville bakes glistening tree cakes for its German-American households. Around Bleecker Street there is Italian-style strufoli for sale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The Selective Service System announced today that it would start next month to reconsider for military service some 300,000 young men who had been rejected earlier for failure to pass the mental test.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Dec. 20-- Two college students returning home for Christmas were killed on slippery Taconic State Parkway today eight miles beyond the point where two others were injured critically yesterday.

A long separation, complicated by months of dodging Communists in Korea and bucking official red tape, has ended for the Whang family of Seoul. The story of how the Rev. Andrew Whang and his wife and four children were reunited here after a five-year separation was told yesterday by the Korean minister at a luncheon in the Presbyterian Labor Temple, 242 East Fourteenth Street.

Another facet of Emlyn Williams' diversified histrionic equipment will be displayed by the actor-playwright-director when he appears here in a one-man program of readings culled from the impressive output of a favorite author, Charles Dickens.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Dec. 20 --Formation of an organization to aid small business men in international trade was proposed by Richard C. Patterson, American Minister to Switzerland, in a speech before the American Club of Geneva today.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec, 20-- At a sales meeting of the PhillipsJones Corporation here today Clinton Smullyan vice president fort sales and advertising, announced

The Kremlin has lost a major propaganda battle in Paris. The defeat came when the General Assembly of the United Nations, acting as a committee, turned down by an overwhelming vote the Soviet "disarmament" proposals and adopted instead the Western plan.

Mrs. Evyleen Cronin testified yesterday that, as Tallulah Bankhead's maid, she had advanced her own money and borrowed from others to pay for the actress' filet mignons, lobsters, champagne, bourbon and $10 tips to cab drivers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Government hopes of heading off a New Year's Eve steel strike dimmed tonight as top Federal mediators reported "no progress" in their initial efforts to effect a wage agreement.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 24--James A. Rafferty of Rye, N. Y., vice president and a director of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, died here last night, after a brief illness. His age was 65.
Jean Letourneau, French Minister of State for French Union Affairs, has expressed dissatisfaction over the rate of delivery of United States military aid to Indo-China.

SYDNEY, Australia Dec. 20 (AP) --Capt. Frank Shields will not make any decision on his singles players until just before the Davis Cup tennis matches with Australia, but every sign points to Ted Schroeder and Vic Seixas as the nominees for the United States.
The eleven-story-and-penthouse apartment building at 11 East Sixty-eighth Street, corner of Madison Avenue, has been resold by Louis J. Glickman, operator, to a clent of Jacob Aks, attorney.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20--Today was the last session for trading in December deliveries of grain for 1951, and the market had a seesaw character in all pits, as contracts were evened up.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Dec. 20-- Carl H. Stoffregen, head of Steinwender, Stoffregen Co., coffee importers and exporters of Wall Street until its liquidation was started last year, died here yesterday in his home, 240 South Mountain Avenue.

LONDON, Dec. 20--Two of the largest Cunarders ever built, specifically for the steamship line's Canadian service, are to be constructed by John Brown of Clydeside, the Cunard Shipping Company announced today.

A certain amount of friction in families is "just plain natural," six youngsters agreed yesterday, adding that the only way to ease difficult situations is for each family member to try hard to understand and respect the wishes and rights of the others.
Many retailers all over the country have increased their dollar sales volume for television receivers in the last four weeks as much as 100 per cent, store spokesmen reported yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 20 (AP)-- Thirty to forty pro-Government supporters joined in an organized boycott of the Iranian Parliament today and a scheduled session had to be postponed as political tension mounted.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 21--Gen Matthew B. Ridgway, the United Nations Commander, called on the Communists today to admit the International Red Cross to prisoner-of-war stockades in North Korea in advance of an armistice in the Korean war "with no other consideration in mind than the welfare of these men and the distress of their families."

Cross-currents ran through the stock market yesterday with preholiday influences bringing a lag in trading, leaving final prices highly mixed. Changes spread out a point and more in both directions and, while more stocks showed declines than gains, the composite rate managed an increase of 0.36 point due to the strength in a few of the industrial issues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24--The Navy Chapel was the setting here this evening for the marriage of Miss Rosalie Janaon Barringer, daughter of Rear Admiral Victor Cameron Barringer, U. S. N., retired, and Mrs. Barringer, to Second Lieut.
Management and control of D. A. Schulte, Inc., operator of 161 of the familiar Schulte stores in ninety-seven cities, was assumed yesterday by a group headed by N. C. Earl Jr. and Frederick Lewisohn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The Railway Express Agency and Class I railroads which own it, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve an increase in express rates of almost twice that authorized late in October.
The city and its assortment of cats, dogs, birds arid others feathered and four-footed creatures will lose the services of a leader in the humane field on Jan. l,...
Midwinter conditions in the Northlands should provide Eastern skiers wills their best ChristmasNew Year's holiday sport since 1947-48.

ROME, Dec. 20--The first description of the original grave in which St. Peter's body was laid immediately after his martyrdom was given today to the Italian and foreign press by the archaeologists who carried on the excavations under the floor of St. Peter's Basilica.

LONDON, Dec. 20--William L. Batt, chief of the United States aid mission in Britain, made an attack today on two assumptions about the United States that are widely held here--that Americans are not sacrificing enough for defence and that arms production is lagging unduly.

The Beethoven program given by George Szell and the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, with Nathan Milstein as soloist in the violin concerto, not only attracted but greatly moved an immense audience.

What the Oliviers began on Wednesday evening they completed last evening magnificently. In their scheme the Shaw play about Cleopatra is prologue to Shakespeare's romantic tragedy, "Antony and Cleopatra,"...
The belated release by the enemy --a seeming concession--of the names of the United States prisoners of war in Korea has given the Communists another advantage in the armistice negotiations.

The Board of Estimate rejected yesterday the request of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System for a 15-cent fare and a 2-cent transfer charge on its bus lines in Manhattan and the Bronx. The company now charges an interim fare of 10 cents with no charge for transfers.
PARIS, Dec. 20 (AP)--Charles Humez, European welterweight champion, said today he had agreed to meet the world title-holder, Kid Gavilan of Cuba, in a title bout at Madison Square Garden, March 28.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--A talk with Henry W. Grunewald revealed today that the mystery witness whose testimony was sought by the House Ways and Means subcommittee investigating tax scandals did not speak with a heavy German accent and that his voice was not thick and guttural.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The United States has "categorically" denied charges by the Soviet Union that the Mutual Security Act is aimed aggressively at the Soviet Union and that it violates an exchange of correspondence in 1933 between the late President Roosevelt and Maxim M. Litvinov, the then Soviet Foreign Minister.
TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 20 (UP)-- Many messages of condolence on the death of former Senator Arthur Capper, including one from, President Truman, arrived here today.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20--Two more Pennsylvania companies have, voluntarily returned to the Goverment $221,000 in extra profits made on Federal contracts.
Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., usually leaves a door ajar when he negotiates a new contract with the employers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--W. Stuart Symington, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, made it clear today that his agency has not budged in its insistence that $1.12 a pound is a fair price to be paid for Bolivian tin, which Bolivians insist is worth a minimum of $1.50 a pound.

Dechard A. Hulcy, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, urged more help yesterday for Great Britain, where, he said, the Conservative party was trying to "shore up the failure of a socialist experiment."

The Yuletide spirit prevailed yesterday in the Golden Age Center at 24 Pell Street, in the heart of Chinatown, and through the afternoon the joyous shouts of 150 Chinese children mingled with expressions of delight from elder folk in the exchange of gifts.

PARIS, Dec. 20 (AP)--The late Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain said he had wanted to escape France and join the Allies after the Germans had invaded the unoccupied zone of France in 1942 but did not have a plane and then was forced to go to Germany.
Thomas P. Hoier of 629 West 135th Street, veteran actor, died yesterday at Polyclinic Hospital. His age was 74.

The Goodphil Realty Corporation purchased the apartment house at 870 East 175th Street, the Bronx; from a client of Langsam Schiffman, brokers. Assessed at $61,000, the property was sold subject to mortgages of $29,775.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- The Public Affairs Institute said today the American aluminum industry is not competitive enough, and is dominated by the "Big' Three of Alcoa, Reynolds and Kaiser."

The first major efforts of City Council President Rudolph Halley to effect reforms in the city administration failed yesterday when the City Council almost solidly rejected his resolutions proposing an inquiry into the Fire Department and asking Mayor Impellitteri to remove two city officials.

A man known as "The Angel," long sought as a key figure in the East Harlem marijuana racket, was arrested on his arrival from Panama yesterday and accused of possessing enough marijuana to make 30,000 to 40,000 drugged cigarettes, or $10,000 worth.

MONTREAL, Dec. 20 (UP)--The Montreal Canadiens staged a threegoal uprising during a hectic minute and 45 seconds of the third period tonight to beat the secondplace Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 to 1, in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 13,661 at the Forum.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Multiple and "unwarranted" Congressional investigations at the Savannah River hydrogen-bomb materials plant now under construction near Aiken, S. C., have "plagued" both the Atomic Energy Commission and the prime contractor and hampered work, according to testimony and reports released at the Capitol today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--Multiple and "unwarranted" Congressional investigations at the Savannah River hydrogen-bomb materials plant now under construction near Aiken, S. C., have "plagued" both the Atomic Energy Commission and the prime contractor and hampered work, according to testimony and reports released at the Capitol today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- The Russian Embassy asked today, for the second time this week, that the State Department find the "unknown hooligans" it said had torn down brass name plates at the embassy.

A thoughtful if somewhat too earnest production of "The Skin of Our Teeth," Thornton Wilder's comedy on the struggles of the human race, served on Wednesday night to mark the return to television of one of last season's better dramatic attractions, the Pulitzer Prize Playhouse.
California Eastern Airways, Inc., has purchased three instrument and electronics companies for S69,700 and 73,171 shares of Airways stock, Andre de Saint-Phalle, board chairman disclosed yesterday.

Home building throughout New York State continued to decline in November, and unemployment in the building trades increased. This was disclosed yesterday in a report issued by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner.

CAIRO, Dec. 20--A ceremony described in the local press as "imposing" took place on the grounds of Fuad I University of Cairo today to mark the departure of the first contingent of about fifty student guerrillas for the Suez Canal zone "front."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20,--During the week ended Dec. 19, member bank reserves increased $834,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Mayor Impellitteri moved yesterday to head off a strike by coal and fuel-oil delivery men, threatened for New Year's Eve, after receiving reports from Daniel Kornblum, his chief labor troubleshooter, that contract talks were making no progress.

Moving quickly to beat the Dec. 31 capital budget deadline, the Board of Education in a special meeting yesterday awarded contracts totaling $22,319,916 for the construction of thirteen new school units and in doing so established three school construction records.

Over the opposition of Minority Leader, Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Republican-Liberal, the City Council approved yesterday the proposed record $505,483,396 capital budget for 1952. The final tally was twenty-four Democrats solidly in favor, with Mr. Isaacs not voting.

A Kings County jury returned verdicts last night providing both for a death sentence and a fortyyear-to-life prison term for Camilo Leyra Jr., who won a new trial after being sentenced last May for the hammer slaying of his mother and father. Which of the two possible sentences will be imposed was not made clear.

They didn't give a party for Marty the Cop yesterday, for the hugely agreeable reason that Patrolman Martin Sheehy of the East Fifth Street station may be back on his post after all when the holidays are over.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 21 --Montgomery Waddell, a retired consulting engineer who had worked with Thomas A. Edison in his laboratories at Menlo Park, N.J., died today in Norwalk Hospital after a month's illness. His age was 89.
The State Board of Regents will appoint next month a commission to investigate whether school textbooks contain any subversive material.

PARIS, Dec. 21--Gen. Charles de Gaulle announced today that he had his own plan for a European Confederation and the organization of its confederal military armed forces, which ha said he would submit soon to the French National Assembly in a formal bill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)-- Secretary of State Dean G. Acheson has urged W. Stuart Symington, director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, to review his agency's attitude toward foreign tin purchases, informed officials said today.

CENTREVILLE, Md., Dec. 21 (AP)--Two United States Air Force pilots reportedly dived the tail off a British Canberra jet bomber during a test today and one was killed when the plane exploded in the air.

Cardinal Spellman was among the 494 contributors to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. They donated $10,817.16 to bring the campaign total to $181,483.90 on the twelfth day of the drive.

The Gulf Oil Corporation has sold the gasoline station with two stores on a plot 57 by 135 feet at Rockaway and Woods Avenue in Rockville Centre, L.I., to L. Marshall for cash above a mortgage of $16,000. Title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--In an atmosphere of pessimism, the Government's top industrial peacemakers abandoned today their efforts to ward off a New Year's Eve steel strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The Department of Justice disclosed today that four former employes of the Office of Alien Property or its predecessor had received, individually or as members of law firms, an aggregate of about $110,000 from a company seized in the war.

The flowers and greens with which florist shops fairly bulge before Christmas, may serve to decorate homes from doorway to dining table, or be sent as gifts. In either case, last-minute shopping is apt to be the rule.
Laszlo Halasz, musical director of the New York City Opera Company since its start in February, 1944, was dismissed yesterday by the board of the City Center of Music and Drama.
New Yorkers gave voice yesterday to the summer cliche: "It's not the heat; it's the humidity."
Ruling out influence, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan said yesterday that merit alone would dictate promotions in the department as long as he was its head.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)-- The Government said today its order setting dollars-and-cents ceiling prices on pulpwood produced in Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan will become effective on Monday.

Christmas group shows of painting and sculpture are as varied as might be expected. The display at the Art for Interiors Gallery features work by ten American artists who have been working under the G.I. bill. That is their only common denominator, for, stylistically, they travel alone or in small company.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (UP)--Joseph Short, White House press secretary, has branded as a "detestable slander" portions of a resolution adopted by the convention of Sigma Delta Chi, the professional journalistic fraternity reported to night.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 21--The rain for which the Israelis had prayed in vain for more than a year has turned to disaster in the last seven days of an almost continuous downpour.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 18 --Prof. Gustav Hertz, German scientist who won the 1925 Nobel Prize for Physics, and who was reported dead after having been kidnapped by the Russians after the German surrender in 1945, is alive and working in the Soviet Union.

CAIRO, Dec. 21--British military authorities in Suez Canal zone imposed a sunset-to-sunrise curfew today an the southern approaches to Ismailia, where one British officer was killed and two enlisted men were wounded by Egyptian snipers Tuesday night.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 22 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 1,105, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A.M., Saturday (4 P.M., Friday, Eastern standard time):

BONN, Germany, Dec. 21--John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner in Germany, charged today that Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, had indulged in "hit-and-run" tactics that had led to "hit-or-miss" statements when he asserted that Mr. McCloy and members of his staff were living "like princes" at United States Government expense.

WEST FRANKFORT, Ill., Dec. 21--The bodies of four men were taken out of a coal mine near here tonight and state police said that about 100 men were believed trapped by a fire that followed any explosion.
Westerly winds and high seas on the Atlantic continued to abate yesterday and, as a result of the clearing weather, inbound liners adhered to their storm-tossed schedules.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP)-- Connie Mack will be 89 years odd tomorrow and his only regret is that the 1951 baseball season wasn't long enough for his Athletics.

ATHENS, Dec. 21--The sum of economic aid Greece will receive from the United States during the current fiscal year is $182,000,000, Roger D. Lapham, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration's mission here, told the Greek Government today shortly after his return from Washington.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 21-- Maj. Gen. Frederick A. Irving, superintendent of the United States Military Academy, announced today that a medallion has been struck in commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the founding of the academy.

An undersea mountain, more than a mile high, with its peak more than a mile and a half below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean, was discovered last summer off the New England coast by a team of Columbia University geologists.

Mrs. Evyleen Cronin testified yesterday that she had used her own money to pay for cocaine for Tallulah Bankhead and for marijuana cigarettes, which she watched the actress and her friends smoke "with deep breaths."

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 21--As the second winter of war in Korea begins officially today a team of surgeons, physicians and technicians of the three branches of the United States armed forces is working around the clock to prevent cold-weather injuries from reaching last winter's alarming number.

Magistrate J. Roland Sala was cleared of charges of unfitness in a report by Official Referee Peter B. Smith of the Brooklyn Supreme Court, made public yesterday after its approval by the Appellate Division, Second Department.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 21 (UP) --Herbert Mortimer Trull, 37 years old, managing editor of The Nashville Banner, was burned to death today in a fire that destroyed his cottage in suburban Belle Meade. He apparently had fallen asleep on a couch. He lived alone.
ASTORIA, Ore., Dec. 21 (AP)--A storm forced the Coast Guard today to abandon an attempt to control the fire on the motorship Erria, her plates glowing red from a blaze that left eleven missing.
Trading was highly active in cocoa and coffee futures yesterday, the former reaching new highs for its recovery movement, the latter zigzagging irregularly to even up.

The stock market was unable yesterday to maintain the moderate lift present in some of the previous sessions of the week and drifted to a lower position. None of the news developments seemed to upset the general tenor of the day's proceedings. In fact, the steel issues generally maintained an unchanged course despite the collapse of the talks between the steel workers' union officials and the representatives of that industry.

Dan Bucceroni, rangy Philadelphia heavyweight, last night projected himself into the front ranks of the title challengers by pounding Roland La Starza, Bronx collegian, into defeat in ten rounds of torrid fighting at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--John Stewart Service, career diplomat dismissed last week on grounds of reasonable doubt of his loyalty, challenged today the authority of the Loyalty Review Board to reverse his acquittal by the State Department's loyalty board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)-- The Federal Power Commission authorized the Portland General Electric Company today to build a power project on the Deschutes River in Oregon despite claims by conservation groups that the dam would be harmful to salmon runs.

Lee Sabinson, producer of the successful "Finian's Rainbow" and "Home of the Brave," has acquired for Broadway presentation a new musical called "Love Is the Doctor." His plans are to have the project under way by mid-March, if casting can be completed by then. The leading role is said to call for a star "with a distinctive comic style."

As late shoppers and office party-goers poured out of the city last night for the beginning of their four-day holiday, transportation facilities creaked under what some officials called an "unprecedented burden."

In a glittering silver and white holiday setting the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball was held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria and adjoining suites. More than 100 young women, most of them making their formal debuts, had subscribed to the ball. Underwritten by Kayser, the party was a benefit for the New York Infirmary.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 21--Timed to promote the ratification of the Schuman plan by the West German Bundestag next month, the text of an Allied promise to abolish the International Authority for the Ruhr, one of the last remaining symbols of the occupation, was published today.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 21--Communist-ruled Hungary announced tonight that she would bring to trial the four United States airmen whose plane was forced down in this country last

St. John's, which has good reason to respect the Southeastern Conference brand of basketball after the thumping it received from Kentucky in Lexington last Monday, will oppose Vanderbilt, one of the two teams that beat the Wildcats last season, at Madison Square Garden tonight.

FRANCONIA, N.H., Dec. 21-- Cross-country and slalom skiers will make their earliest competitive start since 1945 in this part of the country tomorrow and Sunday when pre-season races are held at this state-owned project on 4,200-foot high Cannon Mountain. Close to 100 were busy tonight trying to determine the proper wax for the slender boards that will carry them over nine miles of roll ing country.
Japanese manufacturers are speeding up deliveries of scarce ultraprecision inspection and testing instruments greatly needed by plants working on national defense contracts.

PARIS, Dec. 21--The top political committee of the United Nations General Assembly rejected today formal Soviet demands that the world organization condemn the United States for an item on the Mutual Security Act providing aid to anti-Communists of Eastern Europe and call on Washington to repeal the law.
An Associated Press survey of All-America players and leading teams showed yesterday that many gridiron stars are betterthan-average students--contrary to the general idea.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The Department of Agriculture fixed 1952 quotas for imports and domestic production of sugar today and purposely set the figure 400,000 short tons below estimated consumption as a price stimulus.
ROME, Dec. 21--The Italian Government considers that revision of the Italian treaty is an accomplished fact as of today, the Foreign Ministry announced early this afternoon.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 22-- The United Nations and Communists made charges and countercharges against each other today as the truce subcommittee on an exchange of prisoners in the Korean war met again in a tent at Panmunjom.

Shoppers fought the inclement weather yesterday to complete late Christmas shopping to the extent that merchants were willing to predict sales this week would equal volume for the like week last year.

PARIS, Dec. 18 (By Airmail)-- Fashions in Christmas tree adornment, as exciting as other Paris fashions, once again make enchanting backgrounds for gift displays in glittering couture boutiques. Against snowy rabbit skins smothering the bows of Jacques Heim's bewitching tree gleam red balls tied on by black velvet bows.

After one day of attempted intercession in the steel wage dispute, Cyrus S. Ching, Director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, has found the possibilities of this approach "hopeless." He has referred the problem to the President.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on $32,835,000 worth of temporary loan notes for the financing of three state-aided projects. The best bids represented borrowing costs ranging from 1.25 per cent to 1.40 per cent.

PARIS, Dec. 21--Dr. Luis Padillo Nervo of Mexico, president of the United Nations General Assembly, expressed the belief today that the current session had improved peace prospects between East and West. He added that the "calmer atmosphere" in Paris had helped. The Assembly adjourned this morning for the Christmas recess and will reconvene Jan. 2.

There is hardly any inhabited spot on earth today, except for the lands behind the Iron Curtain, where a citizen may not look up from his work at almost any time and see a United States Senator or Representative bearing down on him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--Dan A. Kimball, Secretary of the Navy, said tonight he had not decided yet whether to keep William E. Willett, who was under fire as a director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, in his new $11,800 Navy job.
Fred T. Caldwell of 770 Park Avenue, a director of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and associated companies, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. His age was 68.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP)--Robert J. Caldwell, industrialist and former United States industrial commissioner and author, died in a hospital today after a brief illness. He was 76 years old. Until early last year, he had made his home in New York, spending his winters here.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 21-- Amid surroundings of academic pageantry at Syracuse University today ninety-three Air Force officers and airmen were graduated as fully qualified Russian language specialists, the first group to finish the intensive eleven-month course in the Russian language school here.
Public hearings on the demand of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., for a forty-hour week on private bus lines were completed yesterday.

Italy has thrown off the shackles imposed by the peace treaty of 1947 and has resumed an equal station among the nations of the world. This has been achieved by a procedure which sets a precedent in the peaceful revision of treaties. Responding to an Itailian appeal, the majority of the ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The consumers' price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics went up 0.6 per cent to a new high in the month that ended Nov. 15, assuring pay rises for millions of workers under the Government's cost-of-living wage stabilization policy.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP)--Charlie Burr, 17-year-old rider from Arkansas City, Kan., pushed a long-shot through on the inside in the eighth race at Tropical Park today to become the seventh jockey in American turf history to boot home 300 or more winners in a year.
A homeless Pennsylvania youth with 60 cents in his pocket stood yesterday before Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman to be sentenced for the interstate theft of an automobile.
FORT BRAGG, N.C., Dec. 21-- Fourteen hundred North Carolina orphans were the happy guests of airmen at Pope Air Force Base here today as a $50,000 Christmas party was staged for them.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21--Grain futures, after showing a little early strength, were under considerable selling pressure later and markets sagged. Trade was quiet and largely of a holiday character.

With the four-day Christmas week-end beginning today, New Yorkers yesterday were rushing through their late shopping, dropping in at office parties, and in many cases, playing Santa Claus to thousands of children in settlement houses and hospitals.
An upstate attorney, poured a bagful of 117 summonses and complaints into the lap of the Corporation Counsel yesterday to begin suits for $1,500,000 damages against the city for its rainmaking.
VIENNA, Dec. 21 (AP)--A big shake-up in the Soviet occupation command in Austria was disclosed today.

Sixty attorneys, title men and other realty experts and an agenda containing more than seventy items were required yesterday to close a complicated realty transaction transferring a controlling interest in the Empire State Building to the Detroit syndicate that contracted for its purchase last May.
Pierre Du Pasquier and Serge Landeau on Jan. 4 will form the new New York Stock Exchange firm of Du Pasquier Landeau, with offices at E.F. Hutton Co.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The cost of borrowed money to the Treasury is rising rapidly. The Government today incurred a cost of 1.865 per cent in refunding for three months an issue of $1,200,000,000 of 91-day discount bills.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 21 (AP)--The third Bolivarian Games closed tonight in a brilliant pyrotechnical display before 20,000 persons in Olympic Stadium.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 21 (AP) --The average American, who takes his tennis in stride, could have no comprehension of the fever heat with which the Australians are awaiting next week's Davis Cup challenge round.

Refusal of Denmark to sign the recently negotiated Torquay agreement on tariff reductions by Dec. 31 was believed certain yesterday. Such a decision, it was said, would constitute a Danish "protest" against the drastic new United States restrictions on cheese imports.

Ralph Kiner of the Pirates, perennial home-run king of the circuit, and Stan Musial of the Cardinals, highest percentage batter among all the long-service players currently active in baseball, shared National League slugging honors in 1951.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The first of the price advances granted to auto manufactures under the so-called Capehart Amendment to the Defense Production Act was approved today by the Office of Price Stabilization.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 21 (AP)--Premier Marshal Tito lashed out tonight at Western critics of military aid to Yugoslavia and declared that "our glorious army can defeat any enemies who would dare to attack."

ALTON, Ill., Dec. 21 (AP)--The Frost Lumber Industries, Inc., of Shreveport, La., will become a division of Olin Industries, Inc., of East Alton as a result of a deal involving four small railroads and large holdings in three states. The merger was approved on Wednesday by Frost stockholders and yesterday by Olin.

KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 21--One man was killed and three others critically injured early today when a car traveling in the opposite direction crossed the white dividing line and crashed head-on into the automobile in which the four men were riding on rain-swept Pulaski Skyway over the Passaic River.

Speaking before the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei Y. Vishinsky, referred to the case of four American military fliers forced down in Hungary a month ago. "I hope," he shouted, "that due attention will be given to them by our military and judical ...

Directors of the Franklin National Bank, Franklin Square, L.I., declared yesterday a stock dividend of four shares for each 279 held of record of Jan. 8. It is subject to approval by stockholders and the Controller of the Currency. The bank had paid a stock dividend of four shares for each 250 held as of Oct. 22 and a 100 per cent stock dividend on July 1.

An Army general court-martial on Governors Island sentenced three soldiers yesterday to fifteen years' imprisonment as ringleaders of a guardhous riot at Fort Jay on Sept. 17. Four others were sentenced to nine years each.
Federal Judge Edward A. Conger refused yesterday to dismiss the conspiracy indictment against the seventeen secondary Communist leaders. At the same time he denied four other pre-trial motions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The railroads of the nation filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today advance copies of evidence to be presented in support of their request for an increase in freight rates of 15 per cent over those prevailing last March 1.
Solemn prayers for peace will mingle with the joyous chanting of Christmas carols during they next three days as the churchgoers of America renew their devotion to the Christ Child.

Laszlo Halasz said yesterday he still considered himself director of the New York Opera Company and had refused to resign because he "did not wish to sell the truth for $12,000." He produced letters in his support from forty-four members of the company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--The Senate's special investigating subcommittee has subpoenaed Frank Nathan, already under fire in a charge involving a $500,000 tax shakedown attempt, to explain what he did to earn a $57,000 commission in a surplus property transaction.

LONDON, Dec. 23--Salisbury Cathedral's Gothic spire, the tallest in England and the one generally considered to be the finest, has been thoroughly repaired and partly rebuilt for the first time in its 600-year history.

For today's column, some of the just-published cookbooks are considered. They are as varied as the subject of cooking itself. One deals with barbecuing, another with the traditional French cuisine and a third is devoted exclusively to meats and poultry.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23--The steel operating rate last week advanced to a new high of 105 per cent of rated capacity, up one point from the week before. There was little doubt in steel circles here that the tonnage for the year would go over 105 million tons--a figure undreamed of less than ten years ago.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 24--Allied and Communist truce negotiators agreed, at Panmunjom today to an exchange of mail between prisoners of war and their families, and the Communists delivered the first one--a letter from Maj. Gen. William F. Dean.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 23 --The project to create a Nordic interparliamentary advisory council headed by the premiers and foreign ministers of each country has run into difficulties.

Declaring that New York City is unable to meet fully the need for new school buildings, the United Parents Associations has urged Governor Dewey to recommend to the Legislature an appropriation for the construction of ten buildings here in 1952.

FORT KNOX, Ky., Dec. 23 (AP)-- Master Sgt. Andrew M. Timchick, 38 years old, of Pittsburgh today became the twenty-second Fort Knox soldier to die in an automobile accident on the "Dixie DieWay" in 1951. The "Die-Way" is a fifty-mile stretch on United States Route 31-W between Louisville and Elizabethtown, Ky., so named because of its high rate of traffic fatalities.

John M. McMillin of 435 East Fifty-second Street, a vice president and director of Cities Service Company, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack in 745 Fifth Avenue. His age was 68.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman directed the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation yesterday to get its Bronx bus operations on a self-sustaining basis and indicated that he would order the lines abandoned unless this could be done.

Two companies announced yesterday prices on men's shirts and underwear for next spring. Quotations on all staple Van Heusen merchandise will be the same or lower than in the fall, according to Ben Smullyan, executive vice president of the Phillips-Jones Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--A Congressional appropriation of "several million dollars" for research into the suppression of airplane noise was proposed today by Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Gen-- eral Peyton C. March, chief of staff of the Army during World War I, today marked his eightyseventh birthday.

ALBANY, Dec. 27--Another battle in the Legislature over the legislation of yellow-colored oleomargarine appeared likely today as Governor Dewey disagreed with a state-wide farm group that had urged him to continue the ban.

The Board of Education, at its final meeting of 1951, established yesterday the $8,500-a-year position of public relations assistant and named Austin J. Collins to the post.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--T. Lamar Caudle, whose unwise choice of social companions and occasional dim concept of ethical standards resulted in his dismissal by President Truman from the Department of Justice, was made an assistant attorney general by Tom C. Clark after the latter was confirmed as head of the department in June, 1945.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 27-- National maritime freight rates will be increased if the maritime workers win their demand for higher pay.

Gil Turner, the 21-year-old welterweight from Philadelphia, will make his first appearance in a New York ring when he opposes Vic Cardell of Hartford tonight. The pair will clash in the star bout scheduled for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.
With a song in their hearts and a tidy dollar in their pockets, tunesmiths are hailing 1951 as the most lucrative year in the history of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP)-- The United States produced between 4,500 and 5,000 military aircraft of all types in 1951, Admiral DeWitt C. Ramsey, president of the Aircraft Industries Association, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--A former attorney and investigator for the Senate subcommittee considering the proposed expulsion from the Senate of Joseph R. McCarthy charged today that evidence was being assembled to follow "a predetermined pattern of prejudice" against the Wisconsin Republican.

BOSTON, Dec. 27--Top economists in finance, Government, business and the universities agreed at the annual meetings of their professional organizations here today that inflation in this country, for the time being, had been fought to a "stand-off."

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 28 (Reuters)--New orders for British ships reached an all-time record in 1951, J. Ramsey Gebbie, president of the Shipbuilding Conference, reported today in Lloyd's List, an annual review. More than 1,000 orders, worth $1,540,000,000 to British shipyards, were placed.

Police Commissioner Monaghan dismissed nine plainclothes men yesterday as an aftermath of the Brooklyn gambling investigation. Assistant Chief Inspector John J. Travers, who was demoted to captain, filed his retirement papers. [1:l.]

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 27--Another gasoline price war appeared imminent today as three major refining companies dropped wholesale prices in northern New Jersey counties and service stations passed the reductions along to their customers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)-- The Department of Commerce said today that a New York exporter and two foreign concerns had been ordered barred from United States export trade for secretly shipping strategic war chemicals to Communist Hungary.

Sales of Lewyt Corporation vacuum cleaners this year are 40 per cent higher than in 1950, Alex Lewyt president, reported yesterday. The gain was achieved, he pointed out, in the face of strong consumer buying resistance to all types of appliances.

Two of America's major symphony orchestras--the Boston and Philadelphia--are likely to be touring in Europe next May. The Boston Symphony's trip was announced definitely yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The Bureau of Internal Revenue will seek "substantially more" manpower and higher pay for at least 15,000 of its employes as it seeks to root out sources of corruption in the nation's tax collecting apparatus.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 27 --Sheriff Fred W. Ruscoe of Westchester County died this afternoon in the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital at the age of 58. He had entered the hospital for an emergency operation, performed last Monday. His home was at Lake Waccabuc, in northern Westchester.

Startling as it may seem, GianCarlo Menotti, composer-authordirector, is no longer eager to have his works done on Broadway. Such wasn't the case, though, with his previous successes--"The Consul" and the double bill of "The Medium" and "The Telephone."

Some assurance returned to the market for United States Government obligations shortly before the close yesterday afternoon after twenty of the Treasury's thirty-six issues of interest-bearing obligations had touched new lows for the year and 2 per cent bonds due in eighteen years had touched a yield basis of 2.76 per cent.

Alfred Lunt, star of the Broadway stage for a quarter of a century, will appear in a brief bit at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight in the first performance of the revival of Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte."

ROME, Dec. 27--Egyptian Foreign Minister Mohamed Salah elDin Pasha expressed gratification at a press conference here today over King Farouk's appointment of two allegedly pro-British former Ambassadors as his foreign policy advisers.

The absence of further sales for tax purposes enabled the stock market yesterday to chalk up its sharpest recovery in three weeks. The rebound, although not accompanied by any increase in volume, canceled the losses sustained on Wednesday and produced a rise of 1.30 points in the composite rate.
