CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP)--Farm real estate moved up 3.6 per cent in value in the July-September quarter in the North Central States, the Seventh Federal Reserve District reported today.

City Council President Rudolph Halley and Janice Brosh, a registered nurse, were married yesterday afternoon by David W. Peck, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in the justice's chambers at Twentyfifth Street and Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, head of the Maritime Administration, said today that serious problems were in store for America's merchant marine. As examples, the Maritime Administrator cited shortages of steel, manpower and a "pressing" need for new passenger vessels and tankers.

Erica Morini, last night's violin soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony, played the immortal--although well worn--Concerto in E minor by Mendelssohn. Fortunately, Miss Morini is one of the world's best violinists, and her playing was on the level where technique transcends technical matters.

A 56-year-old janitor Was rescued yesterday from his burning one-room apartment in the basement of 3871 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx, where he was stubbornly trying to save his pets, a black cat and a fox terrier with a litter of puppies.
Alexander Trachtenberg, 67-yearold Communist official and party worker since the 1905 Russian revolution, who is one of the sixteen lesser Communists now out on bail and awaiting trial on an ...

PARIS, Dec. 27--For the second time today the Finance Committee of the National Assembly revised the Government proposals on the appropriation bill, rejecting among other items, plans for the reform of the social security and railway systems.
Elaine Cutler, designer for Kay Dunhill, introduced her latest cruise costume collection yesterday at a showing in Franklin Simon's.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27--A New York psychoanalyst said today that in sex education parents should take what they readily can accept of experts' advice and use their own intuition, common sense and natural understanding.

St. James Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Kristin Longfellow Curtis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Curbs of Washington, to Officer Candidate Francis Bacon Lothrop Jr., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lothrop of Boston.

SYDNEY, Friday, Dec. 28 (AP)-- Australia retained the Davis Cup, 3 matches to 2, today when Frank Sedgman crushed young Vic Seixas of the United States in the deciding singles match of the challenge round, 6-4, 6-2, 6-2.

ALEXANDRIA. Va., Dec. 27-- In historic Christ Protestant Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Leandra Sherman McCormick-Goodhart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leander McCormickGoodhart of Bellapais, Alexandria, ...
Refiners announced here yesterday that lead prices have been reduced one-half cent a pound in Mexico. This is the second price reduction this month for prompt deliveries.
A redesigned front end, with longer and lower hood, is among the outstanding new factors in the 1952 line announced yesterday by the Studebaker Corporation.
In the few months that have passed since it was formally established with headquarters at Zurich, the International Press Institute has made some remarkable progress.

A.E. Ratner, chemical exporter accused of shipping aluminum oxide that ultimately reached Hungary, said yesterday that he was "never apprised of any other destination than Belgium" on either of two orders until an investigation by the Department of Commerce started.
The Brownsville Boys' Club of Brooklyn was host yesterday at a party for l0,000 children in the 106th Regiment Armory on Bedford and Atlantic Avenues.

Three meet records were broken and another was equaled last night at the Third Engineers Group Armory, where the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior championships provided some 400 local athletes with the first title competition of the indoor track season.

Race relations seem to be improving throughout the United States, but not without some horrifying setbacks. One of these happened last July in Cicero, near Chicago, when a mob wrecked a Negro's apartment in a district previously restricted to Caucasians.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP)-- The Government spent $346,000,000 keeping farm prices up during the year ended last June 30. This was the biggest loss in any year of the price-support program since it was established in 1933.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 27--In every hamlet of the Netherlands a campaign will be launched around the beginning of the year to finance a gift to the people of the United States. The gift will take the form of a carillon.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27--Dr. Edward U. Condon, a leading nuclear physicist and once center of a controversy about atomic security, was chosen today as president-elect for 1954 of the American Association for the Advancement of Science at its annual meeting here.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27--Grain futures reversed an early price trend on the Board of Trade here today and registered a substantial recovery. Commission absorption was more active than looked for, and ...
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 28--Two Soviet-designed MIG jet planes were shot apart in the skies over North Korea yesterday and a third was badly damaged in the first major air fight in almost two weeks.

After eighteen years, the electric scoreboard at Madison Square Garden finally ran out of space or which to record a college basketball score last night as N.Y.U streaked to a 103-76 victory over Arizona.

The newly organized International Press Institute is now operating in twenty-four countries, Lester Market, chairman of the Institute's executive board and Sunday Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, announced yesterday.

A recent letter to this paper concludes that the "so-called shortage" of teachers "is absurd." When we consider the facts in New York City that may be so, yet in most school districts of the state outside of New York City there is a teacher shortage that threatens to grow worse.
With poultry and ham prices unchanged, shoppers will find that the bill for the New Year's feast will add up to about the same as that for Christmas.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 27 (AP)--Nils Nilsson Skum, Lapp painter and one of Sweden's most prominent artists, died today at his log cabin in the Siskavaara Mountains. His age was 79. He had had several exhibitions in Paris and was well known abroad.

LONDON, Dec. 27--Busily engaged in preparations for his trip to Washington, Prime Minister Churchill talked for more than two hours today with Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, Commander in Chief of British forces in the Middle East.

The Board of Estimate, at a meeting at City Hall that ran late into last evening, approved agreements that will establish the price at which private housing redevelopers will purchase land for four major housing projects from the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Congressional demands for a full-dress Senate investigation of Hungary's "ransom" conviction of four United States Air Force personnel and for a "get tough" policy to head off future incidents kept official Washington on edge today.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 27 (UP)--The Government announced today the execution by a firing squad of four Rumanians convicted by a military court of spying for the United States.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27--Soviet acceptance of Georbe F. Kennan as the next United States Ambassador to Moscow was greeted by foreign diplomats in Moscow as one of the most encouraging developments in international affairs in recent months.
PARIS, Dec.27--A private United States citizen is engaged in a challenging attempt to increase production and lower costs in one of Belgium's poorest coal fields--

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 27--Iran is going on a regimen of austerity to meet the increasing financial and economic crisis. A decree has been prepared by the Ministry of National Economy for presentation to the Cabinet Saturday for approval.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 27--A Federal judge ruled here today that a state fair trade practice law must be changed to conform with Office of Price Stabilization regulations.

The ski areas of Eastern United States and Canada should attract record-breaking crowds over the New Year's holiday period, judging from reports received last night. Many already have arrived at the major points and facilities have begun to roll.
The patronage claims of James A. Roe, Democratic leader of Queens County, received striking recognition yesterday in two of seven appointments announced at City Hall by Mayor Impellitteri.

A long-overdue drive to advance frequency modulation radio, which, in the New York area in particular, offers a listener an almost sublime escape from routinebroadcasting drivel, is scheduled to be started next month by the set manufacturers and FM broadcasters.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan has issued an order, effective at one minute past midnight Monday, retiring for age 278 members of his department. He directed that the retirements of eight other policemen be effective on various dates in January coinciding with their sixty-third birthdays.

Profits of corporations are likely to continue to decrease because of the tightening "squeeze" between rising production costs and controlled prices, it was predicted yesterday by Herman A. Papenfoth, president of the National Association of Cost Accountants.
The Board of Transportation awarded yesterday seven contracts calling for expenditures of $5,547,203. The money will be used for a series of city transit improvements.
Two small polio victims braved a strong, chill northwest wind yesterday morning to make sure that a ceremony transforming Times Square into "Dimes Square" was properly brought off.

Proposals for improving the city's fiscal position, made Dec. 20 by two consultants under the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, were attacked yesterday by City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses as "screwball" and as "in many cases not practical."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP)-- Following is the text of an address by Harold E. Stassen tonight before the Friends-of-Stassen Committee announcing his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination:
The dramatic play has shown a tendency to resign from the contemporary scene and, as a result, the musical drama is beginning to dominate our theatre, Richard Rodgers, the composer, said yesterday.

As a reward for his all-around excellence last season, when he helped the Giants win the National League pennant, Monte Irwin yesterday signed a 1952 contract for just about twice the amount he earned this Year.
The screen version of the Tennessee Williams play, "A Streetcar Named Desire," produced by Charles K. Feldman and released by Warner Brothers, garnered a ...
The thirty-day period in which the battle line of Nov. 27 in Korea was to be the accepted basis for an armistice has expired. Some progress was made in the "temporary" truce period.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--During the week ended Dec. 26, member bank reserves decreased $590,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., rolled up the largest dollar sales in its history in the fiscal year ended with September, in contrast to a declining production trend in the automotive industry generally, Ward M. Canaday, president, informed shareholders in the annual report yesterday.
The Athletics, who carried away some choice offensive honors this past season, added several defensive laurels to their record during the 1951 American League campaign.

Gerald Barrack of Bayonne, N.J., defending champion, and Alan Englander of Larchmont, N.Y., seeded No. 2, reached the quarter-final round of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's junior indoor championship on Elwood Cooke's courts in the Third Engineers Group Armory yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27--The United States District Court of Appeals here issued an enforcement order today against the International Typographical Union, A.F.L., which supported the National Labor Relations Board in its charges that the union and its Local 16 of the Chicago Typographical Union, had violated the Taft-Hartley Law ...

Former associates and representatives of the apparel and merchandising fields were among the several hundred persons who attended a mass of requiem yesterday for Charles Frank Hughes, business news editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, 42 West Sixteenth Street.
LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP)--Iraq has moved to control the refining and sale of oil to her own people, a spokesman for the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company reported today.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 28--United Nations delegates negotiating for an armistice in Korea hinted yesterday that agreement might be reached on the over-all exchange of prisoners, for which the enemy has pressed.

THE Chicago Cardinals achieved a monumental upset in their last game of the season not long ago. They upended their tradi tional foes, the Chicago Bears. It must have been another drop of gall in the cup of Curly Lambeau, coach of the Cardinals who had been peremptorily ousted just before the grand finale.
Three times in the last seven weeks Howard Morris and Edward Manser have tried to break out of the Bronx into more open spaces and three times they have failed. The third failure came yesterday.

The thirty-three-story Empire Trust Building at 580-586 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of Fortyseventh Street, has been acquired by an investment group headed by Louis J. Glickman in a transaction which also involved the resale and leasing back of the land.

William Zeckendorf has contracted to sell all the outstanding stock in Webb Knapp, Inc., real estate concern, which he owns, to American Superpower Corporation, it was announced jointly yesterday by Mr. Zeckendorf and B. A. Tompkins, chairman of American Superpower.
NEWARK, Dec. 27--The Board of Public Utility Commissioners was formally advised today that the Public Service Coordinated Transport and the Public Service ...

THE great Russian purge of the Nineteen Thirties is the most mysterious political phenomenon of our time. That totalitarian tyrannies should use terror as an instrument of government is at least understandable--granted the nature of the regime and its rulers is understood.

WEST FRANKFORT, Ill., Dec. 27 (AP)--Federal and state officials completed today their underground investigation of the blasted coal mine in which 119 men were killed. Their findings will be made in a report by both groups, possibly within ten days.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27--Members of the American Educational Theatre Association were admonished today by George M. Savage, a professor of playwrighting at the University of California in Los Angeles, that "the educational ...

WITH the Connecticut waterfowl season closing tomor row and the wind-up in the rest of the Atlantic flyway states scheduled for Jan. 5, wildfowlers already have begun to figure the score for this season, and the majority seem to think it better than they were led to expect.

The knotty and disturbing problem of a pet dog, an ill neighbor, and the dog's devoted owners appeared to have been solved yesterday, after a session before Magistrate Hyman Bushel in Mid-Manhattan Court.

Three firemen testified yesterday that they were acting under orders when they falsely signed the log book at Hook and Ladder Company 119, 26 Hooper Street, Brooklyn, for Gerard Purcell, then under suspension and since dismissed from the department.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 27 (AP)-- Columbia burned up the boards during the first half and fought off a desperate rally by Duke to defeat the Blue Devils, 66--58, tonight in the final opening-round game of the Dixie basketball classic.

PARIS, Dec. 27--Aggregate expenditure on defense by Western European members of the North Atlantic Treaty in the three fiscal years that will end July 1, 1954, has been estimated by experts of the Atlantic Pact organization at $66,500,000,000.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (AP)-- Two former winners advanced to the semi-final round today in the annual Sugar Bowl invitation tennis tournament, played in chilly weather.
New drafts drawn against LatinAmerican importers last month declined $24,700,000 from the record October drawings of $66,700,000, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 2,806,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 117,618,000 barrels, compared with 114,812,000 a week earlier and 112,631,000 a year ago.

Whatever doubt there may have been that Harold E. Stassen would be willing to run for President on the Republican ticket next year has now been removed. Mr. Stassen's hat is in the ring. Under the hat is a personal platform.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)-- The United States is not getting its share of the world's supply of copper but considerable quantities are moving to Europe, it was disclosed today. Some of the shipments to Europe are being made with Marshall Plan dollars.

To wind up the festivities of this holiday week, many homemakers may be planning parties for New Year's Eve or New Year's Day. To relieve herself of some of the chores attached to such an undertaking, the hostess might avail herself of some services for parties.

State Senator Fred G. Moritt, defense attorney for Tallulah Bankhead's former maid-secretary, quoted Shakespeare, Alfred E. Smith, Keats and a poem he had written himself in appealing to the jury yesterday to acquit Mrs. Evyleen Cronin of charges that she commited grand larceny and forgery against the actress.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 27--Col. Sherman P. Moreland, chief prosecutor in the trial of Brig. Gen. William (Billy) Mitchell in 1925, died today at his home in near-by Van Etten. He was 83 years old.
From now into spring was the theme of the Saks 34th Street junior fashion show on the second floor yesterday morning.
A five-story elevator building containing nine apartments at 13 Gramercy Park has been sold by Simon B. Zelnik, architect, to John Bass for investment and part occupancy.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27--The Soviet press announced today that Russian athletes would enter the 1952 Olympics with an all-out determination to fulfill the obligations outlined by the Communist party on the necessity of winning world championships in the "most important" sports.
TRENTON, Dec. 27--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll held out prospect to the people of New Jersey today that the state administration would be run next year within present revenues.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)-- American railroads took in more money this year than ever before, but found taxes and other expenses also at record levels and increasing faster than operating revenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27-- James T. Sherwin of Columbia tonight took the lead in the National Intercollegiate Chess League championship at Houston Hall, University of Pennsylvania, by defeating Allen Kaufman of New York University in twenty-two moves.

State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi announced yesterday that notices of initial account balances from which 114,300 employers will be able to calculate their own individual unemployment insurance tax rates for 1952 in advance of formal notice would be mailed this week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)-- The Department of Commerce today increased coal export quotas for January and February to a total of 8,530,000 tons.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 27 --President Truman attended a neighborhood Christmas party tonight and prepared to return tomorrow to his White House desk and an accumulation of problems, ranging from corruption in Government to next year's defense budget.

WASHINGTON; Dec. 27--A substantial cutback in the production of automobiles for the second quarter of 1952, beyond a 13.7 per cent reduction ordered for the first quarter, was predicted today by Manly Fleischmann, administrator of the National Production Authority.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27--A New Year's Eve strike of 700,000 workers in the principal steel and aluminum mills was canceled tonight.

The Government, through the Atomic Energy Commission, is being forced to pay $35 apiece for "stray" dogs and $3.50 apiece for "stray" cats that are virtually being bootlegged into its research laboratories at the University of Rochester and at Brookhaven, on Long Island.

The cotton futures market eased yesterday, and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 20 to 37 points. The market opened 16 points lower to 5 points higher, but during the early trading there was considerable price-fixing for domestic mills.

WHITINSVILLE, Mass., Dec. 28 --With prudence befitting a Yankee community, the town officials of Northbridge today placed a $100,000 cash gift from the Whitin Machine Works in the town's postwar rehabilitation fund, there to await due consideration on its ultimate disposition at the annual town meeting.
Hotels probably will experience a higher occupancy rate next year than in 1951, J.B. Herndon, president of the American Hotel Association, said yesterday.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 28--The Radio Corporation of America entered the major electric appliance field today. The company's R.C.A. Victor division announced that a line of home air-conditioners was almost ready for shipment to the trade.
Unbeaten Gil Turner hit boxing's "big time" last night, winning his first main bout in Madison Square Garden.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 28 (AP)--Minnesota defeated a faster Princeton team, 63--57, tonight in the opener of two nights of competition between Western Conference and Ivy League quintets.
Allan C. MacDonald and Capt. Edgar A. Shergold will succeed Capt. R.W. McMurray and Capt. R.N. Stuart in the two top posts of Canadian Pacific Steamships Ltd., on Jan. 1.
Year-end liquidation and evening-up for the four-day week-end in most markets, together with a general lack of interest, ruled commodities futures yesterday. The tone was generally softer.

The fifteen-game string of successess compiled by local quintets at Madison Square Garden will be subjected to a severe strain tonight. Manhattan and St. John's, metropolitan representatives in the season's ninth college doubleheader at the Eighth Avenue ...

State income tax claims of $92,000 were filed yesterday against the three Dalesaio brothere, accused by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee and the New York State Crime Commission of heading a gambling ring on Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--President Truman's first official business on returning to Washington today was a conference with Government officials on the military expenditures he will recommend to Congress in his budget message next month. The meeting lasted three-quarters of an hour.

A gathering of scholars and educators from over the nation was told here yesterday that no evidence existed that "a political bargain" was made in World War II between Allied and Russian leaders permitting Communist forces to capture Berlin and Prague.

THE popularity of the muzzle loader as a sporting as well as a target rifle is increasing considerably, and a number of shooters reported killing both whitetails and mule deer with these old rifles during the recent season.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 29--The Communists indicated yesterday that negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war might break down if the United Nations continued to insist on limitation of airfield construction in North Korea during the cease-fire.
PARIS, Dec. 28--Gen. Charles de Gaulle's personal plan to replace the European army program was submitted today to the National Assembly in the form of two measures.

Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday that the resignations of the board of directors of Youth House, 331 East Twelfth Street, were a "complete surprise" to him. He said he had had no previous knowledge of dissatisfaction among the board members.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 28-- New excavations at the site of the Agora, or gathering place, of the ancient city of Athens, reported here today, indicate that Athenian culture flourished during the height of the Bronze Age at least fifteen centuries before the birth of Christ.

Maintenance of export markets for fabrics in 1952 under current trade conditions will be difficult, cotton textile men said yesterday. Tightening of dollar exchange, they asserted, will make it impossible to hold the current rate of exports which show a 50 per cent improvement compared to a year ago.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 29-- Outnumbered almost three to one, a group of Allied Sabre jet planes tangled with Communist MIG's over North Korea yesterday for the second day in a row. The milling air fight cost the Reds one MIG shot down in flames.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--General business activity, with the exception of record steel production, continued to show little change from a year ago at the end of 1951, the first full year of accelerated defense production.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--With a scheduled New Year's Eve strike of steel and aluminum workers canceled, the Wage Stabilization Board today began its efforts to bring about a settlement of the dispute.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 28--Publication by the United Nations statistical office of comparable data on world exports for the first six months of 1950 and 1951 provides factual evidence of the rapid momentum of economic recovery in two of the former Axis countries, Germany and Japan, during the post-war era.

BOSTON, Dec. 28--An economy stabilized near present high levels of production and income, and one that will achieve new production miracles in such fields as steel, chemicals and machine tools, is in prospect for 1952.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 28-- When India's first national elections are over next month, and if Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party Government has the expected majority, this country's foreign policy will be made clearer, according to informed prognostications here.

SAIGON, Indo-China Dec. 28-- Increased Chinese Communist participation in the Indo-China war during 1952 has been foreseen by qualified observers here. Some informed quarters, including a number of American officials, believe that the Chinese may be getting set for a ground and air invasion ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--Asscared of the freedom and safety of the four airmen imprisoned by the Communist authorities in Budapest more than a month ago, the United States placed today another ban on private travel in Hungary and once again closed the Hungarian Consulates in New York and Cleveland.

LONDON, Dec. 28--In Cairo, there have been demonstrations against King Farouk's appointment of two supposedly pro-British advisers to his entourage. In London there have been a few dinner table conversations about the matter.

LONDON, Dec. 28--Prime Minister Churchill will meet with his Cabinet tomorrow morning before he and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden board the Queen Mary at Southampton late tomorrow night for their trip to the United States.

WEST FRANKFORT, Ill., Dec. 28 (UP)--John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, charged tonight that the explosion in the Orient Mine here that killed 119 diggers last week had been "preventable."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28-- Lang Turner has a new seven-year contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, effective Monday. There are two option clauses in the agreement that may be exercised at the end of the third and fifth years, it is understood.

In the third major commercial building deal to be completed in Manhattan this month, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York has acquired the former homeoffice properties of the Mutual Life Insurance Company at 34 Nassau Street and adjoining land closely linked to the early history of New York.

A jury of twelve men found Tallulah Bankhead's former maidsecretary guilty yesterday of second-degree larceny on three counts but acquitted her of all charges of forgery. The jurors took more than four hours to reach their verdict.
The eight-story loft building at 441-47 Pearl Street was sold by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to Pearl Equities, Inc., headed by David Rapoport, operator.

After the second round of the international masters tournament at the annual Christmas Chess Congress in Hastings yesterday, not one of the ten competitors had a clean score, according to a report from London.

BOSTON, Dec. 28--The makings of another Boston Tea Party appeared in the offing today as word got around that Police Superintendent Edward W. Fallon had given orders to poll listers not to accept "over 21" as an age for Boston women.

A search of the records in the office of the Commissioner of Jurors is being made for a juror's questionnaire sent last fall to Alexander Trachtenberg, Communist official, who is one of seventeen Reds awaiting trial on a Federal indictment charging conspiracy to advocate the overthrow of the Government.
Two lively group shows of paintings and work by an American modern, Sholam Farber, who has studied abroad, form exhibitions of interest this week.
DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 28 (AP)-- The executive secretary of the Dallas Cotton Exchange said today that reports that the British had cancelled an order for 126,000 bales of cotton were false.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28-- With a well-earned victory over Eliot Hearst, his predecessor as champion of New York State, James T. Sherwin of Columbia gained his fourth consecutive point today in the national intercollegiate title chess tourney at Houston Hall, University of Pennsylvania.

Pan American World Airways reported yesterday that in the current year it carried more passengers and cargo than in any year in its history, exceeding the million-passenger mark for the second consecutive year.

Although there will be an "inexorable" upward trend in defense expenditures next year, there will be no marked increases in prices, according to twelve of the nation's top economists. They participated in a symposium, sponsored by the National Industrial Conference Board.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 28--The long-awaited decision of the Yugoslav Government to devalue the dinar and to establish a rate bearing some reasonable relationship to prices was announced today in Parliament by Finance Minister Milentije Popovic.

VIENNA, Dec. 28--The four United States airmen who were forced down over Hungary by Soviet fighter planes Nov. 19 and accused of espionage were freed today by the Hungarian Government after the United States had paid $120,000 in fines. They were flown from Vienna tonight back to their base in Erding, Germany.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 28 (UP)-- High banking sources said today that recent Mexican purchases of refined silver bullion in the London market might be a new phase of the policy followed by the world's largest silver producer in recent years to stiffen the price in the international market.
ALBANY, Dec. 28--Governor Dewey today designated two Supreme Court justices to serve on the Appellate Division and redesignated three other justices now members of the Appellate Division.

Despite delays caused by a shortage of skilled seamen, the movement of coal to Marshall Plan countries in the final quarter of 1951 will amount to nearly 10,000,000 tons, according to officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 28--Our star, the sun, is now known definitely to be situated just on the inside edge of one of the spiral arms of the Milky Way galaxy.

A tract of ninety acres in Suffolk County, formerly owned by Frank N. Dodd and known as Millfield, has been sold by Benjamin and Emanuel Ebin to a client of Oscar Murov, attorney. The property fronts on Deerpark Avenue anti Sunrise highway in Islip and on Liberty Avenue in Babylon. Snover Co. were the brokers in ...

Racial discrimination in the United States is one of "the weakest spots in democracy's armor" and is being exploited by Communist propagandists, it was asserted yesterday in a discussion of race problems among a group of eighty European teen-agers and leaders in the New York Negro community.

The cost of celebrating New Year's Eve in public here next Monday night will be about the same as it was last year. However, the number of revelers at cafes and theatres, as well as in the traditional convergence upon Times Square, will depend on the weather.

A threatened tie-up of coal and fuel oil deliveries scheduled for midnight on Monday was averted last night when an agreement was reached between Local 553, Coal and Fuel Oil Drivers, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L., and the Coal Consumers Protective Association.
LONDON, Dec. 28--The stock markets remained quiet and firm today. British Government securities made a further small rally.

Richard MacAtee of Flushing, Eastern junior champion, advanced to the quarter-final round yesterday in the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's indoor junior and boys' tennis championships at the Third Engineers Group Armory. MacAtee, a freshman at Rice Institute and seeded No. 6, defeated Peter Dell of Bethesda, Md., 6--2, 6--4.
Tha average market price of a bond listed on the New York Stock Exchange dropped exactly $3 between Nov. 30, 1950, and Nov. 30, 1951, according to figured released by the Exchange yesterday.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 28-- The city's net grand list of taxable property, on which next year's rates will be based, has been increased 28 per cent in a revaluation made as a result of a year and a half study.

Split-ups of corporate stock in ratios of two-for-one or higher this year equalled or exceeded similar New York Stock Exchange records as far back as 1946, according to the current issue of The Exchange Magazine.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28--Although the "typical American family" is frequently thought of as having only one or two children, there are more youngsters under 18 years of age living in families with five or more children in the United States than there are children in the smaller family group, Dr. James H.S. Bossard, Professor of Sociology at the University of Pennsylvania, said yesterday.

The Madison Avenue Presbyterian was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Margaret Osborne Bradley, daughter of Mrs. Otis T. Bradley of 1160 Park Avenue, and the late Mr. Bradley, to George Henry Potts ...

Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., and subsidiaries had a net profit in the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, last, of $9,427,000 after providing $9,100,000 for Federal income taxes and $700,000 for contingent liabilities, according to the annual report, to be released today.

After forty days of Communist imprisonment the four American Air Force fliers who lost their way and were forced down in Hungary by Soviet planes have been freed. They were freed when the American Government, responding to overwhelming popular sentiment in this country, agreed to ...

First reports of year-end inventory-taking in heavy-goods industries shows that stocks on hand in many factories and wholesale establishments are considerably larger than had been anticipated, it was reported here yesterday by members of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 28--They controversy over a uniform for the 600 auxiliary policemen of the Yorkers Civil Defense forces resulted today in the suspension of the leading critic of the new toggery.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 28-- Teheran's Communists from the banned Tudeh party will take part in the present election behind the cloak of a new front, with five to seven candidates whom they will support for the first time since their party was outlawed twentytwo months ago.

United States Government bonds staged their first price rally yesterday since the year-end money market was shaken by the increase in prime commercial lending rate from 2 per cent to 3 per cent by major banks last week.

So delicate are Russian-American relations these days that some slight optimism legitimately arises whenever the Soviet Government fails to seize any possible opportunity for baring its teeth and instead behaves even briefly in a calm and reasonable manner.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 28 (UP)-- Alfred G. Vanderbilt's brilliant filly, Next Move, made a smashing comeback today after having been away from the races most of the year by speeding to a one-length victory in the $18,500 Las Flores Handicap, opening-day feature of the fifty-day Santa Anita winter meeting.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 28--Official Israeli choler has been raised in recent days by reports of possible impending political and military changes along her frontiers. The transfer of British garrisons from the Suez Canal zone to the Gaza strip and a Jordan-Iraq merger are among these disturbing reports.
GENEVA, Dec. 28--European steel production achieved new records during 1951, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

A new and heartening report has been issued by the city's Welfare Commissioner, Henry L. McCarthy. In November, for the eighteenth consecutive month, New York's public assistance rolls showed a decrease. The total decline for the eighteen months' period was from 352,770 to 295,955.
Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday the appointments of eleven city officials who will be sworn in at City Hall on Tuesday along with seven others who were named last Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP)--A special committee of the House of representatives will urge Congress soon to pass a sharply restricted "G. I. Bill of Rights" for Korean veterans.

A lone figure was reported last night to be clinging to the bridge of the battered Flying Enterprise as the United States cargo ship was tossed about in the stormy North Atlantic some 300 miles southwest of Ireland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP)-- The Government reported today that profits of United States manufacturing corporations continued during the third quarter of 1951 the general downward trend that began at the end of 1950.
PARIS, Dec. 30--Soviet diplomacy is concentrating now on efforts to expand commercial relationships between the Eastern bloc and the rest of the world.
CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 30--Controversy is mounting in South Jersey over one of 1952's most important projected improvements for the area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30-- The famed Marshall Plan for European recovery goes out of business tomorrow on the day that General of the Army George C. Marshall, who gave the program its name, observes his seventy-first birthday anniversary.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 31--The Eighth Army reported late yesterday that the United States Fortyfifth Infantry Division, formed originally as a National Guard unit in Oklahoma and famed for action in Europe during World War II, is now holding an important sector of the Korean front.

The opening concert in a series of six in celebration of the sesquicentennial of the United States Military Academy at West Point is scheduled to be broadcast Saturday, 8:30 to 10 P.M., over WNYC from Carnegie Hall.
St. George's Anglican Cathedral Choir of Kingston, Canada, became yesterday the first cathedral choral group from another nation to sing Sabbath services at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Highlights of the first week of the New Year in the local art galleries are three exhibitions, all opening on Wednesday. They will be new oils and water-colors by John Marin, at the Downtown Gallery; paintings by Philip Guston, at the Peridot Gallery, and recent oils by Leonid at Durlachers.

Gerald Barrack, Cornell freshman from Bayonne, N.J., and Dick Raskind, first year student at Yale who lives in Forest Hills, gained the final in the junior singles of the Eastern junior and boys indoor tennis championships at the Third Engineers Armory on Washington Heights yesterday.

With price support ended, recent imports of Canadian potatoes by this country have been a small fraction of their former volume, it is reported by Kris P. Bemis, secretary of the potato division of the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association, in a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The differences between Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion of Israel and American Zionist leaders are not so wide as had been indicated, Representative Emanuel Celler of New York, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Frank E. McKinney, Democratic National Chairman, declared tonight that his party would "not try to gloss over mistakes" but would bid to stay in power in 1952 on "a sound job of stewardship" in Government despite difficult problems at home and abroad.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Dec. 30-- Early renewal of Vietminh attacks in Tongking were predicted today by a French military spokesman here in summing up the results of the fighting this month in north Vietnam.

Although their number tended to dwindle as the holiday season waned, contributions to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund yesterday again showed the wide range, in point of geography and motivation, that invariably has characterized them.

A prayer for the residents of Florida in their "moment of degradation and humiliation" was offered yesterday by Donald Harrington, minister of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.

Factories are beginning to appear on a large scale, on the "ghost lands" surrounding airports, according to American Aviation Daily. Woodruff DeSilva, airport manager of the Los Angeles International Airport, reported that some seventy-five different plants had sprung up within a half-mile radius of that airport since World War II.

Rudolph Guenther, a pioneer in the field of financial advertising and a lifelong friend and confidante of many of the leading financiers of the country, will celebrate his eightieth birthday tomorrow.

Another member of that tradition-bound and exclusive society of the sea--the United States Ex-Apprentice Association--has "swallowed the anchor" and henceforth will plot a course no sharper than the line of the flower beds in his Staten Island garden.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30-- James T. Sherwin of Columbia, who won the New York State championship at Syracuse last September, annexed, another title today when he finished first among twenty-three players in the biennial National Intercollegiate Chess League tournament at Houston Hall, University of Pennsylvania.
The American Federation of Labor made known yesterday its determination to resist moves to bring the Yugoslav trade unions into the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

Three items in the news recently point up once again, if any repetition is needed, not only the tremendously increased complexity of basic human problems today over those of decades past but also the great part education must inevitably play in the solution of those problems.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 30 (UP)--One person was lynched in the United States during 1951, Tuskegee Institute reported today. The Negro institution, in the annual report on mob violence compiled by its records and research department, said the lynching occurred in Orange County, Fla., where Melvin Womack, 26 years old, of Winter Garden, was fatally beaten by a band of masked men March 31.

YONKERS, Dec, 30-The Rev. Edward William Levin, 27 years old, will conduct an annual Watch Night service here tomorrow at the First Church of The Nazarene, of which he has been pastor for three years while supporting himself and his family as a junior official of Devenco Inc., consulting engineers, 150, Broadway, New York.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30--The Soviet press said today that the United States foreign policy was facing a "deep crisis" within the United States itself, by a rapidly developing conflict between British and United States interests and a profound loss of support among Middle-Eastern and Asiatic nations.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 30 --Twenty-nine-year-old Arthur Devlin of the host club twice soared beyond the 200-foot mark off Olympic Hill today to capture the annual Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' invitation ski jump for the second year in a row.
LONDON, Dec. 30--About a dozen battered ships struggled to reach West European ports tonight while a storm as wide as the Continent continued to rage on sea and land.
Diversification of products can save the business life of the medium-size manufacturer, R.S. Evans Jr., president of the Evans Products Company, Plymouth, Mich., said last week.

The proposed gross receipts tax of up to 1 per cent on business concerns in this city was attacked yesterday. It was asserted that it would force into bankruptcy many small businesses and larger companies that operate on a small profit margin.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Gordon Dean, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, today urged that public knowledge and understanding of the great peacetime potentialities of atomic energy be widened.

ZURICH, Dec. 30--All last week the price at which monetary gold was offered by Zurich banks was 5,500 Swiss francs a kilo which at the prevailing dollar rate of 4.37 francs is equivalent to $38.50 anounce.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP)-- The nation spent $39,000,000,000 on construction this year and will spend almost that much next year despite scarcities of materials, the Associated General Contractors of America reported today.
FORT, LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP)--The West beat the East easily today in the thirteenth annual East-West men's collegiate swimming meet at the Municipal Casino pool.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30--A statewide program to end the recent series of terror bombings in Miami and elsewhere was proposed today at an emergency meeting of the Florida branch of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.
The next President of the United States, it seems, will be brought to television viewers and radio listeners through the courtesy of Betty Furness, who knows how to open and shut an ice box.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 30--Sixty men and women among the parishioners who attended services this morning at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church here turned in questionnaires that had been distributed to them by the pastor, the Rev. Charles Brackbill Jr., in which they frankly appraised the pastor's sermons in the last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP)-- Michael V. DiSalle, Price Stabilizer, announced today that a new "community food pricing" system requiring grocers to post dollars-andcents ceiling prices would begin soon in three key cities.

There is a statute on the law books of this city prohibiting unnecessary noise on the city streets. Horn-blowing, one of our best sources of noise, is most often a sign of poor driving ability when it is not a sign of impatience.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec, 30-- Connecticut supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft are taking steps to set up a formal organization in this state to work for his Republican Presidential nomination, it was learned today.

The saddest traffic news we have heard in many a day is that the station-wagon taxi is on the way out, allegedly because the customer doesn't like it. In a matter so fraught with emotion as the size and shape of taxicabs we recognize the duty of every citizen to keep calm; but we cannot...

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., served notice last night that the union would "force the city to take over" the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation rather than cooperate in lay-offs and other economies recommended by Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman.

The foreign ministers of France, Western Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg agreed yesterday to propose that their countries establish a single parliament, with power to levy taxes, to finance a joint defense budget and oversee coal and steel operations united under the Schuman plan.

LONDON, Dec. 30--Prime Minister Churchill's departure for the United States was postponed for twenty-four hours today because one of the anchors of the liner Queen Mary, on which he is to travel, was jammed.

PARIS, Dec. 30--Amid all the other joys of the holiday season, Frenchmen now have an opportunity to become partisans in a battle of epithets and epigrams between two of their most famous waters, the mercurial Jean Cocteau and Academacian Francois Mauriac.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 30-- A five-block area here was without electricity for forty-two minutes shortly before noon today after a 26-year-old tree surgeon had brushed a 5,000-volt power line running through a rotting seventy-year-old elm tree he was cutting and fell dead to the ground.
New York churchgoers will usher in another year tonight at traditional Watch Night services and holy hours.

Growers of apples and pears in the Western Hemisphere, most of whom are in this country, have been put in a precarious business situation by the serious drop in their export market, it is reported in a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Samuel Fraser, secretary of the International Apple Association.

Advances in the control of cancer in the last four years were summarized in a report of the Memorial Center for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Disease, made public by Laurance S. Rockefeller, president of the board of managers.

The Scots Americans of Kearny, N.J., retained the lead in the American Soccer League by defeating Brookhattan-Galicia, 1--0, at Croke Park yesterday. Ted Kavanaugh's late goal decided. The champion Philadelphia Nationals triumphed over Hakoah, 2--0, in the second game of the doubleheader.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 30--Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion has softened the attack on Zionist leaders in the United States that he made in a speech in the knesset (the Israeli Parliament) on Dec. 12, when he was heard to describe them as "bankrupt."

For most of the final week of the year-1951, foreign exchanges idled along quietly with unimportant price changes on a reduced volume of business. However, the holiday atmosphere which was responsible for this lull was rudely shattered on Friday by stepped-up activity in British sterling and the Canadian dollar, the end result of which found the pound hammered down close to its new buying price, while there was a resounding rise in the Dominion unit.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 30--The Iranian Government announced today that because of a lack of foreign exchange no more passports would be granted to Iranian subjects and accordingly they could not leave the country.

PITTSBUBGH, Dec. 30--Despite the holiday last week the steel industry was able, by paying premium wages, to keep the steel rate at 101.5 per cent of rated capacity; this was down only 3 points from the week before.

Two weeks ago Canada's Finance Minister, Douglas C. Abbott, announced to the House of Commons at Ottawa that the Government had decided to abolish all foreign exchange controls. The Dominion thereby became the first country to take such...
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 30 (AP)--In a small office here plans are going forward for a nation-wide attack on the problem of automobile parking, a major headache for most American cities.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30--A technique that extends the range of an atomic calendar 10,000 years farther back in time won a $1,000 prize here today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

CAIRO, Dec. 30--The Egyptian Cabinet approved today the terms of a bill that would make collaboration with the British forces in Egypt a crime punishable by imprisonment and fine. Parliament must act on the measure.
LONDON, Dec. 30--Stock exchange business last week shrank to what was probably the lowest on record and the markets managed to live up to tradition by staging a cheerful year-end.

The ties that bind free labor internationally, loose as they may be, have been woven principally of two main strands: (1) the desire to aid workers in undeveloped areas and (2) the need to fight Communist and totalitarian penetration and control of the trade union movement this side of the Iron Curtain.

The Metropolitan Opera will mount a new English version of Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi" on Thursday, Jan. 10, during its ninth week, which begins next Monday. The opera, which will be played to aid the Free Milk Fund for Babies, will be on a double bill with Strauss' "Salome," in which Ljuba Welitch will have the name part.

NEW CITY, N.Y, Dec. 30--Inspite of a dense fog, the worst weather for a bird census, twentysix members of the Rockland County Audubon Society recorded three "firsts" and a few other records in their annual count today over an area with a sevenand-a-half-mile radius from the Rockland County Court House here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Average primary market prices advanced two-tenths of 1 per cent for the week ended Dec. 25, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, 177.4 per cent of the 1926 average, was 0.2 per cent above a year ago and 13.1 per cent above the pre-Korean average (May 24-June 25, 1950).
A melancholy combination of fog, drizzle and unseasonably warm weather thawed out the city yesterday and served as a rather inappropriate backdrop for New York in the midst of the holiday week-end.
Those who have not settled down yet to the writing of their thankyou notes might find an incentive in some new note papers available in shops here.

A year ago at this time the United States was in the midst of the second of two inflationary spasms stemming from the Korean situation. Both spasms were based on war-scare buying. The first followed the invasion of South Korea and the prompt decision by the United Nations to intervene in this act of aggression.

Lenox Hill House, a ten-story and penthouse apartment building for thirty-six families at 168 to 176 East Seventy-eighth Street has been purchased by Rose Levenson of Brooklyn from a syndicate of investors controlled by Ralph H. ...

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 30--The members of collective farms in Croatia who fought a losing battle in the spring, summer and autumn of 1951 to resume their status as independent farmers have begun to slow up the compulsory deliveries of corn to the state that are due at this time of year, according to the Zagreb newspaper Vjesnik.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30--Mist and fog swallowed a silvery twinengined C-46 transport plane and its forty occupants today as search parties combed a wide mountainous area in vain attempts to confirm repeated reports of an air crash in Western Pennsylvania.

Among the things that will disappear at the stroke of twelve tonight is the Economic Cooperation Administration, the agency which put the Marshall Plan into action. But General Marshall, whose seventy-first birthday this is, need not fear that the project he outlined in his Cambridge speech...
The Rev. Michael Deacy of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral drew a parallel yesterday between the crucifixion of Christ and present-day suffering of Christians behind the Iron Curtain.
Following is the text of the speech delivered last night by Secretary of State Dean Acheson in accepting the Jewish War Veterans' Medal of Merit at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:

After moving within a relatively narrow price range during the last week, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the period 4 points higher to 22 points lower than final quotations of the preceding week.

Harry Weisenberger, the pawnbroker who helped apprehend some 1,500 criminals and was instrumental in the recovery of more than $1,000,000 in stolen property during the last thirty-five years, died on Saturday in the Medical Arts Center Hospital of a heart attack suffered the same day. He was 51 years old.

THERE was an item in the Sporting News not so long ago. Perhaps it didn't attract too much attention as it, stated that Augie Galan was retiring at the age of 39 after twentytwo seasons in organized ball, but it stirred up some memories of one of the most wonderful guys who ever wore a big league uniform.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican of New York, said today that he would ask Congress to pass a measure making it impossible to appropriate more funds for Federal expenditures than the amount of the Government's income.

American war plans just before Pearl Harbor were based on the unfounded fear that the Soviet Union had been beaten, Maurice Matloff of the Office of the Chief of Military History of the Department of the Army said in a paper he read here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30--Active long liquidation of grain futures increased in volume late last week, with selling stimulated by various developments. A downward plunge in prices for soybeans, with an equally violent setback in hog...

Last night the Secretary of State of the United States offered a public review of the major developments in the foreign field during the course of the year that draws to its close today. He also offered something of a forecast for the coming year and something of counsel on positions that we should sustain and attitudes that we should embrace.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP)-- Fleet Dean Smith of Texas University ran a spectacular 10.3-second 100-meter race today to set a new Sugar Bowl track meet record.

MUNSAN, Korea, Dec. 30 (AP)-- The following list of fifty-five Civilians, believed by the United Nations to have been taken prisoner by the communists in June and July, 1950, was delivered to the enemy in Panmunjom today with a request that the Civilians be released when prisoners of war were exchanged:

ALBANY, Dec. 30--Governor Dewey will urge the 1952 Legislature to give the State Thruway Authority the power to ban virtually all billboards and other advertising devices along the 535-mile superhighway between Buffalo and New York.

WASHINGT6N, Dec. 30 (UP)-- The C-46 airplane, one of which apparently crashed near Belltown, Pa., during the week-end, has been a controversial plane since the first one flew in March, 1940. Performance of the craft has been praised and assailed by both military and civilian pilots.
ROME, Dec. 30--In a message of encouragement broadcast this morning to inmates of prisons everywhere in the world, Pope Pius XII expressed his "human affection" for political prisoners.

The United States has welcomed to its shores in the last twenty years more than 12,000,000 persons --as many as live in Sumatra, White Russia, Afghanistan, California, Czechoslovakia or the Union of South Africa.

PARIS, Dec. 30--The most notable move yet taken for a United States of Europe was an agreement today by the foreign ministers of six nations to propose that their countries establish a single, directly elected bicameral parliament with power to levy taxes,...

ALBANY, Dec. 30--Citing new high records for employment, total income and savings this year, the State Commerce Department predicted today that business would continue to be good in New York State in 1952.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Cardinals today signed Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell, 21-year-old southpaw, to a 1952 contract. St. Louis bought Mizell's contract from the Houston farm of the Class AA Texas League, where he compiled a 1.93 earned run average last season while pitching to a 16-14 record.

Fifty years ago the late H. H. Windsor founded Popular Mechanics. This month the magazine celebrates its golden anniversary with the publication of a commemorative issue and of a book in which its history is traced. From the outset Popular Mechanics made its appeal as simply and directly as it could.

The stock market closed out the old year yesterday on a rallying note but encountered sufficient last minute selling for tax record purposes to cut down gains. Changes in either direction were generally limited to fractions with alterations of a point or more reserved for a few high price issues.

American shipping reached a new post-war peak during 1951, but the activities of United States-flag vessels were characterized mainly by martial and rehabilitation efforts, Frank J. Taylor, president of the Americn Merchant Marine Institute, said here yesterday in a review of maritime events.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Sam Giammalva of Houston and Karol Fageros of Miami scored upsets today to win singles titles in the junior boys' and juniors girls' divisions of the fifth annual Orange Bowl tennis championships.
Midnight last night marked the forced separation from their jobs for 259 "superannuated" policemen despite a last-minute legal move to stay their retirement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., head of the movement to "draft" General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination, promised today "a really important announcement" to be made here six days from now.
PARIS, Dec. 31 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Chief of Staff for Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, said in a New Year's statement today that "the forecast for 1952 is bright."

BOSTON -- The boom in the New England textile industry came to an abrupt halt during the first half of 1952 and was succeeded by serious depression. Cotton manufacturers are hopeful of some improvement in the early months of 1952 but at the moment they can see no prospect of a return to satisfactory conditions soon.

THE matter of big game rifles, involving actions, types and calibers, is one that stirs up considerable comment before, during and after the deer season. And the mail that has flowed our way on the subject during the past few months indicates that a number of shooters are nourishing beliefs that could be more accurately termed illusions.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Bright skies and a promise of a fast field tomorrow brought sighs of relief all along the Rose Bowl front today.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- The second million-dollar betting day in Tropical Park history was recorded today.

Seventy persons, including five expectant mothers and ten persons more than 60 years old, arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday from Munich, Germany. It was the last plane load of the year for the "compassionate airlift," which under the sponsorship of the International Refugee Organization brings displaced persons requiring priority transportation into the country by airplane.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 1 -- Communist truce negotiators at Panmunjom reversed themselves today on an issue in the proposed exchange of prisoners in an armistice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Great Britain's payment to the United States Government of $138,527,725.57 through the Federal Reserve Bank in New York was noted today officially without further comment by the Treasury Department.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Fifth Air Force today said that three Communist biplanes had dropped bombs in the vicinity of Seoul's Kimpo air base and Inchon harbor, causing no damage.

The year 1951 was meteorologically remarkable in New York chiefly for a sharp decline in the amount of snowfall, the Weather Bureau reported yesterday. The normal snowfall here is 30.8 inches a year, the bureau said. Last year only 10.9 inches fell.

Only a very limited number of foreigners have ever succeeded in grasping the essence of Swiss neutrality, which, to us, is not merely a privilege but also an obligation, and a very costly and heavy obligation at that. It is above all the obligation to mind our own business and, if need be, to ward off any aggressor, whoever he may be.

Public flotations of new bonds here in December declined to the lowest total since August, while stock financing was rising to its best level in nine months and to the largest total for any December since 1946.

The City College basketball team crushed the University of Puerto Rico, 72 -- 54, last night in the Beavers' gymnasium. It was City's fourth victory in eight starts and Puerto Rico's second successive setback since beginning its tour of Eastern colleges last week-end.

The recent letter of your correspondent Richard A. Wels was timely indeed. It is easy for a fair-minded person to share his indignation at the current proposal for reapportioning seats in the New York State Legislature.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 1 -New York's bargain basements had better look to their laurels. Yesterday the ladies of London put on a New Year's Eve demonstration of department store battle tactics as savage as anything ever seen on Fourteenth Street.

Three Brooklyn policemen formed a perilous human chain yesterday to rescue a 55-year-old woman who threatened to jump from a window of her blazing apartment at 632 Herkimer Street, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section.
Miss Mary Fallon, who had been confined to City Hospital, Welfare Island, for forty-two years, for much of that time paralyzed from her neck down, died there yesterday at the age of 62.

Joseph Mendlowitz has purchased the six-story building containing two stores and twenty-eight apartments at 226-28 East Eighty-third Street from Celia Gerrish and Dora Tanklofsky. The City Title Insurance Company insured title to the property, which occupies a plot 42 by 102 feet.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Grain futures were more active today than many traders had expected and there was broader general buying than for some time. The stimulation in the demand was laid to somewhat more pessimistic Korean developments, the prospect for liberal export sales of wheat some time this week and the forecast for another storm which is now raging in the Northwest and is expected to overspread the Middle West by tomorrow.

LITTLE VALLEY, N. Y., Dec. 31 (AP) -- "The only ones that got out were those of us who were in the after part of the ship," reported Lieutenant Bischof, a Navy lieutenant stationed at Key West, Fla. Lieutenant Bischof told reporters that the plane ran into rough weather within a half-hour after it left Pittsburgh en route to Buffalo.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Four of Prime Minister Churchill's colleagues in the wartime British Government received viscountcies in the New Year's honors list issued today, the first honors awarded by King George on the recommendation of Mr. Churchill since his return to power.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Dec. 31 -- The last stymie was played today on the hallowed Old Course at St. Andrews -- birthplace of golf -- and the pesky little thing bowed out of the game for good.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- John J. McCloy, the United States High Commissioner, in a New Year's radio speech in German here tonight, warned the nations behind Russia's Iron Curtain that they would have to reckon with the moral impact of a Europe united against oppression.
Following are the lists of those on the Air Force C-47 plane reported down near Phoenix, Ariz., and the survivors and the dead of the crash of the commercial C-46 near Salamanca, N. Y.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31 -- Pravda published today a long review of the conservative and, from Moscow's viewpoint even reactionary United States public opinion, from which it drew the conclusion that United States foreign policy had reached a new and extremely serious crisis.

Eight new appointees to judicial and municipal posts were announced yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri, bringing to twenty-six the total of officials who will be sworn in at City Hall today. Included in yesterday's list was the name of Hyman Barshay, Brooklyn attorney, to a $17,500-a-year Special Sessions Justiceship.

The Associated Press, in an end-ofthe-year report covering six months, finds that restraints on the reporting and transmission of news have tightened. Despite the efforts of newspapers and news agencies, the man in the world's great street simply can't find out all that he ought to know as to what is going on.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President Truman was said today to favor bringing before the United Nations the case of the four United States fliers who were held for thirty-nine days in Hungary. The fliers were released from custody last week upon payment of fines totaling $120,000.

The United States Steel Corporation shipped a record 24,250,000 net tons of finished steel products in 1951, a gain of 7.1 per cent over the previous record shipments in 1950 and 15.2 per cent above the company's wartime record shipments in 1944, Irving S. Olds, chairman, reported yesterday in a year-end statement.

JOSEPH HILAIRE PIERRE BELLOC is 81 years old. He has written no new books since 1942, when he suffered a serious illness. Such literary inactivity must seem strange indeed to the author of 106 books published between his twenty-sixth and seventy-second years. "A hack writer" Mr. Belloc has called himself, meaning that he wrote for money as well as for the sake of beautiful letters.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- Unable to end its long debate on the appropriation bill, the French National Assembly put through a special measure today to allow expenditures and tax collections on this year's basis until the disputed measure has been passed.

Warner-Hudnut, Inc., manufacturer of pharmaceutical and cosmetic products, is offering to holders of the 146,980 outstanding shares of common stock of the Maltine Company the opportunity to exchange their holdings for 293,960 shares of Warner-Hudnut common.

A threatened strike of 1,200 truck drivers employed by fifty wholesale grocery warehouses, scheduled to start last midnight, was averted, at least temporarily, as negotiators for Local 138, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., and representatives of the food suppliers decided to continue sessions today.

The general average of Mayor Impellitteri's year-end appointments to city and court jobs is one of uninspired mediocrity, disappointing when measured against his pre-election promise of a "nonpolitical administration." The quality of the men named for judges is better and more uniform than that of the men named for other offices, undoubtedly because of anticipated bar association scrutiny on the judgeships.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in December totaled $65,359,000, the largest amount for any month since April. The total compared with $41,756,000 in the preceding month and $147,012,000 in December 1950, and $51,073,000 in December 1949.
RENO, Nev., Dec. 31 (AP) -Three persons were known dead, four were missing and at least thirteen hurt today as the result of a year-end storm that lashed the High Sierra and Rocky Mountain regions.

The controversy over the sale of the $66,500,000 Washington Water Power Company to public power interests in the Pacific Northwest was thrown into focus yesterday. Officials of the states of Washington and Idaho, in which the utility operates, as well as a major stockholder of the American Power and Light Company, which owns Washington Water Power, called for a thorough airing of the matter by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Harry C. Oliver, western divisional manager of the United States Rubber Company, has been promoted to assistant sales manager, United States Tires. Roy W. Collings, formerly manager of market development, has been named western divisional manager.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Representative Clarence Cannon, Democrat of Missouri, a key figure in Congressional money matters, returned to Capitol Hill today, pledging himself to work hard for a balanced budget to prevent any new tax rises.

Controls worked out jointly by industry and Government subjected rubber manufacturers in 1951 to the most severe restrictions in their peacetime history, but despite this the industry was able to meet all military and civilian requirements, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Arthur S. Flemming, manpower chief in the Office of Defense Mobilization, says more high school graduates, girls included, should be guided to engineering schools to help meet the need for trained personnel for defense purposes that may last as long as twenty years.
LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A business agreement that has had the effect of keeping the price of diamonds high and stable throughout the world comes to an end at midnight.

CHAPPAQUA N. Y., Dec. 31 -- Permission to establish a Roman Catholic convent and retreat on part of Billy Rose's large estate on Armonk Road, New Castle, was granted today by the town Zoning Board of Appeals. The permit is for the use of seventy-five acres and several buildings by the Cenacle of St. Regis, which is moving from New York.
The penny postal card will cost 2 cents starting today.

Television and radio coverage of the Republican and Democratic national conventions in Chicago next July, plus Presidential election returns on Nov. 4, will be carried over the National Broadcasting Company networks under the sponsorship of the Philco Corporation at a cost of $3,800,000.

United States Government obligations continued with vigor yesterday the price rally which developed late last week. For the most part, however, the market continued to be a professional affair, largely reflecting the restored confidence of the dealers.

FAIRMONT, W. Va., Dec. 31 (AP) -- The $100,000 slander suit in which a college art teacher sought to clear herself of talk that she is an atheist was declared a mistrial today because of a minister's remarks.

Capt. Walter Herzer was to begin a one-year term as commodore of the Rudder Club of Brooklyn today, taking over the office from Vincent J. Griffin, vice president of William Spencer and Son Corporation. Mr. Griffin is the club's new chairman of the board of governors.
OSLO, Norway, Dec. 31 (AP) -Entries for the 1952 Winter Olympic Games closed at midnight tonight without word that Russia would compete in the international carnival of snow and ice.

Gerald Barrack, Cornell freshman from Bayonne, N. J., and Stephen Bank, De Witt Clinton High School sophomore from the Bronx, won singles titles as the Eastern junior and boys' indoor tennis championships were concluded at the Third Engineers Armory on Washington Heights yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- In face of a tightening labor market in skilled categories, the Massachusetts State Division of Employment Security has worked out a recruitment plan with the Raytheon Manufacturing Company that officials on both sides feel could serve as a model elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Either the establishment of stable world peace or the outburst of the most calamitous war in history can conceivably become an entry in the chronology of the new year. To these possibilities even the fact that in 1952 the identity of the next President of the United States will be disclosed must take second place.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- President Truman's appointment of a National Health Commission is "another flagrant proposal to play politics with the medical welfare of the American people," Dr. John W. Cline, president of the American Medical Association, asserted today.

Tuskegee Institute reports that one lynching occurred in the United States during the past year. The temptation is strong to write "only" one, for the total has been as low but twice before (there has never been a year without lynchings); and the figure compares with well over a hundred lynchings annually at the turn of the century, and more than fifty as recently as 1922.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- At the meeting late in January of the six Foreign Ministers negotiating for a European Army the French will seek to remove what appears to be an ambiguity in the statement the Ministers issued yesterday to proclaim their desire for European unity.
Indianapolis, Ind., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Jan. 10 on $2,195,000 of loan notes due on May 29, 1952.

The supply of corporate bonds available for public investment in 1952 will be smaller than in 1951, and an augmented demand for a reduced supply of corporate investments could strengthen bond prices, Halsey, Stuart Co., bond distributors, said in its annual year-end survey out today.

The winter series of the American Museum of Natural History Story Hour Clubs, exclusively for pre-school children, will begin next Monday. Sessions are scheduled for Mondays, Tuesdays or Wednesdays at 3 P. M. at the museum. The $5 fee entitles a child to attend ten weekly hours devoted to stories about animals and people of the world.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Draft calls will continue heavy in at least the first few months of 1952, and thousands of youths previously deferred or rejected will wind up uniform.

WILMINGTON, N. Y., Dec. 31 -This New York State project, now entering its fourth year, was crowded with skiers today despite only fair conditions. While the lower portion of the Alpine-lift served development was closed because of thin snows and the bare spots caused by rising temperatures, the facilities at the 4,400-foot level were opened for the first time.

The cotton futures market closed irregular yesterday and 10 points lower to 12 higher than on Saturday. Starting 2 points higher to 9 points lower, the market steadied in the late trading on year end-price fixing. The short session, which ended at 1 o'clock, was moderately active. Hedge-selling was light all day. A leading spot house sold about 2,000 March early in the morning.

Any immediate financial relief for the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation was withheld by the Board of Estimate last night when the board voted to extend all existing franchise agreements with ten bus operators for one month ending Jan. 31.
Union contracts covering 30,000 aluminum workers were extended yesterday for one month, thus averting a New Year's Eve strike that would have crippled the nation's aircraft program.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Amory Houghton Jr. of New York and Queenstown, Md., gave a supper dance last night in their home at 3 Sutton Place for 1Vr. I-Iouhton's debutante daughter, //ss Sylvia Bigelow Houghton, and Miss Charlatte Paxton Taylor, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Foxhal! P. Keene Taylor of 19 East Ninety fifth Street.

ATLANTA -- A few snags and disappointments marked the economic picture in the Sixth Federal Reserve District during 1951, but generally this area is able to look back on another year of new highs in business activity. Prospects are, too, that barring an all-out war 1952 will see a continuation of record prosperity.

The cup that soothes after the glass that cheered may be the order of the day in many homes this morning. Some new containers for coffee or tea, many of which could double also as chocolate pots, are available for those who might like to invest in one to use in the New Year.

Recent recommendations by Washington administrators that manufacturers substitute aluminum for copper have "tended to alarm consumers and were in the main unsound," according to James J. Russell, chairman of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., in a year-end statement.
DETROIT, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Gordie Howe's "hat trick" went to waste tonight as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the league-leading Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 3, before 11,028 fans at Olympia.

I. W. Wilson, president of the Aluminum Company of America, reported yesterday in a year-end statement that the company's plant-building program to increase its capacity by 55 per cent, was "moving ahead at full speed." The Government has authorized Alcoa to add 205,000 tons, or 410,000,000 pounds, to its annual aluminum-smelting capacity, all of which is expected to be in operation before the spring of 1953, Mr. Wilson said.
The wreckage of the missing Pittsburgh-to-Buffalo airliner was found yesterday on a snow-covered forest ridge near Salamanca, N. Y., with fourteen of its forty passengers and crew members alive.

The trial of James J. Moran, former first deputy Fire Commissioner, accused of being the "guiding genius" of a $500,000-a-year "shakedown" racket, is scheduled to begin Thursday in General Sessions. It was indicated yesterday, however, that the trial would be adjourned at least a week by Judge John A. Mullen.

The stock market closed higher for the third consecutive year with the averages below the best levels of 1951 in less active trading than in 1950. Sales as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES amounted to 443,504,076 shares, compared with 524,799,621 the year before and with the record of 1,124,990,980 shares registered in 1929.
