PARIS, Dec. 31 -- The adoption today by the National Assembly of a bill providing for public works investments assured the start of an ambitious project, entailing construction of a feeder pipeline that will bring to Paris gas produced in the Saarland cokeries and Lorraine factories.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -Tennessee's football legions will defend their No. 1 national ranking and a 20-game winning streak against unbeaten Maryland in the Sugar Bowl tomorrow, and the Terrapins' young coach, Jim Tatum, confesses:

A resurgence of something of the old New Year's Eve tradition -- of the spirit of the strident horn, the clanging cowbell, and tossing of confetti -- unaccountably enlivened Times Square last night and filled most of its space from building line to building line.

Weavers' and knitters' interest in blends containing the new acrylic fibers goes beyond the mere question of price, according to William Luttge, sales manager of Chemstrand Corporation, manufacturers of Acrilan. There has been no letdown in the textile manufacturers' request for the fiber, he explained yesterday, even though wool prices are down considerably from the high level reached early in 1951.

MADRID, Dec. 31 -- Paul A. Porter, acting Mutual Security Administrator for Europe, announced today that he and Stanton Griffis, the United States Ambassador, had cabled to Washington this morning urging the establishment of a Mutual Security Agency mission to Spain.

Sales of department stores in the New York district during 1951 were nearly 4 per cent above 1950, it was estimated as the year closed. Although volume fell off in the latter half of the year, high levels reached last January in the peak post-Korea "scare buying" wave served to keep the over-all yearly gain relatively high.

New York's Negro population of 1,012,883 has risen 63.1 per cent since 1940 and tripled its income in the same time, according to a survey released yesterday by Station WLIB, which has been concentrating on the market with its own studios in Harlem.

Terminating an ownership of three weeks, Estate Securities Company, operators, resold the three four-story apartment buildings at 301 to 307 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, to an out-of-town client of Edward I. Koch, attorney. The A. J. Clarke Management Corporation was the broker.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn, Dec. 31 -- The South's expanding economy averaged one new multi-million dollar industrial plant every working day in 1951, according to a special year-end report released today by the Southern Association of Science and Industry.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Capt. John J. Swift won a race against death today when he arrived here by plane to see his critically ill father.

To make their own happy New Year, the New York Knickbockers had to overcome a 9-point deficit against the pace-setting Boston Celtics last night at Madison Square Garden to gain an 82-82 regulation deadlock and a victory in overtime, 87-86.

The public health and safety are both endangered by the unlawful usurpation of both sides of many of our public thoroughfares by so-called "parked" automobiles. Dirt and refuse of all kinds accumulate beneath the cars because street cleaners are unable to do their job.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 31 -- A United States-sponsored inquiry has provided Western policy makers with evidence that the people of Western Germany favor European union to the extent that almost half of them would be willing to give up national sovereignty for that ideal.
Charles E. Dykes has been named director of Hines-Park Foods, Inc., Ithaca, N. Y., it was announced yesterday by Roy H. Park, president.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- A last minute protest strike on the liner Queen Mary threatened today to delay Prime Minister Churchill's departure for the United States a second time, but the threat was quickly dispelled and the vessel sailed two minutes before noon.

One of the largest gifts received by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, $11,000 from the Sophia Louise Miller Trust Fund, made it possible yesterday for the 1951-52 campaign to end the year with a total of $291,779.03. Thus, on the twenty-third day of the appeal it stands $266.58 ahead of 1948; $40,389.05 ahead of 1949, and $20,854.43 ahead of 1950.

Innovations in the food field during 1951 were far less numerous than in the years immediately after World War II. One of the few was a liquid yogurt, a modernization of an ancient dairy food that had always been custard-like in consistency.

AND a Happy New Year to you, too. Ordinarily this is the day which sends the sports year spinning merrily on its way with the various bowl games. But the feeling persists that this may be the last of such flamboyant getaways. The reform movement in college athletics has moved reluctantly but inexorably beyond the conversational stage.

Let us all, as Americans, make a New Year's resolution -- to be patient. It is such a simple virtue, and yet so foreign to the American temperament! We feel as if we must get everything over with in such a hurry -- rearmament, European unity, Korea, China, the cold war.

Dollar sales volume of New York land Brooklyn department stores for the week ended Dec. 29 was 6 per cent higher than for the comparable week of 1950, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Two United States Navy ships were speeding tonight to the area 250 miles southwest of Ireland, where the 6,710-ton United States freighter Flying Enterprise lay disabled and listing sharply, with nobody aboard her still but her 37-year-old captain, Henrik Kurt Carlsen of Woodbridge, N. J.

Citing the huge tasks of meeting the record world-wide needs for petroleum products last year, Eugene Holman, president of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), in a year-end statement expressed confidence that the still-mounting demand for 1952 would be satisfied.

Winning in 47 moves from H. Golombek, former British champion, Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia yesterday held first place in the international chess masters tournament at Hastings, according to a report from London.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1115 for the twenty-four-hour period ended at 6 A. M. today [4 P. M. Monday, Easter standard time]:

Reprints of articles that appeared in The Economist of London over the summer are arousing interest in Wall Street. They are based on the premise that inflation is here, cannot be avoided and we should try to learn to live comfortably with it.

DALLAS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Neither is mentioned among the top football teams in the country, but Texas Christian and Kentucky will play before the usual packed house of 75,000 tomorrow in the sixteenth annual Cotton Bowl game.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Confidence prevailed in both camps today as the Baylor Bears and the Georgia Tech Engineers took their last light limbering-up exercises for the football battle tomorrow in the Orange Bowl.

CAIRO, Dec. 31 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British commander in chief of land forces in the Middle East, declared today on his arrival at Fayid, in the Suez Canal zone, that Britain would uphold her position in the zone and maintain the freedom of the Canal until four power proposals for a Middle East Command had become a reality.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- In accordance with a decree published last Saturday, the Bank of Indo-China, a private banking firm, tomorrow will cease to be the bank of issue for the piastre in Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- In a slack trading session, induced by the approaching end of the current bookkeeping account, most sections of the stock market here were inclined to dullness.
Department store sales this month will put more-than-usual emphasis on markdown promotions as merchants strive to offset a disappointing Christmas season, key retail executives said yesterday.

December dollar volume of home furnishings stores throughout the country registered a reversal of the sharp upward trend shown in November, the National Retail Furniture Association reported yesterday. Best preliminary estimates of the organization, which represents 8,000 stores, placed December volume 3 to 5 per cent below the similar month in 1950.

The Argentine regime does so many disgraceful and shameless things that one is in danger of getting to take them for granted. President Peron is at least consistent. The process of destroying another fine newspaper and persecuting its publisher for no reason except political opposition and "disrespect" for the Perons has now reached its fulfillment.

In a notable advance toward European unification, the Foreign Ministers of six Continental nations have reached agreement on what is in effect a three-year plan for the creation of a United States of Europe. In substance this plan provides for the creation of a Continental European federation in three stages, the last stage to be reached by Jan. 1, 1955.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today that the defense program could be financed "without danger to our economy." But to do this, he said, the nation "must be willing to bear a very high level of taxation for a considerable period to come."

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- The New York Central's Wolverine rolled into the La Salle Street Station at 1:30 P. M. today, ending what for more than thirty minutes had made it the central figure in "the great train robbery of 1951."
BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A fifteen-man United States Olympic hockey squad for the 1952 winter games in Oslo was selected tonight following a 2-2 tie played by candidates at the Arena.
SALAMANCA, N. Y., Dec. 31--A haggard survivor of the C-46 plane crash in western New York State scrambled out of the Allegheny foothills today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The end of the old year brings with it a deadline for payment of the first month's tax on the "handle" of gamblers, but it will be several days before the Government knows how much it has collected.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -Aben Kandel will come in for a share of the profits from the film to be based on his script called "Kid Monk Baroni," a psychological study of a prize fighter who was born with a deformed face.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 31 -- In the view of United States officials here, six words in the United States Mutual Security Act may deprive Iran of the means that might prevent her from becoming a new Korea and possibly a center of a new world war.

WATERLOO, Iowa, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Net sales of the Rath Packing Company of Waterloo during the fiscal year ended Oct 31 were $243,381,389, an increase of 14.6 per cent over the previous year, the annual report to stockholders showed today.

With the new year the winter Meeting Season is in full swing. The "Events Today" column is filled with notices of Meetings, large, medium and small. The number of societies, clubs, orders, federations, associations, councils, round-tables, forums, auxiliaries, institutes, unions, reunions, foundations and boards that meet daily, and sometimes on Sunday, in this city for breakfasts, luncheons, teas or dinners (welcoming or testimonial) is impressive. Indeed, it is somewhat staggering.

ROME, Dec. 31 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi returned to Rome this afternoon in extremely high spirits over the progress he and the Foreign Ministers of five other Western European nations had made in Paris toward creating a European army and achieving "a total European federation within the foreseeable future."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, suggested today that the Old North Church in Boston should put the country on guard against the arrival soon of Prime Minister Winston Churchill, as it once alerted the countryside against the invading British during Revolutionary days.
Trading in commodities futures markets that were not closed yesterday was featured by the strength of prices on the Cocoa exchange, reversing recent trends. Vegetable oils were weaker.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- The Chicago Defender, Negro newspaper, named ten Americans and five institutions to its 1951 Honor Roll of Democracy today.

PHILADELPHIA -- Early months of 1952 are expected to witness only occasional and limited spurts of business improvement. This is the forecast for industry and trade in the Third Federal Reserve District. Expectation is that average results for the fourth 1951 quarter will continue at least until the Easter season commences.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31 -- Long-smoldering tension between Negroes and white persons over lowcost housing is mainly responsible for the series of bombings and attempted bombings that has cast an ominous shadow for the last seven months over this traditionally happy and carefree vacationland.

RICHMOND -- The Fifth Reserve District is closing a generally satisfactory business year and will start 1952 in a favorable position. Department stores set a new dollar record and the sales trend continues definitely upward. The soft goods industry in midyear reached its bottom and price levels are firming.

Joanna Roos, actress, and Edward Mabley, author of the current "Glad Tidings," have obtained the rights to dramatize the recently published book, "By the Waters of the Danube," by Alexandra Orme. As soon as the stage script is completed, it will be handed over for perusal to Harald Bromley, who sponsored "Glad Tidings."
Six foolhardy boys found out the hard way yesterday that the "Danger!" signs on the ice of Central Park lakes mean what they say.

KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- Big industrial developments, including war plants, planned or under construction, are expected to be in operation in 1952 to help maintain business activity at a high rate. New high records in trade are hardly expected although expanded marketings of cattle and hogs may keep gross farm income at a record pace for some time.
Unbeaten Illinois led The United Press college basketball ratings for the third straight week yesterday.

Seeking more scoring punch, the New York Rangers yesterday acquired Jack Stoddard, right winger from the Providence Reds of the American Hockey League. The Rangers gave up three players and a fourth to be delivered before next season in exchange for Stoddard, top scorer in the American loop.

MUNSAN, Korea, Dec. 31 -- Although the armistice talks are still cluttered with disagreements, the United Nations already has begun clearing the ground adjoining its advanced base here to prepare the way for a tent hospital to care for sick and wounded Allied soldiers now held by the Communists.
The first trickle of what promised to be a record post-war flow of passenger traffic at air, train and bus terminals today and tomorrow began yesterday afternoon.

CLEVELAND -- Industrialists here are looking forward to a continuation of business activity at a rate comparable to that of 1951. Leaders are not predicting much beyond the first half but the general impression seems to be that even should the trouble in the Far East subside, the cutback in defense operations probably would be not more than 10 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- Important advances in the development of the transistor, a tiny amplifying device that can perform most of the functions of vacuum tubes and is expected to lead to a revolution in electronics, were announced here today at the close of the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which closed today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Work has been started on three detention camps that could hold more than 3,000 spies and saboteurs in the event of war or a similar national emergency.

Senator Estes Kefauver and City Council President Rudolph Halley are expected to be the principal Government witnesses against Frank Costello when he goes to trial next Tuesday on charges of contempt of the United States Senate.

P. H. Newby, English biographer and novelist, who has had three novels published here, has a new one on Knopf's list for Jan. 8. Titled "A Season in England," it is a comedy of misunderstanding arising from a young man's revolt against parental authority.

BURLINGTON, Wis., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Flabbergasted judges of the Burlington Liars' Club today pinned the title of the world champion liar on a member of the clergy -- the Rev. Arthur R. Kirk of Biggs, Calif.

Consumption of petroleum products in the United States in 1951 exceeded 100,000,000,000 gallons for the first time in any year, Robert G. Dunlop, president of the Sun Oil Company, pointed out in his year-end statement. He explained that this was equivalent to two gallons a day for each man, woman and child in the country and that it compares With about a half a pint a day a person for the rest of the world.

CHICAGO -- Seventh District retail trade and manufacturing continued at record or near-record levels in 1951 despite curtailed output of some civilian lines due to shortages of critical materials. Although contracts for war materials started out slowly in the first half of the year, they gathered momentum as the armed services developed programs more completely.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 31 (AP) -- William L. Patterson, secretary of the Civil Rights Congress, charged here today the United States was attempting to prevent him from submitting his accusation of genocide in the United States orally to the United Nations.

"The Wild Blue Yonder," which opens at Loew's State, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Republic drama, which revolves around the Air Forces B-29 Super fortress, features Wendell Corey, Vera Ralston, Forrest Tucker, Walter Brennan and Phil Harris.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27 (By Airmail) -- The Yogis of India, who stand on their heads as an aid in carrying out their philosophic concepts, have something, according to Dr. Ernesto Escudero, a chest surgeon of Buenos Aires. He believes none of them should ever suffer from asthma.

Less dogmatism, more cautious statements and the suggestion of possible alternatives in infant care -- so long as the baby's needs are satisfied -- mark the latest writings in the parental advice field. And, if the past is a reliable guide, this trend may be expected to continue through 1952 and well beyond.
The past year was another big one for the financing of local government activity in the market for tax-exempt-interest bonds.

DALLAS, Tex., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Vito (Babe) Parilli pierced Texas Christian's pass defense for two first-half touchdowns today and that was enough working margin for Kentucky to win the sixteenth annual Cotton Bowl game, 20 -- 7.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Although West Coast ports recorded a postwar decline in their share of the nation's foreign trade, they rolled up a foreign trade total last year that in dollar volume was within striking distance of previous highs.

The thirteen-story office building at 346 Broadway, once the home of the New York Life Insurance Company, has been sold by the City Investing Company, Robert W. Dowling, president, to a syndicate represented by David Rapoport, attorney.
The tremendous demand for gas service that has continued steadily since the end of World War II lifted the gas utility industry to new levels last year.
Hope was expressed yesterday "that 600,000 urgently needed volunteers will be signed up and trained by the middle of 1952" for civil defense assignments in this city.
DALLAS -- Heavy Government spending, the key to booming business in southwest Texas and in the state as a whole last year, assures the same condition in 1952, Southwestern economists agreed.

The travel industry will remember 1951 for the way the year ended. Christmas and New Year week-ends gave every type of transportation service a workout such as the oldest men in the business had never seen. Every piece of equipment that could safely roll, fly or sail was put to work to handle the crowds that jammed all major terminals.

Corporations arranged for about $4,000,000,000 of external financing in 1951 without going to the public market, according to trade estimates. This is a new high record. More than 600 private placements, mostly bonds, were arranged during the year with insurance companies and institutional investors.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Woodchuck made it three straight as he overpowered seven rivals with his burning speed in the New Year Purse this morning at Tropical Park before a crowd of 13,944.

Though perhaps by nature a quiet and scholarly group, university archaeologists and researchers are none the less untiring in their work. Recent reports point up some of the unusual discoveries which have been made in the past few months. For example, a Roman basilica, dating back to 150 B. C. and believed to be the earliest restorable forerunner of Christian church architecture, has been unearthed by American archaeologists in Italy.

Mozart "was obliged," writes a biographer, to accept a libretto of Lorenzo da Ponte when the Austrian Emperor Joseph II in 1789 commanded "an Italian opera." The result was "Cosi fan tutte," which nowadays reads and sounds, in its revival at the Metropolitan, as if there were no obligations in life except to be witty and ironical, pyrotechnic and lovely, lavish and gay.

The floor-covering trade, which underwent a slump in 1951, made some gains near the year-end but its recovery was much less marked than that of other branches of the home-furnishings industry Linoleum and other hard-surface products face the current year with somewhat brighter prospects than carpeting.

Judge Harold R. Medina is the subject of a new book by Hawthorne Daniels, which Wilfred Funk has scheduled for spring publicatioru The book will portray the personality and character of Judge Medina as well as asses; his work and the influence his decisions have had.

Our Civil War was the worst agony we ever passed through as a nation -- brother killing brother for four horrible years. It was supposed to have been settled eighty-six years ago. But the bomb killing in Mims, Fla., on Christmas night -- the ultimate violence in an increasing series of attacks -- will raise further doubts not only among ourselves, but throughout the entire world.

Predicting trends of business and prices for 1952 is complicated, according to George A. Renard, executive secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. In attempting to prepare such estimates, Mr. Renard said, the missing links are both overseas and domestic influences on economic conditions.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Jan. 1 (UP) -The head of the "walking Murphy" family admitted today his story of hiking 1,400 miles with his wife and two children from flood-ravaged Kansas was a hoax to get a job.

The outlook is optimistic for the men's shirt industry as retail inventories have been brought to more normal levels. The clearance was not achieved through demand for shirts by the consumer so much as by cuts in manufacturers' production.

The volume of retail sales of foundation garments during 1951 was estimated at approximately $440,000,000 by Fletcher D. Dodge, president of the Corset and Brassiere Association of America. Sales for the year just ended, he said, were 2 per cent above the all-time record set in 1950.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- La Salle College stayed in basketball's unbeaten ranks tonight by downing Western Kentucky, 67 -- 58, in the second game of a twin bill. The victory was La Salle's eighth in a row.

Advertising volume in 1951 more than lived up to the rosy predictions made for it at the spring meetings of the Association of National Advertisers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies. Preliminary figures indicate that American industry spent well over $6,000,000,000 in 1951 to promote its products.

Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia, winning in fifty-one moves on the black side of a Reti opening from S. Popel of France in the fifth round yesterday, added to his lead in the international masters tournament at the Hastings Chess Congress, according to a report from London.
NEW ORLEANS -- The South's stake in foreign trade increased sharply in 1951, making itself felt in both export-import volume in the region's Atlantic and Gulf coast ports.

Two influences were at work on cocoa futures prices through most of last year. The first was buyers' resistance to the higher prices for manufactured goods that followed the scare buying induced by the Korean war. Europe notably was unable to buy in its old volume.

May I congratulate you on the excellent editorial of Dec. 20 about the Arab refugees. The spirit of understanding which is growing in this great country concerning Arab problems is most encouraging and promising for a development of better American-Arab relations.

Research awards totaling $20,712 for eleven universities and institutions were announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, honorary chairman of the National Council to Combat Blindness. They will be used for studies in the maintenance of sight and the conquest of blinding eye diseases.
CAIRO, Jan. 1 -- British posts in Ismailia were subjected to heavy gunfire by Egyptian guerrillas during a series of clashes that continued for the first four hours of New Year's Day.

Improvements in engine, brakes, electrical system and chassis are listed for the 1952 line presented yesterday by the Plymouth division, Chrysler Corporation. The new cars will go on display Friday at the Chrysler International Auto Salon, 405 Lexington Avenue, at Forty-second Street, and dealer showrooms throughout the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON -- Deliveries of armaments currently are running at the rate of nearly $2,000,000,000 monthly, the Office of Defense Mobilization announced at the close of the year. The figure they add, is nearly three times what it was at the end of 1950.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 1 -- Dr. George W. Corner, director of the Department of Embryology of the Carnegie Institution at the Johns Hopkins Medical School, has been appointed George Eastman Visiting Professor for 1952-53 at Balliol College, Oxford University, England.

Philadelphia plan equipment trust certificates aggregating $293,000,000 were sold in the public market by sealed bidding in 1951 to finance acquisition by railroads of equipment costing more than $381,000,000, according to a survey by Salomon Brothers Hutzler, manager of the banking syndicate which marketed more than 60 per cent of these issues.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- Chile, Greece and Pakistan became members of the United Nations Security Council today in place of Ecuador, India and Yugoslavia as the General Assembly prepared to resume its work tomorrow.

WASHINGTON -- The cost of initially equipping a basic Army infantry division has increased since World War II from $19,000,000 to $91,000,000, with the cost of an armored division jumping from $40,000,000 to $293,000,000, according to estimates here.

The aluminum industry, important cog in the nation's industrial machine, is looking forward to historic production and expansion achievements in 1952. Unless unforeseen snarls develop, this pivotal industry expects to establish a new production record this year.

With an output of approximately 535,000,000 tons in 1951, the bituminous coal industry has increased production by almost 100,000,000 tons in two years. Under pressure of the nation's expanding industrial program, plus expanded demands for exports, according to the Bituminous Coal Institute, Washington, the industry produced at least one-fifth more coal than the 437,000,000 tons of 1949.
LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 2 -- The Moscow radio announced today that former Soviet Foreign Minister Maxim Litvinov was dead at the age of 75.

Productive capacity of the United States rayon and acetate producing industry toward the close of 1951 was 1,444,000,000 pounds, or 10.5 per cent more than a year ago, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. A survey showed that by mid-1952 rayon and acetate capacity will reach 1,510,000,000 pounds.

EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- Texas Tech's Red Raiders rolled to a 25-14 lead in the first three periods, then held off a desperate College of Pacific eleven today to win the seventeenth annual Sun Bowl classic before 17,000 fans.

The nation's savings banks, which registered a gain in deposits of more than $800,000,000 last year and are now approaching a deposit total of $21,000,000,000 for the first time in their 135-year history, expect even further expansion in 1952.

Pension planning in 1951 compared favorably with the year before despite the failure of the Government to determine whether pension payments should come under wage stabilization rulings. New pension plans and revisions of old ones were made on a tentative basis, pending clarification of their status by the Wage Stabilization Board.

About 5,250,000 television receivers and more than 12,500,000 radios will have been produced in 1951, Glen McDaniel, president of the Radio-Television Manufacturers Association, estimated yesterday. This represents a decline of 2,150,000 television receivers and 2,100,000 radios from the 1950 production, he said.
Big defense plant construction and concentration of new housing in military and industrial centers will dominate the realty and building picture for 1952.

Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra arranged a New Year's night program in Carnegie Hall that had the double merit of taking less time than usual and of offering delightful music. This concert also presented to New York Maryan Filar, the young Polish pianist, who made his first appearance in this city as soloist in the performance of the Chopin F minor concerto.

Reflecting abnormal demand resulting from the preparedness effort and the high level of civilian requirements, copper was in tight supply throughout 1951. In the late summer, the situation became acute following a strike that had tied up operations for nearly three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Congressional critics of the Office of Alien Property are laying plans for an investigation early in the new year of that unit of the Department of Justice and promise to daub new smudges upon the slate of the Administration.

Shipments of structural and alloy steels -- types of steel which have come into heavy demand for the defense effort and programs relating to it -- will show a sharp rise for 1951 over 1950, statistics indicate.

There will be no liquor advertising appealing directly to women, it was learned yesterday. The distillers, following the self-policing code they adopted shortly after repeal, have long refused to use television because of its feminine and home appeal.
WASHINGTON -- For the third time since hostilities began in Korea eighteen months ago, Congress produced a stiff tax-increase bill last year to help finance the stepped-up rearmament program.

When United States Government long-term bonds sold below par last winter for the first time in more than a decade, the bond market underwent a fundamental change ranking in significance with two other fateful episodes of a generation of finance.

The shipping industry in the United States enjoyed one of its best post-war years in 1951, financially and operationally. At the same time, qualified students of maritime affairs agree that the seeming good health was largely the result of artificial stimulation and believe that the future of American-flag shipping is extremely gloomy.

Production of synthetic rubber in the Soviet Union in 1951 reached a new record of between 250,000 and 300,000 metric tons (275,575 and 330,690 tons), close students of the Soviet chemical industry believe.
GALVESTON, Tex., Jan. 1 -The Lone Star flag, Texas' proud state symbol, did not originate in Texas.

AFTER yesterday's discussion of the .30 '06, the next logical step in any discourse on big game calibers should be the .270 (standard and magnum). This seems to have forged to the front among the shooting enthusiasts who can afford to indulge a whim if it is not too costly.
A battle, with no holds barred, is shaping up on the issue of fixed minimum prices for branded merchandise.

Despite the Government's basic policy of advocating industrial dispersion, this country is not spreading out its plant, "no matter what President Truman and other Government officials might claim," according to Leonard Yaseen, New York partner of the Fantus Factory Locating Service.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Generally high employment throughout the nation has forced unemployment insurance reserve funds to a new high, the Government reported today.

The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. issued yesterday a New Year's message of "love and hope" to Christians and others in Communist-dominated countries "who face restriction in the following of their religious convictions."

A special advisory committee for the Day Camp Unit of the Department of Health, which has been studying conditions in day camps and other summer programs for children, has been established, Miss Cornelia Goldsmith, chief of the department's Division of Day Care and Foster Homes, announced yesterday.

Strange things have come out of Washington during the past two decades, but it remains for the homely postal to herald an amazing innovation in business rules. Heretofore the accepted practice has been lower prices for larger quantities, and certainly no purchaser of anything ever has been penalized for increasing an order.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Western European nations have been hit harder by inflation since the Korean war than the United States, Federal Reserve Board figures showed today.

SAN FRANCISCO -- The business economy of the Far West continued its "war growth" and at somewhat reduced pace during the year. Injection of defense dollars offset the lag caused by credit restriction and higher taxes. California, key to the west economy, experienced a 10 per cent increase in business during the first ten months of 1951.

By mid-December the New York Curb Exchange was assured of a higher annual turnover in stocks than the 107,792,340 shares of 1950. Its final figure of 111,600,000 shares gave it the best year since 1946 and one of the three best years since 1936.

Well-trained salesmen continued to be in demand in 1951 and there is every indication that there will be no change in the situation because of the projected stepup in the defense program. This is the consensus of sales executives in many lines.

LINDEN, N. J., Jan. 1 -- Edward Seiler, 40 years old, author of "When the Lights Go on Again All Over the World" and other song hits, died of a heart attack here today in his home at 836 Summit Street. He was stricken while playing basketball with several nephews in the rear yard.
With mounting demands for defense production, a corresponding drop in the output of consumer goods is forecast for 1952 by Gwilym A. Price, president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

The impact of "discriminatory" Federal taxes on operations is a major problem of the nation's commercial banks as the new year begins. Forced to use the so-called "average earnings" method to compute their taxes, the bankers say they are at a disadvantage.
There is a certain constancy in the public's choice of stocks in which it trades from year to year, and 1951 was no exception to the rule.

OTTAWA, Jan. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Canada dug up a record $1,228,000,000 of strategic and other minerals during 1951 to help the western world increase production of planes, ships and guns for defense against the Communist threat.

Considerable improvement in the plastics raw material supply situation has been brought about in the past year, William T. Cruse, executive vice president of The Society of the Plastics Industry, Inc. reported. While one or two of the scores of types of plastics are still a bit tight, in the main the raw materials are generally available, he stated.

Bright prospects for a record year in 1951 for women's apparel were dimmed by consumer resistance to higher prices and the cautious policy of retailers. For the great majority of manufacturers of coats, suits and dresses, 1951 did not prove to be a profitable year, although there was marked recovery in production and sales in the last two months.
The foreign trade of the United States, spurred by the huge raw material needs of the defense program and inflationary effects of the Korean war, reached new high levels last year.
In your editorial of Dec. 28 on "Automobile Insurance" it seems to the writer that you are recommending a mere nostrum for the serious conditions which prevail regarding this type of coverage.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 1 -- Mrs. Catherine Burr, a widow 70 years old, was fatally burned and five other persons were routed early today when a fire attributed to careless smoking wrecked a two-and-a-half-story frame dwelling here at 121 Price Street.

Reflecting high activity in holiday buying and in economic affairs generally, money in circulation reached the largest volume in history as 1951 came to a close. As of Dec. 26, the total stood at $29,403,000,000, up $1,487,000,000 over the comparable date in 1950, and $240,000,000 above the previous high of $29,163,000,000 set on Dec. 24, 1946.
Prices and earnings were at record levels in New York City as 1951 drew to a close, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported.
CHATTANOOGA -- The South's expanding economy, which in the last decade has held major interest for the world of business and finance, continued to be bullish in 1951.
BALTIMORE -- United States defense spending during 1951 brought to Maryland business and industry a record year, with prospects that the trend would continue in 1952.

For almost two years "Curtain Going Up" (the title adorned a number of unproduced works intended for Broadway) has been aiming to achieve that happy moment in its career. The ordeal of thirty-two auditions to raise capital for the intimate revue during that period hasn't dampened the spirits of those concerned and should be a fleeting memory to them by this time.
Stock split-ups and stock dividends in 1951 touched a new high since 1947 for companies whose issues were listed on the New York Stock Exchange, but the number was far below the record set in 1946.

Before a crowd of 18,000 persons that purchased a total of $2,980,000 in State of Israel bonds as entrance tickets, New York's first city-wide Hanukkah Festival was held yesterday at Madison Square Garden.
Mayor-Impellitteri proceeded at better than a man-a-minute rate yesterday when he administered oaths of office to twenty-eight appointees in City Hall in just twenty-five minutes.

Automobiles that will go farther on less gasoline and use smaller amounts of critical materials will receive increasing attention from the automotive industry during 1952, according to Ward M. Canaday, president of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Text of general headquarters communique 1116 for the twenty-four-hour period ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday (4 P. M., Eastern standard time, Tuesday):

Coming through a poor year as a result of declining sales in popular-priced furs, the fur industry is looking forward to more stable conditions in 1952. Except for those specializing in mink, few manufacturers were able to make a profit for the year and many were forced out of business.

We publish today the first of three sections of our annual review and forecast of business and finance throughout the world. Today's installment deals entirely with the situation in the United States. The international scene will be covered in special sections appearing tomorrow and Friday.

John Foster Dulles, Ambassador at Large and special adviser to the State Department, declared yesterday in his first public address since his return last week from Japan and Korea that the United States must cling to its role of leader of the free world during the Presidential campaign.

DALLAS -- An expanding Southwestern economy chalked up several new high points in business indicators of the Eleventh Federal Reserve District during 1951, and there were indications that 1952 would bring other new records. In the Christmas season just ended, retail sales reached the largest dollar volume on record in this district.

Domestic lead and zinc producers were hopeful at the year-end that the Government would permit the industry to return to a free market this year in preference to imposing increased controls. But the outlook for eased controls remained dim despite the recommendations of leading lead and zinc company executives.

Newspaper linage and readership, hitherto helped rather than hurt by television, seem even less likely to loss through future TV development than any other media. This prognosis is the result of extending recognized studies available earlier in the year.

The public affairs committee of Freedom House proposed yesterday that Congress revise its rules to "protect citizens from unfair and unwarranted attack" by Senators and Representatives who shield themselves behind Congressional immunity.

Refunding of bonds before maturity dates declined sharply in 1951, with all classifications of retirements sharply lower than in the preceding year. The year's prepayments of bonds was the smallest since 1949.

OTTAWA, Jan. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Canada developed another 881,250 horsepower of new hydroelectric capacity during 1951 but her total of more than 13,000,000 is only about 24 per cent of known resources.

GENEVA, Jan. 1 -- With a disregard for taboos that might be fatal to the average international organization, the secretariat of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe is preparing a study that, if it appears next month as planned, can be expected to cause more than a passing stir in international circles. It is a critical review of Russian economic statistics.
The nation's steel industry, which established a spectacular production record and added substantially to its facilities last year, is primed for even greater output and expansion in 1952.
A neat, gray-haired man started 1952 in jail yesterday because he put his hand into the wrong pocket at the New Year's Eve celebration in Times Square. The pocket belonged to a policeman.

National advertising in newspapers, reversing a trend of previous months, held its own in November as against October and showed a 13 per cent gain over November, 1950, according to Printers' Ink. For the first time television showed a decline, along with magazines, but newspapers, outdoor and trade papers kept the general average up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Harry A. McDonald, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today he hopes Congress will revise securities laws this year to make stocks and bonds more understandable and to provide better protection for individual owners.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Canisius handed Utah its third basketball setback in fourteen starts, 62 to 54, tonight in Memorial Auditorium. Temple nipped Niagara in overtime, 61 -- 60, in the first game of the double-header, played before a crowd of 3,829.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Most used car ceiling prices automatically dropped about 8 per cent today, but officials said the reduction will not necessarily mean an actual change in selling prices.

Continued uptrends in sales of business machines, particularly in foreign markets, and marked increases in the use of business machines and systems in the administration and control of industrial production were outstanding developments of 1951, in the opinion of James H. Rand, president of Remington Rand, Inc.

Sugar futures trading has just come through a puzzling year, affected by three separate changes in the official quotas, by war-scare hoarding in Europe and by large invisible inventories at home. For most of the year futures prices for the No. 4 world contract ranged above those for the No. 6 domestic contract -- an unusual situation.

Just back from a two months' trip to Japan, Harold L. Bache of Bache Co. last week underlined once again the acute shortage of capital in that country and, by inference, the opportunities for American investment, once various difficulties have been removed.

It is now nearly a year since the Patterson - Lockwood - Moses commission, appointed by Governor Dewey after tragic Long Island Rail Road wrecks, proposed public authority operation of the road, a solution compelled "because there is no other course open to us."
India's tobacco production is the third largest in the world, according to the Continental Daily Mail Economic Survey of India. Only the United States and China exceed India's output.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Price movements were very narrow on the stock market here today in a slack trading session that ended soon after noon. With the exception of oil and shipping issues, which were firm, changes were negligible, with losses outnumbering gains.
Dry goods retail stores ended 1951 with a sales volume gain of about 3 per cent. In light of the numerous adverse factors affecting trade, this showing was considered good.
Vegetable oil prices on the futures markets dropped about 30 per cent in 1951. The Government stepped in with a new price support program, but the trade availed itself of it only to a limited extent.

Bedding, an item generally taken for granted until the time to purchase replacements arrives, represents such a sizable investment that the homemaker would do well to increase the life of the bedding by taking good care of it, a recent Cornell Extension Bulletin explains.

Some household furniture trade leaders maintain that the industry chalked up the highest annual dollar volume in its history in 1951. Official figures will be ready by the end of the first quarter; if these leaders are correct, more than $6,000,000,000 worth of business at all trade levels was done last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. I (UP) -- Price Stabilizer Michael V. DiSalle was advised by his economists today that the rise in living costs probably could be held to 2 or 3 per cent this year -- barring any "substantial rise" in steel prices.

WASHINGTON -- When the European Recovery Program came to an end on Dec. 31 the combined output of continental industry was 40 per cent higher than before World War II. Such had been the impact of the rearmament program, however, that the two most important participants, Britain and France, were in the grip of financial crises hardly less serious than that which followed the war.

Refreshing fashion trends in shoes now being introduced into stores are the new cruise and resort designs. The latest styles are gay and imaginative in color and style and bespeak leisure days in sunny climates.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 1 -- An agreement including a 10 per cent salary increase and running until Labor Day, 1954, has been reached by J. J. Shubert and theatrical unions serving his Shubert and Cox Theatres here, it was learned today.
Net sales volume in 1951 for the Sonotone Corporation, manufacturer of hearing aids, will be the highest in its history, Irving I. Schachtel, president, declared in a year-end statement.

One of the principal tasks of 1952 will be to determine what is a "reasonable volume" of business to expect, and to find ways to show a satisfactory record of earnings from such a volume, according to Walter E. Hoadley, economist for the Armstrong Cork Company.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen battled alone against the raging Atlantic for the fourth day today with rescue -- the greatest danger -- still to come.

Last year was a historic one for the stock market. For the first time in years it operated from an important base and, in the case of THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks, the rate of 170 formed the underlying structure. While the gyrations of prices at times proved highly erratic, the list at no time shot too far away from a center line.
The nation's electric power and light industry during 1951 responded to the ever-increasing requirements of industrial production and domestic usage.

BOSTON -- A United States Supreme Court decision that wiped out a railroad grain rate differential from the Great Lakes to the Atlantic seaboard was counted the most important development of 1951 for the Port of Boston.
YOKOHAMA Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Camp Drake Army Bulldogs today defeated the Yukosuka Naval Base Seahawks, 26 -- 12, in the second annual Cherry Bowl football game.

Through action just taken by the city -- expected to be followed soon by parallel action by the Federal Government -- some much-needed housing in congested sections of Manhattan is in prospect for middle-income families. The way is being cleared for the prompt construction of four projects to cost altogether more than $80,000,000.
HONG KONG, Jan. 1 -- "Released under supervision of the masses!"

Last year witnessed a marked increase in virtually all phases of communications. The nation's telephone network was strengthened to meet growing civilian and defense needs. The telegraph industry mechanized its operations for emergency and peacetime demands.
As in 1951, a major money market concern this year will undoubtedly arise over ways and means of financing Treasury deficits without incurring new inflationary pressures.

MIMS, Fla., Jan. 1 -- A pledge that Florida was doing its utmost to seize the perpetrators of the Christmas night slaying of Harry T. Moore, local Negro leader, was given here today by Herbert E. Griggs, an assistant state attorney, at a funeral service for Mr. Moore.

PHILADELPHIA -- With a huge industrial expansion and renovation program in full tilt along the Delaware River Valley, the Philadelphia metropolitan area entered 1952 with visions of setting new peaks in employment, foreign trade and general business.

With production and sales about 8 per cent higher in 1951 than in the preceding record year, the flat glass industry expects 1952 to continue "in a growth cycle," John D. Biggers, president of the Libby-Owens-Ford Glass Company, asserted.
Another upswing in industry and business looms this Presidential election year.

SALAMANCA, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- As the last three bodies were removed from the wreckage of a C-46 transport plane that crashed five miles northwest of here Saturday night with the loss of twenty-six lives, Donald W. Nyrop, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, flew here today from Washington to make a personal inspection of the wreck scene.

LOS ANGELES -- The Los Angeles industrial area, the nation's fifth-ranking manufacturing center, broke all its past records, including those of World War II, in expansion of industrial facilities during 1951.
With Government moving into the driver's seat in labor-management relations, time lost through strikes in 1951 dropped to the lowest level since V-J Day.

For the first time a substantial number of companies in many parts of the country began during 1951 to pay tuition money for hundreds of employes taking one-term or two-term specialized courses in the evening branches of leading colleges.

Festoons of silvered smilax, huge clusters of silver bells and glittering Christmas tress provided a holiday d6cor for the thirtieth annual Debutantes New Year's BaH held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf*Astoria and the adjoining suites.

While we welcome the news that Governor Dewey is opposed to billboards on the New York State Thruway we urge that he take a stronger position than has yet been reported from Albany. If the Thruway is not to develop into another billboard alley, as offensive and dangerous as most through highways have become in recent years, it must be legislatively protected from the blight of outdoor advertising.

MOUNT AIRY, N. C., Jan. 1 (UP) -- The police turned to Federal Bureau of Investigation scientists today for help in finding the slayer who expertly booby-trapped the truck of a popular high school teacher with high explosives wired to the ignition.

Encouraged by a 40 percent increase in sales in 1951 over 1950, Kaywoodie, Inc., manufacturer of smoking pipes, will embark during 1952 on its most ambitious advertising and sales promotion campaign according to Morris Levinson, president of the company.

Spurred by extraordinary military and civilian demands, the nation's pulp and paper industry set a new production record last year of more than 26,600,000 tons of paper, paperboard and building board. The outlook for 1952 was regarded as highly favorable.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 1 -- The wreckage of a missing Air Force C-47 plane and the bodies of the twenty-eight persons aboard were found today on the face of a central Arizona mountain.
A year-end shift in end-uses of metal products by manufacturing consumers is reported here by executives of big metal warehouses.
There is plenty of food. This conclusion is drawn both by those who review 1951 and those who predict for 1952. Prices are, and will continue to be, lower than expected.

Tightening of supplies of copper, nickel and other metals needed in defense production will be felt by the costume jewelry industry in 1952. Most spring lines have a liberal sprinkling of precious and semi-precious minerals, according to leading manufacturers.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Two railroads ordered an embargo on export coal shipments into Norfolk as a strike of 250 tugboat workers brought harbor business to a virtual standstill today.
HONOLULU -- An expansion in the volume of Federal expenditures and a continuing increase in tourist spending made 1951 a year of general economic improvement for Hawaii.

Reflecting the relaxation of controls in August, consumer instalment credit at the end of 1951 continued to show an upward tendency. Such credits outstanding last year, however, were below the levels of 1950, and there were indications that consumer instalment debt was levelling off.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Illinois, set ablaze when a Stanford pass backfired in the third quarter, swept over the gambling Indians by 40 to 7 in the Rose Bowl today and stretched Big Ten football supremacy over the Pacific Coast Conference to six straight victories.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The resurgence of a movement for a constitutional amendment limiting Federal taxes to 25 per cent on individual and corporation incomes, gifts and estates is causing concern among Congressional tax leaders and in the Treasury.

Redemptions of the United States Treasury's Series E Savings Bonds exceeded sales throughout 1951 but as the year ended this gap was being narrowed. Sales during the first eleven months totaled $2,935,000,000, against redemptions of $3,721,000,000.

MADRID, Jan. 1 -- Negotiations for a bilateral agreement between Washington and Madrid defining the terms of United States aid will begin here within a fortnight, Paul A. Porter, acting Mutual Security Agency Administrator for Europe, said today.

Fellow executives and associates will honor Frederick R. Wierdsma, general manager here of the Holland-America Line, on the completion of twenty-five years of service with the company at a dinner tonight. It will be held in the Nieuw Amsterdam Room of the Netherland Club, l0 Rockefeller Plaza.

The nation's gold stocks at the end of 1951 were slightly below the total at the close of 1950. As of Dec. 26, last year gold stock totaled $22,551,000,000, compared with $22,820,000,000 a year earlier.

As a convenient short cut for women who do considerable home baking, the State Extenson Service has worked out a ready-mix recipe for gingerbread. Reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, the formula gives directions for assembling at one time the dry ingredients for four cakes.

More mailings to smaller lists carefully screened is the prediction for 1952 of Frank Frazier, executive director of the Direct Mail Advertising Association. He cited increased postal rates and higher costs for labor and materials as compelling the most careful "sharpening of direct mail as an advertising tool."
I still think that it is easier to control the splitting of atoms than the splitting of infinitives, but your Topics effort of today is commendable.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- The Soviet Union's repeated declarations that it would not accept the San Francisco treaty as the final word on Japan received forceful confirmation today in Premier Stalin's unexpected New Year's message to the Japanese people with its bid for Soviet-Japanese rapprochement.

Textile production in the United States appeared headed for all time records at the beginning of 1951, only to meet with heavy curtailment as inventories of cotton, wool, and rayon fabrics became unwieldy well before the middle of the year. In the last six months, broad woven goods production fell off substantially, bringing the cotton goods total just below that of 1950, wool fabric down 25 per cent, and rayon goods down 14 per cent.

WASHINGTON -- Strains that will test the strength of anti-inflationary controls to the utmost were forecast for this year by officials responsible for the maintenance of a stable economy during the defense production program.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 2 -- The United Nations delegates at Panmunjom today proposed to the Communists a new departure in the history of warfare -- the repatriation of war prisoners and civilian captives based on the choice of regimes and ideologies that each individual chose to adopt after an armistice in Korea.

A belief that 1952 "may make a creditable showing in profit" is expressed by Jack I. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., in a year-end statement. He based this expression on the hope that 1952 might yield the sales volume of 1951, which reduced stocks and consequently reduced need for steep mark-downs.

The tempo of activity in the nation's aviation industry -- both air transport and the aircraft manufacturing divisions -- quickened perceptibly during 1951 and was expected to proceed at a much faster pace in the next twelve months.
The mutual fund or open-end investment company industry is expected to pass the $4,000,000,000 asset level during 1952.
Not to be outdone by Bill (Hopalong Cassidy) Boyd and Gene Autry, Roy Rogers has come to television with his own program of Western pictures at 6 o'clock Sunday evenings over N. B. C.

While inflation remains a dangerous potential, the public is not aware of the threat to the extent it was a year ago, according to leading executives in the insurance business. At the same time deflation, always a possibility in a free economy, does not appear as any great menace within the year, they deal.

Drivers and warehouse men for fifty wholesale grocery concerns that supply dry, staple and canned goods to 20,000 independent stores and restaurants in the city will go on strike at 8 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Senator Blair Moody, Democrat of Michigan, appealed today to Manly Fleischmann, Administrator of the National Production Authority, to keep automobile production at a quarterly level of 1,000,000 cars during the second and third quarters of this year and suggested a program by which he thought this could be accomplished.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- The New Year's Shooters and Mummers pranced up Broad Street today in gay sequins, bangles and plumes.

With business riding in a modicum of comfort along a not-too-bumpy road, the New York Stock Exchange last year devoted most of its attetntion to matters that, in former years, it had given little heed.

MAUDHEIM, Queen Maud Land, Antarctica, Dec. 26 -- Late last Saturday night, before we had arrived here, two heavily bearded, wild-looking men came to see us aboard the Norsel. They were the topographer, Nils Roer, and photographer, Stig Hallgren.

Unless the doubled domestic production of virgin aluminum this year is wholly absorbed by defense orders, the outlook for increased use of the metal in building is good, according to Frank Nichols, president of Nichols Aluminum and Wire Company of Davenport, Iowa.
The New Year's Day mail brought 109 contributions totaling $2,315.20 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and thus increased its lead over last year's appeal by $863.20 more.

Travel advertising may be the fastest growing classification in 1952, in both domestic and foreign travel. Lowering of rates for air-travel, making far places easily available to the man or woman with limited time, will be one favorable factor.

SEATTLE -- The Pacific Northwest has ended its most prosperous peacetime year. The latter half, however, saw a slackening, characterized by some official analysts as "a mild recession" in the civilian economy, but with many prospects pointing toward a pick-up early in 1952.

CHICAGO -- Stimulated by rapidly mounting defense outlays over-all business activity in the Chicago area rose to new peacetime levels during the first eleven months of last year, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1 -Plans are being made for a sequel to "The African Queen," which was rushed into a theatre engagement in Los Angeles in order to qualify for an Academy Award nomination before the Dec. 31 deadline, but will not be released generally for some time.

Preliminary estimates indicate that the nation's 6,000 savings and loan associations will show an increase of $2,000,000,000 in savings account balances for 1951. Although the flurry of public spending in the early months slowed the rate, the trend turned upward at the start of the second quarter.

The difficulties in establishing a United States of Europe are being surmounted one by one because the overwhelming strength of European public opinion favors the plan, Roger Seydoux said here yesterday at the annual New Year's reception at the French Consulate, 610 Fifth Avenue.

MIAMI, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Georgia Tech, seemingly bottled by a strong Baylor line, popped the cork with a trick play in the last six minutes today and went on to score a touchdown and field goal to win in the Orange Bowl, 17 to 14.

Those interested in experimental piano music turned out in force last night for David Tudor's recital at the Cherry Lane Theatre in Greenwich Village. They filled all 220 seats of the little playhouse, overflowed onto the stage and into the pit and stood at the sides and back.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- A strange atmosphere of political calm has fallen upon Britain since the Conservatives' defeat of the Labor Government last October. It is not a truce but a period of waiting to see which way Prime Minister Churchill's new Government will jump.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Jan. 1 -- Councilman James F. Segriff, a Democrat, was elected President of the City Council at an installation meeting today in City Hall before 250 well-wishers. Councilman Morris Fleishman was elected vice president. Mr. Segriff, a painting contractor, had been vice president of the Council for the last two years and succeeds Frederick V. Fell as President.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn. -- This community, because of its diversified manufactures, both of consumer and capital goods, as enjoying a boom period. In this five-town area of more than 250,000 population, 574 industrial plants employ more than 50 per cent of the 115,500 persons now employed.

Thousands of volunteers still are needed for the "Mothers' March on Polio" that will mark the climax of the New York March of Dimes. Louis H. Pink, general chairman of the drive, said yesterday that efforts would be made to send 200,000 mothers as collectors to homes throughout the city.

The rubber industry will set a new record for production in 1952 to meet the predicted demand for civilian and military products, according to leading rubber goods makers. Predictions of total volume for the year envision sales about 6 per cent above the record-breaking 1951 total of $5,000,000,000. Supplies of natural and synthetic rubber available to American industries are likely to exceed their needs, manufacturers said at the year-end.

New York City business men predict a drop in employment this year for the first time since the outbreak of the Korean War, according to a survey by the New York State Employment Service of the State Labor Department. By March, they see a 1 per cent job decline, it was said.

TIFTON, Ga., Jan. 1 -- Clint E. Trimble was charged with a fatal traffic accident today shortly after he served as foreman of a coroner's jury that ruled the death was caused by an unknown hit-and-run driver.

DETROIT -- The prodigious material needs of a parallel peace-and-war economy combined with tapering demand for new automobiles, cut the auto industry's 1951 output 15 per cent below the record total of a year ago.

As the new year gets under way all Americans will wish that the toll of American lives, the hardships and the heartaches that Korea means to us will end in 1952. We cannot know that they will and we cannot wish for an end unless there be what Vice Admiral Joy yesterday called "an honorable, equitable and stable armistice."

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- The housewife's influence on industrial production and her increasing role as a participating worker will receive consideration at the twelfth annual Congress of Industrial Health, to be held in Pittsburgh, Jan. 18 and 19. The meeting will bring together representatives of the medical profession, industry, labor and welfare agencies.

SEATTLE -- January and February will be critical power months for the Pacific Northwest. But the danger, raised last September, of a six-month "brownout," which would have slashed primary aluminum production and crippled other regional industries, was averted by above-normal October and November rainfall.

A record tonnage of iron and steel scrap was provided for domestic steel mills and foundries last year, and an even greater quantity will have to be found this year to satisfy scrap users' expanding requirements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- David S. Ingalls, manager of Senator Robert A. Taft's campaign for the Republican nomination, asserted today that the Ohioan's designation at the party convention next July "on an early ballot now seems a certainty."
NEW ORLEANS -- The Deep South experienced its greatest industrial expansion in 1951, and there are signs that this expansion will continue through 1952.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Harry Mallios ran for both touchdowns and Jim Dooley staged a one-man stand against Billy Hair's passes today as Miami trounced Clemson, 14 -- 0, in the Gator Bowl and avenged a year-old humiliation.
Judged by the usual economic indicators, 1952 should be a year of good business, Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., declared in a year-end statement
LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Portsmouth, crack South Coast soccer team, took the lead in the first division of Britain's soccer league today with a 1-0 victory over Manchester City.
The tobacco industry's continued growth and prosperity in 1952 is indicated, according to A. E. Lyon, board chairman of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The sons of three officers at Hamilton Air Force Base were among those aboard the wrecked C-47 in Arizona. A 1948 Olympic games champion and the nephew of a former major league baseball star also were aboard.

Shipments of heavy industrial equipment during the first quarter of 1952 will be at least 25 per cent higher than during the first quarter of 1951, members of the American Supply and Machinery Manufacturers Association and other equipment manufacturing associations predicted.

Government controls virtually closed the Commodity Exchange in 1951. Washington imposed controls in turn on marketing of rubber, zinc, lead, copper and raw hides. Dates were set by which "trading in liquidation" must end. These dates have all passed and today only tin is theoretically traded on that once-busy Broad Street market.
Judged by the usual economic indicators, 1952 should be a year of good business, Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., declared in a year-end statement
LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Portsmouth, crack South Coast soccer team, took the lead in the first division of Britain's soccer league today with a 1-0 victory over Manchester City.
The tobacco industry's continued growth and prosperity in 1952 is indicated, according to A. E. Lyon, board chairman of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc.

The formation of two wholly owned subsidiaries of the Dow Chemical Company was announced yesterday in Midland, Mich., by Dr. Mark E. Putnam, executive vice president of the parent company. The two companies, Dow Chemical Inter-American, Ltd., and Dow Chemical International, Ltd., were described by Dr. Putnam as representing a move to extend Dow's international activities.

Although gross revenue of the nation's railroads showed a further rise in 1951, reflecting an increase in the traffic volume in the first half and slightly higher rates, the net was again disappointing and below that of 1950. But the improvement and modernization program continued at an accelerated rate, nearly $1,500,000,000 being spent on road and equipment during the year.

WASHINGTON -- Despite the acceleration of defense production and recognition of the fact that "big business and monopolies are bound to get the bulk of defense orders" the Department of Justice has not relaxed its watchfulness lest the defense effort result in weakening the Government's re-restraints on monopoly.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Ed Modzelewski and Ed Fullerton, both from the Pennsylvania coal country, turned Maryland's Split T into an instrument of destruction today and shattered Tennessee's football empire with an astonishing 28-13 Sugar Bowl victory.

The world shortage of sulphur, which became pronounced as 1951 wore on, will become worse in 1952 as the rearmament program of the nation and its allies gains momentum, Langbourne M. Williams Jr., president of Freeport Sulphur Company, predicts.

The New Year was born in the city with a sign of good portent yesterday. It wore a caul, or kind of veil of fog that gave mysterious outline to holiday-empty skyscrapers, and shrouded the city parks in heavy springlike mist. It came in warm too, for the season, with temperatures in the upper forties.

Coffee futures trading presented a number of imponderables all last year. So many were they and so puzzling that the volume on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchanged dropped away from the figure of 12,244,750 bags for all 1950 to 5,438,750 bags for the first eleven months of 1951.

American ingenuity in adapting to changing conditions was exemplified in 1951 by a high degree of prosperity despite the many difficulties that business had to meet and overcome. But inflation seemingly has been frozen into the nation's economic structure.

When inflation results from deliberate acts of government, as in the carrying out of its fiscal policy, the inflation may be said to be in the category of a tax. And although the taxpayer's loss from depreciation of the dollar is confined to the amount of his net income after tax, the government also loses by reason of the decline in the purchasing power of the dollar.

The New York Board of Title Underwriters, representing four member companies doing a major portion of the realty title insurance business in the New York metropolitan area, yesterday announced a new schedule of rates. The schedule, which has been accepted by the State Superintendent of Insurance, calls for an over-all increase of about 4 per cent over the 1951 rates, the announcement said.
TOKYO, Jan. 1 -- United Nations artillerymen celebrated the New Year today by hurling thousands of shells into enemy strongholds and crushing any possibility of a Chinese Communist attack.

BOSTON -- New England, a region with two distinct economies, ended 1951 with a definite depression in the soft goods fields and strong activity in durables. Observers profess to see signs, however, of a soft goods upswing that will bring the two facets of the economic picture more in balance for 1952.
The Korean war accelerated industrial developments in end-uses of chemicals in 1951 and made the year more outstanding in application of chemistry to industry than in new discoveries or inventions.

Although many manufacturers, retailers and wholesalers found themselves hard-pressed to meet their obligations on the due date, the failures and credit picture in 1951 on the whole was more favorable than in 1950.

DES MOINES, Iowa -- The United States, still faced with an increasing world-wide demand for food and agricultural raw materials, had record farm crops in 1951, but trouble spots developed that could cause serious concern this year.

United States Rubber Company is arranging to borrow privately $50,000,000 on a sinking fund loan due on Jan. 1, 1982. The loan, which will have an average life of a little more than twenty-four years unless certain prepayment provisions are exercised, will bear interest of 3 3/4 per cent for all money drawn down and a standby commitment fee for funds not borrowed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Big atomic and defense plant expansions helped boost total building expenditures in the nation to nearly $30,000,000,000 in 1951, the Government disclosed in a year-end report today.

Cautious buying by retailers will force production, sales and profits in the men's clothing industry for the first half of 1952 to lag behind the figures of the first six months of 1951, manufacturers said in year-end predictions. While inventories have been reduced through cuts in output and by retailers' sales, the comparison with the boom buying of 1951 will be necessarily unfavorable.

John E. Carton, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, asserted yesterday that Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., represented only three of the 19,300 members of the force.
The United States was moving rapidly as 1952 began to the position of military strength that is the goal of all its post-Korean defense policies.

The radio and television industry enters 1952 with its greatest peak production capacity, according to Frank M. Folsom, president of the Radio Corporation of America. He said record productive capacity will be used in an all-out attempt to meet increasing demand for defense output and domestic production and service of radios, television receivers and other civilian electronic items.
WASHINGTON -- Two factors operated to minimize the United States over-all manpower problem last year.

MINNEAPOLIS -- The great agricultural region embraced by the Ninth Federal Reserve District weathered the economic ups and downs of 1951 "as soundly as could be expected" and looked ahead to some improvement of position in 1952, business analysts agreed.

Perhaps the most startling result of the U-turn taken by wool prices in the last eighteen months has been the growth of the futures market maintained by the Wool Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange. For the six months preceding the outbreak of the Korean war, average monthly volume in grease wool futures was 3,159,000 pounds. For the six months to Nov. 30 it was 23,027,000 pounds.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan 1 -- Two savage year-end local attacks by Vietminh forces were repulsed by French and Vietnamese troops along the Tongking delta perimeter, French communiques reported here today. Two hundred fifty Vietminh bodies were counted, it was reported.

Carloadings of the thirty-two principal commodity groups in the first quarter of 1952 are expected to be 2.2 per cent above those in the similar period last year, according to a compilation by the thirteen regional Shippers Advisory Boards.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- For the first time in his nine-year Administration, Governor Dewey will recommend flatly to the Legislature next week that the state's sixty-five-year-old ban on the sale of butter-colored oleomargarine be repealed.

Cotton, the nation's second most important farm crop, had a spectacular year. The price touched the highest level since the Civil War in the winter and a ceiling was imposed by the Government for the first time in history of the domestic cotton industry.

Sales of electrical appliances, machinery and equipment this year will be slightly below the sales peak of $12,000,000,000 reached in 1951. This is the prediction of W. J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, and A. J. Nesti, its chief statistician.

For the Chrysler Corporation, l and the automobile industry in general, 1952 poses a continuation of the adjustments to a defense economy that prevailed during 1951, L. L. Colbert, president, announced in a year-end statement.
Following is the report submitted to Governor Dewey by the Long Island Transit Authority:

PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) -- United States mills cut more lumber in 1951 than they could sell, which represented a change, and plywood ran into trouble. It was a money-making year, though, for most of the industry.

DETROIT -- A year of labor peace, marred only by disputes in supplier plants and occasional wildcat walkouts, was the auto industry's reward in 1951 for its investment in long-term escalator agreements with the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O.

The Long Island Transit Authority reported to Governor Dewey yesterday that under existing law the only workable solution for the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road's difficulties lay in authority ownership with operation by a private corporation.

Although the construction industry operated in one of the most confused years in United States economic history last year, it reached a new high in dollar volume, according to Harold R. Berlin, vice president of the Johns-Manville Corporation and general manager of the building products division.

Last year 163,003 babies were born here. The five boroughs recorded more births than in any other year in the city's history except 1947, when a record high of 171,174 was set. There were 155,818 new-born listed in 1950.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 1 -- Successful conclusion of Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck's negotiations with New York bankers for a $15,000,000 loan made an excellent impression in financial circles here. The fact that the conditions are about equal to those granted on the loan to Belgium confirms the view that Holland's recent monetary recovery made a good impression in American quarters.

Arthur Krock's interesting articles on corruption in Government, both federal and local, raise the question for each of us: What can we do about it? Is it not time that we frankly faced the fact that as matters now stand the expenses of our elections are largely borne by individuals who have either received or hope to receive favors at the hands of the Government?
WASHINGTON -- For the first time since 1948 the Federal Government wound up a fiscal year last June 30 with a surplus, but this promised to be the briefest sort of respite from deficit financing.

Spurred by abnormal demand for its products, the result of increased industrial activity, the defense effort and the interruption of Iranian operations, the petroleum industry in 1951 attained new peaks in virtually every division. Despite increased income tax rates, the earnings of the industry also were at a new high level.

On figures thus far available, the brewers are happier over last year and more cheerful about this year than either the distillers or the vintners. They worry about taxes and packaging, but less than the others.

A recovery in appliance sales will occur this spring, according to W. A. Blees, vice president of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation and general sales manager of its Crosley division. He emphasized that this prediction was an "educated" guess.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Steve Kraftcheck set the scoring pace with a pair of goals tonight as the New York Rangers started the new year right by breaking a five-year jinx to beat the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 2, before 6,301 Boston Garden fans.
