ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Michigan's improving basketball team routed Princeton, 62 to 44, before 400 fans tonight to hand the Easterners their third straight loss at the hands of Big Ten quintets.

The appointment of Irving K. Peck as vice president of Columbia Gas System Service Corporation was announced yesterday by Stuart M. Crocker, chairman. Mr. Peck, who has been vice president and general manager of the Pittsburgh group companies of the Columbia Gas System, Inc. since 1946, will have the added responsibility of procuring natural gas from the Southwest.

WASHINGTON -- Conceived three years ago, and in operation about half that time, the Point Four program of assistance to underdeveloped areas was making at the end of last year what its directors regarded as "good progress."

Commercial banks increased capitalization by more than $120,000,000 in 1951, thereby improving ratios of capital funds to deposits and risk assets. The money was raised by new issues of capital stock sold to bank stockholders.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The campaign to collect a cash wedding present for Frank Sedgman, Australian Davis Cup star, and his fiancee moved at a merry clip today as Herbert V. Evatt, former United Nations president, added to the contributions which already total approximately $4,200.

WASHINGTON -- Cutbacks in civilian production, especially in durable goods, will reduce the output of autos, refrigerators, television sets, radios and such items by at least 50 per cent in 1952, according to calculations of defense production officials here.

BOSTON. Latest employment figures for New England showed 3,456,000 jobs filled, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, a decline of 16,500 from 1950 levels. As an indication of the region's economic strength, however, the bureau reported that jobs in the durable goods fields were 53,500 above the 1950 levels, offset by a decline of 70,000 jobs in soft goods.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- A Gold Star mother, classified 1-A by a draft board, asserted today that she was ready to go into military service if the Government continued its efforts to draft her.
Productivity and prosperity may continue to boom -- but profits after taxes are bound to be pruned!

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 1 -- Hector Prudhomme and Torkild Rieber, the representatives of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, who arrived here yesterday, asked Premier Mohammed Mossadegh today if he wanted the bank to make an effort to reach a temporary solution of the Iranian oil crisis, and Dr. Mossadegh answered that he welcomed the bank's effort and hoped it would be successful.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Army said today it surely was all right for soldiers to wear suspenders to hold up their pants. It just required that the suspenders be covered with a jacket.

SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Frank Sedgman's "bride fund" reached u2,109 ($5,905) today amid indications that the gift would have no effect on the amateur tennis standing of Australia's Davis Cup star.

BRUSSELS, Belgium -- A fierce controversy rages in Belgium over the Schuman plan. Pooling the coal and steel production of Italy, France, West Germany, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands endangers Belgium's economic security, the mine owners argue.

RENO, Nev., Jan. 2 (UP) -- United States Senator Pat McCarran left St. Mary's Hospital today and was pronounced fully recovered from a heart attack which he suffered two months ago. The senator said he planned to drive to Death Valley tomorrow to spend ten days basking in the sun. He hopes to return to Washington for the new session of Congress about Jan. 21.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The man who was private secretary to Jan Masaryk at the time of the Czechoslovak Foreign Minister's death in March, 1948 provided new material today in the controversy whether it was suicide or assassination.
Prices of cotton on the New York Cotton Exchange were easier yesterday. The close was unchanged to 31 points lower than on Monday on active months.

VIENNA -- Austria enjoyed a boom year in 1951. With production maintained, there was full employment, and exports, especially of such essential raw materials as paper, lumber and magnesite, held up until the last quarter.

NEW DELHI, India -- India's industrial production and foreign trade registered a marked improvement in 1951 over the previous year. Official figures available for the first six months indicate that forty major industries recorded an upward trend in production ranging from 10 to 15 per cent.

Maxim Litvinov did many notable things in his life, but nothing in his long career was so extraordinary as that he should have died peacefully and naturally in bed at the age of 75. Almost all his associates of the Bolshevik revolutionary days came to a violent end -- Trotsky by assassination, Tomsky by suicide, Bukharin, Radek, Zinoviev, Kamenev, Rykov, and so many, many others by imprisonment, exile to Siberia and execution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The automobile industry has been cut back far less in allocation of materials than any other consumer durable goods industry, Henry H. Fowler, deputy head of the National Production Authority, asserted today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- The Rev. Martin Niemoeller was greeted at Moscow's windswept airport today by Archbishop Macary on behalf of Patriarch Alexei of Moscow and all the Russians at whose invitation the German churchman was arriving here for a week's visit -- his first to the Soviet Union.
ZURICH, Switzerland -- In 1951, the Swiss tourist business showed a substantial increase.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Evidence forcibly extracted from the stomach of a prisoner may not be used validly to convict him of a crime, the Supreme Court ruled today. Such procedure, it held, violates the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
Exeter and St. Mark's renewed their hockey rivalry yesterday in a game at Madison Square Garden and the contest ended in a 2-to-2 tie, with a live-minute overtime scoreless session.

The New York Zoological Society has provided a fund of $5,000 to set up its own "Point Four" program to aid Europeans working in the biological sciences, Fairfield Osborn, president, announced last night. He spoke at the fifty-sixth annual meeting of the society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
VIENNA -- Poland's chief customer and supplier, according to official statements, is now the Soviet Union.
The heads of all city departments and agencies have been warned that their budget requests for the fiscal year beginning July 1 must not exceed their appropriations for the current fiscal period.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 81 more battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 17 dead, 49 wounded, six missing in action, one prisoner of war and eight injured. It also listed 14 killed who were previously reported missing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The average taxpayer hardly Will notice any difference in his dealings with the Internal Revenue Bureau under President man's proposal today for reorganization of the tax service.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- Industrial production has risen during the first half of 1951, but has subsequently decreased somewhat. The index of average daily production in industry (1938 equals 100) was 145 in October against the high mark of 157 in March and 139 for 1950.

VIENNA -- Poland, like Czechoslovakia and Hungary, was required, to enlarge the aims of her original Six-Year Plan, 1950-1955, from a 90 per cent over-all increase in industrial production to 158 per cent. The Poles achieved disappointing results in the third quarter of last year, the last period for which official statistics are available.
VIENNA -- Czechoslovakia, the most important Soviet satellite industrially, ended 1951 far behind the goals she had set herself in her stepped up Five-Year Plan.

TRENTON, Jan. 2 -- An optimistic prediction that New Jersey can be carried by Democratic candidates next November, providing the organization went to work, was made today by David T. Wilentz, president of the National Democratic Club of New Jersey, and Representative Edward J. Hart, Democratic state chairman.

Operations of the United States Trust Company of New York in 1951 were the most satisfactory in the bank's ninety-eight years of business, Benjamin Strong, president, reported to stockholders yesterday. Gross income last year, he said, amounted to $6,478,654, the highest ever recorded by the bank, but Federal income taxes took $12.78 a share, compared with $9.34 a share in 1950.

Thousands of aliens flocked to registration points here yesterday as the nation's second annual registration of foreigners got under way as called for under the Internal Security Act of 1950. All are required to file report cards by Jan. 11.
Roosters hurled challenges through wire cages, and cackles came from hundreds of hens. Rabbits, peaceful and relaxed, gazed on with magnificent unconcern.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Army said today it would like to get from relatives of United States prisoners of war any information they had reflecting efforts by the Reds to communize their captives.
OSLO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Five United States speed skaters, their manager and coach arrived in Oslo tonight to train for the Olympic Winter Games.
PUSAN, Korea -- After eighteen months of a pulverizing war, the Republic of South Korea faces a new year of more of the same grim rigors, but with some surprisingly healthy upsurges in its economy.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 2 -- An Air Force ground party, clambering over precarious ice-sheathed cliffs atop 7,000-foot Armer Mountain, reached the wreck of the Air Force C-47 transport that disappeared Sunday, and began bringing down the bodies of the twenty-eight victims.

More diamonds will be purchased during 1952 on a charge of installment basis than in any previous year, according to Alexander E. Arnstein, senior partner of Arnstein Brothers Co., diamond cutters and importers.

TOKYO -- Japanese industrial recovery took a spurt upwards in 1951, but the still shaky national economy faced a set of new and difficult problems based on the peace treaty and the end of United States Defense Department aid.

SAIGON, Indo-China -- The Indo- Chinese economy during 1951 continued to function under abnormal war conditions. Production and Government incomes in the three associated states of Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos showed some recovery, but were still far below pre-war levels, and economic life in general was sustained by heavy French and United States support in the form of economic and military aid.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The political New Year got off to an early and lively start at the White House today with a sharp dispute whether President Truman had told an Ohio Democrat that he hoped to disclose by Feb. 6 if he would be a candidate for re-election.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Recent suggestions for a settlement of the treaty dispute between Britain and Egypt, suggestions coming from Washington and Baghdad, have met with a cool reception in London.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- State Department officials reacted with surprise today to reports that the United States and Spain were on the verge of opening negotiations for an economic aid agreement. Paul A. Porter, acting Mutual Security Agency Administrator for Europe, had been quoted to this effect in Madrid dispatches.

The world's largest operating utility, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., is planning to spend $105,000,000 for plant expansion and improvements to existing facilities this year. This will bring total expenditures of this nature since 1947 to about $530,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Safeway Stores, Inc., a food chain organization, lost in the Supreme Court today its fight to compel the Office of Price Stabilization to permit it to charge higher prices on many food items. It was the first challenge before the high court of price regulations promulgated under the Defense Production Act.

RANGOON, Burma -- Guerrilla activities in various parts of the country by Communist bands and minority racial groups kept Burma in a state of unrest and instability during 1951 and prevented any substantial improvement in the country's economy.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- South Africa's expanding gold output will play a prominent part in the British Commonwealth's talks on the dollar-sterling problem in London on Jan. 15. Finance Minister N. C. Havenga will attend the conference, despite the opening of the South African Parliament at this time.

DUBLIN -- At the end of 1951 the Republic of Ireland faced these three economic difficulties: a fiscal deficit of several million pounds, an adverse balance of payments between 60,000,000 and 70,000,000 and the end of Marshall Plan aid.
Twelve hundred employes of fifty wholesale grocery concerns went on strike yesterday morning, but the walkout caused no discernible hardship to retail outlets of consumers.

August Horrmann, president of Rubsam Horrmann Brewery, Staten Island, contributed his customary $1,000 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to bring the day's gifts to $3,512.43 and the total for the fortieth annual campaign to $297,606.66.

TRENTON, Jan. 2 -- About 400 mentally retarded children have received aid in adjusting to their home environment since the start eight years ago on a home training program for such children by the New Jersey Department of Institutions and Agencies, Dr. Lloyd N. Yepsen, director of the department's Division of Classification and Education, reported today.
NEW DELHI, India -- The largest share of foreign technical assistance received by India in 1951 under the various international projects came from the United States.

MANILA -- The Minimum Wage Law in the Philippines, one of the fundamentals of the reconstruction program fostered with United States Government assistance, is not succeeding. United States administrators in the Economic Cooperation Administration find that evasion of the law is prevalent, enforcement machinery is insufficient, and there are too many loopholes in the law itself.
BONN, Germany -- West Germany, potentially one of the strongest economic links in West Europe's chain of defense, is preparing to make an important contribution to Western rearmament.
PARIS -- France's tourist business had another record-breaking year in 1951.

The men's and women's Alpine teams of the United States Olympic ski squad yesterday left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, via Pan American Airlines on the first leg of a campaign that eventually will bring them to Oslo, Norway, for the quadrennial games, Feb. 14-25.

Parents of teen-age boys and girls might be interested in bringing to their attention the following booklet, published recently by Science Research Associates, 57 West Grand Avenue, Chicago 10, at 40 cents a copy.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 2 -- The Israeli Government will break its hitherto firm resolution against establishing contact with any Government representing the German people whom it blames for the extermination of 6,000,000 Jews. Under tacit pressure from Western powers, Israel will make a direct approach shortly to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Boom Government demanding reparations to cover the cost of resettling Jewish refugees from countries once under Nazi control.

ANKARA, Turkey -- Turkey's economy, 80 per cent devoted to agriculture, may best be described as a subsistence type. Her living standard is the lowest in free Europe. Her economic potential, however, is immense.

Adolescent users of narcotics should receive rehabilitation treatment in institutions for periods up to two years when necessary, but with trial visits home at intervals, it is suggested in a report by three psychiatrists of Bellevue Hospital and the New York University School of Medicine.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 2 -- There is evidence of increasing opposition to the more extreme neutralist and somewhat isolationist aspects of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's policies that seems to be modifying the previously decidedly negative outlook for Iranian acceptance of United States military and Point Four aid under the terms of the Mutual Security Act.
PARIS, Jan. 2 -- Maxim Litvinov, whose death two days ago has just been announced by Moscow, had been physically ill and spiritually disappointed for years.

SOUTH SUDBURY, Mass., Jan. 2 -- The Ford Foundation has decided to retain ownership of the Wayside Inn, historic hostelry on the old Boston Post Road to New York, at least temporarily, the resident manager, Arthur Purdy, said today.

United Electric Coal Companies common had the distinction of being the first stock traded on the New York Stock Exchange in 1952. One hundred shares of U. C. C. at 20, unchanged from the end of 1951, was the symbol that first appeared on the stock tape. In 1951 the stock had a range of 19 to 25, closing at 20, off 2 1/2 points for the year.
SINGAPORE -- Despite a Communist guerrilla rebellion, the economy of Malaya in 1951 continued to operate at a high level of productivity and prosperity.

DURHAM, N. C., Jan. 2 (AP) -- A trio of Pennsylvanians, Dick Groat, Rudy D'Emilio and Bernie Janicki, scored 56 points for Duke University's Blue Devils as they defeated the University of Pennsylvania, 62 to 52, in a basketball game tonight.

WELLINGTON, N. Z. -- For New Zealand 1951 was a year of unusual prosperity. Returns from primary industries, particularly from wool growers, were at record levels. The consequent increase in sterling funds held in London made it possible for the Government to relax import restrictions, which were a feature of the previous (Labor) Government's economic policy.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein advised the State Controller's Office today to withhold pension payments from John H. Wells, retired City Judge of Ogdensburg, against whom removal proceedings are pending.

LONDON -- Estimates of the requirements of the British military services rose sharply during 1951, although the new Churchill Government expressed doubts that the figures set by its predecessor could be met.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President Truman will send his private plane, the Independence, to New York Saturday morning if it is needed to bring Prime Minister Churchill of Britain here in time for luncheon Saturday noon.
Bobby Dykes, 151, San Antonio, Tex., scored a unanimous decision over Raoul Perez, 145, Havana, Cuba, in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena, last night.
Homemakers faced with repairing holiday damage to their floors and upholstered furniture might find use for two new products and some bits of advice.

Camilo Leyra Jr., 51 years old, who was convicted last month for the second time in the slaying of his aged parents, was sentenced twice yesterday -- to die in the electric chair in the week of Feb. 3 and to serve a prison term of seventy-five years to life.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands -- The Netherlands has weathered the economic storms of 1951, including a buffeting from an almost doubled defense budget and a deterioration in terms of trade, and is facing the New Year with moderate optimism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Charles E. Davis filed a $100,000 damage suit against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today. He complained that the Wisconsin Republican stopped his salary when he was arrested in Switzerland for spying on United States diplomats.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Temperatures along the war front lifted from the zero range that had prevailed for ten days to about 25 degrees last night, as Allied and Communist patrols exchanged fire in several minor clashes.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Korea -- Korea's vast housing program is well under way and it is likely that about 10,000 homes will be ready for occupation early in 1952. These homes are part of a program supervised by the United Nations Civil Assistance Command, Korea, which hopes to make 400,000 war-ravaged homes habitable as part of the rehabilitation program.
ROME -- A great increase in housebuilding activities began in 1950, and a further notable increase occurred in 1951.

VIENNA -- Czechoslovakia's foreign trade with the West declined last year to an unreported but certainly substantial degree. Even had the Western countries been ready to deal with her as readily as a decade ago, this would have been rendered impossible by her switch from consumer to heavy industrial goods and by Moscow's insistence on a virtual monopoly of her foreign trade.

JAKARTA, Indonesia -- During 1951 Indonesia shared in the general prosperity that came to Southeast Asian countries, producing rubber, tin, copra, oil and other primary products in big demand among world nations engaged in rearming and stockpiling.

ROME -- United States aid to Italy, as with aid to the West generally, entered its third post-war phase during 1950-51. Immediately after the end of World War II, relief was the main objective. Relief gave way to reconstruction when the Marshall Plan went into effect in 1948.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- South Africa's industrial color bar, based on the doctrine of apartheid (separation of the races), is cracking under economic pressure. The main causes are the vast expansion of industries during 1950 and 1951 and the Malan Government's restriction on immigration from Europe.

TOKYO -- The free-spending American G. I. and the wives and children of occupation personnel -- inveterate souvenir hunters -- were perhaps Japan's biggest foreign investors in 1951. While staid banking houses, manufacturers and industrialists put $6,000,000 in private capital into Japan, the soldier and his dependents were spending more than half that amount a month on silk, lacquer ware, jewelry, ivory and nicknacks through Army Post Exchanges alone.

PARIS -- The French merchant fleet made important progress in 1951. The number of units and over-all tonnage were increased. As a result, the drain on the country's foreign currency holdings, through payment to other nations for sea transport were reduced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Department of Justice confirmed today the resignation of Howard G. Campbell, veteran Government attorney who returned to the Department last summer after his Washington law firm, active in defending tax cases, had been dissolved.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The impression is being created here by responsible British journalists in Washington that the welcome mat definitely is not out for Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden at Blair House or the State Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration has ordered tighter safety inspections of C-46 Curtiss transports, it became known today, as inquiries continued into two recent crashes involving the planes built during World War II.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman ran away with an Associated Press poll of New York State Democratic County chairmen to determine their preferences for the party's Presidential nomination.
Two factors of our national life are receiving a great deal of separate attention: the 1952 Presidential race and the national armament program.
VIENNA -- Rumania began her first Five-Year Plan last year, with 42 per cent of her budget earmarked for coal, oil, iron and electrification.
MUNSAN, Korea, Thursday, Jan. 3 -- The Communists today flatly rejected an Allied proposal for an exchange of prisoners of war and civilians.

Nationalization and shutdown of oil operations in Iran were among the outstanding developments affecting international petroleum operations last year. Through the cooperation of the industry in almost every non-communistic country, the loss of the 700,000-barrel daily production in Iran was offset by increased production elsewhere and the defense program of the "free world" proceeded virtually undisturbed.

We are delighted to see that Governor Dewey will lead the fight at the coming session of the Legislature for repeal of the ancient ban against sale of colored margarine in New York State. New York and Vermont are the only Eastern States that retain this prohibition. Wisconsin, Minnesota, Iowa, South Dakota, Montana and Washington State are the others in this select company of eight states still in thrall to the dairy lobby.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- Maxim Litvinov, former Commissar for Foreign Affairs, was buried today in a quiet corner of Novo-Dyevitchi Cemetery, whose ancient convent walls overlook the ice-choked Moskva River.

BRUSSELS, Belgium -- Helped by the liberalized trade program of West European countries and by the defense efforts of the Western world generally, Belgium's trade and industry expanded in 1951. But the picture was clouded by the fact that a large part of the exports was on credit.

Kenneth Lamott, who left Yale during the war to join the Navy, served as a lieutenant interrogating Japanese prisoners of war. One incident during his Navy life serves as the basis of his first novel that Little, Brown has set tentatively for June 3 publication.
LONDON -- Amid all the uncertainties of the economic situation in Britain in 1951 there was one certainty -- that taxes would be high.

Total resources and deposits of the National City Bank of New York as of last Monday were at the highest levels ever recorded by the bank, it was announced yesterday. At the close of 1951 the quarterly statement of condition showed, resources amounted to $5,909,863,665, compared with $5,556,379,159 on Sept. 30, 1951, and $5,526,348,028 on Dec. 31, 1950.

Snow, sleet and ice storms that blanketed the West and the Midwest over the New Year holiday crept toward the Atlantic seaboard last night. Official forecasters thought that the effect in the metropolitan area today would be a sharp temperature drop from spring-like readings to near freezing.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- World production of basic raw materials continued on the upswing during 1951, according to United Nations statisticians. In steel output, in fact, figures for the first ten months indicate that 1951 will be a record year. In the United States these estimates -- compared with a similar period in 1950 -- show production was 9 per cent higher.

Business will remember the lesson learned in 1951 and keep a better balance of inventories this year, according to Theodore H. Silbert, president of Standard Factors Corporation and the Association of Commercial Discount Companies, Inc. Factoring companies, he said in a year-end statement, will not aid or abet the stock-piling of civilian goods or encourage hoarding and speculating manipulations.
BRUSSELS, Belgium -- Belgian hotels reported that business in 1951 was 30 per cent better than the year before, with foreign tour-lists contributing largely to the increase.
The March of Dimes campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis got under way yesterday as 2,938 local chapters staged opening ceremonies in parks and town squares over the nation.

TEHERAN -- The year 1951 would have been an auspicious one for Iran if it had not been for Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's oil nationalization drive, which brought the national economy to the brink of bankruptcy.

BERLIN, Jan. 2 -- Persons in a position to obtain reliable information expect the Russians to start releasing a large number of Germans they have held in the Soviet Union for various reasons since the end of World War II.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 3 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,118, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Thursday (4 P. M. Wednesday, Eastern standard time):
LONDON -- Reduced allotments of steel have cut down British motor vehicle production from 785,200 cars and trucks in 1950 to an estimated 730,000 for 1951.

CAIRO -- Egypt went through the year 1951 with no important disturbances to business. Unemployment increased somewhat, and the cost-of-living index rose from 286 in September, 1950, to 320 in September, 1951, with the summer of 1939 as 100.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Trading on the Midwest Stock Exchange fell off somewhat last year compared with 1950 both in share volume and dollar value.

TOKYO -- When the Korean war began, a year and a half ago, there was a crying need here for facilities to expedite foreign exchange. As more and more troops came pouring into the country, the problem of dealing with multiple forms of legal tender became complex.

With few exceptions, major appliances for the kitchen -- refrigerators, ranges, dishwashers and freezers -- now are readily available. This encouraging account of the supply situation, based on inquiries to several leading manufacturers, comes despite Government-imposed curtailments on raw materials that in some cases cut back production last year by as much as 50 per cent.

LISBON, Portugal -- How the example of the Tennessee Valley Authority may be applied to the River Douro, north of Portugal, is being investigated by United States experts who arrivel from New York recently.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Charles Cohen's Crafty Admiral, a 4-1 shot, drove to an impressive triumph in the sprint feature of Tropical Park today.

New York University and Seton Hall will risk their unbeaten basketball records against formidable visiting quintets at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Violets, aiming for their thirteenth straight victory, will oppose West Virginia at 7:45 P. M. The Pirates, seeking their ninth straight success, will meet Western Kentucky in the second contest.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 2 -- President Juan D. Peron has begun the new year with a concilatory gesture to the Socialist party, his foremost opposition in the labor ranks, by releasing five of the party's top leaders, who have been imprisoned since last Sept. 29.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France -- Quietly but effectively, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has built up in Western Europe in the last twelve months an Allied force of more than twenty combat-ready divisions, matching roughly the twenty-six small divisions the Russians are reported to have in East Germany and Poland.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 2 -- A fugitive rhesus monkey, roaming the bilges and engine room of the American President Line's freighter President Arthur, is under a sentence of death if it isn't captured within the next twenty-four hours.

The Federal Government, starting March 1, will "relieve" the Long Island Rail Road of the financial burden of carrying parcel post by operating its own fleet of leased trucks on eighteen routes, it was announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Mrs. Joe Willie Riley of Chicago, a Gold Star mother and prospective draftee, was reclassified "strictly 4-F" by the State Selective Service board today.

A continuation of the post-war recovery in most countries last year brought consumption of raw cotton throughout the world to a new peak. The heavy demand, resulting in part from the West's preparedness program, pushed cotton prices to the highest level in modern history.

For several years we have been fed a steady diet in the news concerning the laments emitted by leading citizens over the woeful shortage of teachers and social workers. A recent "Education in Review" column in your paper reports that the New York State Board of Regents and the Ford Foundation are setting up a few scholarships in the teaching field.

MOSCOW -- The year 1951 undoubtedly was the most successful in the history of the Soviet economy. It was marked by high new levels of production and expansion in heavy industry, favorable crop returns, an abundance of food at somewhat lower prices and a considerable increase in consumer goods and services.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Livestock sold for meat kept Chicago the packing center of the world last year, but by a slimmer margin over Omaha, final figures indicated today.

VIENNA -- Austria's tourist trade for the first nine months of 1951 brought in $21,557,000, almost $6,500,000, or 43 per cent more than for the whole of 1950. Registered overnight stays for foreign tourists in the first nine months of this year were 5,227,686, compared with 4,582,907 for the whole of the preceding year.

OSLO, Norway -- Economic activities in Norway were on a high level last year. Increases in industrial production and favorable trends in foreign trade and shipping combined to improve the Norwegian balance of payments.

ROME -- The revenue from taxation of the Italian Government has shown an upward trend in recent years. Apart from interim aid and European Recovery Program grants, total revenue amounted to 962,000,000,000 lire ($1,540,000,000) in 1948-49, to 1,098,000,000,000lire ($1,757,000,000) in 1949-50 and to 1,250,000,000,000 lire ($2,010,000,000) in 1950-51.

BONN, Germany -- West Germany's spectacular industrial and commercial recovery of 1950 continued apace in 1951. By the end of the year the question arose in many minds whether Germany, in 1952, would again rise to dominate the economy of Europe.
ZURICH, Switzerland -- "Chronic prosperity" might be the correct description of the state of business and finance in Switzerland in 1951.

HONG KONG -- The economy of Communist China was profoundly affected in 1951 by the impact of the Korean war and the Western embargoes that accompanied it. Among the effects were heavier budgetary burdens, higher taxes and special levies, key raw material shortages and the displacement of the West by the Soviet bloc as China's leading foreign trade partner.
LONDON -- Neither the dire consequences predicted by opponents of nationalization nor the high expectations of the nationalizers developed last year.

TOKYO -- If Japan is to recover sufficiently to become once more a self-supporting member of the world family she must rehabilitate her shipping. To replace the enormous amount of shipping tonnage Japan lost in World War II has been a major problem.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- The development of Dutch foreign trade is best characterized by the percentage by which imports are covered by exports: This was 68 per cent for 1950, 67 per cent for the first eight months of 1951, but 98 per cent for September and 101 per cent for October, an all-times high mark.

HONG KONG, Jan. 2 -- Information from authoritative sources here indicates that guerrilla resistance to the Communists in the provinces of China bordering Indo-China has reached a low ebb and would be a factor of no great significance in hampering a possible Chinese Red invasion of Tongking.

PARIS -- Because of the uncertainties regarding United States military aid and the difficulties of the French fiscal and budgetary programs, the Government has removed the defense budget from the civilian budget, and funds for defense will be voted on separately afterward.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 2 (UP) -- On Trust, the greatest money-winning horse still in training, delighted a crowd of 18,000 racing fans at Santa Anita today by getting up in the stretch to win the $7,500 Echo Park Purse by a length.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers, leading by only 2 points at half-time, spurted away from the last-place Milwaukee Hawks to an 89-67 National Basketball Association victory tonight.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands -- Dutch port, shipping and shipbuilding activity expanded considerably in 1951.

TAIPEI, Formosa -- The major economic problem in Nationalist-held Formosa throughout 1951, as in the preceding year, was that of getting the island with a population of about 10,000,000, including many non - productive refugees from the Chinese mainland -- to support armed forces of 550,000 to 600,000.

PARIS -- The material and psychological consequences of rearmament, the reduction of United States economic aid, and the political uncertainty that reigned here until the French Assembly elections on June 17, 1951, have greatly prejudiced the economic and financial recovery achieved before the Korean war.
PARIS -- Not since its organization has the United Nations entered so fully into the development of backward areas as it did in 1951.

KARACHI -- The year 1951 saw the justification of Pakistan's policy of partial independence within the sterling bloc. In spite of dire predictions of financial disaster from England and India, Pakistan did not change the rate of her rupee when the rest of the bloc devaluated in 1949, and financial officials here are unanimous in the assurance that she will not follow suit in any further devaluation on the part of Britain.
Steel output in virtually all of the world's producing countries rose to record levels last year. The general expectation is for further gains in 1952 in the production of it his basic metal.

A booklet showing how $14,000,000,000 in retail sales moves over the countres of 149,099 outlets in the New York market, broken down by types of store for each of eighty kinds of goods, has been issued by the research department of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The Navy transport Gen. M. B. Stewart, one of the victims of last week's North Atlantic storms, arrived here yesterday morning with 1,307 displaced persons. The big ship went through the worst of the storms, but managed to escape with only the loss of a few feet of railing and minor cuts and bruises for sixteen persons aboard, ship's officers said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Senate Preparedness subcommittee was critical today of the Army's practice of sending numbers of recruits, including draftees inducted in the United States, to Hawaii for basic training.

HONG KONG, Dec. 31 -- Notwithstanding tightening embargoes and a general uncomfortable feeling among business men, the value of foreign trade handled by this British commercial entrepot during the first ten months of 1951 exceeded the record money figure for all of 1950.

WASHINGTON -- Continued inflation of costs and prices in major industrial countries, and efforts of governments to deal with it at domestic and international levels, dominated monetary and fiscal activity in the free world last year.

There is "no justification for participation by the United States Government in any form of fixed-price or cartel agreements in rubber," according to John L. Collyer, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company.

ATHENS -- Work on the big Aliveri thermo-electric plant about forty miles north of here on the island of Euboca, is progressing swiftly with United States aid. Workers are completing the installation of a large water tank to supply the project.

There can be little doubt that the Bureau of Internal Revenue has long stood in need of the "sweeping reorganization" which President Truman now proposes. The revelations of the past few months, with their toll of more than 100 resignations, firings or indictments of Bureau personnel, have made this clear.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement today on plans for reorganization of the Internal Revenue Bureau:

ANTWERP, Belgium -- With the completion of the Societe Industrielle Belge des Petroles oil refinery on the banks of the River Scheldt upstream from Antwerp, Belgium took a big step last year toward supplying her oil requirements.

Despite price and material control handicaps, the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation's production and sales for the fiscal year ended with last September compared well with the previous year's record totals, but earnings were sharply reduced.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- The 1952 session of the United Nations General Assembly may be postponed until after the United States Presidential election. The decision will depend in part on whether the Assembly Building in New York will be ready by Sept. 16, when the body is scheduled to open its seventh annual session.

NEW DELHI, India -- India is entering her fifth year of independence with bright hopes for permanent economic stability, barring the always doubtful factors of crop conditions and the ability to finance urgent development projects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Maritime Administration announced today that it did not plan to claim priority for National Shipping Authority ships carrying Economic Cooperation Administration cargoes during the present shortage of skilled seamen.

Straw is providing one of the most novel notes in resortwear fashions. Not only is it used in all manner of beach accessories, bags, millinery and shoes, but also with great effect as applique, embroidery and even as a sheer overlay to veil other fabrics.
BELFAST -- A sharp decline in the last quarter of 1951 has created economic difficulties for Northern Ireland.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden -- In a review of economic developments in Sweden in 1951, the upsurge of inflationary forces stands out as the leading feature. Not since the years following World War I has a similar inflationary trend been experienced by the Swedish people.
VIENNA -- Austria's exports in 1951 increased 33.5 per cent over those of 1950. Her imports were 34 per cent greater.
LONDON -- Britain learned again in 1951 the truth of the adage, "It never rains but it pours."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Brazil is contemplating resuming diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union, broken since October, 1947, a high government official said today.

MADRID -- Spain ended 1951 in better economic condition than she expected earlier in the year, with her farm production 30 per cent higher than the 1950 average, and her industry also showing an upward trend. She was still a long way from the pre-Civil War level of 1936.

Defying all form and probability the New York Rangers struck again with an "impossible" triumph over the Detroit Red Wings Opposing the leaders of the National Hockey League in combat Madison Square Garden last night, Bill Cook's Broadway Blue registered a 1-to-0 shutout to the complete joy of a crowd of 9,385 observers.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 2 (UP) -- A strike of 250 tugboat workers tied up shipping today and curtailed rail shipment of export coal to this largest of the Hampton Roads harbors.

MANILA -- Government figures on 1951 give evidence of some progress in the Philippines toward a stable economy, and a picture of an agricultural nation of limited development reaching toward financial solvency with gradual industrialization.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (UP) -- The Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen, A. F. L., announced today that they had signed an agreement with Armour and Company calling for a 6-cent hourly increase. The increase affects some 10,000 workers in thirteen Armour plants across the nation.

CAIRO, Jan. 2 -- British military authorities in the Suez Canal zone said today that they had rescued one Cypriot and two Greeks arrested by Egyptian police in Ismailia yesterday for "collaboration with the British forces."

EDMONTON, Alberta, Jan. 2 -- CANADIAN PRESS -- A record 108 oil and natural gas discoveries were made in Western Canada in 1951, industry sources reported today. Forty were oil shrikes, sixty-three gas discoveries in new areas.
BONN, Germany -- West German tourist traffic increased by about 50 per Cent in 1951. In such areas as Bavaria and the Rhineland, income from tourists has become a vital part of the economy.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Jan. 2 -- Cpl. Bertram J. Audley, 26-year-old airman who was one of the victims of the Arizona crash, was the son of Mrs. Gertrude Audley and the late Frank Audley of 147 Rutland Avenue here.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 2 -- Several hundred persons thronged the Union County Courthouse here today for the annual organization meeting of the Board of Freeholders, an unusual feature of which was music by a string orchestra and a free buffet luncheon.

ROME -- Italian labor statistics, taking into account only the strikes that last at least one working day, showed a great diminution of strikes in the first eight months of 1951, as compared with the same period of 1950.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, -- The land of dikes, windmills and inflation controls, which believes it offers more for the tourist dollar than any other Western European country except Austria and Spain, was disappointed with the number of American visitors in 1951, but is hoping for better luck next summer.

The Norwegian freighter Topdalsfjord sailed slowly into a Brooklyn berth yesterday with the fantastic story of a three-day battle to repair a disabled rudder while the ship was being buffeted in the hurricane-swept North Atlantic.

BANGKOK, Thailand -- The economy of Thailand was in a prosperous and expanding condition as 1951 ended. Total production and foreign trade will represent an all-time high in value and produce a large favorable balance of payments.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands -- Two years after Indonesian independence, the Netherlands is maintaining a flourishing trade with her materials-rich former colony. This despite an unresolved conflict over West New Guinea, Indonesian agitation for dissolution of the Netherlands-Indonesian Union, and continued terrorism in some parts of the archipelago that has hampered Dutch planters.

BOB RICHARDS sat in the sawdust pit in Madison Square Garden, wisps of sawdust festooning his hair and a huge grin splitting his face. He peered anxiously at the still trembling pole vault cross-piece and that grin grew even wider as the bar finally shuddered to a stop.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Latin-American countries have almost completed a 300 per cent postwar expansion of their merchant fleets and are in a position to cut heavily into the ocean cargo business of other nations, the National Federation of American Shipping said today.
PONTIAC, Mich., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Two youths were jailed on open charges today in the New Year's Eve deaths of Barbara Holloway and Jessie Anastos, teen-age girls.
PARIS -- France's trade, which up to the last quarter of 1950 had been steadily improving, increased its deficit throughout 1951, owing largely to rearmament and the effects of the Korean War.

PARIS -- Western European integration, preached incessantly by United States officials for three years as a means of increasing production by reducing or eliminating national trade barriers, gathered notable momentum in spite of great obstacles in 1951.

LONDON -- Britain entered the new year with a new Government facing the same old problem of how to make ends meet. Britain was paying more for what she bought and getting less for what she sold. The already overstretched economy was groaning under the added burden of a heavy rearmament program.

Debt. There is an evil word. Debt: "That which is due from one person to another." Debt. There is a word so evil and sly that its pronunciation does not even follow its spelling. It is a stiletto type of word, a knife which plunges into the back during darkness, in the silence of one letter.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- A demand that action be taken to prevent the sale of United States comic books, "these pernicious and degrading publications," was made today by a group of British school teachers.

BERLIN, Jan. 2 -- Communist East Germany opened its 1952 campaign for unification tonight by starting a drive to reconstruct East Berlin and announcing the completion of a draft law for "free" and "secret" elections for an all-German national assembly.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark -- The Danish economy remained last year under the influence of unfavorable international price trends. The prices for the bulk of Danish extorts were frozen at a comparatively low level, while import prices have continued to rise.
Martin F. Shea has been appointed vice president in charge of car radio manufacturing sales in the auto-radio division and head of the Detroit operations for Philco Corporation, Philadelphia.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- South Africa will buy less abroad in 1952, especially from the United States, than in 1951 when she imported at the record rate of 470,000,000 a year for the first eight months. This Korea-caused rush to stockpile reduced her gold and foreign exchange holdings from 172,000,000 in March, 1951, to a low point of 44,000,000 at the end of September, 1951, after which there was a steady but probably temporary improvement.

Reinvestment demand failed to develop yesterday in the stock market as it began a new year, while the pace of business was the slowest in several weeks. Scattered buying saved the session from being exclusively a mechanical operation and, although stocks showing gains were well in the majority, the composite rate slipped 0.61 point because of declines in two of the units included in the industrial component of THE NEW YORK TIMES index.

Many of us will rejoice at the Presidential appointment of George Kennan as United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union on the quite solid grounds that he is a person by virtue of experience and intellectual ability admirably qualified to deal at close quarters with the Moscow regime.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 3 -- Ground contact was almost nil along the 145-mile Korean front by daylight yesterday. Activity increased slightly over night.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- The Rev. Michael Scott, whose activities in the United Nations on behalf of South-West African tribes recently led to the withdrawal by representatives of the Union of South Africa from plenary meetings of the United Nations General Assembly, today charged that the South African Government in recent months had adopted a public "program of expansion."

The high rate of personal savings and the fact that the recent shift in the production of goods has been accompanied by a like shift in demand are factors keeping the nation's economy in "precarious state of balance," the National City Bank declares in its monthly letter on business and financial conditions.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- Estimates of the Enterprise's value, including her cargo, ranged here from 750,000 ($2,100,000) to 1,000,000 ($2,800,000). Lloyd's had underwritten the ship for 500,000 ($1,400,000).
PARIS -- Full employment and wage agitation characterized the labor situation in France in 1951.

By utilizing a semi-freeze for the last two minutes of play, the St. Francis Terriers won their sixth straight basketball game, 69 -- 60, at the expense of the Greyhounds of Loyola (Baltimore) last night.

MADRID -- The year 1951 was a boom tourist year for Spain. Incomplete figures released by the Government Tourist Bureau estimated the number of foreign visitors at 1,200,000, as compared with 750,000 in 1950.

It is encouraging to note a Bureau of Labor Statistics report for the first ten months of 1951 showing a loss of approximately 20,000,000 man - days due to strikes as compared with 35,900,000 for the same period in 1950. Such a comparison, however, may be somewhat unrealistic because 1951 ushered in a period of controls and creation of a Wage Stabilization Board to handle labor-management disputes.
PARIS -- Political tremors shook France's colonies and associated states in 1951, but produced no discernible effect on trade relations within the French Union.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Two suits asking $1,800,000 in damages were filed in Federal District Court today against Compania Cubana, Inc., Pan American World Airways, Inc., and the United States Government.

The chief of the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe's mission in Yugoslavia believes that Premier Marshal Tito is about to promulgate to his countrymen "the line that true socialism exists in the United States."

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Renewed weakness in British Government securities and further strong buying of shipping shares were the main features of the stock markets here today. British funds closed at their lowest, with losses in undated loans ranging up to 10s.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Grain futures all showed strength in the early trade today, but offerings increased moderately and buyers backed away from the selling, with prices sagging in the absence of any aggressive support.

Medium-priced parking for some of the thousands of baseball fans who drive to games in the summer will be provided by the New York Yankees if the city approves a parking-lot application that was laid before the City Planning Commission at its meeting yesterday.

ROME -- After the severe drought of 1949, the production of electric power moved forward in 1950, reaching an all-time high of more than 24,000,000,000 kilowatt hours, and an even higher level in 1951, by thee end of which it was expected to exceed 28,000,000,000 kilowatt hours.

ROME -- Italian exports, as expressed in dollars, showed a greater increase in the first nine months of 1951 than in the same period of 1950. Imports, however, increased even more rapidly, with the result that the trade deficit was larger. The figures, adjusted to allow for the fluctuations in the value of the dollar, are given in the following table:

LISBON, Portugal -- The trade position in Portugal during 1951 showed an improvement over the previous year. This was attributed principally to liberalization of trade and to the effect of the European Payments Union.
Charles S. Zarka, 34 years old, of 1574 Second Avenue, went on a toilet goods buying spree last night for the sake of law and order. His action aided in the capture of two hold-up suspects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Wage Stabilization Board completed assembling a special panel today to hear the wage dispute between the basic steel industry and the steel union. Hearings will begin in Washington next Monday.

Now that the one-millionth traffic victim is dead this driver would like to say that he considers the primary reason for accidents to be the utter ruthlessness, recklessness and lack of courtesy of many drivers on the road. If these people display manners privately as they do when behind a wheel it can be no pleasure to meet them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- John W. Gibson, chairman of the Displaced Persons Commission, today personally reported to President Truman that the commission had closed its main operation, resettling persons from International Refugee Organization camps, on Dec. 31, when all 336,000 visas authorized by Congress actually had been assigned to individuals.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores in December, 1951, showed an aggregate decline of 5.5 per cent, from the volume in the same month of 1950, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. November sales last year were 3.5 per cent over the 1950 level.

Svetozar Gligoric, Yugoslav representative in the international tournament at the Christmas Chess Congress in Hastings, yesterday retained first place by winning from G. Abrahams of England in the sixth round, according to a report from London.

Uday Shankar and Amala and their "Indian ballet of dancers and musicians" presented a second program at the Anta Playhouse last night, holding over only three numbers from their previous schedule and adding six new ones. It was again an engaging evening.

PARIS -- French industrial production in 1951 was higher than in 1950. For the period to Oct. 1, official indexes showed an increase of 8.3 per cent over the first three quarters of the preceding year. French production of coal, iron ore, steel, electricity and automobiles all showed increases.
The Citizens Budget Commission urged yesterday that the state government insist on economies in city administration before granting the city more state funds or more taxing powers.
VAN NUYS, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) -- A father and daughter killed in a plane crash last Sunday died in a strange suicide plan, the police said today after finding a note addressed to his widow.

TOKYO -- Costs of living rose sharply in Japan in 1951. Orders for goods and services to support the United Nations Korean war effort made a continued impact on the domestic economy and there was a corresponding increase in wage levels.

GENEVA -- Europe began in 1951 in a mood of grave apprehension about its economic future, worried about inflation, worried about its precarious and hardly won recovery and uncertain about United States foreign economic policy. By the end of the year this apprehension seemed, on the whole, to have been justified.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- Governor Dewey ruled out the possibility of any cut in state taxes, at a four-hour conference this afternoon with leaders in the Legislature, political advisers and key figures in the State Administration.

" Pal Joey," the musical play with music by Richard Rodgers, lyrics by the late Lorenz Hart and book by John O'Hara, returns to Broadway tonight at the Broadhurst Theatre. Vivienne Segal and Harold Lang are co-starred in it. The supporting cast features Lionel Stander, Helen Gallagher, Pat Northrup, Elaine Stritch, Helen Wood, Jack Waldron and Robert Fortier.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer reserved decision yesterday on a motion to test the constitutionality of the new local law requiring members of the Police Department to retire at the age of 63. The law went into effect at 12:01 A. M. Tuesday.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 2 -- The garrison flag, which flies atop Trophy Point at the United States Military Academy, was lowered to half staff this afternoon when word was received here officially of the death of the nineteen cadets in the crash of an Air Force C-47 in Arizona.

" When Worlds Collide," a new science-fiction drama fror Paramount, has been scheduled as the next offering at the Mayfair Theatre, following the current run of "Detective Story." Adapted from the novel by Philip Wylie and Edwin Balmer, the Technicolor film was produced by George Pal and directed by Rudy Mate.

A 70-year-old woman was burned to death in a fire that swept through her four-room apartment in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn at 7 o'clock last night. Her 72-year-old husband was overcome by smoke poisoning and was taken to Kings County Hospital in critical condition.

The city's 50,000th inductee to enter the Army through Selective Service since the start of the Korean action was sworn in yesterday at 20 Whitehall Street. He was 20-year-old James J. Seiter, eldest of the four sons of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Seiter of 31-33 Forty-seventh Street, Astoria, Queens.

LONG before the .30 '06 reached its peak of popularity and more than a generation in advance of the ultra-modern .270, the old reliable "thutty-thutty" was knocking down its quota of big game from the Adirondacks to the Rockies, and this rifle cannot be ignored in a big game caliber poll even today.

John J. Shipherd has been elected president and a director of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Coal Company, it was announced yesterday. Formerly vice president and general sales manager, Mr. Shipherd succeeds the late Edward Griffith.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 26, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The British seagoing tug Turmoil drove through a continuing gale tonight toward the United States freighter Flying Enterprise, which was drifting 360 miles off the coast of Ireland with only her skipper aboard.

LONDON -- As the year drew to a close, British shipyards had more merchant tonnage under construction than at any time in the last thirty years. Orders for more and bigger tankers for British and foreign oil companies did most to account for a 10 per cent increase over the previous year.

VIENNA -- Hungary, in common with all the other Soviet satellites, did not fulfill her Five-Year Plan for last year and the failure was most notable in mining and heavy industry where it hurt the most.

The appointment of William E. Cleary as general manager of the New York Towboat Exchange and the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York was announced jointly yesterday by James B. McAllister and Charles F. Kellers, presidents of these marine trade associations. Mr. Cleary succeeds Paul D. Jackson, resigned.
LONDON -- Some political and economic theories were turned topsy-turvy in Britain by the situation that the new Conservative Government found on taking office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President Truman today ordered a sweeping reorganization of the Bureau of Internal Revenue and promised more executive actions and legislative proposals "to insure honesty, integrity and fairness in the conduct of all governmental business."

HOBOKEN, N. J., Jan. 2 -- Describing Spain as a country where there is no unemployment but where salaries are unbelievably low, Sidney C. Sufrin, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration's Temporary Economic Study Group in Spain, arrived here today aboard the Holland-America Line's storm-tossed liner Westerdam.

CAIRO -- The year 1951 has been an over-all good one for the economy of the Arab states in Asia, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Jordan, Syria and Lebanon, with local weaknesses caused by certain special conditions.
VIENNA -- Since the end of the war, Austria has received $1,417,520,000 in foreign aid, $1,327,200,000 of it from the United States and the rest from Britain.

It would seem that the United States has a legal remedy at hand to recoup the $120,000 ransom paid to Hungary for the release of members of our armed forces and the value of the plane in case Hungary should refuse to return it, by reimbursing itself out of Hungarian funds still held by our Office of Alien Property.

Young women, headed by Mrs. George K. Ross and including Miss Iris Miller, co-chairman, and Mrs. Albert D. Perry-Miller, will sell flowers at the performance of "The Constant Wife" tomorrow night at the National Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Grenfell Association of America.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The Teachers Union, United Public Workers, announced today it would file an appeal with Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, State Education Commissioner, asking him to bar the New York City Board of Education from disqualifying teachers on the basis of Communist party membership.

The explosion of at least two Soviet atomic bombs in 1951 and the appearance in Korean skies of hundreds of Soviet-built jet aircraft gave abundant proof that the Kremlin's post-war emphasis on military-economic development had paid off handsomely. These developments gave the lie clearly to the oft-repeated Stalinist claim that Soviet economic development was aimed solely for "peace."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 2 -- Yale tonight handed the touring University of Puerto Rico basketball team the third straight setback to its current tour, 96 -- 46.
GENEVA, Jan. 2 -- The ground is being prepared for a full and frank discussion of the long-range international economic policy objectives of the United States and Britain.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- The United Nations was asked today, in view of the impending dissolution of the International Refugee Organization, to authorize the collection of a $3,000,000 fund for aid to the neediest refugees during 1952.

LISBON, Portugal -- Like so many things in Portugal, tourism is being developed slowly but surely. Hotel-keeping and catering in the modern, high-pressure fashion is not understood yet, though attempts are being made to improve existing hotels and to build new ones.

LONDON -- The tourist trade in 1951 continued to be Britain's best single source of dollars, providing her with more of that valuable currency than any other of her tangible exports to the United States, such as machinery, textiles or Scotch whisky.

Sales by the Graybar Electric Company in the New York metropolitan district last year increased 30 per cent compared with 1950, Herbert Metz, district manager, revealed yesterday. He predicted, following a district meeting in the Commodore Hotel, that this year will equal or surpass 1951 in sales.

The volume of world trade continued at high levels last year. However, the pace was less hectic than in the closing months of 1950, and prices of a number of major international commodities receded from peak levels.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- Benjamin V. Cohen, United States representative in the General Assembly, said today that the Korean War had demonstrated that collective action under the United Nations Charter could be achieved and expressed hope that the Soviet Union would support new proposals for action by the General Assembly in the event of aggression elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that meat production under Federal inspection fell 21 per cent during the last week in December because of holiday layoffs and bad weather.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- Benjamin V. Cohen, United States representative in the General Assembly, said today that the Korean War had demonstrated that collective action under the United Nations Charter could be achieved and expressed hope that the Soviet Union would support new proposals for action by the General Assembly in the event of aggression elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that meat production under Federal inspection fell 21 per cent during the last week in December because of holiday layoffs and bad weather.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Supreme Court held today in a 7-to-2 decision that a workman engaged in repairing boats that have been beached for the winter was not a seaman within the meaning of the Jones Act and therefore an action for damages in case of death could not be maintained under the provisions of the Federal Employers Liability Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The United States has proposed, as one possible solution to the bitter Anglo-Egyptian dispute, the recognition of King Farouk as ruler of the Sudan in exchange for Cairo's participation in the Middle East Command.

Eugene Higgins, the multi-millionaire, required his secretary to be "a sort of living encyclopedia," an expert yachtsman and a champion chess player, a suit filed in Surrogate's Court here yesterday contends.
Jo Davidson, the famous sculptor, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack at his estate in Bercheron, France, according to word received here. He was 68 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 -- Total resources of $7,617,206,104 as of Dec. 31 were reported today by the Bank of America, the world's largest non-government bank. This figure, comparing with $6,863,358,213 at the end of 1950, includes resources of the institution's wholly owned subsidiary, the Bank of America-New York (International):

CAIRO -- The year 1951 has been an over-all good one for the economy of the Arab states in Asia, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Jordan, Syria and Lebanon, with local weaknesses caused by certain special conditions.
The port of New York Authority filed a brief with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday urging the cancellation of proposed tariff schedules published by southern and eastern railroads.

January white sales, off to a slow start, are expected to produce a sizable volume of business, according to suppliers of sheets and pillowcases. Profit margins on some staple numbers, however, will be very low, it was pointed out, as department stores continue to feature items for drawing store traffic.
Changes in commodity prices were mixed yesterday. Cocoa was lower again. Soybean oil fell. Coffee and cottonseed oil were higher. Sugar and wool were irregular.
Dwellings dominated trading in Long Island areas in transactions reported yesterday.
The Rev. Robert E. Richards, better known to track and field fans as just Bob Richards, yesterday was named the 1951 winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Air Force said today that the 117th Tactical Reconnaissance Wing, a former Air National Guard outfit composed of squadrons from Alabama, South Carolina and Ohio, would leave soon for Europe.

The report of the Long Island Transit Authority on the future of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road was greeted generally yesterday as a realistic appraisal of the road's plight, and a positive step toward eventual solution of its reorganization problem.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 -- The description "arrogant and insulting" was applied today by Gov. Earl Warren to a statement issued yesterday in Washington by David S. Ingalls of Cleveland, manager of the Presidental campaign of Senator Robert A. Taft, Ohio Republican.

LISBON, Portugal -- Port wine, developed since the eighteenth century by British vintners in Portugal, mainly for the British market, and not drunk much in the country of its origin, is gaining in its battle for survival.

FORT PAYNE, Ala., Jan. 2 (UP) -- A convicted bootlegger was arrested today in connection with the bombing of the farm home of an outspoken prohibitionist and her husband, who live in a "moonshine" neighborhood.

NEW DELHI, India -- The continued deficit spending year after year and the very meager flow of private capital into industry have compelled the Indian Government to resort to an all-around additional taxation program for this year. The over-all budget deficit for the fiscal year ending March, 1952, is estimated at 830,000,000 rupees ($166,000,000).

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Stanford took a 40-7 beating in the Rose Bowl, but may wind up with nearly twice as much money in the bank as Illinois. And both will do a lot better than ever before, thanks to television.

Revival of Israel's Dead Sea potash works later this year will mark resumption of an industrial development capable of making the young nation a leading chemical producer, according to Israel B. Brodie, vice chairman of the Palestine Economic Corporation, 400 Madison Avenue, Mr. Brodie recently returned from Israel after helping to arrange for renewed production.

NEW DELHI, India -- India's normal trade with the Soviet Union, Communist China and the satellite countries is negligible. Through bilateral agreements with some of the Eastern European nations, particularly with Czechoslovakia and Hungary, India has been able to obtain part of her medium-scale industrial equipment.

HELSINKI, Finland -- Outstanding in economic developments in Finland during 1951 was the pronounced boom in exports. Leading export items are forest products, timber, pulp and paper, for which world-market conditions were exceptionally favorable during the year, with the demand high and prices soaring.

TEL AVIV, Israel -- Israel's economy was in a vortex in 1951. As the discrepancy widened between what the farms and factories of this three-year-old republic could produce, and what its fast-growing population consumed, the state became more deeply involved in debt.
RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 2 (AP) -- A fast rangy Fordham team nipped North Carolina State, 62 -- 59, tonight in an overtime intersectional basketball game.
ATHENS -- Any survey of Greece today must entail six major considerations.

Austin House, a fourteen-story office and showroom building at 27-29 West Fifty-seventh Street, has been purchased by a syndicate of investors from I. Jerome Riker, who bought it in 1948 from the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 2 -- The Yugoslav Government is reexamining its entire policy of land collectivization with a view to finding a new solution for the problem of increasing agricultural production. The Government has ordered a series of drastic reforms in the existing collective farms.

TOKYO -- Foreign investment in Japanese industry increased slowly in 1951, but is still far short of exercising a major influence on the national economy or of providing the capital for which Japan hoped for post-war reconstruction after the termination of United States aid through defense appropriations.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- When the Free State gold fields are in full production (expected by 1955 or. 1956) South Africa's currency will be as hard as the dollar, Harry Oppenheimer, member of Parliament, who with his father, Sir Ernest Oppenheimer, is the biggest gold-mine owner in the Union, said recently.

NEW DELHI, India -- At the close of the year, the Indian Government concluded an agreement with the Standard Vacuum Oil Company of the United states for setting up of a 1,000,000-ton refinery on terms that, according to official and business circles, are expected to set a new pattern for future foreign investments in this country.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called on President Truman yesterday for fast, resolute action by the Federal Government to bring to justice those responsible for the Christmas bombing that killed Harry T. Moore, Florida Negro leader.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- The Netherlands in 1951 seems to have reached a turning point. Until July the general financial and monetary situation gave rise to the greatest concern and doubt whether a devaluation of the guilder could be avoided.

NEW DELHI, India -- Governmental efforts to keep imports from the dollar countries 25 per cent below their pre-devaluation level and to promote exports have been effective. Statistics of the Ministry of Commerce for the first seven months of 1951 show that trade in terms of value has gone up by 74.4 per cent, compared with the corresponding period of 1950.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A major purpose of the two forthcoming press conferences here, called with portentous overtones by Mr. Stassen for tomorrow and by Senator Lodge for Sunday, is suspected to be to release positive information about the attitudes of Mr. Stassen and General Eisenhower toward the Presidential primary in New Hampshire, the first of the 1952 series.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 3 -- The Communist armistice delegation today studied the proposal of the United Nations for an exchange of prisoners taken by both sides in the Korean war and a transfer of populations on a voluntary basis after a cease-fire.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- In the absence of Warren R. Austin, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today resumed her duties as acting head of the United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly. Mr. Austin returned to the United States before Christmas with a severe respiratory infection. It is expected here that he will not be able to return to Paris for two or three weeks.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 2 -- The international executive board of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., voted unanimously tonight to accept President Truman's plan for preventing a national steel strike.

British machine tool makers are announcing price increases ranging from 7 to 10 per cent, but even at the new levels these products are still competitive in price with American-made machine tools, it was reported here yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia -- When the fiscal year opened on July 1, Australia seemed able to cope with any adverse trade balance, but by Oct. 31 the balance had fallen to a record low level of A164,000,000 ($328,000,000 at the unofficial rate of 2 to $1). In the same period of the previous year it was A6,000,000.
Kansas University is the new No. 1 basketball team in the country, but up to now every team to win top ranking in The Associated Press weekly poll has fallen victim to a jinx.

Borrowings by member banks from the Federal Reserve System reached an eighteen-year high at $959,000,000 in the week ended on Dec. 5, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Commenting on money market developments in its Monthly Review, the bank said that bank borrowing showed more sensitivity to changes in excess reserves last year than in earlier years.

While no boom is expected in the shirt industry this year production should be about 17,000,000 dozen shirts and sports shirts, assuring manufacturers, retailers and wholesalers a steady and profitable year, according to Seymour J. Phillips, president of Phillips-Jones Corporation, manufacturer of Van Heusen shirts.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France -- It is almost a year since General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower doffed his mortarboard and put on his helmet again and in that time he and the Allies of the United States have jointly brought about a powerful improvement in West Europe's defenses.

Eddie Lopat, ace southpaw, yesterday became the first member of the Yankees to sign for 1952. Lopat accepted terms just before heading for St. Augustine, Fla., where he will conduct a baseball school with Art Passarella, American League umpire, and Gus Mauch, Yankee trainer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Alvin J. Cook, Iowa director of the Federal Crop Insurance Corporation, was ordered suspended for five months today for prohibited political activity in 1950.
Jim Fuchs, national indoor shot-put champion, scored the most points in championship competition for the New York Athletic Club for the second successive year.

BONN, Germany -- The latter half of 1951 found West German labor, like German politics, in a state of transition. The unquestioning, apathetic obedience that characterized the trade unions and unorganized labor in the immediate post-war years was being replaced by a more positive, ambitious program.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 3 -- The Canada Steamship Lines, Ltd., owners of the Noronic, which burned at a Toronto pier Sept. 17, 1949, with a loss of 119 lives, offered today to post $2,150,000 for complete settlement of $19,000,000 in claims arising from the fire.
Commodity futures prices changed moderately yesterday. Vegetable oils moved higher. Cocoa recovered some of its recent losses. Other commodities showed slight movements.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina -- No other country of South America has more to offer the tourist than has Argentina. In Buenos Aires, she has one of the world's great and beautiful cities. Mountains rise for 2,400 miles along her western border. She has the warm South Atlantic along 1,200 miles of her eastern shore.

WASHINGTON -- The United States has successfully exported the Four-H Club idea to Costa Rica. This project is described by Rey Hill, Director of the Agriculture and National Resources Development Division, Institute of Inter-American Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota announced today that he planned to enter Republican Presidential primaries in Minnesota, Ohio and Pennsylvania in answer to what he called a challenge from Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.
MOSCOW, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Diplomatic sources said today they believed that the Soviet Union might offer Japan a peace treaty.
BALBOA HEIGHTS, C. Z. -- The operation of the Panama Canal was transferred to the new Panama Canal Company, a Government corporation, July 1, 1951, in accordance with Public Law 841.

The use of atomic tactical weapons will be simulated down to division level for the first time in Army-Air Force history next month, when a joint two-sided field maneuver, intended to test the efficiency of our forces in snow and sub-zero weather, will be held at Camp Drum, N. Y.
OTTAWA -- Canada's defense program calls, for a three-year expenditure exceeding $5,000,000,000, with Federal appropriations for the present fiscal year of $1,993,152,000.

The new year saw the introduction of a spring hat collection yesterday morning, the first to show which way the straws will blow in 1952. Instead of looking forward, the originator of the new millinery styles, Sally Victor, looked backward for her ideas.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 4 -- The United Nations delegates at Panmunjom awaited today a counter-proposal from the Communists on the exchange of prisoners after an armistice in the Korean war. The Chinese and North Koreans "categorically" rejected yesterday the Allied program for a stage-by-stage voluntary transfer of captives and displaced civilian populations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The suasible apprehensions of the Washington correspondent of The Times of London and others that Prime Minister Churchill will encounter a "surly" reception here, indicated by an advance display of "bad manners," are not supported by anything substantial the staff of this newspaper has discovered thus far in the capital of the United States.
