HAVANA -- Cuba's economic development is being retarded greatly by organized labor's arbitrary attitude, according to financial circles.

The formal showing of Nelly Don Southern and advance spring fashions, held yesterday on McCreery's fourth floor, was marked by diversity of fabric and styles. Informal showings of these same styles will be held all day today in the new fourth floor shop, which carries these designs exclusively.

GALESBURG, Ill., Jan. 3 -- Shortages of various types of consumer goods that have been predicted in recent months are not likely to materialize this year, according to Ross D. Siragusa, president and chairman of the Admiral Corporation.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- An increase of almost 50 per cent in tax payments in 1951 more than offset the higher income Philadelphia banks derived from a 15-per-cent rise in loans outstanding.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- The Soviet Union proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly ask the Security Council to hold a special high-level meeting to consider measures for the removal of international tension. The Soviet resolution provided that the first item on the agenda would be "the measures which the Security Council should take to help to bring to a successful conclusion the negotiations taking place in Korea for the cessation of hostilities."

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Irregular price swings marked the course of grain futures on the Board of Trade here today. Initial trade was at prices only fractionally changed from yesterday's close, but pressure developed in the early trading, with corn taking the lead on the down side.

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, French West Indies -- The islands of Martinique and Guadeloupe are intensely French and their economy is linked far more closely to that of France than to that of the United States.
" DO you know what?" asked Bobby Thomson, a note of incredulity still in his voice, "it's finally reached a point where I'm starting to believe that it actually happened."

Up in the Adirondack hamlet of Sugarbush, where Virgil Lissom's rocky acres are frozen solid right now, he has been disturbed by an item recurring in recent newspapers. It has to do with misdeeds in Washington and the way mink coats, questionably possessed, have become symbols of possible plunder.
Forecasts of a promising volume of trans-Atlantic traffic on Canadian Pacific passenger vessels in 1952 highlighted the completion of the line's 1951 record operations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Public Housing Administration today offered to sell the Greenbelt, Md., "Model Town" to a veterans group for $8,971,200.

WASHINGTON -- The main features of what became known as the Point Four program, after President Truman outlined it in his inaugural address in 1949, have been in operation for ten years in most of the Western Hemisphere.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Government lost $40,550,000 carrying out price support operations during the first five months of the current fiscal year, the Commodity Credit Corporation said today.

I was deeply pained, but not at all surprised, to read C. L. Sulzberger's article regarding Masaryk's murder -- pained because I had known Masaryk well for several years, and not surprised since the terrible story that THE TIMES records is so much in keeping with what has happened to others who would not go all the way with the Communists.

LA PAZ, Bolivia -- An experiment in government of unusual interest is to be tried in Bolivia this year, when ten administrative assistants and twelve technical experts, all provided by the United Nations, take their places at the elbows of the responsible department heads of the Bolivian Government.
If the records of the Collectors of Internal Revenue in Manhattan are any criterion, there is only one honest-to-goodness gambler doing business here -- and not much business at that.
A New York Central Railroad official declared yesterday that, even if it won its requested commutation fare increases, it still figured to lose more than $600,000 a year on its commuter operations.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- There is virtually no aspect of the Brazilian scene in which the tangible cooperation of the United States, of unofficial United States agencies and of inter-American organizations, cannot be observed. This is apart from the direct financial assistance of institutions such as the Export-Import Bank -- apart from the concept of lending and concerned more with the idea of men working physically together to solve a challenge posed directly by nature.

When asked what was the most important achievement of his record-setting ten consecutive years as District Attorney of New York County, Frank S. Hogan replied that it was the fact that he had "survived" in office that long.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- In a hearing punctuated by a war whoop, Indians of several tribes argued today before Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, for the unrestricted right to hire lawyers of their own choosing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- During the week ended Jan. 2, member bank reserves increased $156,000,000 the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

NEWARK, Jan. 3 -- New Jersey leaders of building trades and maintenance employe locals of the American Federation of Labor today announced that more than 100 of their members would join striking Prudential Insurance Company district agents in a sympathy walkout tomorrow.
The January quota of the New York Regional Blood Program has been set at 30,000 pints. This is the highest since the start of hostilities in Korea.

As an augury of a Happy New Year, the town has inherited a brilliant production of "Pal Joey," which opened at the Broadhurst last evening. This is the Rodgers and Hart musical play for which John O'Hara wrote the book in 1940, and, strictly speaking, the new production is a revival.

Cautious play, marked the strategy of eight of the ten contenders in the international masters tournament at the Hastings Chess Congress yesterday, leaving the relative standings of the leaders virtually unchanged after seven rounds, according to a report from London.

CARACAS, Venezuela -- Venezuela continued to do a big trade with foreign countries last year. Her imports amounted to approximately $600,000,000 while her exports, chiefly petroleum, topped that figure, giving her a favorable balance of trade.

A program of Jewish community life that would be based on the principles and ideals of American democracy and the values of Jewish heritage, "rather than on the negative fight against anti-Semitism," was called for last night by Dr. Israel Goldstein, newly elected president of the American Jewish Congress.

CARACAS, Venezuela -- Venezuela produced more oil last year than in any previous year in its history. Average daily production amounted to almost 1,700,000 barrels -- a figure that kept Venezuela comfortably in second place among the producing nations of the world and in first place among exporters.

Guido Cantelli, who conducted his first American concert with the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra at the invitation of Arturo Toscanini on Jan. 15, 1948, made his first appearance as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

OTTAWA -- Canada has shown such strong basic economic growth during the last ten years that hopes for the future are higher, and probably more justified, than ever before. Old and young prophets join in saying that perhaps the country is at last going to embark on a surging development comparable to that of the United States in the last century.

Orange County, Calif., announced yesterday that it will take bids Jan. 23 on an issue of sanitation district bonds totaling $8,308,000. The bonds will be dated Aug. 1, 1951, and will come due Aug. 1, 1952 to 1990.

The driving license of a Yonkers physician was revoked in Traffic Court yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh, who sought also to end the offender's privilege to operate an automobile in Connecticut.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- In probably the most important economic action of the new Vargas regime, Brazil's Congress established legal machinery to provide the basis for floating a 10,000,000,000 cruzeiro ($550,000,000) internal loan aimed at financing a vast program of development.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Approximately 4,000 C. I. O. packinghouse workers employed in the pork processing plant of Armour Co., walked off the job today in what was termed an organized demonstration against a wage rise of 6 cents an hour proposed by the packing company. The rise would increase average hourly wages to $1.66.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Truman reacted sharply today to reports that Prime Minister Churchill of Britain would not be very welcome when he arrived here on Saturday.

NEWBURGH, N. Y. Jan. 3 -- The Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation, which serves a half million customers on both sides of the river in the Mid-Hudson Valley, dedicated a new 60,000-kilowatt steam electric - generating plant today.

MEXICO CITY -- Heavy importation of agricultural machinery industrial tools and equipment and other "producer goods" was chiefly responsible for Mexico's unfavorable foreign trade balance in 1951. In the year's final quarter there was a rush to import merchandise classified as nonessential before anticipated higher duties became effective early in 1952.

Resolutions advocating state action on the treatment of "problem drinkers" and the establishment of compulsory inspection of motor vehicles were adopted yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. The group also supported proposals for additional Niagara electric power development by private concerns and establishment of a Federal commission to clarify and revise the anti-trust laws.

PANAMA -- The continued high price and ready market for coffee, an important source of dollar exchange, helped the economy of all the Isthmian Republics in 1951 with the exception of Panama and Honduras, where banana exports are more important than coffee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Reports spread today that Attorney General J. Howard McGrath soon may leave the Cabinet and President Truman, at his news conference, did nothing to dispel them.
BUENOS AIRES -- Nineteen fifty-one was a year of political and economic contrast in Argentina. It began with a period of prosperity. It ended in a state of economic crisis.

OTTAWA -- During the first seven months of 1951, all sourcees of revenue in Canada ran so far ahead of estimates, while expenditures remained lower than expected, that the budgetary surplus rose to the record figure of $604,000,000.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 3 -- Coach Paul Bryant announced today that Kentucky would cease recruiting football players outside the state. The plan is effective immediately and will apply to newcomers in the 1952 season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Truman said today he planned to accept this month the resignation of W. Stuart Symington as Administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Cor poration. The news disturbed Congressional investigators who had forced a major R. F. C. reorganization last spring after a series of scandals involving influence peddling had been reported.

WASHINGTON -- Extension of the Government's sugar control program until Dec. 31, 1956, was the high point of the year's developments in this key commodity. United States sugar consumers had ample supplies and the outlook was for another banner production year in 1952, not only in the United States and its principal supplying areas, but throughout the world.

Because Jo Davidson devoted his great sculptural gifts largely to portrait making, future generations will know as they would not otherwise have done how the leading personalities of this generation looked in three dimensions. Mr. Davidson had a genius for seeing and an accompanying genius for turning what he saw into plastic form.

A remarkably lucid and informative half-hour discussion of family relations and child psychology is being presented locally by television station WNBT (10:30 A. M., Tuesday through Friday). Helen Parkhurst, founder of the Dalton School, and Fannie Hurst, the author, appear on alternate days in a program that is eminently educational without being stuffy and deals discerningly with problems seldom mentioned on the air.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Questioned about his political plans, President Truman told his news conference today that he knows what he is going to do and when he gets ready he will announce what he is going to do.

WASHINGTON -- The St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project, buffeted for two decades by economic and sectional cross-currents, enters a critical stage this year with somewhat brighter prospects for its realization.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- This winter's renewal of Hialeah Park's $50,000 added Flamingo Stakes promises to be the richest in the history of the mile and a furlong fixture for 3-year-olds, with a record 101 nominations.

With the closing of the old year the last visas (except to some orphans and to expellees of Germanic origin) were issued under the Displaced Persons Act, thus bringing this great humanitarian program one step nearer its final termination. The United States is richer today because during the past three and a half years it has granted haven to more than 300,000 European D. P.'s, victims of war, persecution and totalitarianism.
Attempts to mediate the strike by 1,200 drivers and warehousemen against fifty wholesale grocery concerns in the metropolitan area were unsuccessful yesterday as the walkout passed its third day.
PARIS, Jan. 3 -- By a margin of only seven votes the National Assembly gave Premier Rene Pleven a vote of confidence tonight on his demand for discussion of the Government appropriation measure.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Revision of the State Rent Control Law to limit any rent increases that could result from a prospective rise in New York City assessed valuations was proposed today by a Democratic member of the Temporary State Rent Commission.

Opera on television is becoming a habit with the National Broadcasting Company. Just ten days after its highly successful premiere of the latest Menotti opus, N. B. C.-TV aired a reduced version in English of Tchaikovsky's "Pique Dame." It may not be a bonanza yet -- N. B. C. is the only company now mounting opera -- but it is a healthy sign.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 3 -- Formal talks between the United States and Brazil to work out a mutual military assistance pact began here today.

The cost of living in most of twelve Latin-American countries visited by James S. Carson, chairman of the foreign trade committee of the National Foreign Trade Council, on a three-months trip, has "risen dangerously," with the possible exception of Argentina.

A forty-four family apartment house at 3307 Hull Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Charles Levy and Leo Levy to Otilia Komondy. The property is assessed at $110,000 and was sold subject to mortgages of $95,000. Allan S. Feldman Co., and Joseph F. Panman were the brokers.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 3 -- The Israel bond drive organization will invite 150 persons representing a cross-section of the Jewish industrial leadership in the United States to visit Israel next April, Henry Montor, executive vice president of the bond drive, said today.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- Costa Rica's economy has been restored since the inaguration Nov. 8, 1949, of President Otilio Ulate Blanco. Moreover, this little republic has reclaimed the title of the most democratic country in Latin America.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 3 -- Despite the Eastern blandishments of election proposals and other indications of a possible "deal" for the unification of Germany, the West German Government is determined to carry on its program of military and political integration with the Western Allies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board, in an act of retaliation approved by President Truman, suspended today the right of a Cuban airline to fly between Havana and New York.
MEXICO CITY -- Mexcio's position as one of the world's principal exporters of metals and minerals was maintained in 1951 despite her lower production of gold, silver, lead and zinc.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- The most spectacular of all Chile's projects for industrial development and economic independence is Huachipato, near Concepcion, the second largest steel mill in Latin America. It began operating in October, 1950, with important financial contributions in the form of loans from the United States.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- There is disagreement over the size of the 1951-1952 coffee crop and the exportable surplus. The consensus is that it will not be larger than the last crop because of the damage done by the leaf miner.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Government ended last year about $7,470,000,000 in the red, the Treasury said today. Taxes were up, but spending increased even more.

The United States Treasury issued a series of calls yesterday on its tax and loan accounts held by banks throughout the nation on Jan. 2. Larger, Class B banks were ordered to pay out 30 per cent of the balances in the regular tax accounts in three equal installments, on Jan. 8, 9 and 10.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Navy has picked two cruisers to become the first guided missile warships for bombarding inland cities of an enemy with atomic or conventional explosives.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Government today put a ceiling on tire industry discounts in a move to reduce "monopolistic conditions" in the industry.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 4 -- Allied armored forces, combined with foot soldiers, fought their way back across frozen mud and ice in the hills near Korangpo, on the west Korean front, in a new drive to win back positions lost to the Reds Dec. 28.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The bodies of all twenty-eight persons killed Sunday in the crash of an Air Force C-47 on an Arizona mountain have been brought to the base of the 7,000-foot peak.

Today the publishing house of E. P. Dutton Co. celebrates its hundreth birthday. The fact serves as one more reminder of an odd paradox: that a business which is also a profession characterized by a larger gambling element than most yet manages somehow to provide an extraordinary number of long-lived firms.

Eight members of an alleged boy robber gang that operated in the Sheepshead Bay and Lower Flatbush districts in Brooklyn, according to the police, were arrainged on various charges in that borough yesterday. A ninth boy, said to have handled their loot, was held as a receiver of stolen goods.

Sales of the W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company for the nine months ended last November increased over those of the like period in the previous year, but a tax rise of 84.9 per cent reduced the net profit by 17.4 per cent, Craig Sheaffer, president, reported yesterday in a statement mailed to stockholders.
Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan has set 2 P. M. Monday for the selection of a jury to try Frank Costello for contempt of the United States Senate. Testimony will begin the next day.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- Hungary's arrest, trial and fining of four United States airmen is believed here to have killed behind-the-scenes attempts to arrange a "deal" to admit nine Communist and non-Communist European countries into the United Nations.

Nolde Westminster, hosiery manufacturer, has reduced the price of its nylon hosiery for spring 65 cents to $1.90 a dozen, it was announced yesterday by Dane F. Hahn, sales manager. At the same time the company announced reinstatement of the 2 per cent ten-day end-of-month trade discount which was in effect ten years ago.

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Scattered opposition was voiced today at a Public Service Commission hearing on the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation bid for a $2,500,000 boost in electric rates.

To achieve maximum cooperation from South American countries United States interests should revise some of their policies on the purchasing of minerals and metals, it was stated last week by Sidney L. Jaffe, vice president of the North American Mineral and Asbestos Corporation.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- President Getulio Vargas did not depart from the slogan "o petroleo e nosso," ["the oil is ours"], when he sent last month a message to Congress asking legislation to provide means for petroleum research and drillings.

Officials of the Yonkers Railroad Company, subsidiary of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Company, testified yesterday that their trolley lines must be abandoned. At the same time citizens and Yonkers city officials, at a hearing before the Public Service Commission at 233 Broadway, stressed the need for substitute transportation.
The cotton market closed irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, 6 points lower to 15 points higher than on Wednesday.

Federal and state income taxes on earnings of the National City Bank of New York last year were 69 per cent higher than in 1950, according to the bank's annual report issued yesterday. The report, reviewing 1951 operations of the bank and its affiliate, the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, is being sent to 59,900 shareholders in advance of their annual meeting on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A shortage of scrap metal has forced three open hearth steel furnaces to close down in Gary, Ind., and threatens work stoppages in four other localities, the Government reported today.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- A general overhauling of New York's archaic blue laws will be recommended to the Legislature by Governor Dewey in his annual message. Mr. Dewey's decision has been prompted by protests that have resulted from occasional attempts at enforcement.

With today's issue we present the third and final special section of our annual economic review and forecast. In the opening installment of the series on Wednesday the financial and busi ness specialists of our staff combined their efforts with those of our correspondents across the nation to present a cross-section of the American economic scene as it looked at the beginning of the new year.

Mayor Impellitteri will defend his administration against charges of waste, inefficiency and fiscal fumbling in a "major address on city finances" to be delivered at 3:15 P. M. next Monday at a meeting of the New York State Chamber of Commerce at 65 Liberty Street.

Courtlandt Palmer, composer and pianist, who died Dec. 15 on the eve of his eightieth birthday, left nearly all of his estate for charitable and educational purposes, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

A pleasure cruiser that probably won't sink -- at least it didn't yesterday on Raritan Bay -- although filled with hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of gallons of water, is the latest wrinkle in the long history of building recreational and commercial craft.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay -- Uruguayan economic conditions continued relatively favorable during 1951, primarily because of highly profitable wool exports and the revenue from tourists. Strikes in the latter half of 1951 seriously interfered with transportation and business in Montevideo.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Dewey will recommend to the Legislature next week that the authority of the State Commission Against Discrimination be broadened to include jurisdiction over violations of the civil rights law which makes it illegal for public places to exclude or discriminate against persons because of race, religion or national origin.
A "reasonably" busy time is in prospect this year for shipbuilding and ship repair yards but after 1952 the outlook is not encouraging.

Loans outstanding of The Chase National Bank on Dec. 31, 1951, amounted to $2,161,951,615 -- a new record high, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition published today. The total compares with $1,953,537,210 on Sept. 30, and $1,815,387,722, on Dec. 31, 1950.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Truman Administration has decided to make a new effort to help India solve her economic problems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Declining to issue a formal statement at this time, United States diplomatic officials nevertheless rejected today any proposal that the Korean truce talks be moved to the United Nations Security Council, as was indicated by the proposal in Paris of Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister.

With egg production on the seasonal upswing, both the large and medium Grade A's dropped 4 cents a dozen this week-end. The large are marked down to 75 cents a dozen and the medium to 65 cents, the city department of markets reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board, for the first time in its sixteen-year history, has directed an election among employes of a labor union. It was the first such case ever to come to the board for decision.
BOGOTA, Colombia -- Business was greatly stimulated in Colombia in 1951 by Presidential decrees influencing finance, production and trade.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 3 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh rejected today one and possibly other primary points in the tentative statement of conditions under which the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development would undertake temporary management and financing of Iran's paralyzed oil industry.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 -- The major motion picture producers have begun to make out-of-court settlements of the multimillion-dollar suits brought against them by members of the "unfriendly ten" writers and directors who were discharged in 1947 for declining to tell the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives whether they were Communists.

The trial for extortion and conspiracy in General Sessions of James J. Moran, former first deputy Fire Commissioner, was adjourned yesterday to next Thursday by Judge John A. Mullen. The court put over the case because of the previous commitments of one of the defendant's lawyers, George Wolf, who is attorney for Frank Costello in the latter's contempt trial in Federal court.

LA PAZ, Bolivia -- Bolivia has been accurately described as "a beggar seated on a golden chair." Her high plateaus and snow-covered mountains hold this hemisphere's greatest deposits of tin, tungsten and many other minerals. But she does not feed herself nor produce many of the things she needs to live.

CARRYING on our discussion of big game rifles and their potentials, we inevitably arrive at the assorted magnums, which have become increasingly popular during the past few years, especially among those who can afford one or more "extras" in the gun cabinet.
In both economic and social terms, the most important long-range fact about Latin America is that its population is growing faster than any other in the world.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Greyhound Corporation announced today it has offered to buy American Buslines, subject to approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission and acquisition of all of American's securities.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Relief, education and general assistance to local governments will cost the state $32,500,000 more next year than was appropriated for these purposes in the current fiscal year, according to estimates submitted to Budget Director T. Norman Hurd.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 4 -- The British tug Turmoil made her rendezvous with the hull-cracked freighter Flying Enterprise and her one-man crew, Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, in the Atlantic late last night.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 4,940,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they amounted to 122,558,000 barrels, compared with 117,618,000 a week earlier and 116,695,000 a year ago.

Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, criticized city officials last night for refusing to help the commission achieve its goal of ridding local government of "extravagance, corruption and mismanagement."

WASHINGTON -- Public financing totaling about $210,000,000 in repayable loans and credits helped to spur Latin-American agricultural and industrial development in the last year and increase the free world's supply of critically short manganese, tin and tungsten, sulphur, cement and steel.

The two-volume, pictorial history "Life in America" compiled by Marshall B. Davidson and published last October, won yesterday for the Houghton Mifflin Company of Boston the 1951 Carey-Thomas Award for creative book publishing, a prize for which Publishers Weekly was sponsor for the tenth year.

The Canadian aluminum industry shipped to the United States last year an average of 16,500,000 pounds of aluminum monthly, or about 23 per cent of total Canadian production, according to a year-end statement by Nathanael V. Davis, president of Aluminum, Ltd., the parent organization of the Aluminum Company of Canada.

OTTAWA -- Canadian manufacturers are producing more newsprint than all other countries combined, and users in the United States are taking 60 per cent of the total world supply, according to a statement by the Newsprint Association of Canada.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The average American ate less meat during 1951 than in any year since 1941 but he may do better this year, the Agriculture Department reported today.

British cotton textile exports to the United States last year were the lowest in fifteen years, New York importers said yesterday. The American market has taken fewer goods, it was pointed out, because of high prices and excessive inventories held over from the previous year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Robert L. Foree of Dallas was named today as production director of the Petroleum Administration for Defense.

Cutbacks in the European rearmament program, if made, will not be sufficient to reduce the volume of foreign demand for American heavy earth-moving and construction equipment which is now at a record, it was reported here yesterday.

The Peiping radio, in announcing the plans for the coming year, states that roughly a million and a half Chinese will be employed in the department of propaganda. This seems, on the face of it, rather an unusual expenditure in payroll for a country that is trying to meet an economic crisis and that is dredging "voluntary" contributions to the limit to carry on its military operations.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- The French have asked that the meeting of the Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which had been set for Lisbon, Portugal, Feb. 2, be postponed for three weeks to allow more time to complete the negotiations for a European army.

Equipped with two new routines, Dick Button, 1948 Olympic figure skating champion, left by air yesterday on the first lap of his journey to Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany, for training and exhibitions before going to Oslo, Norway, for the 1952 Olympic Games in February.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today began hearing the arguments by two giant airlines engaged in a fight for choice overseas air routes.

HONG KONG, Jan. 3 -- An official report from Peiping indicated tonight that the Chinese Communist party had decided to play a larger direct role in the activities of the satellite political groups clustered around it in Red China's "coalition Government."

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 3 -- Spurred by a fresh appeal from President Truman to stay on the job, the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., will give the Government and the steel industry forty-five days to settle the contract dispute that threatens to shut off 95 per cent of the country's steel supply.
BUENOS AIRES -- A rebirth of enthusiasm for sports has taken place in Latin America since the war.
ROME, Jan. 3 -- The fact that the Pope made no mention in his Christmas message of a Consistory for the creation of Cardinals has quieted reports that such action was planned early this year.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- Raw shipments to the United States of sugar, Puerto Rico's chief crop, for the first ten months of 1951 totaled 748,692 tons, valued at $95,884,115, while refined sugar shipments for the same period were 107,303 tons, valued at $15,987,770.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A proposal that white potato prices be frozen at their present levels was made to the Office of Price Stabilization today by a Western group which included several members of Congress.
A snow storm swirled over New England, a cold snap hit the West Coast, and a balmy "heat wave" covered the Southeast yesterday, The United Press reported.
GUATEMALA CITY, Jan. 3 -- Foreign insurance companies may be forced to stop doing business in Guatemala under a new law that became effective today, according to statements of their agents here.

WACO, Jan. 3---Colonel Miller had been trampled last summer by donkeys which broke away from while he was attempting to load themon a trailer on the ranch of his son-in-law and daughter, r. and lVfrs. Jim Gibbs of Valley Mills.
SAN JUAN, P. R. -- The fiscal year 1950-51 was a period of expanded business activity for Puerto Rico, as measured by the current account of the balance of external payments.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- Although Chile's production of crude oil -- about 2,000 barrels a day -- does not carry much weight in world markets, the industry is moving forward cautiously to make no mistakes. A year's developments appear to back the assertion that the petroleum deposits in the neighborhood of the Strait of Magellan may become a commercial asset of the highest order to Chile within the near future.

The 1951-52 campaign of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday passed the $300,000 mark, well ahead of the progress reported in recent years on the twenty-sixth day of the appeal. The day's records showed that 165 contributors gave $3,529.10 to arrive at a grand total of $301,135.76.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 3 (Reuters) -- The last batsmen, Doug Ring and Bill Johnston, gave Australia a one-wicket victory over the West Indies in the fourth test today and a 3-1 lead in the five-match cricket series.

WASHINGTON -- Ignorance in the United States of the basic geography of Latin America is a constant source of amusement and chagrin to diplomats of the other Americas stationed here. A man whose post had been Mexico City had a friend who could never understand why be didn't run down for occasional weekends in Rio de Janeiro, for example.

ASUNCION, Paraguay -- A loan of $5,000,000 by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to Paraguay to finance imports of farm machinery and tools, road-building equipment, trucks, fertilizers, insecticides and animal medicines was announced near the end of the year.

TRENTON, Jan. 3 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll had an opportunity today to give his support to either of two possibilities for the Republican Presidential nomination, but sidestepped both. The Governor himself is considered a dark horse for the nomination although he has declared he was not a candidate.
BUENOS AIRES -- A factor of considerable importance in Argentine economics is the large number of paid holidays for workers.

Mexico has established the National Rural Roads Committee as an adjunct of the Asociacion Mexicana de Caminos to direct her rural roads program. The committee is charged with the responsibility of developing a system of these roads, including the financing and actual construction of the roads.

The 500,000-year-old Peking Man bones may have been eaten some time within the last ten years by Chinese peasants as medicinal "dragon's teeth" or they may lie in storage, unrecognized by local Communist authorities as one of the world's archaeological treasures, but they are not in New York's Museum of Natural History.

WASHINGTON -- From an unhappy history, something approaching real economic cooperation between the United States and Canada is beginning to take form under pressure of the common defense effort and its impact on available production facilities.
OTTAWA -- Tourism is big business in Canada, involving 5,000,000 visitors from the United States yearly.

The Dominican Republic in 1951 experienced its most prosperous year in history, according to the Dominican Republic Information Center here. For the first time, exports reached the $100,000,000 level.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Jerry McCarthy Stables' Eagle Eye, who just celebrated his eighth birthday, continued on his merry, winning ways as he decisively captured the top event at Tropical Park today.

Much to the surprise of Carly Wharton, sponsor of "A Month of Sundays," the musical show now trying out in Boston, her friend, Margaret Webster, is there in a a purely unofficial advisory capacity, suggesting improvements in the second act of the show, slated to arrive Jan. 31 at the Martin Beck.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Jim Thorpe, noted Indian athlete, will be the "fall guy" in the 140th anniversary meeting of the "horse thieves" here next week.

A new pattern of international development has taken shape since World War II in a score of business enterprises and philanthropic activities organized by the Rockefeller brothers and cooperating individuals and groups in the United States and Latin America.

Physical education teachers who are not paid directly or indirectly for coaching now are eligible for amateur competition, the Amateur Athletic Union pointed out yesterday in calling attention to the revisions in its rules which went into effect on Jan. 1.

The increased strength of the Canadian dollar, culminating in the Dominion's recent action eliminating all of its foreign exchange restrictions, was undoubtedly the major development in the foreign currency market during 1951.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- John B. Dunlap, Internal Revenue Commissioner, said today he did not expect future tax scandal firings to effect any high officials and dismissals among the lesser employes probably would be fewer than expected.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- Roberto de Jesus Toro, formerly director of the Bureau of the Budget and now vice president of the Government Development Bank, calls the large emigration to the United States mainland, "the greatest economic fact in Puerto Rico during the post war years."

BUENOS AIRES -- The most interesting development in 1951 in labor-management relations in Argentina, where all organized workers are grouped in a Government-controlled federation, was the introduction of attendance-bonus clauses in contracts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 -- Television figured importantly today in the termination of a long-term contract between Joan Crawford and Warner Brothers, and in the cancellation of a loan-out agreement between the Stanley Kramer Company and Metro - Goldwyn-Mayer involving the services of Kirk Kasznar.
ATLANTA, Jan. 3 -- Gov. Herman Talmadge today answered a charge by Gov. Dennis J. Roberts of Rhode Island that the South was luring New England industry.

Jewels and a mink stole with a total estimated value of $12,500 were reported missing yesterday from the apartment of Linda Darnell, screen actress, when she returned to her suite in the Warwick Hotel, 65 West Fifty-fourth Street, after an absence of three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Supreme Court heard arguments today on the constitutionality of the Feinberg Law, enacted by the State of New York to purge its public school system of Communists, "fellow-travelers" and members of subversive organizations.

WASHINGTON -- The political tensions afflicting the world as the year drew to its end were lightened materially in the Caribbean area by the signature of a good neighbor agreement by Cuba and the Dominion Republic.
HAVANA -- The year 1951 was highly prosperous for Cuba and the prospects for 1952 are bright, though marred by rising inflation and the possibility of lower sugar exports.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- The long drought that afflicted a large area of this country extending from the far south through the northeast reduced agricultural production last year, according to the Brazilian Department of Agriculture. The crops that were most affected were rice, manoic, corn, castor beans, flax and cotton seed, yields of which were below those of 1950. On the other hand, production of soybeans and peanuts increased.

The twenty-fifth annual report of the General American Investors Company, Inc., released yesterday, shows that net assets of the trust on Dec. 31 aggregated $51,789,254, an increase of $5,403,249 over Dec. 31, 1950. Net assets, after deducting $6,200,000 for outstanding preferred stock, were equal to $25.32 a share on the common stock, compared with $22.35 a common share at the end of 1950.
Chico Vejar, 20-year-old Stamford, Conn., boxer, will enter the Madison Square Garden ring tonight a 5-12 favorite over 27-year-old Enrique Bolanos in the ten-round main bout.

Robert Merrill, the baritone who was dismissed from the Metropolitan Opera last spring for alleged failure to live up to his contractual obligations, has apologized to the company and will rejoin it as a regular member for the spring tour at the end of the present season.

The Reynolds Metals Company expects to complete in April of this year all construction work in connection with the development of its large new bauxite mine in Jamaica, British West Indies. Work is now being expedited on a pier, storage bins, overhead tramway, and the processing and power plants that are part of the development program.

BOSTON, Jan. 3 -- Denis W. Delaney, discharged Boston Collector of Internal Revenue, sat in Federal District Court today and heard himself described as a man to whom a New York tax consultant had paid $10,000 in fees.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 3 -- Albert R. Moy, 46-year-old business agent of Local 18, Bricklayers, Masons and Plasterers Union, A. F. L., was shot dead this morning by an unemployed bricklayer, who turned the pistol on himself a few minutes later in a suicide attempt.
MEXICO CITY -- There are still unlimited opportunities for foreign capital to establish new industries or invest in going enterprises that can return greater profits with expansion.

RIVERHEAD, L. I. Jan. 3 -- E. Conway Plummer of Port Jefferson was replaced today by Fred B. Hose Jr. of Brentwood as clerk of the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors. Mr. Plummer had served as clerk for the last two years. The position pays $5,500 annually.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The University of Maryland football team, conqueror of Tennessee in the Sugar Bowl, got an enthusiastic welcome tonight on its return to Washington.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Buying on credit jumped for the fourth straight month in December to a point just short of the all-time high, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
Directors of the Transamerica Corporation at a meeting in Sant Francisco yesterday declared a dividend of one share of Bank of America stock for each-twenty h-es of Trnamerica.
OTTAWA -- For the second successive year, Canada will in 1951 have a current account deficit of possibly $400,000,000 to $500,000,000.
EDMONTON, Alta. (AP) -- A pipeline to funnel Alberta natural gas to Montana defense industry has been completed, but not a cubic foot of gas has been delivered.

Out of the Cheat Mountain sector of the Alleghenies and into Madison Square Garden last night came a whirlwind that answers to the name of the West Virginia University basketball team. Fortunately, this was a brief visit Bob Brown's Mountaineers made to the big town, stopping over long enough to swamp a hitherto undefeated New York University squad, 100 -- 75.

After five successive weekly advances, loans to business by New York banks turned downward last week, dropping $77,000,000 in the largest weekly decline since April 19, 1950. Whether the decline represented year-end payoffs or the entry of seasonal influences was not readily apparent from the data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

TORONTO, Jan. 3 -- Communism is beating Christianity at its own game of evangelizing the world, the Rev. Richard Shaull, missionary from Chile, told the opening session of the annual meeting of the Foreign Missions Division of the National Council of the Churches of Christ here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Defense Department said today that United States battle casualties in Korea were now more than 103,739, an increase of 321 over last week's report.
WASHINGTON -- Free, organized labor in Latin America was able to report progress in 1951, but still faced a long, uphill climb to security and stability.

MEXICO CITY -- Mexico's improved social welfare, political stability and strong financial position offer extraordinary guarantees for continuation of her rapid industrial expansion. Agricultural and mining development also are being aided substantially by credits from the Export-Import Bank and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Whether Bermuda should link her currency closer to the United States dollar is a question being weighed by the Government behind the scenes, as the colony emerges more and more definitely as a dollar earner for the British pool.

MEXICO CITY -- Another 10 per cent increase over the preceding year's crop not only made cotton Mexico's leading agricultural product in 1951 but gave it top value among this country's export commodities.

Your editorial of Dec. 28, "Auto Insurance," is an able and plausible statement of the case for compulsory automobile liability insurance. It dismisses peremptorily "arguments offered by some insurance companies against compulsory insurance" as "empty of persuasion," without informing your readers as to what such arguments are.

QUITO, Ecuador -- Business was generally active in 1951 in Ecuador, with prospects appearing better for 1952. There was a tendency, however, to increase inventories of imported goods, while at the same time consumers purchased less because of higher prices.

The New York Board of Rabbis, representing conservative orthodox and reform rabbis, voiced strong opposition yesterday to the New York State Board of Regents' recommendation for daily prayers in the public schools. It was contended the proposal "will give rise to sectarian practices in the public schools."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- In an inter-service disagreement that defense officials have been attempting to minimize, the Air Force has in effect served notice on the Army Ordnance Corps that it intends to break away from Army domination in the development and purchase of special weapons for combat planes.

The National Maritime Union is carrying its challenge of the Wage Stabilization Board's jurisdiction over the wages of seamen engaged in foreign commerce to the United States Court for the District of Columbia.

The one-story garage at 407-11 West Sixteenth Street running through to 408-12 West Seventeenth Street was resold yesterday by Frederick Brown to a client of John T. McCormick Jr., for occupancy. It adjoins the southwest corner of Ninth Avenue and is the last parcel in the entire square block originally owned by Seeman Brothers.

MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 1, in a rough hockey game at the Forum tonight to take sole possession of second place in the National Hockey League.

Dollar volume of the phonograph record industry last year increased 10 per cent above 1950, Lawrence W. Kanaga, general sales and merchandise manager, record division, Radio Corporation of America, reported yesterday. He said unit volume of records about equaled 1950.

Ralph Branca relived some agonizing moments yesterday when, with some 400 other persons, he saw himself again deliver the ill-fated pitch that Bobby Thomson rammed into the Polo Grounds stands to beat the Dodgers in the last inning of the National League's final playoff game and catapult the Giants into the world series.

WASHINGTON -- The tin dispute between the United States and Bolivia has reached such intensity within the last ten months that it seems rapidly shaping up into a full-fledged Western Hemisphere diplomatic cause celebre.

At the annual sales meeting of Ronson Art Metal Works, Inc., in Newark yesterday it was shown that the company's volume on its combined lighter sales in 1951 exceeded $40,900,000. Alexander Harris, president, said that the business had doubled in five years, with the company now employing 5,000 persons. John Des Reis, sales vice president, said that Ronson's 1952 advertising program will be the largest in the company's history.
COLQUIRI, Bolivia -- The begrimed naked back of an Aymara Indian tin miner tensed as he strained to adjust the bit of an air drill to the exact spot on the tunnel wall.
The greatest single change in the Western Hemisphere below the Rio Grande in the last quarter-century has been brought about by the tremendous advance of air transport.

The Hospital Council of Greater New York announced yesterday that it had agreed, at the request of the city's Board of Hospitals, to investigate "the policies and practices" at Kings County Hospital. The Brooklyn medical center, whose understaffed and overcrowded facilities have been under attack recently, is second in size only to Bellevue among municipal hospitals.

Skiers, who jammed Eastern resorts the past holiday week-end to enjoy the finest early sport in many years, will find good conditions still prevailing. Despite the recent thaw, considerable snow base still remained at most areas and many of them were being visited with new covers yesterday. Those points reporting icy or crusted depths or surfaces were hopeful that the Weather Bureau's forecast of additional snow and cold weather starting tonight would materialize.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- A ten-year program for new public improvements costing $1,500,000,000 as the setting for vast redevelopment work by private enterprise was proposed today for Chicago's "central core" by the Chicago Plan Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Economic aid to Spain totaling about $150,000,000 a year for badly needed raw materials and to improve transport and power production is recommended in a report to the Mutual Security Agency by Sidney Sufrin, just returned from a special economic survey mission to that country.

THE fifth and concluding volume of Van Wyck Brooks' monumental work on American literature is called "The Confident Years 1885-1915"* and is published today. With its completion Mr. Brooks has also found a title for the series of which it is a part, "Makers and Finders: A History of the Writer in America, 1800-1915."

John Knight, a Canadian pianist, last heard in this city three years ago, gave a Town Hall recital last evening. His program, by no means an easy one, included the Ray Lev arrangement of the Vivaldi Concerto Grosso in D minor, Beethoven's "Appassionata" Sonata, a Chopin group topped by the F minor Ballade, Ravel's "Valses Nobles et Sentimentales" and a Liszt Rhapsody.

The combination passenger-refrigerated vessels of the United Fruit Company will end on Friday their practice of sailing between New York and Guatemala. Instead, the company is sending the three ships on its run to Havana, the Canal Zone and ports on the Caribbean shores of Colombia.

WASHINGTON -- The World Health Organization's Regional Office for the Americas, also known as the Pan-American Sanitary Bureau, has reported that at the close of 1951 seventy-one health programs were in progress throughout the Americas and thirty-eight others in various stages of negotiation.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 3 -- A labor appeals court has ruled against the United Fruit Company in a case involving work suspension for approximately 4,000 employes on the Tiquisate banana plantations. The work was suspended Sept. 26 after winds had destroyed 10,000 acres of bananas.

A 33-year-old former plain-clothesman became yesterday the first person in New York City to be charged with violating the new Internal Revenue Law requiring a $50 occupational tax stamp for bookmakers.

The stock market generated a little more momentum yesterday both in price appreciation and interest, but again the absence of reinvestment demand kept the list from rallying in major fashion. It was mainly the bidding for railroad issues that raised the list to the position it showed at the close.

The blockfront taxpayer at 500-526 Park Place, in Long Beach, L. I., has been sold by a syndicate represented by Peter Alpern to a client of the Taylor Company in a transaction negotiated by Seeger Co. as brokers. The one-story building, between East Hudson and East Market Streets, contains fourteen stores.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Less than 1 per cent of the country's individual income taxpayers would benefit by the 25 per cent Federal tax ceiling advocated by the Committee for Constitutional Government and the American Taxpayers Association, according to Treasury figures that were made available today.

BUENOS AIRES -- Juan Peron told a group of visiting United States Congress members in November that during his second six-year term as President of Argentina, to which he had just been elected, he hoped to double this country's agricultural production.

John Knight, a Canadian pianist, last heard in this city three years ago, gave a Town Hall recital last evening. His program, by no means an easy one, included the Ray Lev arrangement of the Vivaldi Concerto Grosso in D minor, Beethoven's "Appassionata" Sonata, a Chopin group topped by the F minor Ballade, Ravel's "Valses Nobles et Sentimentales" and a Liszt Rhapsody.

The combination passenger-refrigerated vessels of the United Fruit Company will end on Friday their practice of sailing between New York and Guatemala. Instead, the company is sending the three ships on its run to Havana, the Canal Zone and ports on the Caribbean shores of Colombia.

WASHINGTON -- The World Health Organization's Regional Office for the Americas, also known as the Pan-American Sanitary Bureau, has reported that at the close of 1951 seventy-one health programs were in progress throughout the Americas and thirty-eight others in various stages of negotiation.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 3 -- A labor appeals court has ruled against the United Fruit Company in a case involving work suspension for approximately 4,000 employes on the Tiquisate banana plantations. The work was suspended Sept. 26 after winds had destroyed 10,000 acres of bananas.

A 33-year-old former plain-clothesman became yesterday the first person in New York City to be charged with violating the new Internal Revenue Law requiring a $50 occupational tax stamp for bookmakers.

The stock market generated a little more momentum yesterday both in price appreciation and interest, but again the absence of reinvestment demand kept the list from rallying in major fashion. It was mainly the bidding for railroad issues that raised the list to the position it showed at the close.

The blockfront taxpayer at 500-526 Park Place, in Long Beach, L. I., has been sold by a syndicate represented by Peter Alpern to a client of the Taylor Company in a transaction negotiated by Seeger Co. as brokers. The one-story building, between East Hudson and East Market Streets, contains fourteen stores.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Less than 1 per cent of the country's individual income taxpayers would benefit by the 25 per cent Federal tax ceiling advocated by the Committee for Constitutional Government and the American Taxpayers Association, according to Treasury figures that were made available today.

BUENOS AIRES -- Juan Peron told a group of visiting United States Congress members in November that during his second six-year term as President of Argentina, to which he had just been elected, he hoped to double this country's agricultural production.

LIMA, Peru -- The year of 1951 was a prosperous one for Peru. The year ahead promises to be as good or better. Foreign trade for the first half of last year was 50 per cent higher than for the same period of 1950. Agriculture production was increased by 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON -- A new combined attack on malaria is under way in five states of Colombia, Dr. Henry van Zile Hyde, director of the Health and Sanitation Division of the Institute of Inter-American Affairs, has announced.

MADRID, Jan. 3 -- Statements of United States State Department officials who expressed surprise at "learning" that Paul A. Porter, acting Mutual Security director for Europe, had announced the early opening of talks for an economic aid agreement caused puzzlement and confusion in both Spanish and United States circles here.

Population is pressing on Puerto Rico. Now at 2,250,000, it is rising at the rate of 70,000 a year and by 1960 should be 3,000,000. Officials of the Insular and Federal Governments are laying their plans to meet that challenge, to see that Puerto Rico not only supports itself but betters its living standards.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- The city of Sao Paulo has been called the Detroit or the Chicago of South America. It is expanding industrially at a remarkable rate.
While millions of miles of roads -- good, poor and indifferent -- extend over the Western Hemisphere, one of the greatest undertakings in the history of route-building is the Pan-American Highway.

In a move whose real significance is still to be disclosed Soviet Russia has called on the Security Council of the United Nations to hold a special meeting, attended by top-ranking Government representatives, to consider measures for bringing the Korean armistice negotiations to a successful conclusion.
HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Columbia County Board of Supervisors today reappointed County Attorney Thomas P. Kennedy, whose name was mentioned in testimony before the State Crime Commission.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- The Joint Brazil-United States Economic Development Commission was formally established here in July, and by year's end the first projects stemming from its work already were pointing toward an era of more efficient progress for Brazil.

MEXICO CITY -- Tourist business has become so important to Mexico that the Government's 1952 budget will provide 6,000,000 pesos for a special commission in the Interior Ministry to expand its promotional work on behalf of this rich source of dollar income.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Truman defended today his creation of the Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation against charges that the purpose was "political propaganda."
The Bankers Trust Company has been appointed New York paying agent of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts for the following issues of bonds:
CAIRO, Jan. 3 -- Fire was exchanged today between British troops and Egyptian snipers in the area of the Suez water filtration plant. Two British officers were reported wounded.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- The Puerto Rico Industrial Development Company in the first eleven months of 1951 granted $1,109,000 in loans to private enterprises, according to Dr. Richard F. Behrendt, its economic director. The company is considering loans to nine additional concerns, totaling more than $3,000,000.

PANAMA -- Tourist business declined in Central America in 1951, with the trend from the United States generally in the direction of Europe. The Grand Colombian countries hardly were touched by travelers, although tourist dollars would be a welcome addition to the income of Colombia and Ecuador.

ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, at sea, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The liner Queen Mary chalked up a near-record day's run of 720 miles at noon today and ship's officers guaranteed that they would deliver Prime Minister Churchill in New York in plenty of time to keep a Saturday luncheon date with President Truman.

" The Last Days of Nijinsky," by Romola Nijinsky, has been scheduled for April publication by Simon Schuster. It is the story of Vaslav Nijinsky, considered the world's greatest male dancer, and of his wife's twenty-seven-year odyssey in search of safety and sanity for her husband.

Most industries in Brazil have provided excellent profits for their owners, with the figures usually much higher than those customarily earned in older industrialized countries, according to the American Republics Division of the Office of International Trade, Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A labor newspaper reported today that a poll of union presidents had showed that in their judgment the Democratic party's best issue in the 1952 elections would be full employment and prosperity.

Early-stage development work and other preliminaries proceeded apace last year/in Venezuela and Canada at the two larger new iron ore mines being made ready to take their place within the next few years as important raw material suppliers for United States steel mills.

With virtually a perfect debt record over the centuries, Haiti, the first part of the Americas to be discovered by Columbus, has started to borrow again. Back in 1923 she paid off her 1910 French franc loans at par. In 1938, 1941 and 1948 she borrowed from the Export-Import Bank and paid off the advances according to schedule.

CARACAS, Venezuela -- Tourism in Venezuela made little progress last year, although a special tourist commission was established by the Government to study ways and means of encouraging travelers to come to this country.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 3 -- The agreement for new economic direct aid to India, which will be signed here within a few days, will provide for an outright grant.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 4 (AP.) -- General Headquarters communique 1,119, covering Thursday's operations:
FAIRBANKS, Alaska -- Spurred by record-breaking military spending and heavy private construction, Alaska's economy boomed is 1951.

LIVERPOOL, England, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen's own story of his battle against the seas aboard the Flying Enterprise was told for the first time today in a 25-minute wire recording of his radio message to the skipper of a rescue ship.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A House hearing chamber looked like a stockroom today as an Armed Services subcommittee prepared to call Defense Department officials on the carpet for alleged wasteful buying of supplies.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 -- Dr. Josef Wirth, German Chancellor in 1921 and 1922, quoted Vladimir S. Semyenov, political adviser to the Soviet Control Commission in East Germany, today as having said a "milder" attitude could now be adopted toward many of the estimated 24,700 political prisoners in the Soviet zone.
WASHINGTON -- The Organization of American States listed four major achievements of 1951, all of them contributing toward hemispheric solidarity and the Good Neighbor philosophy.

Peter Casale, a thin, dark-haired youth of 18 years, lives with his mother and eight of his sixteen brothers and sisters in a six-room apartment at 2423 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx. His father, a laborer, is a patient at Manhattan State Hospital on Wards Island.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 -- Dr. Josef Wirth, German Chancellor in 1921 and 1922, quoted Vladimir S. Semyenov, political adviser to the Soviet Control Commission in East Germany, today as having said a "milder" attitude could now be adopted toward many of the estimated 24,700 political prisoners in the Soviet zone.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's new appeal addressed to Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, to cancel the steel strike threat:
N. F. Lampert has been appointed general sales manager of M. F. G. Watch Band Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would offer to buy the 1952 crop American-Egyptian-type cotton at an average of $1.071 a pound for grade No. 2, 1.5 inches in staple length. It bought similar cotton from the 1951 crop at an average of $1.04 a pound.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Defense Production Administrator Manly Fleischmann said today that criticism of this country's steel-for-aluminum trade with Britain is "unrealistic."

Recent efforts to effect a reconciliation between the vestry of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn and the Right Rev. James Pernette DeWolfe, Bishop of the Long Island Diocese, struck a snag yesterday when it became known that the Bishop had formally rejected a move to name as rector the Rev. William Howard Melish.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Supreme Court was openly dismayed today when the Justice Department handed in a ten-volume court record of 8,000 pages, with the admonition that the justices had no alternative but to read it.

The original remains of prehistoric Peking Man, one of the great treasures of natural history, were last known to be in the possession of Col. William W. Ashurst of the Marine Corps, who commanded the marine detachment at the American Embassy at Peiping when it was captured by the Japanese on Dec. 7, 1941.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) - Factory lay-offs in November, for the fifth straight month, continued at one of the highest rates reported for the season in the last decade.

The announcement of the increase in automobile insurance rates brings the thought that it is long past the time when the burden should be placed where it properly belongs -- on the pockets of those responsible.

Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, former chairman of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, said here yesterday that he was very much interested in the Democratic nomination for President. He added that he was "appraising'' the Presidential situation and would make an announcement early in February.

PARIS, Jan 4 -- The French Foreign Ministry announced today that it had asked for a postponement from Feb. 2 to Feb. 9 of the meeting of the Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Lisbon, Portugal. Officials had said yesterday the request would be for a three-week delay.
Chico Vejar met his first experienced ring rival last night in Madison Square Garden and acquitted himself admirably.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The twenty-eight-nation International Materials Conference apparently has abandoned plans for international allocation of newsprint.

HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- Milton V. Saulpaugh, Columbia County Sheriff, has resigned as Republican County Chairman with the charge that the recent State Crime Commission hearings here "left me in a position where I have been unable to defend my character or reputation."
Federal narcotics agents, aided by local police, arrested fifty-eight alleged heroin sellers in a series of Harlem and Bronx raids beginning late Thursday afternoon and extending through last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath conferred with President Truman and other Cabinet members today and told reporters later no change was contemplated in his status.

NEWARK, Jan. 4 -- A sympathy strike called this morning by American Federation of Labor building service employes appeared to have little effect on operations in the Prudential Insurance Company here, whose district agents declared a nationwide strike last Dec. 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Treasury agents who sent the late "Scarface" Al Capone to prison for tax evasion are beginning to close in on some of the top racketeers of the post-prohibition era.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 -- A rift has developed in the motion-picture industry over making out-of-court settlements of law suits brought by members of the "unfriendly ten" screen writers and directors discharged in 1947 for alleged Communist affiliations.
TRENTON, Jan. 4 -- Republican leaders of the New Jersey Senate and Assembly took steps today to revise two legislative practices that have caused much public criticism.
MUERREN, Switzerland, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The American downhill and slalom ski team arrived today to begin training for next month's Olympic Games in Oslo.

Shot in the foot at 4:30 A. M. yesterday in a midtown restaurant hold-up, a man was taken to St. Clare's Hospital, 415 West Fifty-first Street, and at 5 A. M. identified a patient in the next bed as his assailant. The police said that the victim's attention had been attracted to the accused youth when the latter mumbled, "I shot a man in the foot."
CAIRO, Jan. 4 -- British Centurion tanks went into action today against Egyptian snipers on the outskirts of Suez.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Benjamin V. Cohen, the United States representative, today attacked the Soviet proposal for a special high-level meeting of the United Nations Security Council on the ground that it would hurt and perhaps disrupt the Korean armistice negotiations.

The fortieth appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received yesterday an additional 168 contributions totaling $2,933.15. This brought the overall total for the 1951-52 renewal to $304,068.91, or $17,531.69 more than at the corresponding date a year ago.
PRINCETON, Ind., Jan. 4 -- A political squabble put two sets of appointees in twenty-seven city jobs today, with the workers scrambling to see who did the chores.

Donations to the New York Regional Blood Program on Thursday totaled 753 pints, it was announced yesterday. The donations were made at four bloodmobiles and at the two main Red Cross stations in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
A number of new words were added to the homemaker's vocabulary last year. The following is a glossary of some of them.

A small piece in yesterday's paper about four American movie actors who each gave a pint of blood for our fighting men in Korea tends to overshadow the main point -- namely, that it takes thousands of pints of blood every month to keep up adequate supplies of the life-giving fluid in Korea.

New York University, still stunned by its upset at the hands of West Virginia last Thursday, will attempt to get back into winning stride tonight when it opposes Lafayette in the second half of a double-header at Madison Square Garden.
MOSCOW, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Fifth Congress of the Kazihstan Communist party has revealed serious defects in party activity in that republic, according to Pravada.

A man, captured on the roof of the Broadmoor Hotel, 235 West 102d Street, was linked yesterday to the series of recent jewelry and fur robberies that have plagued New York hotels in the last eight months.

ROME, Jan. 4 -- Pietro Campilli, Minister of Industry and Commerce, has written to James C. Dunn, United States Ambassador, inquiring what the present status of the United States offshore procurement program was and what prospects for the future were.

The armed forces will have a good deal of explaining to do about their purchasing policies if the price data assembled by a House subcommittee turn out to be correct. The House investigators have gathered together a number of "horrible examples" of waste, carelessness or ignorance that have allegedly shown up in military procurement.

BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- New England's six Governors were told today that the "diseases of the textile industry are urgent enough to require prompt diagnosis, and remedial measures should be proposed at the earliest moment."
A wildcat bus strike halted operations of the Triboro Coach Company in Queens yesterday afternoon, but it appeared likely the strikers would return to work before this morning.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 4 -- The two-man mission of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development awaited today the bank's reaction to the stand taken yesterday by Premier Mohammed Mossadegh on the proposals for solving the oil crisis.

Dr. William Samuel Carlson, 46-year-old president of the University of Vermont, an opponent of commercialized college sports and a former Arctic explorer, has been elected the second president of the State University of New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A drop in retail food prices in the first half of December, the first since October, was reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The National Production Authority will act tomorrow to adjust alleged inequities in the allotment of steel under the Controlled Materials Program. The action is expected to step up deliveries to steel-starved projects.
The Title Guarantee Trust Company declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share, the first in eighteen years. It is payable on March 3 to holders of record Jan. 28.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- The State Employes' Merit Award Board reported today that "practical ideas" suggested by state workers had resulted in the saving of $76,620 to the state during the last year.
Three new films will arrive in town over the week-end. Opening today at thirty-two Loew's neighborhood theatres on a double-bill program are "Another Man's Poison" and "The Lady Says No."

The State Liquor Authority confirmed yesterday that it had accepted on Dec. 19 the resignation of George W. Gatz, former chief executive officer. Mr. Gatz had been on voluntary leave of absence since last fall, when his name was mentioned at hearings of the State Crime Commission on Staten Island.

Horse show judges who have not officiated for a period of three years will be removed from the accredited list, Adrian Van Sinderen told the annual luncheon-meeting of the American Horse Shows Association yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Cheung Hang Chak, Chinese pantryman on the Grace liner Santa Rosa, probably is still wondering today, as he awaits arraignment in United States District Court, how a Customs port patrolman ever suspected he was carrying opium when he left his ship Thursday evening.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 5 -- United Nations delegates negotiating an armistice in the Korean war charged yesterday at Panmunjom that the Communists were bringing crated aircraft into Korea to be put into operation after a cease-fire had ended Allied bombing of North Korean fields.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The Government announced today that because of a 1,500,000-ton steel shortage it had decided to allocate steel to manufacturers on the basis of priority of national interest. In other words, rearmament and exports come first and consumers' needs last.

Harry Sacher was disbarred yesterday from Federal Court practice here and Abraham J. Isserman was suspended for two years for their unprofessional conduct as defense counsel during the 1949 trial of the eleven convicted Communist leaders.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Some ninety engravings and etchings by the noted French painter Henri Matisse, now in possession of the New York Museum of Modern Art, became the subject today of a legal controversy with the filing of a complaint aimed at recovering them.

After more than a year's delay, the alternate - side - of - the - street parking plan of the Departments of Sanitation and Traffic will be extended to West Manhattan between Ninetieth and 110th Streets "by early spring."

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Interest in the stock markets again was concentrated today on shipping shares and foreign bonds. They continued to gain despite profit-taking. Most other markets seemed slightly firmer although business was light.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 4 -- The special convention of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., voted today to postpone a national steel strike for forty-five days, but warned that the union was prepared to shut down the steel mills if the truce period ended without a satisfactory wage agreement.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer refused yesterday to enjoin the city and Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan from enforcing a new local law which requires members of the Police Department to retire upon reaching the age of 63.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4 -Hal Wallis has the jump on his fellow-producers in planning a motion picture based on the epic adventure of Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen and his storm-battered ship, Flying Enterprise.

PARIS, Jan. 4 (AP) -- "Smuggling" an article into the official Hungarian Communist newspaper, an anti-Red underground movement in Hungary has published an appeal to the United Nations "to free us from our Russian overlords."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- That well-stocked special sales counter of surplus farm products Uncle Sam set up two years ago is taking on the appearance of a bargain basement after a shoppers rampage.

The distinguished and valuable Oliver R. Barrett collection of Lincolniana, consisting of several thousand letters by and to the Civil War President and other manuscripts, documents and memorabilia relating to Lincoln's life and times, will be auctioned here next month.
BAY SHORE, L. I., Jan. 4 -- The moral of this story is: Suffolk County officeholders who want to keep their jobs should stay out of Nassau County -- and embarrassing situations.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 4 -- A loyalty oath for members of Connecticut's educational system was described today by the State Board of Education as "unnecessary, unrealistic and discriminatory."

From London comes word that Martyn Green, for many years an outstanding member of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, has signed a long-term contract whereby he will serve as the leading comic in a program of Gilbert and Sullivan presentations sponsored by S. M. Chartock.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Abraham Teitelbaum, former Capone attorney who testified in the House investigation of tax scandals, offered today to sell his Fine Arts Building in the Loop to satisfy income tax liens.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Dec. 29 totaled 501,956 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
Securities and Exchange Commission figures for the third 1951 quarter show the advantage enjoyed by the big company in obtaining capital.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's military planners have now completed, after ninety days of intensive work, a full-scale report on the network of air bases that must be built or developed across Europe in the coming months from the tip of Norway to the heel of Italy.
Prices of commodities in New York futures markets advanced yesterday.

One asks if Joseph Fuchs, the violinist, who gave a recital last night in Town Hall, is by temperament a romanticist of the virtuosi sort, or whether the mere fact of warming up for the first half of a recital explains the contrast between his uninteresting playing of Bach and Beethoven and his brilliant later performances of Bruch and Richard Strauss.

Emphasizing his intention to safeguard boxing, Chairman Robert K. Christenberry of the State Athletic Commission yesterday warned licensed operatives under the board's jurisdiction they face imprisonment for violations of the Commission's rules.
Spirited battles over measures restricting imports into this country will get off to an early start in the new session of Congress opening next week, trade sources here predicted yesterday.
TORONTO, Jan. 4 -- The United States State Department was asked today to take vigorous action to halt attacks on Protestant missionaries and church property in Colombia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Joseph H. Rosenbaum, a Washington attorney, pleaded innocent in Federal Court today to a charge of perjury growing out of Senate investigations of alleged influence peddling at the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Foreign entries in the international masters' tournament at the Hastings Chess Congress appeared set to clinch the three top places after the eighth and semi-final round yesterday, according to a report from London.
