WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 --The country's mink farmers complained today that the stories about mink coats acquired by Washington political figures had put an "unjust stigma" on their product and had hurt business.

The railroad issues again kept the stock market in higher territory yesterday but even some of the important units in this division failed fully to maintain original increases. The advance over the last few sessions, while of limited proportions, returned the list to the highest rate since last mid-October.
Frederick R. Eisele, associated with Freeman Co. more than twenty-six years, has become a partner.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 4 -- The United States, British and French Governments advanced $25,000,000 to the Yugoslav Government today to cover its most pressing import requirements. This is pending a tripartite decision on the amount of aid to be granted to cover the foreign trade deficit for the first six months of 1952.

TOKYO, Jan. 4 -- The Japanese people, after the long new-year's holiday, at last read in their newspapers today the message Premier Stalin sent them at the request of the Kyodo News Service -- and the general reaction is that, though Communists operated a neat propaganda trick, nothing has been done to solve the outstanding issues between Japan and the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that the outcome of proposals by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, for taking the Korean truce talks and a general discussion of world tension into the United Nations Security Council would be nothing short of disastrous.
Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 31 to 47 points net higher than on Thursday.

It is not generally known to the trading public, but all orders for the unit of trading given to specialists, other than "day orders," must be good until canceled.

The value of the Treasury's short-term obligations continued to improve yesterday as bank investment money kept flowing back to the market. Yields on the longest-term discount bills -- those due next June -- fell to a 1.75 per cent basis on the bid side, against 1.77 per cent on Thursday, and yields on eleven of the Treasury's fifteen other outstanding issues of discount bills improved to like extent.

AGAWAM, Mass., Jan. 4 -- An elderly inventor who says he gave Britain a device to fight off Nazi planes asked Secretary of State Dean Acheson today to dun Winston Churchill for him.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Within twenty-four hours after winning a vote of confidence from the National Assembly, Premier Rene Pleven today was obliged to seek another under dangerous conditions for the Cabinet. Several more confidence votes will probably be asked tomorrow, with the ballots taken all together Monday.

GENEVA, Jan. 4 -- The International Refugee Organization will cease operations Jan. 31, after having re-established in new homes about 1,045,000 displaced persons in four and one-half years of operation.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Loyola University of Los Angeles -- despite offers of $60,000 in aid -- declined tonight to continue football next fall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Federal Reserve Board has decided to "re-examine" its enforcement policy under Regulation W, re-stricting consumer credit in retail transactions, to take account of opposition from a number of reserve bank presidents to the present vigorous administration of the law.

Changing ideas and practices in the care of children who need help from the community -- as well as changing economic and social conditions -- are reflected in a statistical report just released by the city's Department of Welfare. The report covers youngsters under care as public charges in institutions and boarding homes, from 1919 to the present.
Arthur R. Hines has Been elected a commercial vice president of the marketing services division of the General Electric Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was given a ten-day extension of time today for consideration of the proposed sale of Washington Water Power Company common stock to three Washington State public utility districts.

Thomas H. Koerner, an amateur culinary expert, took a stand yesterday in favor of the taste-as-you-cook school. An accountant by profession, he has been at home at the range in spare hours -- in France, China and more lately in Darien, Conn. -- for some twenty years.

Plans for a reception in honor of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the association with Brooklyn religious enterprises of the Rev. Dr. J. Henry Carpenter, executive secretary of the Brooklyn Division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Higher ceiling prices on all passenger automobiles manufactured by the Ford Motor Company were approved today by the Office of Price Stabilization under the Capehart Amendment to the Economic Controls Law.
A slowdown in clearance of export declarations yesterday at the Customs House threatened to delay outbound shipments and upset trade commitments and credit arrangements.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- The principle that the inhabitants of United Nations trust territories should have some sort of voice in the United Nations Trusteeship Council received the backing of thirty-three nations today.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- United Nations diplomats, worried about the possibility of Communist attacks in Southeast Asia, have been discussing the practicality of calling in the year-old Peace Observation Commission to try to ward off trouble or to be on the spot to report if fighting should start.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 (AP) -United States Steel Corporation closed five open hearth steel furnaces in Pittsburgh district mills today for lack of scrap metal.

Industrial furnace manufacturers in the United States have increased their gross volume of production 400 per cent since the start of the Korean war. This was asserted here yesterday by S. N. Clarkson, executive vice president of the Industrial Furnace Manufacturers Association, a national trade organization of forty-two members making heat processing equipment.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 4 -- The West German Socialist party directly challenged the keystone of the Bonn Government's and Allies' policy in Western Germany today, warning that in 1952 it would raise the issue of German reunification in opposition to West German integration with Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Telford Taylor, head of the Small Defense Plants Administration, created an Office of Materials today to protect small companies from hardship arising from the Government's, allocation of scarce metals and other materials.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The Chicago Board of Education voted most of the 22,000 school employes a pay increase of 8 per cent today and set the minimum rise for employes at $25 a month. It also set the highest pay increase at $800 a year and a $3,000 starting salary for grade school teachers.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 5 -- A strong pair of hands joined Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen on board the Flying Enterprise yesterday afternoon when Kenneth R. Dancy, 27-year-old mate of the British salvage tug Turmoil, climbed over the stricken American freighter's taffrail after several attempts to get a towline aboard had failed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Democratic leader of the Senate in effect warned the Truman Administration today to expect no very large or complicated program to pass through the second session of the Eighty-second Congress, which opens Tuesday.

A report to the American Association of Advertising Agencies by Sydney H. Giellerup, chairman of its examinations for advertising committee, says that a quarter of the young people who took the examinations in 1949 report they are now filling advertising jobs.

A friend of ours, a newcomer from across the Atlantic, has finally found the America he used to dream about in childhood. It was a long time, he says, before he ferreted out the things that he had heard about our land, but then they all came at once, in a pre-Christmas spate of advertisements toward the rear of the Sunday newspaper.

The dispute between the C. I. O.'s United Steelworkers of America and the basic steel industry has reached what may be roughly designated as Halfway House. A strike deadline which the union deferred at President Truman's request before the contract expired on Jan. 1 is now put over until Feb. 18.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 -West Coast longshoremen were disclosed today to have voted "overhelmingly" to strike any commercial dock where a worker was laid off for security reasons. Locals of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, unaffiliated, locals from Seattle to San Diego, have been voting on the proposal for two weeks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- In a nation-wide dawn-to-dusk series of narcotics raids United States agents had seized nearly 500 suspected peddlers as the drive continued late tonight.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 4 -- Scoring an impressive 7-1 victory over second-seeded Phillips Andover Academy, Belmont Hill School of Belmont, Mass., moved into the final round of the Lawenceville invitation hockey tournament tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The Salary Stabilization Board has approved increases for four major league baseball players, but still is sitting on a substantial boost granted to outfielder Stan Musial of the Cardinals last year, it was disclosed today.
St. Peter's College gained a 72-to-64 triumph over Manhattan in the Jaspers' Bronx gymnasium last night. The victory was the eighth in ten starts for the Jersey City quintet.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 4 -Gov. Earl Warren today closed the door on participating in the Ohio presidential primary election, said he was still undecided about entering the Wisconsin primary and added that he had not given "specific consideration' 'to the Oregon situation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -E. O. Cocke, vice president of Trans World Airlines, Inc., said today that approval of proposed changes in the carrier's routes overseas would bring about a new era of low-cost transocean flying.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 5 -- United Nations troops fought seesaw engagements yesterday on the western and east-central Korean front. Positions have been approximately restored, as a result of the week's skirmishes, to where they were Nov. 27 when the Panmunjom truce talks fixed for thirty days a prospective line for a possible armistice.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Navy tonight announced plans for refinancing the defense production program of the Glenn L. Martin Company, Baltimore airplane producer.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Miss Betsy Rawls, national open champion, and Miss Louise Suggs each clipped three strokes off par today to share the first-round lead in the $3,300 Jacksonville open tournament.

Frank Z. Atran, textile manufacturer and a refugee from the Nazi regime, who last year gave $1,000,000 to Mount Sinai Hospital, donated yesterday a five-story building at Seventy-eighth Street and Madison Avenue to the Jewish Labor Committee, an organization representing 500,000 Jewish trade unionists in the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The Citizens Budget Commission, Inc., won its fight yesterday to compel the Municipal Civil Service Commission to make available its records on the qualifications and backgrounds of all city officeholders in "exempt" positions.

When any sensible person begins to think about the seventh or eighth round of pay increases demanded by labor a serious doubt as to the wisdom or integrity of labor leaders must arise. To increase take-home pay by demanding higher wages is like the stupidity of killing "the goose that laid golden eggs," because industry can create wealth only by using productive not confiscatory labor.
MADRID, Jan. 4 -- With two gestures the United States underlined today what Spaniards regard as its desire to let bygones be bygones and embark on a policy of friendship and collaboration.

Changes in the management of the Boeing Airplane Company that are designed to assure close coordination between engineering and manufacturing functions and between operating divisions at Seattle, Wash., and Wichita, Kan., have been announced by William M. Allen, president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, outlined in a statement today the matters he believed should be examined if Congress undertook an investigation of the Office of Alien Property. Senator Wiley has announced that he will introduce a resolution to authorize such an investigation as soon as Congress reconvenes.

NEWARK, Jan. 4 -- Four officers of the defunct American Packing Company of Jersey City, who had entered pleas of guilty to charges of defrauding the Government of $500,000 by shipping inferior-grade meats to Army installations in 1946 and 1947, were sentenced today to prison by Federal Court Judge Thomas F. Meaney.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- A Government order placing ceilings on the prices of white potatoes effective Jan. 19 was approved tonight. The Office of Price Stabilization said details of the order would not be made public until it is formally issued tomorrow.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Jan. 4 -- A new schedule of fares to be charged by Hoboken's taxi operators to persons whose destinations are outside this city was completed today at a meeting in the offices of the city law department. The session was the third held in the last two months by taxi operators, city officials and representatives of steamship lines having piers on the local waterfront.

The Board of Higher Education filed plans yesterday for enlarging the main library on the City College campus at a cost of $2,000,000. Lorimer Rose are the architects for the alteration, which will leave the four-story building with a front and rear of 199 feet, instead of the present seventy-six.

A new electronics industry, based on the transistor an electronics device employing germanium, that will become the rival in size of the chemical industry was predicted last night by Dr. Robert M. Burns, chemical director of the Bell Telephone Laboratories.
A first one-man show by a Japanese painter living in Hawaii and two group shows of work in various mediums are among art events of interest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Office of Price Stabilization is protesting a proposal that Pacific Northwest truckers be permitted to figure Federal income taxes and surtaxes as operating expense in computing their service rates.

The Metropolitan Opera keeps shifting its casts, and in last night's performance of Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro," the season's fourth, there were some important changes. Hilde Gueden, the new soprano from the Vienna Opera, sang Susanna here for the first time and made it clear that she understood the role and had the voice for it.

ONE of the leading literary milestones of 1952 is the fiftieth anniversary of the publication of Owen Wister's "The Virginian." It is hard to believe, in a way, that only half a century has passed since the immortal phrase "When you call me that, smile" took its place in the language. And it is harder to trace all the varieties of influence Wister's immortal cowboy has had on American literature and American life in general.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Public Health Service today reported that, due chiefly to a higher incidence of measles, the total volume of cases of communicable disease reported weekly by the states increased from about 780,000 cases in 1950 to 892,000 in 1951.

A great deal of ink was spilled in THE NEW YORK TIMES series of Dec. 10 to 15 on the war of ideas between the United States and the U.S.S.R., without indicating clearly why it is that American "psychological strategy" or "propaganda," call it what you will, has not been a success.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

Three five-story buildings containing sixty apartments and occupying a plot 75 by 100 feet at 426-28-30 West Fifty-third Street were sold by the Gerles Corporation and Rudo Associates in a deal negotiated by Mullen Woods, Inc., and Isidor Stahl in conjunction with Rowley Realty Management.

BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- Gov. Paul A. Dover of Massachusetts said tonight that he and other Democratic party leaders had served notice that if President Truman decided not to run for re-election their intended to make their "weight felt" in the selection of a candidate.

ATHENS, Jan. 4 -- A breach wider than seems normal or healthy between main factions in any democratic community, exists now in Greece. It appears to be widening at the very time when solidarity of effort here is being urged by the United States diplomatic and Mutual Security missions, which tend to be sympathetic toward Greece in everything but her internecine struggles.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Curly-haired Jackie Burke Jr. shot a sizzling back nine 33 today to take the lead at the end of the first round of the $17,500 Los Angeles Open with a 69 after the event had lost much of its luster when favored Dr. Cary Middlecoff withdrew with a sprained wrist.

Ten thousand volunteer workers began yesterday an intensified four-week campaign to raise at least part of the remaining $8,000,000 in the $20,000,000 goal set by the Federation of Jewish Philanthrophies to support its 116 affiliated hospitals and social service agencies.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- The Union of South Africa has informed the Rev. Michael Scott, British missionary champion of several South-West African tribes, that if he returns to that part of the world he will be refused admission.

" Our Children Today: A Guide to Their Needs From Infancy Through Adolescence," edited by Sidonie Matsner Gruenberg and the staff of the Child Study Association of America, will be published by Viking Press on Jan. 25. Twenty-eight experts have contributed a chaper each on the latest findings of child development and guidance, among them Arnold Gesell, Anna Freud, Carl Binger, Fritz Redl, Goodwin Matson and Pearl Buck.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Television receiver production this year may drop to 5,000,000 units, William Balderston, president of the Philco Corporation, told the company's national distributor organization today.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- European and Chinese tin producers in Malaya said today they expect a quick rise in the price of tin following the resignation of Stuart Symington, head of the United States Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 4 -- A law for the protection of youth in public went into effect in West Germany today, succeeding the Nazi youth law of 1943. The distinguishing characteristic of the new law is that it provides for the punishment of parents or other grownups rather than youths in most instances.

The Lafayette National Bank of Brooklyn reported as of Dec. 31, 1951, total deposits of $47,918,130 and total assets of $51,276,816, compared, respectively, with $43,344,486 and $46,910,733 on Sept. 30. Holdings of United States Government securities to $15,077,626 against $14,736,991 and loans and discounts to $20,599,779 against $19,656,090.
BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The United States Weather Bureau tonight issued the following forecasts and reports of winter sports conditions in New England:

The sixtieth annual report of the Chain Belt Company, mailed to stockholders yesterday, showed net sales for the year ended with October up to a record of $38,969,396 from $27,875,640 the year before.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration today set a goal of 2,930,000 tons annually for United States production of nitrogen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The American Bar Association joined the Indians today in demanding that they be allowed to hire lawyers with a minimum of Government regulation.

A new platform operating arrangement is being worked out at the New York Union Motor Truck Terminal, 325 Spring Street, under which complete responsibility for management will be given to over-the-road carriers, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday.

As plans are now shaping up, some $54,000,000 of the current Mutual Security Act appropriation will be applied immediately to assistance for India, particularly in agricultural development. Meanwhile a larger aid program has been submitted to the Bureau of the Budget, and Ambassador Bowles will return to this country shortly to speak in support of it.

Because of comparison with near-record "scare buying" sales a year ago, retail trade volume recorded a statistical drop this week of 15 to 20 per cent, trade observers estimated yesterday. Unit sales for the current week were considered high, but they ran chiefly in lines featured in reduced-price clearance sales, whereas the week a year ago saw demand concentrated in high unit-value items.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Grain futures extended their upturns of yesterday in the early trade, showing more strength than expected as the weather news from the West and Southwest was more favorable from the winter wheat standpoint, and no new export business actually was reported put through.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 (AP) -Bolton Farm, a 373-acre experimental farm owned by the University of Pennsylvania's School of Veterinary Medicine, has been sold for $840,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- A word-picture of their favorite candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination was presented today by a group that promises to be a strong force at the party's national convention. They are members of the Midwest and Rocky Mountain Republican State Chairmen's Association, and they left little doubt that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio was the candidate they wished to nominate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill will start their first conference aboard the Presidential yacht Williamsburg tomorrow with a general survey of the "cold war."
ALBANY, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported these conditions at ski centers in New York State:

The new president of the State University of New York is Dr. William Samuel Carlson, who, though only in his mid-forties, has had a richly varied experience in education, science and administration. He has studied at the University of Michigan, the University of Copenhagen and Columbia.
BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- "Bold" strip teasers and female impersonators were banned today as a clean-up campaign that has already affected eight Boston night spots gained momentum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -The Bureau of Mines reported today that tin stocks held in this country on Sept. 30 total 49,482 long tons, a drop from 52,178 on Sept. 1. Included were pig tin, tin in ore, raw materials in process and other stocks.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Salary increases for Chief Judge John T. Loughran of the Court of Appeals and his six associates that would make them the highest paid jurists in the country, will be recommended by Governor Dewey in his annual message to the Legislature, it was disclosed today.

Much of the ground rental collected by the New York Central Railroad on its properties along Park Avenue is based on the appraised valuation of the land as of 1915, an official of the line admitted yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission.

BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- Daniel Friedman, a New York tax consultant, testified today that he had reported in his income tax returns for 1949 the $10,000 in checks he had paid to Denis W. Delaney, ousted Boston Collector of Internal Revenue, as fees for producing clients.
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Six players were named today to captain the North and South teams in the Senior Bowl game tomorrow.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers, in Brooklyn Federal Court, yesterday dismissed a $100,000 damage suit against the Government. It had been brought by James Googe, a former marine, who said he had jumped out the fourth-story window of the Marine Hospital at Neponsit, Queens, on Jan. 5, 1948, because of the negligence of hospital employes.

The application of Christian principles to daily tasks will be foremost in the minds of Protestant and Eastern orthodox leaders this month and next, with particular reference to the business, professional and political fields.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan 4 (UP) -- A Maryland barber was reprieved from the electric chair today on the basis of a story that he overheard the two accused Negro defendants in the Groveland rape case plotting an escape from a sheriff who later shot them, saying they tried to escape.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- If a consumer should ask an economist where prices will go in 1952, his response might well be another question:
" AND the leper in whom the plague is, his clothes shall be rent, and his head bare * * * and shall cry, Unclean, unclean."
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Sporadic fighting for hill outposts on the Korean western front resumed yesterday with the Allies reporting some gains in a three-pronged attack.

IF Coueism is still a valid philosophy the prospect is good. The outlook for 1952 is variously described (by publishers) as "healthy," "greater trade business expected than ever before," "best season since the lush reading years of the war," and "wonderful.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 6 -- At 9:37 A. M., Greenwich mean time, yesterday, Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen of the Flying Enterprise, assisted by the mate of the salvage tug Turmoil, secured a steel towline from the tug to the bow of the listing United States freighter and prepared for at least four dangerous days of the haul to Falmouth, some 300 miles away.
WITH the January issue, American Photography Magazine changes hands for the third time since the late Frank R. Fraprie relinquished ownership and editorship of this publication about two years ago.

Out in the sagebrush of southeastern Idaho near Arco stands an unpretentious brick and concrete building in which for the first time the heat of an atomic reactor is raising enough steam to drive a 100-kilowatt turbine plant and thus light some lamps and operate pumps and other apparatus.

EVERY American has heard of Buffalo Bill, legendary figure and hero of Indian fights and Wild West adventures, but few remember the name of the writer who "discovered" him and gave him a life altogether at variance with reality.

ALONG with death and taxes, crime has been too much with us morning, noon and night and in the past year. It seemed a logical thing to start 1952 by moving in on Burton B. Turkus, noted crime-buster and author of "Murder, Inc.: 'The Story of the Syndicate.'"

Regarding the photograph captioned, "Storm damage -- the carrier Hornet after a bout with a typhoon," illustrating Hanson W. Baldwin's article, "When the Third Fleet Met 'The Great Typhoon'" (Dec. 16):

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- As for the last several years, New York City's fiscal problems are expected to dominate the new session of the Legislature that opens on Wednesday with the reading of Governor Dewey's annual message.
The first five-and-ten-cent store was opened by F. W. Woolworth in Utica, N. Y., in 1879. (It failed.)

THE All-America Selections Committee for 1952 chose new varieties of four flowers and six vegetables as being worthy of awards and recommendation. At least a hundred others vied for attention, but only these ten proved different and superior in their class, or answered a good garden purpose.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 5 -- Roman Fair, making his first start of the winter, had to be much the best to take the top honors in the $4,000 Ponce de Leon Handicap before 12,170 at Tropical Park this afternoon.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 6 (AP) -Captain Carlsen's storm-cracked Flying Enterprise nosed toward a British harbor behind the tug Turmoil under nearly ideal conditions early today. The Atlantic was calm for a change.

Thousands of ready-to-wear buyers are enroute to New York for one of the busiest market periods in the city's history. Drawing them here are trade shows, added showings of manufacturers' spring lines in Seventh Avenue showrooms, merchandising sessions in resident buying offices, and the National Retail Dry Goods Association convention.

Repeal of the Hughes-Brees amendments to the Unemployment Insurance Law is urged by the Liberal party in its state legislative program that will be sent today to members of the Legislature by Leo J. Rosett, chairman of the party's legislative committee, and Ben Davidson, its executive director.

Manifestations of another baseball campaign only a short jump around the next corner came to light on two fronts in the Metropolitan area yesterday. The Dodgers released their schedule of home dates at Ebbets Field for the 1952 season.

Colleges are doing adult management training for industry of a type that was sponsored by the Federal Government in World War II, a survey of seventy-seven colleges and universities has disclosed. The study, conducted by Dr. Robert A. Love, president of the Association of University Evening Colleges, showed that defense business courses were being offered by institutions throughout the nation.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 5 -- Three points in the last 25 seconds of play provided the margin of victory for Maryland today as the Terrapin five defeated Navy, 48 -- 45, before 2,500 spectators in Dahlgren Hall.

ISMAILIA, Egypt, Jan. 5 -- It was reported from Suez today that riotous crowds, presumably inflamed by guerrilla attacks against the British, stormed into a Christian Coptic church here yesterday at noon and murdered the beadle, or parish officer.

IN search of the picturesque, Leonid, painter-laureate of the coastal areas disputed by sea and land, has cast a discriminating eye and brandished a deft brush in many parts of the world. His latest work at Durlacher's offers up pictorial reports of these quests, faithful and exact enough in their way, but invested, also, with degrees of sophisticated design and color which transform it into something approaching the visionary.

DARIEN, Conn., Sunday, Jan. 6 -- The open jumper championship of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club's twentieth New Year's horse show was awarded after midnight last night to the veteran Peg's Pride, the big gray gelding from the Hutchinson Stables at Closter, N. J.

RENO, Nev., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Telephone maintenance men in Nevada, who said they have been refused pay for time when storm-bound, have given notice they would no longer maintain isolated microwave television relay stations during severe storms.

THE profession of bridge teaching goes back to the parent game of whist. Miss Kate Wheelock of Milwaukee was the first profesional teacher, giving whist lessons in 1886, when that game was at its height. A Miss Gardner of Boston followed her in the profession by less than a year.
MONTREAL, Jan. 5 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins defeated the Montreal Canadiens tonight, halting their winning streak at five games with a 3-2 victory on Lorne Ferguson's late goal.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Hungary accused the United States tonight of "rude and open violation of obligations" in the closing of the Hungarian Consulates in New York and Cleveland.

Three and a half weeks have now gone by since President Truman, hurrying back from Florida, announced that he was going to take "continued drastic action" against corrupt Federal officials. We have no reason to doubt that he made an earnest effort to get together an investigating commission which he hoped would be headed by Judge Thomas F. Murphy of New York.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 5 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh is reliably reported to have agreed to terms that will put the $23,000,000 Point Four program of the United States into effect.

A college friendship that began a year ago ended in matrimony yesterday, but it was by no means a boy-meets-girl situation. In September, 1950, Carol Levy turned to the student seated next to her in a history class at Hunter College and began talking.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5 -- The University of Pittsburgh basketball team defeated Princeton, 58 -- 52, tonight before 2,152 in Pitt's Memorial Field House as four of the Tigers' starters left the game on personal fouls.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 5 -- Jamal Imami, leader of the Parliamentary Opposition, charged today in an open letter to Premier Mohammed Mossadegh that certain associates of the Premier in the National Front were supporting leftist Tudeh candidates in the elections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Truman-Churchill talks are being discussed by many people here in terms of the wartime Roosevelt-Churchill meetings, and this is unfortunate, for the men and the time are very different.
Ever since the Kremlin proposed the Korean truce talks last June, the Russians have kept in the background of the negotiations. Last week they took a running broad jump into the foreground.

WHEN Robert Whitehead asked me last summer what sort of play would like to direct for the series of five productions he is to present for Anta, I answered almost automatically, "A classic -- if possible, an American classic.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 5 -- Calumet Farm's Kentucky Derby hopeful, Hill Gail, came through with a smashing four-length victory today in his first start of the 1952 racing season, the $20,000-added San Vicente Stakes, at Santa Anita Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Excerpts from minutes of a Loyalty Review Board meeting last February, made available today by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, disclosed sharp criticism of the State Department's handling of its employe loyalty program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The wholesale prices of white potatoes were ordered reduced 5 to 10 per cent today by the Office of Price Stabilization, which will seek next to arrest the rising price trend of several other vegetables.

IN common with most of the men and women who have spent a good part of their lives in and around the theatre, I am overcome with the urge at this time of year to write a piece on what are the causes of the decline of this form of art, entertainment or enterprise.

THE publishers call this a "humorous and wry little fable" -- and with some justice, for it tells of a fox whose nature impels him to snoop but whose intelligence profits not one whit from the information he gleans.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- Establishment or a separate North Atlantic Treaty command in the Balkan area, including the armed forces of Greece and Turkey together, is now being considered by the Standing Group of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, by Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, and by the statesmen of the countries that would be affected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -The United States is far ahead of schedule in supplying its quota of wheat to foregin countries under cut-rate prices of an International Wheat Agreement, the Agriculture Department reported today.
TORONTO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs hit a fast clip in the third period tonight to edge the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 -- 1, before 12,840 hockey fans.

PARIS. THE forces of nationalism that have made the post-war history of colonial peoples a turbulent one everywhere are particularly strong today in Morocco -- the primitive "Far West" of the Arab world which has been a French protectorate since 1912.

Your editorial of Dec. 18 on Uruguay's "Experiment in Democracy," admirably pays respect to one of the few democratic peoples left among us. It is a bold step that Uruguayans have taken, and we can only hope that their determination to be ruled democratically is rewarded by success, although we must recognize that we have no assurance that such will be the case.

BEDRAGGLED ship travelers who have been sprinting down the gangways to solid earth after days of rolling and pitching on the North Atlantic during the past few weeks may take some pride in the fact that the storms on the European side of the ocean during the past two weeks have been the worst in twenty-five years.

Christmas gifts that a 31-year-old mail handler allegedly rerouted from their original destinations to his home might have made him seem like Santa Claus to his wife, but they resulted in his arrest for stealing from the mails. Ironically, it was his wife's refusal of one package that led to his seizure.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Jan. 5 -Apparently the Communists are trying to starve the United Nations staff into submission on Item 4 of the armistice agenda. At least Rear Admiral Ruthven E. Libby decided yesterday that precautions must be taken against this danger, and a plan went into effect today.

IT is a great experience to read of a spiritual awakening as dispassionately objective in the telling as Ruth Suckow's Memoir, which precedes seven stories in "Some Others and Myself." The life story of her father, an American son of immigrant parents, reveals her own life, the background of all her stories.
Passenger arrivals in New York by ship and plane from foreign countries reached the highest level in thirty-one years in 1951, when a total of 864,000 persons were recorded on Customs lists.

Presentation of diversified reading material to employes by means of easily accessible racks of booklets on many subjects, much as different foods are served in a cafeteria, is rapidly becoming a standard method of company-wide employe education.

THE use of television in an unusual way is one method by which the San Francisco Museum of Art is trying to demonstrate to the public that art is not something cached away in a musty repository but is a part of everyday life; that almost any ordinary household article, if well designed, may be a form of art.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- Britain and three other commonwealth countries have made a profit of u180,000,000 ($504,000,000) by selling off surplus wool, private wool sources here estimated today.

At the first sign of what may be a cold, influenza, grippe or a boil on the neck the average citizen is likely to buy some antibiotic at the corner drug store and swallow it in haphazard doses. Sometimes unexpected complications follow this reckless practice and cause no end of trouble.

FOR THIS WEEK: When mild weather softens even a thin layer of soil, stick in evergreen branches to protect biennial and perennial seedlings, and small perennial plants set out last fall. . . . Attend to pruning odds and ends such as branches that rub in small ornamental trees, the tangled overgrown forsythia bush, and old climbing roses.

There never was a time when Winston Churchill could come to the United States and not find the red carpet rolled out for him. British correspondents in Washington and a few editorial writers in London seem to doubt the grand old warrior is as welcome this year as in other years.

Fred Wilt's time of 8 minutes 59.5 seconds for two miles, the fastest ever recorded on a flat track, distinguished last night's twentieth annual Columbus Council Knights of Columbus meet, the first important Olympic-year rendezvous of the indoor season.

For some time educators have been concerned over the lack of knowledge, among many public school teachers, concerning economic trends and developments. Under the direction of the Joint Council on Economic Education, a non-profit educational organization, a program is being developed to correct the deficiency.

THE most important event in American painting during the past decade has been the emergence of a new avant-garde, whose work might be described, for lack of a better term, as "abstract expressionism." Since the end of the war this group has become the storm center of the controversy over modern art in general.

Prevention of trade mark violations is more difficult for textile manufacturers than for those producing other types of consumer goods, it was observed last week by Charles A. Waltuch, sales manager of the St. George Textile Corporation. The company manufactures "Salyna," a linen-like fabric made of viscose rayon and cotton.
