WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath today ordered United States Attorneys to convene special grand juries in all parts of the country for a new offensive against organized crime.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 5 (AP) -The body of a Negro soldier killed in Korea has been held in a Phoenix mortuary for five weeks awaiting clearance for burial in a veteran's plot. The soldier, Pfc. Thomas C. Reed, 19 years old, died in front-line fighting.

A GIRL of 21 who hates parties, loves books and marries a rake is a fair subject for comedy: but it is not as a comic subject that Louis Auehincloss lakes Sybil or the Long Island tribe against which she rebels. The title of his previous book "The Injustice Collectors," a collection of stories about people who create their own troubles -- gives a clue to his view of Sybil's misfortune.
HELSINKI, Jan. 5 -- Russia formally announced today she would participate in the summer Olympic Games here July 19-Aug. 3, but remained silent about the winter games at Oslo Feb. 14-25.

When a man can emerge from his luxuriously appointed office, spick and span in a well-tailored suit, shed his coat, roll up his sleeves and tackle a problem in the machine shop, that man must know his business. Especially, when he can solve a knotty engineering or mechanical problem that has confounded his technicians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Truman made it plain this week in announcing a plan for sweeping reorganization of the Bureau of Internal Revenue that it was only "one of a series of actions I am taking to insure honesty, integrity and fairness in the conduct of all Government business."

NOTWITHSTANDING the passing of the old year, the tumult and the shouting have not died; in so far as the motion picture industry is concerned. With typical sobriety, accredited observers are in the midst of taking stock of 1951, and at least two have come up with annual newsworthy results.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- United Nations delegates, taking another slap at the Union of South Africa, gave heavy support today to a resolution calling on the Union Government to suspend the enforcement of its racial segregation law.

PIERMONT, N. Y. -- This Hudson River village, which one hundred years ago was one of the nation's major railheads, holds more interest today for hikers, painters and amateur camera men than for railroaders. A great, grassgrown pier -really a mole, thrown up on ninety acres of reclaimed land -juts a mile into the Tappan Zee, where the river is three miles wide.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Eisenhower-for-President forces will give the country what they have billed as "a really important announcement" tomorrow, but few expected that it would be the answer to the big question of whether General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would be a candidate for President.

The ancient controversies over the Tennessee Valley Authority grow fainter each year as the annual reports roll off the presses. This is not because the principle of federal development of electric power has been universally accepted, but because T. V. A. stepped into the breach at a critical time and is so manifestly necessary.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Coming from behind in the late stages of a close game, West Virginia's basketball team nipped Niagara, 74 to 71, tonight in Memorial Auditorium.

THE first show by a new group of photographers, The New Eleven, opened last week at Rabinovitch Photography Workshop, 40 West Fifty-sixth Street, where it will continue through Jan. 31. Just three months old, the group is composed of former students selected by Mr. Rabinovitch on the basis of their past performances in photography.

GOVERNOR DEWEY'S advocacy of compulsory periodic motor vehicle inspection in this state is regarded by highway safety experts as a move in the right direction. Now there is a growing belief that a corresponding procedure might be applied to motorists.

POSSIBLY the most significant conservation development in the year just ended was the announcement a few days ago in Philadelphia at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science that a synthetic chemical had been developed for conditioning the soil.

TECHNOLOGICAL progress has a curious way of showing up old statutes which probably seemed omniscient and all-inclusive when they were originally drafted. Now that dance notation has been perfected and put into general practice, it has become possible at last to produce a written choreographic score comparable to the written score of musical compositions, and one which presumably could be similarly copyrighted.

Dr. Samuel Belkin, president of Yeshiva University, reported last week that considerable progress had been made in establishing the university's medical school. The occasion for his report was the first anniversary of the granting of a state charter enabling the institution to expand its programs in the medical sciences.

Last year Dr. Louis W. Granirer of Jamaica, N. Y., reported to a medical society that he had been dripping post-partum plasma into the veins of rheumatoid arthritics with notable success. By post-partum plasma is meant the clear plasma of blood taken from women twenty-four hours after they have given birth to a baby.

A number of changes in the United States tax laws are necessary, in addition to similar changes in Brazil, to provide adequate incentive for investment of United States risk capital in that country. This is one of several findings in a report to be released soon by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.
TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 6 -- The negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war remained solidly deadlocked yesterday.

Hopeful of making it three in a row for 1952, the New York Rangers will oppose the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The pace the local team has been setting has aroused considerable interest, and it is likely that a crowd of 14,000 will witness tonight's activity.

Americana incunabula, manuscripts in many languages and other literary property of Roger W. Barrett of Kenilworth, Ill., will be auctioned on Tuesday in the first of four sales this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

Alfred Crimi, muralist and Pratt Institute art instructor, will speak on "Art as a Profession" at a free lecture on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The current series of the library's Art Education Project ends next week.

The flow of January reinvestment money is already visible in the market for prime investments, imparting a substantial measure of reassurance to the structure of basic yields which was so rudely shaken during the holidays by the momentary drying up of the market for the Treasury's ninety-one-day discount bills and other short-term investments.

Delegates to a special wage conference of the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., voted yesterday not to ask management for a wage reopening, March 15, for 95,000 northern cotton and rayon workers.

After listening to baroque music last time, the youngsters attending the young people's concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony heard classical music yesterday morning at the second in the Carnegie Hall series. As usual, Igor Buketoff conducted and supplied the explanatory comment.

SINCE no two authors select and interpret facts in exactly the same way, it is possible, by a change, of emphasis, to lend variety even to such a well-explored subject as the life of Washington. Although full treatment of his public career is given here, the special contribution of this excellent biography is its vivid picture of Washington's youth and early manhood, stressing the youthful tastes and habits which were to form his character.

Indians called it the Wolf Moon, knowing well the time when fangs were eager and hunger drove the pack. Most of the wolves are gone but the fangs remain, fangs of ice and cold, the great primal forces of winter's depth. The wind courses the valleys and harries the hills, and the long nights sharpen its fang.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat of Georgia, proposed today a plan designed to give an early start to Universal Military Training and at the same time appeal to eligible young men who wanted to get their military service behind them as soon as possible.

LONDON. WHEN Winston Churchill was returned to power in England, many of the other distinguished casualties of 1945 returned with him. Among them, inevitably, was Lord Cherwell, whom Churchill likes to have with him wherever he goes.

LIKE a conjurer who counts on the conspicuous movements of his right hand to distract your attention from what he is doing with his left, this thriller relies on exotic backgrounds, a little mild (by present-day standards) sex and sadism, and a case of war-induced neurosis, to prevent your noticing its outrageous coincidences, and the questionable behavior by its hero.

MYTHS rush in where scholars fail to tread. Historians have avoided a broad treatment of the period between James Monroe's first inaugural in 1817 and John Quincy Adams' in 1825; consequently, for convenience, it came to be glossed over as the Era of Good Feelings.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- This hospitable country offers a good climate, floral beauty and striking volcanoes -- if not many top-flight tourist facilities -- to the visiting North American. Costa Rica is just north of Panama in Central America, but the 4,000-foot altitude of the central plateau, where most of the population is concentrated, makes the climate generally spring-like rather than tropical.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 5 -- Miss Louise Suggs, who hasn't won a major golf tournament in a year, shot her second-straight sub-bar score today to take a long lead in the Jackson ville women's open. Miss Suggs, smooth-stroking player from Carrollton, Ga., scored 37, 38 -- 75 to go with her opening round 73 for 148.

ALUMINUM COMPANY OF AMERICA (Alcoa) originated in a woodshed in Ohio, where Charles Martin Hall, a stripling just out of Oberlin College, produced in 1886 the first shining granules of metallic aluminum by a new and commercially practicable process.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The art work of an Army officer who started to paint partly to win an argument from his wife, will go on public display tomorrow for the first time.

OTTAWA, Jan 5 (AP) -- Stanley Woodward, United States Ambassador to Canada said today the United States Government would not delay Canadian plans to go ahead with construction of the St. Lawrence seaway and power projects.

" MULBERRY" should have had a more bloodthirsty name, says Commander Stanford. The whole invasion of Europe in World War II depended on this force, but the very mildness of its designation seemed to make it harder to obtain materials.

ALBANY, Jan 5 -- If you plan this Sunday to putty up nail holes on the outside of your house or build a tool shed in the backyard, it would be well to ascertain first whether any of your neighbors are crotchety enough to complain to the police.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Small Defense Plants Administration expects to carry its operations into most of the nation's cities by the end of this month, Harry Pontius, head of the agency's field operations, said today. He told a reporter he hoped to announce the personnel of thirteen regional advisory boards by mid-January, then shortly afterward create regional offices to coordinate the program.

A momentous season was capped for Dick Kazmaier, Princeton's star football back, yesterday, when he was announced the "male athlete of the year" for 1951 -- a year the 21-year-old senior will never forget.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Pickwickian figure of Prime Minister Churchill returned to Washington today sporting a gold-headed cane and wearing a remarkable sawed-off stove-pipe hat.

BABYLON, L. I., Jan. 5 -Sunken Meadow State Park, situated on Long Island Sound in Smithtown, Suffolk County, has been nearly doubled in the past two years by the acquisition of several large parcels of land.
The New York edition of The Daily Racing Form will be discontinued after tomorrow's edition, Triangle Publications Inc., announced yesterday.

A young Englishman said yesterday in a transcribed trans-Atlantic session of the New York Times Youth Forum that Great Britain should resume her historically successful mission to maintain a balance between world powers.

A co-enzyme known in laboratory shorthand as TPN and chemically as triphosphopyridinenucleotide, was one of a number of rare biochemicals described in a scientific exhibit shown to the American Association for the Advancement of Science by the research division of Armour Co. of Chicago.

More and more Los Angeles is coming to the fore as a couture center. Long known for its sportswear, it is now developing a name in another field. The fashions of such great designers as Adrian, Irene, and Howard Greer have long been known in the East and have been available in the retail market
Anthony Anastasia, notorious South Brooklyn waterfront figure, was arrested yesterday on a charge of felonious assault as a result of a complaint by a State Liquor Authority investigator.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Last week President Truman announced the creation of a Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation that he said would "make a searching inquiry into the facts and give us the benefit of objective and constructive thinking on these problems which are of vital concern to every American."

MOSCOW, Jan. 5 -- It became clear today that the Soviet Union was working in close collaboration with Communist China and proposed to back its drive for rapprochement with Japan with economic proposals of great attractiveness.

Although the nation's railroad probably need greater net earnings to safeguard their financial stability, there is some doubt that the answer is to be found entirely in another rise in freight rates. With competition already keen in freight transportation, a boost in present rates might result in diverting more of this profitable traffic to other agencies.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Jan. 5 (UP) -- Hundreds of steel workers, charging "company pressure tactics" refused today to work at the tank-producing plant of the American Locomotive Company The exact number made idle by the walkout, which began late yesterday, could not be revealed for security reasons.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, Jan. 5 -- Sigurd Sorensen, Norway's newest ski jumping ace to perform here, again defeated Art Devlin, two-time American Olympian, in tonight's Swedish S. C. invitation event. The 170-pound 22-year-old Kristiansand athlete, who won in his United States debut three weeks ago, scored an impressive triumph.

IN a casually furnished, high-ceilinged room in a shabby building on the Lower East Side a unique drama is unfolding. On either side of a long conference table sit two lawyers, facing a slight, gray-haired woman whose voice shows warm concern as she quickly questions, searches, probes.

FROM the beginning of his administration at the Metropolitan Opera House, Rudolf Bing has sought to present operas with a maximum of dramatic credibility and effectiveness. He has experimented in this direction in various ways, and has appointed men and women connected with the spoken drama on Broadway to restage various standard pieces of the opera repertory for him.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- Premier Rene Pleven asked the National Assembly today to meet Monday for a series of eight separate confidence votes on various features of the disputed Government appropriations bill.
ATLANTA, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge charged today that several national television shows violated the spirit of the South's segregation laws.

THE pleasure of watching plants grow from seed need not be confined to spring and summer. If the indoor gardener has a warn, enclosed porch, a well-lighted room or a sunny window, certain house plants may be started from seed now.

EVER since man first put to sea shipwrecks and the plight of castaways have stirred the blood and stimulated the imagination. From Homer's time to the present these subjects have inspired writers of fiction and verse.

HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 5 -- Officials of the Port of Houston announced today that the city's public grain elevator had shipped a record total of 61,486,750 bushels of grain during 1951, a 22 per cent increase over 1950.

THE director of "Rasho-Mon" is a fellow who doesn't let the artistic insensibilities of his employers stop him. And if this sounds like a trans-Pacific echo of a Broadway craftsman's moans against Hollywood, that's just what it is.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- Eduardo Anze Matienzo, United Nations commissioner for Eritrea, said today he would leave for Geneva tomorrow to complete a draft resolution for a constitution for the former Italian East African colony. The draft resolution is expected to be completed in time for a constitutional assembly, which will be convoked in March.
The cease-fire negotiations in Korea were still deadlocked last week as the time of decision neared.

Readers everywhere will regard your remarkable editorial, "Patience Per-force," as a welcome new year's gift. Our people must show firm patience, the intelligence of long-range views and the virtue of restraint and moderation -- qualities distinguishing the statesman from the politician -- to remain the trusted leader of a cooperative fellowship of the free world.

BOSTON, Jan 5 -- Rapid deterioration of the waterfront labor situation in the closing weeks of 1951 has dimmed the immediate outlook for a revival of Boston as a leading Atlantic Coast port. Observers feel that the effects may be felt for a long time.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 5 -India and the United States signed a five-year agreement here today calling for a $50,000,000 contribution by Washington toward Indian economic development projects.

IN previous adventures Jenny Linsky has established herself as a cat of character. Once again she proves her good sense and a special kind of courage when that famous red scarf of hers is stolen by Rob the Robber, one of those horrid Mulligan Street dogs.

Spirit was lacking in financial markets last week. This may have been the result of the qualified and conservative forecasts for 1952, or the fact that a considerable number of unfinished problems were carried over from last year. There was less than the usual January reinvestment demand for securities and, as a result, stock prices showed small improvement in dull and narrow trading.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Grain prices rolled upward in brisk dealings for a half-day session on the Board of Trade today. Buying centered largely in near-by contracts, particularly March wheat.

Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee said yesterday that, if he decides to announce his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President early next month, it would not be with the intention of being nominated for second place on the ticket.

EVEN before smoke had cleared above bomb-shattered Pearl Harbor, while our forces groped to defend themselves against expected invasion, Free French authorities on strategic New Caledonia issued a frantic appeal for assistance.

Increased imports of European and Japanese hardware are expected to offset any shortages of domestic products during the peak of the rearmament program, hardware dealers predicted here last week. Current inventories of many dealers are satisfactory and gaps can be filled in with purchases from overseas, they said.

FOR most of his adult life C. E. M. Joad has been steadily churning out various-sized volumes on philosophy and morals, yet he is probably most celebrated in this country as an official wit -- a British celebrity who not only used to know all the answers on the radio but had a pointed beard and frequently, if figuratively, stood on his head.

TRADITION ordains that an opening night in the theatre shall be a thrillingly glamorous event. In many ways it is. Marquee lights blaze, celebrities gather and over all a hush of expectancy falls as houselights dim for the magical moment when the curtain rises. That, however, is the superficial portrait.

International affairs are affected to a great extent by individual tendencies to become annoyed and by malice, hatred and "cold disdain" among neighbors, Rabbi William F. Rosenblum said in a sermon yesterday morning at Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first street.

DON'T expect the theatre to be intimidated by the inconsistencies of history. Now that the town is very properly enthralled by the Oliviers' versions of the Cleopatra legend, it is amusing to consult the historians about the fatal, fascinating Serpent of the Nile.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Schering Corporation, a pharmaceutical concern and one of the largest enemy enterprises seized in wartime, will be offered for sale in February by the Department of Justice, according to present plans.

Once the annual turnover on the New York Stock Exchange was equivalent to 319 per cent of the number of shares listed. That was in 1901. Last year the figure was 18 per cent -- and annual volume was only twice that of the earlier year.

BAINBRIDGE, Md., Jan. 5 -The first 147 Waves to complete the course at Bainbridge Naval Training Station, the only Wave recruit training area, were graduated and reviewed today in four companies. Six companies of men were graduated in the same ceremony.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 5 -The United States should guarantee at once the integrity of Southeast Asia against Communist invasion to prevent "another Korea," Governor Dewey declared today in a speech here.

LONDON, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -Portsmouth retained its lead in the First Division of the English Soccer League today by defeating Huddersfield, 3 -- 1, on a rainsoaked field Hard-fighting Manchester United, undefeated in nine games kept the race neck and neck by drawing with Stoke City, 0 -- 0.

With the national doubles champions Alastair B. Martin and Esmond B. Martin accounting for the No. 1 test, the New York team turned back Philadelphia, 4 to 3, yesterday in the intercity court tennis doubles matches at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

VIENNA. IN spite of the serious crisis in Vienna's show business, which has been on the edge of bankruptcy for the past few years, a new theatre recently opened here to the complete astonishment of all the experts. So far this new little playhouse has had a good following, while the big professional theatres have felt a steady falling off in their clientele.

THE only winter "straw hat" in the West, if not in the nation, is starting on Jan. 15 the fourth season of a career calculated to make the dourest theatrical Cassandra pause in his tearful dilution of his beer.
With its fast-breaking attack working smoothly, City College's basketball team rolled to a 75-43 triumph over Union College last night at the Beavers' gymnasium.

The second aircraft carrier recalled from the "mothball" fleet to serve with the Military Sea Transportation Service, Atlantic Area command, was recommissioned yesterday at the Todd Shipyards, Erie Basin, Brooklyn.

A HUNDRED years ago in Coupvray, a little French village about twenty-five miles from Paris, Louis Braille died -- a complete human being, though blind, and great because he had greatly used his loss of sight to liberate his afflicted fellow creatures. He had both lived and died in the glorious light of a victorious spirit and a brilliant inventive intellect.
Educators throughout the state were still debating last week the issue of omitting from high school examinations questions that deal with the bacteria and germ theories of disease.

The December slump in the rate of ordering of industrial products was ended by a sharp increase in buying during the first days of January, it was reported by equipment manufacturers and purchasing agents here last week.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Governor Dewey's annual message to the Legislature will urge a three-fold increase in state expenditures for the rehabilitation of alcoholics and increased contributions for reclaiming narcotic addicts. The message will be delivered at the opening of the legislative session Wednesday.

DURING the next two months some twenty-five camellia shows are scheduled throughout the southern states. One of the first will be held on Thursday, and there are four on the list for next week-end (Jan. 12 and 13) at Cordele, Ga.; Tallahassee, Fla.; Summerville, S. C., and Orlando, Fla.

THE French Riviera is very good, but what goes on behind the front lines is equally good. About two miles back from the coast and perched on the hills that rim the sea is a second string of resorts, which have developed a passionate following, mostly made up of types allergic to the crowds who gather on the beaches.

Sir David Kelly's "The 'Counter-Revolution' in Russia" (Dec. 23) produces an overwhelming impression, nowhere explicitly stated, that Russia's economic system has not yet attained to capitalism, but is lingering in a form of organization which existed before capitalism in some Western countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Truman will resubmit his Fair Deal domestic and international program to the new session of Congress on Wednesday in a State of the Union message expected to constitute an important campaign document for the 1952 Presidential and Congressional elections.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The British people have become so inured to austerity that they hardly notice it. Ever since the beginning of the war there have been shortages of food and household goods, clothing and the little luxuries that enrich life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The United States was being forced to acknowledge this week that the freedom of four Americans caught behind the Iron Curtain was worth $120,000. For paying that price -- designated "fines" by the Hungarian captors of the United States airmen and termed "ransom" and "blackmail" by prominent American citizens -- the State Department was under severe criticism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A Senate-House group announced plans today to fight for a widening of the Social Security program to embrace 11,000,000 more persons and provide larger benefits. The program now covers 45,000,000 and provides retirement benefits ranging from $20 to $80 a month.

JUDGING by the continuing interest and concern of many school officials, teachers and parents, the possible effect of television viewing on a child's scholastic record and cultural tastes is a field where sound research data are especially needed.

Judge Robert A. Inch, as the senior jurist of the Federal Court for the Eastern District of New York (Brooklyn, Long Island and Staten Island) designated United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein yesterday to take testimony relating to the mysterious death in Italy in 1944 of Maj. William V. Holohan, an officer in the Office of Strategic Services during World War II.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Jan. 5 -- The Wagner College basketball team, paced by Bob Bosley, defeated the United States Merchant Marine Academy, 78 to 41, in a Greater New York Collegiate Conference game at O'Hara Hall today. It was the seventh victory in a row for the Seahawks, who have lost four games.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday, Jan. 6 -- Frank Sedgman, the Australian star who has shattered United States Davis Cup hopes for for the past two years, struck a heavy blow at America's long-range hopes of regaining the international trophy today when he announced he probably never would turn professional.

BELGRADE, Jan. 5 -- The economic situation in the cities and towns of Yugoslavia has begun to show some improvement for the first time since the establishment of the Cominform economic blockade. This improvement has resulted from the Government's adoption of such simple measures as the return to a partial system of free trading in food and the realignment of the internal price structure on the basis of real values.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 5 -- Russell Kingman's goal in the final three minutes of play gave Belmont Hill a stirring 2-1 victory over Noble and Greenough School in the championship game of the fourth annual Lawrenceville invitation hockey tournament today.

WHAT with the official installation of 1952 and the end of all the hubbub which preceded it, the dance world has settled down to more substantial schedules. Shankar closes at the Anta Playhouse tonight, but he can still be seen three more times elsewhere, and there is a little bit of something for everybody on the week's agenda, here and there.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 5 -- The Times-Star, one of the two local afternoon dailies, is negotiating for purchase of The Enquirer, this city's only morning and only Sunday newspaper, Hulbert Taft, president of The Cincinnati Times-Star Company and publisher and editor of The Times-Star, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -Herschel Young surrendered today and pleaded innocent to a perjury indictment growing out of an investigation of "favoritism and influence" in the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

FRANCES LANGFORD, a favorite of service men during her tours of the battle areas in World War II, is now catering to their mothers and other housewives among the television audience. The blond vest-pocket singer with the torchy voice co-stars with Don Ameche in a variety show over Channel 7 on Mondays through Fridays from 12 noon to 1 P. M.

MANY home gardeners are currently comparing notes with their neighbors concerning an unusual discoloration on some of the foliage of their broadleaved evergreens. And, according to Dr. C. H. Connors of The New Jersey State College of Agriculture, those who haven't had this happen to their azaleas, rhododendrons, laurels or pieris are keeping their fingers crossed.
SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Squadrons of French bombers launched their heaviest raids in months today and carried the war to within a few miles of the Red Chinese border.

COMPULSORY state inspection of all motor vehicles, a measure long urged in the interests of safety, may finally be adopted in New York State in 1952. This was indicated by the announcement last week that Governor Dewey, in his message to the Legislature on Wednesday, would ask for a bill requiring semi-annual inspections, costing motorists 75 cents each.

IN last Sunday's feature story about the Ford Foundation and its forthcoming program, "The People Act," you quote Robert Saudek, the workshop director, as being "troubled by * * * a great lack of production talent capable of combining education and entertainment."

BLIND flying is a relatively ancient art, considering aviation's brief history. It is possible for a pilot to take off in fog, climb through clouds on instruments, make his whole flight through an overcast and then let down and land without visual contact with the ground but with the aid of radio and radar.

IN the years just before World War I, South Florida was America's last frontier, an Eldorado of watery mucklands of incredible richness and lush tropical beauty. The dreamy little town of Miami was just stretching itself while men talked feverishly of drainage, canals, water tables and the vast unstirred treasures of the Everglades mucklands, soon to be freed from the waters by the dredges clanking toward Lake Okeechobee.

" RED" books are read by more and more people in India today. It is not that Indians are becoming more Communist-minded or more interested in communism, but that these books are widely available -- and incredibly cheap.

Governor Dewey has been asked to deny to the city increased state aid and the power to levy new special taxes to balance its budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. The request was made in a letter from Walter Hoving, department store executive and chairman of the Anti-Sales Tax Committee.

THE third novel by Hester Chapman to appear in America, "King's Rhapsody," is the romantic tale of a royal family in Murania, a mythical country in middle Europe. The story concerns the Nordic princess, Christiane, who, at the age of 18, is married to Nikky, King of Murania, for political reasons.

In Washington last week there were the stirrings of the beginning of a new Governmental year -- a year in which the political red-letter day is Nov. 4, when the voters elect a President and Eighty-third Congress.

Decca has made two handsome additions to the catalogue of Bach's recorded works. In one two-record album it has issued the Six Sonatas for Flute and Harpsichord, and it has followed the footsteps of Allegro in recording all six of the Trio Sonatas originally written to be played on a clavicembalo with two manual and a pedal board.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Jan. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Almost $1,000,000,000 worth of new industrial development is in prospect for Alberta. It will top the province's prodigious growth since the Leduc discovery less than five years ago marked Alberta as one of the world's great oil-producing areas and drew attention to its other unexploited natural wealth.

John Sharnik's merry equation (in "That Snooty, Apolitical Mink," Dec. 23) of a mink coat and Princeton University -- "something that most people can't afford to get into" -- must be an insidious attempt to lower the regal status of the mink.

Women, in their tradition as good shoppers, are serving in increasing numbers on Federal juries in New York, and decreasingly on the juries of the state and county court systems here, it was disclosed yesterday.
Prime Minister Churchill was jovial and affable throughout the Queen Mary voyage from England, according to stewards who served him in his three-room suite.
PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 5 -- Princeton's powerful hockey team notched its fifth victory in six starts by defeating Army, 6 -- 2, today in Baker Rink before a crowd of 1,500.
The cotton-futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices on active months were 41 to 52 points net higher than on Friday.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the double bill performance of "Salome," with Ljuba Welitch, and "Gianni Schicchi," with Salvatore Baccaloni, Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Congress convenes Tuesday for what promises to be an election-year session that will settle a few big issues but leave many more for decision at the polls or by future Congresses.

ONE of the curiosities of concert and opera attendance for the American in Europe is the opportunity for reacquaintance with artists once wellknown in the United States but now, for one reason or another, restricted to the European side of the ocean, in some cases all but forgotten by those who applauded their trans-Atlantic triumphs a generation ago.

Convinced that when the defense program has been completed competition for the consumer's dollar will be extremely severe, many companies already are setting up long-range sales programs to be put into effect at that time. This is revealed in a survey made last week by National Sales Executives, an organization representing more than 2,000,000 persons in the sales field.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Coal mine operators want to write higher price tags for their product in 1952.

WHEN Jesus of Nazareth was a boy of 10, according to historians, Hillel the Elder died. He was the Nasi or Patriarch of the law-interpreting council of Judaea, the Sanhedrin. Preaching and practicing a life of kindliness and humility, Hillel became the most revered name in Jewish sacred literature of the post-Biblical era.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 5 (AP) -- A Superior Court judge here ruled this week that a man convicted of manslaughter in the slaying of his wife was not barred from taking her $400,000 estate.

DETROIT, Jan. 5 -- This city of assembly lines, prodigious builder of automobiles in peace and of weapons in war, faces the awkward adjustment of being forced to work at half throttle for the next six months without the hope of again achieving full employment for at least a year.

Debutantes headed by Miss Josephine Lloyd and Miss Diane Douglas, are furthering the success of Tuesday night's performance of Bernard Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra," with Sir Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh, at the Ziegfeld Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Union Settlement.

Those who value ideas and respect the human mind have a right to be outraged by the smooth sophistries of Bertrand Russell's "The Best Answer to Fanaticism -- Liberalism" (Dec. 16). After arbitrarily equating liberalism with skepticism, he goes on to rejoice that "Englishmen who have beliefs are treated as licensed buffoons or court jesters."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Battle lines are being drawn in a fight concerning plans for the first state-financed recreation center in Westchester. It would be Rochambeau Park on Ridge Road, Greenburgh, with a golf course, swimming pool, picnic area and other facilities within easy reach of New York motorists.

One fireman was injured in a fire yesterday afternoon in a four-and-a-half story commercial building at 6 East Twenty-third Street, opposite Madison Square. The fire began at 3:15 A. M. and, after two alarms were turned in, was extinguished in forty-five minutes.

Serious problems facing retailers this year will bring record attendance of more than 6,000 merchants and store representatives at the forty-first annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association opening tomorrow at the Statler Hotel.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- The United States, Britain, France and eight other members of the United Nations Collective Measures Committee decided tentatively today to support a special high-level meeting of the Security Council to alleviate international tension, but only on condition that the Council itself should decide when this should be held.

A "minimum of 250,000 Jews in Europe, Moslem areas and Israel" will require the assistance of the Joint Distribution Committee this year, Edward M. M. Warburg, chairman of the overseas welfare agency, reported last night. He spoke before 300 delegates at its thirty-seventh annual meeting held at the Astor Hotel.

Mrs. Reginald W. Pressprich will give a tea on Tuesday in her home, 1185 Park Avenue, for members of the committee serving with her in behalf of the dinner dance for the benefit of the Yorkville Community Association to be held on Jan. 18 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

Dorothy Barclay's illustrated article, "Banishing Fear" (Dec. 16), described a new film called "Fears of Children," and the photographs were all from this film. Since we made the film -- and Francis Thompson of our staff directed it and wrote the script -- we were naturally disappointed that no such credit was given.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 5 (UP) -- The Indians today moved the starting time of night baseball games next season from 8:30 up to 8:15 o'clock, in response to requests of fans wishing to get home earlier.

The long-standing shortage of ferrous scrap, which came to a head last week and caused a shutdown of several steelmaking furnaces, probably will become worse before the situation improves, the steel industry believes.

Plans for nearly universal metering of water in New York and for a widely expanded program for detecting leaks and waste in underground pipes are expected to be laid before the Board of Estimate for action in the near future.

For six months Premier Mohammed Mossadegh has met every approach which Britain and the U. S. have made to Iran for a settlement of the Iranian oil dispute with the same words: "Iran would welcome a solution within the framework of the nationalization law." So far, he has rejected every plan put forward.

The European ledger is hard to read, the balance difficult to compute, so uncertain is the writing, so complex the entries. Yet, because Europe is essential to us, the effort must be made to discover what Europe is, what she thinks of us and why, and what needs to be done.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Social Security Administration today made public its third annual analysis of private sickness insurance. The analysis showed that in 1950 such benefits met only 12 per cent of the nation's private medical care bills.
I'M not trusting in it as an omen or a precedent; but it's gratifying none the less that the first 1952 book to reach this reviewer's desk is one which wouldn't disgrace any Best-of-the-Year list.

IN the spring of 1945 William Primrose, the violist, commissioned Bela Bartok, the ailing and enfeebled composer, to create a Viola Concerto for him. On Sept. 8 of that year Bartok wrote to Primrose, reporting progress.

IN his review of "A Pictorial History of the Confederacy," Mr. Craven writes, "Even the better Confederate stamps were engraved and printed in England." Actually, only one Confederate stamp was engraved, and only part of the production printed in England.

Canadian exporters have completed a very successful year, according to Alex Gray, president of Canadian Exporters Association and president of Gray Forgings and Stampings, Ltd. When final figures are available, he said in a year-end statement, export activities probably will reach a record high of $3,700,000,000.

FARMINGTON, N. M. -- The horseless carriage having successfully replaced the buggy, the airport is now taking the spotlight from the railroad station throughout the once-wild West. True, four-engined sky giants still bypass most back-country airports.

MUNSAN, Korea, Sunday, Jan. 6 -- Communist truce negotiators seemed "sincerely interested" today, for the first time, in a United Nations proposal for an exchange of prisoners in the Korean war, an Allied spokesman said.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Two youngsters today dethroned the top-seeded pair to gain the final of the twenty-fifth Dixie tennis tournament.

BETWEEN now and the end of February Punta del Este, Uruguay's leading beach resort, is planning to present the most elaborate entertainment program in its history. Designed to attract southern-cruise passengers from North America as well as South American vacationists, the list of special events is headed by a movie festival which opens next Thursday and in which film stars from the United States, France, Italy, Sweden, Mexico, Brazil and Japan are expected to participate.

DETAILED studies of typical towns and regions have done much to help Americans understand themselves and their country. The particular region that sits for its portrait in Morton Rubin's "Plantation County" is the farming country of the Mississippi-Alabama Black Belt.

AMONG the many Congressmen who'll be wrestling with election year problems during the coming months will be Joseph T. Gresham, currently rounding out his third term representing the Sixteenth Massachusetts district.

FOR once that salty English lad, Tim is landbound, but it is the sea which is responsible for his third adventure. Tim and his old friend Ginger rescue a half-drowned little girl after a stoma at sea. Charlotte settles happily into Tim's household, although Ginger, we regret to say, is a bit jealous.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The vanguard of an expected 25,000 buyers from throughout the nation began arriving in Chicago this week-end for the two-week international home furnishings market which opens Monday. Furniture industry spokesmen said they expect a "thoroughly normal" market. Manufacturers are expected to engage in aggressive selling, and buyers to do a lot of shopping around before placing orders.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 5 (AP) -"Freedom of information" is the battle cry of a growing band of newspaper editors who contend that the public has the right to know what its paid servants are doing.

SOME idea of how retailers appraise spring prospects will be had this week when large numbers of buyers attend major market events in this city and in Chicago. Their operations will show whether inventories have been reduced sufficiently in important lines to warrant the placing of substantial orders for spring selling.

A WESTERN in a sense and a mystery in a sense, "Winds Morning" is much more than either or both of these. It is a persuasive and mature work, honest to experience, wide in its embrace. It is great fun to read.

ONE of my hopes for the New Year is that the growing revolt against the bloodless character of so much of our more pretentious literary criticism of recent years may mount in strength. The sniping is more frequent now, and bolder than it was.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Syracuse defeated Cornell, 81 -- 79, in a slam-bang basketball game before 8,200 in Barton Hall tonight. The score was tied fourteen times.

Lehigh and New York University inflicted the third consecutive losses of the season yesterday on the Fordham swimming and fencing teams, respectively, in matches at Rose Hill. Lehigh downed the Ram swimmers, 54 -- 30, and N. Y. U. trounced the Maroon fencers, 20 -- 7.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -Hungary protested tonight the closing of her consulates in New York and Cleveland, and the United States immediately and brusquely retorted that the action was "more than justified."

THE same annual flowers planted year after year in the same place inevitably produce an impression of monotony. Repetition can be avoided, at least in a few places, by a thorough reading of the seed catalogues.

The wildcat strike that has halted operations on all fourteen lines of the Triboro Coach Company in Queens since Friday continued yesterday although the city and the impartial chairman of the private transit industry admonished the strikers to return to work.

Legislation to establish a statewide system of permanent personal registration will be a major goal of the Democratic party at this year's session of the Legislature, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, state chairman, announced yesterday. He declared that Democratic leaders and workers throughout the state were convinced that permanent personal registration would do much to strengthen the two-party system.

THE baseball folks were in mid-season conversational form the other day when they gathered for the preview of the official world series movies. Otto Miller, the old Dodger catcher, had just finished telling the sad tale of how he finally broke up baseball's worst infield when he managed Atlanta in 1923 by dismissing his least adroit operative, Babe Herman.

Diehl Mateer and Hunter Lott, Merion Cricket Club stars from Philadelphia, the defenders, paced the field into the semi-final round of the three-day invitation A. H. Lockett Trophy squash racquets doubles tournament at the University Club yesterday.

NEWARK, Jan. 5 -- Emergency Federal, state and local action was urged today by the New Jersey State Congress of Industrial Organizations to solve "a critical employment problem in key industrial areas of the state."

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 5 -- While thounsands of New York commuters from this city and other municipalities in Union County will not benefit by an ordered rollback of intrastate fares on the Central Railroad of New Jersey, others will, with the cut averaging 15 to 20 per cent.
The recent discussion in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the advisability of revising visa restrictions recalls an incident which occurred in Paris last spring.

IT isn't every boy who has an ex-circus star for a pet, or every boy who has as many problems as young Gilbert McGillicuddy. Scalawag was a horse of great charm, but he was also full of tricks which enchanted Gil and his friends, but which annoyed the neighbors.

YOU can't really call this thing of Smith's a satire: the word has just a little too much class for it. Maybe it would be all right to call it a burlesque. Yes, it would be. At the same time, one would hesitate to call it a book, though of course one would have to wind up calling it that because there isn't a better word lying around.

President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill met yesterday as Chiefs of Government for the first time since that July day in 1945 when they met in defeated Germany for the Potsdam conference. In the six and one-half years since that meeting there have been changes in Great Britain's power and therefore in her world position.
Eighteen more alleged narcotics peddlers were arrested by Federal agents and the city police in a series of East Harlem raids late Friday night and early yesterday.

TRIESTE -- Winter sports in Austria and Italy will have a rich international frosting this year. Many teams entered in Oslo's Winter Olympics will try out at Bad Gastein before moving north, and the end of the Olympics on Feb. 25 will certainly bring a southward trek of the snow-sport crowd to the traditional ski resorts of the sunnier Alps.

NOELL GOFFE is the grandson of one of the judges who condemned Charles I to death. Now in Restoration days, the threat of royal retribution hangs over the family. The grandfather has fled to the American colonies.

This winter's opera season in Germany and Austria had in the beginning a few performances which not only compared very favorably with some' of the festival performances this writer saw last summer, but surpassed them both in musical exactness and interpretatidn.

A buff 10-month-old American cocker spaniel, Norbill's Fancy Vagabond, and a black and white English cocker spaniel, Ch. Cartref Canyon, became the first principal winners of the 1952 dog show year yesterday.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 5 -- Al Dorow of Michigan State passed for one touchdown and ran 86 yards after an interception for another today as the Northern All-Stars beat the South, 20 -- 6, for their first victory in the three-year-old Senior Bowl.
MAY I check a couple of references in Edward Fitzgerald's review of my "Lady of the Mohawks?"

Contributions to the fortieth renewal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund continued to arrive yesterday. They bought the 1951-52 total to $306,217.41, as against $288,026.72 a year ago and $277,231.19 two years ago, on the twenty-eighth day of the campaign.

THIS is a brief, graceful primer of New York City, verging a little on the ecstatic here and there but, on the whole, avoiding nicely either the breathlessness or the pinched cynicism characteristic of so many books written about what the author does not hesitate to call the "primary city" of the earth.
Deep-water as well as shallow-draft skippers along with hordes of landlubbers who don't know an anchor from an andiron hut would like to learn will have a glorious eight days, beginning this week.

NOT since 1930 has a full-length Tannhaeuser been recorded. In that year Columbia brought out a substantially complete version that emanated from Bayreuth. It was to be expected that with the present-day emphasis on complete operatic recordings a new "Tannhaeuser" would be forthcoming; and here, finally, it is, on four Urania disks.

HONG KONG, Jan. 5 -- The number 4,302 is apt to have unpleasant memories for various Communist and non-Communist government officials in Shanghai before too long. It is the number of the postoffice box to which the Shanghai Military Control Commission has asked the public to write letters denouncing functionaries deemed guilty of "corruption, waste and bureaucratism."

There was talent to the playing of Marialcina Lopes, who made her debut yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. A young lady from Brazil, via the Paris Conservatory, she showed herself to be a pianist with considerable drive and innate musicianship.

Ready-to-wear and housewares clearances, "now - into - spring" dresses and newly introduced cruise wear were stressed in retail promotions here last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

PROBABLY it was inevitable that finally someone would make an anthology of other anthologies, and that is just what Martha Foley has now done. Miss Foley, of course, is the present editor of the annual "Best Short Stories" volume formerly edited by E. J. O'Brien.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- What may prove to be an important step toward a Western European federation was taken this week. It came when the Foreign Ministers of the six countries negotiating for a European army agreed to the drafting of proposals for a European parliament, which, some thought, might come into being within about three years.

Women headed by Mrs. Alan T. Schumacher and Mrs. Bedell H. Harned and including Mrs. Frederick C. Rogers and Mrs. Bronson Trevor are active in the arrangements for the bridge and canasta party to be held on Monday, Jan. 21, in the ballroom of the Colony Club for the benefit of the Association for the Relief of Respectable Aged, Indigent Females in the City of New York.

Many buyers are expected in the wholesale market here this week and a great deal of activity is expected as orders are placed to complete spring lines, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

TORONTO, Jan. 5 -- The United Nations program of technical aid for underprivileged countries should not be jettisoned completely by the West in its determination to rearm, Dr. Walter Van Kirk of New York told a conference of leading Canadian and United States missionary executives here today.

THE climbing or trailing philodendron (P. cordatum) is known and grown by apartment dwellers and home owners throughout the country. But it is only one of a large and useful family, a few of which recently have been sought out and propagated by nurseries.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 -- Charging "very evident ill will," the Loyola University Alumni Association demanded today that the school sever all athletic relations with U. C. L A. and Southern California.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 5 -- The American President Line's freighter President Arthur sailed from Pier 9 here early today, carrying with it the secret of what happened to Singapore Joe, its 35-pound Rhesus monkey supercargo.

BONN, Jan. 5 -- Some American officials here have made it clear that they feel foreign correspondents too often stress the negative side of German affairs and neglect democratic developments. These officials include High Commissioner John J. McCloy.

HONG KONG, Jan. 5 -- Recent Chinese Communist assistance to the Vietminh forces in Indo-China has been not only military but economic and technical as well, in formation reaching official Western sources here reveals.

IN spite of the steady stream of sermons, books, magazines and reports deploring the spread of divorce, 8,000,000 Americans were divorced in the last ten years. THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 5 -- The Mutual Security Agency is applying the full weight of its power over economic assistance funds to obtain commitments from the Western European nations on the expanded defense programs recommended by the Temporary Council Committee of the Atlantic Alliance.

Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen asked the Board of Estimate yesterday to authorize him to build the proposed bridge between Long Island City, Queens, and Welfare Island for an amount nearly 30 per cent higher than the 1952 capital budget allocation.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 -- Jack Burke Jr. of Houston and John Barnum, Grand Rapids, Mich., shared the lead with 36-hole 144's today at the half-way mark of the $17,500 Los Angeles open golf tournament, but the rugged Riviera Country Club was the day's real champion.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 5 -- Rachie Regan scored 30 points tonight to break a school scoring record while leading unbeaten Seton Hall to a 80-48 victory over the Boston College five before 3,800 in the Seton Hall gymnasium.

IT is happening this winter, and it has for years: egg stocks are increasing, prices decreasing. We are entering into the seasonal production peak. One half the year's supply is turned out from March through June; the price we pay is considerably lower in winter and spring than summer and fall.

THE unprecedented experience presented this past holiday of having a Japanese movie turn up as one of the choice films of the year has fired such amazement and interest in this particular neck of the woods that it rates an exclusive contemplation in this first screed of 1952.

When Captain Carlsen flashed the message that his battered Flying Enterprise was "safely in tow" he could not have realized the extent of the sigh of grateful relief that went up throughout the whole Atlantic world. It was relief, not for the safety of the ship and her cargo, but for the man.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- It's the budget season again on Executive Avenue, the block-long street that separates the White House from the big dingy granite pile known as the Old State Department Building.

NOW that the wintry blasts are gathering force the exodus of anglers to warm waters is gaining every day, and according to repots from Florida and the Bahamas the fish are cooperating with the chambers of commerce.

Despite a marked decline in attendance at the Brooklyn Museum when the hearings of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee were televised here last spring, the number of visitors for the fiscal year 1950-51 increased 21,054 over the previous year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The voting-age population of the United States increased by 13,419,736 men and women, or 16 per cent, between 1940 and 1950, Roy V. Peel, Director of the Bureau of the Census, said today. In 1940 the total was 83,996,629.

Winston Churchill said here yesterday that he considered the prospect of world peace in 1952 to be "solid." Repeating his recent statement that he saw no greater danger from Soviet aggression than at the time of the Berlin airlift of 1948-49, he added, "provided we take prudent measures."

The Soviet Government's hunt for minority group nationalists, begun last summer, is still going strong, with more high-placed individuals falling victims to the accompanying purge, a review of recent Soviet newspapers indicates.
MUERREN, Switzerland, Jan. 5 (AP) -- America's Olympic skiers started training on one of Switzerland's most famous slopes today -and everybody was happy about the results.

CAIRO, Jan. 5 -- The most significant event in Egypt during the last fortnight was the appointment Christmas Eve of Dr. Hafez Afifi Pasha, former Egyptian Ambassador to London, as chief of Cabinet to King Farouk.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- The Economic Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today unanimously adopted a heavily revised Polish resolution on the needs of underdeveloped countries. The unanimous 43-to-0 vote was made possible as a result of a deal engineered by the smaller countries under which Poland and the United States agreed not to press for wording reflecting the East-West world split.

Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade, Yugoslavia's international grandmaster and four times national champion, yesterday emerged undefeated in nine rounds to win first prize in the masters' tournament at the Hastings Chess Congress, according to a report from London.

A victory by Miss Margaret Landers of the Ohrbach Athletic Association in the 100-yard breaststroke was one of the highlights in the season's first Metropolitan A. A. U. swimming meet at the Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A. last night.
WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Jan. 5 (AP) -- A new radio station for the exclusive benefit of motorists driving under the Hudson River is operating these days.
The twentieth anniversary of the public opening of the building now housing the Museum of the City of New York will be celebrated Tuesday.

THE year which ended last Monday brought more than 2,500 new major and minor varieties of postal paper. The figure recorded in New York last week was 2,495 but other stamps which must be added to this total appeared during the final week of 1951.

Mentally and emotionally disturbed persons may find the door of help opening wider under the growing use of the group method of treatment, speakers at the ninth annual conference of the American Group Psychotherapy Association reported yesterday.

SET in a logging camp in southern Oregon, this story portrays with unusual honesty the relationship between two brothers, young Jeff and Joe Kinnery. The boys, taken to the camp by their mother, the new cook, are not made welcome by the camp owner.

A NEW school of historical writing is growing up, with Allan Nevins as its high priest. Its aim, in Nevins' words, is to invest the pioneers of American industry with the heroic radiance of the Elizabethan period or the Age of Pitt.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Despite sharp cuts in imports, Britain's gold and dollar reserve has continued to fall and her trade gap with the rest of the world to remain alarmingly large. This will be disclosed when the gold and dollar reserve figures for 1951 are published Tuesday.

EVER since Czar Peter the Great opened the door toward the West, Russia's relations with Western Europe have been a burning issue for her. Two powerful groups developed inside the country: the Slavophiles and the Westerners.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 3 -- The establishment in India of a government-sponsored program for birth control was hailed here today by Dr. Abraham Stone, a consultant of the World Health Organization, as the first joint effort by the United Nations and a member state to meet the world's growing problem of over-population.

The "abominable snowmen" of Nepal are not without precedent. Mysterious giants spread terror through Central Italy in the fourteenth century. And these "sandmen" may very well be the same as today's Asiatic "snowmen."

SAM LEVENSON, former Brooklyn school teacher with an inexhaustible fund of stories, will return to the C. B. S. television network to spin humorous anecdotes about his youth and family and human foibles on Sunday, Feb. 10, from 6:30 to 7 P. M.
A new manual intended to improve instruction techniques at commercial driving schools has been issued by New York University's Center for Safety Education.

St. John's and New York University were the victors in the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night. The Redmen, comfortably in front of St. Joseph's of Philadelphia most of the way, had to freeze at the finish to defeat the Hawks, 59 -- 57.

TOKYO, Jan. 5 -- The New York Metropolitans, an amateur ice hockey team, began a thirteen-game tour of Japan tonight with an easy 10-4 victory over Waseda University. Four of the Americans scored two goals each before a crowd of 3,000.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Rutgers scored a basketball sweep over West Point today when the varsity beat the cadets, 75 -- 72, in the field house, and the Scarlet and Gray freshmen defeated the Plebes, 70-63. The varsity game was a nip-and-tuck battle until the final quarter. Then the cadets found themselves stymied at every turn, with the Rutgers boys outplaying them to a great degree.

Department store sales, as compared with the 1951 week, did not do so well. The comparison with the "scare buying" of a year before, which was at near-record levels, caused a drop for the latest week of 15 to 20 per cent, according to trade estimates.

Mrs. Elda Mazzocchi Scarzella, an energetic social worker from Milan, Italy, who has just wound up a brisk four-month tour of this country, feels that, despite their frequent complaints about the shortcomings of their social agencies, Americans probably have the most efficient ones in the world.

THE Rodgers and Hart Song-book is put into sound by Patrice Munsel and Vaughn Monroe -- as unlikely a combination of voices as you may find (Victor, ten-inch). The soprano sounds surprisingly unsophisticated in this music, the baritone's cigarette-husky voice is blase but loud.
The United States Treasury is considering methods of increasing the investment attractiveness of its savings bonds in order to stimulate sales.
A new and highly significant note has been injected into the controversy of private vs. public ownership of the nation's electric power facilities.

" WE cannot change human nature, Mr. Marek, but we can consider it," remarks shrewd, aristocratic Ida Birk-Borovec as she observes the eccentric inhabitants of Castle Kirna, manor house of her family's ancient Bohemian estate.

New calendars which appeared everywhere and in all shapes and sizes last week agree that 1952 is a leap year. If the year were exactly 365.25 days long a leap year every four years would be all that is needed to keep the calendar running true with the equinoxes, the solstices and the seasons.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 6 -- Substantial gains in the continuing campaign to prevent blindness at birth among Latin America's natives in isolated areas and underprivileged groups in urban centers were reported at the opening here today of the fourth congress of the Pan-American Ophthalmology Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered two large Washington food concerns to halt practices allegedly in violation of the brokerage section of the Clayton Anti-Trust Act.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Extension of the state's Emergency Housing Law to permit continued use of the converted barracks, erected immediately after World War II as temporary housing for returning veterans and their families, will be recommended by Governor Dewey in his annual message to the Legislature on Wednesday.

The American Woolen Company notified the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., yesterday that it desired to cancel its present contract when it expired March 15. Union officials interpreted the notice as an indication that the company would press for contract changes intended to relax union work rules or cut wages.
PARIS, Jan. 6 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman told a meeting of his Popular Republican party in Toulouse today that he was "sure that war is not now imminent or inevitable."

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Jan. 7 (AP) -- United States Sabre jets -- outnumbered two to one -- today shot down two more red-nosed MIG-15's and damaged two others in the second day of furious air battles high over northwest Korea.

British sterling and the Canadian dollar vied with each other in the foreign exchange market last week. Stimulated by a heavy turn-over in active trading, pound sterling staged a sharp rebound from its earlier irregularity, and the Canadian dollar continued to roll along on the strong buying which has marked its course over the last month.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 6 -- It is the ceaseless wonder of many German and Allied experts here that the West German Government, under the guidance of the United States, where the practice of advertising and publicity is so professionalized, has been repeatedly outmaneuvered by the propagandists of Eastern Germany under the sponsorship of the Soviet Union.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 6 -Everyone knew it would have to break sometime, even Arthur Knapp, who had compiled an unprecedented string of victories in thirteen sailing dinghy regattas.

Many buyers are expected in the wholesale market here this week to place final orders for spring merchandise, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. With inventories at more normal levels, stores appear to be anxious to get spring goods early, it was said.
