Thomas Scherman conducted a long and meaty program yesterday afternoon. Four young musicians made their Town Hall debuts as winners of the Music Education League's contest last year, three of them playing the solo parts of concertos and one singing two major arias.

The Hakoahs defeated the Brookhattan-Galicia eleven, 4 -- 2, in the first round of the annual National Challenge Cup competition of the United States Soccer Football Association at Croke Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Indications are that heavy attendance and unusual activity will characterize the semi-annual wholesale home furnishings markets opening here tomorrow. At the merchandise mart, alone, advance registrations were up 15 per cent and a pre-market tour of the building revealed corridors piled high with new, rather than familiar, merchandise.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan: 6 (AP) -- Tony Vincent, Miami netman with an unorthodox service and backhand won the Dixie tennis tournament today, defeating Grant Golden of Chicago, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 6 -With returns of India's first national elections straggling over three-fourths of the country, the Congress party, headed by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, continued tonight to hold the lead among the individual parties in the races for the central Parliament and the state assemblies.

The 52,000 - ton superliner United States, now nearing completion at Newport News, Va., will be put through her trials in early May and sail July 3 on her maiden run from New York to Le Havre and Southampton, John M. Franklin, president of the United States Lines, announced yesterday.

Only a sound America dedicated to the principle of collective security in its foreign relations and buttressed by "clean and healthy" government at home can sell democracy to other nations, Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee said yesterday.

Mrs. E. Link has sold a tract of twenty-eight acres on Southdown Avenue, in Huntington, L. I., to a client of Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., for residential development. John C. Toaz represented the seller and L. Buck was attorney for the buyer. Title Guarantee Trust Company insured the title.

Robert Shaw reappeared after a two-year absence from the concert platform last night in Carnegie Hall as conductor of the first of seven concerts of a Choral Masterwork Series. There will be six more of these concerts, which will explore the literature of great choral music.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -Public Health Service "trouble shooters" went into action against eighty-eight epidemics and outbreaks last year and are ready to combat possible biological warfare attacks, Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, the United States Surgeon General, reported today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 6 -- The Dutch Cabinet will consider tomorrow whether to start the long-delayed conference on future relations with Indonesia following receipt of note from Jakarta concerning seizure of New Guinea-bound Dutch arms.

One of the best designers of custom-made and ready-to-wear fashions in New York also is one of the best-dressed women in the country. She has repeatedly been on the list of the ten best-dressed American women. It is her design that the American Designer pattern series of Patterns of The Times offers you today.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6 -- The steel industry made a good start in the new year when operations last week were stepped up a half a point to 102 per cent of rated capacity. Within a few weeks or so it is expected that the American Iron Steel Institute will issue revised figures for the industry's capacity.

The Metropolitan Opera mounted its first "Madama Butterfly" of the season last night, for the benefit of the Mizrachi Women's Organization, and made it a production to soften the most cynical observer's heart.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings snapped a two-game losing streak and increased their National Hockey League lead to twelve points tonight with a hard-fought 4-to-2 victory over the Boston Bruins.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- Eleven members of the United Nations Collective Measures Committee are expected to introduce tomorrow the West's counter-proposal to the Russian plan for a high-level meeting of security Council members.

VIENNA, Jan. 6 -- Because the Austrian Government has not submitted a sufficiently convincing and immediate program of its own, the office of the European Economic Cooperation in Paris has, it is reported, proposed a plan designed to stabilize Austria's finances and balance her trade.

Contracts with oil companies to supply bunker fuel and diesel oil to National Shipping Authority vessels in foreign ports will no longer be subject to renegotiation, Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer announced in Washington yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- The French, always anxious when British and American leaders indulge in exclusive discussion Of world affairs, feel some apprehension regarding the talks between Prime Minister Churchill and President Truman.

The enigma of the surcharge on postal cards is not the complex puzzle as expressed by reader L. M. Hodges, and it need not be referred to the Senators and Representatives. Your own postman will eradicate the mystery in short order.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A possible avenue of escape from the impasse in the dispute between the Iranian Government and the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, in the form of submission of the issues to the Permanent Court of Arbitration at The Hague, is the subject of interested discussion among some international lawyers here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Radio receiver production in November totaled 747,914 sets and 415,332 television units were produced, a total decrease of 40 per cent from the corresponding 1950 month, the Radio - Television Manufacturers Association reported today. The association's estimates were a decline of 38 per cent in radio receiver output and a drop of 44 per cent in television sets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., manager of the Eisenhower-for-President campaign, announced today that he had authorized entry of the name of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the New Hampshire Republican Presidential primary on March 11.

Lynn Riggs is perhaps best known to playgoers for "Green Grow the Lilacs," which was the basis for the book of the historic musical, "Oklahoma!" Mr. Riggs has often concerned himself with the southwestern part of the United States.

In the Dec. 22 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES The Associated Press reported that the Federal Government was asking all farmers to conduct an increasingly vigorous campaign against rats and other grain-consuming rodents. As effective weapons the Department of Agriculture is recommending the use of poisons and traps, both fairly expensive controls.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- Mrs. Ada Doty, central figure in a "cribbing-in-reverse" scandal at the Pine Island Central School near here, has been replaced as district deputy grand matron of the Orange-Rockland district, Grand Lodge of the Order of the Eastern Star.

The lowly punchboard, the seemingly innocuous gambling device that separates school children from their small change and older people from quarters, half-dollars and dollar bills, has become the latest target of the Treasury Department.
IOWA CITY, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Forest Evashevski tonight was appointed head football coach at the University of Iowa, succeeding Leonard Raffensperger.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission announced last night opponents of the proposed Washington Power Company common stock sale have been invited to meet informally with the commission Friday, Jan. 11.
Four new films, including an importation from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The preliminary sessions of the conference between President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill have gone well.

Bruce Bromley, chairman of the recently incorporated Election Reform Committee, announced yesterday that it would conduct a campaign for the Legislature's passage of a bill for permanent personal registration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Following are the texts of the letters exchanged by Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, and Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire on entering the name of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the New Hampshire State Presidential primaries:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A year of "tremendous achievement" in defense preparation and the certainty of a coming year of still further increased production, with a proportionately severe pinch on civilian economy, were reported to President Truman today by Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 6 (AP) -Western Germany has completed plans for a draft army modeled on United States lines to join the proposed European defense force, Western Allied officials disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -John B. Dunlap, Internal Revenue Commissioner, reported today that Treasury agents had collected $27,360,000 in the last eight months in a wholesale "crackdown" on racketeers.

In the death of Lord Linlithgow India loses one of the best friends she ever had -- and one of the most misunderstood. He served as Viceroy from 1936 to 1943, remaining beyond his term in the office because of the critical war period. He was obliged by duty and loyalty to "take India into the war" against the wishes of the Congress party, then dominated by Mohandas K. Gandhi.

Twelve-year-old Kenneth Sherman of 1021 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, was the victim yesterday of a highly erratic automobile. His injuries were slight, but the damage to his self-confidence was considerable.

Governor Dewey is on sound ground when he asks the Legislature to provide for periodic state inspection of all motor vehicles. Some fourteen states have requirements of this sort and the accident rates in those states average about 40 per cent lower than the national figure.

ZURICH, Jan. 6 -- Besides the sensational jump in the price of Interhandel ordinary shares from 1,035 Swiss francs on Dec. 22, to a new high of 1,310 in the period ended Jan. 4 when it tapered off to close at 1,275, there was still a more dramatic rise last week in the prices of German shares.

Yule logs were burned yesterday afternoon in the churchyard of St. Sava's Serbian Orthodox Cathedral, 15 West Twenty-fifth Street, in celebration of Christmas according to the Julian calendar. Officiating were Bishop Nicholai of Zicha and Ochrida, Yugoslavia, and Dean Doushan J. Shoukletovich.
NORTHLAKE, Ill., Jan. 6 -- The Chicago underworld won a victory today over a private citizen who tried to wage a one-man crusade against crime. It is chasing Robert H. Niemeyer out of town.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The traditional but obviously strained cheerfulness displayed by the stock markets at the close of 1951 has not been maintained except in a few security groups where general economic conditions do not count as a market factor.
Roger L. Putnam, Economic Stabilization Administrator, disclosed yesterday that he was trying to find a "better" yardstick for regulating price increases than the past-profit formula now in effect.

Pedro F. Rojas, personnel manager and public relations director of Transportadora Grancolombiana, agent in this country for Flota Mercante Grancolombiana, has resigned to enter the public relations department of the Creole Petroleum Corporation at Caracas, Venezuela.

CAIRO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Egyptian Government has informed Britain that it cannot be held responsible for a newspaper offer of 1,000 (Egyptian) as a reward to any Egyptian who would kill Lieut. Gen. Sir George Erskine, British commander in the Suez Canal zone.

The twelve-story mercantile loft building at 42-48 West Thirty-eighth Street, on a plot 62 by 100 feet, has been sold by the Central Leasing Corporation to the Mayflower Hat Company, which intends to occupy a substantial part of the building.

Gov. Herman Talmadge of Georgia has managed, against all the laws of probability, to get even louder and funnier. He now objects to television shows in which Negroes appear on an equal footing with non-Negroes. Just what he proposes to do about it is not quite clear, but he seems to be suggesting some sort of a boycott against the sponsors of the offending programs.

MIAMI, Jan. 6 -- The Southern Regional Council, in its first statement on the terror bombings in Miami and elsewhere, today placed part of the blame for the atrocities on the inefficiency and lack of "fairness and decency" of the police departments in the state.

Clean rivers, lakes and bays in the nine-state area of the North Atlantic Drainage Basins will require sewage treatment facilities costing $1,500,000,000 at 724 municipal and 880 industrial locations.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 6 -Thousands of immigrant families spending this winter in tents, flimsy huts and former army barracks will have no better shelter next winter, Dr. Giora Josephsthal, head of the Absorption Department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The United Packinghouse Workers of America, O. I. O., authorized its executive board today to set up a strike strategy committee of twenty-five men, representing the "Big Four" packing locals, after representatives of 150 union locals had voted to "strike if necessary."

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 7 -- Comdr. W. L. Thompson, captain of the United States destroyer John W. Weeks, estimated yesterday that the disabled United States freighter Flying Enterprise, now being towed in from the Atlantic with her gallant master still on board, had a "75 per cent chance" of reaching safety.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 6 -- At the request of West German Government authorities, the British courts are reviewing the sentences of more than 150 convicted German war criminals, including Field Marshal Fritz Erich von Mannstein and Field Marshal Albert Kesselring.

National wealth in terms of constant prices has increased considerably since the end of World War II, it is reported in a study released for publication today by the National Bureau of Economic Research.

The work of many fine organizations proves as the years pass that New York is a city with a conscience. It is a warmhearted city and its citizens are genuinely concerned for the moral, social and physical welfare of all who live or work within its borders. It is a city of hope and ideals rising from the spiritual inspiration of its churches and synagogues.

The biggest hole in the ground in our city -- since the one dug for the Port Authority Bus Terminal -- can hardly be missed by anybody who takes the straight road from Times Square to the Grand Central Station.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Miss Louise Suggs battled a strong, chill wind in championship style to win the 54-hole Jacksonville women's open golf tournament today.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- It is learned here that negotiations with the United States for increased aid to the French administration in Indo-China will be based not only on the improvement in the military situation effected under the leadership of Gen. Jean Delattre De Tassigny but also on the economic progress made in the past two years and notably since the beginning of 1952.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 6 -- Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire said today that a petition to place the name of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower on the state's Republican primary ballot for March 11 would be filed, probably on Friday.

Several thousand aliens of all faiths, many of whom came from New Jersey and Connecticut, converged on the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, 425 Lafayette Street, yesterday and filed report cards in accordance with the Internal Security Act of 1950.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers swept to their sixth straight National Basketball Association victory tonight, beating the New York Knickerbockers, 107 to 92, with Jim Pollard scoring 32 points for the winners.

The dramatic and unusual case of the distressed ship Flying Enterprise and her master, Captain Henrik Kurt Carlsen, has awakened widespread interest in the complicated questions involved in marine salvage. Newspapers, admiralty law firms and other sources of information have been besieged in the last few days with inquiries on the broad subject and more specifically on the question why the determined shipmaster has stayed aboard his vessel.

There is at least some measure of irony in the fact that we often have to work hard to induce needy countries to accept American economic aid. We are discovering that it is not only more blessed to give than receive; it is also turning out to be a darned sight harder in a number of cases.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- One hundred lamp manufacturers began their semi-annual trade show here today at noon, twenty hours in advance of the formal opening of the winter home furnishings market in the Merchandise and American Furniture Marts.

Unemployment in this state is rising so fast that New York may have one-quarter of the country's jobless workers by July 1, Milton O. Loysen, executive director of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance, declared yesterday in a year-end report to Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner.
Paul Bellam, who has not played here since 1947, gave a violin recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Martin Carlsen "telephoned" to his son last night and the Keith relayed the message to the dauntless skipper -- in his father's voice.

The congregation of the First Presbyterian Church of Newtown, Fifty-fourth Avenue and Queens Boulevard, Elmhurst, Queens, was urged yesterday by its minister, the Rev. Dr. Howard A. Northacker, to maintain resolutely its position in the community as a tribute to its first 300 years of hardships.

Two of the nation's atomic leaders agreed yesterday that it would be "quite difficult" to detect already manufactured Soviet atomic bombs even under the United Nations majority atomic control plan, first offered June 14, 1946, by Bernard M. Baruch as American delegate to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.
WESTFIELD, Mass., Jan. 6 (AP) Sixteen persons were missing tonight in a fire which destroyed a four-story business and apartment building here.

Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, preaching yesterday at devotions commemorating the sixtieth anniversary of the first worship service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, expressed the hope that the cathedral would be completed "in our time."

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 6 -Advance elements of the Eleventh Airborne Division flew here today for winter maneuvers as the Air Force completed arrangements to bring in the remaining 10,500 men from Fort Campbell, Ky., this week in what was described as the largest single troop airlift ever held in this country.

Loans, deposits and total resources of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York on Dec. 31, last year were higher than at the close of the previous quarter and at the end of 1950, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition, issued for publication today.

Steaming bowls of pea soup, as ordinary and as good as a hotdog with mustard, are a wintertime supper favorite in many American homes. This nourishing, long-simmered dish based on dried peas is not only appealing now but also economical.

In his fourth quarterly report to the President, Defense Mobilization Director Charles E. Wilson brings us down to date on the most stupendous peacetime production effort in history. There are three phases to this story: first, what has been accomplished; second, what it is proposed to accomplish; third, the problems, pains and penalties of diverting so much work and so much material to economically barren purposes.
A wave of drug store hold-ups and an increased use of forged prescriptions are expected as the result of the current Federal drive on narcotics peddlers.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France, Jan. 6 (AP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower warned today, at the end of his first year as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, that "peace and freedom are not to be bought cheaply."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- E. Roland Harriman, president of the American Red Cross, today announced a 1952 fund goal of $85,000,000. He said the goal "must not merely be reached, but generously over-subscribed."
A Hunter College mathematics professor will have the opportunity Feb. 5 to witness the graduation of his favorite Hunter student -- his wife.

TOKYO, Jan. 6 -- The Japanese Government, preparing for the regular 1952 Parliamentary session scheduled to open this month, is under considerable pressure to dissolve the Diet and end its own life as soon as the San Francisco peace treaty is ratified by the Allied Governments, probably within the first half of this year.
A more spiritual outlook to replace materialism was urged in the Epiphany sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday by the Rev. Edward M. Connors.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 7 -- Communist delegates at Panmunjom discussing terms for an armistice in the Korean war accused the United Nations representatives this afternoon of failure to make a serious approach to disputed problems.

To help celebrate the sesquicentennial of West Point, the 140-year-old United States Military Academy Band gave its first Carnegie Hall concert Saturday night. Walter Cassel, baritone, and Marguerite Piazza, soprano, were the assisting soloists. In the latter part of the program the bandsmen were joined by the 125-voice Cadet Glee Club.

Sir Bernard Spilsbury, the British pathologist whose name became legendary in the annals of Scotland Yard, is the subject of a biography by Douglas G. Browne and E. V. Tullett, entitled "The Scalpel of Scotland Yard." Sir Bernard, called "the incomparable witness," figured in famous British criminal trials after 1911.

A strongly worded and critical analysis of waterfront labor conditions in the Port of New York, together with recommendations for alleviating many existing abuses, is expected to be handed to State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi within the next three weeks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The National Federation of American Shipping said today that industry could not continue to pay present seamen wages if competition should rise and business should drop.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- Philadelphia will induct its first Democratic Mayor in sixty-seven years tomorrow when Joseph S. Clark Jr., former City Controller and a prominent lawyer, will take the oath of office at the Academy of Music.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- Merrill (Mezzy) Barber, 35-year-old Brattleboro (Vt.) Outing Club athlete, who has been one of the nation's foremost ski jumpers for many years, today dominated the annual Harold Nelson and F. D. Roosevelt Memorial events held on the lightning-fast Bear Mountain 50-meter incline.

Estates figured in sales of four old Manhattan holdings yesterday. One of the properties -- the four-story vacant building at 214 West Twentieth Street, in the Chelsea section -- long was occupied as a rooming house. Title was just closed after a prolonged partition action, on a contract which had been signed in September, 1949.

Actuated by the laudable objective of providing employment for its members as well as giving them an opportunity to demonstrate their skill, Actors Equity is about to launch the third season of its Community Theatre, a branch of the Equity Library Theatre, at the DeWitt Clinton High School, 100 West Mosholu Parkway, the Bronx.

Outplaying the visitors most of the way, the New York Rovers scored their sixth home victory in nine starts yesterday afternoon by belting the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 17 -- 3, at Madison Square Garden.

The advertising budget of Lydia E. Pinkham Medicine Company, Lynn, Mass., will be increased during the next six months. A 10 per cent increase in sales was noted during the last quarter of 1951 following a new advertising campaign, the Company said.

SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, Jan. 6 -- The Communist underground in South Korea has been cut up so badly that the Reds will be unable to carry out any plans they may have to undermine the Republican regime and take over the country by infiltration after the war ends.

The Supreme Court has frowned upon pumping evidence from the human stomach, as reported on your front page in the case of a suspected narcotics dealer in California. The court has furnished us with an ironic historical contrast.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France, Jan. 6 (UP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was silent tonight on a Washington report that he was a Republican Presidential candidate, and a high officer close to him commented that "silence is sometimes more eloquent than any statement."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -Representatives of regional college accrediting associations today expressed "every willingness to cooperate" with the American Council on Education in its drive to de-emphasize intercollegiate sports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, expressed doubt today that Congress, at its session that opens Tuesday, would approve the legislation needed before Gen. Mark W. Clark could serve as Ambassador to the Vatican.

In his superb column in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 27 Arthur Krock succeeds in justifying payment by the United States Government of the fines amounting to $120,000 imposed by a Hungarian military court against four Air Force personnel for alleged violation of Hungary's air frontier.
LONDON, Monday, Jan 7 (Reuters) -- The entry of General Eisenhower's name in the New Hampshire primary received top display in the early editions of three London morning newspapers today.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 7 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,121, for Sunday's operations:

A Wac stationed at the Army Hospital in Osaka, Japan, sent $5 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. She asked that it be listed "in loving memory of my dearest friend large," without use of her own name.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, who announced his candidacy ten days ago, declared today that he was in "an all-out drive far the Presidency" and that he would enter the Illinois Republican primary.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 6 -- The exchange of letters yesterday between Premier Mohammed Mossadegh and United States Ambassador Loy Henderson, which Washington has accepted as covering the requirements for a recipient of nonmilitary assistance under the Mutual Security Act, was released today.

It was all uphill for the New York Rangers in their game with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night, but the Blues finally made it. Thanks to a tie-breaking goal in the third period by their rookie forward, Jack Stoddard, the local stick wielders turned back the Windy City six, 3 to 2.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Jan. 6 (UP) -- The aircraft division of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation signed a three-year contract today with the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., that provides a wage increase of 9 cents an hour for about 5,000 employes.

Much of the charm and wit that distinguishes "Kukla, Fran and Ollie" has been caught by a new television show that also employs a mixed cast of puppet personalities and a human. It is called "In the Park" (12 noon Sundays over C. B. S.) and features Bill Sears and his friends, who turn out to be a thoroughly engaging array of articulate animals.

CAMP GORDON, Ga., Jan. 6 (UP) -- Coast Guard officials forced open the camp safe here today and found about $44,000 missing. Also gone from the camp is its pay-master Warrant Officer Ernest L. Whetzel Jr., whom the Federal Bureau of Investigation charged with embezzlement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -George Jessel found time last week to sign a top singer, pianist and ballerina for "Tonight We Sing," his film about the life of Sol Hurok, the impresario. He denied a published report that he was leaving Twentieth Century-Fox to take charge of television production for the Columbia Broadcasting System.
Let me offer my appreciation to THE NEW YORK TIMES for the article on "Broadway Starts a Clean-Up Drive."

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The grain markets staged a radical reversal of trend last week, changing from a weak and semi-demoralized position, to close with a strong, buoyant tone. Early weakness was largely the result of long liquidation in all pits, reflecting disappointment regarding export business and the expectation that after the turn of the year country holders would market more freely.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6 -- A Christmas sermon of peace on earth and goodwill toward men was preached on this snow - spangled Orthodox Christmas Eve in Moscow's Russian Evangelical Baptist Church by Pastor Martin Niemoeller of Germany.
Many events are planned in New York galleries and museums for this week, the most notable being the retrospective exhibition of work by John Sloan, which opens on Thursday at the Whitney Museum.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., who is combining business with a honeymoon, shoved some of the nation's better known golfers into the background today when he took over the lead at the end of the third round of the $17,500 Los Angeles open with the lowest score thus far in the tournament.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Jan. 6 -Fifty persons climbed the hill in Youngs Cemetery here today and placed a wreath on the grave of Theodore Roosevelt to mark the thirty-third anniversary of the former President's death.

On March 29, four days after his eighty-fifth birthday, Arturo Toscanini will conclude his season with the N.B.C. Symphony with a gala concert in Carnegie Hall. The event, for the benefit of the New York Infirmary Building Fund, will consist of a performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.

UPTON, L. I., Jan. 6 -- The Brookhaven atomic oven, which produces some radioisotopes more intensively radioactive than those obtainable in the reactor at Oak Ridge, Tenn., has in its first full year of operation supplied 270 radioisotopes that have been used for medical purposes and for experiments in food preservation.

WASHINGTON Jan. 6 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent over the week ended Jan. 1, 1952, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, at 177.2 per cent of the 1926 average, was 0.4 per cent below the level of a year ago but 12.9 per cent above the average for the pre-Korean period (May 24-June 25, 1950).

Despite the assertion of Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had informed him that he was a Republican, records of the New York City Board of Elections do not show that he is technically a member of the Republican party.
PADUCAH, Ky., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Management and labor today set up machinery designed to wipe out work stoppages at the atomic energy plant construction project near here.

A comprehensive outline of the city's budgetary needs for the rest of the current fiscal year and all of 1952-53 will be one of the high points of a major address on city finances to be made by Mayor Impellitteri this afternoon at a meeting of the New York State Chamber of Commerce, 65 Liberty Street.

ALBANY Jan. 6 -- The State Board of Law Examiners today announced the names of 614 persons who passed the examination for admission to the state bar last Oct. 24 and 25. The test was taken by 1,196 applicants.

An exhibition of Caruso memorabilia, shipped from Italy a short time ago and discovered by accident, will be placed on public view Jan. 28 at the R. C. A. Exhibition Hall in Radio City. Costumes, wigs, letters, caricatures and photographs of the great tenor will be on display.

Anthony Anastasia, Brooklyn waterfront figure and a brother of Albert, reputedly the one-time leader of Murder, Inc., was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court on a felonious assault charge growing out of an assault on Saturday upon an investigator for the State Liquor Authority.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned upward late last week after a weak start. At the close of trading on Saturday, the market showed a net gain of 58 to 81 points over the final quotations of the preceding week.

Senator Lodge has encouraged the hopes of those who have waited eagerly for news that General Eisenhower will accept the Republican nomination if it is offered to him, but a clear and unequivocal statement from General Eisenhower himself is still lacking. The reason for this is obvious.

HONOLULU, Jan. 6 (AP) -- College All-Stars from the Mainland passed and ran almost at will today to defeat the pro-bolstered Hawaii All-Stars, 41 to 40, in a Hula Bowl football game before a crowd of 25,000.

Efforts to end the wildcat strike of 300 drivers on fourteen lines of the Triboro Coach Company in Queens failed again yesterday, and the Board of Transportation prepared to supply extra service this morning on its own Queens bus routes to minimize hardship to stranded riders.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 6 (UP) -The body of a Negro killed in action in Korea, denied a plot in the veterans section of a private cemetery for five weeks, will remain unburied at least several more days until the cemetery's board of trustees "clarifies its policy."

The Budapest String Quartet, which performs annually for the New Friends of Music, played for that organization yesterday afternoon when it resumed its chamber music series at Town Hall after a two-week holiday interruption.

The five-story apartment house for sixty-five families at 1815 Prospect Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold by Joseph Marder, Israel Mykoff and Joseph Brown to a client of Julius Riedler, subject to three mortgages amounting to $132,644.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A special House committee proposed today four ways in which it said the Government could help the little man in business. A report to the House by the small business group which Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, heads contained these general recommendations:

Several sales of homes in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn were reported yesterday by the Charles Partridge Company, brokers. The brownstone house at 507 First Street was sold by Kathryn Miles to Alfred and Agnes Cammann, and the four-story building at 54 Montgomery Place was purchased for investment by Irving Sobelsohn from Mrs. Felice J. Lourie. Charles Rickerson acted as co-broker in that sale.

Increased retail sales are in prospect for the coming spring season, according to a survey released over the week-end by the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The group begins its forty-first annual convention today at the Statler Hotel.

AMSTERDAM, an. 6 -- An urgent plea for restoration of convertibility of the guilder was published in the Holland Bank Union's December review. It urged the Government to gradually abolish all foreign exchange controls. The review held that cautious reintroduction of convertibility would be possible because of the recent Dutch monetary recovery.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- Although Premier Rene Pleven has asked the National Assembly for eight votes of confidence on which the balloting is scheduled tomorrow, it appeared tonight, in the light of the positions taken in the parties, that no more than one vote would be taken and that the first cabinet since the June elections would resign tomorrow night.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 6 -- Tax problems and redistricting will be among the major items for the biennial sixty-day session of Virginia's Legislature, which opens here Wednesday noon.

And they had arrived at this place of doubtful eminence, one might say, by directly opposite routes.

The first of three modernized buildings that will comprise the Mary Manning Walsh Home for the Aged at 418 East Fifty-eighth Street was dedicated yesterday afternoon by Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 -- Measured by the yardstick of America's experience in World War II, the program for equipping the Army with new tanks that meet the highest postwar standards is running six to nine months behind schedule.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- The Commodity Exchange Authority announced today that the value of commodity futures trading increased $14,792,194,000 in fiscal 1951, with cotton trading more than doubled in value over the previous year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Howard C. Petersen, president of the Fidelity-Philadelphia Trust Company, will be finance chairman of the Republican Eisenhower-for-President movement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Republicans supporting General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidency were elated today over his statement in Paris and predicted it would pave the way for his nomination and election.

Soviet Russia has now made it plain that its main reason for seeking at this time a special top-level meeting of the Security Council of the United Nations is to shift the Korean armistice negotiations to a larger political forum. Here it could attempt to use the world's hope for peace as a means of paving the way for a settlement which it has not achieved by proxy war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, announced today that he would enter the name of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee in the Democratic presidential primary in Ohio.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 8 -- The disabled United States freighter Flying Enterprise and her two-man crew have passed the halfway mark in the 300-mile tow to Falmouth harbor. The weather outlook still is favorable, according to the latest communique yesterday from the headquarters here of United States naval forces in the eastern Atlantic.

ATHENS, Jan. 7 -- The Greek Government has advised United States diplomatic authorities that the "wish of the Greek people is that the nation's armed forces should come directly under United States command -- if feasible, under Eisenhower."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- It is up to those who will be delegates to the Republican National Convention, opening at Chicago July 7, whether or not General of the Army Eisenhower is to be their candidate for President in 1952. He made this perfectly clear in his statement sustaining what was said at a press conference yesterday by the manager of his Republican volunteer supporters, Senator Lodge.

DETROIT, Jan. 7 -- The new tanks rushed into production after the Communist assault on the Republic of Korea eighteen months ago have not yet been issued to the troops because they are unacceptable to the Army Field Forces.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Jan 8 (AP) -- Allied troops fought within grenade-throwing distance of an important outpost position on the western front of Korea yesterday, but the Communists forced them back.

BONN, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Germany's industrial Ruhr will be able to jump steel production by 30 per cent to 19,000,000 or 20,000,000 tons twelve months after the Schuman Plan starts, Michael Harris, American chief of the Mutual Security Agency in Germany, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The question of what effect recently imposed price ceilings might have on production of potatoes this year was raised today in farm circles here.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Two Sydney newspapers today published sharp criticism of the Australian system of amateur tennis that kept Davis Cup star Frank Sedgman from turning professional.

It was an excellent collection that Walter Florell presented to the press yesterday in his showroom at 29 East Fifty-third Street. Mr. Florell made news with his new envelope shapes in hats that cleared the hair at the back to provide room for the now-accepted poodle-dog cut.
CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 7 -- Governor Adams accepted General Eisenhower's statement as confirmation of a green light given yesterday by Senator Lodge as to the general's Republicanism.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky was just about the only United Nations delegate who had anything to say on the record today about General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's indications that he would accept the Republican nomination for President.
Walter Hoving, singled out for sharp criticism in Mayor Impelletteri's review of city finances yesterday, replied with another attack on the Mayor's financial policies.
Two new wallpaper collections, being shown in connection with the semi-annual wholesale home furnishings market, give evidence of common sources of inspiration.

The vogue of new convertible preferred stock continues to be widespread in the new-issue market. At the moment there are nine issues of such stock aggregating more than $91,000,000 in par value in registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Department of Defense declared today in answer to inquiries about the status of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower that Army regulations "do not require an officer to resign his Army commission if he announces his willingness to accept a nomination for public office if tendered * * *."

The Communications Workers of America, C. I. O., announced yesterday it had asked the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board to conduct an election to determine whether 4,600 New York employes of the Western Union Telegraph Company still wanted to be represented by the left-wing American Communications Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today certified to the Federal District Court for New Jersey the results of balloting on the $16,000,000 plan of reorganization for the New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company.

A delicate "high suspension" arch was the focal point around which Herman Delman styled many of his latest spring shoes, exhibited yesterday at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel. This subtle variation on the shoe silhouette, called "pons bella" (beautiful arch), indicated an increasing emphasis on delicate, femininely fashioned shoes.

HONOLULU, Jan. 7 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California, himself an avowed candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, said today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would be a very powerful candidate for President. He expressed "very great admiration for the general both as a soldier and a great American citizen."

Chuck Dressen, who will be honored by the New York Press Photographers at a dinner at Leone's tonight, arrived in town yesterday and learned that Roy Campanella, his industrious catcher, had changed his mind about permitting surgery on his left elbow.

A reception honoring the Rev. Dr. J. Henry Carpenter for a quarter century of service to Brooklyn's religious enterprises was held last night at the Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, St. Felix Street, Brooklyn.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin will leave for Washington by plane tomorrow to attend the conference Friday of French, British and United States military authorities on the Indo-Chinese war. He will be accompanied by Admiral Henri Louis Nomy and Gen. Rene Cogmy.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Chief interest in the stock markets here switched today to the oil shares which had some good rises as a result of the record oil output in 1951. Shipping shares also were active again.

Three outstanding soloists and the Philharmonic-Symphony under George Szell donated their services for a brilliant concert in Carnegie Hall last night. It was the first of two such events this season for the benefit of the orchestra's Pension Fund, and it delighted a large audience.

TRENTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The State today announced it had denied claims for unemployment compensation by 780 striking agents of the Prudential Insurance Company in New Jersey. The denial came in a ruling by Edward J. Hall, chief of unemployment benefits.

A fight for control of the Segal Lock and Hardware Company, Inc., got under way yesterday in Supreme Court when Justice Bernard Botein set Monday for argument on a motion which seeks to bar the certification of directors elected Oct. 5, because of alleged irregularities.
In some instances apologizing for their "lateness," thirty-three donors yesterday brought the New York Times Neediest Casese Fund to $307,041.41 by contributing $445 in gifts ranging from $200 to $2.

FREDERICK BUECHNER, a teacher at Lawrenceville School, had his first novel published two years ago when he was only 23. It was called "A Long Day's Dying" and a small group of literary intellectuals professed to admire it very much. As one who dissented violently from their enthusiastic verdict, I take pleasure in reporting today that Mr. Buechner's second novel, "

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- When General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower finally leaves his post as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe for the Presidency of either the United States or of Columbia University, his successor here will almost certainly be an American.

" Musical Talent in Our Schools" has chosen twenty-one students for its second annual series of broadcasts, it was announced yesterday. The series, jointly sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and station WQXR, will begin on March 16.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The winter home furnishings market opened here today in the American Furniture and Merchandise Marts with retailers placing individual small quantity orders in aggregate volume far greater than was expected. More than 7,413 retailers registered at the American Furniture Mart during the day and the Merchandise Mart, which does not supply actual figures, reported attendance as "more than satisfactory."

SEATTLE, Wash., Jan. 7 -- Seven public utility districts of western Washington, seeking to purchase electric properties and certain assets of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, hit a snag today.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- An open fight between Governor Dewey and the Republican state organization on the question of substituting permanent personal registration of voters for the existing annual registration system appeared in the making today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The State of Tennessee may not impose sales and use taxes on materials sold to concerns under contract to the Atomic Energy Commission on a cost-plus-fixed-fee basis, the Supreme Court ruled today. It upheld a ruling by the Tennessee Supreme Court that, although the taxes are not forbidden by the Constitution, they are prohibited by the Atomic Energy Act of 1946.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Dollar interests lost in the Supreme Court today in an action they had hoped would restore to them immediate control of the $68,000,000 American President Lines, presently operated by the Federal Government.
Frank Nawrocki, business agent of Local 808 of the International Longshoremen's Association, was arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court on an indictment charging two counts of perjury.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania applied today to the State Public Utility Commission for a $32,355,600 annual increase in rates for its 2,000,000 customers.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its associated Bell System telephone companies announced yesterday that they had appealed to the National Production Authority for an allotment of aluminum in the first quarter of 1952.

Eleven thousand unionized millinery workers in the metropolitan area agreed last night to drop demands for an immediate wage increase and to cooperate with their employers in trying to stimulate the demand for women's hats.

TRENTON, Jan. 7 -- The New Jersey Legislature will convene at noon tomorrow for its 176th session, with highway improvement, crime prevention and the 1952 Presidential election among the foremost topics.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- The Wald-Krasna Producing unit has worked out a one-year extension of its contract as a semi-autonomous operation within the framework of R. K. O.-Radio Pictures, it was announced today by Howard Hughes, managing director and majority stockholder of R. K. O.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a jury must decide whether an "evil mind" was in concurrence with an "evil hand" when Joseph Edward Morissette removed three tons of used bomb casings from an Army Air Force bombing range in Michigan and sold them for $84.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 7 -- The groundwork for a national educational television network was established here today at a meeting of educators from nineteen states. The meeting was called to discuss the plan of a committee that had been named by Mayor Joseph M. Darst.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 7 -- The Michigan Supreme Court, upholding the constitutionality of a state law outlawing strikes by public employes, ruled today that the fifty-nine day Detroit transit strike last summer was illegal.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week fell 26 per cent below abnormally high levels of the like week last year, but matched those of the corresponding 1950 week, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Miss Maureen Connolly, the second youngest player ever to win the national tennis championship, yesterday was chosen woman athlete of the year for 1951 in the annual Associated Press poll.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 7 -- Chester Bowles, United States Ambassador to India, will advocate in Washington additional aid to India beyond the $50,000,000 grant agreed upon by the Technical Cooperation Administration Saturday, he indicated at a press conference today.
The address yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York follows:

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The dramatic combination of a missed putt, a spectacular approach shot and a stretch charge sent the twenty-sixth annual Los Angeles open golf tournament into a three-way tie late today and a play-off tomorrow for the top money of the $17,500 purse.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Trans World Airlines contended today it should be allowed to operate from Bombay to Tokyo in order to give the United States two round-the-world air routes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Strikes cost the country fewer work days in 1951 than in any year since World War II, the Bureau of Labor Statistics asserted today.
More guns and less butter now are essential to the mobilization drive, not only to preserve freedom but to prevent jolting deflation, a leading business economist declared last night.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- The Soviet Union has asked the United Nations to adopt a definition of aggression under which a country that refused to take action against armed bands hostile to another nation would be branded as an aggressor in case of war.

The apathetic attitude of physicians toward arthritis may lead to socialized medicine in this country, Gen. George C. Kenney, Commander of the Allied Air Force in the Southwest Pacific in World War II, declared yesterday.
TRENTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The 1952 horse racing season in New Jersey will be six days longer than last year's program.

Thirty-five competing Federal medical agencies must be streamlined by setting up a Federal Department of Health before any recommendations of President Truman's new Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation can be effective, the President was advised by letter yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The active demand that was responsible for the sharp recovery in grain futures late last week faded from the picture today, and all cereals were lower. Longs, who had bought on the break of a few days back, took profits freely, while there was no important support from commercial interests to stimulate a general demand.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 7 -- "Temporary insanity" was cited by Walter Wanger, film producer, in Superior Court today as the reason he shot his wife's agent in a Beverly Hills parking lot Dec. 13.

BRITISH HEADQUARTERS, Suez Canal Zone, Jan. 7 -- A strike of 1,500 Canal Company workers in Port Said ended late this afternoon as the Egyptian workers returned to their jobs. The strike had tied up all movements in the port for some hours today, paralyzing loading and unloading of ships, mooring and pilot activities.
" Fair and Warmer" was the title of Emme's spring collection of hats shown yesterday at the Stork Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Strong movements in the Eighty-second Congress for reducing foreign aid and for a much harder line toward the Soviet satellite countries were forecast today on the eve of the second session.

One hundred and fifty years ago next March 16 the bill authorizing a United States Military Academy at West Point became law. One hundred and fifty years ago next July 4 the Academy actually opened, with twelve cadets in attendance. Since the Amy of that period was minutely small, and since West Point merely continued a sort of apprentice system already in use, the glittering future of the Academy was not foreseen.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 -- Assets of $16,070,255.76 were listed today in the first inventory filed in the Superior Court on the estate left by William Randolph Hearst.

VIENNA, Jan. 7 -- Because an Austrian Court of Administration last week returned to Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg, exiled Austrian Fascist leader, eighty-two estates, castles and ancient fortresses he had owned before 1938, Socialist protest meetings interrupted work all over Austria today.

Young women, including Miss Nancy Adler and Mrs. Donald Hirst, are aiding the entertainment known as a "Trifles and Treasures" luncheon to be given tomorrow in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Society of Memorial Cancer Center. A feature will be a fashion showing of the latest costumes for spring wear.

HAVING recently recovered from the "crick" in our back, occasioned through carrying a small deer over a Maine mountain, we feel sympathetic rather than envious toward the hunter who hauled the biggest buck of the season out of the Maine woods.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- Britain, France, Turkey and the United States introduced a plan in the United Nations General Assembly today for the continued but limited operation of the Palestine Conciliation Commission.

" It's a Big Country," an episodic drama produced by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which arrives at Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Among the featured performers in the eight sequences of the picture are Ethel Barrymore, Gene Kelly, Van Johnson, Fredric March and Gary Cooper.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- The Eastern Air Defense Force at near-by Stewart Air Force Base announced today that the Great Lakes region would undergo a simulated air attack on Saturday as part of an exercise to sharpen the eyes and ears of the Ground Observer Corps.
If wealth was what Joseph Graber sought when he arrived in the United States from Poland in 1929, he found it in Brooklyn yesterday by becoming the father of quadruplets.

Short Symphony, by Howard Swanson, 42-year-old New York Negro composer, was judged the best orchestral work performed in New York between October, 1950, and the end of last year by the New York Music Critics Circle, when it met yesterday afternoon in the clubroom of THE NEW YORK TIMES to vote its annual awards.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 8 -- Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy, senior United Nations delegate to the Korean truce conference, expressed doubt openly yesterday that the Communists at Panmunjom were negotiating in good faith to end the eighteen-month-old war.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- A copy of that hat Winston Churchill wore on his arrival in the United States last Saturday can be had by anyone who is willing to pay $9.10 and does not mind a reputation for eccentricity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Truman today selected Harry A. McDonald, Michigan Republican and chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to be Administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, succeeding W. Stuart Symington, whose resignation, effective Jan. 15, was accepted by Mr. Truman "with utmost reluctance."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Wiggins Airways, Inc., pressed before a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner today its application for renewal of a permit to operate local air service in New England.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court dismissed today an appeal by two airlines from an order requiring them to make $1.75 refunds on certain tickets sold for flights between San Francisco and Los Angeles.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, in the fiscal year ended with October, achieved the highest sales and earnings in its history, despite tax charges which climbed to $75,750,000 from $39,200,000 the year before, Harvey S. Firestone Jr., president, reported yesterday.

Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis and former president of the American Red Cross, received the Medal of Merit and a citation from President Truman for humanitarian achievements last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on the eve of Mr. O'Connor's sixtieth birthday.

Legal representatives of the Security Bureau, Inc., made 300 court appearances last year in connection with cases of theft and pilferage on New York piers, it was announced yesterday by Benn Barber, bureau president.

The first poster of the $2,000,000 drive of the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America was presented yesterday to Mrs. Vincent R. Impellitteri, wife of the Mayor, at Gracie Mansion. The presentation was made in the presence of Nathan M. Ohrbach, general co-chairman of the campaign, by Scout Paul Fitzgerald of 3 Pomander Walk and Cub Scout Stephen Weiner of 41 East Ninety-sixth Street.

Tammany Hall, through its executive committee, voted last evening unanimous approval of a legislative program that could have the effect of reforming Tammany Hall itself, the election law under which it and other political machines operate, and the local government that has resulted from machine government here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Larry Jim Gross, the 6 - year - old "March of Dimes" poster child, wore his Hopalong Cassidy costume in to see President Truman today, and got a Presidential directive to draw both his toy six shooters and clear the crowd out of his office.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky said today that Maxim M. Litvinov, who died in Moscow last week, was "a magnificent diplomat" but that Vyacheslav M. Molotov, who succeeded him in the post now held by Mr. Vishinsky, was "a still more magnificent diplomat."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, a 59-year-old four-star officer who, as a long-time associate put it today, has done "just about everything in the Air Force book," intends to retire in the near future.
The bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation served notice yesterday that it planned to eliminate 10 per cent of its Bronx bus service, effective Jan. 20.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Text of General Headquarters communique 1,122 for Monday's operations:
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- Two city departments here were being run today under dual control -- and not for the sake of efficiency.

One must again register that sense of dismay which contemporary French politics brings to all France's friends in the West It is hard to avoid an element of exasperation as one watches Government after Government going down at crucial moments over issues that in themselves are often trivial, even though they mask profound social and economic maladjustments.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Reynolds Metals Company has issued a letter of intent for the engineering and construction of a $42,000,000 alumina plant in San Patricio County, Tex., to C. F. Braun Co., Alhambra, Calif., R. S. Reynolds Jr., president of Reynolds Metals, announced today.

Operations of steel mills are scheduled to increase this week to 102.1 per cent of rated capacity and turn out 2,041,000 tons of steel ingots and castings, despite the closing of some furnaces because of a steel scrap shortage, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Amid all the time, money and effort expended on democratic propaganda in Europe, it seems incredible that so little attention should have been paid to the problem of what to do about Iron Curtain escapees once they have managed to slip through to the West.

A renewal of the dock strike that virtually paralyzed deep sea shipping here for twenty-five days last fall was narrowly averted last night when the strike committee of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., rejected a proposal calling for a port-wide work stoppage at 8 A. M. today.

The program offered by the Little Orchestra Society last night in Town Hall was one of the liveliest and most interesting that this highly enterprising instrumental organization has given here. The concert began with Hindemith's score for viola and small orchestra, "Der Schwanendreher."

Your editorial of Jan. 2 advocates the complete prohibition of billboards along the New York State Thruway and states that Governor Dewey is represented as feeling that a few uniform hotel advertising signs might be permitted at the approaches to the cities along the route.
For the second straight week, unbeaten Kansas topped the nation's college basketball teams in The Associated Press poll of sports writers and sports broadcasters yesterday.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 8 -- (Reuters) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's statement yesterday that he would continue as Atlantic Supreme Commander until clearly called to political duty kept London newspaper editorial writers busy today, but almost as neutral as the general.

The Churchill conversations in Washington and the tacit acknowledgment from Paris that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will be a candidate for the Presidency again emphasize the crisis that confronts Western Europe during 1952.

With the arrival this week of its first shipment of caviar from Turkey, Macy's announces plans for offering regularly this variety of roe from sturgeon caught in the Black Sea. The caviar is packed, under the store's Lily White label, in a one-ounce jar for $2.14, two ounces for $4.24, four ounces $8.47.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, said today the Korean armistice talks had reached a deadlock but that the Soviet proposal for a special high-level meeting of the United Nations Security Council was merely intended to provide "additional assistance," not to shift the negotiations from Panmunjom to the Security Council.

United States Attorney Frank J. Parker in Brooklyn yesterday said that his office would convene a special grand jury to look into possible crime syndicates in the Eastern District of New York as soon as possible. Mr. Parker was one of the ninety-three Federal prosecutors directed to take such action in a week-end announcement by Attorney General J. Howard McGrath.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- John Thomas Schneider, New York lawyer and business executive, is slated for selection as Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs. President Truman is expected to send his name to the Senate to fill the long vacant post sometime this week.

A well-known estate in Rye, N. Y., has been sold by Mrs. Robert M. Smith to Frank M. Donohue of the Donohue Sales Corporation of New York, Blakeman Quintard Meyer, broker in the sale, reported yesterday. The property is on Kirby Lane near Long Island Sound and overlooks Manursing Island. It consists of almost nine acrest emd a fifteen-room English-styleI stone house which was originally built for the late Waldron Williams.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 7 -- The French Government crisis has serious ramifications for Western Germany. Allied and German officials made no secret of their consternation on the eve of resumption tomorrow of negotiations to grant near-sovereignty to the Bonn regime.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- King George VI, Queen Elizabeth and Princess Margaret will spend a brief time in South Africa during the spring cruise that the King will take to regain his strength. He underwent an operation for the removal of one lung last September.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 7 -- A mob of 1,000 adherents of the extreme right-wing Herut party today stormed through police barricades, set fire to or demolished automobiles and stoned the Knesset (Parliament) building in protest against the Israeli Government's intention to negotiate directly with West Germany for reparations.

Mayor Impellitteri's "major address on city finances," delivered before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, should make for better understanding of the city's budget and tax problems, even among those who differ with him.

With the reconvening of the Congress it is to be hoped that action will be taken to end the serious economic discrimination that has been in operation against practicing physicians and dentists in the United States since Jan. 1, 1950.
The cost of running the city in the fiscal year beginning July 1 will be about $200,000,000 more than the $1,336,400,575 appropriated for 1951-52, Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday.

The stock market ran into a moderate flurry of selling yesterday afternoon that forced prices back from the peaks set during the forenoon. In effect, the market staged another of its recent inconclusive performances. General Eisenhower's statement that he would be willing to accept a clear mandate to run as Republican Presidential nominee failed to raise any ripples in financial circles.
The twenty-fifth anniversary of the first trans-Atlantic telephone conversation was celebrated yesterday in a four-way call linking New York, Washington and two points in England.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Stanley Kramer, film producer, today began a $1,000,000 personal libel action against the Wage Earners Committee of the U. S. A., Inc., which has attacked him in a circular as being "notorious for his Red-slanted, Red-starred films."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Henry H. Fowler, a Washington attorney and former manager of the War Production Board, will become Administrator of the National Production Authority tomorrow. He has been deputy administrator since last September.

IN the ordinary course of events no one pays attention to the entry of any nation in the Olympic Games, including that of the United States. But when Soviet Russia formally accepts the invitation to compete in the great international sports carnival, eyebrows raise questioningly and suspicions stir. Everyone asks: What does it mean?
A New Yorker who had lost more than forty pints of blood in less than seventy-two hours was alive yesterday with the aid of forty-two pints of blood withdrawn from a hospital and a Red Cross bank.
The cotton futures market closed yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange 15 to 31 points net lower.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Truman today increased the customs duties on hatters' fur, effective on Feb. 8, but warned the Tariff Commission that higher tariffs imposed for the protection of American industry must not remain in effect too long lest they invite retaliatory actions and result in raising unnecessary barriers to world trade.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The Army Corps of Engineers has approved a program for deepening the Hudson River channel between New York City and Albany to thirty-two feet, a depth sufficient to accommodate merchant shipping constructed during World War II.

A three-alarm fire on Saturday that all but destroyed a commercial building at 6 East Twenty-third Street swept away a large part of the life work of Jacques Lipschitz, sculptor. In the forty-five minute blaze Mr. Lipchitz' studio, at the top of the building, became a burial ground for plaster and composition models, the originals of which are in museums and private collections.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, headed by Harry Bridges, must pay $750,000 in damages to an Alaska lumber company.

December linage in seven New York daily newspapers was 3.44 per cent below the same month a year ago, according to figures made available yesterday. The total for the month was 13,328,123 lines. Automotive showed the most serious loss at 31.73 per cent less than a year ago.

French machine tools are arriving here on a large scale, with deliveries expected to continue through the entire year, it was reported yesterday by Herbert Winter, partner in Winter Wolff Co., 76 Beaver Street. Shipments cludne products made by fifteen French machinery builders.

Denis M. Hurley, corporation counsel for the city, will be the speaker at the Brooklyn Real Estate Board's forty-seventh anniversary dinner at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, on Saturday, Jan. 19. Frederick V. Goess is chairman of the dinner committee.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The emergence of a new style in fashions for the home is under discussion by many attending the semi-annual wholesale home furnishings markets here.

Now that the holidays are over and a certain young man is back at school and already writing home concerning emergencies requiring the expenditure of funds, it is possible to view those holidays with a detachment which, a short time ago, was out of the question.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Britain ordered a new cheek-up today on her atomic scientists, whose alleged unreliability in the past supposedly has been one of the reasons for United States reluctance to exchange atomic information with this country.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- James D. Hopkins of North Castle, an attorney, was elected chairman of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors this afternoon to succeed Jefferson Armstrong of Yonkers. Mr. Hopkins, a Republican, defeated Supervisor John E. Tobin of Yonkers, a Democrat, by 31 to 7.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill reviewed the military and production problems of the Grand Alliance today in two long private conferences at the White House.

The handling of the wildcat strike of Triboro Coach Corporation employes on fourteen bus routes in Queens is in marked contrast to the treatment of some previous unauthorized stoppages. This time Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private bus industry, promptly announced he would not consider the strikers' grievances until they returned to work in accordance with their contract, which provides for continuance of operations pending the processing of their complaints.

An underwriting syndicate headed by the Van Alstyne Noel Corporation and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Beane will place on the market today an issue of 240,000 new shares of the Atlas Plywood Corporation convertible preferred stock at $23.75 a share.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first eleven months of 1951, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $5,069,391, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $4.12 a share on the company's outstanding capital stock, and compared with a net of $7,349,461, or $5.97 a share, in the eleven months to Nov. 30, 1950.

Net asset value of the capital stock of the Lehman Corporation was higher on Dec. 31, 1951, than at the end of any previous quarter in the investment concern's twenty-one-year history, it was announced yesterday by Robert H. Lehman, president, in his semi-annual report to stockholders.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- After an inspection tour today, Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, commander of the First Army, described as satisfactory advance preparations for Exercise Snowfall, a joint Army-Air Force field maneuver to be held here next month with 33,000 troops and hundreds of carrier and fighter planes participating.

The leasehold of the China Clipper Building, a landmark at Journal Square in Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by Theodore Lappas to an investing client of Gerald Kanengiser, attorney, in a transaction negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.

Meyer Feldman has purchased the four-family dwelling at 45 East Ninety-fifth Street, Brooklyn, from Beke Novick. Louis Belenko was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Jan. 7 (AP) -- A German court decided today that by 1956 Germans no longer would resent the name "von Ribbentrop." It ordered the Henkell Champagne Company to employ Rudolf von Ribbentrop, 31-year-old son of Adolf Hitler's late Foreign Minister, Joachim won Ribbentrop, a former salesman for the concern, who was hanged as a war criminal in 1946.

The Rochester Royals, only club the New York Knickerbockers have failed to defeat in league play this season, will supply the opposition for Joe Lapchik's outfit tonight in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden.

The story of the dramatic rescue of thirty-two of the crew members and passengers of the storm-shattered Flying Enterprise, as told in a radio message from Capt. Neil Olsen, master of the New York bound Navy transport General A. W. Greely, was made public yesterday by the Military Sea Transportation Service. The Greely is due here tomorrow.

Saint Subber and Lemuel Ayers will bring back to New York tonight their highly successful production of "Kiss Me, Kate." The Cole Porter, Sam and Bella Spewack musical variation of "The Taming of the Shrew" begins a limited engagement at the Broadway Theatre at 8:30 P. M.
PARIS, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Following is text of the announcement here today by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower on his political position:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Cash payments by corporations dropped during November, along with several other business indicators, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- John Stewart Service appealed directly to President Truman today to reverse the Loyalty Review Board's finding of "reasonable doubt" of his loyalty to the United States.
GENEVA, Jan. 7 -- Belgium has been talking back rather sharply to the larger members of the North Atlantic community who have criticized her contribution to the Common defense effort.

A taxpayer building containing six stores on the south side of Union Turnpike at 271st Street in Bellerose, Queens, has been sold by the Mangum Realty Corporation to Lawrence M. Lyons. The sale was negotiated by Citadel Realty as broker.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 7 -- Balloting has finally started in a small way in Iran's elections, which will stretch out over many weeks as one province after another votes.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 7 -- Fire driven by a freezing forty-mile wind blowing seaward destroyed two Boardwalk blocks here today with an estimated property loss of $4,000,000.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York in its annual report to stockholders released for publication today shows a net income of $17,578,808, equal to $17.57 a share, for 1951, compared with $17,817,849, equal to $17.81 a share in 1950. Income taxes for the year cut $17,200,000 from the earnings of $34,778,808 against $10,875,000 deducted from the preceding year's earnings of $28,692,849.

Commodity price changes followed no pattern yesterday. Coffee, in heavy turnover, rose the daily limit of 100 points and gained 155 points in the "spot" March delivery. One delivery of cocoa rose the limit at one point but the market lost some of its gains by the close.

Frederic W. Lord, who died last week, founded a business organization, the Lord Electric Company, known throughout the United States for its important electrical work in great projects such as La Guardia Field and Idlewild, and in his later years he became deeply interested in selective methods of contract which would prevent collusive bidding.

Philip Loeb, veteran character actor, was dropped yesterday from the cast of the television version of "The Goldbergs" as a result of the inclusion of his name in "Red Channels," the privately published anti-Communist booklet.

The contempt trial of Frank Costello for refusing to answer questions last March before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee got under way yesterday in Federal Court when ten men and two women were chosen as the jury to sit in judgment on the racketeer.

The failure of some schools and colleges to give proper attention to the place of religion in education was sharply criticized yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president of Union Theological Seminary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Nathan P. Feinsinger, chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board, called today on labor and management in the steel industry to rise above "immediate self-interest" in working for a settlement of wage and other contract differences.

Penn-Art Fashions, in 149 W 36th St; Parade Dress Co, in 1214 Broadway; Alsol Frocks, in 101 W 37th St; Morris Goddman Textile Co, through Williams Co, store in 202 W 40th St; Marrow Modes Co, in 463 7th Ave -- Spear Co, brokers.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Prime Minister Churchill, who is now conferring with President Truman in Washington, hopes to get the cooperation of the United States in checking the dangerous drain on the sterling area's gold and dollar reserves, which declined by nearly $1,000,000,000 in 1951.

Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers throughout the country, as gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Associated Press on General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's announcement yesterday that he would be willing to accept the Republican Presidential nomination:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France, Jan. 7 -- This correspondent has talked with dozens of persons who visited General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower during the last year. From them he has elicited what should be an accurate composite view of the general's opinions on nonmilitary matters in which he must from now on be involved.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association, under fire for its inability to curb excesses in college athletics, will try to formulate a new "sanity code" this week to replace the one it junked a year ago.

The memorial to the American dead of World War II at Cambridge, England, the American cemetery in which several thousand soldiers, sailors, airmen and coast guardsmen lie buried, is in its final building stage. Two murals, one for a wall of the stone chapel and the other for its ceiling, were approved yesterday by the Battle Monuments Commission headed by General of the Army George C. Marshall.
PARIS, Jan. 7 -- Premier Rene Pleven's center coalition Cabinet was overthrown today in the National Assembly by a vote of 341 to 243.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Mrs. Maybelle Kennedy of Pawhuska, Okla., was sworn in today as Assistant Treasurer of the United States -- keeping women technically in charge of the Government's money.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- A special sports committee of college presidents recommended tonight that all athletic scholarships be abolished and that football practice and games be limited to the period from Sept. 1 to the first Saturday in December.

H. M. Moolman of the South African Information Office claims, in his letter published Dee. 15, that non-white South Africans enjoy full opportunity for betterment. Without dwelling on the long list of squalid racial laws, better grasped by American students of racial trends than by most colorphobic South Africans, let me ask Mr. Moolman two simple questions.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France, Jan. 7 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower stated in effect this afternoon that he would accept the Republican nomination for the Presidency if he were drafted at next July's party convention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, paid off a football bet today.
