He gave his coonskin campaign hat to the University of Maryland, but said that he might have to "borrow it back one of these days" -- a possible indication that he might campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today set the so-called "Southern Governors' Case" for rehearing in Washington on March 19, before Commissioner William E. Lee and Examiner Michael T. Corcoran.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Truman has no intention of relieving General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower from his post as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe because of his announcement that he would accept the Republican Presidential nomination if it was offered to him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, paid off a football bet today. He gave his coonskin campaign hat to the University of Maryland, but said that he might have to "borrow it back one of these days" -- a possible indication that he might campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Real shortages and new inflationary pressures are on the way and will make necessary sound and effective controls, Roger L. Putnam, Economic Stabilization Administrator, said yesterday at the forty-first annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Despite a tightening market in critical materials, 1951 was the biggest year in New York's history for construction of public improvements, a study of Public Works Department records indicated yesterday.

On Dec. 17, Victor G. Fourman, in a letter protesting the 1950 amendment of the State Education Law by which a "pupil may be excused from such study of health and hygiene as conflicts with the religion of his parents or guardian," made the statement that "we have reached a new low in our public education system when such amendments can be passed and signed with very little protest or notice from our educators."
Seattle, Wash., sold yesterday $28,000,000 of municipal light and power revenue bonds to finance plant expansion at an interest cost of 2.8144 per cent.

NEWARK, Jan. 8 -- Officials and medical experts for three of the twenty-nine railroads involved in a Board of Public Utility Commissioners hearing on seven proposed safety rules objected today to the principal proposal, requiring locomotive engineers and firemen to have quarterly medical examinations.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The stock markets stood up today much better than had been expected to the news of gold and dollar reserve losses. In fact, British Government securities showed strength, attributed largely to further bear covering now that the scale of the gold losses is known.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- The United Nations High Commissioner for refugees reported today that infectious cases of tuberculosis were scattered among 4,800 refugees -- most of them of Russian origin -- housed in camps at Trieste and issued a plea that individual nations adopt and rehabilitate small groups of these persons.

THE villian is declaiming in "The King of the Sea: A Tale of the Fearless and Free" by one of the most widely read of nineteenth-century American writers: "Go bid the mad ocean be calm, while the wild hurricane careens over its rushing waters; go chain the red lightning of high heaven; go curb and dam up the boiling lava which rolls down Elia's rocky sides, but do not stay the course of my revenge."
A $10,000 check from Arthur Murray, director of a chain of dancing schools, gave a sharp late-season spurt to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which rose yesterday to $318,356.41.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- The Turkish Government has officially advised the United States, Britain and France that unless it is unqualifiedly admitted to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization it may have to reconsider its application to join that body.

J. D. Bowden has been named assistant to the vice president in charge of distribution of Scott Paper Company, Chester, Pa. He also will direct traffic and sales correspondence activities. L. H. Wight, New England divisional manager, replaces him as sales personnel manager. J. B. Kirkpatrick replaces Mr. Wight in Boston.

TOKYO, Jan. 8 -- The closest to an official declaration yet made that Japan will negotiate with the Chinese Nationalist regime, and not with the Communist mainland, after the peace treaty is ratified comes from Premier Shigeru Yoshida.

A film, intended to help deepen public understanding of the problems of deaf children and the ways used to educate them for normal adult living in a hearing world, had its first performance yesterday at the Lexington School for the Deaf, 904 Lexington Avenue.

CHICAGO, Jan., 8 -- Grain futures followed an irregular course today, opening lower on scattered selling, advancing sharply from the initial lows and then reacting sharply from the tops. Early strength was attributed to a little export business in corn and a sharp upturn in soybeans, led by the January position.
BOSTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau tonight issued the following forecasts and winter sports conditions:

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman, proposed today that the spring primary be postponed for two weeks to strengthen his efforts to get New York four more delegates to the Republican National Convention at Chicago in July.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 8 -- Relations between India and the neighboring kingdom of Nepal, which interposes between this country and Communist-occupied Tibet, apparently are taking significantly firm shape this week in conferences between the prime ministers of the two countries with special reference to Red China.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Jan. 7 -- President William V. S. Tubman was inaugurated today for a second term. In a forty-minute address, the President summarized the achievements of his first eight-year term and told of plans for an expanded development program during his new four-year term.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- Arrangements for merging the First National Bank of New Rochelle and the Bronxville Trust Company were approved today by stockholders of both banks at annual meetings. The vote in favor comprised 83 per cent of the shares of the New Rochelle bank and 94 per cent of the shares of the Bronxville bank.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were quiet yesterday, but closing prices were 5 to 17 points net higher than on Monday.
The investing public will get a first big helping today of the equity securities of the plant at Battle Creek, Mich., where Kellogg's corn flakes have been manufactured since 1906.

In the hope of making its parkways the "safest in the country," the Long Island State Park Commission promulgated two new regulations yesterday. The first sets a minimum fine of $10 for speeding, while the second defines dangerous driving so that the licenses of "wild" motorists may be suspended immediately.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- A special hearing into affairs of the bankrupt Empire Tractor Corporation was postponed today for three weeks because of the illness of Robert B. Wolf, counsel for the concern.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath disclosed today he had given the Federal Bureau of Investigation unusual authority to track down racial terrorists in Florida. He said F. B. I. agents had been told to find and deal with persons responsible for the recent outbreak of violence before doing anything else.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 8 -- Rita Hayworth and Columbia Pictures have agreed for the second time in recent weeks to end their disagreement over "Affair in Trinidad" and the star will report Thursday morning at the studio to resume rehearsals, it was announced today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 8 -- The Tudeh (Communist) party's election campaign has become more active, creating an increasingly strained situation in Teheran and, according to reports, in the northern provinces.

For many years the League of Women Voters has carried the fight almost singlehanded for Permanent Personal Registration. Under this system the voter who registered once and then appeared with reasonable regularity at the polls on Election Day would remain eligible to vote without further registration.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 -- Austin T. Cushman, vice president and director of Sears, Roebuck Co. and head of the company's Pacific Coast operations, was elected to the board of the Bank of America today to fill the vacancy left by the death of Dr. C. C. Caglieri.

Enlightened self-interest is a trait too seldom visible in Tammany Hall, but the reforms proposed by Leader Carmine G. DeSapio and adopted with amazing unanimity by the executive committee suggest that a temporary awakening, at least, has occurred.
TOKYO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Japanese winner of the Stalin peace prize calls the United States-sponsored Japanese peace treaty "preparation for future war."
A bill is now in Congress which, in order to stimulate the sales of savings bonds, would make the interest on these securities exempt from taxes.
MOSCOW, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The official greeting said:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The United States signed an economic agreement today with Yugoslavia. The pact is designed to promote Yugoslavia's economic stability and "strengthen mutual security and individual defenses against aggression."

QUEBEC CITY, Jan. 8 (UP) -- There will be no merchantable forests in Canada within twenty-five years if the pulp and paper industry continues to cut trees at the present Quebec rate. Thomas Maher, consulting forestry engineer, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Congressional leaders of both parties made it plain today that President Truman probably would be rebuffed in any request for a tax increase at this election-year session.
Except for coffee and sugar, commodity futures prices were generally higher yesterday.
HONG KONG, Jan. 8 -- The Chinese Communist Array is not exempt from the Peiping Government's nation-wide campaign against "corruption, waste and bureaucratism."

CINCINNATI, Jan. 8 -- Delegates assembled here for the forty-sixth convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association will consider adoption of a code for the conduct of intercollegiate sports that closely parallels the recommendations of the committee of college presidents representing the American Council on Education.

Another late selling wave hit the stock market yesterday. Selective improvement in the morning soon gave way to a highly contrary pattern that developed into a preponderance of losses at the close. Declines in most cases were not of major proportions and held mostly within a fractional range, although a few of the high-priced stocks registered declines well beyond a point.

The Modern Industrial Bank reported yesterday, that as of Dec. 31, 1951, total deposits were $47,498,011, and total assets were $53,158,628, compared, respectively, with $47,425,108 and $53,125,111 on June 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $12,843,573 against $14,454,385; holdings of United States Government securities to $9,252,083 against $7,069,853, and loans and discounts to $30,641,157 against $31,021,327.
The Graber quadruplets of Brooklyn -- three girls and a boy -- started eating yesterday, but it was from an eyedropper.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- The fall of the Pleven Government has caused in France greater disquietude than ever before regarding the effects of such strokes of political paralysis upon France's foreign relations and upon her allies in the North Atlantic Treaty.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 8 -- Faulty rock dusting of the New Orient Mine at West Frankfort was declared today to have been a primary reason for the spread of destructiveness in the explosion Dec 21 that killed 119 men.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 8 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes today called on the South Carolina Legislature to submit to the people of the state at the next general election a resolution repealing the state constitutional provisions for a public school system.

The custom collection of spring bridal gowns, designed by Josephine Oro, were modeled yesterday at a press preview in the fifth-floor bridal salon of Jay Thorpe. These gowns were both elaborate and varied.

Paul Windels, former Corporation Counsel, said yesterday that the failure of United States foreign policy in the last ten years was directly responsible for the present domestic "mess" of high taxes, inflation, economic controls, compulsory military service and the expenditure of our national wealth on the Korean battlefront.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill finished their formal discussions this evening with agreements on at least three subjects. These were:

JERUSALEM, Jan. 8 -- With the Parliament building cordoned off from the rest of Jerusalem by barbed wire entanglements and a wall of policemen and 3,000 workmen, Israel's legislators continued today their debate on the Government's decision to take up Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's offer to discuss reparations by the West German Government to Israel.

Twentieth Century-Fox will release a total of thirty-six feature films during the coming year, it was announced yesterday at the company's annual sales convention at the home office, 444 West Fifty-sixth Street. According to the announcement, this is the first time in Fox history that a "whole year's line-up has been envisioned so long in advance, due mainly to the highly geared production pace maintained at the studio."

JIMMY BRONSON is a dapper little guy who is ageless and who has been a part of the boxing scene for many years. He's the fellow who ran the A. E. F. boxing championships during the first World War and he's still at it, serving as coordinator for 235,000 amateur fist-throwers now competing in the various branches of the Armed Services.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Oerlikon Machine Tool Works, a Swiss concern, lost in the United States Court of Claims today an action to obtain compensation from the United States for the manufacture in this country in World War II of the Oerlikon antiaircraft cannon on which the company held the patents.

Tammany Hall received praise yesterday from two civic groups for sponsoring Monday night a legislative program that called for direct election of district leaders, permanent personal registration of voters, and primary elections held when convenient to the largest number of voters, instead of in the summer months.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- The entire Soviet press published on page one today a large photograph of Deputy Premier Georgi M. Malenkov together with fiftieth birthday greetings from the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party, which described him as "a true pupil of Lenin and a co-adviser of Comrade Stalin."

Before an audience of 1,500 store executives and buyers at the Millinery Stabilization Commission showing last night at the Astor Hotel, fifty New York custom milliners and manufacturers proclaimed the look of romantic prettiness as the key to spring milinery for 1952.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Woody Dumart, scoring two goals, led the Boston Bruins to a 7-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game tonight and drew within one goal of hockey's 200 club.

DENVER, Jan. 8 -- Albert N. Williams Sr., former president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, was elected president of the U. S. National Bank of Denver today to succeed Thomas M. Dines, who was named vice chairman of the board. In his new position Mr. Dines replaces Henry Swann, who became vice president.

Never better, the New York Knickerbockers put on a fine show for 5,247 spectators at Madison Square Garden last night, routing the champion Rochester Royals, 107 -- 74, in a National Basketball Association encounter. Hooking, driving, setting, feeding and rebounding spectacularly, the Knicks wrapped up the decision early, holding a 43-32 edge at half-time.

AS a result of last week's discussion of the various categories of big game rifles our mail has been crowded with communications from scattered deer hunters, many of whom now seem convinced that the only reason they failed to get venison was because they had the wrong rifle.

The supply of plastics raw material has improved substantially from a year ago, it was reported yesterday by William T. Cruse, executive vice president of the Society of the Plastics Industry, Inc. While one or two of the scores of different types of plastics are still a "bit tight," plastics raw materials are generally available, he said.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 8 -- Six new directors were elected today at the annual meeting of stockholders of the Miner's National Bank, Wilkes-Barre's largest financial institution, to fill vacancies created by four deaths and two resignations.

Having heard the last cackle and crow as its poultry show closed, Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue yesterday became an indoor yachting harbor under construction, with decorators transforming the four exposition floors into a summery, blue-water expanse of pleasure craft and yachting gear.
On Dec. 20 a news release from the sixth world conference of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the U. N. stated:

Manhattan romped to an 83-43 triumph over Brooklyn College last night. It wasn't much of a basketball game, but it produced a shot that the handful of onlookers in the bandbox Jasper gymnasium won't soon forget.

Mayor Impellitteri hurled defiance last night at the threat of Tammany Hall to oppose continuation of the sales tax at its present 13 per cent rate. Legislative enactment of the Tammany proposal to reduce the sales tax to 2 per cent, the Mayor charged, would be "catastrophic."

Two new dramatic presentations now adorn the Sunday schedule of N. B. C. television. One is the durable story of "Claudia," the young lady with the bangs, whose marriage to David has been related in just about every known language and medium.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, confirmed tonight that John F. Carter, whose pen name is Jay Franklin and who has worked for both the Fair Deal and New Deal, would soon start doing publicity for him.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- John L. Collyer, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company, said here today this country now has enough rubber, crude and man-made, to meet all essential needs for a "five-year all-out war should such an emergency occur."
The Aluminum Company of America is arranging a financing program to raise around $225,000,000 to help meet the cost of a huge defense expansion program already underway.

Fifty soldiers, airmen, marines and sailors, overdue at their bases on the West Coast after spending the Christmas holidays at their homes in the East, were stranded in New York yesterday when a non-scheduled airliner failed to appear at Newark Airport to take them back to California.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Despite the continuing gravity of the Indo-Chinese military situation and constant concern over other possible trouble spots in Southeast Asia, authoritative sources said here today that there was no immediate crisis underlying the tripartite discussion on that area to be held here Friday.

I have read the editorial "Economy With Defense" in your issue of Jan. 5. You could write editorials similar to this every day in the year with "horrible examples" from the facts and information found by the Hoover Commission of waste, inefficiency and duplication in every department of the Government.

Your superb editorial demanding ratification of the Genocide Convention by the Senate of the United States and stressing its urgent need to curb genocide as perpetrated now on the nations enslaved by Soviet Russia has drawn unjustified criticism from Carl B. Rix in his letter published in your columns on Jan. 2.
GENEVA, Jan. 8 -- News that the central reserves of the sterling area lost $934,000,000 during the fourth quarter of 1951 has sent something akin to a shudder through Europe.
GENEVA, Jan. 8 -- Huge gaps in the international control of narcotic drugs, principally in Iran and Italy, are revealed in the annual report of the Permanent Central Opium Board published here today.

BOSTON, Jan. 8 -- A Boston wool merchant testified today at the trial of Denis W. Delaney, ousted Collector of Internal Revenue, in Federal Court that the defendant had told him on two occasions to pay $5,000 to Daniel Friedman, New York insurance man and tax consultant.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Congressional investigators today gave the Maritime Board thirty days to revise "excessive" subsidies for the construction of passenger liners or face renewed hearings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The United States Court of Claims ruled today that an amount paid as damages for violating ceiling prices fixed by the Office of Price Administration was deductible from income and excess profits taxes paid to the Federal Government.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The Government today called a special meeting of twenty-five labor unions for next Monday to determine what, if anything, could be done about the copper shortage.
Elrby (Crazy Legs) Hirsch, a former halfback who hit the jackpot as an end, yesterday was the only unanimous selection on The Associated Press All-Pro football team.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Mrs. Harry S. Truman returned to Washington today from a month's stay at the Truman home in Independence, Mo., to hear the President's State of the Union Message and to hold a series of preLenten luncheons and teas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The National Commission on Accrediting, after more than a year of study, today recommended in effect that more than 300 independent college-accrediting agencies should bow out of the country's educational life except as advisers.
The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., denounced yesterday as "unworkable and unacceptable" a plan by the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation to cut its Bronx bus service by 10 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat of Georgia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said today that he would ask the House of Representatives on Jan. 21 to vote a 10 per cent pay increase for the members of the armed forces.

Beverly Somach, violinist, who will be 17 on the seventeenth of the month, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. It was her first appearance in that auditorium, though she made her debut at Times Hall at the age of 12, and has played twice at Town Hall and once at the Lewisohn Stadium.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 9 --- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's headquarters said today that the Communist armistice delegates "represent only a small clique of power-mad masters in the Kremlin."

A review of the 1951 achievements of the Bureau of Smoke Control, bristling with threats of "crackdowns" on "willful and chronic" offenders, was issued yesterday by William S. Maxwell, deputy and acting director, in the temporary absence of Director William G. Christy.

Treasury agents who during the last six months have investigated the finances of racketeers and alleged grafters have worked their way through hundreds of lesser figures and have now practically completed fraud cases against three of the underworld's first lieutenants.

John J. Mann, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange has been nominated to succeed himself, according to an announcement yesterday. Mr. Mann served as vice chairman in 1950. He has been a member of the board since 1948.

Lincoln's search for a general to win for the Union the War Between the States is the subject of a new book by T. Harry Williams, which Knopf has scheduled for February publication. "Lincoln and His Generals" has been chosen as the March Book-of-the-Month Club selection.

The Television Authority, organization of video artists, announced yesterday that it would investigate the dismissal of Philip Loeb from the cast of "The Goldbergs" because his name appears in "Red Channels."

Despite pleas yesterday by William B. Herlands, special deputy attorney general, and Sidney O. Simonson, Richmond County District Attorney, that Chief City Magistrate John M. Murtagh impose sentence immediately, he remanded two convicted bookmakers to jail for another week.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 9 -- The Communist delegates at Panmunjom today submitted a new proposal for the enforcement of an armistice in the Korean war but refused to recede from their demand that airfield construction without limitation be permitted in North Korea during a cease-fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat of South Carolina, today ordered public hearings to make sure that the political house cleaning at the Reconstruction Finance Corporation would not be interrupted by the departure of W. Stuart Symington, retiring administrator.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved tonight a resolution calling on member nations to take the preliminary steps necessary to provide armed forces on the recommendation of the Assembly if a veto should prevent the Security Council from taking action.
The New York Rangers, almost invincible on home ice since Bill Cook became coach, tangle with the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League fixture at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Several dinner parties were given last night in advance of the performance of Bernard Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra," with Sir Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh, at the Ziegfeld Theatre, for the benefit of Union Settlement.

PORT ARTHUR, Ont., Jan. 8 (Canadian Press) -- The keel for a sister ship of the Sir James Dunn, longest Canadian bulk freighter on the Great Lakes, was laid today at the yards of the Port Arthur Shipbuilding Company.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- City National Bank and Trust Company's corporate cousin and largest stockholder, Central-Illinois Securities Corporation, signaled today its readiness to do battle with the bank's management on its operating policies.

VANCOUVER, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Celgar Development Company announced today that it planned to embark soon on a $65,000,000 wood pulp and newsprint development in the Arrow Lakes region of southeastern British Columbia.

" Anna Christie" will be presented at 8 o'clock this evening at the City Center. And to the records will be added this notation: The first Broadway revival of Eugene O'Neill's famous play since the original 1921 presentation. Why it took thirty-one years for another generation to witness the Pulitzer Prize work is something for stage analysts to ponder.

PORT SAID, Egypt, Jan. 8 -- British naval authorities here were considering plans to take over the operation of the Suez Canal as 1,500 canal workers at Port Said went out on strike again this morning for the second time in two days.

The United States copper supply should begin to improve materially in the latter half of this year, Cornelius F. Kelley, chairman of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, said yesterday in reviewing the outlook for the metal. He said domestic mine production was now averaging about 90,000 tons a month and an additional 35,000 tons was available from foreign sources.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 9 -- The towline between the Flying Enterprise and the salvage tug Turmoil parted at 1:30 A. M., Greenwich mean time, today in rough weather, with only about fifty miles to go to the safety of Falmouth harbor. The Turmoil reported that she would try to take the battered American freighter in tow again after sunrise.

Threat of renewed strife along the city's vast waterfront appeared to be growing last night as Patrick J. Connolly, executive vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., indicated that four insurgent leaders would not be restored to union jobs from which they were recently ousted.

TRENTON, Jan. 8 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll called on the 1952 New Jersey Legislature at its first session today to establish a state law enforcement council and expand the highway system by resorting to toll routes where feasible.

Banking syndicates will place on the market today new issues of stocks and bonds with a market value of more than $57,000,000. The major offerings are intended to raise about $52,000,000 for the expansion of a public utility plant in the Philadelphia area and for building an aluminum plant in the South.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder announced a streamlined procedure tonight for handling tax fraud cases that would by-pass the chief counsel of the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 3,624, compared with 180 last week and 4,488 in the corresponding week of 1951, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 2,128 arrivals yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 8 -- Pope Pius XII has appointed a committee of five Cardinals to determine up to what point the Order of Malta is a religious organization subject to the control of the Vatican Congregation of the Religious and up to what point it is a sovereign order independent of Vatican control.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 -- A Superior Court ruling today cleared the way, unless new legal moves are made in the meantime, for the State Toll Bridge Authority to deliver $21,000,000 of new revenue bonds on schedule at 5 P. M. next Monday.

A new $5,600 heated brick garage, constructed especially for a massive tow truck, is standing vacant on the suburban bus level of the Port Authority Terminal while the truck's engine is kept warm outdoors.

As a result of a recent appeal to city personnel by Mayor Impellitteri for support of the blood-donor program, employes of the New York City Housing Authority gave blood yesterday to a mobile Red Cross unit at 63 Park Row. Employes of The Journal of Commerce and of several other private concerns also contributed.

A recommendation by Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson for the purchase of eighty-nine two-way mobile radios for installation on emergency ambulances and disaster units operated by the Hospitals Department and by voluntary hospitals was made to the Board of Estimate yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Backed by a battery of 140 machines that do everything but figure out exemptions, the State Tax Commission is preparing to set another record for the largest centralized tax collection operation in the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said today that he would pick up at least seventy-five of the 600 votes needed to win the Republican Presidential nomination from the states of New York, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and Kansas.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 8 (AP) -- A Phoenix cemetery announced a change in its policy today to allow burial of a Negro soldier who was killed in action in Korea June 3.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- The impossibility of accurately labeling the many kinds of furniture designs that can be put in the "contemporary" category was pointed up in a panel discussion held at the American Furniture Mart here today. Participating were six designers, all of whose work may be examined in this building.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The heaviest ground action in nearly six weeks flared along the western Korean front Tuesday, when the Chinese Reds hurled an estimated 4,000 troops into battle.

Preliminary figures prepared by the central research department of McCann-Erickson, Inc., to appear in Printers' Ink this week, indicate a total of $6,548,200,000 spent on national and local advertising in 1951. It was 15 per cent above the 1950 record and may go higher as final figures become available.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Truman has requested that his name be kept out of the Minnesota Presidential primary on March 18.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Residents of some United States cities are paying up to six times as much in city taxes as are residents of some other cities, a survey indicated today. The study was made by the Commerce Clearing House, Inc., a private organization that reports on tax and business law developments.
PARIS, Jan. 8 -- The United States delegation said today it was "strongly opposed" to holding the 1952 United Nations General Assembly session away from United Nations headquarters in New York.

A slowdown in nylon hosiery shipments in the last quarter of 1951 has brought about a surplus of 3,000,000 dozen pairs of full-fashion stockings in the hands of the mills, according to Walter J. McTigue, divisional merchandise manager of Carson. Pirie Scott Co., Chicago.
It was cold out-of-doors yesterday in eastern Long Island. And it was just as cold aboard Train 205 of the Long Island Rail Road when it stopped at Holbrook at 7:12 A. M. on its westbound trip.
Two men, trapped in the sub-basement of a six-story loft building at 16 Waverly Place, died yesterday afternoon as the result of a fire set off by sparks from a welder's torch.

Camilla Williams, who has veen singing in opera at the City Center for the last six years, has not appeared in many New York recitals. Her first took place five years ago, and her second Town Hall recital took place last night. She has a special gift for the concert stage, but like her work in the opera, it is not all-embracing.
Big Johnny Mize became a Yankee for the fourth consecutive year when he signed a contract estimated at $22,500 yesterday.

Dr. William Henry Dean, chief of the African Unit of the Division of Economic Stability and Development of the United Nations, ended his life yesterday by inhaling gas in the Harlem apartment of his father-in-law, Dr. Channing T. Tobias, noted Negro leader.

A brief respite is about due for housewives for whom the holidays meant much extra work in the kitchen. As a time and effort saving alternative to meal cookery, this department suggests today some restaurants and service kitchens that prepare hot main dishes or whole dinners to be picked up or, in many cases, to be delivered to the door.

Dr. A. Douglas Quick, a cancer specialist who has treated Frank Costello for a throat condition for eighteen years, testified at the gambler's trial in Federal Court yesterday that Costello was in condition to testify before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee last March 16, at least in limited degree.

Flota Mercante Grancolombiana, one of the largest shipping operators in Latin America, plans to spend $30,000,000 in the next five years on the construction of thirteen cargo-passenger vessels. In addition, the company will extend its present services within the next few months to include the West Coast of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Mines said today that the Illinois mine disaster was caused by an electrical spark that touched off gas clouds present because of faulty ventilating equipment.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Three Coptic Christians were killed recently in Suez in a renewal of the religious strife between Moslems and Christians that has marked Egyptian history for centuries.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Egypt told the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today that if Israel was unable to pay full compensation to the Arabs driven from their lands in Palestine, the United Nations should foot the bill.

Gross operating income of The Hanover Bank for 1951 totaled $30,103,000, largest in its history, comparing with $24,973,000 the year before, the report disclosed yesterday. Net operating earnings of $7,831,384 equaled $6.53 a share against $7,120,648, or $5.93 a share, for 1950.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- A newly formed "Eisenhower-for-President" organization opened offices today, pledging to elect a full slate of delegates to the Republican National Convention here in July to back the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as the Republican candidate for President.

The United Nations reasserted its authority as a peace-enforcement agency yesterday when the General Assembly, acting as a committee, rejected a Soviet demand for the abolition of the Collective Measures Committee and instead approved a veto-free system to combat aggression.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The second session of the Eighty-second Congress convened today, with its Democrats and Republicans jockeying, largely behind closed doors, for favored positions in an election year.

If the threat of another wildcat strike of longshoremen in the Port of New York should be carried out it would be piling disaster on disaster. Coming so soon after the recent costly twenty-five-day unauthorized walkout, the ostensible cause would be the ousting of four leaders of the recent strike by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, and by the District Council which he controls.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Republican leaders, assembling here tonight for tomorrow's opening of the 1952 legislative session, have adopted a wait-and-see policy toward Mayor Impellitteri's financial program for New York.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 8 -- Harold E. Stassen, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, told a press conference here today that he did not expect to be "a shadow candidate for Eisenhower or anyone else."

Shocked at finding itself out of town, "Kiss Me, Kate" has come back in a hurry for a limited engagement at the Broadway Theatre, where it opened last evening. On the whole, this is a sensible maneuver. For the Spewack travesty on Shakespeare, with music and lyrics by Cole Porter, is still an amusing song-and-dance show.

Five connected national and international car theft gangs dealing only in deluxe Cadillacs were smashed yesterday with the arrest of seven men here and one in Hoboken, N. J., J. Edgar Hoover, Federal Bureau of Investigation director, announced.

New York City taxpayers are receiving a new form with their Federal income tax declarations this year but do not have to fill it out, only send it in with their tax returns. This is called Form T-25. It is intended, according to Collector of Internal Revenue Monroe D. Dowling of the Third New York District, 110 East Forty-fifth Street, to save the Government time and money in collecting taxes.

The Democratic State Committee filed suit yesterday in Supreme Court here for a declaratory judgment that would rule out as unconstitutional the Congressional reapportionment bills voted by the Republican-controlled Legislature at a recent special session.

For the second straight year, the Yankees' baseball club was picked as the team of the year as results of the annual Associated Press poll were disclosed yesterday. The Yanks, who swept to their third-straight American League and world series triumph under Manager Casey Stengel, beat out the Giants in the poll just as they did in the series.

The universities and schools now have taken back the young, and about the resultant peace there is something strange, a little unnerving. Indeed, it may even be a little unnatural, for at the end of other vacations the sense of peace was mingled with one of loneliness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 131 additional battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 29 killed, 79 wounded, 8 missing in action and 15 injured. It also listed 4 dead who were previously reported missing.

The First National Bank of the City of New York would have been "better off" if it had cut its dividend rate a few years ago, Alexander C. Nagle, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

Harry Gross, Brooklyn bookmaker who scuttled the graft conspiracy trials of nineteen members of the Police Department by refusing to testify against them last September, will get another chance to testify when he appears today at the departmental trial of three of his former police guards.

Hiram Walker-Gooderhan Worts, Ltd., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday, for the quarter ended on Nov. 30, net profit of $5,280,254, compared with $7,560,848 for the November quarter of the prior year.

The West Side Association of Commerce, Inc., re-elected Harry M. Williams, president of the H. M. Williams Company, Studebaker automobile agency, as its president at its annual meeting yesterday at the McGraw-Hill Building, 330 West Forty-second Street.

It often pays to ask the most obvious questions and to avoid taking things for granted just because they have always been a part of our mental equipment. The visit of Winston Churchill and his advisers takes on a different light according to the weight we give to the Anglo-American alliance.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Top retailers throughout the country declared their intention today to place quantity orders for furniture before the Winter Home Furnishings Market ends on Jan. 18. Meanwhile, the second day of the market in the American Furniture and Merchandise Marts here saw an increase in quantity orders placed by small home furnishings stores.

CENTREVILLE, Md., Jan. 8 (AP) -- George Monroe Moffett, who started as a day laborer and acquired an estimated $200,000,000, left the residue of his estate to the Whitehall Foundation, an organization that helps send young people through college, his will showed today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 8 -- The timid giant was stirred to fighting spirit today.

BETHEL, Conn., Jan. 8 -- The Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors in a unanimous decision today upheld the Bethel Zoning Commission in its refusal to grant permission to the Fairlawn Cemetery Association to develop thirty-three acres in the Elmwood district into a cemetery on which a crematory also would be situated.
PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Christian Pineau, former Minister of Finance, was selected from among the Socialist leaders today as the first to try to form a Cabinet for France.
I cannot understand the lethargy of the people of this city and the newspapers they support for the manner in which they allow themselves to be hoodwinked.

Sales of special tools, jigs, dies and fixtures used in metal-working production are at least 200 per cent heavier now than in the first quarter of 1951, it was reported here yesterday by Carl Kertesz, past chairman of the house of delegates of the American Society of Tool Engineers and vice president of the Design Tool Corporation, 80 Washington Street.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 8 (AP) -- A wildcat strike that slowed work today on the Atomic Energy Commission's huge hydrogen-bomb plant near here apparently was near settlement tonight.

St. Nicholas Arena, the old boxing center on the West Side of Manhattan, where many fistic champions got their start, has changed hands in a realty deal that also may mark a change in the character of the entertainment offered there.

The railroads may ask for an additional freight rate boost above its pending request, hearings on which are scheduled to start on Monday in Washington. It is understood that the question will be considered by top executives of the railroads at a meeting to be held in Washington prior to the opening of the hearings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, the senior Republican member of the Senate in point of service, was chosen today by his party colleagues to be the Republican Floor Leader, succeeding the late Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 8 -- New directors of the First Camden National Bank and Trust Company were elected at the annual stockholders' meeting here. They are C. Lothrop Ritchie, former secretary-treasurer of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania, and a director of the Blue Ridge Mutual Fund, Inc., of New York City; William H. Dunn, president of the American Cotton Products Company of Philadelphia, and Samuel P. Orlando and Emphrain Tomlinson, Camden attorneys.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. David J. Crawford, removed as commander of the Detroit tank arsenal, has been reduced to his permanent rank of colonel and assigned to a post in Turkey, the Army reported to a House of Representatives investigating committee today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Joe Kuharich, former coach of the University of San Francisco's unbeaten 1951 eleven, today was named head coach of the Chicago Cardinals. He signed a two-year contract.

When a group of 229 pioneering men enrolled last fall in the first co-educational class at Hunter College they realized that they would have to struggle for survival in what had been for eighty-one years a woman's world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The National Production Authority has agreed to allow the automobile industry to produce 900,000 automobiles and 240,000 trucks in the second quarter of 1952, Senator Blair Moody, Democrat of Michigan, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration has certified 3,000 business concerns, mostly small manufacturers, as meriting "special attention" in the placement of defense contracts.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (AP) -- North Carolina's Tommy Bolt won the play-off of the $17,500 Los Angeles open golf tournament today with a brilliant score of 69 that cracked par by two strokes and the hopes of his rivals for the $4,000 top money, Jack Burke Jr. and E. J. (Dutch) Harrison.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 8 -- Mrs. Loren B. Thompson of this city is endeavoring to impress upon Congress and defense officials that, despite Army regulations, a woman can serve her country and raise a family at the same time without loss to either.

Patrolman John Kiesel has been guarding the banks of the Harlem Meer for three years. The Harlem Meer is not as far away as it sounds. It is at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street and Mr. Kiesel works out of the Central Park Station of the New York City Police Department.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 8 -- On the eve of the opening of the Schuman plan ratification debate tomorrow, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was understood to have raised again today the question of the extent to which the Allies insisted on carrying out the decartelization of the Ruhr industries. A good part of the program has been completed on paper but many Germans still hope to salvage the big industrial enterprises.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The National Football League and its twelve member teams today lost their first battle to continue television and radio restrictions, which the Government charges violate the anti-trust law. A motion to dismiss the Justice Department's anti-trust suit against the N. F. L. was denied by Federal Judge Allan K. Grim because of the "great importance" of the case to the public.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- The airlift of 10,500 men of the Eleventh Airborne Division from Fort Campbell, Ky., to this post began auspiciously today as fifty-four C-46's, four C-124's and two C-82' s put down on Wheeler-Sack Field here with more than 2,600 of the men.

MONTREAL, Jan. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Charle St. Pierre, president of La Banque Canadienne Nationale (National Canadian Bank), coupled some warning signals today with a review of a prosperous year in Canada.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 9 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,123, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Office of Price Stabilization, in two orders today, lowered the price ceiling on soaps and raw wool. The ceiling reductions, in neither instance, however, will mean lower prices at retail, inasmuch as the lowered ceilings still have not been brought down to the current market levels.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 9 -- Agents here of the Vietminh forces this forenoon staged one of the most spectacular and destructive single incidents in the long history of revolutionary terrorism in Saigon.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 9 (UP) -- The chances of a battle between the forces of Generals of the Army Douglas MacArthur and Dwight D. Eisenhower in the March 11 New Hampshire Presidential primary dwindled today. While petitions to place General Eisenhower's name on the Republican ballot began circulating, two MacArthur supporters announced they would run as unpledged delegates.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 9 -- Philadelphia Athletics officials conferred with Jersey City civic and business leaders today and said they would decide within twenty-four hours about purchasing the Ottawa International League franchise and transferring it here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman gave Congress today a fairly encouraging report on the state of the nation and of the world, but declared that unless the free nations fought and won the battle against hunger around the world, "we can't win the cold war, nor a hot one either."
Directors of the American Can Company voted yesterday to split its common stock on a four-for-one basis, subject to approval by shareholders at the annual meeting on April 29.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The United States has asked the Soviet Union either to settle its long overdue lend-lease account or agree to take the issue to the International Court of Justice.

Something good may yet come out of all the recent scandals in intercollegiate athletics that have shocked the country. The professionalization of so-called amateur sports has gone so deep and spread so far that only the most drastic action on the part of college academic and athletic administrations seems likely to cure the evil.
PHENIX CITY, Ala, Jan. 9 (UP) -- A bomb wrecked the home of an anti-vice leader today in this Army post amusement center.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 9 -- Premier Joseph Pholien's Social Christian (Catholic) Cabinet resigned today after having met in extraordinary session. King Baudouin withheld his decision to accept or refuse the resignation.

More diagnostic clinics for patients of moderate income are needed and should be established by voluntary hospitals here, the Hospital Council of Greater New York urges in its annual report just issued. A study of the clinic facilities available, to ambulatory patients is included among the accounts of council activities for the year ending June 30, 1951.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 9 -- Hugh White, state president of the United Mine Workers of America, ordered all members of his union tonight to leave the workings of the new Orient mine at West Frankfort, where 119 men died in an explosion on Dec. 21.

The showing of motion picture scenes of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee's hearing last March at the perjury trial of James J. Moran, former city official, was sharply questioned yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

The art of politics is nowhere else cultivated to such a point of finesse as in France. A political crisis like the present one is no more to be hurried than a Frenchman sitting down to one of his incomparable meals. Each course is to be savoured to the full -- no hasty gulping down of boiled fish and suet pudding as in England, nothing brusque, nothing matter-of-fact, no hurry.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- After three other party leaders had declined today to try to form a new Cabinet, former Premier Georges Bidault told President Vincent Auriol that he was willing to make the first attempt to solve the current French political crisis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 104,084 today, an increase of 345 since last week.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- How to make Western Europe independent of United States coal will be discussed as a major and urgent problem by members of the Cabinets of the participating countries when the European Marshall Plan Council holds a special meeting on the subject here Friday.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- The 1952 Legislature met for the first time today with one vacancy in each house and four new faces in the Assembly.

Only three Government witnesses -- two physicians and Council President Rudolph Halley -- were heard in Federal Court yesterday in the third session of Frank Costello's trial on eleven indictments charging contempt of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee at hearings last spring.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 9 -- Communist and other Opposition victories in the incomplete elections in South India have eliminated some important figures upon whom Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party had relied for certain success in their constituencies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill issued a communique today that contained a resolution, a promise and a warning.

City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses rejected yesterday suggestions, offered recently by the Regional Plan Association, that an attempt be made to unify the ownership and operation of all the commuting railroad facilities entering the city or to link them with the city subway system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 2:

Exotic in savor and aspect, the party snacks caterer Daisy Amoury prepares and delivers anywhere in Manhattan are as delectable as they are different. The recipes for these hors d'oeuvre and sweets come from Lebanon, a country with a superb cuisine that has been somewhat overlooked here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The shape of the Presidential contest of 1952 will change as it progresses, like cloud forms hurrying before the wind. But at the moment these outlines are appearing:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9 -- The Screen Writers Guild, in the first such action on record, has called on Hal Roach Jr., producer of motion-picture and television movies, to answer charges of alleged contract violation.

The Department of Sanitation has invested $200,000 in a new method of garbage collection in market areas, hospitals, schools and other places in the city where large amounts of rubbish accumulate. The plan, put into effect several weeks ago, was hailed yesterday by agency officials as "a complete success."

The United States Leather Company, which was an outgrowth of the original company organized in 1893, will be dissolved and liquidated. Stockholders overwhelmingly approved the action at a special meeting held here yesterday.
Winston Churchill returned to New York from Washington last night to spend two days with Bernard M. Baruch, at the latter's home, 4 East Sixty-sixth Street.

The Whitney Museum will open to the public today a retrospective exhibition of painting and graphic work by the late John Sloan, covering sixty years of his long and influential career. Ninety-eight paintings, the first a self-portrait of 1890 and the last a portrait of 1951; forty-three drawings; sixty- seven etchings; three lithographs, and sixteen illustrations are included and all galleries of the museum are being utilized.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 9 -- The Iranian Foreign Ministry presented to the British Embassy today a note threatening to take the most serious measures if the "open interference" of British Government officials in Iranian affairs did not cease.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 9 -- Unfazed by Communist threats of war and unwavering despite the French Government crisis, the West German Bundestag began today its final debate on ratification of the Schuman plan for pooling West Europe's heavy industrial resources.
CARMEL, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- A campaign to raise $45,000 to save from liquidation the 103-year-old Drew School for Girls here has been started by the trustees of the Methodist Church institution.

Revenue from the city's first parking meter program not only is 20 per cent higher than estimated, but City Treasurer Spencer C. Young is building up an interesting collection of foreign coins, some of which might turn out to be worth more than the dimes motorists saved by the substitution.

More cigarettes are sold through independent food stores than any other type of retail outlet, according to the first report of the recently established research division of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors.

Efficiency among retail sales personnel deteriorated in 1951 to the dangerously low state prevalent in World War II, Maxwell I. Schultz, executive vice president of Willmark Service System, Inc., declared yesterday. His conclusions were based on the results of a nation-wide survey made by Willmark of retailing techniques and performance.

DES MOINES, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Iowa Supreme Court has directed the Appanoose County District Court to enter a judgment of $2,211,549 in favor of the Iowa Southern Utilities Company against George M. Bechtel, retired Davenport, Iowa, financier, his son Harold R. Bechtel and the estate of the late J. Ross Lee, also of Davenport.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A dividend of $200,000,000 will be paid this year -- starting in March -- to about 5,000,000 holders of National Service Life Insurance, the Veterans Administration announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The British "like Ike," but they are not going to campaign for him. In the United States elections they are pointedly neutral and besides they have a warm spot in their hearts for President Truman.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 10 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,124, for Wednesday's operation:
Harry Gross testified yesterday, willingly and in colorful detail, at a police trial.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Governor Dewey raised speculation today on whether he planned to finish the four-year term to which he was elected in 1950, and informed sources said Mr. Dewey would resign after the November elections to accept a Cabinet post if a Republican won the Presidency or resume private law practice if the Democrats were victorious.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- An Army investigator began giving today a detailed account of his inquiry into the mysterious slaying of an American secret agent behind enemy lines during World War II.

THE essence of war is mystery. You spend your time trying literally to surprise the life out of your enemy and trying to prevent him from surprising the life out of you. If you are dealing with a maniacal totalitarian you have a special interest, after you've beaten him, in finding out what cards he really held and why he played them as he did.

Boys' apparel buyers will place orders for about half their spring needs this month and rely on manufacturers to be able to supply fill-ins later in the season, it was reported yesterday at the opening of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association display at the Astor Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman today addressed a joint session of Congress surcharged with the atmosphere of a knock-down-drag-out election year.

Practicality is the theme of a showing of new groups of furniture as well as some newly decorated model rooms, all of which will go on view at Gimbels today. Homemakers with limited budgets or those with small living quarters may find solutions to their problems in the display.

In his message to Congress on the state of the Union yesterday President Truman laid down three main propositions the truth of which is scarcely open to challenge. The first is that the threat of a new world war is still very real: "We had one Pearl Harbor -- let's not get caught off guard again."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 9 -- The election of Carl Muelhaupt, secretary of the Central Service Company, to the board of directors of the Iowa-Des Moines National Bank, the retirement of Herbert L. Horton as chairman of the board and the election of five new cashiers were announced today by the bank following its annual meeting.

The election of Paul Hall to a fourth term as secretary-treasurer of the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, in two months of balloting that ended Dec. 31, was certified yesterday by the union's elections committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Dr. Guy E. Snavely, executive director of the Association of American Colleges, predicted in a report to the thirty-eighth annual meeting today that the association's resolutions committee would come out tomorrow against Universal Military Training.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- The United Nations Headquarters planning staffs estimated that building costs in the New York area have risen an average of 19.4 per cent since December, 1947, when the organization's home on the East River was approved.

The subject of the wedding gift to Frank Sedgman, hero of Australia's recent 3-2 victory over the United States in Davis Cup play, was brought up yesterday at the offices of the United States Lawn Tennis Association in a press interview with Frank Shields, the sun-tanned, non-playing American captain who returned from Sydney earlier in the week.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 9 -- The Netherlands announced today her readiness to open negotiations with Indonesia on a treaty to replace the abortive two - year - old Netherlands - Indonesia union and on the stubborn dispute over the status of Western New Guinea.
The services of the Nassau Bus Lines, Inc., subject of bitter criticism by passengers, halted yesterday at 3 P. M. as seventeen drivers went on strike.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 9 (UP) -- King Ranch's Islay Mist, coming off an easy victory on a sloppy track, proved her ability on a fast one today by nosing out the favored Season's Best in the $15,000 La Centinela Stakes at Santa Anita.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Attorneys for Jacob (Greasy Thumb) Guzik drew admissions from a Government witness in Federal Court today that the one-time Capone paymaster had good reason to remain silent before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee last year.

An increase last week of 2,651,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 125,209,000 barrels, compared with 122,558,000 a week earlier and 119,308,000 a year ago.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- At the request of the Soviet Union the United Nations today circulated as an official document statements from the "Central Committee of Peace Organizations of American and British Prisoners of War" in Korea that accused the United States of starting the war and "trampling" on the United Nations Charter.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Governor Dewey told the opening session of the 1952 Legislature today that the urgent need to accelerate the state's highway and institutional building programs made any reduction in state taxes impossible.
The Board of Estimate gave its official support yesterday to the plan of Construction Coordinator Robert Moses to activate the long dormant City Parking Authority.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Legislation designed to weaken the power of political bosses and encourage rank-and-file citizen participation in party primaries was introduced in the Legislature today by Assemblyman John R. Brook, Republican of Manhattan.

ALTHOUGH commercial fishing for tuna has constituted no problem for sports fishermen of the Atlantic Coast in the past, with the exception of a few minor clashes between anglers and harpooners in Maine, there is a possibility that school tuna enthusiasts may now face competition from the netters.

As City Council President Rudolph Halley returned yesterday from his two-week California honeymoon and again assailed the 3 per cent sales tax, departmental hearings on 1952-53 budget requests opened amid grim warnings by Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson that he was going to be "tougher than ever before in my life."

A right-alley thrust by Cal Gardner midway in the second period gave the Toronto Maple Leafs the edge that they held over the New York Rangers for the remainder of their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Mrs. Henry S. Prescott and Mrs. Gardner D. Stout, co-chairmen, are holding a series of meetings at the Pierre with members of their benefit committee to further fundraising plans for the Homemaker Service of the Children's Aid Society. The performance Tuesday night of "Antony and Cleopatra" at the Ziegfeld Theatre has been taken over to aid the charity.

The ninth annual Tobe award for distinguished contribution to American retailing was presented last night to Edward R. Mitton, president of the Jordan Marsh Company, Boston department store. The award was made at a dinner of about 300 educators, public officials and retail executives in the St. Regis Hotel.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- The repatriation of Soviet nationals among the refugees under the control of Western powers continues despite Soviet allegations to the contrary, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today in a communication to the members of the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 10 -- The United Nations delegation in Panmunjom rejected today for the second time a new Communist proposal for terms of an armistice in the Korean war that it had tentatively turned down yesterday but had promised to study further.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Stockholders of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank elected five new members to the board of directors at the annual shareholders' meeting today. The change was made in conjunction with the bank's adoption of a definite policy regarding the tenure and settlement of directors.

Action of the Armed Services Board of Contract Appeals in rejecting the Government contention for reversal of its decision on certain deliveries of knitwear should have wide significance for contractors, according to Harold Korzenik, counsel to the Bergman Knitting Mills, the appellant.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Once more the Red Cross is offering additional first-aid courses to New Yorkers. We hope that many will take this opportunity to help their neighbors and themselves. Ours is a big city where accidents occur all the time, and too often these accidents are fatal only because no one knows what to do and does nothing or, worse yet, does the wrong thing.

As the strike committee of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., warned yesterday that a port-wide dock strike would be called tonight unless its demands were met industry leaders appealed to Governor Dewey to intervene in an effort to stave off such a walkout.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- The Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today a resolution asking the nations administering United Nations trust territories to set deadlines for the independence of those regions.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The impression among diplomats here tonight was that the conversations between President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill left United States- British relations just about where they were before, if the communique issued today must be taken at face value.

Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, head of the United States Maritime Administration, announced yesterday that a new allotment of 117,000 tons of steel for shipbuilding for the second quarter of the year would permit resumption of the Government's mariner-class construction program.
A warning that business concerns found paying gratuities to Fire Department inspectors will face loss of their licenses was voiced yesterday by Third Deputy Fire Commissioner Albert S. Pacetta.

Fresh, bright colors and crisp, simple shapes long have been a strong point with Irene of New York. In her spring collection of millinery, viewed yesterday at her salon on East Fifty-second Street, she continued in this vein with a refreshing variety of level-on-the-head silhouettes ranging from large to small.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Eighteen bills carrying out recommendations of Governor Dewey were introduced in the Legislature today as the state's lawmakers convened for their 175th regular session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Start Musial, star outfielder of the Cardinals, improved his financial batting average today by winning a promise of quick action on his long-delayed $35,000 salary increase from Government stabilizers.

Following is the text of President Truman's State of the Union Message that he delivered to the joint session of the Congress of the United States in Washington yesterday, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

A black and white chow-and-police dog named Jackie did everything but take the witness stand yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Court in its efforts to testify against one of two persons who claimed to own it.
The Consolidated Edison system and the Utility Workers Union, C. I. O., agreed yesterday on a new contract covering 25,000 workers and granting wage rises that will cost $10,250,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Governor Dewey did not refer in his budget message to Mayor Impellitteri's proposal that the State take over the four city colleges in New York, but he did disclose that the state would increase its contribution for their support by $1,500,000 in the next fiscal year.
Sixteen gold bars valued at $60,000 to $70,000 were found late last night by the police in an automobile parked in a public parking space at Ninety-fifth Street and the Henry Hudson Parkway.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- Using its superior height to good advantage, Army's basketball team evened its record for the season by defeating Puerto Rico, 78 to 65, in the field house today.

A taxpayer building on plot 40 by 100 feet at 5222 Church Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by Clara Pollack to Morris Lerner and Faye Hashinsky. The sale was negotiated by E. Hashinsky as broker and title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

A gift of $2,549,000 to build a twelve-story student residence hall for Cornell University Medical College here was announced yesterday by the Olin Foundation, Inc., of 1 East Forty-fourth Street. The foundation was set up in 1940 by the late Franklin W. Olin, a Cornell engineering alumnus and chemical manufacturer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Washington Committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, which has opposed the presence of the Russian Tass agency's representatives in Congressional press galleries, today urged a revision of the gallery rules.

Dallas W. Smythe of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters and his research staff are in town again, watching all television programs over the seven metropolitan-area stations on a round-the-clock basis.

The seven New York daily newspapers showed a gain of 1.23 per cent over 1950 with their 1951 total linage at 151,838,055, according to figures made available yesterday. As shown in monthly reports, classified at 22,044,062 lines for the year showed the greatest gain, up 17.98 per cent.

Although "Anna Christie" is not the best of Eugene O'Neill's plays, it is better than most of the plays that turn up on Broadway, and it outranks any of the new plays of this season. Fortunately, it is also just right for a City Center season.

Let me express agreement with your splendid and timely editorial, entitled "Terrorism in Florida," where you state, in referring to the bombing to death of Harry T. Moore, state coordinator of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People: "The matter is not one for Florida alone, for when any citizen, for any reason, in any community, is denied basic liberties and protections we are all threatened."

The Press Attache of the Legation of Lebanon in his letter published in THE TIMES of Jan. 2 speaks of those Arabia "who were the only people fighting the battle of the Middle East side by side with the British Army during the First World War, while behind their backs the Balfour Declaration was issued.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The United Packing House Workers, C. I. O., protesting against a stalemate in nation-wide wage negotiations, staged temporary walkouts in five cities today. The demonstrations hampered meat production in Chicago, Kansas City, Omaha, South St. Paul, Minn., and St. Joseph, Mo.
A drive for $2,000,000 in 1952 was started yesterday by the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America at the annual dawn patrol breakfast.

HONG KONG, Jan 9 -- Expelled from China by the Communist authorities in Kwangsi Province, nine haggard looking United States Roman Catholic missionaries -- eight priests and one nun -- crossed the Hong Kong border amid the gloomy chill of a January drizzle today and found a welcome surprise awaiting them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Without knowledge of wrongdoing but ready to expose any that might be found, an Interstate and Foreign Commerce subcommittee of the House of Representatives today began the first investigation of the Securities and Exchange Commission in the eighteen years of its existence.

Net sales of the Consolidated Grocers Corporation for the twenty-four weeks to Dec. 15 rose 19 per cent above the volume attained a year earlier, but net profit was 45 per cent below that in the 1950 period, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- John Carter Vincent said today that he had a hand in State Department protests against seizure of an allegedly pro-Communist magazine published in Shanghai fifteen years ago.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 9 -- Dr. Elsie F. Doob plans to use funds deposited by her two brothers, Noel H. and Hermann Field, in a search for them, she said here today. The brothers have disappeared behind the Iron Curtain.

Raymond M. Hilliard, executive director of the Welfare Council of New York City, yesterday urged the licensing of all "percentage-basis" fund raisers as one of two steps toward suppressing- the charity racketeers that compete with legitimate organizations for the gift-dollars of New Yorkers.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly rejected today a Soviet proposal for immediate discussion of the Korean question at a high-level meeting of the Security Council. The committee then decided, over strenuous objections by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky, to postpone its own discussion of a permanent settlement in Korea, for the time being at least.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 9 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal court dismissed today an effort by railroads to prevent continued operations by a company hauling loaded freight cars by boat between Savannah, Ga., and New York.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Preliminary shopping ceased in mid-afternoon at the Winter Home Furnishings Market in the Merchandise and American Furniture Marts here today. Large as well as small retailers began to place furniture orders to cover their needs for the next sixty to ninety days and the third day of the market drew to a close with salesmen writing business at san accelerated pace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Members of the Joint Congressional Committee on Defense Production (the so-called "watchdog committee") were told today that mounting demands of military needs would cut more deeply into the civilian economy in the second quarter of 1952 than at any time since the rearmament program was started.

With the tube operations of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company producing $510,492 less net income last year than in 1950, the company's over-all operations resulted in a deficit of $899,380, William Reid, the president, reported yesterday.

FALMOUTH, England, Jan. 9 -- Seafaring folk of this port are proud but not astonished at Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen's fortitude and mate Kenneth R. Dancy's boldness aboard the drifting, sea-battered Flying Enterprise.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Solicitor General Philip B. Perlman asked the Supreme Court today to uphold contempt sentences meted out to the five attorneys who defended the eleven top Communist leaders jailed for conspiracy.

Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman of Temple Emanu-El, Sixty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, has been elected president of the Association of Reform Rabbis of New York and Vicinity, succeeding Rabbi David J. Seligson of Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.
I read the letter by Peter Perine which you recently published, on Tito's position in Yugoslavia today, and the rejoinder by Sherman Ewing published in your Issue of Jan, 7.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Gov. Fielding Wright, former Vice Presidential candidate of the States Rights Democrats, said today the cause was not lost. In a speech to the opening session of the Mississippi Legislature the retiring Governor maintained:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman's reference today in his State of the Union Message to an increase in the active military forces does not portend any surprisingly large increases in manpower procurement, according to authoritative sources.
BERLIN, Jan. 9 -- Otto Grotewohl, East German Premier, charged today that the Schuman plan would lead "directly" to a third world war and end all hopes for a reunited Germany.
MADRID, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Thirty warships of the United States Sixth Fleet steamed into eight Spanish ports today on a good will mission.

" It is my purpose again to offer you a budget balanced without increased taxes." With this sentence in it, Governor Dewey's annual message to the Legislature can hardly avoid being, to the New York taxpayer, among the most pleasant reading available to him at the moment.

Directors of the Long Island Lighting Company at a meeting yesterday in Mineola, L. I., voted to place the common stock on a 90-cent annual basis with the declaration of a quarterly dividend of 22 1/2 cents a share. Previously the stock paid 20 cents quarterly or a total of 80 cents a year. The dividend will be distributed on Feb. 1.
Dr. Fred R. Conklin has been appointed works manager of Tennessee Eastman Company, Kingsport, Tenn., a division of the Eastman Kodak Company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Counsel for four Knoxville Negroes asked the Supreme Court today to order a review of Tennessee's racial segregation laws that apply to education.

Formation of the Westchester Commuters Committee to oppose the New York Central Railroad's efforts to obtain new fare increases was announced yesterday by Dr. S. L. Nash of Yorktown Heights, N. Y. He is temporary secretary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman's recommendation for larger Social Security benefits was received by Congress with lack of enthusiasm today, but the proposal's political appeal in an election year may prove to be a strong force for favorable action.

Nineteen civics students from a Brooklyn junior high school brought the proceeds of a cake sale to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday and increased total receipts for the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to $319,744.97 for the year.

It will be the team of James Russo and Michael Ellis that will sponsor the return to Broadway of Orson Welles in his production of "Othello." According to the terms of the deal just concluded. Mr. Welles will open here in the Shakespearean drama of the violent Moor between Oct. 1 and Nov. 15, alternating it with "The Merchant of Venice." The project will be limited to sixteen weeks.

The recent announcement that an Amateur Artists Association is being organized under the aegis of the very professional "American Artist" magazine serves to focus attention on the burgeoning interest in art, evident from increased museum attendance, sales of paintings and enrollment in art schools.

Columbia opened its defense of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League title by defeating Harvard, 68 -- 51, before a scant crowd at the University Hall gymnasium last night. The Lions, taller and faster than their old rivals from Cambridge, were in command from the outset.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 9 -- Dr. Russell H. Wagner, head of the University of Virginia's Department of Speech and Drama, was found dead today beside his automobile not far from his home. Dr. Woodberry Perkins, Coroner, said death had been caused by a gunshot wound in the head, apparently self-inflicted.
Dry goods retailers were urged yesterday to give more emphasis to products which have won consumer confidence as a means of increasing sales in a year of tighter profits.
