SEATTLE, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The forty-five-man crew of the storm-battered freighter Pennsylvania abandoned the ship tonight as she wallowed bow down in heavy seas off the British Columbia coast.

France would "demand" United States aid in the event of an invasion of Indo-China by the Chinese Communists, General Alphonse Pierre Juin, Inspector-General of the French Army, one of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's top aides in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said yesterday.

The Soviet attempt to shift discussions of a Korean armistice from Panmunjom to Paris failed yesterday when the General Assembly of the United Nations rejected a Soviet demand for a special high-level Security Council meeting to take up the Korean problem.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 -- The tanker Nissyo Maru, first ship to be sent here by the Idemitsu Kosan Company, one of the biggest petroleum distributors in Japan, took on a large load of petroleum products today at near-by Oleum while world traders and civic leaders at a reception aboard the vessel hailed an expansion of trade between Japan and the San Francisco Bay area.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Most sections of the stock market were dull today. Investors appeared to be waiting to see what further steps the Government proposed to take to meet the financial crisis.

The once-beaten quintets of St. John's University and New York University will tackle high-scoring opponents at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Redmen are paired with Loyola of Chicago in the 7:45 P. M. opener. The Violets will face Duke, whose line-up features the heralded Dick Groat.

Edmund Kurtz, with Artur Balsam as his pianist, gave a rarely interesting 'cello recital last night in Carnegie Hall. The fact that Mr. Kurtz played with remarkable warmth and brilliancy is the half of it: his program was one of the most interesting and admirably contrasted that we have heard at any 'cello recital in recent years.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Choppy fluctuations were the rule in grains today, but with July and September, wheat showing strength on rumors that a move might be started in Congress to have the support level raised 5 per cent on wheat, which, if put through, would mean a rise of about 10 cents a bushel in the loan level.

The I. Miller spring shoes displayed yesterday at the Pierre Hotel introduced a delicate, feminine feeling. This was apparent from sandals to spectator pumps and in a new molded three-inch heel called "Eiffel," and even in very low flats.

FREEPORT, L. I., Jan. 9 -- Officials of Utilities Lines, Inc., a subsidiary of Bee Lines, Inc., operating a bus route from Freeport to Patchogue, said that a slowdown in schedules was started here today by the drivers in protesting the dismissal of a driver last Monday.

The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that it would file today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed issue of $125,000,000 in sinking fund debentures. The company also said that arrangements were being completed for borrowing $100,000,000 from a group of banks.
ATLANTA, Jan. 9 -- A 22-year-old bride, whose first husband "came back to life" with the recent publication of Korean prisoner of war rolls, today sought an annulment of her second marriage.

VIENNA, Jan. 9 -- For the first time since the earliest days of the four-power occupation of Austria, all four powers participated this evening in what was described as an "international sports night," at which the United States Army in Vienna was host.
ATLANTA, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Very Rev. John B. Walthour was consecrated as the fourth Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Atlanta today.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 9 -- The Israeli Parliament today overruled opposition attempts to prevent direct negotiations with Germany on reparations. At the same time it put brakes on the Government's plans to begin negotiations.

The public interest aroused in the law of salvage by the mettle of Capt. H. K. Carlsen suggests that this is an opportune time to direct attention to an anomaly which exists in the law of life salvage.

The public interest aroused in the law of salvage by the mettle of Capt. H. K. Carlsen suggests that this is an opportune time to direct attention to an anomaly which exists in the law of life salvage.

Solution of the problem of "obvious tax inequities" affecting banks will influence "vitally the future of our independent banking system," according to the annual report of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

" College students ought to be the first to obey the law instead of flouting it," Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh told Nathan Korman, 19-year-old New York University freshman and basketball player arraigned yesterday in Traffic Court for ignoring sixteen traffic tickets.

California borrowed $50,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance state aid to veterans and to local schools. Bond issues totaling this amount were awarded to a banking syndicate headed by Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and National City Bank, here, at an interest cost to the borrower of 1.7995 per cent for the school bonds and 1.7275 per cent for the veterans' aid bonds.
Commodity prices were irregular yesterday. Vegetable oils followed cotton to higher ground. There were strong gains in coffee. Wool lost ground. Sugar and cocoa moved irregularly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration said today that a number of rules violations and "discrepancies" had been turned up in an intensive three-day inspection of all C-46 aircraft operated by nonsceduled airlines.
Greentree Stable's flashy Tom Fool, champion 2-year-old of 1951, tops the weights under 126 pounds in John B. Campbell's Experimental Free Handicap ratings announced yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 9 -- A proposed pension plan for bank employes was approved by the Union Bank of Commerce shareholders today. All directors were re-elected.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- In a surprising reversal of form, Colgate rolled up its most top-sided basketball victory over Cornell tonight, 60 -- 34. The Big Red had beaten Colgate earlier in the season, 58 -- 51.

Fillip jewelry and scarfs contribute to the "costume look" it was demonstrated yesterday at a showing of Coro Jewelry and Glentex scarfs presented at the Pierre Hotel. A panorama of fashions from beachwear to ball gowns was accompanied by the corresponding accessories for the coming season.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of the communique issued today by President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill on their talks:

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Gov. Fuller Warren told a group of northern whites and Negroes today that he was increasing the reward for conviction of the persons who killed a Florida Negro couple by placing a bomb under their bedroom.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's annual message to the Legislature today:

The bleak, hazy Port of New York could not dampen the high spirits of the thirty crewmen and two passengers from the hurricane-battered Flying Enterprise who arrived here at 4 P. M. yesterday on the Navy transport General A. W. Greely.
BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Ted Williams, the Red Sox slugger, today was recalled by the United States Marines for what is expected to be at least seventeen months of active service.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday and closed with gains of 8 to 26 points, with new crop months showing the most strength.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio announced late today that he would enter the Republican Presidential primary in Illinois on April 8.

A sixty-family apartment house at 1226 Sherman Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Rubin Grutman to the 1226 Sherman Avenue Corporation. The property is assessed at $250,000 and was sold subject to mortgages of $190,000. Saul Berger, broker, represented the buyer. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Bank of America, the world's largest, reported today that its savings and time deposits in 1951 recorded the sharpest increase of any post-war year. It also reported that use of bank credit reached a new peak. Resources totaled $7,531,296,927, up $667,938,714 for the year.

The stock market covered a wide range of operations yesterday, but only in relation to individual issues. Various stocks reacted in varying fashion to the latest Washington directives on the use of materials for civilian products. These cross-currents produced no clear-cut result on the market and left prices irregularly lower at the close.

Nicholas Nyaradi, former Finance Minister of Hungary, went to Moscow in an endeavor to reduce a Russian claim of $200,000,000 to a sum his country could begin to pay. From his experiences there, he has written a book that Crowell will publish Jan. 31 under the title "My Ringside Seat in Moscow."
Trains of the Long Island Rail Road were 98.4 per cent on time in December, J. Frank Doolan, its chief operating officer, announced last night.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 10 -- Threatened by renewed gales, the battered American freighter Flying Enterprise, by now almost on her beam ends, continued to drift helplessly toward the English Channel early this morning after all efforts to connect a new towline from the salvage tug Turmoil had failed.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- Israel today proposed the dissolution of the Palestine Conciliation Commission and the creation of a new good offices group that would be available, when conditions improve, to mediate the political differences between Israel and the Arab states.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Fighting halted on one western Korean battlefield yesterday, but flared near-by. Smaller clashes erupted on the eastern front near what is known as Heartbreak Ridge, north of Yanggu and west of the Mundung Valley.

IN many respects horses are similar to people. They have likes and dislikes. Some may even prefer vanilla, although that cannot be guaranteed. But it was obvious last summer that Alfred Vanderbilt's crack 2-year-old colt, Cousin, didn't like the main track at Saratoga. He sulked whenever he had to train there.

A fair labor practices bill that would permit policemen and firemen, in addition to all other city employes, to join labor organizations of their own choosing was introduced into the City Council yesterday.
The stagehands of the Metropolitan Opera yesterday surprised Rudolf Bing, their general manager, when they threw an impromptu party for him to celebrate his fiftieth birthday.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 9 -- The Tunisian Government expressed its official dissatisfaction today with the response of French authorities to Nationalist demands for Tunisian control of the internal affairs of this French protectorate.

SEATTLE, Wash., Jan. 9 (UP) -- A New York doctor who contended he had been illegally drafted into the Army as a private after his commission as a captain in the Air Force had been revoked lost his court case today to force the Army to release him.

SEATTLE, Wash., Jan. 9 (UP) -- A New York doctor who contended he had been illegally drafted into the Army as a private after his commission as a captain in the Air Force had been revoked lost his court case today to force the Army to release him.

Gross operating income of the New York Trust Company in 1951, amounting to $16,084,885, was $2,586,936 above the previous year and marked a new high in the history of the bank, Charles J. Stewart, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday. However, he said, the provision for taxes also reached a new peak of $4,259,000, equivalent to $7.10 a share on capital stock.

A triangular plot of about 25,000 square feet at the southwest corner of Broadway, Seventy-third Street and Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased by Smilen Brothers, operators of a chain of fruit and grocery stores, who are erecting a super market on an adjoining site.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Fighting halted on one western Korean battlefield yesterday, but flared near-by. Smaller clashes erupted on the eastern front near what is known as Heartbreak Ridge, north of Yanggu and west of the Mundung Valley.

IN many respects horses are similar to people. They have likes and dislikes. Some may even prefer vanilla, although that cannot be guaranteed. But it was obvious last summer that Alfred Vanderbilt's crack 2-year-old colt, Cousin, didn't like the main track at Saratoga. He sulked whenever he had to train there.

A fair labor practices bill that would permit policemen and firemen, in addition to all other city employes, to join labor organizations of their own choosing was introduced into the City Council yesterday.
The stagehands of the Metropolitan Opera yesterday surprised Rudolf Bing, their general manager, when they threw an impromptu party for him to celebrate his fiftieth birthday.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 9 -- The Tunisian Government expressed its official dissatisfaction today with the response of French authorities to Nationalist demands for Tunisian control of the internal affairs of this French protectorate.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 9 -- The long-awaited report of the television committee will be made public tomorrow as one of the most important developments of the forty-sixth annual convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

New markets for cotton and wool may be developed as a result of research studies under way in natural and synthetic fibers, Dr. John H. Dillon, director, Textile Research Institute, Princeton, N. J., predicted here yesterday.

New issues of railroad, public utility and industrial securities having a market value of more than $12,000,000 will be put on the market today by underwriting syndicates. The offerings are as follows:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UP) -- The Supreme Court refused today the plea of four Tennessee Negroes for a ruling on whether school segregation laws in themselves were unconstitutional.

IF maps of the Caribbean were drawn to show all the imaginary islands which novelists have located there in recent years the blue that indicates salt water would be largely replaced by the green that stands for dry land. Writers have always loved the sun, and have sought it in Italy, the Balearic Islands, Honolulu, Tahiti, New and Old Mexico.
Customs collections at the Port of New York last month suffered their usual seasonal drop, but this time the decline was described as "severe" as compared with previous post-war years.
The country owes you deep gratitude for your great editorial on "Eisenhower."

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 10 -- Varying methods of performing the routine inspections of airliners required by law were discussed today at the opening session of the Civil Aeronautics Board's hearings here on the crash of a non-scheduled Curtiss C-46 transport here on Dec. 16 that resulted in the deaths of the fifty-two passengers and four crew members who were bound from Newark Airport for Tampa and Miami, Fla.

The double bill of Puccini and Richard Strauss given last night at the Metropolitan came off extremely well in the performances of comedy and tragedy. We are of those who do not like to dilute our "Salome" with any other operatic ingredient on a single occasion and would fain experience the score of Strauss by itself and be none the worse for a relatively short evening's entertainment.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Several executives of "blue chip" home furnishings factories reported here today that business written so far at the Winter Home Furnishings Market has greatly exceeded volume at the June market. The report indicated that in one instance at least orders are heavier than on the first three days of last January's market, when abnormal "scare" buying was under way.

FALMOUTH, England, Friday, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Capt. Kurt Carlsen and tug mate Kenneth Dancy, bone-tired from their stand against the sea, slept early today under sedatives aboard the British tug Turmoil.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- Ahmad el-Shukairi, assistant secretary general of the Arab League, proposed today that three mixed committees be formed to settle the three chief issues between Israel and the Arab states -- refugees, Jerusalem and the delineation of borders.

Less criticism and more practical understanding should be applied to young people who have had brushes with the law, because in many instances they are merely following a shallow moral code laid down by their elders, Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl declared here yesterday.

Burglars broke into the block- long garage and salesroom of the N. Y. U. Oldsmobile Company at 281 Fordham Road, the Bronx, Wednesday night or early yesterday morning, ransacked the premises and escaped with two automobiles, tires, batteries, $200 in cash and twelve cases of Scotch whisky, according to the police of the Ryer Avenue station.
The Board of Transportation reported yesterday an operating deficit of $9,462,975 for the municipal transit system for the five months ended on Nov. 30, 1951.

The first sale of a membership on the New York Stock Exchange in 1952, announced yesterday at $51,000, off $3,000 from the final sale price in 1951, coincided with a sharp decline in the volume of bond and stock trading so far this year, compared with a year ago for the period.

Gen. Winfield Scott and Gen. Franklin Pierce, mentioned by President Truman in his press conference yesterday in reference to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and 1952, were rivals for the Presidency in the election of 1852, a bitter campaign in which Scott was "scurriously" attacked. The victor, Pierce, found his Administration difficult and disappointing.

Retail prices on both large and medium Grade A eggs are down 4 cents a dozen for the second successive week, bringing them to the lowest levels since last March. The large are now 71 cents a dozen and the medium 61 cents, a downward shift of 8 and 14 cents, respectively, since a year ago, the Department of Markets reported yesterday.
Engineering and construction concerns responsible for more than $1,000,000,000 annually in industrial and commercial contracts see no let-up in operations in the next two years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that stocks of corn on farms on Jan. 1 were 1,919,269,000 bushels. This compares with 2,106,698,000 bushels a year ago and 2,050,791,000 for the ten year (1941-50) average on Jan. 1.

HARRISON, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- Churches, schools, the Boy Scouts of America and several charitable organizations here are receiving from the Harrison Tax Receiver some New Year's "greetings" that are knocking annual budgets out of kilter. Letters from the official contain bills for special taxes never before levied against exempt properties in this town.
BAYONNE, N. J., Jan. 10 -- The strike of 1,900 employes of the Tidewater Associated Oil Company refinery and tank farm here, now in its sixth day, appeared far from settlement today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Supporters of Harold E. Stassen for the Republican Presidential nomination said tonight that a slate of delegates would be entered in the Illinois primary April 8 to provide a full test with Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

Consumption of portland cement in 1952 is expected to be about 10 per cent less than the record 240,000,000 barrels in 1951, it was reported here yesterday by producers. The expected volume of about 216,000,000 barrels will be the third largest in the history of the industry.

KALIMPONG, India, Jan. 10 -- The first Chinese Communist attempt to fly essential supplies to Lhasa has failed, according to latest reports reaching here. It is understood that strong winds over lofty mountain ranges prevented the plane, which took off from an airfield near Chamdo, on Tibet's eastern border, from reaching the capital of Lhasa.

As to the possibility of compulsory liability insurance on automobiles in New York State, Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature said, merely: "Consideration is * * * being given to the insertion of a question on automobile registration blanks requesting information on insurance to procure an accurate survey of the number of uninsured motorists."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, and four Republican colleagues formally called today for a nonpartisan investigation of the Office of Alien Property Custodian.

Today's new film is "The Model and the Marriage Broker," a Twentieth Century-Fox romantic comedy with Thelma Ritter, Scott Brady, Jeanne Crain, Zero Mostel and Michael O'Shea, at the Roxy. George Cukor directed and Charles Brackett produced from a script written by Mr. Brackett, Walter Reisch and Richard Breen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Chrysler Corporation applied to the Office of Price Stabilization today for higher wholesale ceiling prices for its four makes of cars, Chrysler, Plymouth, DeSoto and Dodge. This leaves only two major companies, Crosley and Packard, that have not made similar requests under provisions of the Capehart amendment to the Defense Production Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today gave Tennessee as Gas Transmission Company and its wholesale customers eighteen more hours to reach an agreement on rate increases designed to add $11,400,000 annually to the company's gas revenues.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- During the week ended Jan. 9, member bank reserves increased $5,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Louis M. Kratz, former Wright-Patterson Air Force Base procurement employe, pleaded guilty in Federal Court today to five counts of receiving gifts from an Air Force contractor and of conspiracy to commit fraud.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- The Economic Committee of the United Nations General Assembly adopted a nine-power resolution today suggesting that international loan institutions give "sympathetic consideration" to economic projects designed to aid land reform programs.

Methods used by workers in the adoption field to judge the suitability of couples seeking a child and to predict the probable future development of infants should be submitted "to the clear light of objective research," Miss Dorothea P. Coe, executive director of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, 304 East Thirty-third Street, said yesterday.

THOSE who planned their Florida sailfish excursion for this week will put more faith in their hunches in the future, for a call just came in from Stuart reporting more of these fish than ever known in the memory of the most doddering inhabitant of that angling resort.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Judge James W. Morris ruled today in the United States District Court here that Lieut. Gen. P. T. Mow and Col. V. S. Hsiang, former Chinese Air Force officers, must answer by Jan. 21 the complaint filed against them by the Republic of China.
Charles B. Reeder has been appointed economic analyst by the Armstrong Cork Company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Association of American Colleges, by a voice vote that was not unanimous, urged Congress today to defeat the pending program to begin Universal Military Training.

Among the many shows that opened this week in the art galleries, those worthy of special note include the paintings of Italy and Little Italy by Frank di Gioia at the Milch Galleries; Peter Todd Mitchell's portraits and drawings at the American-British; and "sculpture for children" by Frances Weiss at the Tibor de Nagy Gallery.

CARNARVON, Wales, Friday, Jan. 11 -- An Irish airliner crashed and burned on a Welsh mountainside during a storm last night, and airline officials announced that all twenty-three persons aboard were killed.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- At the personal request of President Truman, Representative Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, returned to Paris today to remind United Nations delegates publicly of Washington's "deep concern" over the arrest and fining of four United States fliers by the Hungarian Government.

The strike committee of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., after a two-hour session, voted unanimously last night to hold in abeyance its threatened port-wide work stoppage set for 8 A. M. today.
AUBURN, N. Y., Jan. 10 (AP) -- A desperate fugitive shot and wounded himself today after holding a woman hostage for six hours in a cemetery caretaker's house surrounded by 100 policemen.
GENEVA, Jan. 10 -- Eight countries signed today two conventions that would reduce the delay to railway traffic caused by customs inspection at frontiers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Thirty-eight Republican Senators, headed by Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, the new Minority floor leader, petitioned the Senate today to recommend, in effect, that Dr. Philip C. Jessup, Ambassador-at-Large, be recalled on a vote of "no confidence" as a delegate to the sixth session of the United Nations General Assembly meeting in Paris.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 1 to 5 points net lower than on Wednesday.

Acquisition by the city of the last piece of land in Brooklyn needed to construct the new $80,000,000 Brooklyn-Queens Expressway was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The strip is about 4,000 feet long from Kent Avenue to Grand Street Extension.

Fernando Valenti bridged the gap between the antique nature of his instrument and the necessity for present-day expression by giving the first performance of Vincent Persichetti's Sonata for Harpsichord in Town Hall last night. With equal conviction he filled the remainder of his program with music from the sixteenth, seventeenth and eighteenth centuries.

The National Motor Boat Show, which has been taking shape for several days on the four exposition floors of Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue, will open with the usual elaborate ceremonies tonight at 7 o'clock.

CHICAGO, Jan, 10 -- A modest revival in the export buying of wheat, flour and corn stimulated buying of grain futures today. There was also some support for wheat due to bullish reports from Australia, indicating that that country would be unable to fill all its International Wheat Agreement export quota sales.

Management representation was in the minority yesterday at the postponed first annual meeting of the R. K. O. Theatres Corporation, with the result that the Irving Trust Company, holding 929,020 of the 3,914,913 shares outstanding as trustee for Howard Hughes, had the balance of power.
Commodity prices tumbled yesterday. In New York futures trading there were no exceptions. Sugar reached new lows.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Philip Murray's United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., told a Wage Stabilization Board panel today that the union's whole wage "package," variously estimated at from 30 to 50 cents an hour, was entitled to approval under Federal pay controls.

ABILENE, Kan., Jan. 10 (UP) -- Henry Jameson, president of the original Eisenhower-for-President Grass Roots Club here, said today that President Truman "apparently was confused on his facts" when he told a news conference in Washington that General Eisenhower was a Democratic precinct worker at the age of 18 here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Sales of Armour Co. reached a record high in the fiscal year ended Oct. 27 but higher taxes and price controls dragged net earnings below the 1950 level, Frederick W. Specht, president, said today.

TOKYO, Jan. 10 -- The first of the major Japanese war criminals sentenced by the International Military Tribunal for the Far East and now free on parole from Sugamo Prison, former Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu, now is being backed for an important party office as many of Japan's pre-war figures return to public life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Serious delays in the production of essential weapons were acknowledged to Congress today by the Administration as it appealed for quick action in expanding the North Atlantic Treaty Organization by formally bringing in Greece and Turkey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The United States proposed to Britain today that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Chinese Nationalist Government be given limited participation in the signing of the Japanese peace treaty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended Jan. 5, dropped 21 per cent below sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Jo Davidson, the sculptor who died in Tours, France, on Jan. 2, left an American estate of more than $150,000, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The Court of Appeals refused today to grant a new trial for Lewis Wolfe, self-styled Messiah convicted of first degree murder in the death of his wife.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Michael V. DiSalle, Director of Price Stabilization, charged today that various wholesale gas pipeline companies were attempting to raise profits above the pre-Korean war level and, through rate increases, to pass on to the consumer recently imposed Federal income tax rises.

Washington's decision to unpeg Government bonds was the outstanding business news development of 1951, according to a poll of the 102 office managers of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, just released.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- Raising of a fund estimated at $3,000,000 for the relief of those stranded by the dissolution of the International Refugee Organization was approved today by the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Following is an abridged and unofficial transcript of President Truman's news conference today during which he replied to questions dealing with the 1952 Presidential campaign. Direct quotation of the President's remarks is forbidden, except with specific permission. Reporters who ask the questions are by custom unidentified except in instances where identification is necessary because the President, in his reply, refers directly to the reporter or his newspaper.
Corn meal, an excellent energy food for cold winter days, is the thrifty staple employed in today's main dish recipes devised by Mrs. Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, THE TIMES' home economist.

The fate of the old Brevoort Hotel and ten adjoining brown-stone dwellings, including the historic Mark Twain house, finally has been resolved after many recurrent rumors concerning the future use of the valuable block-front.

A protest demonstration against the arrest yesterday of 140 striking agents of the Prudential Intrance Company of America as sorderly persons will be staged day at the company's home office Newark, officials of the Insurance Agents International Union, F. L., announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Truman has declined for a second time to release for investigation by a Senate investigating subcommittee a confidential report made by the Securities and Exchange Commission to President Roosevelt on the Empire Ordnance Corporation during World War II, it was disclosed today by Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican of California, subcommittee head.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- Within the next two months two developments of importance to the relationship between Spain and the United States are expected. Officials working on the problem hope that by approximately March 1 a pair of bilateral agreements will have been signed by Madrid and Washington covering economic and military aid programs.
Production of raw steel in the United States in 1951 reached the record level of 105,133,424 net tons, according to a preliminary report issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The plight of the contemporary worker is the subject of a study by Gordon Rattray Taylor that Houghton Mifflin will issue Jan. 22 under the title "Are Workers Human?" Mr. Taylor contends that good pay ranks seventh among the factors that make a job attractive.
A new system of crime reporting, designed to assure the citizen of quick and thorough action on his complaint to the police, was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

The Stuyvesant Residence Club at 74 St. Marks Place, an interim for emotionally disturbed teen-age boys who are well enough to leave institutional care but are not ready to live alone or with their families, was dedicated last night. The building was converted from the former Stuyvesant Neighborhood House at a cost of $125,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Truman today turned the Governmental clean-up job over to Attorney General J. Howard McGrath and said that Mr. McGrath would remain in his Cabinet.

If inflationary trends abroad continue, the United States may soon be in trouble with its ceiling prices for coffee, which put this country in the position of "interfering in the economy of friendly foreign nations," Robert E. Atkinson, president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, said yesterday in his annual report for the board of managers.

Congratulations on the bold and weighty editorial carrying the endorsement of General Eisenhower. Two points, not often referred to, seem to me especially worthy of emphasis. One is the extraordinary ability of Eisenhower to weld diverse and sometimes discordant elements into an effective operation team.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Treasury abandoned today its thirty-three-year-old policy of granting immunity to tax evaders who disclosed their violations before an official investigation began.

SEATTLE, Jan. 10 -- Two ships arrived today in the area where forty-five men abandoned the disabled freighter Pennsylvania but found no trace of the wallowing vessel or her crew. A misty dot on a radar screen was the only reported clue.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Prices fell in nearly all parts of the Stock Exchange today. Statements by the Government that its measures to meet the financial crisis would hurt scared away investors and led to a little more selling that kept industrial shares dull all day. British Government securities also weakened, but they recovered their losses.

A panel of 300 blue-ribbon tales-men was reduced rapidly to half that number in General Sessions yesterday as preliminary proceedings began in the extortion and conspiracy trial of James J. Moran, one-time city official and friend of former Mayor William O'Dwyer.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals of the National Basketball Association smashed their own season's scoring record tonight by defeating the New York Knickerbockers, 110 to 96.

Children see the world through their parents' eyes. and this interpretation is one of the most influential factors in their over-all character development, Dr. Joseph Michaels of the Mental Hygiene Clinic at Lebanon Hospital, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- J. C. Bradford of Nashville, Tenn., the first delegate actually chosen for the Republican National Convention, said today that he was pledged to support Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the nomination. Unanimously elected in the Fifth Congressional District convention at Nashville, he issued this statement through Taft headquarters:

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The creation of a joint legislative committee to investigate the State Liquor Authority and county, alcoholic beverage control boards was proposed today by State Senator Harold I. Panken, Manhattan Democrat.

The Port of New York Authority is prepared to spend $500,000,000, including $200,000,000 for an entirely new Hudson River tunnel to handle increasing vehicular traffic, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the bi-state agency, said yesterday.

The public interest requires a change in the Food and Drug Law to insure proper pre-testing of cosmetic products and synthetic detergents, according to medical authorities who testified yesterday at hearings of the Select House Committee investigating the use of chemicals in food and cosmetics.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- The fact that there are many kinds of modern, a matter fully apparent to anyone shopping the semi-annual wholesale home furnishings market now in progress here was emphasized at the opening of the Good Design exhibit this morning.

YONKERS, Jan. 10 -- Oral bombs breached this city's civil defense front at two strategic points tonight, with fifteen members of the air-raid warden service, on the one hand, resigning because they felt the service was being treated as an unwanted "step-child," and, on the other, seventy-three members of the Second Battalion of the Auxiliary Police Corps quitting in a row over their uniforms.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 10 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who has taken the lead in an effort to bring land reform to Iran, completed today the distribution to the peasants of his most fertile and valuable estate, Varamin, near Teheran.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Republican Committee on Committees today assigned Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, to the Senate Appropriations Committee. He will will the seat left vacant by the death last month of Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican of Nebraska.

The Government's case against Frank Costello on eleven indictments accusing him of contempt before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee last spring was at resting point at 6 o'clock yesterday, the close of the trial's fourth day.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 10 -- The Allied-German plans for the remilitarization of West Germany probably would be modified to permit the creation of a national Germany Army subject to the decisions of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization should the European army project fail, authoritative sources indicated today.
Leaders of a major retail trade group called yesterday for "substantial rethinking" on whether price controls should be modified.

The transition of "My Friend Irma" from radio to television, where it made its debut at 10:30 P.M. Tuesday over C.B.S., is a matter on which there evidently is going to be considerable difference of opinion. The saga of the proverbial dumb blonde, basically what
An alabaster bust of Sri Ramakrishna, an Indian mystic, was unveiled last night at the Ramakrishna-Vivekananda Center, 17 East Ninety-fourth Street. The bust had been executed by Malvina Hoffman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Truman today named six public members of a Committee on Government Contract Compliance, which is charged with policing enforcement of Federal contract clauses barring racial or religious discrimination in employment.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, informed the Board of Education yesterday that the city's public school system would require $271,701,303 for operating expenses in the fiscal year 1952-53, starting July 1. This is $32,790,468 more than the current budget and the largest in the system's history.

One of the largest judgments in history against an individual was handed down yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld. His target was Harrison Williams, 78-year-old utilities executive whose empire rivaled that of the late Samuel Insull in the Twenties.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 11 -- Heavy snowstorms grounded nearly all United Nations planes yesterday, and ground fighting was limited to light clashes for the possession of a few hills.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 10 -- Further information regarding a financing plan to meet the needs of its sizable military and Commercial production programs was revealed today by the Glenn L. Martin Company.

A Brooklyn brassiere firm and its two owners were indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury for seeking to defraud the United States Government of a total of $461,315 in taxes for 1945 and 1946.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- President Truman today nominated retired Admiral Raymond A. Spruance of California to be Ambassador to the Philippines.

Frank D. Schroth, publisher of The Brooklyn Eagle, has won the 1951 Medal of the Downtown Brooklyn Association for "the most distinguished service for Brooklyn." The presentation will be at the annual luncheon of the association in the Towers Hotel,
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- An obscure Rembrandt self-portrait has been placed on sale here for an asking price of $50,000.

Ernie Durando will tackle Rocky Castellani in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The meeting will be the second between the pair, Castellani having outpointed the Bayonne, N. J., middleweight in the Garden two years ago.

Prime Minister Churchill received visits from the Duke of Windsor and other friends yesterday at the apartment of Bernard M. Baruch, 4 East Sixty-sixth Street, before leaving last night for Ottawa, where he will confer with Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent and other Canadian leaders.

The Bankers Trust Company has been appointed trustee, paying agent and registrar for $5,000,000 of Empire State Building Corporation's fifteen-year 5 per cent sinking fund second mortgage leasehold bonds due on Dec. 1, 1966.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 -- A plastic wafer, about the size of a five-cent piece, as displayed to civil defense leaders today as a device designed to permit mass screening of persons for radio-activity after an atomic bomb attack.

Bids for the construction of the 205-bed Long Island Jewish Hospital were formally opened yesterday at the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, 71 West Forty-seventh Street. The action came after a two-year community drive for a large, general non-sectarian hospital to serve Queens and Nassau.

In two major upsets at Madison Square Garden last night, St. John's bowed, 68 -- 64, to Loyola of Chicago and New York University lost, 74 -- 72, to Duke. It was the second setback of the campaign for both local quintets, which were logical choices to triumph before 6,538 fans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Two former Government girls said they were notified today that they had won a four-year fight to clear themselves of security charges brought by the Army Department.

President Truman has submitted to the Senate the peace treaty with Japan, together with the parallel security pact permitting continued maintenance of American defense forces in that country, and has asked for ratification of these documents. Both have already been ratified by Japan.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Jan. 10 -- Word of her husband's safe withdrawal from the long vigil aboard his doomed ship Flying Enterprise broke a forty-eight-hour news blackout this morning for 31-year-old Mrs. Agnes Carlsen. Physically ill and emotionally upset, she had been unable for the last two days to read or listen to reports of Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen's heroic efforts.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- A proposal to amend the State Constitution to permit bingo games by organizations promoting religious and charitable activities was introduced in the Legislature today.

GENEVA, Jan. 10 -- The United States has decided not to press Britain just now on recent divergencies between Britain's trade policy and her obligations to other countries under various international agreements.

When the Flying Enterprise finally succumbed in the unequal battle with the sea, she took down into the depths with her valuable antiques and art objects, many of which had survived two centuries before they vanished forever.

Percy C. Spender, Australian Ambassador to the United States, in an address here last night pledged Australian support to overall British world policy, and counseled the United States it could not continue to exercise leadership of the free world without British support.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 11 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,125, for Thursday's operations:
The things said about General Eisenhower in your editorial are commendable and agreed to by most citizens. He is a great soldier and worthy.

The majority of the fifty service men who are overdue at their bases on the West Coast after spending Christmas furloughs here and were stranded by lack of air transportation were on their way back yesterday by train.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- An injustice has been done to Winston Churchill, the well-known hat fancier. That hat he wore to Washington the other day was not bought in 1917 as may have been inferred from a dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 8. It was a relatively new model only 25 or 30 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Jacob (Greasy Thumb) Guzik, at one time linked to the Capone gang in Chicago, was acquitted today of contempt of Congress charges stemming from his refusal to testify before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Superior Court Judge Thomas E. Troland ruled today that Republican Mayor William C. Celentano had been elected to his fourth term on Nov. 6 by the margin of only two votes over Richard C. Lee, his Democratic rival. More than 68,000 votes had been cast.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Judge Emerich B. Freed has taken under advisement a demand by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it be permitted to go ahead with an action against Otis Co., Cleveland investment concern.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 10 -- William A. Purtell of West Hartford, former president of the Connecticut Manufacturers Association, announced today that he was a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator.

A horizontal 8-letter word in the crosword puzzle in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday caused quite a stir in the Marine Corps Public Information Office at 346 Broadway where three telephones were tied up most of the day handling several hundred calls.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Seven thousand workers staged a plant-wide walkout at the giant Armour Co. meat plant today, capping a series of "hit and run" strikes in the industry.

Underwriters headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will offer to investors today 51,550 shares of new $100 par value 4.9 per cent cumulative dividend convertible preferred stock of Florida Power Corporation at $100 a share.

The Home Loan Bank Board, which administers Federally-chartered savings and loan associations, has "continued to ignore the laws of New York State" on branch office powers, William A. Lyon, Superintendent of Banks, asserts in his annual report to the Governor and the Legislature.

Prejudicial trial errors were attributed to Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman yesterday by Emanuel H. Bloch, defense attorney for atom bomb spies Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, when he argued their appeal from a joint conviction and death sentence last spring.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Britain's most distinguished newspaper, The Times of London, was ordered today to stand trial in the Old Bailey on a charge of aiding and abetting in corrupt practices during the British general election last October, an accusation that is vigorously contested by the newspaper.
BOSTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Testimony that a manufacturer settled a $135,000 tax claim for $75,000 was offered today in the trial of Denis W. Delaney, ousted Internal Revenue Collector.

A program calling for issuance of 256,007 additional shares of common stock and a new series of $15,000,000 in first mortgage bonds has been announced by K. C. Long, president of the Dayton Power and Light Company.

DETROIT, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Gordie Howe, Detroit's high-scoring right-winger, blasted home two goals little more than a minute apart in the second period tonight to lead the Red Wings to a 5-to-2 victory over the New York Rangers before 10,299 fans at Olympia Stadium.

Many tickets have been sold for the performance of Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra," with Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh in the leading roles, on Monday night at the Ziegfeld Theatre for the benefit of the Children's Village. Mrs. Edwin S. Webster Jr. heads the women

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 10 -- Undefeated Seton Hall University rolled to a 60-44 triumph over Creighton University of Omaha, Neb., tonight at the Seton Hall gymnasium. It was the twelfth straight victory for the Pirates, last major undefeated college basketball team in the metropolitan area.

In his State of the Union message President Truman promised "to see to it that the honest and hard-working great majority of our federal employes are protected against partisan slander and malicious attack." If the President wishes to expand this observation he could do no better than turn for details to Robert Ramspeck, the able chairman of the United States Civil Service Commission.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 11 -- United Nations delegates at Panmunjom charged yesterday that the Communists were seeking an exchange of prisoners of the Korean war only on such a basis as would serve to increase their military strength in case of a resumption of hostilities after an armistice.
The liquor wholesaler is threatened with extinction, representatives of all levels of the liquor trade were warned last night.

Is it too much to believe that the "Atlantic Community" is at last shaping up as a functioning, coherent organization? Are we going beyond the military concepts of Nato to the broader field of a confederation of free Western nations? The communique given out after the Truman-Churchill talks poses these questions and gives some reasons for hope that the answers are affirmative.
FALMOUTH, England, Jan. 10 -- The following is a log of the Flying Enterprise's final hours, recorded as radio and radio-telephone messages crackled between the escort convoy and shore stations:
CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Bob Feller got a pay increase today and wondered if earning about $55,000 from the Indians in 1952 might not be easier with Joe DiMaggio and Ted Williams gone.
J. Arthur Warner Co., Inc., securities dealer, has announced that Thomas Kehlenbach and Theodore J. Moynahan have been elected president and vice president, respectively.

At 11:10 A. M. yesterday here, when the Flying Enterprise off the coast of England quit her two-week fight against the sea, a family of four survivors wandered almost hopelessly in a two-room suite on the fifth floor of the Towers Hotel in Brooklyn.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- In recognition of his accomplishment in nuclear physics, Dr. Enrico Fermi, whose research led to the discovery of uranium fission and who designed the first atomic pile, received an honorary Doctor of Science degree tonight from the University of Rochester.

OTTAWA, Jan. 10 -- In the welcome to be extended tomorrow to Prime Minister Churchill by the Canadian Government and people there will be additional warmth because of the work he has done with President Truman in getting Anglo-American relations back to a solid basis.

William Boyd, a New Haven Railroad Conductor identified by his smile and the fresh flower in his lapel, will receive early next week a token of affection from Connecticut commuters on train No. 373, whose tickets he has taken for the last nine years.

President Truman described his plan for reorganizing the Bureau of Internal Revenue, announced a week ago, as one of a "series of actions" he was "taking to insure honesty, integrity and fairness in the conduct of all Government business." On Dec. 13 he had spoken of "continued drastic action" and had led the public to believe he intended to set up a commission to clean house.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, dashed cold water today on a Republican effort to speed a Senate vote on this country's joining Canada in the construction of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Not a street car, trackless trolley or bus moved in Baltimore today as a transit strike hit the nation's sixth largest city.

The stock market took an unexpected turn for the better yesterday. Despite the bearish attitude prevalent recently in Wall Street, prices scored the best advance of the new year accompanied by a moderate increase in business. Corporate news items provided the main prop for the sharp reversal of form, with "outside" developments of no consequence as a basis for action by traders.

DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 10 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, warned today that a further decrease in employment would eventually follow the Federal Government's continued "discriminatory" restriction of automotive production and would affect the "general economic health" of the country.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 10 -- Substantial United States aid to India over at least the next four years, possibly on a half loan, half grant basis, will be urged upon Congressional leaders by Chester Bowles, United States Ambassador, upon his return to Washington next week for a quick round of conferences.

Emerging like a kaleidoscope of spring, Laddie Northridge's collection, viewed yesterday at his West Fifty-seventh Street salon, was woven of many silhouettes and themes. Never satisfied with just one silhouette in any category, he turned forth first one and then another, giving each exquisite detail.

An event of incalculable significance to many in our land occurred the other day, although it was merely the publication of a photograph in local sports pages. The picture concerned the opening of a school in Florida -- a baseball school conducted by Prof. Edward Lopat of the New York Yankees.
The end of the cargo liner Flying Enterprise, after a fifteen-day fight against the North Atlantic, was announced officially yesterday by her owner, Hans J. Isbrandtsen.

A shoal of unusual snails possibly of a species alien to this country, has invaded the lake in Central-Park. Yesterday afternoon cast-off snail shells by the hundreds were visible around the edges of the frozen lake, which is now at its winter low, about four feet below the summertime high, or boating, level.

Eastern skiers this week-end will continue to enjoy one of the finest winters in recent years as reports from the major areas indicated prospects for good to excellent sport. Snow was visiting a number of the areas yesterday. The Weather Bureau, however, doesn't look for much new cover.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 10 -- Dr. Willem Drees, the Socialist who rose from a shorthand reporter to Premier, will leave the Netherlands by air tomorrow on a thirteen-day voyage of discovery to the United States.

Henri Bonnet, French Ambassador to the United States, criticized yesterday charges for some quarters that France was not playing her full part in opposing Communist aggression and declared that "we are doing all we can to build up the defenses of the Western world."

CINCINNATI, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Lloyd Jordan of Harvard University, president of the American College Football Coaches Association, took issue with the college presidents' special sports committee tonight and outlined a three-point program for eliminating abuses in athletics.

Two brothers and the wife of the younger one, who were admited to the United States two years ago as displaced persons from Czechoslovakia, were accused yesterday of trying to smuggle $100,000 of this country's controlled gold abroad.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 10 -- A $30,000,000 citrus deal by which the Florida Citrus Exchange would have acquired the citrus processing facilities of Clinton Foods, Inc., fell through today.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- The program that will be submitted to the Council of the North Atlantic Treaty powers at its meeting in Lisbon in February calls for increasing the defense budgets of the Western European members of the pact by $3,100,000,000 in the period ending July 1, 1954.

Henrik Kurt Carlsen, captain of the Flying Enterprise, who remained on his ship from Dec. 28 until yesterday, forty minutes before she sank, and Kenneth R. Dancy, who volunteered to go aboard the doomed vessel, might find it hard to explain why they so risked their lives.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 10 -- Billy Rose, while on a recent visit here, worked out a movie deal with his brother-in-law, Alex Gottlieb, independent film producer. Their plan is to make a four-episode picture this summer to be called "Billy Rose's Broadway Tales."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Defense mobilizers raised their sights on sulphur production by 1,250,000 tons today to prevent a worsening shortage in the years ahead.

TRENTON, Jan. 10 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll disclosed today that conditions resulting from the war in Korea had led the state to abandon immediate plans to make Sandy Hook a second Jones Beach. New Jersey recreational authorities have tried for several years to obtain from the Army control of the sandy peninsula extending into lower New York Bay.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd Jr., new Marine Corps Commandant, declared today that he was hopeful the Army and Air Force would come around to the Marines' technique of providing air support for ground troops.

Today's events: Philharmonic- Symphony, Franco Autori, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; Maro and Anahid Ajemian, piano and violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Margaret Pardee, violin, Town Hall, 8:30; Chamber Music program, Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:30.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Top Australian tennis officials strongly defended Frank Sedgman's "bride fund" today when they learned the gift had been criticized by United States tennis leaders.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Speedy legislative approval of compulsory automobile inspection, legalization of pre-colored oleomargarine and other specific recommendations made by Governor Dewey in his annual message appeared in sight today.

Franco Antori found himself unexpectedly on the Philharmonic- Symphony podium last night, as a replacement for an indisposed Guido Cantelli. Mr. Autori, who is the assistant conductor of the orchestra, somewhat revised the original program, retaining only the "Emperor" Concerto.
PARIS, Jan. 10 -- After working all day to bring the French political groups, together, Georges Bidault, Minister of Defense in the fallen Cabinet, abandoned tonight his attempt to form a Cabinet.

Robert A. Vogeler, American business executive who was imprisoned for seventeen months by the Communist Government in Hungary, told a luncheon audience yesterday in the Towers Hotel, 25 Clark Street, Brooklyn, that the Bible gave him "comfort, inspiration and hope" while he was being held.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 10 -- The televising of college football games in 1952 on approximately the same controlled program as in 1951 was recommended today by the television committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

Dark since Feb. 23, the extensively renovated Playhouse finally will be relighted on March 20. What will force the house to emerge from its somnolence is "Bernardine," a comedy about adolescent romance, written by Mary Chase, whose "Harvey" titillated theatregoers for more than four years.

TRENTON, Jan. 10 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll had little sympathy today for tavern operators on New Jersey highways who complained that business had been poor since motorists began riding over the New Jersey Turnpike.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- No sleight-of-hand artist, even those in full-dress suits who used to be introduced to open-mouthed audiences in the old opry house as prestidigitators, ever made an "object" appear and disappear more bewilderingly than the President did with his political plans for 1952 at his press conference today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Jan. 5 totaled 612,780 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

ALBANY, Jan 10 -- During the first ten months of 1951 motor vehicle accidents cost 1,694 lives in the state, an increase of 5.7 per cent over the same period of 1950, James R. MacDuff, the state Motor Vehicle Commissioner, reported today.

A modern tale of two cities -- Haifa and New York -- that began before World War I had a happy ending here yesterday as a plane from Israel winged its way into the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

Were I to give my general reasons for naming General Eisenhower as my candidate for the Presidency of the United States I would say that he is the best physician for a sick world. He can heal the individual mind of its smallnesses and meannesses because, although, of course, he has shortcomings of his own, he is on a higher mental and spiritual plane than any other candidate.

Jerry Coleman, utility infielder of the Yankees, has been recalled to service by the United States Marines. Coleman notified General Manager George Weiss yesterday coincident with an announcement of his recall by the Marine Corps in San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Truman declared today that he always had hoped and thought General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was a Democrat, that he had just found out he was a Republican, and he did not think the country would be good under any Republican President.
General Eisenhower, I believe, is by far the best of the possible Republican candidates for President. So far as foreign affairs are concerned I would trust him implicitly.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 10 -- A tuition increase of $150 a year was approved today by Princeton University board of trustees to meet rising educational costs, it was announced by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The National Grange, historic advocate of legislation to regulate the railroads, has come to the aid of the roads in their fight to obtain a reexamination of the nation's transportation policy.

Block Drug Company yesterday announced expansion of its advertising program for Amm-I-Dent for 1952, calling it the largest in the product's history. Chief additions to the schedule will be in radio and television though a heavy share of the appropriation will get to Sunday newspaper supplements, with local newspaper copy to be scheduled later in the year. Cecil Presbrey, Inc., is the agency.

The South, with its belles and its beaux, its beauty and its romance, was beckoned North to a crowded showroom yesterday morning. The brilliance of red calicos and the coquetry of little sunshades dispelled the gloom outside. The occasion was the unveiling of Mr. John's spring and summer millinery collection.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- As the British Commonwealth finance officials were making preparations this week for a ministerial conference to strengthen and defend the status of sterling in world trade, concern was being expressed here about the future of the sterling area.
Furniture volume for 1951 as a whole exceeded the record set in 1950, Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants for the industry reported yesterday in a summary of the industry's year.
There is a great deal of pressure being exerted to force General Eisenhower to enter the Presidential race in 1952.
Seventy-one persons contributed $1,134 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, bringing the total of the 1951-52 appeal to $320,878.97.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 10 (UP) -- Irish-bred Ollerton Hills, making his first start in this country, stumbled today during the running of the sixth race at Santa Anita, throwing Jockey Jack Westrope. The veteran rider was not hurt but the horse broke his right foreleg and had to be destroyed.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 10 --An expansion of trade between The Soviet Union and India is quite possible, M. V. Nesterov, chairmon of the Chamber of Commerce of the Soviet Union, said at a press conference here today.

Control over decisions leading to peace or war must be restored to the American people if this nation is to escape crushing burdens of an armed peace or disasters of a third world war, it was declared last night by Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer (U. S. A., ret.).

FALMOUTH, England, Jan. 10 -- After struggling twelve days against the fury of Atlantic winds and waves, Henrik Kurt Carlsen, captain of the American freighter Flying Enterprise, finally left the ship today shortly before she sank in the English Channel.

Fairfax County, Va., sold yesterday $3,500,000 of school bonds due Dec. 1, 1952 to 1970, to a banking syndicate headed by National City Bank here, at a bid of 100,2027 for interest of 2 3/8 per cent. Reoffering was at yields ranging from 1.20 per cent to 2.40 per cent.

Earning assets of the reporting New York member banks of the Federal Reserve System were cut $504,000,000 last week, the largest reduction to be registered in any week during recent years. Business loans, continuing their resumed downward trend for the second successive week, dropped $71,000,000, reflecting heavy repayments by finance companies.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois, speaking before Harvard Law School students today on "The Lawyer in Government and Politics," criticized some members of the Securities Exchange Commission and the Federal Communications Commission for participating in decisions in which they had personal interest.

Under a new program announced yesterday by the John Hay Whitney Foundation, five small independent colleges that can not ordinarily afford unusual teaching talent will have the services for at least a year of outstanding professors who have reached retirement age at other institutions.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11 -- Richard Conte has signed with Universal-International to play the lead in "The Riding Kid," which is slated to go before the cameras in March.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, High Commissioner and commander of the French forces in Indo-China, died today in a clinic near Paris after a month's illness. He would have been 62 on Feb. 2.
Payrolls totaling $4,331 were seized yesterday from women bookkeepers in two holdups occurring within five minutes of each other in Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Truman has offered the Ambassadorship to France to Ellsworth Bunker, now Ambassador to Argentina.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A father mourning the death of two sons on Korean battlefields has refused to accept the Medal of Honor awarded one and a Silver Star conferred on the other, on the ground that President Truman was "unworthy to confer them on my boys or any other boys."
BOSTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Veteran relief hurler Ellis Kinder and first baseman Walt Dropo today signed their 1952 contracts with the Boston Red Sox.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today exempted the Atlantic Coast Line from seeking competitive bids on $22,388,000 of General Mortgage Bonds, Series B.
Earlier this week food editors stole a march on delegates to the United Nations by being the first to dine in their new private dining room at the world headquarters here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -President Truman told civil defense officials today that he would make another attempt this year to get "adequate" funds from Congress for their national program.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 11 -- By the overwhelming vote of 163 to 8, the National Collegiate Athletic Association today committed itself to a program of controlled telecasts of college football games in 1952 such as was carried out during the past season.

The ten-man executive board of the Uniformed Firemen's Association of Greater New York was faced yesterday with the problem of calling a meeting of its 8,500 members to discuss the question of a general strike among city firemen.

Crew members of the General A. W. Greely, a troopship that shared in rescue operations alongside the stricken freighter Flying Enterprise, will make a mass blood donation this morning at the Brooklyn Red Cross Blood Donor Center, 57 Willoughby Street.

PICKET MEADOWS, Calif., Jan. 11 -- Here at an altitude of 7,000 feet in the Sierra Nevada, in temperatures down to 40 below zero, all Marines headed for Korea are getting a brief but rugged dose of what the corps calls "free life insurance" against the rigors of climate and combat they will meet overseas.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 11 (UP) -Husky Bernie Crimmins, assistant football coach and former star at Notre Dame, was named head coach at the University of Indiana today to succeed Clyde Smith, who stepped down under alumni pressure.

Your editorial of Jan. 5 on "The U. S. A. and India" was like a breath of fresh air in these days of vituperation and recriminations. I believe that the majority of people in this country deeply regret the pressure which so many of their Congressmen and politicians bring to bear in order to use our aid programs for political purposes.

The Economic Cooperation Administration has awarded a "Certificate of Cooperation" to the Building Trades Employers Association and the Gregory-Roth-Schenker Corporation, builder of homes, for furnishing technical assistance and sharing their technical knowledge with European industry.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Acting Mayor Arthur Price conferred with union officials late today and reported some progress in his effort to settle a city-wide transit strike.

In support of Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh's new policy of levying a mandatory $15 fine for double parking, the police are waging an intensive campaign to eliminate this traffic evil. In the first week the stiff penalty prevailed, policemen tagged 1,732 violators, an increase of 62 per cent over the average for 1951.

Highly inflammable sweaters, which burn up quickly with an intense heat, are being sold in the metropolitan area by peddlers, city and state police warned last night. The garments were fashioned from a synthetic material brushed so that it resembles expensive camel's hair or cashmere.

NEWARK, Jan. 11 -- A two-day jubilee Sabbath celebrating Rabbi Emeritus Solomon Foster's fiftieth year of ministry opened tonight with more than 2,000 persons present at the Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, where he has served for forty years.

A ring of nine correction officers and civilian employes at the city penitentiary on Rikers Island that allegedly had smuggled narcotics to inmates for "about a year" was broken up yesterday in what was described as "one of the largest narcotics round-ups inside a prison."

During a period traditionally marked by prosperity and activity, the Broadway theatre will be experiencing its largest number of defections. The announcement made yesterday by the Theatre Guild that it is retiring its presentation of "Lo and Behold" after tonight's performance increases the number of closings for the week-end from four to five.

Your correspondent in Vienna tried to present a picture of the Czech managed economy in the second year of the current Five-Year Plan. His remarks as regards the accomplishment of the plan in the third quarter of last year are almost correct, but the data published in THE TIMES on Jan. 3 are not.

ROME, Jan. 11 -- A split between anti-Communist workers represented by the Italian Confederation of Free Labor Unions and the dominant Christian Democratic party was foreshadowed today when the confederation protested strongly against an intention attributed to the party of founding its own labor unions in competition with both the Communist and free unions.

Five Roman Catholic Bishops will participate in an annual eight-day period of prayer for the reunion of Christians, to be held at Blessed Sacrament Church, 132 West Seventy-first Street. The meetings start Jan. 18 and will be held at 8 P. M. daily.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- The Leo Burnett Company, Inc., has announced that on the basis of its 1951 operations it will divide about $260,000 among the 201 persons in the agency's headquarters in Chicago and branches in New York and Los Angeles who were at the year-end eligible to membership in the Burnett Profit Sharing Trust set up in 1943.

Volume of retail trade here this week ran close to 25 per cent below abnormal sales levels of the comparable week of 1951, trade observers estimated yesterday. In the corresponding week last year, department store sales were 30 per cent ahead of volume in the like 1950 week, when the second Korean-war "scare-buying" rush neared its peak.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -The Government today asked Federal courts to prohibit eight meat packing concerns from continuing to buy live cattle at prices above legal ceilings.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 12 -Yesterday, for the first time in the Korean war, enemy MIG-15 jet planes jumped United Nations jets within easy flying distance of the front lines. Four of the Soviet-built fighters attacked three F-84 Thunderjets only twenty miles north of the battlefront.
Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, warned yesterday that the United States and the British Commonwealth must remain united "at all costs" or risk disaster.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Samuel Cherr, vice president of Young Rubicam, Inc., one of the country's largest advertising agencies, accused furniture stores today of doing "the worst advertising of any industry in the United States." He termed retail furniture advertising "blatant" and "untrue."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy called on the Administration today to submit "quickly" a proposal for expanding weapons production at a rate regarded as certain to be heavy and perhaps enormous.

ANTIOCH, Calif., Jan 11 (AP) -Fined $10 each in Antioch's "battle of the pin curls," Mr. and Mrs. Amos Barton confused the court today by leaving five of their nine children in the care of Yates Hamm, Justice of the Peace. Mrs. Barton, after reading a long statement, explained:

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Legislation designed to offset the impact of inflation on the pensions of employes of 600 higher education and research institutions has been introduced in the Legislature by Senator Walter J. Mahoney, Republican of Buffalo and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.

One of the first acts of the new Congress will be to start committee consideration of the Universal Military Training Bill. This measure, carrying out the proposals of the President's National Security Training Commission, provides for six months' service under carefully prescribed conditions for all young men 18 years old who meet minimum physical and mental qualifications, after which they would enter the Reserves.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- A final route for the Westchester County segment of the $450,000,000 New York Thruway was outlined here today by state engineers at a conference in the County Office Building. Embracing four major changes from earlier plans, the route was lauded by county, Yonkers and Greenburgh officials.

Winston Churchill's volumes on the Second World War are best sellers, but now that he is Britain's Prime Minister for the second time his thoughts must have turned back to some passages in his little-known autobiographical work, "A Roving Commission," published in 1930.

The stock market operated yesterday on a higher level but with considerable selectivity. Gains in the oil issues were dominant, some ranging well beyond 5 points, but the lack of strength in such stocks as the steels and motors and the inability of the rails generally to adhere to the leadership gave the market a ragged appearance.

The French Line in New York announced yesterday that Capt. Albert Zanger, veteran shipmaster and for the last five years port captain of the company in New York Harbor, had been named director of operations in Paris and that he would leave for his new post later this month.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday that he soon would submit to the Board of Estimate a proposal to impose a separate county tax on real estate to raise funds for county purposes. The new tax would be in addition to the present city tax on real estate, now levied to finance general city activities in the expense budget.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 11 -- Reports in the Opposition press of extensive disorders accompanying the elections in certain northern areas of Iran seem exaggerated, but the consensus appears to be that they will probably be somewhat more serious than those that usually accompany Iranian elections.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- The United Nations General Assembly flatly rejected tonight Soviet demands that the United States be found guilty of aggressive intervention into the affairs of the Cominform states. The vote, which came after a Soviet warning from the rostrum that interference in the business of other countries could lead to war, was 42 to 5.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 11 -- The body of First Lieut. Lee R. Hartell, who won the Medal of Honor on a smoky ridge at Kobangsan-Ni, Korea, came home today to be buried, bringing an hour of grief and glory to his young widow, Margaret.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Commanders of twenty-five divisional organizations of the Army's Organized Reserve Corps were notified today that several thousand officers would be drawn from their ranks in the coming months to meet officer requirements of the expanded Army.
Following is the text of the speech delivered yesterday by Anthony Eden, at a special convocation at Columbia University, where he received an honorary degree:

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan said at the promotion of twenty-nine members of the force yesterday that the department was now rid of the "venal few" who had brought discredit on it and that public confidence had been restored.

The first national survey of aluminum distribution through warehouses has been completed and a five-year program of activities has been recommended for approval by the distributing establishments in the field, it was revealed here yesterday by Raymond L. Collier, secretary of the National Association of Aluminum Distributors.

An almost incredible story of narcotics use by sub-teen agers came to light yesterday with the disclosure by Capt. Peter Terranova, head of the Police Narcotics Squad, that an 8-year-old chronic smoker of marijuana was in Bellevue Hospital's psychiatric ward.

GENEVA, Jan. 11 -- The coordination of European transport systems on an international level is making such good progress that the creation of a Schuman plan type of high authority at present would serve no useful purpose, European transport leaders said here today.
FALMOUTH, England, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Following is the transcript of Captain Henrik Kurt Carlsen's news conference today:

Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, Maritime Administrator, said yesterday that 49,660 tons of the industry's steel allotment would go to seven shipyards engaged in building the Government's new Mariner class freighters and that another 67,340 tons had been earmarked for twenty-six tankers on order for private operators.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 11 -- The British Embassy and the Iranian Foreign Ministry played a game of diplomatic ping-pong, today, as the former issued a note refusing to take cognizance of Iran's note of Wednesday in which British officials were accused of open interference in Iranian affairs. The match ended 3 to 2 for the British Embassy.
MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- The seventeenth annual Douglas Medal bonspiel reached the quarter-finals at the indoor curling rink of St. Andrew's Golf Club today.
SEATTLE, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Coast Guard planes and a search vessel tonight reported finding wreckage and debris near the last known position of the missing freighter Pennsylvania.

Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, who rose to heroic heights in his doomed efforts to save his ship, will receive the traditional ticker-tape welcome when he arrives here. The only difficulty is that nobody seems to know when the master of the foundered freighter Flying Enterprise will return.

Establishment of a joint legislative committee to investigate the extent of mental retardation in New York State and recommend ways of easing the problems that condition creates was urged yesterday by Assemblyman Samuel Roman of the Fifteenth Assembly District, Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Top priority was given by the Senate's permanent investigating subcommittee today to further inquiry into large quick profits made by investors in surplus World War II tankers and other vessels.
