GRINDEWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Competing against a brilliant international field, members of America's Olympic team captured second and fifth places today in the slalom event of the Swiss women's national ski championships.

BOSTON, Jan. 11 -- New Bedford and Fall River cotton and rayon manufacturers announced today that they would reopen March 15 existing contracts with the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., in an attempt to improve the industry's competitive position.

BOSTON, Jan. 11 -- By a margin of 293 to 246, members of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., voted today to break a Congress of Industrial Organizations picket line and terminate a tie-up that has cut drastically into Boston shipping.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Conditions at New York State ski centers as reported today to the State Department of Commerce follow:

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 11 -Evidence that the Curtiss C-46 airliner that crashed here last Dec. 16 had a faulty right engine prior to take-off was brought out today at the second session of a Civil Aeronautics Board investigation into the accident. Fifty-six persons, including a crew of four, were killed in the crash.

Repeal of the United States silver purchase laws "is confidently expected" in the near future, Rear Admiral Donald J. Ramsey, United States Navy, retired, told the advisory committee of the Silver Users Association in an address last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 11 -- Captain Chuck Devoe's set shot with five seconds left gave Princeton a 50 -- 48 basketball victory over Dartmouth before 1800 spectators in alumni gymnasium tonight. It was the Eastern League opener for both teams.

OTTAWA, Jan. 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill arrived here by train at noon today for a four-day visit during which he will prepare the two speeches that he will make next week, one to a Canadian audience and the other to the United States Congress.
A 29-year-old automibile mechanic, said to be a courier for a ring smuggling gold out of the country, was arrested yesterday by Secret Service agents.

4>DALLAS, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Internal Revenue Bureau officials revealed today that every "important" income tax official in Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi was being investigated and confirmed that an employe of the Austin branch office had been suspended.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense (P. A. D.) said today it has been advised by some fuel oil suppliers that present price ceilings may make it economically impossible to keep New England supplied with heating oil.

The estate of Barnet Glekel has sold the four-story twenty-family apartment house at 1773 Park Place, Brooklyn, to the 125 Herzel Street Realty Corporation, represented by Segal Gilbert, attorneys. Eugene Shrifrin was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

BOSTON, Jan. 11 -- While Denis W. Delaney was Collector of Internal Revenue for Massachusetts he intervened in several tax cases and overruled subordinates, according to testimony today in Federal District Court, where he is being tried on charges of receiving bribes and filing false certificates in connection with tax lien discharges.
The dynamite-laden right fist of Ernie (The Rock) Durando turned impending defeat into spectacular victory last night at Madison Square Garden and narrowly missed touching off a riot.

The Long Island Rail Road might have to seek another fare increase, because of an increase of 4 cents an hour in wages paid to 6,623 employes based on a rise in the Labor Department's consumers' price index, William Wyer, trustee of the railroad, announced yesterday.
Nurses in city hospitals should be paid as much and work the same hours as those in other hospitals, Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday.

Less than thirty hours after the cargo liner Flying Enterprise plunged into the waters off the western end of the English Channel, her American insurers paid $800,000 to representatives of the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., owners of the vessel.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 11 -- The first official step of the campaign to make General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower the Republican nominee for President was taken today with the filing of papers by nine candidates for delegates to the national convention, who listed themselves as "favorable" to him. This move does not require the general's consent.

With elections coming to the fore in 1952 it would be worth while for the taxpayer and voter to take a careful look at their Congressmen. We over here in Europe have had an excellent opportunity to observe at close range a group of said gentlemen.

Death penalties for two convicted atomic bomb spies and a thirtyyear sentence for a third are not excessive in view of their transmission of the atom bomb secret to Soviet Russia, Federal attorneys argued yesterday before the United States Court of Appeals in Foley Square.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A strong possibility that the nation would be faced with simultaneous strike threats in steel and coal arose tonight.

THE management of the New York State Forest Preserve, a matter which has been referred to on many occasions as a "hot potato," has now been firmly grabbed by Conservation Commissioner Perry B. Duryea, and regardless of how long or in what manner he holds it there is an excellent chance that he will end up with burned fingers.

Bruce Bromley, chairman of the Election Reform Committee, announced yesterday that former Representative Ellsworth Buck had become a member of the committee. Mr. Buck succeeded Edward A. Ruppell as Richmond County Republican chairman when the latter resigned after witnesses before the State Crime Commission had testified that they had made payments to him to obtain retail liquor licenses.

In the first five months of New York City's fiscal year which began July 1, 1951, the transit system failed by $9,462,975 to pay its operating costs. In the same period debt service, not covered by transit revenues, was about $30,000,000. So the total five-month outlay to be paid out of the taxpayer's pocket is more than $39,000,000, or a daily deficit of more than a quarter of a million dollars.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath said at the White House today that he had not received any precise instructions from President Truman as to how to proceed on cleaning up corruption in government.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 11 -- A coma that lasted almost nine years ended today when Robert C. Steger of Lexington, Ky., died at Bethesda Hospital at the age of 63. Local medical authorities said they knew of no case in which a coma had lasted so long.

The placement of the television program, "The Goldbergs," on the unfair list as long as Philip Loeb is barred from the show was recommended yesterday to the governing body of Actors Equity Association, the council, by members of the actors' union.

Established cosmetic manufacturers take more than reasonable care in pretesting new products, according to the testimony yesterday at the hearings of a House committee investigating use of chemicals in foods and cosmetics.

Four officers of the ill-fated Flying Enterprise testified yesterday that they had heard no noise that would indicate the cargo shifted when the vessel took her fatal list on Dec. 28 in hurricane winds of more than seventy-five miles an hour.

An increase of nearly 100 per cent in the budget of the city's Department of Traffic, raising its appropriation from the current $1,166,194 to $2,230,696 in 1952-53, was submitted yesterday to Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- Pakistan proposed today that the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission be enlarged from four to seven members and be clearly given the task of implementing the General Assembly resolutions of 1948 and 1950.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Montgomery Advertiser, one of the South's oldest newspapers, and traditionally Democratic, endorsed General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for President last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- The board of directors of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company today declared a stock dividend of 25 per cent, subject to the approval of the Controller of the Currency and by shareholders at a special meeting scheduled Feb. 15.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 11 -John N. Gennerich, one of the owners of the Universal Funeral Chapel at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-second Street, was found hanged from a tree last midnight behind his home at 29 Northway, Eastchester. He was 53 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -The Defense Department identified today 136 additional casualties of the Korean war, including 19 dead, 101 wounded and 16 injured. The following are from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut).

A vote will be taken on Monday by the 3,800 employes of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System on whether to accept proposed layoffs of 120 bus operators or to strike, it was announced last night at a mass meeting of about 1,500 members of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., in Transport Hall, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street.

VALENCIA, Spain, Jan. 11 -Vice Admiral Matthias B. Gardner, commander of the United States Sixth Fleet, said today that the use of Spanish naval bases would "undoubtedly" facilitate the strategic and operational tasks of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in the Mediterranean.

Thirty-five donors -- including, as a unit, the pupils of a religious school -- contributed $503.50 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. Their gifts, ranging from $100 to $1, raised the total for the 1951-52 appeal to date to $321,382.47.

Like tourists in a strange country New Yorkers gazed with wonder and delight at scenes from Father Knickerbocker's town, presented yesterday at the Museum of the City of New York to mark its twentieth anniversary in the building at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 11 -The belief that recent increased deliveries would allay French concern over the tardy arrival of certain items of equipment under the United States military aid program for Indo-China was voiced today by Brig. Gen. Francis Brink, chief of the United States military aid mission here.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- With the Soviet bloc fighting to the last, the United Nations General Assembly established today a twelve-nation disarmament commission and instructed it to start work by Feb. 10 on the "regulation, limitation and balanced reduction of all armed forces and all armaments."

Greenish snails, the size of golf balls, found Thursday around the edges of the lake in Central Park, were definitely identified yesterday as specimens of a native American species by the American Museum of Natural History.

"Cage of Gold," a British-made Ealing Studio production starring Jean Simmons, is scheduled to have its American premiere on Friday, Jan. 18, at the Seventy-second Street Trans-Lux, it was announced yesterday. Ellis Films is distributing the offering, which was produced by Sir Michael Balcon and directed by Basil Dearden.

In New York commodity futures trading yesterday coffee showed the best gains, advancing 37 to 60 points on volume of 69,000 bags. Two upward influences were reports of renewed Brazilian buying and the report that the Colombian Coffee Federation had advanced its prices the equivalent of 3/4 to 1 cent a pound.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Truman came strongly to the defense of small business today as a vital part of the mobilization program.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- The Soviet Press wrote off the Truman-Churchill talks today as a "failure" and said it was evident that the two leaders had not reached agreement on any of the basic issues on which United States and British policies were opposed.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -Cy Foster of Toledo, Ohio, battled strong, chilly winds today to shoot a two-under-par 35, 35 -- 70 and take a two-stroke lead in the National Senior P. G. A. golf tourney.

A new syndicate of investors has purchased the twenty-five-story office building on plot 62 by 63 by 79 feet at 99 to 101 Wall Street from Amsinck, Sonne Co. in a deal negotiated by the Murrimac Realty Company, broker. The building contains about 72,000 square feet of rentable space and was erected in 1931.

Deposits held by the mutual savings banks in this state rose $529,100,000 last year to a record high of $12,174,619,000, according to the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York. Earl B. Schwulst, the association's president, pointed out that despite higher taxes and living costs the increase approximates the 1950 gain of $558,363,000.

Six exhibitions in this crowded art week deserve special mention. Two of them are devoted to contemporary sculpture -- work by three artists at the Sculpture Center and figure studies by Nancy Proskauer Dryfoos at the Contemporary Arts Gallery.

One of the most important changes in the Florida citrus field's history was announced yesterday. Richard M. Moss, chairman of the board of Clinton Foods, Inc., announced breaking off of negotiations for sale of that company's plants to the Florida Citrus Exchange and conclusion of agreements with other and independent packers and growers that would almost double production capacity for Snow Crop frozen orange concentrate.

FALMOUTH, England, Jan. 11 -- Captain Henrik Kurt Carlsen of the Flying Enterprise, who lost his ship yesterday after a two-week struggle to save her from the raging Atlantic, declared today that he would keep going to sea.
JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 11 (UP) -- Money fell on the lawns of a residential block today and startled residents reaped $1,040 in a short-lived bonanza.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The fall in prices gathered pace on the stock markets here today, especially in the industrial section, which finished with widespread losses ranging up to 2 shillings (28 cents). The only groups to offer any resistance were British Government securities and insurance, tin and copper shares.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -Lieut. Gen. George E. Stratemeyer, former commander of the Far East Air Forces, will retire Jan. 31 for health reasons after thirty-six years of military service.

Fred Wilt and Don Gehrmann, whose mile rivalry will be resumed with the start of banked-track racing in Philadelphia and Boston next week, head the casts of meets here and in Washington that will provide the track and field set with a final flat-floor tune-up tonight.

Your Tel Aviv correspondent recently reported that some 150 Indian immigrants staged a demonstration outside the Jewish Agency offices. These demonstrators declared that there is a color bar in Israel, as a result of which they were subject to unfair discrimination as compared with the immigrants from Europe.

A dream of a "castle with a deep moat surrounding it and a dozen knights all in shining armor" was the vivid impression gained by one schoolboy on his visit to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Miss Louise Condit, supervisor of the Junior Museum, reported yesterday.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 11--The Army's largest American airlift was declared "highly satisfactory" today by Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, First Army commander, on an inspection here of cold-weather exercises. After a talk with Maj. Gen. Robert W. Douglass Jr., directing the operation, General Crittenberger said: "It is proceeding like clock work."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company and its wholesale customers have reached a "generally satisfactory agreement" on rates intended to increase the company's revenue by $11,400,000 annually.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the organization certificate of the Royal Safe Deposit Company, 326 East 149th Street, Bronx, was filed for examination. Incorporators are Henry G. Barber, I. Wolrich, William Goldfine, Samuel Schneider and Max M. Lippman.

A 36-year-old longshoreman, described by Brooklyn rackets investigators as "important" to the borough's grand jury inquiry into gambling and corruption along the waterfront, was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Gamblers Court on a charge of possession of policy slips.

For a good many thousands winter ended last night at 7 o'clock and summer began. Another National Motor Boat Show -- the forty-second in the long chain -- had its launching in Grand Central Palace, forecasting what boat-minded Americans will be doing for vacation fun a few weeks from now.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Meeting in extraordinary secrecy in a guarded section of the Pentagon, military representatives of the United States, Britain and France, with members of the British Commonwealth as observers, discussed today a full agenda on measures and policies in Communist-threatened southeast Asia.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 11 -- After three sober debates, the West German Bundestag voted 232 to 143 today to ratify the Schuman plan for merging coal and steel industries of Western Europe. There were three abstentions.

Joe Lapchick's Knickerbockers will go after their eighth straight home victory tonight when they tangle with the Indianapolis Olympians in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks haven't been beaten at home since Nov. 29 when they lost to the Rochester Royals.
Plans for the early public offering of 500,000 shares of Class A common stock of the recently formed Amurex Oil Development Company were made known yesterday.

VIENNA, Jan. 11 -- Soviet authorities in Austria snatched today at a chance offered them by a decision of the Austrian Court of Administration restoring eighty-two castles, estates and ancient fortresses to Prince Ernst Ruediger von Stahremberg, exiled Austrian Fascist leader.

A condensed, low-priced version of the Columbia Encyclopedia is being prepared by Columbia University Press and will be financed, produced and distributed by Viking Press. The joint venture will be known as "The Columbia-Viking Desk Encyclopedia."

The eternal, unabated hunt for the beautiful and the rare in antiques by dealers and collectors is one that has been accelerated in recent years by great demand. The resultant shortages have placed a premium on ranking objects of the fashionable periods, a state of affairs that is met with equanimity by dealers and their eager clients.

Please accept my grateful appreciation for your editorial in THE TIMES of Dec. 30 on Air Rescue Service operations in Korea. Under the heading "The Wings of Mercy" your editorial does a valuable job in pointing out to your readers how tremendously helpful in saving the lives of desperately wounded United Nations personnel our rescue helicopter crews in Korea are.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- The general trend in grain prices was downward today. While there was more activity on the buying side at times, the rallies did not appear to be specially impressive until near closing time, when new-crop wheat deliveries moved up sharply.

The annual report of the Lukens Steel Company, issued yesterday by Charles Lukens Huston Jr., president, revealed net sales at a new high record of $80,546,418 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 27, last. Sales for the preceding year amounted to $52,935,861.

Bernard M. Shanley, national chairman of the Stassen-for-President movement, announced yesterday that Harold E. Stassen would make a state-wide fight in Ohio against Senator Robert A. Taft for all fifty-six delegates to the Republican National convention.

BOSTON, Jan. 11 -- The problem of checking inflation is complicated by the fact that "we all like some inflation for ourselves," Roger L. Putnam, Administrator of the Economic Stabilization Agency, said today.

The last technical obstacle to the sale of $21,000,000 of San Francisco-Oakland Bay bridge bonds of the California Toll Bridge Authority has been removed with decision of the San Francisco Bay Bridge Commuters not to appeal the San Francisco Superior Court's decision authorizing the sale.
MELBOURNE, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Police had to rope off Swanson Street today to accommodate the 10,000 fans who wanted to cheer the return home of Frank Sedgman, Davis Cup hero.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 11 (UP) -Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, telegraphed the Nebraska Secretary of State yesterday for the "latest compilation of Nebraska election laws" and touched off new speculation that he would enter the state Presidential primary election April 1.

KWANGJU, Korea, Jan. 10 -The Allied efforts to win over most South Koreans to the principles of the United Nations and to the concept of a democratic Korea are being intensified to combat any campaign the Communists may have drawn up to wage a fifth column war after a cease-fire ends the shooting war.

A request that smoke control be placed under a tri-state agency has been forwarded by Mayor Impellitteri to Governors Dewey of New York, Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey and John Davis Lodge of Connecticut, the Mayor said yesterday.

Frederic R. Gamble, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies surprised the members of the League of Advertising Agencies last night with an announcement that the Association was accepting applications for membership and providing service for new or small agencies that might not yet be able to meet the rigid qualifications for full membership.
Anahid and Maro Ajemian, the gifted sister team, usually can be depended upon to offer an interesting program.

A committee report urging that the Greater New York Fund abandon solicitation of privately-owned concerns and corporations and confine its fund-raising activities solely to publicly-owned corporations was placed before its participating agencies yesterday in a public meeting at the Roosevelt Hotel.

CAIRO, Jan. 11 -- Four hundred troops of the British Second Parachute Battalion swarmed across the Ismailia Canal in assault boats before dawn today and conducted a thorough search for arms in two Egyptian villages.

With reference to the article by Warren Moscow in your issue of Dec. 28, "U. S. Pays $35 Each for Stray Dogs for Use in Atomic Research Work," I would like to submit information recently compiled by the Animal Welfare Institute, a new organization engaged in the accumulation and dissemination of facts regarding animals used for research purposes.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were irregular yesterday and closed 4 points higher to 12 lower.
Winston Churchill's visit makes timely the suggestion that we have been negligent in the United States in not honoring this great man to the extent that we should.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- The Association of American Medical Colleges announced today that the largest freshman class in the recent history of medical education in this country was admitted for the 1951-52 academic year. The class totaled 7,381.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- In an unusual tribute to the British missionary who has been barred by the South African Government from South and Southwest Africa for his efforts on behalf of the tribes of that region, forty states voted in the United Nations today to express their "admiration and gratitude" to the Rev. Michael Scott.

Six persons were injured yesterday when an automobile went out of control on the Belt Parkway near 128th Street, South Ozone Park, Queens, and started a chain reaction involving four other cars. The collisions tied up traffic for almost an hour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- An official committee of power experts has notified the Government that its program of electric power expansion for defense is geographically off balance and "may be too small."

Queens County Judge Alfred J. Hofmann decided about noon yesterday to leave his chambers on the ground floor of the Queens County Courthouse in Long Island City and go to the washroom. He walked down the hall, into the lavatory and slammed the door.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- With the new gambling tax as its weapon, the Federal Government has opened a drive to put the country's bookmakers and numbers operators out of business and keep them out of business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged for the week ended Jan. 8, 1952, at 177.2 per cent of the 1926 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 12.9 per cent above the pre-Korean (May 24-June 25, 1950) average but was 1.1 per cent below the average for a year ago.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 11 -- Increased military preparedness was the main theme of King Gustaf Adolf's speech from the throne, as he opened this year's session of the Riksdag (Parliament) today.

Those lucky butterflies who sail off on Caribbean winter cruises rarely call at the Leeward Islands. They lack luxury hotels, casinos, tropical dancers and even souvenirs. The big ships cut southeast from the Virgins and leave the Leewards lying blue, gray-green and unvisited on the horizon.

The personnel officer for a concern constructing an air base in French Morocco under a cost-plus contract with the Government testified yesterday before the Senate Preparedness Investigating Subcommittee that it cost $718 to get a workman to the job site but that

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- The announcement today in Buffalo by Edwin F. Jaeckle, former State Republican Chairman, that he would not attend the national party convention at Chicago next July 7 was interpreted here as indicating his unwillingness to go along with Governor Dewey in behalf of the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Prime Minister Sydney G. Holland of New Zealand departed yesterday from the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, for London, where he will attend the British Commonwealth conference starting Monday.
Two baby-faced boys who may have seen too many cowboy films on television held up a Brooklyn pants dealer yesterday afternoon and escaped with $12.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 11 (UP) -- A forty-five-mile-an-hour gale, accompanied by drenching, cold rain, almost blew the Bing Crosby tourney golfers off the Cypress Point course today and as a result an early two-over-par 74 posted by Jimmy Demaret stood up for the first-day leadership in the $10,000 event.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP) -To Market equaled the Santa Anita Park track record of 1:09 for six furlongs today in the Bixby Park Purse. Eddie Arcaro was in the saddle as To Market tied the time of Mohammedan, established last February.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Sharp cutbacks in materials for practically all phases of civilian production, especially housing, were ordered today by the Government to take effect April 1.

The Long Island State Park Commission, whose ninety-seven miles of parkway already have a fatality rate only one-sixth the national highway average, has added two regulations to its traffic laws. The first doubles the speeding fine to $10 for first offenders. The second will strip wild drivers of their licenses.

A decisive step toward European unification was taken at Bonn yesterday when the German Parliament approved by a large majority a fiftyyear treaty embodying the Schuman Plan for a "European Coal and Steel Community." This treaty, which undertakes to pool the basic industries of six European nations comprising 155,000,000 people into a single economic unit under a virtual super-government, has already been approved by the French National Assembly and the Dutch Parliament.

The Government won out on important legal points yesterday in the trial of Frank Costello, the gambler, on an eleven-count indictment charging him with contempt last spring before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

American lead consumers have ordered enough foreign lead to reduce additional withdrawals of that metal from the national stockpile, large producers said here yesterday. In addition, the first brisk business in Australian lead since late 1950, has just been put through, importers said.
The following is a round-up of new products, including some mail-order items, which might be of use about the house:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -Howard L. Aller, president of the American Power and Light Company, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today it has no authority to rule on his plan to sell A. P. L.'s Washington Water Power Company to three public utility districts in the State of Washington.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- Although a report of experts of the Marshall Pian Council concluded that Western Europe could not meet its coal requirements from its own production by 1956, the council today called on member Governments to "take all measures open to them" to increase output and economize on coal consumption so as to "dispense with exceptional imports."

American lead consumers have ordered enough foreign lead to reduce additional withdrawals of that metal from the national stockpile, large producers said here yesterday. In addition, the first brisk business in Australian lead since late 1950, has just been put through, importers said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -Howard L. Aller, president of the American Power and Light Company, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today it has no authority to rule on his plan to sell A. P. L.'s Washington Water Power Company to three public utility districts in the State of Washington.

POSTMASTER GENERAL JESSE M. DONALDSON'S announcement of seven additional special stamps during 1952 brings to twelve the number placed on the year's program. This compares with six in 1951 and with twenty-nine during 1948, the previous national elections year.

THIS is Mr. Newby's fourth novel to be published in this country. He won the Atlantic Award in 1946 and the Somerset Maugham Award in 1948; he is admired on both sides of the Atlantic for what some critics have called his sensitive style and his psychological observation, yet his work continues to be more admired on trust than read, at least by Americans.
Navy and Columbia each won five swimming events yesterday, but the middies' superior depth prevailed, 48 -- 36, in an Eastern League meet in the University Hall pool.

WHAT is true in Syracuse, N. Y., according to a recent marketing study, is probably true throughout this country: Oranges hold first place among all fruits both in money spent and total pounds bought. In view of this sizable consumption, householders should welcome the news that the current orange crop is the biggest in history. Lowest prices in ten years will be reached this winter.
GETTING a railroad reservation for Florida is a costlier but less troublesome procedure this winter than in any other year since World War II.

TRONDHEIM, Norway, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Ken Henry, United States Olympic skater from Chicago, defeated Norway's best for the allaround 500-meter (about one-third mile) speed skating title today. His team-mate, Johnny Werket of Minneapolis, was second.

VERY small children in Louis Slobodkin's gentle world gravely observe or silently participate, and when something does break loose it is neatly dispatched and the world goes on its quiet way. A wistful parent may enjoy this calm in the literary hurly-burly of cowboys, fire engines and supermen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- About half of the nation's Republican governors, state committee chairmen and members of the party's national committee still are holding to a publicly neutral position toward the rival Taft-Eisenhower Presidential candidacies.

COULD it be possible that we are on the eve of a better collaboration between Hollywood and the dancers? What with Gene Kelly's success with "An American in Paris," on top of "Red Shoes" and Frederick Ashton's interesting stuff in "Tales of Hoffmann," it definitely could be.

THERE is an ominous trend in this nation. We are developing tolerance only for the orthodox point of view on world affairs, intolerance for new or different approaches. Orthodoxy normally has stood in the path of change. Orthodoxy was always the stronghold of the status quo, the enemy of new ideas -- at least new ideas that were disturbing.
Government officials confirmed last week what many had expected: that 1952 will be a trying period for the nation's economy.
Nautical knowledge awaits thousands of men and women at hundreds of lecture sessions planned this year by the United States Power Squadrons.

THE world inhabited by the middle-aged heroine of Jean Stafford's rare and interesting narrative is one that has all but vanished from the earth. Miss Katharine Congreve's background is blue-blood, blue-stocking Boston.

The recent enthusiasm which greeted the present production of "Saint Joan" amazes me. The inferior quality of this production is another instance of the lack of style in the American theatre. Your critic, discussing the Oliviers' production of the Cleopatra plays, commented that although the American theatre has other virtues, it does not have style.

THERE is a festive air at the National Theatre these days. First of all, business has been good. Seats for performances of "The Constant Wife" through May 4 will be in the box-office racks starting tomorrow and engineers already have started tinkering with the playhouse's airconditioning system.

Mervyn Jones' glance through the list of holders of Britain's Order of Merit ("For True Value," Dec. 30, 1951) included the distinguished novelists, Meredith, Hardy, Barrie, Galsworthy; the present poet laureate, Masefield, and one American, British-naturalized, T. S. Eliot.
Miss Barbara Ann Scott, the Canadian girl who won the Olympic figure skating crown in 1948, will make her Madison Square Garden debut with the Hollywood Ice Revue on Thursday evening.
A total of 2,009 more passengers used the Swedish American liners Gripsholm and Stockholm last year than in 1950, G. Hilmer Lundbeck Jr., managing director of the line here, reported yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 12 -- Charles Taft virtually is assured of the Republican nomination for governor as a result of Governor Lausche's announcement today, according to local political observers.

Sailing skippers and crews of canvas-driven creations have a lot more than small boats to look over at the Motor Boat Show. In the past few years they have had the dinghies to scan for their sizable craft and the small sailers whose masts would permit their being installed on the first floor.

BRUNSWICK, Ga. -- For midwinter vacationists driving up or down the Ocean Highway (U. S. 17), a side trip to the islands clustered off the Georgia coast near this city is one good way to break the long stretch between New York and southern Florida. In addition to scenic beauty, they have many interesting associations with history.

MOTOR vacations during the winter have an increased attraction for many thousands of recreation seekers this season, according to reports by motoring agencies. Highway improvements in the South have made for more enjoyable trips and it is predicted that travel into that territory will set a new record before spring.

MADRID, Jan. 12 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco was expected today to begin a series of individual consultations with his closest collaborators next week to define Spanish policy toward the United States in anticipation of the establishment of a permanent Mutual Security Agency office here.

THIS being the season suitable for prophecy (if there really is such a time) I have somehow gathered sufficient courage to stick out my neck once more. If I have an alibi, it must be that I was egged on into this indiscretion by reading my colleague David Dempsey's summing up of the mixed blessings of 1951.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 12 -- The University of Pennsylvania's basketball team outplayed a game Dartmouth squad to win, 73 -- 67, tonight. The Quakers were led by sophomore Dick Heylmun, who scored 20 points, and Ernie Beck, who played only the second half and dropped in fourteen markers.

Since 1918 the Brooklyn Power Squadron has been trying to help small boat owners and those interested in boating to do a better and safer job in their pursuit of pleasure. In these years it is safe to estimate that far over 5,000 have attended free courses and learned to avoid accidents, to get home safely when caught in a storm, to rescue less fortunates and to handle emergencies.

TRENTON, Jan. 12 -- Although nature lovers may consider snow fences an eyesore on the winter scene, Ransford J. Abbott, State Highway Commissioner, considers them essential in keeping the highways open during the snow season.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, Korea, Sunday, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet said today that any all-out Communist offensive in Korea would meet "with complete disaster both on the ground and in the air."

NOW that a sparkling production of "Pal Joey" has set up shop at the Broad-hurst Theatre, Richard Rodgers, the composer, is represented by three plays doing business every night in Forty-fourth Street.

The President of the United States has the biggest job in the world. He is the executive head of a nation of 150,000,000 persons -- not the largest but certainly the most powerful and richest of all nations. He is chief of a Federal establishment of 2,000,000 civilian employes.
COLUMBUS, Ohio. Jan. 12 -- Gov. Frank J. Lausche announced today he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for a fourth term as governor at the May 6 primary election.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 12 -- The stage is set here for a new outburst of the epidemic of Arab nationalism that has jeopardized the economic and strategic interests of the Western Powers throughout the Moslem world in the last year.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Captain Carlsen completed this morning in Falmouth the legal and official formalities accounting for the loss of the Flying Enterprise and for his arrival in Britain without his United States passport.
The trend to more liberal retirement plans gained momentum in 1951. Faced with the need for greater stability in their labor force, management initiated programs giving wider benefits to employes.

The Tee-Nee Boat Trailer line has been enlarged by one new model trailer, an improved cradle support arrangement for all models, an accessory that adapts any model for transporting sailing craft, and a second new accessory that converts the trailer into a portable catwalk dock at water's edge.

City College's basketball team, lacking the experience, height and over-all ability of the opposition, finished a distant second to St. John's last night at the Second Corps Artillery Armory in Brooklyn. The score, 71 -- 46, certainly could have been more one-sided if the Redmen, notching their tenth triumph of the season, had not eased the pressure.
The Owens Yacht Company will produce only thirty-foot pleasure boats this year. Two models, the Owens 30 De Luxe Sedan and the Owens 30 Super Express, are on display at the show.

THE conversational topic of Anatole Litvak's "Decision Before Dawn," which came to the Rivoli Theatre in the pre-Christmas rush of films, may now be entirely exhausted for those cocktail-party prattlers in New York who usually pick a subject to pieces before it is ten days old.
Unlimited possibilities for child and adult education through television were forecast yesterday by Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, State Commissioner of Education, at the American Museum of Natural History.

THREE - dimensional movies will soon be available for any moviemaker who owns a 16mm camera and projector. The job is done by a new converting outfit. Although the system involves the use of polaroid glasses by the observer of the projected stereo images, a feature generally considered by the public to be a handicap and by engineers as inevitable, the device is an important advance in stereoscopy for the public.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Athletics today decided against buying the International League's Ottawa franchise and moving it to Jersey City because the American Leaguers don't want to put a Class B team in a Triple A circuit.

The traditional versus the progressive approach to education will be explored at the fourth annual Barnard Forum to be held on Feb. 16 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A statistical picture has, for the first time, been drawn of the flow of some $15,000,000,000 of commodities through 194,099 retail outlets to the 14,500,000 persons in twenty-eight counties constituting the New York market area.

I LIKE this book. It is hardly complete in any one way, but as a whole it is engaging, honest, informative and even useful. It gives the layman a vivid idea of what it costs in time, money, moral courage and physical effort to become and remain a dancer.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The General Assembly adopted today by an overwhelming majority a resolution calling upon all members of the United Nations to take the necessary steps to keep armed forces in readiness for use whenever the Assembly recommends their employment against aggressors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Young men from virtually all areas of the country opened a Youth for Eisenhower political headquarters here today and elected James L. Guilmartin of Miami, an attorney, as national chairman.

CONCERNING American relationships with Greece as they have been cemented since the inception of the Truman Doctrine, L. S. Stavrianos has this to say in his new book, "Greece: American Dilemma and Opportunity": "If the cold war should become hot, we may discover that our ally is a government rather than a people."

A case against the wisdom of communities in enacting "Green River Ordinances" was presented last week by the National Better Business Bureau. Such ordinances get their name from Green River, Wyo., where the first such legislation was passed years ago. They are designed to keep salesmen from calling at homes without prior permission from householders and were upheld by the United States Supreme Court last June.

VIENNA, Jan. 12 -- A 23-year-old Soviet sergeant, who fled to the British zone of Austria a fortnight ago, said today in Graz that he had deserted to inform the Western world of the terrible conditions in Russia.

DEFINITION may assist in an understanding of the title and context of this tautly construeted novel of mountain-climbing in the French Alps. A crevasse, according to Merriam-Webster's New International Dictionary, Second Edition, is a fissure in the mass of a glacier or snow field caused generally by changes in the grade of the bed and by inequalities of movement.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The composition of a watchdog subcommittee charged with coordinating President Truman's program for guarding security information was announced at the White House today.

TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 13--United Nations delegates to the Korean Truce Confreence at Panmunjom pressed the Communists yesterday to declare specifically whether or not they meant to build military airfields in North Korea during the armistice, but received no clear reply.

RENOVO, Pa., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Two years ago an impoverished farmer drilled a 5,000-foot hole in the ground twenty miles northwest of here. It turned out, to be the discovery well for the Leidy field, Pennsylvania's biggest natural gas strike in many years.

I AM still convinced that John Dickson Cart is the greatest living writer of detective stories, but I'd hate to have to prove that assertion by his latest book under the Carter Dickson byline, BEHIND THE CRIMSON BLIND (Morrow, $2.50).

TORONTO, Jan. 12 -- There never will be total peace in the world, but the West will succeed in maintaining some kind of tolerable international society, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said here tonight.

SKI interest is booming now as it has not in many years, thanks to unusually good early snows throughout the nation's northlands. Record-breaking crowds jammed the facilities of all major skilands during the Christmas-New Year's holidays. With such a start and some extra money in the bank for a change, resort and lift operators look forward to the best winter season a long time.

" TODAY," the N. B. C. presentation which is to introduce New Yorkers to the experience of breakfast television viewing, makes its bow at 7 A. M. tomorrow and, if even half the rumors and reports about the venture should prove true, it's going to be quite an effort.

FOR more than half a century the Pioneers, as the "emigrators" of the Oregon and Overland Trails were miscalled, were pictured as knights in gleaming armor who bore the banner of American culture steadfastly onward toward distant shores.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 12 -- Victory appears remote for either side as the war for Indo-China enters its sixth year. The French and Indo-Chinese forces have an advantage over the Communist-led Vietminh forces in terms of trained regular battalions, in equipment and in economic and financial resources.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Pfc. Thomas C. Reed, 19-year-old Negro infantryman killed in Korea, was buried today beside other soldiers of his country after six weeks of controversy over interment privileges in a private cemetery.

THE word "abstract," as applied to so many obviously different kinds of non-representational art, is already showing signs of strain. Before it breaks down altogether it may permissibly be attached to four current exhibitions of painting, and possibly to a fifth.

THE South will present its full line-up of carnivals this winter, after a year in which several of the big fiestas were canceled or sharply curtailed because of a mild form of war-emergency jitters. Serious attempts to regain the prestige and tourist business lost last winter will be made by the sponsors of the Mardi Gras at New Orleans and Mobile, the Spring Fiesta at New Orleans and the Azalea Festival at Charleston, S. C.

TELEVISION has long since come into its own as teacher of living history. It aroused the indifferent against political corruption by making them eyewitnesses of the Kefauver Crime Committee hearings. It broadened the American people's interest in world affairs through its coverage of the United Nations.

Children in the third and fourth grades, whose ages range from 7 to 9, will read the new comic book, "Uncle Charlie's Fables," both in class and at home.

FALMOUTH, England, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Captain Carlsen is stubbornly rejecting all fat offers to cash in on his fourteen-day saga aboard the Enterprise. He said he just was not interested.

DETROIT, Jan. 12 -- Sweeping in through a cloud layer that blanketed the Great Lakes states this morning, low-flying intruder planes carried out a simulated attack on the vital industrial centers of the Middle West.

BORN in the Deep South of educated but very poor parents, Helen Caldwell Day learned at an early age what it was like to be a Negro living in American society. A career in nursing, which she began at 18 years, afforded the first opportunity to meet white people as equals and develop friendships among them.

ALTHOUGH winter is generally considered the one season when the garden is insect-free, no idea could be more erroneous. True, insects that cannot survive freezing temperatures die with the approach of winter, but usually they remain in some stage of development in order to perpetuate the species.
Four hundred and fifty paraplegic veterans who use wheel-chairs faced yesterday the problem of obtaining a new club with a street-level entrance. They have been at 99 Park Avenue for four years.

Detectives who had watched midtown hotels for more than a week for "a guest" with a deformed left ear spotted their quarry early yesterday morning and arrested him for the murder on Jan. 3 of Carlos Diaz, 38 years old, in the hallway of an apartment house at 10 West Seventy-fifth Street.

GERTIE is a middle-aged horse, bored with life on the farm and misunderstood by Farmer McNab, who mistakes her thoughtful preoccupation for stupidity. Her chance for adventure comes when she is sent to a summer resort, where she meets the boy Tommy.

Richard Farrell displayed a fine uniform level of competence throughout his piano recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. His technique was accurate, his musical aims serious, his tone generally pleasing, his musical developments logical.

THIS is the most useful reference book on Indians that has appeared for many years. Its compass is much more extensive than its title would indicate; for Oklahoma was once an "Indian Territory" and Indians from all the eastern half of the United States were concentrated there.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla. -- A museum devoted entirely to citrus fruit is scheduled to become the Peninsula State's newest year-round tourist attraction. It will be opened to the public in this central Florida city on Tuesday and will be dedicated on Feb. 20 during the 1952 Florida Citrus Exposition.
Navy fliers of the future will be able to fly a carrier-based jet ighter at altitudes of more than 40,000 feet in all kinds of weather without leaving the deck of the ship

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, commanding general of the First Army, presented the Distinguished Service Cross, awarded posthumously to Pfc. Leonard M. Kravitz for extraordinary heroism in Korea, to Sgt. Seymour Kravitz, brother of the award winner in a ceremony yesterday at First Army Headquarters on Governors Island.
Twice recently you have countenanced the suggestion from London that the Loch Ness monster is not a real monster but a mere "legend" of the "silly season." I am amazed!

THE film industry, which has its fair share of woe, had something definite to crow about last week with the disclosure by Arthur B. Krim, president of United Artists, that the distribution company had achieved a "substantial" profit last year.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 12 -- St. Peter's Prep won its second straight metropolitan Jesuit high school basketball tournament today by defeating Xavier, 78 to 61. Tom Burke, with 25 points for St. Peter's, took high scoring honors. Tom Bohen and Dick Engert led the losers with 13 each.

MR. ASHER BRYNES the reviewer of my recent book, "The Citizen Decides," either has failed to grasp the central theme of the book, or has deliberately chosen to ignore it * * * He creates the impression that I have offered "human brotherhood" as a panacea."

The disorderly scene which marked Ernie Durando's seventh-round knockout of Rocky Castellani in their scheduled ten-round middleweight bout on Friday night in Madison Square Garden yesterday appeared headed for a grand jury investigation.

THE French Six have so long been a part of musical history that it may perhaps come as a surprise to some to learn that the group is still intact and as active as ever. Their long association of almost a third of a century is at present being honored in Paris with an exhibition to which each of the composer members of the group has submitted manuscripts, pictures, letters and memorabilia of all kinds.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- Edgar Faure, Radical, who was asked on Friday to attempt to form a new French Cabinet, spent the day conferring with technicians and experts in the social and financial fields rather than with politicians.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 -- Bob Waterfield, leading passer of the National Football League, refused to let a driving rain ruin his aerials today and led the National Conference all-stars to a 30-13 victory over the American all-stars in the second annual Pro Bowl game.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- When General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower agreed to accept the Republican nomination for the Presidency of the United States if drafted by that party's convention, a great many persons in Europe felt as if they were losing a personal friend. These persons know nothing about United States politics -- any more than most Americans comprehend the stylized routine that precedes the formation of so many Continental governments.

MIDWINTER holidays are no longer a luxury reserved only for the few with plenty of time and money to spend. Cooperative planning by resorts, transportation companies and travel agents has produced the package trip which, with its wide variety of choices, provides a readymade vacation to fit any budget and time schedule.

The development and promotion of Port Newark, under the aegis of the Port of New York Authority since March, 1948, has brought record business to that segment of the harbor, and the bistate agency has increased its capital expenditures program for the coming year.

" IT'S about time" was the phrase heard all over Hollywood last week when the policy makers of the motion-picture industry gathered their courage and declared themselves as favoring militant action in the face of onslaughts by irresponsible pressure groups.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Dan A. Kimball, Secretary of the Navy, said tonight that the Navy intended to seek funds to build an aircraft supercarrier of the class of the Forrestal, now under construction, each year for the next ten, and that some probably would be powered by atomic engines.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 12 -- All last Monday afternoon a crowd of 1,000 or more surly looking men stood in cold rain in Jerusalem's central Zion Square blocking traffic and listening to speeches by the leaders of the Herut party broadcast from a loudspeaker van. Most of them were polish and other East European Jews, but there was among them a sprinkling of Iraqis and other Oriental Jews from the squalid immigrant camps.

Rabbi Isar Hehuda Unterman, chief spiritual leader of Tel Aviv, in an address in Carnegie Hall last night, asserted that Israel "is destined to play a historic role as a powerful spiritual force for world peace and brotherhood." Rabbi Unterman, who recently arrived here, was the guest of honor at a rally arranged by the Greater New York Committee for State of Israel Bonds.
Substantial reductions in passenger fares between New York and Mediterranean ports were announced here yesterday by Stockard Co., Inc., agents for the Khedivial Mail Line.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, said today that Government auditors had uncovered "shortages conservatively estimated at $4,000,000 in the Agriculture Department's farm price support program. The Senator told a reporter that a confidential report on the shortages had been supplied by Lindsay C. Warren, Controller General.
WOODS HOLE, Mass., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Two research vessels will set out soon on a 15,000-mile, four-month journey to study the "birthplace of the Gulf Stream."

In line with its established policy, the United States Coast Guard Auxiliary has in progress and in preparation free public instruction courses in seamanship and allied subjects, with particular emphasis on safety. Many of those completing the course become members of the auxiliary, but there is no obligation to do so.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12--Steel union and company representatives told a Wage Stabilization Board panel today they believed they could settle disputes over six non-economic issues without Government help.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- France is in the throes of a political crisis and the rest of the world seems to have the impression that this is just another tempest in a teapot which will end in the formation of another Cabinet just like the one which fell.

THE doors to baseball's Hall of Fame will swing open briefly in the near future and then will slam shut for another year. Whether any new candidates will be admitted to membership will be decided when the ballots of the Baseball Writers Association are collected by Kenesaw Mountain Smith, the indefatigable secretary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- House military leaders warned economy advocates today that if they killed a 10 per cent across-the-board military pay increase bill Tuesday, troops in Korea would have lost their last chance for a rise this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The recent major intensification of Soviet efforts to expand foreign trade with Western Europe, the Middle East and Asia is, in the opinion of Government officials, primarily a propaganda bluff and not based on economic reality.
Fordham's basketball team came from behind in the final period to defeat a scrappy Brooklyn College quintet, 61 -- 54, last night at the loser's court.

WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 12 -- A prominent 52-year-old woman building contractor was arrested here last night and charged with stealing $12,000 in furs and jewels from a house she had built for an inventor.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 12 -- Navy roared to its highest scoring total of the basketball season in downing favored Georgetown, 82 -- 62, today. It was the middies' eighth victory in eleven starts. The Hoyas have a 4-and-3 record.

MANY people, physicians and otherwise, have written longer, bulkier and more rule-bound health tomes than this. Still, nobody has shown quite so delightfully before "how to kill yourself by doing deliberately all the things you have

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The United Nations General Assembly ordered today the formulation this year of a plan for collection and administration of a largo international fund for economic development of backward areas.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (UP) -- The Soviet newspaper Izvestia said today that regardless of the outcome of the United States' Presidential elections "the weasled Congress and the Government will be ruled by a reactionary Republican-Democratic coalition representing the great American monopolies."

A STRANGER in any small town, especially when his spending money is showing, can cause a lot of speculation -- and, often, a lot of trouble. The arrival of Lancelot Cavanna in the dormant hamlet of Wycherly, accomplishes just that. Mr. Cavanna brings with him much talk of magic and a talent for skulduggery that is, to this reader, offensive as it is wall-meaning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Truman, in a statement observing the first anniversary of the Federal Civil Defense Administration, said today that an enemy unable to crush our will to fight and cripple our production lines could never win a war against the United States.

THIS is a novel to be read slowly. like poetry, for Josephine Pinckney's lyrical prose and her ironic humor have an enchanting quality that should be savored to the full. Her exquisite, delicate images mingle oddly at times with the all-too-earthy passions and colloquial conversation of her characters.

GRINDEWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 12 -- American Olympic ski hopes rose and fell today as Andrea Mead Lawrence won the women's Swiss giant slalom and George Macomber suffered a probable broken leg in the international Lauberhorn downhill race. Mrs. Lawrence, 19-year-old veteran of the 1948 Olympics, led the huge international field by two-tenths of a second in the Swiss meet, which drew ski queens from eleven nations.

VICTOR struck pay dirt last year when it dug up a host of old recordings by stars of other years and issued them under the omnibus title, "A Treasury of Immortal Performances." Most of the performances were by singers of a generation or two back, and the name of Enrico Caruso, of course, led the list.

During World War I sawdust was converted by German chemists into cattle fodder by means of sulfuric acid. The acid broke down the lignin (sticky stuff in woody cells) so that the wood or cellulose could be digested in the rumen of a cow. A cow has four stomachs, of which the rumen is the first.

FOR THIS WEEK: Keep azalea and cyclamen well watered. Dead flowers and yellow leaves on cyclamen can be pulled off by yanking the stems; when azalea blossoms turn brown, continue to water and keep in sun while new leaves develop. . . . Check fertilizers that are stored to be sure they are tightly covered and not damp. Liquid insecticides and fungicides should be stored where temperatures do not reach the freezing point.

The executive board of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., will recommend tomorrow night to 3,800 members employed by the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation that they accept reduced bus schedules in the Bronx. This would result in a lay-off of 120 men, it was announced by Matthew Guinan, president of the union's Local 100.

SALT LAKE CITY -- To Eastern ski enthusiasts the region west of the Rockies and east of the Sierras is chiefly attractive because of the widely known resorts at Sun Valley, Idaho, Alta in Utah and the Mount Rose area near Reno, Nev.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The draft may call a third son of Halsey McGovern, who said that President Truman was not worthy to confer awards and turned down the Medal of Honor and Silver Star given to two other sons killed in Korea.

OTTAWA, Jan. 12 -- Prime Minister Churchill visited the Parliament buildings today to lay a wreath in the Memorial Chapel for those who fell in World War I and was presented with a membership card in the Parliamentary Press Gallery.

ELLENTON, Fla. -- This tiny West Coast Florida community, a few miles off U. S. 41 and about ten miles south of St. Petersburg as the pelican flies, has one of the most interesting but generally least known historical attractions in the entire state, the Gamble Mansion, one hundred years ago headquarters for a vast sugar plantation set in the wilderness, and tile stately borne of the slave-owning proprietor.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The only prototype of the Vickers Valiant, Britain's first long-range jet bomber built to accommodate the atomic bomb, crashed near Bournemouth on the south coast of England this afternoon after it had caught fire in mid-air.

Greater boating value and better waterfront service are two of the many benefits that present and prospective boat owners may count on, as direct results of a new fair trades practice program, recently launched by the Marine Trades Association.

IT IS not a question of either/or, but of and." Walter Gropius was speaking specifically about fenestrated and closed wall areas, but the sentence might be a key to the man, for his life has been spent trying to join technical and esthetic possibilities.

In Washington, D. C., even in Presidential. years, the first part of January is normally a period for charting the nation's law-making course. The Congress returns from its Christmas recess. The President makes several important policy statements and reports. There is politics, of course, but for the most part it is the politics of the parliamentary game.

THE scene of this two-fisted novel is Chicago. Hollywood has reversed the usual routine and made a picture from it before book publication. "Come, Fill the Cup" stands up as a fairly entertaining story, even if its characters are on the jerry-built side.

GIDE prefaces his play "King Candaules" by saying: "I have meant quite simply to create a work of art." This sentence, which was not written solely to anger the critics, defines the substance of his whole theatre and remains true even after the realization that possibly he was not a born playwright.

TOKYO, Jan. 12 -- The Japanese flair for imitating, but not equaling, the manufactures of occidental nations has caught up with her machine-tool industry, much to the chagrin of die-casting concerns here. Hopes are high, but exports low for Japan's machine-tool makers. It is a long way between an inquiry and a contract.

William F. Talbert of New York, winner of the national indoor crown, topped the list of men's singles rankings approved yesterday by the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association. Mrs. Betty Rosenquest Pratt of Jamaica, B. W. L., who was placed first in 1950, received the same designation yesterday in the sanctioned listing of the women's singles.

Mercury's line of outboard motors contains seven models ranging from 3 1/2 to 25 horsepower. Among them is the Cruiser, a cold war casualty in 1951 but now in production. It's a middle- horse-power engine weighing a little over seventy pounds.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Jan. 12 -- A five-day armed forces preaching mission, the first of its kind to be conducted in the First Army area, will open at the Signal Corps Center here on Monday, Army authorities announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Truman-Churchill talks are not likely to be included among the great achievements of Mr. Churchill's life, but they were useful and in some ways important.
Rounding out thirty-eight years of free instruction to the public in piloting, seamanship and navigation, the United States Power Squadrons have reached a new peak in their long history.

Construction engineers were anxiously watching the spread of the winter's ice down the Hudson River last week as they began the job of laying an extension to the "Big Inch" gas pipeline across the river about thirty-five miles north of the city.

GENEVA, Jan. 12 -- The Russians are having some success in getting non-Communist European economists and business men to accept invitations to the Moscow economic conference, now scheduled for April 3.

Financial restitution for the property losses of Jews and Jewish organizations in Germany under the Nazis should be arranged for and received by a United Nations agency, declared Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein in a sermon yesterday morning at the Kehilath Jeshurun Synagogue, 117 East Eighty-fifth Street.

IT is a busy week for the concert groups and recitalist. In fact, there have not been so many individual performances to go to in many a long day, with the ever faithful Dance Center of the Lexington Avenue "Y" and the Hunter College Playhouse as the scene of most of them.

Eighteen crew members of a troopship that helped to rescue survivors of the disabled freighter Flying Enterprise took time out from their shore leaves yesterday to give a pint of blood each in fulfillment of pledges made on shipboard.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- President Truman has about decided not to ask this election-year Congress for new increases in income or excise tax rates, informed officials said today.

WHEN "Fancy Meeting You Again" opens tomorrow evening at Broadway's Royale Theatre, there may be more to it than meets the first-night eye. Since the comedy deals amiably with certain forms of reincarnation, it should be quite in order to sit there speculating on the possibility that once, long ago, the team may have called itself Aristophanes or Sheridan, or even Bacon writing under the name of Shakespeare,

Stand-by pay amounting to $317,000 was disbursed last year to 2,500 workers waiting to be sent to build a United States Air Force airstrip in Greenland, a witness admitted yesterday before the Senate Preparedness Investigating Committee.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 12 -- Gasoline prices in Northern New Jersey dropped sharply today as independent dealers and members of the New Jersey Retail Gasoline Dealers Association competed for week-end trade.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -- The American Friends Service Committee expressed concern today over "the present trend in the United States toward restricting the independence of individual thought, judgment and speech."

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 12 (AP) -- An investigation was launched here today into charges of floggings, barefoot marches across the desert and other forms of unusual punishment at the Arizona Industrial School for Boys at Fort Grange.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 12 -- John P. Humes of the Racquet and Tennis Club and H. Robert Reeve of the host organization advanced to the semi-finals in the twentieth annual Luckenbach Memorial squash racquets tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.

Retailers gained increased confidence for a more profitable sales performance in 1952 after reviewing weaknesses of past operations last Week at the four-day annual meeting here of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

OF all the lush adjectives in the travel brochures, "foreign," with nine different meanings listed in Webster's Dictionary, is perhaps the one that can claim most credit for driving an astonishing number of Americans out of the country each year in search of something different, colorful and (exclusively in the tourist sense) un-American.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky submitted to the United Nations today a formal proposal accepting the Western demand that any acceptable atomic control plan should provide for inspection on a "continuing basis."

TORONTO, Jan. 12 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs spotted the Detroit Red Wings three first-period goals, got them back in the second period and then fired home two markers in the third period to beat the league-leaders, 5 -- 3, before more than 14,000 wildly enthusiastic fans tonight.
Bail of $180,000 was set yesterday for the six keepers and three civilian employes arrested Friday as members of a ring that supplied Rikers Island inmates with narcotics.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's announcement last week that he would accept nomination by the Republican party as its Presidential candidate has increased speculation as to how he stands on many vital issues, foreign and domestic -- especially the latter.

In a world in which freedom of the press, the first bulwark of liberty, is steadily shrinking -- in which an Argentine dictator can still seize a great newspaper for his own purposes -- it is pleasant to record that a once famous publishing house is being resurrected from the ashes of tyranny to join in the defense of democracy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, announced today that he would oppose "the naming of any one by the United States as Ambassador to the Vatican."

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 12 -- The Pan - American Ophthalmology Association today termed the treatment of glaucoma an outstanding success in its efforts to prevent blindness. The association ended its fourth congress, which was attended by 1,200 delegates from twenty-two nations. Its next congress will be held in Sanitago, Chile, in January, 1956.

SPORTS and commercial fishermen familiar with conditions at the famous "Mudhole" fishing grounds off New Jersey, before and after the pollution of those waters by industrial waste, should find much to interest them in the 48-page booklet which outlines the results of a scientific survey of the waters in question.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The State Department, in a major organizational reshuffle, is planning to set up a new operating agency to run its Voice of America broadcasts and overseas information programs.

MAMMA is still alive when this heavy-footed novel opens -- and, because of her illness, Maida (the eldest) must assume the burdens of the family. How she shapes the destinies of her sisters make up the bulk of the story-line.

Two civilian technical employes of the naval supply activities office at Third Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, received commendations last week for developing a "thermos boot" that has prevented trench foot in Korea this winter.

Four boats, all of Fiberglas, are in the main floor space of the Cape Cod Shipbuilding Company. They are a 9-foot dinghy, available in either a rowing or sailing model; a dinghy of 11 1/2 feet, a Herreshoff design whose rig has a wishbone type boom; a Raven Class planing sloop of Fiberglas instead of the conventional plywood and a general utility outboard hull that has made some strides as a racer.

Evinrude has come out with a three-horsepower outboard motor weighing only 30 pounds for its chief development of the new year. It replaces two others in the company's line -- the 30-pound 1.5 h. p. Sportsman and 39-pound 3.3 h. p. Sportwin.

Ever taste gasoline in your milk? Never, thanks to a half dozen sharp noses in Bayonne. There the Esso Standard Oil Company operates one of the world's largest petroleum refineries. Sometimes its aroma overcomes even the dubious fragrances of the Kill van Kull at low tide.

CAIRO, Jan. 12 -- One British non-commissioned officer was killed and two Cameron Highlanders were wounded, one of them seriously, in the Tel el Kebir area today as Egyptian guerrillas carried out their most determined attack since the beginning of the Suez Canal Zone troubles in October.

EVERGREEN shrubs contribute color which is pleasing both winter and summer, but is most appreciated during the former season. Enjoyment is doubled if evergreens are located where they can be seen in daily passage through the house or about the property.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 12 -- Fire destroyed 6,000 tons of fine printing paper, valued at $2,000,000, and the $125,000 South Dixie warehouse last night. W. A. Torsch, warehouse manager, said a small oil stove exploded near a platform. The oil caught fire and flowed to the building.

Twenty-six longshoremen were seized in a night round-up by the police and a rackets grand jury was called into special session yesterday as the Brooklyn waterfront investigation broke into open action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- The Justice Department refused again today to disclose the purpose of five prison camps authorized by Congress for handling subversives who would be seized in event of a national security emergency.

" POETRY gives most pleasure when only generally and not perfectly understood." This has seemed to many a shocking, even a scandalous, remark. What, if it is right, must be said of all the school teachers and critics and editors who toil to perfect our understanding? Are they kill-joys? Was Coleridge letting another of his devastating tiger cats out of the professorial bag?

From 10 to 30 per cent of the fatal injuries in the atomic-bomb attacks on Nagasaki and Hiroshima were caused by rays familiar to those who work in hospitals where X-rays and radium are used in the treatment of cancer. Many of the Japanese who were exposed to radiation did not die until weeks after the explosions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Mr. DiSalle will survey the political situation in Ohio in a brief but intensive speaking tour.

UP until the Eighteen Sixties or so Clara Schumann was, to the majority of the public, not the wife of one Robert Schumann, a German kappellmeister who wrote inexplicable music. Rather Robert Schumann was the husband of Clara Wieck, the greatest woman pianist of her time and one of the great pianists of the nineteenth century.

In Marguerite Cullman's "London's Lessons for Broadway" (Dec. 23, 1951 ) it is interesting that Lord Gifford in England, who bears the title of "Chairman of Theatre Tickets and Messengers," has completely controlled the black market and availability of good seats at box-office prices.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- A major battle is shaping up here over what policy the state should pursue with respect to the 2,413,270 acres of land that comprise state forest preserves in the Adirondack and Catskill Mountains.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Hamilton Fish is returning to the political wars, this time wearing the colors of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, with those of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur in reserve.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A proposal by the State Board of Regents that public school pupils open each school day with a prayer was under attack today by two Schenectady Protestant church groups -- the board of the First Methodist Church and the First Unitarian Society of America.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- Theatres and dramatic societies in the Russian zone of Germany have been ordered to perform Benjamin Britten's opera, "Peter Grimes," during the coming season "as often as possible" for propaganda purposes.

Martin outboard motors for this year will be at 10, 7 1/2, 4 1/2 and 2 1/2 horsepower. The motors will carry a full year's guarantee, which the manufacturers claim as a record, since the customary guarantee is ninety days.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Putting the British royal family on the road is an operation involving thousands of persons -- not to mention thousands of pounds. Everything has to be planned to the minutest detail, and many of the operations are rehearsed in advance by those who will perform some function once the tour is under way.

AN unpretentious bit of cinematic exposition, but one which may take its place in American screen history along with "The Great Train Robbery" and other landmarks, was presented to a specially invited audience at the University of California at Los Angeles' Theatre Arts Department recently.
RENO, Nev., Jan. 12 (UP) -- What was reported to be the worst local snowstorm in fifteen years virtually isolated this gambling center today.

FROM 1937 to 1942 Nathan Straus was administrator -- the first -- of the United States Housing Authority. What he has to say about housing in the United States is therefore based upon direct experience, both with the technical problems involved and with the powerful pressure groups that have fought housing and planning to this day.
It was with great interest and yet grave concern that I read your last Saturday's article about the auction of the Oliver R. Barrett Lincoln collection, to be held next month in New York.

This is a superior novel about Navy life, of much the same caliber as James Gould Cozzens' "Guard of Honor," which it resembles in structure and in its striving for verisimilitude. The dialogue is realistic, but not in the least overdone.

If you were a boat enthusiast as long ago as pre-World War I, you probably went sailing, rowing and fishing in good old Jamaica Bay, when the waters still sparkled, the weakfish ran, and clams and crabs were there for the taking. Families summered along the shores of this wild life refuge only a short distance from the booming, growing giant of buildings and paving.
WANT to call attention to the one error in Mr. Leo Lerman's otherwise admirable review of "Ouida: the Passionate Victorian."
Sixty-two publishing, advertising, business and civic groups will begin tomorrow a series of events expected to mark New York's most widely observed celebration of Printing Week.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The first week of the Winter Home Furnishings Market in the merchandise and American furniture marts ended here today with most furniture manufacturers more than satisfied with buying. Large-quantity orders were few but the substantial number of sixty to ninety-day retail commitments virtually assured full-time operation for the entire first quarter.
A young woman's fancy, with the approach of spring, turns to a new suit -- at least if it is fashion she is thinking of. She can suit her fancy in 1952, for fashion offers her much.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 12 -- A ranking Argentine Professor of Law said today that the nation's university life was being debased so that doctor's degrees could be obtained through political influence and skulduggery.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 (UP) -- Sixteen New York winter resorts reported good skiing today, the state commerce department said:

Each new home owner is faced with an individual problem of garden design, but certain basic requirements are determined by the site and the architecture of the house. This article, dealing with the contemporary house, is the first of a series that tell how three gardeners have adjusted their plantings to suit a specific type of architecture.

The performance of the Hollywood Ice Revue Friday night at Madison Square Garden has been taken over to raise funds for the Carroll Club and the Carroll Vacation Club, of which Mrs. Basil Harris is president. Proceeds will further the recreational and educational program maintained by the clubs at 120 Madison Avenue.

As the fourteenth president who ham been called upon to direct the affairs of the American Power Boat Association since this governing body for boat racing was first organized in 1903, I welcome the fact that the new administration will be confronted with more than "business as usual" during the course of the year.

A record number of buyers were in the wholesale markets here last week placing orders to replenish depleted stocks, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Many stores requested early deliveries on spring goods.
