Taxes, generally regarded as inevitable as death, aroused the protests of bankers in their annual reports issued last week. In nearly every instance the bank management pointed out that last year's tax provision was the highest in the bank's history, in some instances the rate per share almost matching that of net earnings.

MONTREAL, Jan. 12 (UP) -- Maurice Richard and Rookie Paul Meger each turned the hat trick tonight as the Montreal Canadiens routed the Chicago Black Hawks, 8 to 3, before a delighted gathering of 14,262 at the Forum.

The Phantom Waterscope, a device for viewing objects under the water, is a feature of the products shown by the Aluminum Marine Hardware Company. It is a 2-foot long cylinder, 1 1/2 inches in diameter, with a special lens at one end.

MAY and December romance is the spark that ignites "Dr. Logan's Wife." Start with a long and tepid marriage on these terms, add a handsome young biochemist to confuse the loyalties of the lady who gives the book its title, and finish with a burst of psychoanalysis after Dr. Logan's convenient demise, and the contents of Miss Gaines' second novel are pretty well blueprinted.

The article "Officials and Reporters Don't Agree on Germany," by Jack Raymond, in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 6, throws some new light on a very serious situation. Even as far back as 1950 it was evident that our newspapers did not print the good side of post-war Germany as readily as they presented the dark side.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Walter L. Green, Deputy Administrator of the Federal Housing Administration, announced today the dismissal of R. Earl Peters, the agency's director in Indiana. Mr. Green said the action was taken because a mortgage on a Fort Wayne apartment house owned by Mr. Peters was insured through Mr. Peter's office.

THE war in Korea is probably not as "peculiar" as E. J. Kahn Jr. believes but it is war, all right, and thanks to this book we at last have an account of Korea that manages to get human interest out of an inhuman situation without sentimentalizing it to maudlin proportions.

The Post Office Department is issuing a stamp to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the 4-H Club. This idea in experimental, out-of-the-classroom education for our farm youth has been an important factor in providing a basis for understanding between the city and country bred youth, as well as in helping to make agriculture the highly skilled profession it is today.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12 -- Whether the political rivalries engendered over a twenty-four-year period by the Long family in Louisiana can be welded into a new alignment with a campaign slogan of "All Together Now" will be answered in large measure in a Gubernatorial primary election on Tuesday.

The Korean cease-fire parleys, the hearings by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee and the fight against narcotics addiction were among the topics selected yesterday as outstanding news events of the year by participants in the Youth Forum, under the auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

AN American author, Peter Reynolds, during a few months' residence on the Italian Riviera, falls in love with a neighbor's wife. The neighbor, Richard Johnson, is an invalided war hero, and his pathetic position arouses the local inhabitants to a strong disapproval of the carryings on of Mrs. Johnson and Reynolds. Johnson shortly dies, and the lovers get ready to seek another Eden.
The two big trade associations in the fresh fruit and vegetable industry, representing all levels of distribution throughout the country, will combine forces to fight further inroads on their volume.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Clarkson College of Technology announced tonight that it was suspending varsity football for the 1952 season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Don Gehrmann made an explosive return to the footracing wars tonight. The slim Wisconsin graduate with the stout finish blazed home in 4:14 to take the featured mile race in the fifth Evening Star Games, which attracted a crowd of 5,500 to Washington's National Guard Armory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A letter, signed by more than 100 Republican members of the House of Representatives, that asked Secretary of State Dean Acheson to lodge charges of genocide against the Soviet Union before the General Assembly of the United Nations was made public today.

Jacques Lipschitz, the sculptor, will speak on "A Point of View on Art" on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. in the last of the winter series of free art lectures presented by the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The Art Education Project was established in 1942 with Simon Lissim, artist, as its head.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The French Cabinet, at a special meeting today, decided to ask the National Assembly to confer the rank of Marshal of France upon Gen. Jean de Lattre da Tassigny, who died yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 12 (UP) -- Charlie Burr, the nation's leading rider in 1951, gave Amphiblen a championship ride today to win the Henry L. Straus handicap at Tropical Park before a season's record crowd of 14,574 fans.
The turbulence in the recent affairs of the American Power Boat Association settled into apparent calm yesterday after a five-hour meeting of the national council at the Hotel Belmont Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Truman Fair Deal, though presumably still available as a Democratic platform for the coming autumn, plainly is moribund as a legislative program -- for this election-year Congress at least.

There are ten marine engines in the space of the Chrysler Corporation's Marine Engine Division at the show. They range from 87 to 165 horsepower. New as standard equipment are two developments made for the armed forces -- radio shielding for better ship-to-shore communications and an improved weatherproofing for the entire electrical system.
An organization which voluntarily and without profit has undertaken to teach the general public the basic principles of small boat handling is the Bronx Power Squadron.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- The flying sno-bird from Lake Placid, Artie Devlin, won the second annual metropolitan invitational ski jumping championship here tonight before more than 9,000 fans, the largest night crowd of the season.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Addison B. Hastings and his Ardsley No. 2 rink gained the final round in the seventeenth Douglas Medal curling bonspiel tonight at St. Andrew's Golf Club, routing the Ardsley No. 3's skipped by William Gish, by 18 -- 9.

A 48-foot Wheeler flush-deck "Promenade" yacht is the largest boat in the Palace. Also present is a 42-foot Sedan Sport Fisherman, which is built also in 38, 45 and 48 foot lengths. There are express and sedan cruisers in the same size hulls, but not at the show.

IN downtown Buenos Aires, in a narrow but important street named after Argentina's revered liberator, San Martin, is the hangout of the country's most rabid, unsavory organization of nationalists -- the Alianza Nacional Libertadora.
Several dinner parties will be given in advance of Thursday night's performance of "Paint Your Wagon" at the Shubert Theatre for he benefit of the Maternity Center Association.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 12 -- Sidney Schwartz of New York and Miami upset Budge Patty of New York, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, in the semi-finals of the twenty-third annual West Coast tennis tournament today.
BOSTON, Jan. 12 -- Harold E. Stassen said today that he would decide "in about a week" about entering the New Hampshire primary March 11.

EVERY spring the storks fly to Denmark from their winter home in Egypt, and one spring Greta got her wish -- to have a stork for a pet. Greta's family was understanding, and Greta was allowed to keep the young stork which, after a year, stayed with her instead of flying back to Egypt.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 12 -- At the final session of the Civil Aeronautics Board's three - day hearing on the crash here on Dec. 16 of a non-scheduled C-46 airliner that took the lives of all fifty-six person on it, it was shown that the twin-engined converted military trainsport's right power plant had a structural failure.

WHEN winter sports crowds relied primarily on snow trains to get them out into the countryside, the choice of ski trips was definitely limited, especially for week-end excursionists. Today, however, the trend toward automobile and air transportation has given ski enthusiasts an unprecedented mobility, which has meant in turn a much wider range of winter-holiday possibilities.

More than 137,000,000 visits were made last year to parks and playgrounds by participants in organized and supervised recreational activities conducted by the Department of Parks, it was reported yesterday. Other uncounted millions used the parks for rest and relaxation or motored along park roads and roadways.

Varied divertisements are being planned for the thirteenth annual White Elephant party -- a buffet-dinner dance to be held Friday night in the ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

A philosophy professor whose love for the profession has remained undimmed despite the experiences of motherhood, authorship and weekly trips from her home in Washington, is setting an uncomfortable example for American mothers who "haven't time for outside interests."
Some Chris-Craft power boats are displayed at the Palace, but the complete line of this large builder of stock craft would make a good-sized show in itself.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 12 -- The Communist party of Yugoslavia has begun to prepare public opinion for abandonment of the Soviet type of collectivized agriculture.

A new "pyramid" system of air transportation in which eighty-eight - passenger Super - Constellations will handle express service exclusively and forty-passenger Silver Falcons will take care of the "commuter" service on intercity schedules was announced yesterday by Eastern Air Lines for its New York-Miami run.

Training personnel for national defense is a role that the United States Power Squadrons have played as far back as World War I, and, in case of national emergency, the 127 units of the U. S. P. S. stand ready to take up the challenge again.

Human experience has established that wherever men submit to an absolute, whether in the field of economics, religion or politics, it is but a short and tempting step to forcing them to live for the benefit of the absolute rather than improving, changing and employing things and ideas for the benefit of mankind.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Army said today "certain desired modifications" are being made in the designs of light and medium tanks.
As further evidence that the 1952 baseball campaign cannot be far off things continued to hum merrily yesterday on two of the three local fronts.

HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY schedules for the first month of the year offer a diversity of programs. Here in New York City, a course in "Landscape and Perennial Garden Planning" is being given by the Horticultural Society of New York, with Mrs. Nelva M. Weber as instructor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower is only one in a long line of military men who have been bitten by the Presidential bee. As a matter of fact only lawyers have exceeded the soldiers among the men who have sought this country's highest office.
Fire Department officials checking local sources of highly-inflammable sweaters sold in the metropolitan area were investigating reports yesterday that an East Side concern was manufacturing them.

The Free Europe College, established in November, 1951, at Strasbourg, France, as a challenge to the Communist domination of Eastern Europe, is training men and women in the principles of freedom and democracy. Associated with the University of Strasbourg, the college is part of the Free Europe University in Exile, sponsored by the National Committee for a Free Europe.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 12 -- While losing further ground to the Communists in the state of Travancore-Cochin, Prime Minister Jawaharal Nehru's Congress party showed unexpected strength in Bombay, according to returns, announced today in India's prolonged first national elections.

In your section on Dec. 30 Leora Dana was quoted as saying something, which, if not explained, may confuse many an honest actor trying to find the right way for his talents' growth. Quoting Miss Dana: "Miss (Charlotte) Perry had a very quiet way of working.

Re Bertrand Russell's (greatest and) First Commandment -- "Do not feel absolutely certain of anything," in his "The Best Answer to Fanaticism -- Liberalism" (Dec. 16) -- you answered Jacob R. Tietje's dissent there-from on the ground of the necessity of "Faith in God." with Webster's definition of an "absolute."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 12 -- Four Tiger players hit for double figures as Princeton defeated Harvard's basketball team, 55 -- 42, at the indoor athletic building tonight.
PARIS, Jan. 12 -- During the last two months there has been increasing alarm in Paris lest the Chinese Communists openly attack the French and Vietnamese armies in Indo-China.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 12 -- Shock and regret, combined with concern for the future, marked the reaction here today to the death of General deLattre. He is credited here with having effected a sharp improvement in the situation on the French and Indo-Chinese side in the war in Indo-China.

President Truman's request to Congress in his State of the Union speech last week for legislation to provide more liberal price support for farm products is expected to meet tough opposition, particularly in the House. With prices of farm products near parity levels -- the goal to which two Administrations have been working for the last twenty years -- the time is considered inopportune for any radical changes in present farm legislation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Much of the enjoyment of yachting comes from a sense of freedom gained in cruising widely and venturing into new and hitherto unfamiliar parts of our Atlantic coastal and harbor waters. Charts, coast pilots, tide tables and current tables furnish yachtsmen information which brings confidence to cruise freely.

FRANK MARTIN'S Mass for double chorus and his secular oratorio, "Le Vin Herbe," have for many years been on my list of modern works which I hoped to perform sooner or later. But performance of a relatively unknown composer risks the possibility of a ruinous deficit.
TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 13 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,127 for Saturday's operations:

If the question could be left to geographers the integration of Western Europe would be simple. Here is a limited space to be organized in the best interests of the people who live there. The geographer's map shows great coal fields extending across northern France, across Belgium and into Germany.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Business trends in the Chicago area during December appeared to have stabilized, the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago indicated. In summarizing the results of the survey the association said December showed no new trends.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12--White House expectations that President Truman's National Advisory Board on Mobilization Policy would recommend continued Government control over prices and wages have been upset by industry objections, it became known tonight.

Fred Wilt, the special agent from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, made his first mile start of the season last night, and it was an impressive one. Running in the annual senior Metropolitan A. A. U. championships at the Third Engineers Group Armory, the fleet-footed Government man, who wears the colors of the New York A. C., covered the distance in 4:14.6 to win the event for the third straight time.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 12 -- The Iranian Foreign Ministry announced tonight that all of Britain's consulates in Iran must be closed by Jan. 21. There are fourteen in all, including the consulates general, consulates and vice consulates.

The death of General Jean de Lattre de Tassigny removes from the rolls one of France's most dashing and aggressive military leaders at a time when his services were deeply needed. The arrival of General de Lattre in Indo-China just over a year ago sparked a new morale and a new effort in that dismal war which now daily grows more threatening.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Grain prices sank quietly on the Board of Trade today after an initial burst of strength in wheat, which soon petered out. Losses were not large anywhere, but the market showed a lack of rallying power.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, formally served notice today that supporters of the St. Lawrence seaway bill would press for early action on the legislation. Senator Tom Connally of the Senate Foreign Relations committee immediately predicted the committee would reject the measure.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 12 -- Dartmouth's brightest Alpine skiing prospect, 20-year-old Tommy Corcoran of St. Jovite, Quebec, today outclassed a field of seventy-five in the fifth annual Louise Orvis giant slalom. The 150-pound athlete plunged down from the 3,600-foot summit of Big Bromley despite wet snow and poor visibility in the sparkling time of 1:31.2.

ALBERT SCHWEITZER is spending his seventy-seventh birthday tomorrow, as he has for most of the past thirty years, in his jungle hospital at Lambarene in French Equatorial Africa. The remoteness of this center of his life's work helps to explain why the philosopher, theologian, physician, writer and organist remains a legendary character, although hailed by many people as the greatest living man.
A NEW type of high-quality squash, adapted to home garden, market or canning use, is fast making a place for itself. For few small gardens have space for the older and large vining varieties.

Debutantes headed by Miss Clare C. Lundbeck and including the Misses Nancy L. Ogden and Frances T. Keresey are aiding members of the executive committee in the plans for the Animal Kingdom Ball to be held on the night of Jan. 24 in the main ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 12 -- The second round of the scheduled fifty-four-hole $10,000 Bing Crosby national pro-amateur golf tournament was called off today because of the unplayable condition of the rain-drenched Monterey Peninsula Country Club course.
SEATTLE, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Bad weather caused a halt today in aerial search for the freighter Pennsylvania and her forty-five-man crew, after floating debris had provided the first clue.

A tiny crystal device called the transistor, about the size of a kernel of corn, has electronics engineers and military men excited over its vast potentials. Some rate it as one of the most important developments in electronics since the vacuum tube, which made possible the modern telephone, radio, television, radar and countless other electronics marvels, according to the Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Republicans began this week the actual selection of the approximately 1,200 delegates to meet at their national convention in Chicago beginning July 7 to choose Presidential and Vice Presidential nominees and approve the party platform for presentation to the voters in November.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- An intensive study of the operations of the Office of Alien Property, which may produce new revelations of scandals in administrative agencies, was brought nearer this week when Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, asked the Senate to authorize an investigation by its Judiciary Committee.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 12 (UP) -- A white minister who was warned to tone down his sermons or face a "Mims-type" bombing death said today that nothing could stop him from preaching against Communism.

THIS third volume in a series on "The Church's Teaching" brings to members of the Episcopal Church and others a clear statement of the content, the meaning and the method of the Christian faith as summarized in the historic Christian Creeds.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Frank Pace Jr., Secretary of the Army, paid recognition today to the work of Army reservists, commissioned and enlisted, in the Korean fighting.

" A THREE-LEGGED cat is not worth a tarnation." said Daddy Reed when Yaller-Eye lost a paw in a trap. But to Randy, a barefooted, Carolina-mountain boy, parting with Yaller-Eye was like losing a friend. Randy's mother, his little sister and the teacher, however, contrive to help the father see that "a three-legged cat can be just as important to a boy as learning to hoe corn and to read.

An auction sale for the benefit of Goddard Neighborhood Center, to which patrons of the settlement have contributed paintings, sculpture, prints and home decorations, will be held at 8:15 P. M. Tuesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

SWIFT travel to strange places around the Gulf of Mexico awaits the Florida vacationist who wants a new route home -- a that is longer but offers varieties of scenery, foreign languages, meadows of flowers, exotic foods, volcanoes, bullfights, life among picturesque natives far from overcrowded tourist centers, glimpses into a great civilization of centuries before Christ and shopping sprees at prices of twenty-five cents on the dollar.
ATHENS, Jan. 12 -- The United States Embassy here announced today that Ambassador John E. Peurifoy would leave next week for consultations in Washington. He is expected to be away about a month.

At the Boston meeting of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics Dr. E. J. Gumbel (Stanford University) read a paper on a new, statistical theory of droughts. A drought is defined as the smallest daily discharge of a river for a certain year. If minimum daily discharges are known for several years it is possible to discover a statistical distribution of extreme values.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The United States Far East Air Forces reported yesterday their costliest week of the air war in Korea -- three Sabre jets shot down in dogfights and thirteen other planes destroyed by Communist ground fire.

New York City's oldest adult education project -- The Cooper Union Free Forum, which was established in 1859 -- has chosen education as the subject of a series of fourteen Sunday evening lectures this winter. Leading educators and Government officials will participate.

CLIO, the Muse of History, does not dwell (as most people think) in cozy libraries and shaded archives. She presides over a dangerous battlefield, where angry groups charge and grapple, and one cohort no sooner gains a height than an enfilading fire is opened from both flanks. Among skirmishers and guerrillas two great central combats never cease.

Joe Lapchick's Knickerbockers still are making it tough for any team to beat them on the home court. At Madison Square Garden last night the Knicks ran their home winning streak to eight games by defeating the Indianapolis Olympians, 86 -- 77, before 8,776 fans.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP)--Today's livestock prices reported by the Department of Agriculture follow:...

The Democratic and Republican leaders of each of the city's five counties were urged yesterday by John E. Carton, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, to support Mayor Impellitteri's plan to increase municipal revenue by about $200,000,000 in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- The Defense Production Administrator, Manly Fleischmann, announced today that a Governmental "task force" would seek to place military contracts in areas where civilian cutbacks had caused serious unemployment.

In the half-century that has elapsed since a small group of race boat enthusiasts held an experimental get-together in New York City, with the result that the American Power Boat Association was formed, the constant growth of membership and boat ownership in this ruling body for the sport has been as marked as the sensational increases in speed.

The Canadiens of Montreal, currently the most formidable team in the National Hockey League, will trade checks with the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight. With a record that surpasses that of any other sextet in the loop over the past three weeks, the Flying Frenchmen promise to attract a large crowd for their clash with Bill Cook's puck chasers.

WHEN the Music Critics Circle of New York met last Monday to vote its awards for the best new compositions in various classes heard in the last fifteen months in this city it cited as the most interesting orchestral composition the twelve-minute symphony by the American Negro composer, Howard Swanson.

Union and business leaders in the dress industry paid tribute yesterday to Julius Hochman, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., and for twenty-five years general manager of its New York dress joint board, on the occasion of his sixtieth birthday.
Christmas activity cleared inventories at the manufacturers' level in almost all toy lines, producers reported last week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 -- In a letter directed behind the Iron Curtain today, an American maritime union leader wrote that it would be well to have a conference to compare conditions of seamen in the democratic nations with those in the Soviet Union and its satellites. But he added that this would be impossible "before Stalin and his co-aides are removed from their control."

Unless one has to face the various hazards it sets up on the highways, snow can be beautiful. A snowflake is the most delicate of all crystals, intricate and varied beyond belief. And a snowdrift, shaped by the wind, is something to delight the eye of anyone who seeks the beauty of pure form.

If the debt settlement to be turned up some day for defaulted German dollar bonds runs along the lines of the Italian settlement, and if market prices thereafter follow likely yield patterns, it can be expected that "old" bonds benefiting from the settlement would sell at prices ranging from 32 3/4 to 49, and the "new" bonds resulting from the settlement would sell at prices ranging from 18 1/4 to 27 1/4.

A SMALL but significant anniversary has just come up for Van Wyck Brooks: twenty years ago exactly he embarked on his extensive and intensive and impressive literary history. Now, with the publication of the fifth volume, "The Confident Years: 1885-1915," Mr. Brooks is done with his masterwork -- which bears the over-all title "Makers and Finders: A History of the Writer in America, 1800-1915."

The first full twelve-hour run of the National Motor Boat Show at Grand Central Palace turned out to be a family day. Youngsters by the hundreds yesterday led their parents in, over, around and under the handsome 1952 boating creations on their display cradles.

IN this account of the development of the human community, Mr. Masani has emphasized the obstacles men have had to overcome to live happily with their fellowmen. He has shown man in his primitive environment, alone and lonely, the discovery of agriculture and the organization of the family, the clan and later the village.

The Beetle Boat Company, a pioneer in the manufacture of Fiberglass boats, is back at the show with craft that range from eight to twenty-four feet. The largest is the "BB-24" cabin cruiser, a utility and a sport fisherman. The purchaser may have it as a hull only, with engine installation and finishing done by the owner or his contractor, or as a finished boat.

CLOSE to forty - eight years ago, an officer of the United States Army made his way up the Korean peninsula, riding a big horse called a "Waler" because it came from New South Wales. There was a war on, between Japan and Russian.

ISABEL LEIGHTON has the unusual distinction of having been "discovered" by a television talent scout on -- of all places -- the lecture platform. It is not known whether the talent man from the American Broadcasting Company wandered into Town Hall one evening for self-improvement and enlightenment or in the line of duty, but there he saw and heard Miss Leighton moderate a panel discussion on psychiatry.
World prices for diamonds will remain firm despite important changes in trading procedures that took place recently.

Dr. Willem Drees, Socialist Premier of the Netherlands, arrived here by air yesterday for a thirteen-day visit. He told reporters his trip had a twofold purpose: to discuss Netherland-United States relations with President Truman and Secretary of State Dean Acheson, and to study the American way of life as seen in its industry and trade unions.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The Korean question, which for more than a year and a half has dominated proceedings of the United Nations, finally came up for debate this week just two months after the start of the current session of the General Assembly.

More than 1,200 dealers and brokers who are members of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc., are expected to attend the organization's twenty-fourth annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel here today through Tuesday.

Resort wear, spring dresses, sportswear and home furnishings were stressed in retail promotions here last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

Ever since the news leaked out just before Christmas that Judge Thomas F. Murphy of New York had told the President first that he would, and then that he wouldn't, head an independent commission to investigate corruption in Federal agencies, there has been an embarrassing little ritual at the weekly White House press conference.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Army's gymnastic team extended its winning skein to seventeen straight today with a 49-to-46 victory over Florida State defending National Collegiate Athletic Association and National Amateur Athletic Union champion in the opening meet of the season.
Cotton futures on New York Cotton Exchange declined 5 to 23 points yesterday.

THE son and grandson of stewards of the powerful Pio family, Bernadine Realino was born on Dec. 1, 1530. At 16, he rode out to Modena, only a few miles from home, to the university, where he roistered around the town in carnival
Before Winston Churchill's official party returns to England, definite agreement is expected to be reached for another Anglo-American barter of strategic materials.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 12--The 1952 Holland Music Festival has been pulled out of a hat after it had been generally expected that it would be canceled because of the withdrawal of support by the city of Amsterdam and the controversy over management of the five-year-old event.

A twenty-six-foot metal stock sedan cruiser that the builder claims cannot sink has been placed on the market and is displayed at the Palace. It is by the Welin Davit and Boat Division of Continental Copper and Steel Industries. Welin claims it to be the first of its kind in power boating history.

NO other type of window gardening can become more fascinating than growing succulents and, what is more, it is a comparatively inexpensive hobby. Tiny succulents are often more interesting than larger types.

EVER since hostilities began in Korea a year and a half ago, two opposing points of view about women on factory production lines have been making headlines regularly. "U. S. to Call Mothers Into Defense Plants," reads one. "Women War Workers Opposed," says another.

SUCH an old and complex misunderstanding as that between the British and Egyptian Governments concerning the Suez Canal and the Sudan can well be expected to have widespread repercussions, and so it is by no means surprising that Egyptians in New York City should have strong convictions on the subject.

A campaign inaugurated last March requesting the cooperation of boatmen has resulted in a 15 per cent reduction in bridge openings of state highway bridges along the coastal waters of New Jersey. Under the joint sponsorship of Highway Commissioner Ransford J. Abbott and Conservation Commissioner Charles R. Erdman Jr., a meeting of Federal, state and county officials in March, 1951, was held at Trenton.

THERE arose a need for scorpions. If the company had been on the set in Hollywood a telephone call would have brought a box full. Out on the Argentine pampa, miles from nowhere, Bill Sittell had his doubts.

Completing a year of much varied activity, New York Power Squadron looks forward to another of progress. Last season's rendezvous ranged all the way from Staten Island, in New York's southwest quadrant, to Port Jefferson, in the northeast quadrant, and included such way stations as Stamford, Lloyd's, and so on.

ROANOKE, Va., Jan. 12 -- The National Park Service announced today that through a grant of about $100,000 by John D. Rockefeller Jr., Linville Falls in western North Carolina would be added to the 500-mile Blue Ridge Parkway. The acquisition includes the falls and 1,100 adjacent acres of woodland.
REPORT on the nation's reading preferences, as revealed by the chart on the right:
THE combination of the great Franklin and one of America's foremost author-illustrator teams results in a beautiful picture book, the fourth in the Petershams' "This Is America" series.

SOME impressive evidence has been developed lately in support of the children of all ages who echo the slogan: "No More Homework." The result has been to reopen a debate that has raged, on and off, during the past fifty years. The question: Shall our schools do away with homework?

Prof. Pascual Jordan, internationally known German nuclear physicist, declares in the Journal of Parapsychology, edited by Prof. J. B. Rhine of Duke University, that extrasensory perception (telepathy, clairvoyance) cannot be explained in terms of what we are taught to believe is "reality."

The 1,300 square feet occupied as usual by the Detroit Diesel Engine Division of General Motors is comfortably filled with engines and auxiliary equipment for pleasure craft, work boats and commercial fishermen.

KEY WEST -- This island city is a great place of rumors, most of which detail new projects to lure more visitors here. Not that Key West particularly needs such publicity: President Truman's visits take care of that, and he made his tenth visit since 1946 just last month.

The Plasti Craft line of small outboard runabouts by the Winner Manufacturing Company is represented at the Palace again. They are of molded plastic, as the name indicates. The company claims that advancements in molding technique give increased strength to its 1952 models.

Inspector Henry A. Larsen, soft-spoken chief police officer of the Arctic wastelands of Canada, recounted yesterday with the characteristic modesty of a man of the North, some of his experiences in a quarter of a century as a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

Interest in economic education seems to be approaching the proportions of a fad. Hardly a trade association has met in the last six months without studying the field or taking action to enter it. Industrial advertisements are explaining in detail how our private enterprise system works and why it should be kept working.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The many observers here who keep tabs on the Stalin Succession Sweepstakes, keenest race in the Soviet Union, had a new item of information for their form sheets this week: Politburo member Georgi M. Malenkov reached his 50th birthday Tuesday and stepped for that day at least out of his usual obscurity into the full glare of the spotlight normally reserved only for Joseph Stalin.

Industrialists and engineers from all major manufacturing sections of the country have prepared an elaborate schedule of events to mark the Centennial Celebration of Engineering in the United States this year.

MIAMI BEACH -- Tourist officials are looking for new phrases to describe the winter season which goes into full swing on Jan. 15. "Bigger and better" is a travel clich. "The best in history" also has been used a lot of times.

PROF. AVERY CRAVEN'S review of Lamont Buchanan's "Pictorial History of the Confederacy" has some interesting statements on Southern pictorial source material. Perhaps there's a bit more to be said about that.

IN the recent series of articles in this column, it was remarked that despite the various conventions that have been devised in defense against an opponent's shutout bid, most expert players simply double such bids for a takeout, even at the level of four or five.

WRITTEN between 1536 and 1541, Fray Toribio de Motolinia's history has long been a classic reference for all investigators of that sanguine, audacious, fabulous and reprehensible episode, the Spanish Conquest of the Indies.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 12 -- Keghan Mekertichian, Reuters correspondent here since the expulsion of Leopold Herman a month ago, was summoned before the investigating judge of the Court of the First Instance today. Bakhtar Emruz, leading organ of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's National' Front, said the journalist had been arrested.

" THE PEOPLE ACT," which now is being heard at 10:05 o'clock on Sunday evenings over C. B. S. radio, is the initial production of the Television-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation and is dedicated to repairing one of the more serious if less noticed breakdowns in modern communities.
Alexander Del Giorno had the pleasure to be sworn in as a City Magistrate in Queens yesterday and then had the misfortune to see his automobile crippled accidentally by one of his well-wishers.

Textron, Inc., once a leading exponent of vertical integration in the textile industry, will retain some remnant of the yarn-to-finished-garment operation by licensing its name to independent manufacturers of apparel.

Harry A. Woodruff, a former member of the United States Embassy staff in Paris, was found dead of a gunshot wound in the head at 8:30 A. M., yesterday, in a room on the thirty-sixth floor of the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.
Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, the skipper who would not give up his ship, will return to New York Wednesday and get the traditional welcome that the city accords its heroes.

A FAVORITE Grimm's fairy tale concerns a little girl who is sent to gather strawberries in the winter woods. Through sorcery the woods become, for a while, a summer garden. Although gardeners cannot duplicate this enchantment, they can, with planning, have bloom outdoors during winter in the vicinity of New York City.

The title of professor emeritus was conferred yesterday on Dr. Richard Schuller, 81-year-old Austrian statesman and educator, after a luncheon in his honor at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

THE current retrospective exhibition at the Whitney Museum brings together an exhaustive selection of paintings and graphic work by the late John Sloan, covering sixty years of that artist's career as illustrator, etcher and painter.
THE first reaction of a person who is shown passenger records of the airlines flying to vacation areas these days could well be amazement that there is any one left in the city.
The Universal line of marine engines for 1952 contains an assortment of low, medium and high speed motors varying from one to six cylinders and developing from 8 to 145 h. p.

FERNANDINA, Fla. -- Pirates, slave traders, hijackers, hidden treasure and wars and rebellions are all part of Florida's newest attraction, the Buccaneer Trail connecting Fernandina and Mayport. Completion of new projects promises to attract double the number of visitors this winter.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 12 -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association today stands reinvested with the constitutional authority of a powerful agency for the enforcement of a new set of regulations designed to eliminate or curb unethical practices and excesses that have brought so much discredit upon football and basketball.

Department store sales dipped sharply last week. Trade observers put the drop below the abnormal levels of the 1951 week, when the second Korean "scare buying" rush was near a peak, at 25 per cent. In that week of 1951 sales were 30 per cent ahead of the 1950 period.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 12 -- Lion, a 29-1 long shot, beat out the favored Moonrush in the $25,000-added Santa Catalina Handicap today to share stakes honors with Special Touch in the mud at Santa Anita.

In his state of the Union message on Wednesday, President Truman, discussing the Point Four program, said," * * * there is nothing of greater importance in our foreign policy. There is nothing that shows more clearly what we stand for, and what we want to achieve."

DR. ROWLAND S. POTTER, a leader in American photographic technology, was honored for his achievements last week at a simple ceremony preceding the regular monthly meeting of the New York Section, Technical Division, of the Photographic Society of America.

GEORGE AVAKIAN has done Columbia Records and all of us a service with the release of his second big retrospective jazz history, The Bessie Smith Story. Four well-engineered twelve-inch disks and the editor's excellently written documentation give a full picture of the greatest blues singer of them all.
The woman's touch has been incorporated in the cold businesslike offices of many of the big corporations of America, and one of those most responsible for the change is Maria Bergson.

The cynical protest of the Soviet Government, both through diplomatic channels and at the U. N. Assembly, against the provision of the 1951 United States Mutual Security Act authorizing the use of up to $100,000,000 in aid to anti-Communists from Eastern Europe has given rise to various reactions in the free world.

THIS businesslike report and appraisal of the mixed economy upon which we depend for our timber supply is prepared from material gathered by the Institute of Public Administration and written by its president.
CINCINNATI, Sunday, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A fire burned through the top three floors of the Sinton Hotel's annex early today, killing at least two persons.

ROME, Jan. 12 -- Pope Plus XII blessed today two diamond-studded gold crowns, which are to adorn the painting of Mary Queen of Peace in the Regina Pacis Votive Shrine in Brooklyn. At the same time, he gave a special apostolic blessing to the shrine and to the people of Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Governor Dewey fought today the efforts of the forces of Senator Robert A. Taft to lure to the Ohioan's side a large number of New York's delegates to the Republican national convention. New York will have at least 96, and possibly as many as 100, delegates at the convention in Chicago -- the largest number from any state.

BUYERS arrived in the wholesale markets here in record numbers last week, but actual order-writing did not measure up to the attendance. Sentiment was on the cautious side, with most stores aiming to lower inventories 10 per cent below the 1951 level.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 12 (UP) -- Undefeated Duquesne University extended its winning streak to ten by trimming Syracuse, 78 -- 67, tonight in the first basketall game played at the new Archbold Gymnasium before a crowd of 2,300.

OTTAWA, Jan. 12 -- Prime Minister Churchill began today a week-end of private talks with Canadian leaders in a new effort to bring the power of British Commonwealth unity into full force against threats of Communist aggression.

Al Parsells last night aided considerably in providing one of the most thrilling indoor polo games seen at Squadron A Armory this season. The eight-goal star hit seven goals as his Ramapo Polo Club rode into the semi-finals of the Metropolitan League tournament by beating Manhattan, 13 -- 9, at the Madison Avenue Armory.
DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 12 -- Danbury bid farewell this afternoon to First Lieut. Lee R. Hartell, Medal of Honor winner. He was buried in St. Peter's Cemetery after a military funeral.
WE HAVE really had a spate of "Cleopatra" plays in the last few years. Probably we shall have more in the future. Hence I should like to put in a protest as to the strange costuming of such dramas.

TEMPE, Ariz., Jan. 12 -- Arizona State College at Tempe president, Grady Gammage, disclosed today that a former Big Ten football player -- Joe Matesic of the University of Indiana -- performed for the Sun Devils under his brother's name during the 1951 season.

THERE is always something new to be said about the glorious days of the New England whalers. Son of a whaling captain, Chester Howland has examined logbooks and musty records and listened to the yarns of old-timers who chased the critters over the whaling grounds.

The University of Delaware is sponsoring the first annual Parents' Conference to provide faculty members and the parents of freshmen the opportunity to know one another and discuss the programs of the freshmen students. The conference will be held Jan. 19.

The University of Delaware is sponsoring the first annual Parents' Conference to provide faculty members and the parents of freshmen the opportunity to know one another and discuss the programs of the freshmen students. The conference will be held Jan. 19.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 12 -- Yale rolled to a 71-52 victory over the Army quintet tonight after holding a 4-point margin at the half.

THERE is a stirring in conducting assignments. Part of it has been caused by Charles Munch's illness lasting longer than was expected. It was hoped he would be back on the Boston Symphony's podium this month, but it has been learned that Ernest Ansermet, who is pinch-hitting for him, has been engaged to conduct the orchestra until late in February.

While the American freighter Flying Enterprise, 6,711 tons, Henrik Kurt Carlsen captain, Kenneth Dancy mate and crew, was trying last week to get into the port of Falmouth, England, the tides of destiny were making stormy weather in other places than the North Atlantic.

With two serious party fishing boat accidents fresh in our minds, I think it is appropriate to call public attention to the factors that contributed materially to last season's tragic toll. Upon investigation of those accidents required to be reported to the Coast Guard, we found that 98 per cent of those who lost their lives in small-craft accidents last season died by drowning.
TEXAS CITY, Tex., Jan. 12 -- A dispute between the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Bolivian Government over the price of tin ore may force a shutdown of the Longhorn tin smelter here.

MANY books have streamed past the critics since Christina Stead first startled them with that teeming, tumultuous novel, "House of All Nations." There was a vitality and huge inventiveness about that story which put Miss Stead within a step or two of the first rank.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Cornell defeated Columbia, 68 -- 65, in a double overtime period, on Barton Hall court tonight to begin its Eastern Intercollegiate League campaign successfully.

JACKSONVILLE -- At one time during the height of the 1950-51 winter season there were an estimated 100,000 automobile house trailers in Florida, each with two or more occupants. The rapid growth of this phase of the Florida tourist flow has taken on almost fabulous proportions.

IF you can get by a choppy opening and resign yourself to an unconvincing ending, you'll find Mr. Huston's seventh novel both amusing and intelligent. A lesser Marquand, he has the satirist's eye for folkway follies, and his manipulation of the strategy and tactics of uppercrust Philadelphia conversation is a delight to mind and ear.
QUONSET POINT, R. I., Jan. 12 -- One of the Navy's most colorful squadrons, Utility Squadron 2, has just been commissioned at the Naval Air Station here.

A forty-five-foot steel flagpole set in a concrete base with a bronze plaque was dedicated at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday to the memory of Ensign Curtis L. Smith, the first reservist from the United States Naval Air Station to die in the Korean fighting.

CORTES was born into a world alert to the romance and excitement of far places, of strange people, new products, great riches. He was a true son of his time and through this vivid narrative of his exploits, young readers will learn of the courage, the cruelty and the daring of the age of exploration. Like many other youths, Cortes, at 19, left Spain to sail for the New World.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 -- Houses at Fairless Hills, the new community of 1,100 prefabricated single homes in the rapidly expanding Bucks County area near Morrisville, were placed on sale Friday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 -- The California Republican Assembly, closing a two-day convention here today, was overwhelmingly on record in support of Gov. Earl Warren's candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Roy Campanella, the Dodgers' catcher, who was named the most valuable National League player in 1951, has signed for 1952 at an estimated $25,000. Official word was received from the Brooks yesterday that, in addition to Campanella, Infielder Rocky Bridges, Outfielder Dick Williams and Pitcher Billy Loes also were under contract.

The beginning of a new school term is a good time to plan your 1952 spring wardrobe. There are exciting ideas galore. The fabrics are fascinating and the colors bright and gay. Patterns of The Times has planned the nucleus of an early wardrobe for the school and college girl.

The National Grange, which seventy-five years ago was largely instrumental in bringing the railroads under Government regulation, has now thrown its weight behind the demands of the carriers for a reform of the nation's transportation policy.

PARIS, Jan. 10 (by airmail) -- Anything but flowers is the word here in prints, so long as the design is delicate or blurred or splotched. Designers seem reluctant to venture too far away from a plain pattern. On silk shantung, crepe, twill or chiffon-taffeta, patterns are in one or two tones, often black and white.

The N. A. C. C., which presents regular programs of American music free of charge, gave its third of the season last night in Town Hall. The selections were of recent vintage -- some, indeed, were first performances -- but the organization prefers not to distract its listeners with such extraneous information.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein urged today that narcotic addicts be quarantined and receive compulsory treatment, just as is done with typhoid carriers. He proposed also that the penal laws be revised to provide life sentences for those convicted three times of felonies involving narcotics.
A 13-year-old boy was crushed to death at 6:15 P. M. yesterday while attending a motion picture performance at the Academy of Music, 126 East Fourteenth Street at Irving Place.

A plan designed to tighten the voluntary restrictions on false and misleading advertising and selling of television receivers and other home appliances was disclosed yesterday by the Better Business Bureau of New York City, Inc.

THE idea sounded slightly daffy when first proposed, but the longer a fellow thinks about it the more favorably disposed he becomes toward the suggestion. The idea in question is the proposal by Commissioner Bert Bell that the National Football League abolish the point after touchdown and automatically advance the worth of the touchdown to seven points.

COVENTRY, England, Jan. 13 -- In the brief space of a two-day visit to this badly blitzed but bustling Warwickshire city, it is possible to see in compact form almost all the problems that British industry and the overstrained national economy are struggling to overcome. These may be summed up under the heading of shortages.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Financial experts here believe that when the independent countries of the British Commonwealth, whose Finance Ministers will meet here on Tuesday, come to weigh the advantages of membership in the sterling area against the restraints and restrictions that membership imposes they will accept the restrictions.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 13 -- A two-man mission of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to investigate the possibility of the bank's getting the Iranian oil industry going again left for the United States today after having visited Abadan and the oil region.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- France cannot halt a major attack on Indo-China by Communist China without substantial air and naval help from the United States and Britain, Gen. AlphonsePierre Juin, Inspector General of the French Army, said today.

Among the features opening this week in the art centers of New York are the tenth annual exhibition Thursday at the National Academy of work by the Audubon Artists; a new show of mobiles by Alexander Calder, tomorrow at the Curt Valentin Gallery; and, also tomorrow, paintings, 1939-1945, by Picasso, at the Louis Carre Gallery.

Regardless of who is right and who is wrong, it seems to us that the time has come for the Board of Estimate to hear in public the Port of New York Authority's arguments for sinking shaft in West Thirty-eighth Street to start work on the admittedly needed third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel to New Jersey.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Roequencourt, France, Jan. 13 -- More than 200 United States and Allied air officers will meet tomorrow at the headquarters of the Allied Air Forces in Central Europe, in Fontainebleau, for a three-day conference aimed at unifying the air logistics of the six nations involved.

The Three-Power proposal for universal disarmament presented to the United Nations last November by Secretary of State Dean Acheson was described yesterday by James P. Warburg, author and economist, as neither "positive" nor "practicable."

About $130,000 still remains to be raised for the 1952 promotional fund of the Father's Day Council, it was reported yesterday by Alvin Austin, executive director. He said two months of campaigning in thirty industries had produced $44,000.

OTTAWA, Jan. 13 -- British officials reported today that an agreement had been completed to make badly needed aluminum and tin available to the United States in exchange for American steel to be turned over to London.

Today the Interstate Commerce Commission begins hearings on an application for a general increase in freight rates. Because these rates have fallen far out of line with prices charged by many unregulated industries some rail officials regard the coming hearings as among the most important of the kind ever held.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Edmond O'Brien will star in and direct "The Murder" for Sam Baerwitz and Joseph Justman. No release has been set yet for the independent production, which will represent the actor's initial effort as a director.

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- A possibility that France will submit proposals for revision of the European army plan was discussed today by Minister of Justice Edgar Faure with leaders he consulted on formation of a new French Cabinet.
Weakness in the British pound while the Canadian dollar edged forward to a new high, represented the contrasting incidents of the week in the foreign exchanges.

Plans for opening a model home within about a month in one of the nation's largest defense housing centers have been announced by George M. Gross, president of Gross-Morton, builders, who have started construction work on a community of 5,000 rental dwellings in Aiken, S. C., in the Savannah River project defense area.

PARAMUS, N. J., Jan. 13 -- A collection of damaged sacred objects, looted from Jewish temples in World War II by the Nazis, was buried today in Beth-El Cemetery in ceremonies that go back to Biblical times.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- The trucking industry and Congress squared off today for another round in the fight over highways and the damage done to them by heavy trucks.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 13 -- Europe is surprised, the French especially are surprised, and a little shaken, that the Bonn Parliament ratified the Schuman plan by the clear-cut majority of eighty-nine votes. This is really a tremendous decision for the West Germans to make. Against the Socialists' impassioned appeals to nationalistic sentiment, all the other parties, with a few individual exceptions, soberly voted to surrender control of their richest national possession to an international authority.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Five of the nation's ranking tennis players today criticized Davis Cup Capt. Frank Shields for what they said was "obvious prejudice shown in determining the policies and personnel of this country's Davis Cup team."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today that $92,531,000,000, or 54 per cent of total deposits in insured banks, were fully protected as of Sept. 19, 1951, a year after individual coverage was raised from $5,000 to $10,000.
" How to Keep Our Liberty," an analysis by Raymond Moley, will be issued in February by Knopf. Mr. Moley discusses dangers inherent in a trend toward socialism and policies and methods to combat it.

Rule infractions proved costly to the New York Rovers yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. With a crowd of 4,612 none-too-pleased fans looking on, Lloyd Ailsby's Red Shirts dropped a 5-2 decision to the strong Johnstown (Pa.) Jets in an Eastern Hockey League battle.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 13 -- The administration forces at the University of Minnesota are standing their ground against charges that the dismissal of a Negro instructor in philosophy violated the principles of academic freedom.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 14 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,128, for Sunday's operations:
ZURICH, Jan. 13 -- Interhandel common shares in Zurich last week touched a new all-time high at 1,360 Swiss francs closing on Friday at 1,357 against 1,275 a week earlier.

LEONIA, N. J., Jan. 13 -- Square dancing in the high school gymnasium, a basketball game, a chestnut roast and soft drinks were shared this week-end by the youngsters of this village with eighteen children from twelve foreign lands.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A committee of thirteen was named today to help the American Red Cross publicize the $85,000,000 fund drive in March.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Britain's steel production fell sharply in 1951, just when the country's need for steel in the export and armaments industries was becoming most acute.

ROME, Jan. 13 -- Hopes of a solution of the Trieste problem by direct negotiation between Rome and Belgrade were revived today with the arrival of the new Yugoslav minister, Vladimir Velebit. He replaces Mladen Ivekovic who was recalled last October.

With the threat of contempt citations in case of non-cooperation, the rackets grand jury investigating reports of kick-backs, payroll padding, gambling and usury on the Brooklyn waterfront will resume today its questioning of more witnesses among the twenty-six longshoremen rounded up Friday and Saturday.

BERTRAND RUSSELL, philosopher, mathematician, skeptic, social rebel and Nobel Prize winner for literature, believes that the only hope for perplexed mankind is for the world to adopt a large proportion of his philosophy. If this consummation, which he devoutly wishes, should ever come to pass then men and women would be free from their destructive emotions of guilt and fear and ready to lead happy and creative lives.

Early last month when Miss Ann Roberts, proprietor of the shop that bears her name, found that the imported accessories and toys ordered for holiday sale were not arriving on schedule, she was forced to a quick change of plans. Her decision -- happily for gourmets -- was to add a delicacy department to her friendly, stepdown establishment at 107 East Sixtieth Street.

After missing last season, the thirty-two veterans of World War II who make up de Paur's Infantry Chorus returned to Carnegie Hall last night to give a program of skillfully rendered selections that began with contemporary works and ended with the Bach-Gounod "Ave Maria" as arranged by their founder-leader, Leonard de Paur.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Joseph A. Bierne, president of the Communications Workers of America, C.I.O., today demanded a "reasonable" wage increase for 314,300 Bell System telephone workers and expressed the hope that a new contract could be negotiated without a strike.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 13 -- A sense of pride in having demonstrated themselves "good Europeans" is evident in the reaction of Western Germans to the ratification of the Schuman plan by the Bundestag.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 13 (UP) -- Jimmy Demaret, the clothes-horse of golfdom, won the $1,500 first prize in the individual pro division of the $10,000 Bing Crosby pro-amateur golf tournament today, but he had to share the spotlight with other stars of the game.

BOSTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Jack McIntyre tallied with 37 seconds to play tonight to give the Boston Bruins a 5-4 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in a bruising National Hockey League game in which the lead changed hands four times and six major penalties were called.
Walter Mercer has joined the Associated Merchandising Corporation as merchandise representative of men's sportswear, including all sportswear outerwear tailored sport coats and rainwear
Eigth new films, including importations from England, Austria and Poland, are slated to arrive in first run theatres this week. The programs follow:
The following books published recently, may be of interest to the home carpenter:
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Hard-fighting Chinese Reds today hurled back attacking South Korean infantrymen in a four-hour battle on Korea's Western front.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The White House announced tonight that Gen. Mark W. Clark had asked to be withdrawn from consideration as United States Ambassador to the Vatican, and, accordingly, President Truman was not resubmitting the general's name to the Senate.
GENEVA, Jan. 13 -- Curious changes have taken place in the line-up of Western European countries according to the strength or weakness of their current international economic positions.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- If Wall Street was not at all stirred by President Truman's message to Congress, London's stock exchange was not exactly thrilled by the outcome of the Washington talks.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Two Air Force privates fell to their deaths from a rope made of bed sheets and blankets early today in a hotel fire that routed 350 guests.

Seventh and Eighth Avenues will be converted to one-way operation the first week in February, directly altering the familiar traffic pattern of Times Square. Seventh Avenue Will be restricted to southbound vehicles and Eighth Avenue to northbound.
Continuation of the fight to repeal the city's 3 per cent sales tax was pledged yesterday by the Associated Men's Wear Retailers of New York, Inc.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- Revision of the athletic organization, modification of the tutoring system, elimination of the preparatory school for athletes on the grounds and strict supervision of the United States Military Academy's participation in intercollegiate football to prevent overemphasis are some of the changes made or planned here as a result of last year's "football cribbing scandal."

Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday his own independent program for balancing the city's 1952-53 budget by means of new revenues and the exercise of "Spartan economy" in municipal government.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Volume on the Board of Trade declined slightly last week, but corn and oats showed larger pit purchases. Average purchases of futures daily were 39,000,000 bushels compared to 43,000,000 the week previous and about 40,000,000 a year ago..

" Understanding the News about Foreign Affairs" will be discussed by eleven news specialists of THE NEW YORK TIMES in the eighth annual Teachers' In-Service Course at the Times Building, beginning Feb. 13.
The eleventh week of opera at the Metropolitan, beginning Monday, Jan. 21, will see several singers in roles they have not previously essayed at the house.

The building of the "City of God" is a task that must be undertaken by Christians throughout the world, Canon Thomas A. Sparks, pastor of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, asserted yesterday in his sermon there.

HONG KONG, Jan. 13 -- An over-all reorganization of the entire state-controlled economy is now being carried out in Red China as means of placing production and distribution on a more rigidly planned basis.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Burke Boyce's letter of Jan. 3, attempting to equate the recent Supreme Court decision on the suspected California narcotics dealer with Gen. George Clinton's handling of Lieut. Daniel Taylor, a British spy, flies both in the face of historic fact and intelligent interpretation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- members of both parties aired their views on what to expect in Sunday radio and television interviews.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 13 -- Today's problems are moral ones, three speakers agreed here today during the second-day session of the Assembly of the Americas for Moral Re-Armament.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 14 -- The Communists' Peiping radio charged this morning that United States warplanes, including fighters, flew yesterday deep inside Manchuria, over the suburbs of Mukden, and towns and villages of Liaotung Province.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, said today that the Government's Controller Materials Plan was a "major benefit" to small business men. He pledged continuance of Government efforts "to be of every assistance" to them.
HEADQUARTERS, Fifth Air Force, in Korea, Jan. 13 -- A literal case of "flying blind" was reported today by Fifth Air Force headquarters.

In the course of the truce negotiations in Korea the United Nations representatives have asked an accounting for some fifty-five non-Korean civilians believed to be imprisoned in North Korea. Thirty-eight of this number are missionaries. Thirteen are United States citizens, and they include nine missionaries, two foreign service officials and two engineers.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 13 -- The Israeli Police today arrested a man accused of having robbed a Tel Aviv bank of 40,000 ($112,000) and handed out a large part of it to new immigrants.

The monthly report of the Shipbuilders Council of America, which covers the construction in this country of all merchant vessels of 1,000 tons and more, is the "heaviest" since the system was begun about four years ago.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- Most all was propitious for real sailing dinghy racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. There was non-splash water and non-freeze overhead and underneath. The absent element was wind.

Unusual as well as conventional treatments of motifs are displayed in the first contemporary collection of decorating fabrics made by Stroheim Romann. Available through decorators at the showroom at 35 East Fifty-third Street, the group, called New Fashioned Prints, marks a departure from the traditional type of fabric pattern for which the concern has been noted.

AMHERST, Mass., Jan. 13 -- Representatives from fourteen chapters of the Delta Upsilon fraternity voted this week-end to request the national organization to change the constitutional membership provision whereby an alumnus may "blackball" a prospective member pledged by his chapter.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is unfortunate that your Vienna correspondent saw fit to use figures in so misleading a fashion in the article on Poland's Six-Year Plan published as part of your International Business and Financial Review Section on Jan. 3.

A year-long series of weekly air-raid drills to prepare volunteer workers for a possible enemy attack will begin next week, the City Civil Defense Office announced yesterday. The first tests will be held at night and will not involve the public.

Two massive reports on Board of Transportation operations are made public today through the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey. One of them, about the size of the Manhattan telephone directory, is the joint work of Day Zimmermann and Coverdale Colpitts, engineering firms. It covers organization, methods and procedures of the Board.

Officials of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., were seeking yesterday to insure backing for their recommendation that would permit 120 lay-offs among Bronx employes of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 13 -- The steel industry last week was hanging on to a 102 per cent operating rate literally by its teeth. This was unchanged from last week. The scrap shortage was no longer a drawing room subject -- it was here with a bang.

Zino Francescatti was at his top form in his Hunter College recital on Saturday evening -- his only New York concert appearance of the season. That meant urbane, super-polished violin playing, technical brilliance and complete security.

The Rev. Edwin B. Broderick, director of radio and television for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday that the television industry deserved "a vote of confidence" for its "prudence" in presenting programs fit for family audiences.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- The First Methodist Church of Mount Vernon, home of the famed Bartholow Everyman's Bible Class and one of the two largest Methodist societies in the New York metropolitan area, began today a celebration of its hundredth year.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The Court of Appeals has unanimously denied increased pensions to two former chauffeurs and bodyguards of William O'Dwyer. They were appointed deputy police commissioners shortly before Mr. O'Dwyer resigned as New York Mayor to become Ambassador to Mexico.

What happened? A good many television viewers must have asked that question when they discovered they had missed the first-class brawl that followed Ernie Durando's technical knockout of Rocky Castellani on Friday night at Madison Square Garden.
Babies and young children often are assumed to be the same the world over, but three Scandinavian public health nurses "interning" here for a year have found that it isn't necessarily so.
New York State will end its $69,800,000 veterans emergency housing program this year, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman announced yesterday.

Once again the nation's public schools are in serious plight. Eighteen months of defense mobilization have taken their toll. Danger signals are flying everywhere, but often are not heeded. Many advances made in the first five years after World War II are being swept away.
PARIS, Jan. 13 -- Searchlights threw a giant V into the sky from the Invalides, where the body of Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny lay in state tonight in the chapel near Napoleon's tomb.

WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Stein Eriksen of Norway established himself as a prime Olympic favorite today by winning two races and placing second in the combined point scores in the international Lauberhorn ski tournament.

BERLIN, Jan. 13 -- East Germany's "cadre" army of about 54,000 officers and men, after a year's intensive training since its reorganization along strict Soviet lines, is now rated capable of preparing at least twenty-five divisions for combat duty in six months.
PARIS, Jan. 13 -- Five eminent economists told the United Nations today that prosperous years would be the rule rather than the exception in the future.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Steel Magazine predicted today the C. I. O. steel workers will receive a "substantial" wage increase and that prices of finished steel will increase $5 to $15 a ton as a result.

TOKYO, Jan. 13 -- Japan, in the first year as an independent nation after ratification of the San Francisco peace treaty, will be required to pay considerably more than half the expected expenses for her own defense, and the total military budget will amount to more than one-third of all national expenditures during the fiscal year of 1952.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 13 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh told British Ambassador Sir Francis Shepherd today that he would not withdraw yesterday's Iranian note demanding the closing of all British consulates in Iran by Jan. 21 and that nothing could be changed "unless Parliament brings about the fall of my Government by a vote of no confidence and another Government comes to power to carry out your object."
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 13 (UP) -- A Baptist Evangelist told his congregation tonight that his enemies again had threatened to bomb the heavily guarded church while he preached.

VIENNA, Jan. 13 -- A number of naturalized Americans, some employed by the United States Government here and others by American business concerns, have been warned by the United states Consulate to leave Austria under penalty of losing United States citizenship.

Through the good offices of the Legal Aid Society, 11 Park Place, New York 7, often aptly known as "the poor man's lawyer," legal advice and representation were given last year to 50,000 clients who were without means to hire attorneys. It is expected that this year will bring an even greater number of troubled souls to its doors.

Paris Discovers the Automat A worried gastronome entered these premises the other day with a piece of news from Paris which had hitherto escaped much attention here. It was contained in a French paper, and the troubled epicure indicated a headline. "Look what it says," he said -- "Les Parisiens ont decouvert les Automats."

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- Reaction in the United Nations to yesterday's surprise statement from the Soviet Union that Moscow was ready to shift its policy on timing and inspection methods for atomic control ranged today from a cold "nothing new" from the United States to a Middle Easterner's hopeful "a good step and a change."
The Mayor's Committee on Management Survey made public yesterday an engineering report recommending conversion of the Board of Transportation into a five-man agency by adding two members.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Bullish news developments found unresponsive markets on the Board of Trade last week, indicating that traders are averse to buying at a period of the year which is traditionally bearish.

Charles Schiff, who organized the Manhattan Chamber Orchestra two seasons ago, brought that ensemble to Town Hall Saturday evening. The program featured Shimon Mishory, concert master of the Jerusalem Radio Orchestra, as soloist, and the first performance of Alexander Steinert's "The Little Hill."

The New York State Society for Mental Health has been organized to carry out a broad program for mental health throughout the state. It succeeds the Committee on Mental Health of the State Charities Aid Association.

Many buyers entered the wholesale market here last week to cover on spring merchandise, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Most buyers placed small orders and concentrated on shopping the new lines.

MOSCOW; Jan. 13 -- New evidence of the vigor with which the Soviet Union is pushing its drive for expansion of foreign trade, particularly in Asia and the Far East, appeared today with the publication in Pravda of a suggestion of the desirability of a Soviet-Indian trade agreement.

Production of men's clothing during 1951 will show a sharp decline from 1950's figures when final results are tabulated, the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. has announced. Based on reports of the United States Bureau of the Census and estimated December production, it is believed that output of men's suits was 19,000,000 to 19,500,000, compared with about 23,700,000 in 1950.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- The resignation of Paul O. Bixler as head football coach and associate professor of physical education at Colgate University was announced today by President Everett Case on behalf of the university athletic council.

A tie was the best the Rangers could do against the Canadiens of Montreal in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Blues had the lead going into the final period, but a late goal by rookie Dick Gamble of the Habitants knotted the count at 2-all, and that it remained to the finish.

Deferred several times, the premiere of "Fancy Meeting You Again" will begin at 8 o'clock this evening at the Royale. As the George S. Kaufman-Leueen MacGrath comedy deals with reincarnation, specifically about a maiden who is determined to get her man despite 5,000 years of timidity on his part, the title fits perfectly. Naturally, the staging was left in the hands of Mr. Kaufman.
Expenditures by manufacturers for research and development have risen considerably, although not as much as expanding sales.
Cotton prices moved irregularly last week. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the period 1 to 41 points lower than the final quotations of the preceding week.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- Art Devlin today was an easy winner of the Harold Doerr Memorial ski jump witnessed by an estimated 25,000 persons at" Palisades Interstate Park.

CAIRO, Jan. 13 -- Ibrahim Farag, acting Foreign Minister, told Britain today that in view of the "grave tension" existing between Egypt and Britain, the Egyptian Government would be justified in ordering the expulsion of all British subjects but, "out of a spirit of clemency," had refrained from resorting to such action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- In what appeared to be an open break with the Truman Administration, Senator Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat of Maryland, announced today he would not be a candidate for re-election this fall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- It became known today that the field of possible Democratic nominees for President, if Mr. Truman is not a candidate to succeed himself, or of possible choices for second place on the ticket, if the President runs again, has been further reduced by the self-elimination of Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court, and that Mr. Truman was advised of this development last September.
Investment buying of apartments featured realty deals in the Bronx reported over the week-end.

Company reports indicate that the passenger service started just nineteen months ago by the Argentine State Line between New York and the east coast of South America has proved a big success, Martin J. Winsch, passenger traffic manager of Boyd, Weir Sewell, local agents for the line, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., called today for an eight-point program of Government action to combat unemployment in the automotive industry, now put at 200,000, as civilian production is cut back for expanding defense production.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Mrs. Ruth B. Shipley, head of the Passport Division of the State Department, explained tonight that under the Nationals Act of 1940 naturalized Americans must limit visits to their native lands to three years, and stays in other countries to five years.

Ch. Tai Chuo's Sun of Dah Wong, a biscuit-colored dog who will be three years old next Washington's Birthday, was the breed winner in the sixty-ninth specialty of the Pekingese Club of America at the Hotel Belvedere yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told a French radio audience tonight that next Sunday she would visit the "cradle of the Roosevelt family" to accept honorary citizenship in a small French town.
HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 13 (UP) -- A French orphan who never knew his right name, but did know a great devotion for the United States that had adopted him, is dead.
