WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- The American Federation of Engineers said today that want ads had caused excessive engineer job turnover that was slowing defense efforts. But it asserted that a Defense Manpower Administration order curtailing such advertising was "substituting a greater evil."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission is working overtime on the complex problem of expanding the atomic energy program without upsetting the over-all economy, Gordon Dean, its chairman, disclosed today.

Persecuted, executed and deported for almost fourteen years in many parts of the United States, members of the prolific Psittacine family have once again become "persona grata" in all New York State counties, except in the five local boroughs.

An increase of 2 per cent over 1951 can be expected for retail jewelry sales in the first six months of the year, it was asserted yesterday by Dr. A. O. Dahlberg, president of the United States Economic Corporation.

Subscriptions amounting to $101,647,300 for State of Israel bonds have been received since the flotation was started in this country May 1, it was reported yesterday by Henry Morgenthau Jr., chairman of the board of governors of the State of Israel Bond Issue. He said cash received as of last Dec. 31, was $54,000,000.

TRONDHEIM, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Hjalmar Andersen, Norway's speed skating ace, warmed up for the Olympics today with a twin triumph in a pre-Olympic meet here, setting a Norwegian record in the 10,000-meter race and winning the 1,500 meters handily.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 13 -- Although the external and internal monetary situation in Holland has showed material improvement for the last half of 1951, some deterioration in the external situation in coming months is unavoidable, according to a high authority here.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Mayor Impellitteri's proposal that New York City be authorized to impose a separate 1 1/2 per cent real-estate tax for county purposes is facing a drastic revision by Republican leaders of the Legislature. The tax would be applied in each of the city's five counties, which have no such separate tax now.

DETROIT, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Enio Sclisizzi, brought up only a week ago from Indianapolis, blasted home a third-period goal tonight to give the league-leading Detroit Red Wings a 2-to-1 victory over second-place Toronto before 15,668 fans, a record at Olympia.

A man recently discharged as assistant superintendent of a Bronx apartment house was arrested yesterday and charged with arson after an early morning fire in the building. The tenants of thirty apartments in the house were forced to the street by the blaze but no one was injured and the fire was confined to the cellar.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, reported today that a "vicious" and "reprehensible" gray market in steel was still active, although it had apparently reached its peak about six months ago.
GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Jeannette Burr of Seattle won the Swiss national women's ski championship today, with Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence of Rutland, Vt., second.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- A further delay in selecting New York delegates to the Republican and Democratic national conventions next July was proposed today by William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Jan. 13 (UP) -- Some 1,000 woolen workers in New England have voted to accept a permanent 50 per cent increase in work loads to meet Southern competition.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 13 -- Nationalist leaders in this French protectorate left here by air for Paris today to ask the support of the United Nations Security Council in their efforts to end French control of the country's internal affairs.

TORONTO, Jan. 13 -- When American Airlines flight 758 from near-by Mallon touches down at New York's La Guardia Airport tomorrow morning its passengers can blissfully ignore United States customs officials and get away with it.

One of the local manufacturers of highly inflammable sweaters conferred yesterday with Fire Marshall Martin Scott and assured him that he had halted all sales of the garments and that "no customers of mine will ever touch" them again.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Congress, after nearly a week of preliminaries, begins actual legislating tomorrow when the Senate takes up a "home rule" bill for the vote-less District of Columbia.

With the air of a man making tremendous concessions, Mr. Vishinsky has submitted to the General Assembly of the United Nations an eight-point "peace program" registering some further adjustments in the Soviet stand on atomic bomb control. But a close examination of this program in the light of all the circumstances reveals that, however flexible the Soviets may be in tactics, they remain inflexible in their objectives.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 (UP) -- An "intense" new storm blew down from the Gulf of Alaska today to dump new rain on flooded regions of California and more snow on Nevada, where Reno already was virtually isolated.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Vice President Li Tsung-jen, absentee claimant to Chiang Kaishek's title as President of the Republic of China, was disowned today by the ruling Kuomintang party.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report urged President Truman today to press for Government reorganization plans that the group said would save more than $5,000,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- W. Stuart Symington, retiring administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today he would support the Democrats this year.

Efforts greater than their record performance of last year will be required of the nation's scrap dealers in 1952 to meet production goals in steel and to prevent further civilian cutbacks in the use of this key metal, Government defense officials declared here yesterday at the scrap industry's twenty-fourth annual convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -Gen. Sir Gerald Templer, 53 years old, now in Ottawa for talks with Prime Minister Churchill, is expected to be named as Britain's new "strong man" in Malaya within the next forty-eight hours.

The second annual entertainment, known as Le Bal Blanc, was held last night in the Carnaval Room of the Sherry-Netherland to raise funds for the assistance of victims of communism. Proceeds will be used to purchase new equipment and materials for the vocational program furthered by the House of Free Russia, Inc., at 349 West Eighty-sixth Street, which was founded by the Russian-American Union to educate and shelter displaced refugees.

The training orchestra of the National Orchestral Association gave its second concert of the season last night at Carnegie Hall. Leon Barzin, who coaches and rehearses the young instrumentalists, was on the podium. The guest artist was Toba Brill, young American pianist selected as being worthy of a solo opportunity.
Large amounts of folding money began changing hands yesterday as the National Motor Boat Show at Grand Central Palace had one of its biggest crowds on record.

Stockholders of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company were told at the annual meeting here yesterday that sales will be between $26,000,000 and $28,000,000 for the fiscal year ending with next September. This would compare with net sales of $21,379,339 transacted in the year ended Sept. 30, 1951.

Cornell's swimmers handed Columbia its third loss in five meets, 48 to 36, at the University Hall pool yesterday. The teams split ten events, but Cornell took six seconds in the eight individual races to even its season's record at 1 -- 1.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 14 - Dr. Charles F. Keeley, former Mayor of Claremont, N. H., today placed himself on record as "favorable" to the nomination of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio as President. The move does not require the consent of the candidate.

Dollar volume of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week was 21 per cent below the abnormal "scare-buying" volume of the like 1951 week, but showed a moderate gain over the more normal comparable week of 1950, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Market research, together with creative selling, must precede increased production, a fifteen-member mission, representing the French electrical appliance industry, was told yesterday by Alex M. Lewyt, president of the Lewyt Corporation, vacuum cleaner manufacturer.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 15 -- The Communists charged today at Panmunjom that a United Nations plane had bombed the hospital at a prisoner of war camp in North Korea, killing ten Allied soldiers and wounding sixty others.

DEAL, England, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A dour French freighter captain tried a "Carlsen" for five hazardous hours today -- on half a ship. Eventually a lifeboat rescued the crew of thirty-five, two passengers and Skipper Maurice Landreau from the cargo steamer Agen.

HONG KONG, Jan. 14 -- The Peiping Government's current "ideological remolding" campaign, designed to refashion "bourgeois" working habits as well as "bourgeois" thought, has caught up with private industrialists and merchants in China.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Four claims of foul marred the racing at Tropical Park this afternoon. The only claim allowed by the stewards came in the featured seventh event, in which Abe Levinson's High Bracket was placed second for drifting out in the stretch.

Despite a loss of 1,146 producers, production of fluid milk rose 3.75 per cent in the New York milkshed in December. Dr. C. J. Blanford, administrator of the New York Metropolitan Milk Marketing Area, has cut to $5.25 the basic price a hundredweight paid to farmers for December from the $5.30 paid the previous month.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan directed yesterday that a "full investigation of facts" be made by a New York County grand jury into the disorder in Madison Square Garden after last Friday night's main fight between. Ernie (The Rock) Durando and Rocky Castellani.

New Yorkers have contributed only 8,017 pints of blood so far toward their January quota of 30,000 pints, it was reported yesterday. The city chapter of the American Red Cross, announcing the total, appealed to "patriotic and responsible Americans" for more donations of blood for both armed forces and civilian needs.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 14 -- There is no place like a home, be it New England or the shores of the Zuider Zee, or anywhere else, a pair of elderly Socialist politicians decided here this afternoon on discovering that they had much in common.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Dr. Paul B. Magnuson, chairman of the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, promised at the group's first meeting today an objective year's study of the nation's health.

CAIRO, Jan. 14 -- An officer and a gunner of the Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders were killed near the Tel el Kebir ordnance depot today when their Bren gun-carrier was ambushed by Egyptian guerrillas south of the Sweet Water Canal.

OTTAWA, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill declared tonight that, even though no one could predict what would happen, the West has "the life strength and guiding light" needed to bring a tormented world to safety.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Edgar Faure of the Radical party, who has devoted the last three days to an intensive study of the French political problem, is expected to inform President Vincent Auriol tomorrow of his acceptance of the task of forming the next Cabinet.

At the end of last summer Mme. Maud O'Connor Alriq returned to New York after five or six years in her native France to open a restaurant that bears the same name as one she ran here from 1936 to 1943 -- Maud Chez Elle.

The Presbytery of New York elected the Rev. Harry W. Foot, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, as executive director of the 1952 General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church yesterday at a meeting in the Christ Presbyterian Church, 344 West Thirty-sixth Street.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- In a preliminary report filed with the Legislature, the State Liquor Authority asserted tonight that it had made substantial progress in dissipating what it described as a widely held but false belief that certain lawyers and "fixers" had special influence with it.

THERE are more arguments in favor of snowshoe rabbit hunting than a desire for rabbit stew and if you happen to hunt with a man who likes to brace up hounds of assorted types that are inclined to chase anything that runs, the experiences can be interesting as well as exciting.

The stock market generated new rising momentum yesterday but lost some headway in the last hour. Wavering tendencies appeared in the early afternoon, were checked, but redeveloped near the close so that previous gains ranging from 1 to 2 points resulted in a net increase for the composite rate of only 0.34 point. It was a highly selective session marked by the interest in stocks not generally among the most active.

A legislative investigation of the operations in this state of "the international Communist conspiracy" was demanded yesterday by the Joint Committee Against Communism in New York, headed by Rabbi Benjamin-Schultz, who is also executive director of the American Jewish League Against Communism.
FORT KNOX, Ky., Jan, 14 (UP) -- Gem J. Lawton Collins said today that United States medium tanks in Korea "have defeated the Soviet mediums in every tank engagement to date."

When growing protests were heard in Delaware that the three R's were being neglected, Dr. Ward I. Miller, Superintendent of School in Wilmington, came up with a bright idea to counteract the complaints. He gave fifth-grade pupiles in the city schools a test that had been given to fifth grades in 1881.
As sweater owners across the country gingerly tested their fleecy garments for inflammable qualities yesterday, hats, jackets, blankets, rugs and trousers were crowding into the panicky picture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- E. Merl Young, former examiner for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and three others were ordered today to stand trial April 21 on charges that they committed perjury during an investigation of "influence peddling" in the R. F. C.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- George Araujo of Providence, R. I., out-pointed the world featherweight champion, Sandy Saddler of New York, in a ten-round non-title bout before 13,859 Boston Garden fans tonight.

The president of the corporation that was the first to sign for sponsorship of the new edition of "The Goldbergs" television show stated yesterday his firm had nothing to do with dropping Philip Loeb from the cast.

SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Jan. 14 (AP) -- A convict went berserk in the library at San Quentin Penitentiary tonight and stabbed two guards to death. He wounded two others trying to subdue him. The prison, one of the nation's largest, is on the north side of San Francisco Bay.
PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The United Nations land reform resolution, unanimously adopted by the General Assembly Saturday, was viewed by United States circles today as a victory for the West.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- A spokesman for the National Petroleum Administration for Defense reported today that the oil supply situation in the United States may be tight for the next few months, with some spot shortages.

The sixth Dodger to affix his signature to a 1952 contract is Clem Labine, 25-year-old righthand pitcher, who became known as Brooklyn's "Forgotten Man" until Chuck Dressen returned him to good standing at the end of last season.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France, Jan. 14 -- The British Government is reported to favor the creation of an Aegean Command embracing Turkey, Greece and Eastern Mediterranean waters as a compromise solution of the long - delayed Mediterranean defense arrangement, according to information in non-British circles here.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, indicated tonight in an interview that Democratic leaders might reconsider their opposition to a Liberal party alliance in order to strengthen their chances of electing a United States Senator this year.

The election of Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr, dean of the faculty of the Union Theological Seminary, as chairman of the board of the International Rescue Committee, Inc., 62 West Forty-fifth Street, was announced yesterday.

Labor leaders in New Jersey voted yesterday to recommend an unannounced one-day "holiday" stoppage for 100,000 members of the American Federation of Labor in nine northern counties of the state in support of striking agents of the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 14 -- Representative Lansdale G. Sasscer of the Fifth Maryland District so far has the field to himself for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate seat now held by Herbert R. O'Connor, who announced yesterday that he would not be a candidate for a second term.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- The Senate unanimously ratified today Republican committee changes that returned Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, to the Appropriations Committee.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- Senator Cabot Lodge Jr. said tonight that "if all the pledges we have received in the last week materialize General Eisenhower could be nominated on the first ballot" at the Republican National Convention.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- A short animated cartoon entitled "Fresh Laid Plans," which has been described as a satire on government price and other control efforts, was endorsed here today by the Farm Film Foundation as suitable for showing to farm groups.

The new French luxury liner Flandre will enter the North Atlantic service this summer. The 20,300-ton ship, which is expected to be the fastest of her size in this run, will leave Le Havre on July 23 on her maiden voyage to New York.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 14 -- The question of determining Western Germany's ability to make a financial contribution to Western defense is proving the main stumbling block to the conclusion of contractual agreements on German sovereignty. The Federal Government not only insists that Western Allied representatives here are overestimating the Federal Republic's capacity to pay, but also is convinced that Allied representatives here are not the best qualified to pass judgment on the issue.

The Rev. Dr. John Heuss was inducted as the thirteenth rector of the Parish of Trinity Church yesterday. Outside the great bronze doors of the building at Broadway and Wall Street, in a ceremony that follows an early English custom, the new rector received the keys of the church and its five chapels.
Attorneys in personal injury cases were urged last night by Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division to settle as many such cases as possible before trial.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Office of Price Stabilization tonight shattred beer drinkers' hopes that prices for the canned or bottled brew would remain fixed at current levels.

Anthony Anastasia, a top hiring boss among Brooklyn longeshoremen, turned up at the Kings County District Attorney's office yesterday in response to a telephone call, and reported later he had spent two hours under "general questioning about the waterfront."
SYDNEY, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A war of nerves appeared to be brewing today between the two great tennis powers -- Australia and America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Seventeen Republican Senators demanded today a "full disclosure" of President Truman's recent conversations with Prime Minister Churchill of Great Britain to establish whether there had been any secret "agreement, concord or understanding."

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores for December, 1951, were 1.2 per cent higher than for the like month of 1950, according to a compilation of forty-three companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

In an unusual survey, the Commodity Research Bureau has charted the courses of stock and commodity markets in election years and has demonstrated that voters have a high capacity for hypnotizing themselves into a belief in victory. Only four times since 1900 have stocks failed to go on the upgrade in the months immediately preceding the election.

Five economists of the United Nations were requested some time ago by the Economic and Social Council of that body to suggest steps that might be taken to "soften the blow" of future economic recessions. Over the week-end this group presented its findings.

Three new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. At the Warner the attraction is "Room for One More," a Warner Brothers comedy-drama starring Cary Grant and Betsy Drake. Norman Taurog directed and Henry Blanke pro duced from a script by Melville Shavelson and Jack Rose and the book by Anna Perrot Rose.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- What the French call a new approach has been made in the negotiations here for a European army. It was hoped that the move would produce an agreement for submission to the Council of the North Atlantic Treaty powers at Lisbon in February.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Soviet Russian bees now are being ordered to follow the party line instead of the traditional beeline. They must fly straight to flowers of the Moscow Minister of Agriculture's choice.
New York prepared yesterday to welcome Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen tomorrow with a reception expected by the Mayor's Committee to be "the largest since Gen. Douglas MacArthur" arrived last April.

A book about President Truman and his work will be published March 18 by Farrar, Straus Young, entitled "Mr. President." William Hillman, the author, has based his book on the President's diaries, private papers, correspondence and a series of special interviews.

Unlicensed crewmen who were rescued from the Flying Enterprise criticized Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen and the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company yesterday in connection with the events leading up to the abandoning and eventual foundering of the American freighter.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Heavy receipts of corn with a semi-demoralized cash market for that grain unsettled other grains today and the general tone of the Board of Trade was heavy. The flood of high-moisture corn that is coming in at present is pressing on the market, with wide price discounts under the May position prevailing.

The Metropolitan Opera has obtained pledges of $900,000 toward the purchase price of $1,200,000 for a Columbus Circle site for a new opera house. It was learned yesterday that the prospects for raising the remaining $300,000 were good.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The United States has agreed to pay Britain $1.18 a pound for 20,000 tons of Malayan tin to be delivered here over the coming twelve months. The figure is 6 cents a pound higher than the $1.12 ceiling fixed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Government agency which has a monopoly of tin imports, but well below the $1.27 a pound which earlier reports had given as a likely figure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Mobilization officials and about forty labor union representatives from copper-consuming industries today discussed the copper shortage, how to meet it and its probable effects on production and employment this year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 -- Gov. Earl Warren returned from a Hawaiian vacation today to work out his strategy to win the Republican Presidential nomination and found himself the target of an anti-Warren Republican meeting almost on the eve of a pre-convention session of the Republican National Committee.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- After a general display of buoyancy most markets were barely steady when the London Stock Exchange closed today.
The 1952 Kaiser Virginian and Henry J. Vagabond line of cars, announced yesterday by the Kaiser-Fraser Corporation, will go on display today in dealer showrooms throughout the metropolitan area.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 15 -- United Nations and Communist delegates wrangled their way through another day of conferences at Panmunjom yesterday with no indications of a break in the deadlock over an exchange of prisoners and terms for an armistice in the Korean war.

" The Shrike," opening this evening at the Cort Theatre at 8 o'clock, brings back to Broadway Jose Ferrer in the triple capacity of producer, director and co-star with Judith Evelyn. It is the first play by Joseph Kramm, who, for the most part, has confined his activities in the theatre to acting.

The Glidden Company, paint and varnish manufacturer of Cleveland, set a high record for sales of $228,522,503 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, last, Dwight P. Jones, president, reported yesterday. This was 21.2 per cent above the $188,607,966 volume for the preceding year and 13 per cent above the previous peak, attained in 1948.
OSLO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Norway's Olympic officials sighed with relief today as snow fell on Eastern Norway, just one month before the sixth Winter Olympic Games are scheduled to open in Oslo.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The Tunisian Government asked the United Nations Security Council today to intervene in what it described as its dispute with France over Tunisian efforts to obtain full autonomy. United Nations officials, however, declined to treat the appeal as that of an independent government and referred it to the permanent French delegate, Jean Chauvel.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 14 -- Col. Allan Sutter of the Marine Corps, executive officer of the Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps unit at Dartmouth College, received the Navy Cross in ceremonies here today for his heroic leadership of the Second Marine Battalion in Korea.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Truman's approval was added today to the pressure that Administration forces had brought to bear on the House of Representatives to win approval of a 10 per cent cost-of-living pay increase for the 3,500,0'00 men and women in the armed forces and those on the retired lists. The measure is expected to add $832,000,000 a year to the military budget.

The New York Film Critics will present formally awards to winners of the group's seventeenth annual poll for outstanding achievements in motion pictures in 1951 at a reception to be held from 5 to 7 P. M. on Sunday in the Rose Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -The American Telephone Telegraph Co. and its associated Bell System companies soon will ask for rate changes on long distance calls that would give them $14,000,000 in additional revenue, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- W. Stuart Symington, retiring director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, who held his last news conference today before leaving the Government, failed to achieve the greatest objectives of his public service -- coordination of federal policies and methods on the basis of grave realities that have brought the free world much nearer to mortal peril than the people of the United States have been told by their officials.

From many corners of the world come signs of a Soviet trade offensive. India is now host to a major Soviet trade exhibit and has been promised shipments of needed machinery in return for Indian raw materials. The bait of cheap coal from Soviet-held Sakhalin is being dangled before Japan.
ANTIOCH, Calif., Jan. 14 (UP) -- Fifteen-year-old Theola Barton won the "battle of the pincurls" today.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 14 -- A detailed and explicit "charter of racial policies," designed to wipe out the practice of segregation and discrimination within the Methodist Church, was unanimously adopted here today by a group of denominational leaders representing more than 1,500,000 Methodist Church women throughout the country.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Troops of the South Korean First Division momentarily regained and then lost yesterday two advance western front positions, which the Chinese Communists seized Dec. 28.

A six-story apartment house to accommodate eighty-five families at 180 East Seventeenth Street in Brooklyn was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The owner is listed as Shoreham Apartments, Inc., 657 East Twenty-sixth Street, Brooklyn. Philip Birnbaum is the architect. The cost is estimated at $575,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The file of Democrats making its way to the White House in ah effort to learn whether President Truman intends to seek re-election began to lengthen today as party leaders, eager to organize for the national campaign, sought guidance.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Senate Majority Leader Arthur H. Wicks and Assemblyman Bernard Austin joined tonight in a bipartisan statement urging the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to reconsider the proposed eviction next Thursday of nineteen tenants who were active on a committee seeking to end discrimination in the selection of tenants at the company's Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village.

Professional wrestling made its return to Madison Square Garden after an absence of a year last night. A crowd of 9,000, including Mayor Impellitteri, paid $26,901.82 to see seven exhibitions and except for a bizarre finish in one of the supporting features it saw nothing it had not seen before. Proceeds were earmarked for Italian flood relief.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that the only major obstacle to conclusion of a Korean truce by the negotiators at Panmunjom was the question of the rehabilitation of the North Korean airfields that had been knocked out by United Nations bombardment.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- While the French political crisis drags on the financial situation shows deterioration. Particular attention has been drawn to the balance sheet issued last Friday by the Bank of France which shows the position of the bank as of Jan. 3.
TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- Proposals to put the question of legalizing bingo games for welfare benefits took principal attention today in the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The system of priorities in the granting of tax amortization certificates was revised by the Defense Production Administration today. The net result was to expand the list of priorities and to make it more detailed as to individual categories. The list now includes fourteen categories as compared with ten heretofore.

The Allied Powers Tripartite Commission on German Debts made known here yesterday plans for an international conference in London Feb. 28 to attack the problem of West Germany's pre-war and post-war obligations to the outside world.

President Truman has found a good man for an important job in his appointment of William Draper Jr. as roving ambassador to Europe under the Mutual Security Act. Mr. Draper, still on the pleasant side of 60, has been a soldier, a business man and a combination of the two.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- The Providence Trust Company has] transferred $300,000 from un-t divided profits to its surplus/ account, William R. K. Mitchell,] president, said in the bank's annual report to be presented to stockholders tomorrow.

Last September when the Second International Congress on Astronautics was meeting in London, H. H. Koelle of Stuttgart declared that Russia is competing with the Western World in a race to establish a space station three hundred miles above the earth's surface.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Jan. 14 (AP) -- H. O. (Fritz) Crisler, chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association football rules committee, today said, "This committee is going to take under scrutiny the unnecessary roughness which has cropped up in the game."

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Sir Robert Watson-Watt, president of the Royal Meteorological Association and the Institute of Navigation, will receive u50,000, tax free, from the Government for his pioneer work in developing radar before and during World War II.

NEWARK, Jan. 14 -- The last nine miles of New Jersey's 118-mile turnpike will be opened for traffic at 5 P. M. tomorrow after dedication ceremonies along the northernmost section earlier in the afternoon.

Buying was brisk yesterday at the spring showing of the Corset and Brassiere Exhibitors Guild in the McAlpin Hotel. The volume of orders represents a vast improvement over the limited amount of business placed last fall, manufacturers said, and is indicative of the fact that retailers' stocks are down to almost normal. The showing will continue through Thursday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- More than $2,500,000 in new or improved industrial supply and equipment products made by 285 manufacturers were displayed here today to 8,000 industrial executives at the opening session this afternoon of the third annual plant maintenance conference and exposition in Convention Hall.
The pilot of the Northeast Airlines plane that crashed into the East River yesterday was unable to give any explanation for the accident.

VIENNA, Jan. 14 -- Hungarian factory managers, Communist functionaries and workers were warned today by Deputy Premier Matyas Rakosi that Hungary's export trade had been "seriously endangered" and her whole Five-Year Plan hindered by the poor quality of their output.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 14 -- The system of ten regional centers staffed by American experts throughout Iran being set up in connection with the United States $23,000,000 Point Four aid to Iran is regarded with some concern by Americans on the spot.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Governor Dewey sent to the Senate for confirmation tonight the appointments of Donald H. Grant of Cooperstown and Alfred R. Loos of Blauvelt to fill two vacancies in the five-member State Parole Board.

The Appellate Division Second Department, reserved decision yesterday on an appeal by the General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches from a lower court ruling that halted the proposed merger of the Congregational Christian Churches with the Evangelical and Reformed Church.

ATLANTA, Jan. 14 -- A Talmadge Administration measure forbidding the use of names of candidates for President and Vice President on the general election ballot was introduced in the Georgia Senate today. The measure sets up a board headed by the Governor and gives it sweeping power over preparation of the ballot.

Bob Richards, Don Laz and Don Cooper, the nation's 15-foot pole vaulters, will compete in their specialty at the Millrose Games, listed for Jan. 26 at Madison Square Garden, Meet Director Fred Schmertz disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- A revision of the four-power proposals to Egypt for a settlement of her treaty dispute with Britain was reliably reported today to be under consideration. After their recent talks in Washington, Prime Minister Churchill and President Truman reaffirmed their belief that the four-power plan offered the best prospect of relieving the present tension between Britain and Egypt.

DETROIT, Jan. 14 -- The technical board of the Society of Automotive Engineers was praised today for its little-known but important work in maintaining the country's industrial supremacy. The society opened its annual spring meeting in the Sheraton-Cadillac Hotel with 3,000 of the nation's leading automotive engineers in attendance.

The principal Democratic party leaders in this city, whose legislative contingents were called upon last year to furnish most of the votes for the increase in the sales tax to 3 per cent, are divided on the issue this year, it was disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY., Jan. 14 -- Two Republican legislators proposed tonight that the Public Service Commission be required to hold public hearings before allowing any natural gas pipelines or facilities to be constructed in any community in the state.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Fifteen railroad presidents are scheduled to appear before a four-man division of the Interstate Commerce Commission in a hearing which began today on a petition of the railroads for an increase in freight rates.

The threat of a strike next week on the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation lines was dispelled last night when officials of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., anounced that its members working for the company had voted to accept a recommendation permitting a lay-off of 120 men.

The Leo Burnett Company, Inc., has announced a number of important changes in and additions to the staff of its Chicago headquarters. Davidyne Saxon, formerly with Grey Advertising Agency, Inc., in New York, will specialize in Burnett fashion accounts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Maj. Robert J. Barrett, retired superintendent of Washington police, told Senate crime investigators today that he had burned documents recording $6,000 worth of his expenditures.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 -- Business and industrial management has a great responsibility in the shaping of this country's future, speakers at the mid-winter general management conference of the American Management Association declared here today. The role of management was outlined by seven leaders from all parts of the country to 1,000 chiefs of business and industry, most of them from the West.

WASHINGTON, Jan 14 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal court decided today to consider only evidence that was before the Interstate Commerce Commission, in acting on a petition that it overrule an I. C. C. order for financial reorganization of the Boston and Maine Railroad.

The Sterling Investing Corporation has purchased the Bayview Park Homes, comprising thirty-six semi-detached units on Bayview Court, Travers Street and Hillside Avenue in Manhasset, L. I., from William Greenway and is offering them in individual lots to the tenants or other buyers. The property had been operated by the previous owners as a garden apartment development.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 (UP) -- There was good skiing at four up-state winter resorts today, according to the New York State Commerce Department.

The Board of Transportation issued an order yesterday to Queens County drivers of city-owned buses to fill their buses to capacity in the morning rush hours. The order also directed the drivers to permit passengers to board the buses immediately at the Flushing, Queens, bus terminal in the evening rush hours.

Lilly Dache, distinguished milliner and more recently dress designer, believes that a woman should be well groomed from top to toe. With this in mind, she has added to her many activities the styling of stockings and gloves.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will investigate another phase of United States Navy weather-forecasting activities in "Ninety Saddles From Kengtu." Edmund G. Love is the author of the story, dealing with the serial-comic adventures in the Gobi Desert of a group of Navy meteorologists during the second World War.

The Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation announced yesterday that it had started to market here a new type of coaxial cable that employs aluminum as the outer conductor and sheath. Whipple Jacobs, president, said the cable generally is cheaper than that previously available for microwave use and also was considerably more efficient.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Britons were all aflutter today over newspaper reports speculating on the possible early announcement of Princess Margaret's engagement to the Earl of Dalkeith, a childhood friend who was her constant escort during her recent visit to Scotland.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- A general reorganization of the structure of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization probably will follow the Lisbon conference of member countries that is now expected to open on Feb. 16 instead of Feb. 2 as planned originally.

This nation's public schools face a dangerous teacher shortage. Although a minimum of 105,000 new elementary teachers are needed annually, only 35,000 are being trained This means that within ten years a shortage of 700,000 teachers will confront our schools.

Mayor Impellitteri predicted yesterday that his fiscal program would fare better in Albany this year than did that of last year, and that a majority of the Democratic state legislators would support continuance of the city's 3 per cent sales tax.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower declined today to enter him in the Illinois preferential primary for President against Senator Robert A. Taft and Harold E. Stassen, on leave as president of the University of Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Twenty- five-year-old Charles A. Comiskey 2d resigned today as vice-president and secretary of the Chicago White Sox in an apparent bid for the club presidency held by his mother.

Lucy and Mary Casale have sold the four-story four-family building at 101 Gelston Avenue, Brooklyn, to Alfred and Marie Franzone. Colonial Realty Company was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $14,000. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The proportion of babies without birth certificates was reduced by almost three-quarters between 1940 and 1950, the Public Health Service reported today.

A ship to replace the ill-fated Flying Enterprise will be made available to the Isbrandtsen Company this week by the Federal Maritime Board. The replacement vessel, according to Vice Admiral E. L. Cochrane, chairman of the board, will be chartered to the line on a bareboat basis and delivered in New York.

In another incarnation it may be possible to take a more cordial view of "Fancy Meeting You Again," which opened at the Royale last evening. It is a comedy about reincarnation by George S. Kaufman and Leueen MacGrath, with Miss MacGrath in the leading part.

The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake of Philadelphia, stated clerk of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., and David W. Proffitt of Merryville, Tenn., president of the National Council of Presbyterian Men, will arrive at 9:25 A. M. tomorrow at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from Germany after a five-week tour of overseas areas of distress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Truman formally submitted to Congress today his reorganization plan for the Bureau of Internal Revenue under which the offices of sixty-four politically appointed Collectors of Internal Revenue would be abolished and replaced by not more than twenty-five career District Commissioners.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Leaders of Boston's striking longshoremen said tonight that the men would return to work tomorrow when a picket line they had respected for six weeks was withdrawn from the Isthmian Line freighter Steel Flyer.
